title: No Meatless Mondays at the U.S.D.A.
description: A trade organization exists to promote the interest of its members; at least some of its work involves lobbying the government for preferential treatment, though most trade organizations would label this fair. Its a clear mission and an unconflicted one; whether the interests of the trade organization coincide with those of the public at large is a matter of chance and not a governing concern. Thus in the course of the events of last week  events that will go down as an amusing footnote in the annals of food progress, and further evidence of government cowardice  the National Cattlemens Beef Association acted appropriately: it defended the interests of its members without worrying about the interests of the rest of us.

title: Why Not in Vegas?
description: Ill make this quick. I have one question and one observation about Mitt Romneys visit to Israel. The question is this: Since the whole trip was not about learning anything but about how to satisfy the political whims of the right-wing, super pro-Bibi Netanyahu, American Jewish casino magnate Sheldon Adelson, why didnt they just do the whole thing in Las Vegas? I mean, it was all about money anyway  how much Romney would abase himself by saying whatever the Israeli right wanted to hear and how big a jackpot of donations Adelson would shower on the Romney campaign in return. Really, Vegas would have been so much more appropriate than Jerusalem. They could have constructed a plastic Wailing Wall and saved so much on gas.

title: New York State Comptroller Says Special Education Provider Bilked City of Millions
description: The owner of a Long Island special-education company misused millions of dollars in public money, employing 11 family members, leasing Cadillacs, and paying a sons living expenses in California, then fabricating documents to cover his tracks, the state comptrollers office claimed in an audit.

title: Cybersecurity at Risk
description: Relentless assaults on Americas computer networks by China and other foreign governments, hackers and criminals have created an urgent need for safeguards to protect these vital systems. The question now is whether the Senate will provide them. Senator John McCain, a Republican of Arizona, and the Chamber of Commerce have already exacted compromises from sponsors of a reasonably strong bill, and are asking for more. Their demands should be resisted and the original bill approved by the Senate.

description: TOP STORIES

title: British Rowers Capture First Gold for Hosts
description: LONDON  After a wait that seemed like forever, Britain finally won its first gold medal at its home Olympics, with the rowers Heather Stanning and Helen Glover dominating the womens coxless pairs in a victory at Dorney Lake.

title: The Once and Future Dream of New York
description: Building the Second Avenue Subway.

title: Tunneling Below Second Avenue
description: Unlike ants, moles, gophers and skinks, humans arent instinctively tunneling creatures. When we go underground, we are partly admitting that weve made a mess on the surface and partly showing off.

title: Standard Chartered Profit Up 11% on Emerging-Markets Strength
description: LONDON  Bucking the industry trend of weak earnings, the British bank Standard Chartered reported on Wednesday that its net income rose 11.3 percent in the first half of the year on strength in Asia and other emerging markets.

title: Wednesday Reading: A YouTube Introduction to College
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: U.S. and Israel Intensify Talks on Iran Options
description: ASHKELON, Israel  A series of public statements and private communications from the Israeli leadership in recent weeks set off renewed concerns in the Obama administration that Israel might be preparing a unilateral military strike on Iran, perhaps as early as this fall.

title: Crunch Time for the Euro  Again
description: LONDON  Sorry to drag you away from the Olympic Games, but reports from the euro frontline indicate that this week could be crunch time for the single currency  again.

title: Again, Wrangling Over Surveillance in the Cybersecurity Bill
description: The so-called cybersecurity bill is being thrashed out on the United States Senate floor this week, a debate that is turning into a pitched battle over how easily the government can go through private data online.

title: Indian Conglomerate Buys New Yorks Plaza Hotel
description: The storied Plaza Hotel in New York is the latest buy for Sahara India Pariwar of Lucknow.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Special Olympic Anger Edition
description: NBC and Twitter have relented and rescinded the order to suspend the account of Guy Adams, the journalist for The Independent who criticized the networks Olympic coverage and broadcast the e-mail address of NBCs Olympic chief. (Did I miss much while I was away? he immediately tweeted.) Twitter also admitted that an executive there had alerted NBC, Twitters business partner in games coverage. Both companies experienced a backlash on  where else?  Twitter.

title: Indian Insecurity vs. British Confidence: The Games Edition
description: Against the backdrop of problems at the Summer Olympics in London and at the 2010 Commonwealth Games in Delhi, and the distinct ways Britain and India reacted to their national embarrassments, my latest column is an attempt to explain why Indians magnify all their flaws. But what also interests me is the difference between national pride and the collective confidence of a country, even though they may appear to be the same emotion.

title: Olympic Ideal Takes Beating in Badminton
description: LONDON  At the Olympics, there have been doping scandals, bribery scandals and officiating scandals, many of them fully emerging only years after the fact.

title: Live Coverage of Mens Gymnastics Individual Finals
description: The team competition was a disappointment for the United States mens gymnastics team, which was a favorite to win gold but finished off the medal stand. Two team members, John Orozco and Danell Leyva, will have a chance at redemption in Wednesdays individual finals. The Times will cover every twist, tumble and misstep live, starting at 11:30 a.m. Eastern time, at nytimes.com/olympics.

title: Image of the Day: August 1
Gore Vidal Leaves the Ring
description: Gore Vidal, who died at 86 on Tuesday, wore many hats: Novelist. Essayist. Screenwriter. Playwright. He was also a combatant, one of the last popular authors whose public persona was opinionated, political and aggressive.

title: Poles Apart
description: So on the third leg of his foreign tour, Mr. Bean Mitt Romney lavished praise on the Polish economy. It wasnt quite as big a blooper as his praise for Israels single-payer-plus-price controls health care system, but it wasnt good.

title: The Kingpin on the Corner
description: IMAGINE that Rick Ross had a heart. That beneath all the bluster, behind the imposing shades, underneath the girth and the tattoos  barriers all  there beat something urgent, a muscle carrying more weight than one man could reasonably bear.

title: Tee Party
description: So the Republican nominee for Senate in Texas is a man who believes that there is a global plot, led by George Soros, to eliminate golf courses. Also, that states can nullify Acts of Congress.

title: What Were Reading
description: Crumbs: The importance of perfectly, freshly cooked rice in Asian meals cannot be overestimated. Perfect yours with these tips.  Julia Moskin

title: Did Solar Storms Cause Indias Massive Blackout?
description: No, were not wearing tinfoil hats over here at India Ink  so-called solar storms, or magnetic eruptions on the suns surface, have been known to take down electricity grids before, most notably in Quebec in 1989.

title: Apples Quiet Deal for AuthenTec
description: Apple wants you to ask Siri questions. But Apple isnt too keen on anyone asking questions about AuthenTec.

title: 1979 Who Tickets Still Good in Providence
description: Thirty-four years would seem an awfully long time to wait to see a concert.

title: For Kayak App Users, Its Smoother Sailing
description: Kayak has upgraded its iPhone app, allowing users to book flights, hotel rooms and car rentals on their mobile phones without going to third-party Web sites. The new version, which also includes an auto-fill function that prevents users from having to enter their data repeatedly, comes a month after a similar upgrade by Orbitz.

title: For Connected Educator Month, Tips From 33 Educators We Admire
description: The U.S. Department of Education has declared August Connected Educator Month, and since wed be nothing without the teachers weve connected with over the years, were enthusiastically on board.

title: Wallace Shawn and Andre Gregory Teaming on Two Plays
description: Wallace Shawn and Andre Gregory, best known for their performances in the award-winning 1981 film My Dinner With Andre, are going to be working together again, this time on a pair of plays to be presented at the Public Theater next year in co-productions with the Theater for a New Audience.

title: A Page a Day
description: TEL AVIV  It is a commitment like few others. Seven-and-a-half years of daily study  every day, no time-off, no vacations, no breaks for holidays, in sickness and in health, at home and while traveling.

title: Republicans Would Interrupt Recess, On Their Own Terms
description: House Republican leaders  on the verge of a monthlong August recess  told the Senate they stand ready to pull the House back into session to reach agreement on legislation to avert the expiration of tax cuts and the imposition of across-the-board defense cuts set to begin in January.

title: Latinos on the Rise
description: Theres enormous and warranted attention in news reports this morning to Ted Cruzs apparent double-digit victory over the Texas lieutenant governor, David Dewhurst, in that states Republican primary for a U.S. Senate seat. It was a headlines-grabbing, come-from-behind trouncing, and the reports focus specifically, and rightly, on what it says about the continued potency of the Tea Party and the lure of a certain sort of purism in the Republican Party, whose establishment seems unable to beat back and control insurgents from the right.

title: Too Big to Profit, a Hedge Fund Plans to Get Smaller
description: 8:21 p.m. | Updated

title: In N.H.L. Negotiation, 76,000 Pages, at Thousands of Dollars Per Page
description: Commissioner Gary Bettman emerged from a negotiating session with the N.H.L. Players Association on Tuesday and announced that the league had supplied 76,000 pages of audited financial documents that the union had requested. And, Bettman said, Theres more coming  lots. Donald Fehr, the union head, said the documents represented only a small portion of the necessary information, with the vast and overwhelming majority yet to come.

title: On the Move, a Recyclarium for New York
description: As a state-of-the-art recycling plant rises in Brooklyn, a mobile educational space known as the Recyclarium will be making the rounds this fall to give young New Yorkers a taste of whats coming.

title: Howard Koch, Longtime Producer, Named Academy President
description: 1:37 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES  Howard W. Koch Jr., known widely as Hawk, was named president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences at a Tuesday night meeting of its board of governors. He succeeds Tom Sherak, who stepped down on reaching a term limit after three years as president of the Academy, which presents the Oscars and oversees programs that promote film education and awareness.

title: A Republican Voice With Tea Party Mantle and Intellectual Heft
description: HOUSTON  As a teenager, Ted Cruz was an intense and eloquent parser of free-market economics, dazzling Rotary Clubs here in Houston by reciting the Constitution. At Princeton, he was a champion debater and an intellectual leader of a band of conservative students. He was a star at Harvard Law School and clerked for the chief justice of the United States.

title: Gore Vidal, R.I.P.
description: Gore Vidal died on Tuesday at the age of 86. The extremely prolific writer was perhaps as famous for his novels and essays as for his feuds. As Charles McGrath notes in todays obituary, Mr. Vidal did not lightly suffer fools and engaged in celebrated on-screen wrangles with Mailer, Capote and William F. Buckley Jr.

title: July 31: Obama Forecast Improves on Data Showing Faster Income Growth
description: President Obamas chances of winning the Electoral College improved slightly on Tuesday, to 69.0 percent from 66.9 percent one day earlier, according to the FiveThirtyEight forecast model. The change was because of new government data showing faster growth in personal income, one of the seven economic data series that our forecast model uses.

title: Fleet Sales Stall, and Automakers Report Results That Are Mixed
description: DETROIT  Auto sales in the United States cooled off in July as the two biggest American carmakers, General Motors and the Ford Motor Company, reported declines that they attributed partly to lower sales to rental car fleets.

title: New Romney Ad Hits Obama on Layoffs After Auto Bailout
description: The Obama campaign often sums up the presidents accomplishments like this: Osama bin Laden is dead. General Motors is alive.

title: Credit Cards With the Best Extended Warranties
description: One of the benefits of shopping with a credit card is that many cards offer free, extended-warranty protection for purchases that come with an existing manufacturers warranty. But a new survey from the card comparison site CardHub.com finds that there are significant differences in the perk, depending on which network sponsors the card.

title: More DeMarco
description: OK, Ive slogged through the technical appendix (pdf) from the FHFA on the proposed debt relief, and while its eye-glazing reading, it makes DeMarcos stonewalling even more outrageous.

title: U.S. Poised to Spend More on Mobile Advertising Than Japan
description: The United States is poised to become the global leader in spending on mobile marketing this year according to new research, passing Japan, which had been the worlds largest market for mobile ads.

title: A Caviar Crackdown Has Worked, Researchers Say
description: The sturgeon caviar industry has changed drastically in the past 15 years or so. And now a study indicates that in New York, it has become more law-abiding and even ethical.

title: Uchimura Wins Gold, Leyva Bronze in Mens Gymnastics
description: Kohei Uchimura of Japan won the gold, Marcel Nguyen of Germany the silver, Dannell Leyva of the U.S. the bronze in the mens gymnastics individual all-around final at the 2012 Olympics in London on Wednesday.

title: Obama Heads to Ohio Battleground, Again
description: MANSFIELD, Ohio  As polls in this battleground state and nationally continue to show voters split over President Obamas stewardship of the economy, Mr. Obama on Wednesday is making his ninth visit this year to Ohio to contrast his vision for the nations future with that of his Republican rival, Mitt Romney.

title: Oakland, the Last Refuge of Radical America
description: The Anti-Capitalist Brigade started gathering early on May Day at Oaklands Snow Park. There was free coffee, oatmeal, doughnuts, fliers with the days agenda and plenty of pot. A street medic  I just finished a wilderness first-aid course, he told me when I asked about his training  tended to his first case of the day, a man in his 20s whose leg had been beaten to a purple hue with a metal rod in an overnight fight in the park. Nearby, an organizer reminded protesters to take down the toll-free number for the National Lawyers Guild: This is important. Do not put it in your cellphones, because if you get arrested, the cops will take those away. Write it on your bodies. In indelible ink. There are Sharpies on the table.

title: Breaking the Mold by Writing a Part for Herself
description: Rashida Jones has a good sense of how directors see her. I am generally cast as the dependable, affable, loving, friend-wife-girlfriend, she said. As Ann Perkins on the NBC series Parks and Recreation Ms. Jones is the voice of reason among her loopier co-stars Amy Poehler, Nick Offerman and Aziz Ansari. But in her new movie, Celeste and Jesse Forever, coming out on Friday, she has the chance to unravel that persona, in wanton fashion. She stars as Celeste, who is in the midst of a lingering divorce from Jesse (Andy Samberg).

title: When a Butterfly Flaps Its Wings
description: If you had to choose the most popular aspect of chaos theory in childrens literature, the answer would have to be, hands down, the butterfly effect. Beginning with Dr. Seuss, who  writing under an even more colorful pseudonym, Rosetta Stone  gave us Because a Little Bug Went Ka-Choo!, and up through the copious If You Give a Mouse a Cookie franchise, children have had plenty of this leads to that tales to marvel over.

title: Business Day Live | August 1, 2012
description: A setback for efforts to hold Wall Street accountable. | Online poker sites forfeit millions. | India's booming TV business.

title: Sir, Youll Have to Surrender That Fork
description: LONDON  The woman beside the X-ray scanner was so polite it almost felt as if it was my fault that she stopped me, which of course it was.

title: Business Day Live: Indias Booming TV Business
description: A setback for efforts to hold Wall Street accountable. | Online poker sites to forfeit millions. | Indias booming TV business.

title: Struggling to Let Go of My College-Student Daughter
description: When I sent my daughter, Emma, off for her freshman year of college a few years ago, I found myself overwhelmed by an incredible feeling of melancholy. I was sad down to my bones.

title: A Glimpse of the Alternative Fuel Future
description: While a variety of new fuel technologies are advancing, policy makers can be assured that the internal combustion engine will remain dominant for decades, the National Petroleum Council told the Department of Energy on Wednesday in a report.

title: Credit Suisse Names DeNunzio as Global Chairman of M.&A.
description: Credit Suisse on Wednesday named David DeNunzio, one of its veteran deal makers, as the global chairman of its mergers and acquisitions group, according to an internal memorandum reviewed by DealBook.

title: Sluggish Entertainment and Publishing Results Hurt Time Warner Earnings
description: A slow three months at the box office for Warner Brothers movies and continued sluggishness at Time Inc. magazines contributed to a 32.6 percent decline in net income at Time Warner.

title: After Dustup Over Churchill Bust, an Apology From the White House
description: Winston Churchill has been gone for a few decades, but he returned for a small cameo role this week in Washington as the overheated campaign season continues.

title: As Banking Titans Reflect on Their Errors, Few Pay Any Price
description: Like a defecting Syrian colonel or converted climate-change denier, Sanford I. Weill has been heartily welcomed among those on the right side of history.

title: Revisiting a German Photo Legend
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: U.S. Women Show Strength in Field Hockey Win Over Argentina
description: Pam Stuper, the head field hockey coach at Yale, played on three national championship teams at Old Dominion University, and on the United States national team from 1990 to 98, earning a bronze medal at the 1994 World Cup. She currently chairs the USA Field Hockey board of directors. She will be writing for the 2012 London Olympics blog throughout the Games.

title: When a Taste for Publicity Bites Back
description: PHOENIX  In nearly 20 years as sheriff of Maricopa County, Joe Arpaio has honed his publicity skills, using headline-grabbing, often outrageous maneuvers to build a reputation as the nations toughest law officer and make himself a hero to many Americans.

title: An Effort to Put First Edition of Shakespeare Online
description: A campaign is under way to digitize and make available online the first collected edition of Shakespeares plays, known as the First Folio.

title: Leaving Mushara as Questions Abound
description: Caitlin OConnell-Rodwell, who teaches at the Stanford University School of Medicine, writes from Etosha National Park in Namibia, where she is studying elephant societies.

title: After a Birth and a Broken Collarbone, a Gold
description: HAMPTON COURT, England  For a brief time, Kristin Armstrong thought her competitive cycling days were over. She had a gold medal from the Beijing Olympics and a beautiful little boy named Lucas, and since it felt right, she retired.

title: John Cornyn Makes Sense
description: I dont often find myself in agreement with Senator John Cornyn, the Texas Republican. But hes rightfully fed up with the secrecy surrounding the Obama administrations targeted killing program, and hes now pushing a measure to force greater disclosure.

title: A Novel Way to Prevent Hip Fractures
description: The Times reports today on a study finding that cataract surgery greatly reduces the risk of hip fracture in the elderly. The benefits accrued particularly to those who were most ill and those in their early 80s; they experienced almost 30 percent fewer hip fractures in the first year after cataract surgery, compared with similar patients who did not have surgery, the researchers found.

title: A First Glimpse of the 2014 Mazda 6 Comes in Moscow
description: Mazda has provided a peek at the revamped 2014 Mazda 6 sedan ahead of the cars introduction at the Moscow Auto Show this month.

title: Follow the Rules for a Beautiful Summer
description: WHEN Byl Thompson ran into a nail salon on East 125th Street a couple summers ago for a quick manicure, he got more than just a simple buff and file.

title: Video Said to Show Execution by Syrian Rebels Stirs Debate
description: As my colleague Damien Cave reported, Syrian rebels on Tuesday said they had captured and later executed several members of a prominent Aleppo family with close ties to the government of President Bashar al-Assad. That act  captured on video and circulated widely  appeared to constitute a war crime, human rights activists said on Wednesday.

title: Easing the Pain of Workouts on the Road
description: ITS called the LiveWell Walking Path: a new, nearly milelong route that includes two 55-foot-high staircases for cardio exercise. At one end, the path leads to the yoga studio where, beyond tall screens, barefoot travelers twist and bend while an instructional DVD plays quietly in a continuous loop.

title: When Banks Wont Lend, There Are Alternatives, Though Often Expensive
description: After years of a small-business credit crisis, conditions seem to have improved. But with the economy still struggling and new regulations meant to eliminate bad lending, bank loans continue to lag.

title: Should a Business Ever Pay 70% to Borrow Money?
description: In a small-business guide to alternative finance we have just published, Ian Mount runs down the list of creative alternatives to bank lending. Some have been around forever; others emerged during the crisis. Almost all are substantially more expensive than traditional bank loans, which is why they have been sources of last resort. But as demand for alternative options has increased, some prices have come down.

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: A Feel-Good Gift From an Uninvited Guest

title: Flood of Errant Trades Is a Black Eye for Wall Street
description: An automated stock trading program suddenly flooded the market with millions of trades Wednesday morning, spreading turmoil across Wall Street and drawing renewed attention to the fragility and instability of the nations stock markets.

title: MF Global Trustees Differ Over Amount Customers Will be Repaid
description: WASHINGTON  An MF Global trustee damped hopes that customers would recover all of their missing money from the bankrupt brokerage firm, telling lawmakers on Wednesday that a $1.6 billion gap remained.

title: Court Must Revisit Legal Fees in Audi-VW Sludge Case
description: A federal appeals court has rejected a $30 million payment to the lawyers who brought a class-action suit against Volkswagen and Audi over engines that were damaged by sludge problems.

title: The Great Disposal Service: Can It Last?
description: The earth is performing an enormous disposal service for the human race. About half of the carbon we are dumping into the atmosphere does not stay there and is instead taken up by the oceans and land. Were this not the case, scientists say, the earth would probably be warming far more rapidly.

title: Pictures of the Day From London | August 1, 2012
description: The sixth day of the London Olympics.

title: Flash Floods Strand Cars in Queens
description: Updated, 2:13 p.m. | Torrential rains flooded highways and stranded cars in Queens on Wednesday afternoon.

title: Wind Credit on the Block
description: A longstanding tax credit for wind power that has broad bipartisan support was caught Wednesday in presidential politics when Senate Republicans removed it from a usually routine package of business tax breaks to show their loyalty to their presumptive presidential nominee, Mitt Romney.

title: American White Phosphorus Shells in Libya: A Challenge to a Pentagon Chestnut
description: The history of how Libya became a bunker state reduces readily to short-hand. After overthrowing King Idris in 1969, Muammar el-Qaddafi, a young army officer, used his nations oil revenue to underwrite a decades long arms-purchasing spree, stockpiling weapons from the West but principally from Russia, China and the Eastern bloc. As his holdings grew, he used his arsenal to supply his expanding army and internal security units, as well as a source of items to export to guerrilla or terrorist groups in Chad, the Palestinian territories, Ireland and beyond. This was one of the many ways that Libya became a menace and regional scourge. Libyas growing arms stockpile was also a means by which the colonels hold on power remained secure, at least until the uprising that toppled him and cost thousands of lives, including his own.

title: Dropbox Spam Attack Tied to Stolen Employee Password
description: A spam attack on users of Dropbox, the cloud-storage service, has been linked to a password that was stolen in a breach on another Web site.

title: Political Gymnastics
description: Gail Collins: David, I feel compelled to discuss Mitt Romney in Europe, but before we get to that, lets try a happier topic. How are you feeling about the Olympics?

title: The Electoral Map: Pennsylvania Now Leaning Democratic
description: Pennsylvania, whose 20 electoral votes have long been among the most closely watched in the race for the White House, is now rated as Leaning Democratic, according to the latest New York Times ranking of presidential battlegrounds.

title: Obama, in Ohio, Attacks Romney Over Tax Cuts
description: MANSFIELD, Ohio  As polls in this battleground state and nationally continue to show voters split over President Obamas stewardship of the economy, Mr. Obama on Wednesday attempted to contrast his vision for the nations future with that of his Republican rival Mitt Romney.

title: The Complacent Romney Campaign
description: My Campaign Stops column this week runs through Mitt Romneys possible vice presidential picks, and concludes that everything weve seen from the Romney campaign suggests theyll make the most cautious, first-do-no-harm, dont-rock-the-boat choice possible which probably means picking the competent, experienced, and completely unexciting Ohio Senator Rob Portman. For further evidence that Team Romney is happy with the course theyre on, heres National Reviews Robert Costa on the plan to reintroduce the Republican candidate during the run-up to convention week:

title: Lichtenstein Painting, Missing for 42 Years, Surfaces in Warehouse
description: The Pop artist Roy Lichtensteins black and white Electric Cord painting, which disappeared 42 years ago, has turned up in a New York City warehouse, The Associated Press reported.

title: The Spy Game: Ben Macintyre Talks About Double Cross
description: Double Cross is Ben Macintyres third book about World War II espionage, following the acclaimed Agent Zigzag and Operation Mincemeat. When MI5, Britains domestic intelligence service, realized that it had turned all of Germanys spies into double agents, it started the Double Cross operation. The German spies fed an ornate series of lies to Berlin, helping the Allies win at Normandy by drawing the attention of the Nazis to other possible points of attack. In a recent interview via e-mail, Mr. Macintyre discussed whether he would have made a good spy, Churchills knowledge of Double Cross, the possibility that German intelligence officers may have been sympathetic to the plan and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: Ancestral Remedies to the Rescue
description: Ethnobotanists are fond of the joke that pills dont grow on trees. The punch line, of course, is that they actually do. Countless pharmaceutical products originate from trees or other plant species, many of which are probably still waiting to be discovered. This week around 1,300 natural products researchers and practitioners gathered in New York to discuss the latest findings in their field, including the ways in which nature, culture and conservation overlap to provide health benefits to millions and how those links can best be preserved.

title: Who Would Gain in a Romney Tax Overhaul
description: An updated version of this blog post can be found here.

title: Fed Sees Slowing Economy, but Defers New Action
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve took no new steps to support the economy Wednesday, but it said in a statement that it was ready to act if job growth did not improve.

title: U.S. Star Loses Chance To Win Her Third Gold
description: LONDON  Mariel Zagunis has always had Olympians around her. Long before Athens or Beijing or the opening ceremony here where she led the United States delegation into the Olympic Stadium waving the American flag above her head, Zagunis, a fencing prodigy from Oregon, could have heard a steady stream of Olympic history if she wanted it. All she had to do was bring it up at the dinner table.

title: New Velodrome Is a Chip Off the Old Cycling Track
description: LONDON  North of Olympic Park, an arena looms in the distance, its roof curved in an odd and yet unmistakable slope. The roof reaches its highest point at either end and sags in the middle, until it forms what architects call a truncated hyperbolic paraboloid.

title: TimesCast Tech | NASAs Rover Nears Mars
description: A mortar-fired parachute will float NASAs rover down to Mars. | People without televisions find alternatives to watching the Olympics.

title: The Cycle of Standoffs
description: Passing bills is pass in the 112th Congress, one of the least productive in history. Rather than work, the two parties prefer to spend their time in ideological combat, making points rather than policy.

title: A Vulnerable Center-Stage Moment
description: LINDSAY MENDEZ was putting her powerful pipes to good use, giving full throttle performances of Bless the Lord in the recent Broadway revival of Godspell when she was cast in the new musical Dogfight. Leave a Broadway show for Off Broadway and play a character everyone thinks is ugly? But of course! Ms. Mendez felt lucky to have the chance to originate a role, though, and her touching performance in Dogfight, based on the 1991 movie starring River Phoenix and Lili Taylor, about some Marines callous who-can-find-the-homeliest-date contest, has made plenty of theatergoers feel fortunate too.

title: Latest Addition to the Yogurt Capital': A Bar in SoHo
description: Let it be known: New York State is now the Greek yogurt capital of the world  at least as far as the Cuomo administration is concerned.

title: Lawmakers Want to Know: What Are Those Drones Doing Up There?
description: Mesa County Sheriffs Unmanned Operations Team, via Associated Press

title: Uchimura Rises Above the Rest, Again
description: LONDON  Kohei Uchimura, the Japanese gymnast, did not fool anyone by qualifying in ninth place last week for the Olympic mens all-around event in gymnastics. His competitors knew all along that he would be the one to beat in the final Wednesday, and they were right.

title: Zac Brown Band Regains Top Spot on Chart
description: In a slow week for music sales Zac Brown Band returned to No. 1 on Billboards album chart, and Carly Rae Jepsens Call Me Maybe has been certified as one of the biggest hits of the year.

title: TimesCast Tech: NASAs Rover Nears Mars
description: A mortar-fired parachute will float NASAs rover down to Mars, and people without televisions find alternatives to watching the Olympics.

title: Stockholms New Flavor
description: Stockholm has long been recognized as a hot spot for fashion and design, but theres another stylish draw as of late: its food. Here, two newcomers that are understated and alluring serve a delightful mix of unmistakably Swedish cuisine and daring, new Nordic dishes.

title: Looking for Health in the Tea Leaves
description: At Physical Graffitea, the tea cafe on St. Marks Place, include clients include casual tea drinkers and those looking to kick the coffee habit or spur weight loss.

title: Rowing for Gold
description: The U.S. womens eight Olympic rowing team won gold in Beijing in 2008. They trained for London with an eye to doing it again.

title: Reading the Tea Leaves for Health
description: WITH a month to go until New York Fashion Week, some editors and models, preparing for the onslaught of shows, are steeping themselves in tea.

title: Democrat Reprimanded for Misusing Staff in Race
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Laura Richardson, Democrat of California, has agreed to be reprimanded by the House and pay a $10,000 fine for compelling her Congressional staff members to work on her 2010 campaign.

title: Where the Heavy Lifting Often Occurs in the Mind
description: LONDON  It may be the cruelest moment of the Summer Olympics, the check-your-watch-and-you-missed-it span of time that weight lifters are required to hold the barbell above their heads. Athletes do not have a successful lift until they prove to the judges that they have control of the weight.

title: Business Day Live | Online Poker
description: August 1, 21012 - Online poker sites to forfeit millions.

title: Cromartie Has Confidence, Perhaps Too Much, as a Receiver
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  The proclamation issued by cornerback Antonio Cromartie that he was the second-best receiver on the Jets annoyed Rex Ryan, who is refusing to tolerate any comments that could produce the sort of dysfunction that derailed the teams 2011 season.

title: Embracing the Web, Boutiques Thrive
description: WHEN Ann Pontius was in the market for jeans recently, she turned to Totokaelo, her favorite boutique in Seattle, to help find her a pair  this despite the fact that she lives in Denver.

title: A Deeper Look at Undisclosed Conflicts of Interest in Frackademia
description: Opponents of expanded gas drilling have coined the term frackademia for university research on the potential impacts of the boom in shale gas drilling that involves industry money or experts with industry ties. The effort, of course, is aimed at conveying that industry money or relationships leads to bad science.

title: Tuning Out Olympic Edict
description: LONDON  One by one, the swimmers emerge poolside from behind a wall, making their way to the starting blocks at the Olympic aquatics center in a procession that combines the drama of sport, the staging of prime-time TV and the posturing of a fashion-show catwalk. This conspicuous scene, playing out many times a day at the London Games, has also become an international advertising bonanza for a product not usually associated with water sports: headphones.

title: American Adrian Wins 100-Meter Freestyle
description: LONDON  Nathan Adrian of the United States won the gold medal in the Olympic 100-meter freestyle on Wednesday night, completing the furious, water-thrashing, lung-busting test one-hundredth of a second faster than James Magnussen of Australia.

title: The Timess Agenda Project for Campaign: Some Readers Vote Yes, Some Scoff
description: Included below is some reader responses to my column Resetting the Campaign Agenda on July 29:

title: A Secret Life Reinvented Once Again
description: Heloise Lewis runs a boutique lobbying firm whose mission statement identifies it as a nonprofit focused on income parity for all women. It is called the Womens Full Employment Network. And when people hear that, they never want to know a single thing more about Heloises business, Laura Lippman writes, which is exactly as she planned it.

title: From Paris to London, British Cyclist Finishes a Record Ride
description: HAMPTON COURT, England  In the aftermath of his latest triumph, Bradley Wiggins sat confined in a chair, his place in cycling history, Olympic history and British sports history secured. His eyes darted about as he shifted in discomfort.

title: Twitter Unveils the Twindex, a New Political Index
description: Weve seen it dozens of times before. The famous scene of a political candidate in a large room, balloons floating and banners strewn about, surrounded by supporters and family, anxiously watching the television as the election results come in.

title: No Comment Necessary: Contraception and Pearl Harbor
description: Via Raw Story

title: Private Equity P.R. Campaign Focuses on Jobs
description: Private equity is on a mission to convince the public that they create jobs.

title: Kudos to Winners From the Well Known
description: You know youve done well when the president of the United States is sending you a tweet, and signing it off with bo. (in lower case), as did Barack Obama when he publicly congratulated Michael Phelps on Twitter on Tuesday.

title: As the Label Turns
description: Fashion is littered with designers who lost control of their names (though some managed to get them back). Here is a sampling.

title: Trash Talk From a Coach
description: As Miranda Pakozdi competed in a video game tournament, her team coach, Aris Bakhtanians, commented on her bra size, told her to take off her shirt, and trained the camera on parts of her body.

title: Wi-Fi Helps Appliances Think for Themselves
description: This is a column about Smart Homes. No, please  dont turn the page.

title: A Hard Spill in Designer Shoes
description: THEY were the girls with the golden shoes.

title: The Billionaire Versus the Little Guy
description: Donald Trump, the archvillain of Anthony Baxters documentary polemic, Youve Been Trumped, is a man many people love to hate. In this unabashedly hostile portrait of a billionaire developer in action as he embarks on a grandiose new project in Scotland, Mr. Trump comes across as an insensitive, lying bully who will do whatever it takes to realize his dream of creating what he promises will be the worlds greatest golf resort.

title: A Gamer and Cartoonist Strikes Back
description: In this clip, two commentators, Martin Phan and Christian Cain, are heard making light of harassment. They later apologized and were disinvited from speaking at future events.

title: On Touch Screens, Rest Your Finger by Using a Stylus
description: When Steve Jobs talked about the iPads rivals, he didnt mince words. If you see a stylus, they blew it, he said in 2010.

title: Virtual Violence
description: After Anita Sarkeesian, a prominent gamer, documented her harassment online, a man from Ontario created an Internet game where players could punch her, leaving virtual black eyes and cuts.

title: Celebrations of Fast-Breaking Unite Muslims and Non-Muslims
description: For many, the Olympics is a time of uniting for sport. Shaukat Warraich has helped unite London in a new form: over iftar.

title: Hoffman to Direct in Coming LAByrinth Theater Season
description: The return of the Academy Award winner Philip Seymour Hoffman to the directors chair is one of the highlights of the 2012-2013 season of the LAByrinth Theater Company, announced Wednesday. Mr. Hoffman, who won the Oscar for best actor for his performance in Capote, will direct A Family for All Occasions, a new comedy by Bob Glaudini, in the spring of 2013 for LAByrinth, with which he has been associated since the mid 1990s.

title: Want a Job? Move to Oman
description: Just a quarter of Americans think it is a good time to get a job. That compares to about a third of adults worldwide, according to Gallup surveys conducted in 146 countries last year.

title: Vertigo Tops Sight and Sound Poll of Greatest Films
description: Orson Welless Citizen Kane has been deposed as the top film of all time by Alfred Hitchcocks Vertigo in the latest Sight and Sound poll, according to the British Film Institute. Vertigo beat the previous champion by 34 votes; a decade ago, when the poll was last conducted, Kane won by just five votes.

title: Olympics Ratings Higher Than Expected
description: An average of 38.7 million viewers watched the London Games on Tuesday night, nearly 5 million more than watched on the comparable day four years ago in Beijing and almost 9 million more than tuned in on the first Tuesday night of the Athens Games in 2004.

title: Two Recent Additions Help Yankees End Skid
description: Casey McGehee waited until after he left the visiting clubhouse at Wrigley Field, gathered his belongings at his hotel in downtown Chicago and hopped onto his flight to La Guardia Airport before he finally gave in.

title: Video: Rowing for Gold
description: The United States womens eight Olympic rowing team won gold in Beijing in 2008.

title: Seeing Things | Standard Goods
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: As Beer Garden Welcomes the Juice-Box Set, Some Barflies Jeer
description: It seemed that every parent in Park Slope was talking about it. A new bar was opening on the edge of the neighborhood and its owner had put out the word to local families: strollers welcome.

title: Uchimura Wins Mens All-Around
description: Kohei Uchimura, the three-time world champion from Japan, won the mens all-around gymnastics event.

title: Going High-Tech and Homey at a New-Music Hall
description: During the last decade or so Manhattan has seemed far less hospitable to the intrepid new-music institutions that give New York its outlier chic and magnetic allure. The Stone, John Zorns frugal East Village laboratory, hangs on tenaciously, and Le Poisson Rouge hosts noteworthy events in its stylish Bleecker Street space. But vital institutions like Roulette and Issue Project Room have decamped to bigger homes and better deals in Brooklyn, gambling that loyal audiences would follow.

title: Channeling Judy Garland, Serenely
description: Its difficult to imagine two more disparate sensibilities than the singer Rebecca Kilgore and the subject of her new show, The Jazzy Side of Judy Garland, now playing at Feinsteins at Loews Regency. Ms. Kilgore, who is based in Portland, Ore., has an invariably light touch. Wearing a half-smile of pure enjoyment, she sails from one number to the next like a butterfly in a field of flowers.

title: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the Philippines, Israel, Greece and India.

title: Summer Is a Word for Opera in Salzburg
description: SALZBURG, Austria  Opera has long been the backbone of the Salzburg Festival. So you might have expected the festivals new artistic director, Alexander Pereira, to treat the opera program with caution, confining himself at first to subtle shifts of emphasis. Instead Mr. Pereira, who was the director of the Zurich Opera House from 1991 to this year, is instituting major changes here, as elsewhere in the festival.

title: Guides to Make Park Days Smoother
description: We know why we love roller coasters: it is the thrill of letting go of our normal life baggage and, for just a few minutes, feeling the physical thrill and emotional uplift of being a child again. Fully grown up as most of us are, we also know why we dislike the theme parks where many roller coasters are found: it is the hassle of hauling children around in the blazing sun while following confusing maps, only to find a long line of thrill-seekers already waiting.

title: In North Korea, Putting a Female Face Front and Center
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Ri Sol-ju, the wife of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, is adding a new look to the nations leadership. Until she began accompanying Mr. Kim in public appearances in recent weeks, holding his arm and smiling at what appear to be adoring crowds, there had seldom been a womans face among the Norths power circles, which are filled with grim-faced party secretaries in Mao suits and military generals in their olive-colored uniforms.

title: After Splashy Introduction, Airtime Seems to Deflate
description: It just goes to show. You can unleash all the star power and venture capital in your arsenal to get a new start-up off the ground, but at the end of the day, people either love your service or they dont.

title: That Flashing Smile
description: THUS far, the only real fashion moment to come out of the London Olympics belongs to Ryan Lochte and his custom-made American flag dental grill (or grillz, if you prefer). After winning a gold medal, the swimmer flashed a mouthful of stars-and-stripes-shaped diamonds that had been created for him by the rapper Paul Wall and Johnny Dang, a Houston jeweler to the hip-hop stars who goes by the handle of TV Johnny. It reportedly cost $25,000.

title: Racing Against History
description: Nathan Adrians 100-meter freestyle won gold. But how would he do against every medalist in this event  ever?

title: Mozart, Naturally, but Snatches of Birdsong, Too
description: On paper the program by the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra on Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, which opened this summers season, looked like a throwback to the festivals boring old days. The evening was devoted to the festivals namesake, with performances of an opera overture, a popular piano concerto, some arias for tenor and the Prague Symphony.

title: My Indifferent Waiter, a One-Man Show
description: OVER the plaintive chords of a French composer, a spurned restaurant patron sits before a gray backdrop and speaks somberly to the camera.

title: Pink Elephant
description: THE corner of Eighth and Macdougal Streets is not exactly the white-hot center of night life. And thats the point of the latest iteration of Pink Elephant, the high-end late-night club run by Robert Montwaid and David Sarner. (The previous one was in Chelsea.) Our new space is equal distance from the meatpacking district and the Lower East Side, said Mr. Sarner, who began at Studio 54 in the 1980s. And theres no competition.

title: Master Polemicists From Similar Roots
description: Gore Vidal, as many have noted, belonged to a singular generation of American literary men  and yes, almost all were men  whose public identities at times eclipsed their literary achievements.

title: Billionaire Boys Club: Bee Line
description: A sneak peak at Pharrell Williams and Mark McNairys line, Bee Line, which will soon be sold in Bloomingdales.

title: Vidal Speaks
description: In 2008, Gore Vidal, who had then just published a new collection of essays, spoke to Deborah Solomon about the stupidity of American critics, his suspicions of John McCains war record and how he felt when he heard William Buckley had died ( I thought hell is bound to be a livelier place, as he joins forever those whom he served in life, applauding their prejudices and fanning their hatred.)The magazines interview.

title: Opera Singer Explains His Troubling Tattoo
description: The Russian bass-baritone Evgeny Nikitin, who resigned from the Bayreuth Festival over body art, wants his American audience to know his side: What appeared to be a swastika tattooed on his chest was just the first stage of a star with a heraldic crest.

title: Campaigns Rapid Response Efforts Get a Little More Rapid
description: Mitt Romneys campaign began a new Twitter account, @RomneyResponse, and Tumblr blog on Wednesday to quickly point out online what it views as false information promoted by President Obama and his campaign team, along with inaccuracies made in reports from mainstream news media organizations.

title: Close Quarters
description: VISITORS to the High Line often marvel at the panorama the elevated park affords: open-sky views across the Hudson River, an unbroken sightline up 10th Avenue to Midtown and beyond. But in recent months, in a section of the High Line around 23rd Street, a more intimate, domestic cityscape has emerged.

title: Dooh Nibor
description: Update: And the Romney people respond with deep voodoo, invoking the supposed fabulous growth effects from his tax cuts. And who could argue? Remember how the economy tanked after Clinton raised taxes? Remember how great things were after Bush cut them? Oh, wait.

title: Homes for $985,000
description: Properties in upstate New York, Los Angeles and Georgia.

title: What You Get for ... $985,000
description: LEDYARD, N.Y.

title: World Youth Teams Championships
description: TAICANG, China  At the 14th World Youth Teams Championships here the qualification stage ended Tuesday. In the junior (under 27) and youngster (under 21) events the USA-1 teams moved forward to the quarterfinals played Wednesday, but the USA-2 teams did not make it. The USA girls team did not move on either.

title: In Bogot, a Corner House With a Courtyard
description: A house in the historic Candelaria neighborhood is on the market for $1.8 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Colombia
description: A REPUBLICAN-STYLE HOUSE WITH A COURTYARD IN BOGOT

title: Pharrell Williams Is Still Asking, What If?
description: In addition to an ever-expanding roster of singers and songwriters with whom he collaborates, Mr. Williams services are increasingly sought by corporations to remix their product designs.

title: Pharrell Williams Has an Idea
description: WHAT about an audiobook? Pharrell Williams asked, sitting at the head of a conference table at the Park Avenue South offices of Rizzoli as he looked at the nearly finished galleys for an October release called Pharrell: Places and Spaces Ive Been.

title: Sunderlands Deal Raises Eyebrows
description: On July 18, Premier League club Sunderland revealed its new home uniform.

title: Reaffirming Family Ties at a Mississippi Fair
description: The Neshoba County Fair is a ritualistic event centered on family life in simple two-story cabins.

title: Family, Southern Style
description: PHILADELPHIA, Miss.

title: Shopping for Console Tables
description: Shawn Henderson, an interior designer in Manhattan, goes shopping for console tables, which can serve functions that make life a little more comfortable at home.

title: Please, Dont Touch the Nature
description: Our environment, were told by climate scientists, is fragile. But are children learning that their natural environment  the trees, dirt and grass that surround us  is fragile, too? Several educators, after observing years of childrens being taught to look, but dont touch, have argued this summer that many programs and policies designed to protect the natural world are actually preventing a new generation from developing an interest in it. Dont climb the trees, dont dig holes, take nothing but pictures, leave nothing but footprints  do we keep nature and children too far apart in the interest of protecting (or overprotecting) them both?

title: Console Tables
description: CONSOLE tables frequently take a back seat to other furniture, hidden behind the living room sofa or tucked into an inconspicuous corner of the entry hall.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. We live on the top floor of a brownstone and have rights to the roof. Would it be worth having a deck built before selling the apartment?

title: A Green Home in Winter Haven, Fla.
description: Inside an environmentally friendly home with a modern, minimalist edge.

title: A Florida House Set for Two Comfort Zones
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla.

title: The Bulb That Thinks Its a Lamp
description: They are not exactly reinventing the wheel, but definitely remaking the light bulb. AlessiLux, a whimsical group of lights including retro and sci-fi looks, dissolves the boundaries between bulb and lamp.

title: Shifting Geometry Underfoot
description: Amy Lau is a designer who likes to mix Op Art with cowhide. Her new hide rugs and pillows for the Texas-based company Kyle Bunting have sinuous geometries and even a little bit of dimension where the material fluffs up in a (theres no getting around the word) cowlick.

title: 40 Under 40: Craft Futures Salutes Young Artists
description: In 1972, the Renwick Gallery of the Smithsonian American Art Museum was created as a home for arts, crafts and design. Four decades later, the gallery is celebrating the evolution and happy confusion of those disciplines in a show of the work of 40 artists born in the last 40 years.

title: Moving Modernism Upstate
description: Having introduced modern design shops to Brooklyn, the meatpacking district and, more recently, TriBeCa, John Erik Karkula has found a new frontier. Last week, the owner of the contemporary furniture store Karkula on Walker Street opened Tree & Three in upstate Callicoon, N.Y.

title: Sales at Green Depot, Aero and Others
description: All organic cotton baby supplies, from bedding to one-piece underwear, are up to 70 percent off at Green Depot while supplies last (the Green Depot Baby crib set, regularly about $250, is about $115); 222 Bowery (Prince Street), (212) 226-0444, greendepot.com.

title: This Boy Band From Ukraine Has Legs, on High Heels
description: ON a Friday afternoon in June, inside XL, the gay club in the heart of Hells Kitchen, the four members of Kazaky, a male dance-pop act from Ukraine, were apathetically rehearsing for a performance in celebration of New Yorks gay pride weekend.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Trademarking Anonymous, and Leaving Twitter
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. See more here.

title: Knicks Sign J. R. Smiths Brother
description: 11:19 p.m. | Updated Chris Smith said he experienced poor cellphone reception for most of Tuesday. When Smith was able to get a rare signal, he received a text message from his agent, Marc Cornstein, that read, Call me ASAP.

title: As Species Vanish, Taking Up a Mission to Protect Birds and Beasts
description: When Cristin Samper told his children, ages 3 and 6, that he might leave his post as director of the Smithsonians National Museum of Natural History in Washington for a job in New York, they were crestfallen. After all, it is hard to top having a father who oversees dinosaur skeletons and stuffed lions, all part of one of the worlds largest collections of specimens and artifacts, 126 million in all.

title: An Olympics Vigil, From 30,000 Feet
description: ROYAL AIR FORCE STATION NORTHOLT, England  More than 70 years after squadrons of Spitfire and Hurricane fighters flew from here into an epic air battle with Hitlers Luftwaffe, pilots flying the fastest fighter interceptors in Britains modern arsenal have been cast in a similar role. But instead of waves of German bombers in the Battle of Britain, these pilots are guarding against a more elusive enemy: terrorists who might seek to rain destruction on the Olympic Games from the air.

title: Guilty Plea Is Expected in the Killing of Brooklyn Boy, 8
description: The man accused of kidnapping, killing and dismembering Leiby Kletzky, an 8-year-old boy who had gotten lost in the Hasidic neighborhood of Borough Park, Brooklyn, is scheduled to plead guilty to the crime and face at least 40 years in prison, a state assemblyman said Wednesday.

title: Biking Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloombergs Soda Ban
description: To the Editor:

title: Visits at Guantnamo
description: To the Editor:

title: Strength From Wilderness
description: To the Editor:

title: A Doctor Shortage and the Health Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Star Running Back for Wisconsin Is Injured in Assault
description: Montee Ball, Wisconsins star running back and a leading contender for this seasons Heisman Trophy, sustained a concussion and injuries to his face after being attacked by a group of five men near the universitys campus early Wednesday morning.

title: House Approves One-Year Extension of the Bush-Era Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  The House on Wednesday easily approved a one-year extension of all the Bush-era tax cuts set to expire in January, but in the Senate, presidential politics are complicating efforts to extend a tax credit for wind power.

title: Google Wallet Now Works With Multiple Credit Cards
description: You might have heard that Google has an app called Wallet that lets you pay for things by tapping your phone instead of pulling out a credit card  but chances are you havent used it.

title: A Giants Goal: Become Refined, but Not Too Fine
description: ALBANY Jason Pierre-Paul, at his best, creates chaos. Batted passes. Collapsed pockets. Skittish quarterbacks.

title: Obama Says Romneys Tax Plan Favors Wealthy Only
description: AKRON, Ohio  President Obama assailed Mitt Romney for top-down economics in his ninth trip this year to this battleground state, brandishing a new study showing that Mr. Romneys plans would mean additional large tax cuts for millionaires at the expense of other Americans.

title: Things I Saw  No. 24
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: Missouri: Priest to Plead Guilty in Child Pornography Case
description: The Rev. Shawn Ratigan, a priest in Kansas City who is accused of producing pornographic photographs of young girls he knew, has filed notice that he will plead guilty in federal court on Thursday. He had previously pleaded not guilty and was to be tried this month. Diocesan employees discovered hundreds of images of girls genitals on a laptop computer the priest had taken in for repair in December 2010. Father Ratigan then survived a suicide attempt, and was reassigned to live in a church facility where he continued to have contact with children. The case led to the indictment of his superior, Bishop Robert Finn, and the Diocese of Kansas City-St. Joseph, on a misdemeanor charge of failing to report suspected child abuse. They are scheduled for trial in September.

title: In Methodist Stronghold, a Dialogue on Gay Rights
description: OCEAN GROVE, N.J.  This sleepy, close-knit Jersey Shore hamlet has been a conservative Christian stronghold for 150 years. Until the 1980s, cars were not allowed on the streets on Sunday. Longtime residents recall moving their vehicles to neighboring Bradley Beach before midnight on Saturday. Today, the beaches stay closed on Sunday mornings.

title: Catholic Church and University in Peru Fight Over Name
description: LIMA, Peru  To its critics in the church, the Pontifical Catholic University of Peru is not deserving of its name. It has spurned the pontiff, they say. It is far from Roman Catholic orthodoxy, they argue. In their minds, the school ought to be called something else entirely.

title: Plan Like Romneys Would Tax Rich Less
description: A tax system overhaul along the lines that Mitt Romney has proposed would give big tax cuts to high-income households and increase the tax burden on middle- and lower-income households, according to an analysis from economists at the Tax Policy Center.

title: Coffee Creamer Brand Focuses on Simplicity and Identity
description: A NEW commercial for International Delight, a nondairy flavored creamer, opens with a brightly dressed, cheerful woman approaching a stone-faced agent at an airport security checkpoint.

title: Local Governments Face Fiscal Peril, State Comptroller Warns
description: Local governments across New York State are collecting less in taxes, burning through their cash reserves and running up deficits, according to a report released Wednesday by the state comptroller.

title: Derided as Dirty and Ugly by Subway Travelers, C Trains Earn Yet Another F
description: Riders of the C train can forgive the typical subway detritus: the wrappers and cheese puffs and unfinished sandwiches.

title: F.T.C. Seeks Tighter Rules on Web Sites for Children
description: WASHINGTON  Seeking to further tighten rules on online collection or disclosure of childrens personal information, the Federal Trade Commission proposed restrictive requirements on Wednesday on companies and Web sites that target youths or that have young audiences.

title: Afghan Finance Minister Under Scrutiny
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistans powerful finance minister came under scrutiny on Wednesday when an Afghan television network broadcast copies of two of his bank account statements that showed sizable payments from businesses and individuals and transfers of money from those accounts to bank accounts in Canada.

title: Tough Legal Issues Converge in Colorado Shooting Case
description: The prosecution of James E. Holmes for the slaughter in a Colorado movie theater last month differs from most criminal proceedings because there is so little doubt that he is the perpetrator. But that will not make it easier.

title: House Approves Tightened Sanctions Against Iran
description: 10:08 p.m. | Updated The House on Wednesday overwhelmingly approved new sanctions targeting Irans oil industry, strengthening efforts to thwart Tehrans nuclear ambitions.

title: Will Wheeler Follow Harvey to the Majors? Collins Says Not So Fast
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The success of Matt Harvey in his first two major leagues starts has some wondering whether Zack Wheeler, the Mets other coveted pitching prospect, might also make an appearance in the big leagues this year.

title: New Jerseys Highest Court Bars Distress Claims in Death of Pets
description: A dog may be mans best friend, but the horror of watching one die is not the same as seeing a close relative killed, the New Jersey Supreme Court has ruled.

title: Tea Party Aims to Apply Its Touch to the Senate G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  The Tea Party is very much alive in the drive for Republican control of the Senate, portending a potential shake-up in the mind-set of the chamber. The easy Republican primary victory in Texas on Tuesday of Ted Cruz, the 41-year-old Sarah Palin-blessed upstart, virtually assured the latest Tea Party candidate a seat in the chamber next year. And he will not be alone when it comes to those backed by the movement, which propelled Republicans to control of the House in 2010.

title: Some PayPal Users Criticize Antifraud Measures
description: Jorge Espinoza, the founder of PreRace, a Web site where bicyclists and runners can register for races, was on a roll in March. In three days his site took in over $1 million in registrations for a major bike race, much more than usual.

title: Facebooks Slide Continues Despite the Companys Reach and the Markets Hopes
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Facebook shares fell nearly 4 percent on Wednesday to $20.88  nearly half of what they were worth when the company went public on May 17.

title: Adviser Draws Attention to Romney Mideast Policy
description: WASHINGTON  Moments after making remarks in Jerusalem about Middle East culture that enraged Palestinians and undermined the public relations value of his trip to Israel, Mitt Romney looked around the room for Dan Senor, one of his campaigns top foreign policy advisers.

title: Lottery Numbers
Property Tax Evasion in City Is Widespread, Report Suggests
description: At the peak of the real estate boom, the owners of a four-story building with a couple of huge billboards in Times Square failed to report money that they received from renting the signs, evading tens of thousands of dollars a year in property taxes.

title: Inquiry Into U.S. Leaks Is Casting Chill Over Coverage
description: WASHINGTON  F.B.I. agents on a hunt for leakers have interviewed current and former high-level government officials from multiple agencies in recent weeks, casting a distinct chill over press coverage of national security issues as agencies decline routine interview requests and refuse to provide background briefings.

title: Advocates Say Special Education Bill Was Misunderstood
Usain Bolts Training Partner May Leave Him Behind
description: LONDON  The sprinter who would dethrone Usain Bolt, his Jamaican training partner known as the Beast, sat before a crowded room of reporters on Wednesday, wearing a T-shirt that said Eat My Dust.

title: Riding Herd on G.O.P. Effort to Produce a Farm Bill in the House
description: WASHINGTON  When Representative Frank D. Lucas arrived in Washington in 1994, he was less concerned with building a name for himself around the Capitol than with quietly shaping the agricultural policy that is the bread and butter of his constituents in rural western Oklahoma.

title: Thousands Await Testing for Hepatitis by Infector
description: BOSTON  Thousands of former patients at a New Hampshire hospital must wait at least another week to learn if they were infected with hepatitis C through syringes used by a traveling medical technician now known as the serial infector.

title: Mexico: Former Defense Officials Are Accused of Aiding Traffickers
description: The former second-highest ranking secretary at the Defense Ministry and three other former officers have been formally charged with aiding drug traffickers, in the biggest military corruption case in recent years. Federal prosecutors announced the charges on Tuesday evening, confirming that the officers, who were initially detained in May, are accused of participating in trafficking with the Beltrn Leyva gang, which had been one of the biggest suppliers of cocaine to the United States. Its leader, Edgar Valdes Villareal, an American-born kingpin known as La Barbie, has been in custody since August 2010. Among the officers are Toms ngeles Dauahare, a retired army general who was the deputy defense secretary from 2006 to 2008 and had been seen as a rising star. His lawyer has denied the charges, and some commentators have suggested the case is politically motivated.

title: Let Chick-fil-A Fly Free
description: Atlanta

title: Needles, Threads and New York History
description: THE garment district, a roughly rectangular swatch of Manhattan between West 35th and 42nd Streets and Seventh and Ninth Avenues, was once the bustling epicenter of Americas clothing design and manufacturing industry. While its boundaries fluctuated over the decades, the garment district, as a culture and as an idea, had resonance in areas much larger than its physical size: its hundreds of thousands of workers  including my father, David Dubinsky, the long-serving president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union  were the living embodiment of New Yorks working-class economy, whose sweat and long hours draped the shoulders of the rest of the country.

title: The Greatest Olympian
description: There is always a lot of inflated drama in the televised broadcasts of the Olympic Games, the product of network executives who like to fill expensive airtime with wall-to-wall minidocumentaries about the heart, courage and personal lives of the competitors  to the frustration of those who prefer to see great athletes actually competing.

title: Further Review for Secret Donations
description: The ploy of disguising secretly financed political machines as tax-exempt social welfare organizations has become one of the alarming trademarks of modern, big-money politics. Under cover of the tax code, the identities of donors are kept secret while they pay for attack ads against candidates, all the while claiming their main purpose is civic and nonpartisan. Operatives from both parties have gotten deep into this shell game.

title: Russias Beleaguered Opposition
description: Russia is growing more rigid and intolerant by the day under President Vladimir Putin. Last month, his Parliament moved to tighten control over Internet sites, protesters and nonprofit organizations. On Monday, three singers in a punk-rock band went on trial in Moscow for the Soviet-sounding charges of hooliganism after they sang an anti-Putin song in a Moscow cathedral. On Tuesday, Russian prosecutors leveled what appear to be trumped-up charges of embezzlement against Aleksei Navalny, one of President Putins most nettlesome and charismatic critics.

title: For God, Texas and Golf
description: Texas Republicans have just nominated a Senate candidate who is promising to protect Americas golf courses from the United Nations.

title: A Budget Crisis Averted, for Now
description: Members of Congress used to be embarrassed when they could not perform their basic job of passing spending bills and instead had to finance the government with a series of short-term resolutions. But such patchwork has now become commonplace, and it is a sign of Washingtons profound dysfunction that the short-term agreement reached on Tuesday came as a relief to both sides.

title: A Day for Chicken Sandwiches as Proxy in a Cultural Debate
description: ATLANTA  The chicken sandwich culture wars are on, at least here in the city where Chick-fil-A began in 1946 as a diner feeding factory workers.

title: Teddy Bears Fall From Sky, and Heads Roll in Minsk
description: The plane crossed stealthily into Belarussian airspace and headed for the capital, Minsk. At the appointed moment, the cargo doors opened, and an invasion force of tiny plush freedom fighters parachuted to the ground.

title: On Rowing Team, Smallest Body Has the Voice of Authority
description: LONDON  Standing among the crew of her eight-oared boat, one member of the United States womens rowing team is a sapling among redwoods.

title: A Law to Strengthen Our Cyberdefense
description: Washington

title: Romney Hasnt Done His Homework
description: Los Angeles

title: Bring It On
description: Photos from the new Broadway musical.

title: After Collapse at British Open, a Title Defense in Ohio
description: AKRON, Ohio  Adam Scott has yet to watch any replays or coverage of his breakdown at the British Open less than two weeks ago. He does not have to. He knows how it must have looked.

title: High School Rivalry, With a Leg Up
description: Cheerleading, that most American of pastimes, is not likely to become an Olympic sport anytime soon. Yet the highly acrobatic, gasp-inducing style of sis-boom-bah competition celebrated in Bring It On: The Musical, which opened Wednesday night at the St. James Theater, almost makes you believe that it should be. The cast of this alternately snarky and sentimental show about rival high school cheer squads often seems to be in constant motion, tumbling and flipping across the stage in elaborate routines that culminate in towering formations of human pyramids.

title: Makes Like Chuck Berry
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  I did it! I figured out that a puzzle was a rebus all by my lonesome!

title: Voter Suppression and Political Polls
description: Polls are the best way to find out who plans to vote and for whom they plan to vote. But polls are imperfect. They ask questions of a sampling of people  often about a thousand  and use those answers to draw conclusions about the public at large.

description: BOSTON

title: Cuban-Americans' Political Success
How the Auto Industry Fared in July
description: How the auto industry fared in July.

title: Egypt Releases Partial List of Ministers
description: CAIRO  Egyptian state news media on Wednesday released the names of more than half the ministers in the next cabinet, selections that included few members of the countrys largest Islamist party and several belonging to the past, military-backed government.

title: Corrections: August 2
description: NATIONAL

title: Monsanto Wins Big Award in a Biotech Patent Case
description: A federal jury awarded $1 billion in damages to the crop biotechnology leader Monsanto on Wednesday, saying that its arch rival DuPont had willfully infringed a patent covering Roundup Ready soybeans.

title: Amid Political Prosecutions, Russian Court Issues Ruling Favorable to Oil Tycoon
description: MOSCOW  Amid signs of a broadening campaign to prosecute opposition politicians and activists in Russia this summer, the countrys Supreme Court has issued a rare ruling in favor of the most prominent political prisoner, the jailed oil tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky.

title: In Virtual Play, Sex Harassment Is All Too Real
description: When Miranda Pakozdi entered the Cross Assault video game tournament this year, she knew she had a slim chance of winning the $25,000 prize. But she was ready to compete, and promised fans watching online that she would train just as hard as, if not harder than, anyone else.

title: Brutal Treatment of Pro-Assad Captives
description: Images taken on Tuesday show the beating and execution of men believed to support the Assad regime in the Syrian city of Aleppo.

title: George A. Miller, a Pioneer in Cognitive Psychology, Is Dead at 92
description: Psychological research was in a kind of rut in 1955 when George A. Miller, a professor at Harvard, delivered a paper titled The Magical Number Seven, Plus or Minus Two, which helped set off an explosion of new thinking about thinking and opened a new field of research known as cognitive psychology.

title: Chick-fil-A Draws Huge Crowds for Appreciation Day
description: Hundreds of thousands of people across the country headed to Chick-fil-A restaurants on Wednesday, answering a call from Mike Huckabee, the former governor of Arkansas, to show support for the fast-food chain after the companys president drew criticism for his opposition to same-sex marriage.

title: Swimming Semifinals Offer Rising Stars an Extra Chance at Glory
description: LONDON  Moving through the water like a motorboat through the Thames, Rebecca Soni increased the distance between herself and the rest of her Olympic semifinal heat in the 200-meter breaststroke Wednesday night. At the finish, Soni spun around to see her time and was delighted to discover she had recorded a personal best.

title: At Funeral of Boy Who Was Shot, Outrage and Despair
description: As hundreds of people gathered Wednesday night at Mount Neboh Baptist Church in Harlem for the funeral of a 4-year-old boy who was killed on a playground in the South Bronx, mourners decried a recent rash of gun violence in New York City that has left two children dead and several wounded.

title: Norman Alden, a Character Actor for 50 Years, Is Dead at 87
description: Norman Alden, a character actor who played a soda jerk in Back to the Future, a cameraman in Tim Burtons Ed Wood, and the title role in the cult director Richard C. Sarafians first film, Andy, died Friday in Los Angeles. He was 87.

title: Orthodox Jews Celebrate Cycle of Talmudic Study
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Nearly 90,000 Orthodox Jews bowed their heads in communal prayer at MetLife Stadium on Wednesday night to open what rabbis hailed as the largest celebration of Jewish learning since the destruction of the Second Temple in Jerusalem in 70 A.D. Yet for the estimated 20,000 women praying in the stadiums top tier, the moment felt private, as well as public.

title: The Clatter of the Hospital Room
description: Clasping her chest and struggling to breathe, the small, birdlike woman had landed once again in the hospital for complications of kidney failure. It was her third visit in the last year and now, with fluid building up around her heart, she had come back in, but only after her family had pleaded with her for a day to do so.

title: Word of the Day | unearth
description: unearth \n-rth\ verb

title: Goldman to Invest in City Jail Program, Profiting if Recidivism Falls Sharply
description: New York City, embracing an experimental mechanism for financing social services that has excited and worried government reformers around the world, will allow Goldman Sachs to invest nearly $10 million in a jail program, with the pledge that the financial services giant would profit if the program succeeded in significantly reducing recidivism rates.

title: Asia Brings Drama to an Otherwise Drab Olympics
description: HONG KONG  Its a good thing that Asian countries are competing in London: Theyve provided nearly all the colorful moments at an Olympics that has looked, so far, like about fifty shades of gray.

title: Day 7: What to Watch For
description: Here are some of the events, athletes and teams to watch Thursday at the Olympics. (All times Eastern.)

title: Nieses Effort Makes Up for Mets Missed Opportunities
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Jon Nieses body of work this season has been marked by overpowering starts interspersed with a number of aimless outings.

title: News Quiz | August 2, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Indias Glee at the Flaws of Olympics
description: There was an honorable reason why many Indians followed the string of mishaps at the London Olympics with glee, Manu Joseph wrote in The International Herald Tribune. Such things usually happen only at home, he wrote.

title: The Blame Game Begins Over Blackout
description: As electric power was restored across northern India on Wednesday, political jockeying over who was to blame for the widespread blackouts intensified, Gardiner Harris and Vikas Bajaj wrote in The New York Times.

title: Gallup Poll: India Worst Country in Asia for Entrepreneurs
description: Indians unwillingness to risk failure has hobbled the creation of small businesses and led the nation to be ranked last in Asia in promoting entrepreneurship, according to a Gallup poll.

title: What We're Watching on Day 7
description: Ryan Lochte will go for two gold medals in swimming on Thursday while Mary Whipple and the U.S. rowing team is favored to win another gold in the women's eight event.

title: Syrian Fighting Intensifies in Battle for Aleppo
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian rebels shelled an airport near Aleppo on Thursday in what was described as one of the first known instances of insurgents using captured heavy weapons, as opposition activists warned that fighting for the city, the countrys main commercial center, would likely intensify.

title: BNP Paribas Profit Falls 13% in Second Quarter
description: PARIS  Europes deepening debt crisis curbed trading revenue at the French bank BNP Paribas, pushing its net profit down by 13 percent in the second quarter compared with the same period last year.
