description: As we announced on Monday, were experimenting with a new kind of Test Yourself question this week.

title: Under Pressure, Biggest Banks Rely on 3 Myths
description: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Along the Road to the White House
description: With a mere 99 days left until the presidential election, the candidates continue to poll at a statistical tie. Unemployment and economic stagnation continue to weigh on the nations psyche and the campaigns have turned negative, hoping to appeal to voters who are still undecided.

description: WHO is Mimi Sheraton?

title: Mumford & Sons Begin U.S. Tour in Hoboken
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.  Mumford & Sons, the British folk rockers, kicked off a monthlong American tour here on Wednesday night with an outdoor concert, providing thrills for more than 15,000 people who crowded into Pier A Park.

title: Why Pakistan is Losing Out in the Mango Market
description: With their golden yellow, blushing pink and pale green hues coloring markets by the cart-full, Pakistani mangoes are a source of national joy and pride. But bad luck  and poor logistics  are now threatening Pakistans king of fruits, Huma Yusuf wrote in the Latitude blog of The New York Times.

title: Chicago Bears, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
description: The Chicago Bears president,Ted Phillips, decided after last season that he was seeing the third cycle of a pattern that his team had been stuck in since the former general manager Jerry Angelo arrived in 2001:

title: An Age-Segregated Dream
description: In New York in the 1970s, retirees were finding that life wasnt so beautiful and the winters were cold, says an elderly voice in the opening minutes of Kings Point, a new documentary. They ran away. They ran to Florida.

title: N.J. Troopers Charged in Leading Exotic Car Caravan on Garden State Parkway
description: What began as citizen complaints about speeding and reckless driving has led the New Jersey attorney general to announce criminal charges against two state troopers accused of leading exotic cars in a high-speed caravan on the Garden State Parkway.

title: In Mets Clubhouse, Tension Over Valdespins T-Shirt
description: SAN FRANCISCO  There was an awkward scene in the Mets clubhouse late on Wednesday, even as the team was celebrating a 2-1 win over the San Francisco Giants.

title: Visit Olympics London. Its Empty!
description: LONDON  We at Rendezvous almost certainly have some kind of house rule about not doing promotions, but the situation is desperate, so here goes anyway: Now is the perfect time to visit London. The place is empty!

title: Douglas Wins Gold in Womens All-Around
description: Gabby Douglas of the United States won the gold medal in the womens gymnastics all-around individual final.

title: Viva Amerexico!
description: It was bound to happen: contemporary, creative, smart no-name food made by an American of Mexican extraction in Mexico. Jair Tllezs restaurant in Mexico City, MeroToro  mero is grouper, toro is bull; its a made-up word, kind of a play on surf n turf  would be equally at home in L.A. or in New York, which goes to show just how American its neighborhood, Condesa, feels. (Condesas gentrification has paralleled that of Manhattans Lower East Side, though it is a naturally more beautiful place.)

title: Speed Counseling for Struggling Business Owners
description: Recently, I was invited to a new effort to help aspiring entrepreneurs in the food business. It is being spearheaded by Jim Koch, founder and president of the Boston Beer Company, maker of Samuel Adams beer. He teamed up with Accion, a microfinance organization, to create a new program called Brewing the American Dream.

title: Q&A: Checking Android App Permissions
description: Q.

title: Big Drought Makes for a Small Dead Zone
description: In yet another display of the inexorable interdependence of Earths ecosystems, a bad summer for Midwestern farmland has turned out to be a good one for life in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: In Assam, Grim Aftermath to July Riots
description: KOKRAJHAR/CHIRANG, Assam  Almost two weeks after their village was burned by rioters, a group of Bodo men sneaked back to see the charred remains of their houses. All their livestock, except the pigs, were gone. Right now, standing here, I am petrified, said Kalidas Brahmo, a farmer, walking through the rubble of his home.

title: Hopeful News From Maryland
description: A new poll of Maryland voters, who will get to decide in November whether to overrule recently signed legislation establishing same-sex marriage in the state, shows that 54 percent favor the law, while 40 percent oppose it. These findings, by Hart Research Associates, will be released publicly later today; The Times was given an advance look at them.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Draghi Edges Closer to Bond Purchases, but Hopes Are Blunted
description: FRANKFURT  Maybe this is why central bankers typically dont like to say much.

title: Imperiled Legacy for African Art
description: DJENNE-DJENNO, one of the best-known archaeological sites in sub-Saharan Africa, spreads over several acres of rutted fields near the present city of Djenne in central Mali. The ruts are partly caused by erosion, but theyre also scars from decades of digging, by archaeologists in search of history and looters looking for art to sell.

title: Rob What Kind of Bank?
description: Speculate about this for a bit: What is the worst possible time for an evangelist bearing Jesus pamphlets to come to the front door? During your Seder? Nah, not even close. While youre berating a misbehaving child at an embarrassing volume? Maybe.

title: Workin 9 to 5
description: By age 8, I was pretty clear about who I was. I loved to read, I loved puzzles, I loved political satire and I loved classic business wear. Blazers, button-up shirts, tweed, front-pleated trousers, oxford shoes. My style aesthetic was that of a sensible adult, and I had an irrepressible penchant for fine tailoring and conservative clothes. I would have even taken a blouse and finely made slacks over a date with Ricky Schroder any day. (Maybe not.)

title: After a Loss in Europe, G.M. Plans Fast Action
description: DETROIT  General Motors vowed Thursday to accelerate changes at its troubled European division after a loss in the region dragged down the companys profit by 41 percent in the second quarter.

title: For Phelps, a Bittersweet Reunion (and Race)
description: LONDON  A chapter closed for Michael Phelps on Thursday when he competed in the last preliminary race of his career, in the 100-meter butterfly. As luck would have it, Phelps was next to Milorad Cavic, the Serbian star who came within one-hundredth of a second of pulling off the upset four years ago in Beijing.

title: Opinion Report: Michael Phelps
description: From the editorial page

title: Anna Hazares Movement Turns Political
description: After leading a civil society movement against corruption for months, Anna Hazare and his team changed their strategy Thursday, saying it was time for a political alternative.

title: When 26 Cents Isnt Worth the Trip
description: Dear Diary:I was in a health food store on the Upper East Side reaching for a package of Kashi cereal priced at $4.25 when an older gentleman in a bright red T-shirt appeared and admonished, Dont buy that; its cheaper in Fairway.

title: London Live: Live Coverage From Olympic Swimming
description: Michael Phelps put an exclamation point on his career, winning the 200-meter individual medley for his 20th career Olympic medal. He held off Ryan Lochte, who had earlier finished a disappointing third in the 200-meter backstroke to American Tyler Clary.

title: States Up the Ante in Bid to Lure Other States Bettors
description: Cash-hungry states have long tried to poach business from one another. Now many are stepping up their efforts to lure gamblers from their neighbors to their growing ranks of slot machines, leaving states like Delaware, which embraced gambling early, struggling to keep up in what has become a feverish one-armed-bandit arms race.

title: U.S. Wins Another Gold in Womens Eight
description: LONDON  For the entire 2,000 meters of the Olympic womens eight final, the United States team had the best view of all.

title: Knight Capital Says Trading Glitch Cost It $440 Million
description: 4:01 p.m. | Updated

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Hunting for Leakers, and Olympic Spotlight on Headphones
description: The F.B.I.s hunt for leakers among the governments national security agencies has cast a chill over media coverage of those issues, Scott Shane reports, with the agencies declining interview requests or background briefings. At the same time, the Senate is considering legislation meant to limit intelligence officials exchanges with reporters; that bill has been criticized by intelligence veterans and civil libertarians fear as counterproductive and raising constitutional questions. The criminal investigation was prompted by, among others, recent media disclosures on American cyberattacks on Iran and the so-called kill list of terrorist suspects approved for drone strikes. The reports were published by The New York Times, The Associated Press, Newsweek and other outlets, as well as in recent books by reporters for Newsweek and The Times.

title: Thursday Reading: Dieting vs. Exercise for Weight Loss
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Dismissed as Too Fantastic, a Fitzgerald Story Gets Another Chance
description: If youre the sort who sees no reason to avoid clichs like the plague, you could do worse than to trot out the one about how there are no second acts in American lives. That was from F. Scott Fitzgerald. It is used and misused a lot, commonly to mean that there are no second chances, which may not be quite what Fitzgerald had in mind, especially considering that his most enduring work, The Great Gatsby, is about a man who reinvents himself.

title: This Isnt The Draghi Youre Looking For
description: Update: Rumor is that the ECB is actually going to do more than Draghi seemed to say.

title: Venezuelas Elusive Voters
description: MONTREAL  How do you imagine the voter who will decide this election?

title: Daily Report: PayPal Measures Cause Trouble for Start-Ups
description: There have been enough horror stories about frozen PayPal accounts to make some companies think twice about using the service, Brian X. Chen reports on Thursday in The New York Times. The victims include individual sellers, start-up companies, creative artists and impromptu philanthropists. They all had to scramble when PayPal decided to hold on to their money longer than expected.

title: Looking for a Different Gear in the 50 Free
description: LONDON  Freestyle sprinters are like racecars: sleek, exquisitely tuned and built for speed. The gears of even the finest engines sometimes get stuck, and unfortunately for Cullen Jones, that is what happened in his 100-meter freestyle semifinal.

title: Apollos 2nd-Quarter Profit Falls 84%
description: Apollo Global Management said Thursday that its profit tumbled by 84 percent in the second quarter, as its core private equity business grappled with difficult markets.

title: Newswallah: The Government Is Broken
description: The massive scale of this weeks blackout in India, which left 684 million without electricity, has galvanized the countrys already critical English-language media.

title: Aug. 1: Obama Extends Electoral College Advantage
description: Barack Obamas standing in the FiveThirtyEight forecast reached its strongest position to date on Tuesday as a result of favorable polls in a set of swing states. The forecast model now gives Mr. Obama a 70.8 percent chance of winning the Electoral College, up from 69.0 percent on Monday and from 65.0 percent last Tuesday.

title: For Delegates in a Hurry, The Bike Lane Beckons
description: Just in time for the Democratic National Convention in Charlotte next month, the city has started offering a bicycle-sharing program that it says is the largest in the Southeast. Charlotte B-cycle, part of the Wisconsin-based B-cycle national network, comprises 200 commuter-style bicycles at 20 stations uptown (Charlottes downtown) and nearby. Most of the stops are near bus, shuttle and light-rail stops.

title: 3 Men Arrested in Spain Are Suspected of Having Links to Al Qaeda
description: MADRID  The Spanish government said on Thursday that it had arrested three men suspected of having links to Al Qaeda and believed to have been planning attacks in Europe.

title: On Our Radar: Facebooks Carbon Footprint
description: In a move toward greater transparency, Facebook discloses its carbon footprint. Coal-fired power accounts for the biggest share of the energy consumed by its data centers  27 percent  followed by renewable energy sources, natural gas and nuclear power. [The Guardian]

title: Lithuania, the Other Dream Team at the 92 Games
description: Between Jack McCallums stellar retrospective (the aptly titled Dream Team, released last month), a 90-minute NBA TV documentary and myriad articles raising pointed cross-decades comparisons, memories of the Dream Teams dominance, personality and global influence continue to ring true two decades on.

title: A Renaissance Man, and Many Eras Besides
description: WHEN studying music, few young conductors begin at the beginning. The Gustavo Dudamels of the world cut their teeth on a 200-year orchestral canon, starting with Mozart and ending with Shostakovich. Rarely does a conductor with an eye on a mainstream career tackle music written before Bachs time, works typically reserved for specialists and scholars.

title: Retailers Beat Expectations, Helped by Midpriced Stores
description: In July, higher-than-expected sales at low- and midpriced stores helped push sales past analysts estimates.

title: Mockingbirds of the Concert Hall
description: IN the busier areas of Central Park, dodging hordes of tourists and would-be Tour de France racers can take precedent over wildlife spotting. But Olivier Messiaen, a French composer who disliked cities and said, Nature never displays anything in bad taste, would surely have approved as two New York City Audubon recently led a small group of music lovers on a fascinating bird-watching tour through the southern section of the park.

title: What Other Professions Deserve $3 Million Prizes?
description: The monster $3 million prize for theoretical physics Russian billionaire Yuri Milner created this week raises a lot of intriguing questions. One of them is the structure of incentives in modern capitalism.

title: Aug. 5  11
description: DETAILS have been scant about Heartless, the new play by SAM SHEPARD that begins an Off Broadway run this week, but for Shepard fans it hardly matters. Its new, and its by the man who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1979 for Buried Child. In that play he dealt with submerged secrets, and in Heartless dark secrets are at issue too, but Mr. Shepard is not simply playing in an old sandbox here. This writer known for many a testosterone-fueled battle (see True West, The Tooth of Crime and others) has  perhaps surprisingly  written a play predominantly populated by female characters.

title: What Were Reading
description: Hungry Ghost: Looking for local produce? Try pickling the milkweed pods that grow by the side of the road.  Julia Moskin

title: Field Hockey Is a Vision in Blue
description: LONDON  Youre at the 2012 Olympics. Your ticket is for mens field hockey at the Riverbank Arena in Olympic Park in East London. So, why does it feel as if youre in Idaho?

title: A Sculptor Creates a Stop on the Bee Train
description: Christopher Russell, 52, a Manhattan sculptor, is one of 10 artists commissioned by the M.T.A. Arts for Transit and Urban Design program in its latest project to enhance New York subway stations. Almost all of the new works (seven are scheduled for unveiling today along the D line in Brooklyn) are laminated glass windscreens that edge subway platforms above ground. One project, by the artist Andrea Dezs, consists of stainless steel railings that are part of a transfer bridge and underpass.

title: J. Courtney Sullivan: By the Book
description: What book is on your night stand now?

title: Answers to Questions About Boating, Part II
description: Roland Lewis, the president and chief executive of the Metropolitan Waterfront Alliance, is answering City Room readers questions about boating in New York waterways. The first set of answers can be found here, the third, here and the second set appears below. We are no longer accepting questions.

title: For New Theater, BAM Commissions a Really Big Painting
description: A decade ago, when the Brooklyn Academy of Music restored its landmark exterior, the Brazilian photographer Vik Muniz decorated the scaffolding of the buildings second, third and fourth floors with images of a giant gingerbread house. It was a colorful confection: melted sugar outlined with giant jelly beans and slithering Gummi Worms recreated the buildings arched windows; giant M&Ms became its frieze.

title: House Reprimands Richardson
description: After hearing Representative Laura Richardson speak in her own defense, the House of Representatives on Thursday briskly approved a report by its Ethics Committee to reprimand her for compelling her Congressional staff to do campaign work. The resolution, which imposes a fine of $10,000 and which she had agreed to accept, passed on a voice vote.

title: Beautifying the D Line
description: Seven of 10 art projects commissioned to beautify New York subway stations along the D line in Brooklyn are now open to the public.

title: Business Day Live | August 2, 2012
description: Examining the fallout of an electronic trading debacle. | What the Fed's inaction means for the economy. | A look at Chick-fil-A, as a business. | Keeping fit while traveling.

title: Resigning as Envoy to Syria, Annan Casts Wide Blame
description: Frustrated by the seemingly intractable Syrian conflict, Kofi Annan announced his resignation on Thursday as the special peace envoy of the United Nations and the Arab League, throwing new doubts on whether a diplomatic solution is possible. He also said President Bashar al-Assad of Syria must leave office.

title: Business Day Live: Runaway Trades Spread Turmoil
description: Examining the fallout of an electronic trading debacle. | What the Feds inaction means for the economy. | A look at Chick-fil-A, as a business. | Keeping fit while traveling.

title: Two Friends Write a Play After Work
description: WORKING construction in Houston one sweltering morning during the summer of 1983, Frankie Hyman overheard the site supervisor chastising another employee for arriving two hours late. When he heard an easy, drawling voice retort, What are you talking about, Im usually the first one in and the last to leave, a claim that definitely was not the case, Mr. Hyman chuckled and decided that I liked this guy, and I hadnt even met him yet.

title: The Caucus Click: Rafalcas Olympic Debut
description: 2:12 p.m. | Updated Rafalca, the horse co-owned by Ann Romney, made her Olympic debut on Thursday.

title: Image of the Day: August 2
Where Is Bourne? Not in an Electronic Version
description: So, my 15-year-old son was heading off to summer camp. Dad, I need some books! he said, waggling his iPod Touch.

title: Facts Are Offensive
description: On a recent episode of This Week with George Stephanopoulos, Rahm Emanuel said Mitt Romney should stop whining about liberal attacks on private equity and simply defend himself. If you want to claim Bain capital as your calling card to the White House, then defend what happened to Bain Capital, he said.

title: Growth of Indonesian Airlines Strains the Infrastructure
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesian airlines are poised for rapid growth, but a lack of critical infrastructure and trained personnel may keep the industry from reaching anticipated heights, experts say.

title: On Cyprus Beach, Stubborn Relic of Conflict
description: FAMAGUSTA, Cyprus  Snakes slither inside dilapidated houses in the abandoned seaside resort of Varosha, a ghost town of decaying vintage cars and crumbling villas where time stopped in August 1974.

title: New Egyptian Cabinet Includes Many Holdovers
description: CAIRO  Egypts president swore in members of his first cabinet on Thursday, marking another milestone in the countrys difficult transition even as reports of deadly violence complicated the new governments work.

title: Lawsuit Over Raging Bull Sequel (Now a Nonsequel) Is Settled
description: A lawsuit that aimed to block a sequel to Raging Bull has been settled, according to Entertainment Weekly, which reports that the movie will go forward under the title The Bronx Bull and will have no connection with Raging Bull.

title: Splashing or Sipping, but Tasting the Pool Before the Swim
description: Swimmers awaiting their races on the pool deck at the Olympic aquatics center in London all have their particular routines. Michael Phelps hides behind huge headphones. Cesar Cielo of Brazil thumps his chest like Tarzan. The Australian Stephanie Rice presses on her goggles four times. A full set of shakes, rattles and rolls goes on in those tense minutes before swimmers mount the blocks.

title: In Track and Field, Tense Rivalries and Wild Cards
description: LONDON  The Olympic caldron is no longer in harms way. Since the opening ceremony last week, it has been moved out of the infield of the Olympic Stadium and transported to higher ground. Track and field can begin without fear of javelins and shot-puts landing in the flames.

title: Options for Providing Women With a More Secure Retirement
description: Its easy to see why elderly women are at a higher risk of living in poverty during retirement than their male counterparts: women tend to earn less, live longer, and they often spend more time out of the work force to care for family members, both young and old.

title: Into the Nothing, After Something
description: A subterranean stream of death and personal tragedy trickles around the margins of Jim Holts new book, Why Does the World Exist? An Existential Detective Story.

title: On a U.S. Team on a Mission, Westbrook Is Waiting for One
description: The architects responsible for designing the United States mens national basketball team had the benefit of selecting from the N.B.A.s most talented players as well as its most versatile ones.

title: Breaking It Down: U.S. Womens Soccer vs. North Korea
description: Ali Krieger is a defender for the United States womens national soccer team and plays for FFC Frankfurt. Because of an injury, she is not playing for the team in the 2012 Games. She was an alternate on the 2008 United States Olympic team and started for the Americans in last summers World Cup. She will be writing for the 2012 London Olympics blog throughout the Games. This is her second post.

title: The Wiggle of Least Resistance
Just Before Olympics, Good Morning America Takes Crown Away From Today
description: The last shred of morning television dominance owned by NBCs Today show came crashing down last week as ABCs Good Morning America won the ratings across the board, even among the group of viewers most prized by news advertisers.

title: The Olympus Games
description: In this weeks Riff, Heather Havrilesky writes about watching the beautiful young masochists of the Olympic Games on television. Below, some anticipatory thoughts about the Games that were published in this paper almost 40 years before the modern Olympics began, on Nov. 19, 1858.

title: Theses On Taxes
description: Some brief notes:

title: Bristol-Myers Executive Is Accused of Insider Trading
description: Federal prosecutors have charged a Bristol-Myers Squibb executive with insider trading, saying he had profited from confidential information about pending deals by the pharmaceutical company.

title: Cybersecurity Bill Is Blocked in Senate by G.O.P. Filibuster
description: WASHINGTON  A cybersecurity bill that had been one of the Obama administrations top national security priorities was blocked by a Republican filibuster in the Senate on Thursday, severely limiting its prospects this year.

title: Stone Links: Boyles Olympic Incoherence
description: At The Paris Review, Rafil Kroll-Zaidi parses the opening ceremony of the London Games and finds it to be a semiotic mess  a jumble of signifiers never exceeding haphazard pastiche. We should have expected no less, he argues, as its director, Danny Boyle, has always shown himself, as a filmmaker, to be more of an executive technician than an artist of coherent vision. The erraticism of the opening ceremony  indeed, its mild insanity  follows from the striking inconsistency (in many senses) of his oeuvre: Boyles films range from the high of Trainspotting to the (very) low of Sunshine, with the treacly, manipulative Slumdog Millionaire falling somewhere in between.

title: Toyota Recalls RAV4 and Lexus HS 250h to Fix Rear Suspension Issue
description: Toyota is recalling a total of 778,000 RAV4 and Lexus HS 250h models sold in the United States to fix a problem in the rear suspension that it says arises when the vehicles are serviced.

title: Want Their VCR, Too?
description: My friendly neighbors renovated their home. Their huge TV (a five-foot black plastic cube) did not go with their new dcor, so they offered it to me. Every time

title: From Here You Could Shoot in Every Direction
description: IF the eight-foot-thick circular walls of Castle Williams could talk, Michael Shaver knows what stories they would tell.

title: 36 Hours in Midcoast Maine
description: Wedged between the indie environs of Portland and the great outdoors of Acadia National Park, Maines midcoast region has long enthralled summertime drivers with its quaint towns and pastoral, pine-lined roads. The tranquil harbors and craggy beaches along U.S. 1 offer settings as quintessentially Maine as can be. (Lobster roll with a lighthouse view, anyone?)

title: Meandering Up Maines Midcoast
description: On a trip from Topsham to Camden, discover the many ways you can connect with the sea.

title: Theater Talkback: Guts and Glory, Onstage
description: Lets begin by acknowledging that all actors, especially stage actors, are brave. It takes guts as well as vanity to unpack your heart in front of a live audience.

title: In War, Moments Worth Remembering
description: Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, 1990; hard to believe there were any good days in the two decades since. How could there be? I have told my war stories both as an embedded journalist and an Army veteran of Desert Storm. When I say Iraq, it is only violence that is remembered.

title: Duet
description: James Carville and former Makers Mark president Bill Samuels Jr. declare their love for America.

title: Whats Your Favorite?
description: A video from Makers Mark featuring James Carville and Mary Matalin.

title: Urban Foraging and Dancing on Skates
description: In a summer of near-record heat, widespread drought and crippling power blackouts, youd be forgiven a few fleeting apocalyptic thoughts.

title: Elizabeth Spiers, Editor of The New York Observer, Is Leaving
description: The New York Observer said on Thursday that Elizabeth Spiers was leaving at the end of this month, becoming the fourth editor in chief in seven years to leave the newspaper.

title: DirecTV Reports Its First Drop in U.S. Subscribers
description: DirecTV on Thursday reported its first drop in net subscribers to its service in the United States, highlighting the challenges for pay television providers in a saturated marketplace.

title: After Protest, Madonna Shows Clip of Warsaw Uprising at Concert
description: Responding to critics in Poland, Madonna showed a World War II-era newsreel about the Warsaw Uprising against the Nazis during her concert on Wednesday in the city on the anniversary of that 1944 revolt, Agence France-Presse reported. Thousands of fans applauded as the two-and-a-half minute film played.

title: Maison Kayser, a Global Baker, Touches Down in New York
description: A global chain of artisanal bakeries sounds like an oxymoron. But thats precisely what Eric Kayser has created since he opened his little boulangerie on Rue Monge near the Sorbonne in Paris in 1996. Now his first bakery-cafe in New York is set to open on Wednesday, and leases have been signed for two more. Like his other Maison Kayser establishments, including some 20 in the Paris area, 22 in Japan and scores of others in Europe, Asia and the Middle East, the new bakery on the Upper East Side has bakers who were trained in his Paris headquarters.

title: For Wall Street, Real Pain When the Fed Fails to Act
description: Looks like the central bankers just destroyed Wall Streets 2012 bonus season.

title: The Goal Is Winning Gold, Not Winning Every Match
description: LONDON  Abby Wambach, the veteran forward on the United States womens soccer team, said the other day that no one gives you anything for finishing at the top of your group. And the goal of every Olympic athlete, from Wambach to Usain Bolt to Ann Romneys horse Rafalca, is to win a medal. The rest is just a journey.

title: Mighty Draghi?
description: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, promised last week that he would do whatever it takes.

title: More on Gas Drilling, Peer Review and Public Health
description: Aug. 3, 9:34 a.m. | Updated with reply from Sandra Steingraber |A recurring focus here of late has been the fractious nexus of policy, politics and science related to the nations gas drilling boom.

title: Shoe News | Coccodrillo Comes to Verso
description: Between the many talented designers whove sprung from its Royal Academy of Fine Arts and its refined retail scene, Antwerp qualifies as one of the most fashion-conscious cities in the world. That reputation has just been further corroborated with the opening of a Coccodrillo shoe salon at Verso. Coccodrillo is one of Europes most design-focused shoe shops (it even offers a yearly prize to a promising young student from the Academy); Verso, housed in a grand 16th-century town house, is one of the citys most glamorous fashion boutiques. That theyve come together makes for some of the best one-stop style shopping anywhere. Until now Verso sold only shoes to the ready-to-wear customer to complete the outfit, Geert Bruloot and Eddy Michiels, Coccodrillos founders, told The Moment via e-mail from Belgium. We want to move towards a more independent shoe store. Which means upping the ante on more adventurous designs: nestled among this falls lace pump by Dolce & Gabbana and glossy velvet slippers by Giuseppe Zanotti are curvy booties by the Turkish designer Burak Uyan.

title: Urologist Charged With Shooting Video Up Skirt in Subway
description: Updated, 5:56 p.m. | A urologist at Mount Sinai Medical Center was arraigned Thursday on charges of taking videos up the skirt of a woman at the Union Square subway station during the evening rush hour on Wednesday, the Manhattan district attorneys office said.

title: A High-Profile Cheering Section for a Horses Olympic Debut
description: LONDON  The crowd was customarily silent, so as not to distract horse and rider. Plastic Champagne flutes and windbreakers abounded, to toast the competitors and confront a rainy day at the park.

title: Readers Debate Trade-Offs Between Security and Civil Liberties
description: Does more liberty necessarily mean less security, and vice versa?

title: Making Waves With Zumba
description: WHEN it comes to low-impact exercise, water-based workouts are a vacation for your joints. But while the aim of swimming is to streamline movement, aqua fitness taps the resistance of water to increase strength and flexibility.

title: In Monterey, Last Call for a Landmark Bars Former Tenants
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The origins of the restaurant proprietor are shrouded in myth.

title: Pictures of the Day From London | August 2, 2012
description: The seventh day of the London Olympics.

title: Reaching Out to Include the Special Needs Child
description: Should you invite the special needs child to your childs birthday party?

title: Douglas Wins Gold
description: Gabby Douglas became the first African-American Olympic all-around champion in gymnastics.

title: TimesCast Politics | August 2, 2012
description: Nate Silver previews Fridays jobs report. | Inside New York Times polling. | Twitters man in Washington. | The Op-Ed columnist Frank Bruni on Romney and the press.

title: Spitzers Parents Give $4 Million to Public Theater
description: The Bernard and Anne Spitzer Charitable Trust, founded by the parents of the former New York governor Eliot Spitzer, have given $4 million to the Public Theater. The money will go toward the theaters free Shakespeare in the Park productions as well its capital campaign to revitalize its downtown home at Astor Place, a $40 million renovation of the building that houses five theaters and Joes Pub and is nearing completion.

title: TimesCast Politics: A Preview of the Jobs Report
description: Getty Images

title: How to Tell an Elephant From a Cat? Check the Larynx
description: Elephants rumble to communicate, sending vibrations across the landscape that other elephants can feel through their feet. But until recently, no one knew how they made their distinctive thundering sounds. Were they purring like cats, or were their voices just very low?

title: Makers Mark Gets Political
description: Mary Matalin and James Carvilles odd-couple shtick has long been a staple of cable news. He plays the irascible liberal with a sharp tongue and a penchant for bizarre Cajun metaphors. She is the conservative counterpoint, far more reserved but ever incredulous.

title: A Very Long Journey Was Very Swift
description: LONDON  To become the Olympic champion in the individual all-around event, Gabby Douglas first had to leave everything she knew best.

title: Cybersecurity Bill Dies Under Weight of Partisan Bickering
description: No amount of death-and-destruction talk about the prospects of cyberattacks on the nations nuclear power plants and water systems could override the intense partisanship on Capitol Hill.

title: Im Outta Here
description: Note to the Europeans: you cannot have a crisis for the next couple of weeks, because Im going on a long-scheduled family vacation  probably without internet access most of the time. Please wait until the last week of the month.

title: Apple AirPlay and the Window of Obsolescence
description: Anytime theres a new operating system, theres somebody who complains. Usually, the new OS breaks some older piece of software. Or maybe your printer wont work after the upgrade. Something.

title: Raismans Hometown Rallies From Across the Pond
description: NEEDHAM, Mass.  At the Aly Rally in Aly Raismans hometown Thursday, a crowd of about 500 fans packed into a flag- and balloon-filled town hall to root her on from across the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Paley Art Collection Heading to the de Young Fine Arts Museums in San Francisco
description: The staggering art collection put together by William S. Paley, the television impresario who founded the Columbia Broadcasting System, first went on view at the Museum of Modern Art in 1992. Paley, a longtime trustee at MoMA, had left his paintings, drawings and sculptures to the museum upon his death in 1990. After MoMA showed the collection it then traveled to museums in Indianapolis, Seattle, Los Angeles, San Diego and Baltimore.

title: Soni Sets World Record to Win 200 Breaststroke
description: LONDON  Swimming is in the worlds viewfinder for only one summer every four years, during the Olympics. For those who pour their sweat, blood and fears into the sport, the stakes and the stress can be suffocating.

title: Briton Emerges From Velodromes Chaos With a 5th Gold
description: LONDON  On the first day of track cycling, one of the Olympic diversions that the British now find most diverting, it was sometimes difficult to distinguish the faster from the slower, the triumphant from the thwarted.

title: Past Forward: On the Possibility of Israel Attacking Iran
description: In last weekends issue, Ronen Bergman wrote about the mystery surrounding the Aleppo Codex: the oldest, most complete version of the Hebrew Bible, whose ownership has been in dispute since it was completed in A.D. 930. Considering the persistent tensions over Irans nuclear ambitions  the most recent round of sanctions against Iran imposed by the United States and the European Union was approved yesterday  it made sense that From the Archives would highlight Bergmans previous story for the magazine, Will Israel Attack Iran?

title: Sondheims Marry Me a Little Returning to New York
description: Marry Me a Little, a Stephen Sondheim musical that hasnt been performed in New York in 25 years, will begin the Keen Companys 2012-13 season next month. The Off Broadway production, with previews beginning at the Clurman Theater on Sept. 11 and an opening night set for Oct. 2, includes songs that, producers say, have never been performed on a New York stage before, most notably Rainbows, from an as yet unmade film version of Into the Woods.

title: A New Election Index From Twitter
description: A conversation with Adam Sharp, Twitters Man in Washington, on a new way to measure public opinion.

title: Inside New York Times Polling
description: August 2, 2012- TimesCast Politics | Inside New York Times polling and a new collaboration with Quinnipiac University.

title: A Home in This World
description: To the Editor:

title: Eggers, Mailer, Balzac
description: To the Editor:

title: Can We Talk?
description: To the Editor:

title: Intolerance
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Cigars Offer Way for Smokers to Save
description: Fewer Americans are smoking cigarettes, but a growing number are turning to cigarettelike cigars that can sell for as little as seven cents apiece or to making cigarettes from inexpensive loose tobacco labeled for pipe use, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported Thursday.

title: 16th Gold for Phelps as Lochte Falls Short
description: LONDON  On the night that closed the book on their rivalry, Michael Phelps and Ryan Lochte slipped into old roles and seemed to switch personalities as if under some sorcerers spell. Lochte, who had taken to describing himself as happy-go-Lochte and whose response to any question in the lead-up to the Olympics about mushrooming expectations was, Its just swimming, was the pinched-faced man of few words.

title: The Food Is Hot; The Mood Is Cool
description: IT is more living room than dining room, this languidly cluttered Jamaican spot on Atlantic Avenue in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. The walls are that blue somewhere between sea shallows and untroubled sky. Reef-print banquettes are encased in plastic. A piece of driftwood like a long bone pins magazines to a battered coffee table.

title: Using Twitter, California Politicians Join Chick-fil-A Debate
description: As Congress wrangles over tax cuts and agricultural assistance heading into the August recess, Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, took sides in a different fight Thursday.

title: In Blue Hawaii, Senate Race Offers a Bit of Suspense
description: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Here is Hawaii, the Aloha State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Neil Milner, a former political science professor at the University of Hawaii, and Andrew Winer, a Democratic consultant and adviser to the Senate campaign of Representative Mazie Hirono, a Democrat representing Hawaiis Second District. Mr. Winer was also the campaign manager for Senator Daniel K. Akaka, of Hawaii, in 2006.

title: Video: A New Election Index from Twitter
description: A conversation with Adam Sharp, Twitters Man in Washington, on a new way to measure public opinion.

title: Filtering Mirs Work Through a Political Sieve
description: WASHINGTON  Was Joan Mir a political artist? A much-beloved Surrealist, he is not commonly thought of as such. On its face, his oeuvre appears remarkably apolitical, especially considering that he lived through two world wars and a murderous civil war in his homeland, Spain. From the hallucinogenic vision of The Farm in the 1920s to his mural-scale fields of color punctuated by wispy signs in the 1960s, evidence of worldly political engagement is hard to find. A reluctant joiner and manifesto signer, Mir (1893-1983) disliked Social Realism. The artists of the past who inspired him were mystic visionaries like Hieronymus Bosch and William Blake.

title: Prepaid Cellphones Are Cheaper. Why Arent They Popular?
description: Daniel Acker/Bloomberg NewsPrepaid mobile phone products on display at a Family Dollar Stores location.

title: After a Dispute, a Retirement
description: LONDON  The fallout from the Olympic badminton controversy continues. A day after eight players were disqualified for deliberately trying to lose their preliminary-round matches on Tuesday, one of them said she planned to retire.

title: Fishermans Dawta
description: Inside the Boerum Hill restaurant that dishes up jerk chicken to the tune of reggae.

title: Even in the Future, Its Not Paranoia if Theyre Out to Get You
description: In the future according to Total Recall  the new version, not the 1990 movie with the same name and the same alleged source in a Philip K. Dick story  Earth has been devastated by chemical warfare, leaving only two populated areas connected by a tunnel through the planets core. On one end of the chute, known as the Fall, is a sleek successor to Britain, an imperial metropole that exploits the teeming, watery Colony (Australia with elements of futuristic Hong Kong and Bangkok) down below.

title: Senate Panel Passes Extension of Wind Energy Tax Credit
description: Senate Republicans rebuffed their presumptive presidential nominee as the Senate Finance Committee passed a one-year extension of the tax credit for wind energy, just four days after Mitt Romneys campaign announced that it wanted the credit to die.

title: Strong, Not So Silent Type | Barbara Krugers Belief+Doubt
description: In pretty much any museum, real estate is at a premium  every inch of exhibition space counts. The Hirshhorn Museum has been getting particularly creative of late, successfully activating spaces where no art was ever intended to hang. This spring, Doug Aitkens Song1 transformed the exterior of the Gordon Bunshaft-designed building into a giant, wraparound movie screen. Next up: Belief+Doubt, a site-specific installation by the artist Barbara Kruger. Even as its tucked into the museums lower lobby, the piece, which will be unveiled on Aug. 20 and remain up through 2014, will be impossible to miss: 6,700 square feet of text-printed vinyl in Krugers signature palette of red, white and black will occupy the walls, the escalators, even the floors of this highly trafficked public space, confronting visitors with questions (Who Is Free to Choose? Who Prays Loudest?) and declarations (Plenty Should Be Enough), forcing them to reexamine their faith in the democratic process  or their need to purchase a souvenir in the museums newly renovated bookstore.

title: Shaping a Legacy for the National Gallery
description: Robert Adams, the 75-year-old photographer who has devoted more than four decades to capturing the lush beauty and stark desolation of the American West, has been working with curators at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, selecting 169 prints from his own holdings for the museum to acquire. His choices not only chart his entire career, they also complement the 25 images by him that the gallery already owns.

title: Untying a Birth Mothers Hands
description: HELEN was across the park when we spotted each other and waved. I could tell by the way she buried her head into her sisters shoulder that she was already crying. We were, too.

title: Buried in Details, a Warning to Investors
description: The bank that put together the unusual security did well. The customers who bought it suffered large losses. No one  at least no one who traded the security  seems to have understood the risks that were hidden deep in the prospectus.

title: Archery Draws a Big TV Audience: Could Hunger Games Be the Reason?
description: The London Olympics have generated plenty of news so far, but how about this headline: Archery is the No. 1 sport so far on NBCs cable coverage of the games.

title: Everyday Treasures Gaze Out to Sea
description: The American Folk Art Museum barely avoided extinction last year when it was forced to sell its ill-suited building on West 53rd Street in Manhattan and retreat to its much smaller branch space at 2 Lincoln Square. Now it is modestly spreading it wings and trying to set more of its great collection before the public by collaborating with other institutions.

title: Idea Is the Object
description: DAmelio Gallery

title: Viva la Raspberries
description: Harris Lieberman

title: Inside the Banana
description: Algus Greenspon

title: DAVID KORTY
description: Kimmerich

title: Phelps, Soni and Clary Win Gold
description: Michael Phelps won his 16th gold medal, Tyler Clary won the gold in the 200-meter backstroke and Rebecca Soni won the 200-meter breaststroke with a record time.

title: Court Decides Not to Certify Ouster Vote in Romania
description: PARIS  Romanian voters may have succeeded in ousting their president after all.

title: "Stretch"
description: A new ad from the Obama campaign attacks Mitt Romney's tax plan.

title: Lost to Her Friends, but There All the Time
description: To what extent are even the most exhaustive biographies unsolved detective stories? Such questions swirl like a ghostly mist through Carol Morleys Dreams of a Life, a wildly speculative documentary biography of Joyce Vincent, a British woman of mystery who is remembered posthumously by former acquaintances. Possible scenes of her life are re-enacted in mostly wordless quasi-dream sequences in which Zawe Ashton portrays her as a grown-up, and Alix Luka-Cain plays her as a wistful, wide-eyed child.

title: The Soccer Chronicles: Between Matches, a Hallowed English Stadium
description: Heather OReilly, a midfielder on the United States womens soccer team and a two-time gold medalist, will be writing regularly for the 2012 London Olympics blog. This is her fifth post.

title: Where Is David Pogues iPhone?
description: 4:58 p.m. | Updated  Not to ruin a good tale, but the phone was recovered.On Monday night, I was taking the Amtrak train home from a Nova shoot in Philadelphia  exhausted, but happy to have power and Wi-Fi for my laptop.

title: Love Letter to Pioneers of Avant-Garde Moviemaking
description: With the loss of several admired avant-garde filmmakers in the past few years, Free Radicals: A History of Experimental Film arrives as a welcome paean to the unfettered, resourceful creativity of its subject. Despite the scope of the title, this friendly, colorful documentary from Pip Chodorov is not the last word on all the shapes, sizes and languages of experimental film, but rather an introduction brightened by a companionable enthusiasm and an apposite sense of community.

title: The Basic Question
description: There could have been nothing. It might have been easier. Instead there is something. The universe exists, and we are here to ask about it. Why?

title: Gabby Douglass Balance Beam Dismount
description: The 16-year-old American gymnast won the gold in the individual all-around competition. A former United States coach, Peter Kormann, analyzes her performance.

title: Freewheelin: Bob Dylan, Jonah Lehrer and the Truth
description: Haddonfield, N.J.

title: Romneys Tax Hike
description: The Romney campaigns increasingly desperate attempts to dismiss a new study of its tax plan are a pretty good sign that the study is devastating. That isnt to say the campaign is trying to counter it with actual specifics.

title: Students Urge Teachers to Embrace Digital Tools
High Style on the North Fork
description: The North Fork of Long Island has many attributes  great wines, (relatively) affordable summer rentals and a lovely carousel  but shopping has never been the areas strong suit. Last weeks opening of Eureka Beach on Main Street in Greenport will give the area a much-needed retail boost. The brainchild of the fashion designer Lucy Barnes, the television producer Heidi Kelso and the antiques dealer Fran Lombardi-Reilly, the shop reflects the trios personalities and specialties, with offerings ranging from new and vintage womens clothing and accessories to childrens items and decorative accessories for the home. The opening also marks the debut of the Eureka Beach collection of caftans, tunics and dresses. We created the line because while there are other things out there, they were just too expensive for what youd get, Kelso explains. Ours are cotton, linen and silk pieces that arent too precious and arent too expensive. The line, which ranges from $100 to $350, hangs alongside pieces by Barnes (look for the stretch denim Miracle skirt), jewelry by the North Fork weekender Paige Novick, Chascona bags by the stylist Karan Schijman, Riudavets summery leather slip-ons, childrens clothing by Wovenplay and textiles from Bali, Turkey and Morocco. Prices start at about $15 for a simple bangle and top out at $750 for a Moroccan blanket adorned with paillettes.

title: Beware the Jobs Report of July
description: The American economy almost certainly shed more than a million jobs last month, just as it does every July. But thats not the jobs number that will get most of the attention when the Bureau of Labor Statistics speaks Friday morning.

title: Bravado and Caresses: Girls on the Way to Life
description: Mosquita y Mari, an unassuming indie jewel, resists all of the clichs that its story of the fraught friendship between two 15-year-old girls invites. Yolanda (Fenessa Pineda) and Mari (Venecia Troncoso) are high school classmates and neighbors growing up in Huntington Park, a struggling, predominantly Mexican neighborhood in Los Angeles County.

title: Why the Backlash on Bloombergs Breastfeeding Initiative?
description: Starting in September, hospitals that have signed on to Latch On NYC, the citys new Baby-Friendly Hospital initiative, will work harder to promote breastfeeding, rather than formula, to the citys new mothers.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Egypt, Syria, Indonesia and Sri Lanka.

title: Jets Proximity at Airport in Virginia Sets Off Inquiry
description: Federal regulators said Thursday that they were investigating an episode at Ronald Reagan National Airport near Washington in which three regional jets were allowed to get too close to one another this week.

title: Where Was NBC When the Russian Gymnast Fell?
description: When Russian gymnast Ksenia Afanasyeva fell on her face during her floor exercise in the womens team all-around Tuesday, NBC edited her out of its prime-time broadcast, as if dispatched to a video gulag.

title: Splitting but Not Leaving
description: A wistful romantic comedy about love, marriage and never wanting to say youre sorry, Celeste and Jesse Forever doesnt try to rock the world  just gently nudge it. Set in Los Angeles, it begins as a mildly, self-consciously quirky story about a young married couple, played by an appealingly matched Rashida Jones and Andy Samberg, who have split up without moving on or out. Best friends, Celeste and Jesse share the same adolescent humor, fondness for stupid voices and even property lines: a hard-driving trend forecaster, she lives in their house while hes a laid-back artist who now flops in the backyard studio. You see what keeps them together, even when it shouldnt.

title: Now for Some Real Hurdles
description: Hi, everybody. Bob Costas here at the International Broadcast Center, welcoming you to our sixth night of Olympic coverage on NYCNBC. To those who have been watching our exhaustive, turgid coverage of the London Games on NBC, MSNBC, CNBC, Bravo and any other unclaimed bandwidth we could find, thank you for joining us.

title: Ad Watch: Obama Campaign Seeks to Recast Romney as Tax Raiser
description: 5:40 p.m. | Updated The Obama campaign is wasting no time getting an ad on the air touting a new study showing that Mitt Romneys plans would mean additional large tax cuts for millionaires at the expense of other Americans. The spot, titled Stretch takes a double-barreled approach, beginning by reminding viewers of Mr. Romneys own tax history, before pivoting to an analysis from the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center of the Brookings Institution and the Urban Institute, two centrist Washington-based policy research organizations. The ad will air in eight battleground states.

title: Comedy Listings for Aug. 3-9
description: Comedy

title: Check Out the Gallery in the Freezer
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, N.Y.  In July and August, Chelsea art dealers typically set off to Europe and the Hamptons while leaving their galleries in the hands of the junior staff. Often these are working vacations, with business conducted on the dinner-party circuit. But Jose Martos has gone a step further, establishing a seasonal branch of his Martos Gallery right in his summer residence. For the last three years he has enlisted the independent curator and critic Bob Nickas to organize lively group shows at a rented 1860s farmhouse here.

title: Movie Listings for Aug. 3-9
description: Movies

title: Pop Listings for Aug. 3-9
description: Pop

title: Adam Sternbergh Sold His First Novel!
description: At the 6th Floor we like to track what the magazine staff is reading, watching, listening to, thinking about and, occasionally, creating.

title: Announcing TimesOpen 2012
description: Its that time of the year again! Weve just released our schedule for TimesOpen 2012. As always, well have four events leading up to an all-day hack day in December. Check out the details below and make sure to grab your ticket for this years first event: HTML5, Apps and JavaScript!

title: Exploring The Space With Stillness
description: BECKET, Mass.  Jonah Bokaer is one of the mystery men of American dance. In 2000, when he joined the Merce Cunningham Dance Company in his teens (the youngest performer in its history), he made an immediate impression: both subdued and intense, alert and unfathomable, quietly graceful and utterly focused. Its hard to forget the unnerving way he stood in the opening tableau of Cunninghams Way Station (2001): fixed, like a doll, dark eyes gazing at the audience with no apparent blink. In movement, his gifts of control and changing dynamics were riveting.

title: Books Analyzing Images of Slaves in History
description: Artists before the Civil War took personal risks when portraying slaves. Southerners did not want their more abusive practices to be professionally documented.

title: Character Counts, Bathtub Essential
description: THREE years ago, after graduating from Georgetown University and working in politics, Kimmie Lipscomb moved to New York for a job.

title: Simplifying Loan Documents
description: THE Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, the federal agency created by Congress after the financial crisis, says mortgage documents should be written in simple, straightforward language, and so after months of researching and testing, it is proposing that lenders provide borrowers with two new forms. One will come at the start of the lending process, the other just before closing.

title: Fortunes Thin Thread, Catching, Not Releasing
description: A butterfly flapping its wings in Chile is a familiar culprit for all kinds of global havoc, like tornadoes in Texas. In the film 360, though, its a woman taking her top off in Vienna who sets off a British mans crisis of conscience, instigates a conjugal dispute in Paris, and obliquely stirs up funny business in Denver and some murderous business elsewhere. Here the world isnt just small, its also a 360-degree metaphor that begins with a womans breasts, leads to the boulevard circling Viennas center and ends with the O of your slack-jawed incredulity.

title: Proving the Reality TV Rule That Nothing Succeeds Like Failure
description: Each episode of Showtimes baseball documentary series, The Franchise, begins with bravado  a chorus of voices from the front office of the Miami Marlins declaring: Ill put this club up against anybodys, When we wear this uniform we are family, and We are now ready to win.

title: Mapping Future Growth
description: AFTER years of confusion, disputes and rule changes, New Jerseys 21 counties surprised many last month by meeting a deadline to produce updated sewer service maps  not only locating infrastructure already in place but also detailing where new infrastructure should go. The maps are expected to guide statewide development well into the future.

title: Shes a Vigilante, and a Belly Dancer
description: For the thickheaded thriller Assassins Bullet the Bulgarian actress Elika Portnoy dreamed up a story with three roles for herself and fails to convince in any of them. Limiting her thespian efforts to wig and wardrobe changes  and adding or subtracting eyeliner  Ms. Portnoy embodies a hackneyed plot device unlikely to fool the average toddler.

title: Pile of Bills Is Left Behind as Congress Goes to Campaign
description: WASHINGTON  An effort to provide emergency aid for American ranchers and farmers reeling from a year of drought, frost and other calamities collapsed on Thursday as members of Congress departed for their five-week August recess, leaving behind a pile of unfinished legislation as they go home to campaign for re-election.

title: Better Than a Backyard
description: FOR some homeowners, the hardest part of downsizing is giving up the backyard. But those contemplating a move to the Maestro, a 94-unit ultraluxury rental building in Great Neck that starts leasing later this month for September occupancy, dont have to fret.

title: Relief for Distressed Borrowers
description: ROBERT PHILLIPS lost his job in publishing eight years ago, and ever since, he and his wife, Kristine, a paralegal, have struggled to keep up with the mortgage payments on their home in Stratford. Mr. Phillips tried finding contract work, and has since switched to teaching, but he cant find a job that matches his previous salary.

title: Those Slings and Arrows of Adolescence Sting
description: Studios generally dont like to see the word excruciating in a movie review. But the makers of Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days wont mind seeing it here, because thats just what this good-natured if not very ambitious family film is going for.

title: Draft vs. Baby Bottle: The Beer Garden Debate
description: Narcissistic parents who let their can-do-no-wrong offspring run rampant in bars. Children-hating philistines who cannot wrap their heads around the time-honored European institution of a child-friendly beer garden. Horrendous role models. Pandering bar owners. Crybaby hipsters. Moms and dads who refuse to grow up. Filthy, smelly children.

title: Three Friends Approaches to Martial Law
description: Girlfriend Boyfriend, the vivid second feature from the Taiwanese filmmaker Ya-Che Yang, views his countrys tumultuous political history through the maturing eyes of three childhood friends.

title: Classical Music and Opera Listings for Aug. 3-9
description: Classical

title: Jazz Listings for Aug. 3-9
description: Jazz

title: One Item on the World Menu Has Its Critics
description: You can get sushi at football games in Texas and in Lodz, Poland. In China, Russia and Brazil, diners have developed a taste for it too. One estimate cited in Mark Halls documentary Sushi: The Global Catch has China adding 50 million sushi eaters in the next few years. That may be good news for sushi as an international cuisine, but its bad news for some fish.

title: As the Wars Ebb, Considering Security at Home
description: On At War, we mostly deal with military engagements aboard, rather than national security issues on the home front. But we want to point out a piece by At War contributor Scott Shane (@ScottShaneNYT) on The Agenda. Mr. Shane writes today about the trade-offs between security and civil liberties going into the presidential campaign. The fallout from 9/11 saw a monumental shift both in the way the government approached counterterrorism domestically, and how it executed it internationally through Iraq and Afghanistan. But the United States has, mostly, withdrawn from Iraq. And the exit from Afghanistan, though its speed will surely be an issue of debate in the campaign, is no doubt hastening.

description: Sea Bright is a slice of small-town America that residents describe as low-key and family-oriented.

title: A YouTube Introduction to U.S. Colleges, by Just Clicking Play
description: Its a rite of passage every year  students from across the world power up their computers and begin to research the colleges of their dreams. With thousands of prospective students starting to think about preparing their applications, colleges and universities in the United States are realizing that, while simple Web sites and information packets worked well enough in the past, the new generation needs new ways of access.

title: In Senate Primary, Republican Leaders Take a Back Seat
description: By Tuesdays runoff, the Republican primary battle between Ted Cruz, the former Texas solicitor general, and Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst had grown larger than a fight for an open United States Senate seat.

title: No Charges in Death at Yonkers Center for Youths
description: No criminal charges are warranted in the death of Corey Foster, a 16-year-old boy who went into cardiac arrest while being physically restrained at a residential treatment center in Yonkers, the Westchester County district attorney concluded Thursday after a three-month investigation.

title: A Brooklyn Hospital, Low on Cash, Says It May Need a State Bailout
description: A small community hospital in Brooklyn is running out of cash and fears it will not be able to make its payroll or pay its vendors by September without a state bailout, the hospitals administrators said this week.

title: Pennsylvanians Are Split on Penn State Penalties
description: Pennsylvanians are divided over the penalties imposed last month by the N.C.A.A. on Penn State for its handling of the Jerry Sandusky sexual abuse scandal, with more than 4 in 10 saying the punishment was too severe, and about a third deeming it appropriate.

title: Q & A
description: E-mail Exchanges and a Rent Increase

title: On Political Disagreement
description: Many proponents of the Affordable Care Act think theres an overwhelming case for a government-supported expansion of medical coverage; opponents just as often think theres an overwhelming case against. Many people may think its a complicated issue on which those knowledgeable and reasonable may disagree. But we dont often hear from them in public debates. The typical op-ed column or letter to the editor implies that anyone competent to judge the issue should agree with its view.

title: Camps Focus Is on Fighting Abortion
description: BRYAN  In a lofted lodge at Messiahs Ranch, a Christian retreat a few miles outside town, about 20 teenagers sat cross-legged in a circle, talking about what it means to be a good listener.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Bill Clinton Stepping In to Assist in Obama Fund-Raising
description: Former president Bill Clinton will headline a New York City event for Priorities USA Action, the super PAC founded by former aides to President Obama, in August, a person with knowledge of the plans said on Thursday.

title: Shame and Indignation in China as Its Olympians Come Under Fire
description: BEIJING  Even as it revels in a mounting heap of gold medals at the London Games, China has been troubled by a maelstrom of emotions: pride in its athletes achievements mixed with shame and disappointment that a pair of badminton players were disqualified for blatantly throwing a game, and indignation over what many here say are unfounded accusations that a record-breaking swimmer may have been fueled by performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Japan Widens Inquiry Into Insider Trading
description: TOKYO  A government investigation into insider trading in Japan has extended onto the trading floors of some of the largest Wall Street companies, including Goldman Sachs, UBS and Deutsche Bank.

description: On Thursday around 4 p.m., my Twitter feed lighted up with people either promoting or critiquing a new national poll from Pew Research that gave President Obama a lead of 10 percentage points, 51 percent to 41 percent, over Mitt Romney.

title: Greatest Olympian of All Time?
description: He might own the record for most Olympic medals, but Michael Phelps is not the greatest Olympian ever, says William C. Rhoden.

title: Suddenly, the Mets Dont Look So Bad
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Mets on Thursday produced a rare convincing victory, beating the San Francisco Giants, 9-1, at AT&T Park.

title: Russia Pulls the Plug on Drunken Paratroopers Swimming Pool of Choice
description: MOSCOW  City governments across Russia drained the water from municipal fountains on Thursday, hoping to keep drunken paratroopers from drowning in them.
