description: JOEL K. GOLDSTEIN, a law professor at St. Louis University, is a leading authority on the United States vice presidency. People seem to respect him anyway.

title: Long Island Man Faked His Own Death, Wife Says
description: The tangled case of the Long Island man who was feared drowned last weekend in the waters off Jones Beach  but who turned up speeding down the highway in South Carolina five days later  took a new twist on Friday, when his wife said he had staged it all without her knowledge.

title: Competitive Armchair Olympics: Modern Triathlon
description: Move your mouse over the image to progress.

title: The Fabric of a Champion
description: When Missy Franklin stood on the winners podium on Monday to receive her gold medal in the 100-meter backstroke in the London Olympics, the folks at Material Connexion, a materials resource company, couldnt take their eyes off her. Sure, they marveled at the 17-year-olds achievements in the water, but what really seized their attention was her hyper-reflective Nike jacket.

title: Chic in Review | Beyonc on Beyonc
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Olympic Racewalking Is More Than Just a Stroll
description: LONDON  Eider Arevalo is just 19, but he lives in a comfortable apartment in Bogot, Colombia. With a monthly income of about $2,500, he earns about twice as much as his father, a construction worker in Pitalito, 233 miles to the south. Arevalos ticket to a better life has been racewalking.

title: With a Unibody Design, the 2013 Nissan Pathfinder Strikes a Sleeker Pose
description: Amid the crunching of nacho chips and the clicking of high heels navigating cobblestone streets, Nissan unveiled the 2013 Pathfinder in Lower Manhattan on Thursday.

title: Hacker Posts False Syria Information on Reuters Blog
description: Reuters News temporarily suspended its opinion blog on Friday after an anonymous hacker broke in and wrote false information about Syria.

title: The Last Days of Honey Space
description: The makeshift gallery and workspace in a Chelsea warehouse is closing after more than four rent-free years.

title: A Gallery Atypical to Its End
description: How long can an art gallery that has no regular hours, no staff, no windows, no air-conditioning and  perhaps more relevant to the question at hand  pays no rent remain open in the heart of Chelsea, one block from behemoths like the Pace Gallery and Gagosian?

title: S.E.C. Gets Encouragement From Jury That Ruled Against It
description: As Beau Brendler sat in the jury box listening to the governments case against a former Citigroup midlevel executive, the same question kept entering his mind.

title: Aug. 3: A Good Week for Obama in Forecast
description: The past week of polling and economic data was relatively newsworthy by our forecast models standards, and most of the news was good for President Obama.

title: Matti Friedman on the Unsolved Mystery of the Aleppo Codex
description: Ronen Bergmans article in our July 25 issue on the Aleppo Codex was occasioned and informed by the recent publication of The Aleppo Codex: A True Story of Obsession, Faith and the Pursuit of an Ancient Bible, by the Israeli-Canadian journalist Matti Friedman. Several readers responded to the article with questions and theories about the whereabouts of the missing pages and the motivations of the various sources quoted. For his book, Friedman spent four years investigating the story of the codex, which he talked about in a brief Q. and A. conducted this week.

title: Far From the Surf, Fruits of the Sea
description: A SUMMER evening may be the ideal time to get acquainted with Fin Raw Bar and Kitchen, which opened in October in downtown Montclair. Withits vivacious crowds, bustling open kitchen and artful lobster-shack dcor, its as welcoming as a neighborhood beach joint at the end of a sweltering day.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Magic Arms and Never Starting Cable TV
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. See more here.

title: In Reids Taunting of Romney, Taxes Are Just a New Opening
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Harry Reids decision this week to hurl a taunting, unsubstantiated accusation at Mitt Romney is hardly out of character for the cantankerous Democratic leader of the Senate, who revels in provocative comments and once called Mr. Romney kind of a joke.

title: Another Threat in Pakistan, in Sheeps Clothing
description: Washington

title: Kelly Criticizes Law Dept. for Not Defending Commander
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly criticized the citys Law Department on Friday for its decision not to defend a police commander who is being sued in federal court for using pepper spray on Occupy Wall Street protesters last year.

title: Microsoft Drops Metro Name for New Product Look
description: Over the last 12 to 18 months, one buzzword at Microsoft has come to encapsulate a bold redesign of the look of its most high-profile products: Metro. First used to describe the new tile- and typography-heavy user interface for Windows Phone, its smartphone operating system, the Metro look has popped up on the Xbox, Windows 8 and even in the layout of PowerPoint slides used by Microsoft executives.

title: Afghan Strike Shows Force and Restraint of Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban made a show of force across a province of northeastern Afghanistan on Friday, Afghan officials said, attacking dozens of government installations but causing relatively few deaths or injuries.

title: Two Solitary Souls, Adrift Far From Home
description: Loneliness can make time seem to slow to a dead crawl. The most mundane tasks  the morning shave, or hanging up your hat and coat in a cafe  become drawn-out rituals that fill out the hours lying heavy in your hands. This quality of time being stretched endlessly is vividly evoked in In Paris, a stage adaptation of a short story by the Nobel Prize-winning writer Ivan Bunin that stars Mikhail Baryshnikov as a former general in the White Russian Army, living a life of quiet exile in the city of the title.

title: Week in Pictures for Aug. 3
A Nautical Setting for Seafood and Steak
description: THIS time of year, the Nautical Mile in Freeport is a magnet for Long Islanders hungry for seafood accompanied by water views. A seven-block stretch of Woodcleft Avenue adjacent to the Woodcleft Canal is chockablock with fish restaurants, marine-supply stores, boat-rental places and docks for charter boats.

title: Cullen Joness Olympic Splash
description: Cullen Jones, who was profiled by Elizabeth Weil in the magazine last year, won a silver medal today in the mens 50-meter freestyle at the London Olympic Games. Weil wrote:

title: So These Comics Drive to a Diner and Drink Coffee
description: Leave it to Ricky Gervais to get to the essential truth, even in someone elses Web series. Youre like a young king, arent you? he says, sitting across a table from Jerry Seinfeld in Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee. If Mr. Seinfeld wants to drive around in cool old cars with some friends hes seen on the telly, well, all he has to do is pick up the phone. Hes Jerry Seinfeld, for Gods sake.

title: Competitive Armchair Olympics: Self-Defeating Badminton
description: Score: 0

title: World Youth Teams Championships in China
description: TAICANG, China  In the 56-board semifinals at the 14th World Youth Teams Championships here on Thursday, there was one very exciting match for American fans. In the Youngsters (under-21) division, USA-1 (Zachary Brescoll, Adam Kaplan, the brothers Adam and Zachary Grossack, and the brothers Andrew and Richard Jeng) were playing against Israel. With 14 boards remaining, Israel led by 30 international match points. This lead rose to 42 on the first board of the last session. But then USA-1 won the remaining deals by 74 imps to 0, to win by 32.

title: Olympic Swimming Replay, Aug. 3
description: Doug Mills of The New York Times provides a broad look at the days competition in the London Aquatics Centre.

title: Cycling and Antidoping Groups Clash on Armstrong
description: The worlds governing body of cycling recently asked the United States Anti-Doping Agency to back away from its doping case against Lance Armstrong, according to documents filed Friday in federal court.

title: Dock Your Boat and Dig Right In
description: FOR a summertime meal with a Caribbean vibe, its hard to do better than the Blue Oar, on the banks of the Connecticut River. Customers pull up in cars or dock their boats at the adjacent Midway Marina, then dig into sandwiches, hot dogs, burgers and more formal entrees at outdoor picnic tables painted in tropical hues. Some dishes seem a bit pricey, but the cash-only restaurants B.Y.O.B. policy keeps the bill reasonable. And the view is spectacular.

title: C.D.C. Reports Outbreak of Swine Flu
description: Federal health officials reported a new outbreak of swine flu on Friday, mostly among children who appeared to have picked up the virus at county fairs. Sixteen people have become infected with the H3N2 swine flu virus over the past three weeks, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said. There were 12 cases in 2011. The new flu has a gene from the 2009 pandemic strain that officials are monitoring because it could make the illness more contagious. So far it has only been picked up from pigs and has not been passed from person to person, said Joseph Bresee, a doctor in the influenza division at the agency.

title: For Martin, Hall Is Latest Stop in a Still Unfolding Career
description: Curtis Martin will not realize a childhood dream when he is inducted Saturday into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio.

title: For Rebel Fight in Syrian City, Baking Bread Is Urgent Task
description: ALEPPO, Syria  Just before sunrise, a select group of Syrian rebel fighters steps away from the front lines here for a task their commanders now consider a vital and urgent part of the war effort: baking bread.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,053 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: A Medal in the Shot-Put, but Not the Right Color
description: LONDON  Most first-time Olympic medalists would be happy with any medal. But after the year Reese Hoffa has had, taking the bronze in the final of the mens shot-put felt like a bit of a letdown.

title: Reading the Fake Reuters Reports on Syria
description: Updated | Saturday, 12:34 p.m. As my colleague Christine Haughney reports on Media Decoder, Reuters temporarily suspended the operation of its blogging platform on Friday after the news agency said its Web site was hacked and false reports of setbacks for Syrian rebels were posted online.

title: Occupation, Not Culture, Is Holding Palestinians Back
description: Nablus, West Bank

title: Beach Essentials in China: Flip-Flops, a Towel and a Ski Mask
description: QINGDAO, China  It was enough to make a trio of heavily tattooed young men stop their playful splashing and to prompt a small boy to run to his mother in alarm: a woman rising out of the choppy waves of the sea, her head wrapped in a neon-orange ski mask.

title: A Summer Crop of Mobile Cuisine
description: The food truck trend has been slow to take off in Westchester. Were a car culture, and most food trucks rely on foot traffic. This summer, though, a few mobile entrepreneurs have set their parking brakes in strategic spots around Westchester County and are dishing out some very fine food.

title: Saudis Greet Olympic First With a Shrug
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia

title: Through the Lens, a Passion in Full Bloom
description: BAYONNE, N.J.

title: Nonprofit Group to Aid Horace Mann Alumni Who Say They Were Victims of Abuse
description: A group affiliated with the leadership of the Horace Mann School is forming a nonprofit organization to help alumni who say they were victims of sexual abuse by teachers, a school board member said on Friday.

title: Karl Benjamin, Rebel of Midcentury Art Scene, Dies at 86
description: Karl Benjamin, a painter who came to art almost by accident and then rose to prominence in the 1950s as part of a West Coast artists rebellion against the reign of Abstract Expressionism, died on July 26 at his home in Claremont, Calif. He was 86.

title: The Adolescence of a Suburban Region
description: A COZY living room with a shag rug, an Eames bent-wire chair, a boomerang-shaped coffee table and a picture window that cleverly doubles as a film screen greets the visitor to Long Island, Americas 1950s Frontier, an exhibition at the Long Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages in Stony Brook. Pop songs of the 50s like Blue Suede Shoes and Mr. Sandman drift in from another display area, where a gaudy Wurlitzer jukebox sits amid teenagers memorabilia. On the picture-window screen, glimpses of Levittown from a 1952 newsreel flicker by.

title: Break in 95 Murder Case Shows Reverberations of Using a Cooperating Witness
description: When Gilbert Vega, once a member of a Bronx narcotics gang called Sex Money and Murder, agreed to cooperate with the government against his former gang a decade ago, he met regularly with prosecutors to tell them what he knew.

title: U.S. Begins Packing Its Afghan War Gear for the Movers
description: CAMP LEATHERNECK, Afghanistan  It has taken the United States years to amass the mountains of gear piled up at huge bases like Camp Leatherneck in southern Afghanistan. It is the job of logistics experts like First Lt. Rachel Opperman, 23, to bring it all back home.

title: Trading Program Ran Amok, With No Off Switch
description: When computerized stock trading runs amok, as it did this week on Wall Street, the firm responsible typically can jump in and hit a kill switch.

title: Pakistan: Contempt Law Rejected
description: The Supreme Court on Friday struck down a controversial law that the governing party had hoped would help fend off contempt charges against Prime Minister Raja Pervez Ashraf. Chief Justice Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry called the law, which provided greater protection to the prime minister and other senior government officials against such charges, unconstitutional and contrary to the independence of the judiciary. In June, the court ousted Yousaf Raza Gilani, then the prime minister, after he refused to support the reopening of a corruption investigation against President Asif Ali Zardari in Switzerland. The law struck down on Friday was introduced by the Pakistan Peoples Party in July to shield Mr. Gilanis successor, Mr. Ashraf, from a similar fate. The court gave Mr. Ashraf until Wednesday to ask Swiss authorities to reopen the case against Mr. Zardari. He has given no indication that he plans to do so.

title: Amid Inquiry Into Cheating, Stuyvesant Principal Will Retire
description: The principal of Stuyvesant High School abruptly announced his retirement on Friday afternoon, even as New York City continued its investigation into a cheating scandal that recently rocked the elite institution.

title: China: Muslim Fasting Discouraged
description: Several local governments in the western region of Xinjiang have ordered Muslim restaurants to stay open during the holy month of Ramadan and are telling civil servants and students to continue to eat and drink during daylight hours, when Muslims generally fast. Ramadan began on July 20. A notice on the Web site of the health bureau of Urumqi, the regional capital, said local officials had discussed increasing eating and drinking during Ramadan and were urged to increase the monitoring of collective eating with supplied food at work units. The goal was to guarantee the health of the masses, the posting said. Local governments have been putting in place such policies for several years. Southern Xinjiang and Urumqi have a large number of Uighurs, Muslims who often express discontent with ethnic Han, who dominate China.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Apple took Samsung to court in a patent case with broad implications for technology innovations, and a brokerage firms costly software malfunction cast further doubt on high-frequency trading.

title: Comedy Pain and Comedy Pleasure
description: I guess this could be called Part 2 of an earlier column, which was inspired by readers asking me to talk about comics and comedy writing. So heres more.

title: Ethiopian Delivers Punishing Kick in 10,000-Meter Race
description: LONDON  The fierce Kenyan-Ethiopian rivalry renewed itself Friday, and the result in the womens Olympic 10,000 meters was as reliably predictable as it was four years ago: Ethiopias Tirunesh Dibaba again drew away with a punishing kick to win the gold medal and perhaps establish herself as historys greatest female distance runner.

title: Day 1 for Track and Field
description: The womens 400-meter run and heptathlon were among the events held at Olympic Stadium.

title: A Deeper Look at Faster, Higher, Stronger
description: GREENWICH, Conn.

title: Powerful Shaper of U.S. Rules Quits, With Critics in Wake
description: WASHINGTON  Cass R. Sunstein, who wielded enormous power as the White House overseer of federal regulation, came to Washington to test his theories of human behavior and economic efficiency in the laboratory of the federal government. Now he is departing with a record that left many business interests disappointed and environmental, health and consumer advocates even more unhappy.

title: Spain: Terror Suspects Face Judge
description: Investigators on Friday continued to search for more explosives and other weapons possibly hidden by three men arrested this week and accused of having links to Al Qaeda and planning terrorist attacks. The suspects, Mohammed Adamov and Ahmad Avar, Russians of Chechen descent, and Cengiz Yalcin, a Turk, denied having any connection to Al Qaeda, said a person close to the investigation. A judge on Friday charged Mr. Yalcin with possession of explosives and ordered the other two detained for 48 hours for further investigation. Mr. Yalcin denied any knowledge of the explosives found in his home, said the newspaper El Pas.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Schoolboys With Talent

title: Young Immigrants Can File to Defer Deportation Aug. 15
description: Obama administration officials said Friday that they would begin on Aug. 15 to process applications from hundreds of thousands of young illegal immigrants expected to seek two-year deferrals of deportation. Applicants will be charged $465 for each request.

title: A Killing Shakes a 12-Story Community
description: The Narragansett Hotel, despite not being located in Narragansett, R.I., and not being a hotel, has proudly kept the name on the awning, outside a stately 12-story Broadway building that looks as good from the sidewalk as it did a century ago, when handsomely furnished suites cost $2 to $6 and were advertised as especially suited for ladies traveling alone.

title: Paul W. McCracken, Adviser to Presidents, Dies at 96
description: Paul W. McCracken, a moderate Republican who served as an economic adviser to both Republican and Democratic presidents and who led President Richard M. Nixons largely unsuccessful effort to tame the rising inflation of the late 1960s and early 1970s, died on Friday in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 96.

title: Panama: President Ends Blockade at Newspaper
description: It took the intervention of President Ricardo Martinelli and a chief of the national police to end a blockade of the newspaper La Prensa on Friday by scores of workers from one of Panamas largest construction companies. The workers from the Transcaribe Trading Company used 30 trucks to surround the offices of the newspaper, which has published investigative articles about the company, reporting that it had received millions of dollars in favorable government contracts. La Prensa has a long history of reporting on corruption and has clashed with the president, although his office released a statement condemning the workers action. A representative of the company did not respond to a request for comment, but its Web site includes videos of workers denouncing La Prensa. Lourdes de Obalda, the editor of the newspaper, said the protest did not prevent the publication of the newspaper, but she called the blockade, which lasted several hours, part of a rising number of actions aimed at intimidating the news media in Panama.

title: Tricks to Finding Food and to Paying for It
description: Where to eat? It is a basic question of life in New York, and one that app developers have attempted to answer in various ways. Apps fall into a few categories: those that try to show you all the information that is out there (Yelp or Urbanspoon), those that rely on the wisdom of selected experts (Immaculate Infatuation or Chefs Feed) or apps that pick a small corner of the food world and focus on that (Tweat.it for food trucks).

title: You Cant Shake the Knicks Out of an Utterly Mad Fan Like Spike Lee
description: So the question hangs there, big as a basketball.

title: Democrats Embrace Once Pejorative Obamacare Tag
description: LEESBURG, Va.  As thousands of people gathered on a sweltering night outside a local high school draped with flags and bunting, the speaker talked about the presidents controversial health program. Thats why he passed Obamacare! she declared.

title: The Battle of Baton Rouge
description: While New Orleans suffered under the rule of Gen. Benjamin Beast Butler in August 1862, it avoided the anguish of actual fighting. Not so its upriver neighbor, Baton Rouge.

title: Bond Traders in Europe Deal in High Expectations, and Fear
description: LONDON  James Konrad, a bookish 27-year-old with a polite manner, used to make a living at a sports betting company, weighing the odds of muddy terrain affecting the sure-footedness of racehorses. These days, he takes bets on the muddy terrain that is European politics.

title: Court Weighs an Order on Nuclear Waste Site in Nevada
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court indicated Friday that it would issue an order for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to resume an evaluation of a possible nuclear waste repository at Yucca Mountain, a volcanic ridge in the Nevada desert, unless Congress acted by December to resolve the legal tangle around the project.

title: Dick Cavett and Jack Benny
description: Jack Benny visits "The Dick Cavett Show."

title: The Closer Is Back
description: SAN DIEGO  The Mets on Friday welcomed Frank Francisco back to the roster, hoping the closer would stabilize their uneven bullpen.

title: Gay Couples Head to Chick-fil-A for Kiss-In Protest
description: Two days after hundreds of thousands of people packed Chick-fil-A restaurants to demonstrate their support for the fast-food chains position against gay rights, supporters of same-sex marriage staged what they called a kiss-in on Friday at locations across the country.

title: Landmark for Many Is Opportunity for University
description: CHICAGO  At night, the floating cylinders of the former Prentice Womens Hospital sit dark, abandoned among the citys glowing towers.

title: Afghan Officials Cite Revenge Killings in Latest Outbreak of Ethnic Hatred
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  At least nine Afghans and perhaps many more were forced out of their homes in rural Afghanistan and executed in what Afghan officials called an act of revenge by one ethnic group against another, underscoring the long shadow cast by the countrys ethnic hatreds.

title: Company Finds Grey and Pink Yield Pure Green
description: CINCINNATI  It was hard to miss them downtown, the women who came here from across the country to attend a training convention for a company called Pure Romance. They filled the lobbies of several high-rise hotels on Thursday and Friday, with their bright rollie suitcases, their Pure Romance tote bags, and a uniform of pink feather flowers in their hair.

title: Man Arrested in Brooklyn Shooting That Injured 6
description: The police on Friday announced the arrest of a suspect in a shooting on Sunday in Brooklyn that left six people injured, including a 2-year-old girl.

title: Putting Genetics to Work to Find Missing Children
description: GRANADA, Spain

title: Face of Marlboro Prefers to Be Alone
description: IN the 1950s William Thourlby squinted at America from billboards and invited smokers to Marlboro Country.

description: To the Editor:

title: Taking Steps to Prevent Medical Errors
description: To the Editor:

title: Afghan Ministers Assets
description: To the Editor:

title: Cooling Power Plants
description: To the Editor:

title: After Councils Deadlock, Syria Is Criticized at U.N.
description: The United Nations General Assembly voted overwhelmingly on Friday for an Arab-backed resolution that severely criticized the Syrian government, blaming it almost exclusively for the killings and other atrocities that have come to shape the 17-month-old uprising there.

title: Palestinian Candor, or a Slip?
description: To the Editor:

title: Thing to Charge With
description: Administrivial Wheres Deb? Alert: By the time you read this, I will be well on my way to visiting The Girl at camp, with all of the Look what I made/Meet my new best friend/The cast comes off next week wonderment that goes along with that. Wordplay will be here as usual, but I will have very little access to the internet, so have a lovely weekend, and happy solving.

title: Military Hazing Has Got to Stop
description: Los Angeles

title: The Curious Case of Chavis Carter
description: Let me get this straight: A young man is stopped by police, who find $10 worth of drugs on him; he had twice been searched by officers and then double handcuffed behind his back and placed in the back of a police car; yet, somehow, he retrieves a gun that both searches failed to find and uses it shoot himself in the right temple?

title: Congress Goes Postal
description: Congress is gone. Yeah, I miss them, too.

title: Frankenstein Takes Over the Market
description: This week, yet another Wall Street firm most people have never heard of, relying on a computerized trading program that they cant possibly understand, shook investors faith in the market. This is happening a little too frequently, dont you think?

title: The House Reprimands One of Its Own
description: At the very least, Representative Laura Richardson could have shown a bit of remorse when the House voted this week to reprimand her for requiring that her staff aides give donations and work for her re-election campaign and for destroying evidence when the Ethics Committee sought the truth.

title: Closer Scrutiny of For-Profit Schools
description: The last several weeks have not been particularly restful for the lucrative for-profit education industry.

title: Mentally Retarded and on Death Row
description: Marvin Wilson, with an I.Q. of 61, is scheduled to be put to death in Texas on Tuesday. His execution would directly contradict the Supreme Courts 2002 ruling in Atkins v. Virginia that the mentally retarded should be categorically excluded from execution because of their disabilities in areas of reasoning, judgment and control of their impulses. The court should accept Mr. Wilsons case for review and end Texass illegal defiance of its explicit holding that the death penalty for the mentally retarded is unconstitutional.

title: Unruly Proceedings in Trial of Russian Punk Group
description: MOSCOW  A day after President Vladimir V. Putin appeared to urge leniency in the trial of three young women who staged a punk prayer in Moscows main church, the prosecution rested its case after showing the judge the dark blue balaclavas that the band members wore during demonstrations.

title: Stuck in Place
description: With 163,000 new jobs created, Julys employment growth topped both analysts expectations and the meager job gains in May and June. While that growth was not enough to reduce the jobless rate  now 8.3 percent  it was enough to boost the stock market. For investors, the job tally was just high enough to be a pleasant surprise and low enough to give them hope that the Federal Reserve would soon intervene to juice the economy.

title: Lottery Numbers
Tribe Revives Language on Verge of Extinction
description: SILETZ, Ore.  Local native languages teeter on the brink of oblivion all over the world as the big linguistic sweepstakes winners like English, Spanish or Mandarin ride a surging wave of global communications.

title: Navigating Olympic Park
description: The Olympic park is as elusive as it is impressive, as chaotic as it is thrilling, and as challenging to navigate as the people who work in it are friendly.

title: A Buoyant Bedlam at the Olympic Park
description: LONDON  How could anyone passing through the St. Pancras International train station in central London fail to locate the new superfast train that hurtles passengers to the Olympic park in a mere seven minutes? Part of a mass signpost refit before the Olympics, the station is full of jaunty pink Javelin Train to  signs.

title: College Town Built on Football Fears Fallout From a Scandal
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  In the scattered towns of central Pennsylvania, Penn State football is as much an industry as a devotion, fueled by the hundreds of thousands of fans who converge here on fall weekends and spend on hotels, meals, drinks and a mind-boggling array of Nittany Lions memorabilia.

title: Where South Beach Meets Inwood
description: A misty, not-quite-full moon hung over the railroad tracks on Tuesday and peered quizzically onto an expansive new waterfront spot in Upper Manhattan, featuring candlelit cocktail tables, twinkling lights, a beach bar with beds and a covered 200-seat restaurant. La Marina in Inwood, open for a month, seems to be trying for a Miami-on-the-Hudson vibe, but its still closer to the South Bronx than South Beach. The incongruity of such a sprawling paradise at the end of Dyckman Street, several blocks from the A train, past broken glass and bingo players, never quite disappears. On weekends, the deck and beach bars are jammed, but this weeknight, the atmosphere was just comfortably buzzing. Patrons smoked hookah pipes in the patio lounge while a modest band played. Diners watched the sun set behind the Palisades, summoning still-learning wait staff. Firefighters, police officers, bankers, romantics, families and old friends converged for the scene and the company. Jet Skis whined on the river, kayakers glided in the moonlight and the George Washington Bridge burst into crystals of light, making the spectacular setting worth the trip.

title: Teixeira Returns to the Yankees Lineup
description: Mark Teixeira returned to the Yankees lineup Friday, playing first base and batting cleanup three days after a magnetic resonance imaging test on his left wrist revealed only inflammation.

title: Sabathias Strong Start Relieves Yankees
description: It certainly felt like August at Yankee Stadium on Friday night, the air choked with heat, stagnant and thick. Fans cooled their faces by waving programs. C. C. Sabathia tugged at his damp, baggy jersey.

title: Olympic Bid, Though Unsuccessful, Helped the City, Its Champion Says
description: The senior Bloomberg aide who tried unsuccessfully to bring the 2012 Olympics to New York seems to hold no hard feelings against London.

title: Moving, on an Epic Scale
description: With a massive amount of gear at bases in Afghanistan, the United States is undertaking a large logistics effort to transport military equipment home as the war winds down.

title: They Win Gold, but a Pot of It Rarely Follows
description: LONDON  Vincent Hancock won gold in skeet shooting here this week, missing just 2 of 150 targets in the competition. It was an extraordinary performance and unprecedented, too. Hancock prevailed in the same event in Beijing in 2008, making him the first skeet shooter to successfully defend his Olympic title.

title: Peace, Quiet and a Frozen Dessert
description: Katrina vanden Heuvel, editor and publisher of The Nation magazine, spends Sundays trying to take a break from the demands of her job. Ms. vanden Heuvel, 52, lives on the Upper West Side with her husband, Stephen Cohen, 73, a professor emeritus of Russian studies at N.Y.U. and Princeton University; their daughter, Nicola, 21, who is known as Nika, is entering her senior year at Princeton.

title: Reviewing the McLaren MP4-12C
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Ezra Dyer reviews the 2012 McLaren MP4-12C, a supercar that he says expresses a particular point of view, with McLarens engineering-driven perfectionism represented in its every nut and bolt.

title: A New View of Old Society
description: In New York hotels, formal balls give socialites the chance to dust off their tiaras. One photographer captures the scene.

title: A Spanish Hat Factory Thrives on Orders From a Finicky Brooklyn
description: SEVILLE, Spain  Since its founding 127 years ago, the Fernndez y Roche factory on the edge of this Andalusian capital has weathered every crisis known to hatters.

title: The Brotherhood
description: Welcome to Fortress Astoria, the home of Danny, Shy, Luke and Rick. Theyre all unmarried and approaching 40, and theyve been roommates for the last 18 years.

title: Mihaela Ursuleasa, Classical Pianist, Dies at 33
description: Mihaela Ursuleasa, a Romanian-born pianist renowned for her prodigious technique and often idiosyncratic interpretations, was found dead on Thursday at her home in Vienna. She was 33.

title: A Confederacy of Bachelors
description: WHAT if you had never settled down? Never taken that job for the health insurance, or decided to start a family? For New Yorkers of a certain age, those are the middle-of-the night questions, the nagging thoughts that occur as they squeeze themselves onto the packed No. 1 train for another day at the office, ignoring that unfinished screenplay or latent desire to chuck everything and live in an ashram.

title: Gene Smith Dies at 83; Wrote Biographies of World Leaders
description: Gene Smith, who with a vivid touch depicted the lives of presidents, prime ministers and generals in a series of popular biographies, among them the 1964 best seller When the Cheering Stopped: The Last Years of Woodrow Wilson, died on July 25 at his home in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 83.

title: A Staten Island Home, Once Brimming With Life
description: In a house that used to be occupied by Frederick Law Olmsted, one of the designers of Central Park, the rooms are dim, water-stained wallpaper curls and dust fills the air.

title: A Lab, a Home, a Memory
description: LIKE the rest of her family, Carlotta DeFillo prefers to live in the past.

title: For a Spicier City, Turn the Page?
description: If two books, strikingly similar in manner and published within a few weeks of each other can be said to suggest a trend, then the arrival of Motherland, a story of midlife shenanigans in Park Slope, Brooklyn, and Triburbia, a story of midlife shenanigans south of Canal Street in Manhattan, signals the emergence of a new strain of pop domestic fiction. Its one in which erotic destiny is ordained by school district  sexual dalliance facilitated by the Department of Education.

title: Play at the Plate Dooms the Mets
description: SAN DIEGO  Carlos Quentin, a burly outfielder for the San Diego Padres, rumbled down the third-base line toward home plate, where Josh Thole of the Mets crouched late Friday night with a baseball squeezed inside his catchers mitt.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

description: Here are some of the events, teams and athletes to watch Saturday at the London Games. (All times Eastern.)

description: INTERNATIONAL

title: What We're Watching on Day 9
description: As the U.S. wraps up another dominant swimming campaign, Michael Phelps goes for one more gold medal before ending his Olympic career. Victor Mather has the latest from London.
