description: To the Editor:

title: In Mets Loss, Harvey Learns From Mistakes
description: SAN DIEGO  Matt Harvey, a young pitcher with the mien and aura of an honor student, received the next lesson on his major league syllabus: how to fail.

title: Training Those Who Guide Young Minds
description: To the Editor:

title: What Does the Free Exercise of Religion Mean?
description: To the Editor:

title: Day 3 of Track and Field
description: Scenes from Sundays track and field events at the London Games, featuring a gold medal run by Usain Bolt in the mens 100 meters.

title: Martin E. Segal, Titan of the Arts in New York City, Dies at 96
description: Martin E. Segal, whose puckish warmth and old-fashioned ways belied his power and influence as one of the citys leading cultural figures, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 96.

title: Gunmen Kill 15 and Steal Vehicle in Attack on Egypt Base
description: CAIRO  Masked gunmen opened fire on an Egyptian Army checkpoint in the northern Sinai Peninsula on Sunday, killing 15 soldiers who were preparing to break their Ramadan fast. The gunmen then seized at least one armored vehicle and headed toward Israel, apparently in an attempt to storm the border, witnesses and officials said.

title: Aggregators Help Radio Reach Online Audiences
description: For the radio industry, there may be no better symbol for the challenges of adapting to the digital age than two candy-colored mobile apps.

title: A Common Refrain as Harlem Loses Its Bowling Alley
description: As groups of cheering children sought to knock down pins at Harlem Lanes on Friday morning, Joey Hill and Marsha Kindell had a different objective: get rid of mounds of documents.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include consumer credit for June (Tuesday); second-quarter productivity (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, the trade deficit for June and wholesale trade inventories for June (Thursday); and import prices for July (Friday).

title: Optimism in Greece After Talks With Lenders
description: ATHENS  Envoys of Greeces international creditors on Sunday wrapped up a review of the countrys progress in meeting the terms of its second bailout and said they would return in September for a final assessment that will determine whether further money would be released and a potentially disastrous default averted.

title: Competitive Armchair Olympics: Olympic Record
description: Click to begin the race.

title: Women Finally Get Their Chance to Be Contenders in Olympic Boxing
description: LONDON  For much of the match, the North Korean boxer seemed intent on wrapping her arms around her Russian opponent as if her strategy were to dance cheek to cheek. Occasionally, they traded blows, and the Russian slightly got the better of that. She won the bout, 12-9.

title: The Clinton Tax Challenge for Republicans
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Security Start-Ups Catch Fancy of Investors
description: MENLO PARK, Calif.  The question is no longer who have hackers hit. It is who has not been hit.

title: Criticism Grows as Check-Cashing Stores Expand in Poorer Areas
description: Behind bulletproof glass, a smiling teller at a RiteCheck store in the South Bronx waited patiently for customers to hand over their checks. For every $100 cashed, she collected a $1.91 service fee.

title: With 10th-Place Finish, a Lifter Earns a Victory Over the Pain
description: LONDON  It was not Holley Mangolds best day. First, she tore her uniform. Then she tore a tendon. And then there was the not insignificant matter of lifting a few hundred pounds over her head again and again.

title: Who Is Jamaica?
description: Kingston, Jamaica

title: To Increase Learning Time, Some Schools Add Days to Academic Year
description: PHOENIX  It was the last Sunday in July, and Bethany and Garvin Phillips were pulling price tags off brand-new backpacks and stuffing them with binders and pencils.

title: Terms of Service
description: In the first of a new series on private languages, we offer a selection of secret codes used in the dining rooms and kitchens of some of New Yorks finest restaurants.

title: Women at War
description: On Aug. 29, 1862, during the Second Battle of Bull Run, Union soldiers could see a young woman helping the wounded seek shelter under a rock ledge, while taking fire herself. At Petersburg in June 1864, Sgt. Frederick O. Talbot, of the First Maine Heavy Artillery, found himself standing beside this same woman as she beckoned soldiers to the frontline breastwork to be treated. He was told that the men of the Fifth Michigan Infantry would have anyones life in a minute for saying any harm of her.

title: A Torrent of Toys, From Lunchables
description: MARKETERS used to entice children with cheap plastic trinkets in boxes of Cracker Jack or cereal. The Lunchables brand is raising the stakes considerably.

title: In California, County Jails Face Bigger Load
description: FRESNO, Calif.  Standing on the footsteps of the Fresno County Jail, where he had just been released one recent afternoon, Juan Diaz rated the food inside a 2. The state prison at Coalinga, where he served three years on a weapons conviction, earned a 10.

title: Fatal Shootings of 2 Brooklyn Shopkeepers Unnerve Fellow Merchants
description: The recent killings of two shopkeepers in south Brooklyn bore eerie similarities, though their deaths occurred nearly four weeks apart. Both were shot in the head or neck with what the police said were .22-caliber guns. Both were Egyptian immigrants around retirement age. And both sold their wares at addresses that contained the same numbers: two 7s, a 1 and an 8.

title: After Phelps, More Prodigies
description: LONDON  Nine months after the Beijing Games, Michael Phelps was in the weight room at Loyola College in Maryland when a photograph of Brett Favre flashed on a nearby television as part of an ESPN report that Favre was considering coming out of retirement a second time.

title: Terms of Service
description: Ever wondered how restaurant staff members communicate with one another? Or why some diners have curious letters appended to their reservations?

title: Aug. 5: State Polls, National Polls, and Likely Voters
description: Good news for polling junkies: pollsters seem to be picking up their pace a bit, and were finally starting to see some state polls released on the weekends. On Sunday, there were two state polls out, each of which were a bit strange.

title: Seeking Economic Lift, Not Just Laughs, in Tie to Comedy
description: JAMESTOWN, N.Y.  For those caught up in the Olympic spirit, there was the traditional grape-stomping competition. Or perhaps the test of chocolate-wrapping skills, even if some of the competitors just could not resist sticking a few candies from the fast-moving conveyor belt inside their blouses.

title: In Kansas, Conservatives Vilify Fellow Republicans
description: TOPEKA, Kan.  In eight years in the Kansas Legislature, State Senator Dick Kelsey said, he never voted for a tax increase and frequently supported spending cuts. As an evangelical pastor, a staunch opponent of abortion and an acknowledged leader in the fight to elect conservative lawmakers, he has been endorsed by Kansans for Life and the National Rifle Association.

title: Zillow and Other Sites Broaden Their Mission to Include Businesses
description: SEATTLE  For the first few years of its existence, the only thing Zillow cared about was getting people to come to its real estate Web site to snoop on the market value of neighbors homes and other properties. Over 34 million visitors a month now do so.

title: In Basketball, a Different and More Literal Globetrotter
description: LONDON  The traveling basketball coach, now on gig No. 12 and in country No. 3, looked across the scorers table as The Star-Spangled Banner played Sunday. He recognized the faces of the opposition, all American, all familiar.

title: Militias Eager to Oust Islamists in Mali
description: The recruits have almost no weapons, little military instruction and not much more than the hard ground to sleep on.

title: A Dtente Before the Election
description: Does voter fraud sometimes happen in the United States? You bet. But we are dealing with this relatively small problem in an irrational and partisan way.

title: Lottery Numbers
At Governors Island Reunion, Childhood Bonds Endure
description: Before Governors Island became the scene of artist-inspired miniature golf and food festivals, before it sprouted bike rentals, hammocks and Mark di Suvero sculptures, before it evolved into a cool weekend getaway for overheated New Yorkers, it was home.

title: Fearing an Impasse in Congress, Industry Cuts Spending
description: A rising number of manufacturers are canceling new investments and putting off new hires because they fear paralysis in Washington will force hundreds of billions in tax increases and budget cuts in January, undermining economic growth in the coming months.

title: Jamestown Loves Lucy
description: Lucys hometown celebrates her life and career

title: The Leak Police
description: In the months leading up to the invasion of Iraq in 2003, this newspaper famously published a number of stories regurgitating the Bush administration hype about Saddam Husseins supposed arsenal of mass destruction. A few journalists elsewhere  notably Jonathan Landay and Warren Strobel, then of the Knight Ridder newspapers  dug deeper, discovered contrary intelligence, and challenged the official line. Later, The Times also published some excellent work on how an administration eager to justify its decision to go to war cherry-picked the intelligence to make its case.

title: Carrots and Sticks for School Systems
description: Education Secretary Arne Duncan has been pushing the states to create rigorous teacher evaluation systems that not only judge teachers by how well their students perform but also  when the results are in  reward good teachers while easing chronic low performers out of the system. More than half the states have agreed to adopt new evaluation systems in exchange for competitive grants from the federal Race to the Top program or greater flexibility under the No Child Left Behind law.

title: As Libor Fault-Finding Grows, It Is Now Every Bank for Itself
description: Major banks, which often band together when facing government scrutiny, are now turning on one another as an international investigation into the manipulation of interest rates gains momentum.

title: In Britains Little Jamaica, Rejoicing Over a Speedster
description: LONDON  The  Electric Brixton might have been a colonial outpost. At this cavernous nightclub nine or so miles southwest of Olympic Stadium, there were no Union Jacks, no cries for Team GB, but the closest thing to a hometown crowd a man can get 4,700 miles from home.

title: Republicans Fail a Security Test
description: Senate Republicans regularly promote themselves as the true custodians of national security. This claim seemed particularly hollow last week when they helped block a new measure aimed at protecting Americas vulnerable computer networks from attack by, among others, potentially hostile foreign governments.

title: When the Sweeper Comes
description: There is a line of cars double-parked on West 12th Street. It is Monday morning, 9:30 or so. In each car, a driver waits, some reading, some making calls, some drumming their fingers on the steering wheel. The opposite curb is empty. It is a quiet block, but the air is full of expectation.

title: Outside Cash in Missouri Race Could Be a National Model
description: WASHINGTON  Missouris long, divisive Republican Senate primary draws to a close Tuesday, but after all the intraparty fireworks, it is the incumbent Democrat, Senator Claire McCaskill, who remains in deep trouble.

title: Times Photographer Is Arrested on Assignment
description: A freelance photographer for The New York Times was arrested on Saturday night while on assignment with two reporters who were conducting street interviews in the Bronx.

title: DNA and the Fourth Amendment
description: Earlier this year, Marylands highest court held that collection of DNA samples from people arrested but not yet convicted violated the Fourth Amendments prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures. Last week, Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. stayed that ruling while the Supreme Court decides whether to hear Marylands appeal of the state court decision. The Supreme Court should take up this case, but there was no good reason for the chief justice to allow the police to continue collecting DNA while the case is on appeal.

title: Afghan President Moves to Reassure Allies After Security Ministers Are Dismissed
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai moved quickly on Sunday to confirm Parliaments decision to dismiss two senior security ministers the day before, but he reassured the Western allies that he would avoid a vacuum in the two ministries charged with fighting the war and organizing the transition to Afghan control.

title: A Big Decision, With Its Timing Carefully Planned
description: Barring a total surprise, the next big thing in the 2012 presidential race will be Mitt Romneys choice of a running mate.

title: Writer Defends His Handling of Interview With Assad
description: Even when his country was not convulsed by war, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria rarely gave televised interviews to foreigners. His session with Barbara Walters in December was a public relations disaster. So it seemed surprising a few weeks ago when Mr. Assad granted another Westerner a face-to-face chat on camera.

title: Its Bradley Left Standing as Furyk Tumbles on 18
description: AKRON, Ohio  Jim Furyk entered Sundays final round of the W.G.C.-Bridgestone Invitational with a one-stroke lead, hoping to overcome some lingering disappointment from his final-round collapse at the United States Open in June.

title: Saying Mali Is Our Country, Militias Train to Oust Islamists
description: MOPTI, Mali  Hundreds of young men are stuffed into makeshift training camps near this provincial capital, arising at 4 a.m. for physical exercises and simulated hand-to-hand combat in preparation for the day when they can free their north Mali homeland from the radical Islamists whose harsh rule has driven tens of thousands of frightened, desperate civilians to flee the country.

title: Should the U.S. Seek More Tech Manufacturing?
Enjoying the Games, Despite What May Be Behind the Curtain
description: I wasnt surprised that Charles Yesalis had been intently watching the London Olympics. The surprise is that Yesalis is actually enjoying the Games.

title: One Race, Every Medalist Ever
description: Usain Bolts 9.63 set an Olympic record in the 100. So how far ahead of every Olympic medalist is he?

title: Jets Linebacker Looks to Add to His Game
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  Aaron Maybin finds inspiration in conventional sources, like his two favorite books, The Alchemist and The Secret, but also by gazing at the ceiling in his bedroom at his New Jersey apartment.

title: NASAs Curiosity Rover Successfully Lands on Mars
description: At 1:31 a.m. Eastern time on Monday, NASAs Mars Curiosity rover completed its eight-and-a-half-month journey from Earth and landed on the surface of Mars. The Times is reporting the news as it unfolds directly from NASAs Jet Propulsion Laboratory, and covering events and reaction from people tuning in around the globe.

title: Warren Winkelstein Jr., Medical Sleuth, Dies at 90
description: Dr. Warren Winkelstein Jr., a physician and researcher whose groundbreaking studies connected unprotected sex between men to AIDS, smoking to cervical cancer and air pollution to chronic lung disease, died July 22 at his home in Point Richmond, Calif. He was 90.

title: Corrections: August 6, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: P.G.A. Championship Will Be Latest War by the Shore
description: In the spring of 1990, there was a news conference for the Ryder Cup, which was coming one year later to the inconspicuous, windswept South Carolina barrier island known as Kiawah. The man charged with turning an oceanside tract of swamp and shrub into a dauntingly beautiful championship golf course was asked where he planned to put the huge galleries expected for the event.

title: Styled to a T | Diane Kruger
description: Hide and Seek. Head-to-toe leather and suede for day  as shown by the likes of Calvin Klein, Bally and Derek Lam  is this seasons second skin.

title: Word of the Day | symbiosis
description: symbiosis \sim-be-o-ss, -bi-\ noun

title: Day 11: What to Watch For
description: Here are some of the events, teams and athletes to watch on Monday at the London Games. (All times Eastern.)

title: A Coming-Out Party in Hanoi
description: HONG KONG  It wasnt much of a parade, as these things go. More like a noisy bike ride with some balloons. But the gathering of about 100 gay Vietnamese in Hanoi on Sunday was still a proud declaration of sorts, a kind of political coming-out in the socially conservative country.

title: Embracing Sheldon Adelson
description: There are two things that set Mitt Romneys presidential campaign apart: his caution and his secretiveness.

title: Gunman Kills 6 in Wisconsin Gurdwara
description: Sikh religious leaders had gathered in the lobby of the sprawling Sikh temple in suburban Milwaukee, and lunch was being prepared as congregants were arriving for Sunday services, Steven Yaccino, Michael Schwirtz and Marc Santora wrote in The New York Times. Instead of worshipers, though, an armed man stepped through the door and started firing, killing six people.

title: FindTheBest: A Comparison Engine Tries to Build a Business
description: Kevin OConnor recalls that he was met with mostly skepticism when he made the rounds of potential venture investors a few years ago. He wanted to build an online comparison engine, but not one for a single product or service like travel or restaurants. He wanted to cover hundreds of topics and products, from lawyers to nursing homes, smartphones to dog breeds.

title: Novartis and Penn Unite on New Anticancer Path
description: The drugmaker Novartis and the University of Pennsylvania announced a research and licensing agreement early Monday that aims to bring to market a new approach to fighting cancer that has shown promising results in early trials.

title: Rover Curiosity Lands on Mars
description: A NASA rover, Curiosity, landed on Mars on Monday.

title: Ending Blackouts, One Solar Lamp at a Time
description: The blackouts in northern and eastern India last week helped highlight a basic fact of life in the country: many people here do not have access to reliable electricity. The humor newspaper, The Onion, perhaps summed it up best with this headline: 300 Million Without Electricity in India After Restoration of Power Grid.

title: News Quiz | August 6, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Curiosity Rover Lands Safely on Mars
description: PASADENA, Calif.  In a flawless, triumphant technological tour de force, a plutonium-powered rover the size of a small car was lowered at the end of 25-foot-long cables from a hovering rocket stage onto Mars early on Monday morning.

title: Saving a Parking Spot in Comfort
description: Dear Diary:

title: First Indian Woman in Olympic Discus Throw Finals
description: With the throw of a discus, Krishna Poonia of India made history on Saturday night, Mary Pilon wrote in The New York Times.

title: Prime Ministers Defection in the Dark Jolts Syrians
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The defection of Syrias prime minister, Riyad Farid Hijab, began like so many others: with coded conversations and furtive planning. He began discussing the idea of fleeing, an aide said, as soon as President Bashar al-Assad strong-armed him into taking the job in June. In recent days, he worked to get his extended family out. Then, early Monday, the prime minister slipped out of Damascus under cover of darkness with his wife and four children, scrambling through the desert as a fugitive.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Aug. 6, 2012
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the special London 2012 section.

title: In the Olympics Shadow, a Tale of Two Cities
description: Both crime-ridden and trendy, Hackney is one of the host boroughs for the Olympic Games in London.

title: What Were Watching on Day 11
description: The U.S. women's soccer team meets its longtime regional rival Canada in the semifinals and the marquee track events continue with the men's 400-meter. Victor Mather has the latest from London.

title: Jets, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
description: Andy Benoit resumes his previews of all 32 teams with a look at the A.F.C. East this week. First up are the Jets.

title: Counselors Calendar | August Checklist for Rising Seniors
description: In March, The Choice introduced a series called Counselors Calendar, to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

title: Measuring Mooching
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: Gunman Attacks Sikh Temple in Wisconsin, Killing Six
description: WHERE did a gunman open fire on Sunday morning?

title: Thigh-Popping Success on a Bike Lies in the Quads
description: LONDON  The picture of the Olympics so far, an image that swept across the Internet and introduced the sports world to the term quad-off, might be one featuring two cyclists in their underwear with shorts around their ankles, their thunderous thighs prominently displayed.

title: Farmers Fight Nuclear Plant in Bid to Save Land
description: Badlu Ram tugged against the tattered strips of the white gauze that bound his hands and legs to the hospital bed in the town of Fatehabad. Please free me, he pleaded. On July 13, Mr. Ram had attempted suicide by consuming pesticide. It was my duty  it was my duty, he repeated.

title: What Were Watching: Soccer Gold Goes Through Canada
description: (function($){var data = chameleonData;var ticker = new NYTD.NYTMM.NewsTicker($('#nytmm_embed_777'), data);})(jQuery||NYTD.jQuery);

title: Jones, Harper and Wells Advance in Hurdles
description: The three American womens 100-meter hurdlers qualified easily for the semifinals in morning heats Monday at the London Olympics.

title: This Week in Small Business: Introducing the Cashtag
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: My Son, Lost and Found
description: My son, who is 12, loves living in Manhattan. He thinks our neighborhood is great. One day last year he told me he never wanted to leave Chelsea. He could live here the rest of his life, he said. I told him he was very lucky to feel this way, but he was going to have to get his own apartment.

title: Israeli Defense Chief Says Egypt Attack a Wake-Up Call
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli defense minister, Ehud Barak, said on Monday that a terrorist attack that killed 15 Egyptian soldiers on Sunday night should serve as a wake-up call to the new Egyptian president about the growing danger in the Sinai Peninsula and the border between the two nations.

title: In Antarctica, Dreaming of Mars
description: Alexander Kumar, a physician and researcher at Concordia Station, writes from Antarctica, where he conducts scientific experiments for the European Space Agencys human spaceflight program.

title: Zaoui Brothers Establish New Firm
description: LONDON  The brothers Michael and Yol Zaoui, two of the most prominent London-based investment bankers of the last two decades, have created a new company called Zaoui Capital, according to British regulatory documents.

title: On Our Radar: Oklahomas Wildfires
description: Hopscotching wildfires persist in northeastern Oklahoma after devouring over 90 square miles, although light rain gave firefighters a bit of respite on Sunday. [Associated Press]

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: London Live: Follow Mondays Action at the Olympics
description: The Olympic action today center on track and field, with Jenn Suhr of the United States winning gold in the womens pole vault, finally beating two-time gold medalist Yelena Isinbayeva of Russia, who settled for a bronze.

title: Opinion Report: The Vehicular Olympics
description: From the editorial page

title: For Many Sikhs, Wisconsin Attack Has Troubling Echoes
description: For Sikhs in the United States, India and elsewhere, the killing of six people at a gurudwara, or Sikh temple, in Wisconsin on Sunday afternoon has brought grief and sorrow but also concern that the rampage might be the latest example of a hate crime against Sikhs on American soil in the decade since the 9/11 attacks.

title: U.S. Fight Against E.U. Airline Emissions Plan Heats Up
description: A meeting of 17 non-European nations hosted by the U.S. State and Transportation departments in Washington last week ended with assurances that the participants were working toward curbing their emissions from aviation.

title: As Knight Capital Gains a Lifeline, It Loses Market-Making Duties
description: The Knight Capital Group confirmed on Monday that it had struck a $400 million rescue deal with a group of investors, staving off collapse after a recent trading mishap, even as the New York Stock Exchange temporarily revoked the firms market-making responsibilities.

title: Daily Report: Consumer Sites Broaden Mission to Include Businesses
description: The clear line between Internet companies that cater to consumers and those that serve businesses is beginning to blur, reports Nick Wingfield on Monday in The New York Times. Sites like Zillow, LinkedIn, Groupon and GrubHub  consumer services that help people find homes, advertise their talents, find daily deals and order takeout food  are among the companies seeking to burrow more deeply into the operations of businesses in their respective markets.

title: Not Cool, Britannia: Plans Are Dropped to Honor Homes of Some Great Britons
description: During his career with the Monty Python comedy troupe, Graham Chapman was set upon by the Spanish Inquisition (which nobody expected), pitted in combat against the fearsome Black Knight and crucified in a musical number, accomplishments for which he surely deserves some recognition. Instead, Mr. Chapman, who died in 1989, is one of several noteworthy Britons and people who lived in Britain whose names have been dropped from a list to have their homes distinguished by ceremonial markers because of budget cuts at the organization that grants them.

title: Signs in China Point to Meeting on Transition
description: BEIJING  At least five senior Communist Party officials have arrived at the beachside resort of Beidaihe, including Xi Jinping, the man expected to be the next leader of China, setting the stage for what some analysts expect to be the climactic negotiations over the coming once-a-decade power transition.

title: Monday Reading: August Checklist for Rising High School Seniors
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Vote of Confidence
description: I kept asking myself, Is that really my skirt?  Mimi Plange recalls of the time she saw Michelle Obama wearing a periwinkle gabardine skirt from her spring collection during an appearance on The View in May. And it was. And it looked great. And I felt really, really blessed. In her fifth season, the 34-year-old Plange, who was born in Ghana and grew up in California, has joined the ranks of White House-approved designers, including Thakoon Panichgul, Jason Wu and Carly Cushnie and Michelle Ochs of Cushnie et Ochs, with clothes that have obvious first-lady appeal: they are romantic (corseted organza dresses in an hourglass silhouette, top left, $2,900; Estis, 718-645-2600), mature (Victorian silk blouses with velvet trim) and practical (lots of A-line skirts). I am catering to every womans body from a female perspective, Plange says. Its not about me or what I want to wear; its about wearable, real fantasy for real women. And although Plange admits that she had never really watched The View  Im still not sure what the episode was all about because I couldnt pay attention, she says  shes now a fan of the show and its star guest for life.

title: Romneys Fund-Raising Outpaces Obamas Again in July
description: The fund-raising machine behind Mitt Romney and the Republican Party once again bested President Obamas effort last month, raising $25 million more in July than the president and his Democratic allies did.

title: Best Buy Founder Offers $8.8 Billion to Buy Out Company
description: Richard Schulze, the founder of Best Buy, offered to buy the electronics retailer on Monday in a deal that would value it as much as $8.8 billion.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Sticking the Mars Landing, and TVs Latino Woes
description: While incredible feats were being accomplished in London, another example of human excellence was occurring millions of miles away: the Curiosity rover landed in a 96-mile-wide crater on Mars at 1:32 a.m. Eastern time. The Mars missions final stage was a thriller  the rover, the size of a small car, was lowered at the end of 25-foot-long cables from a hovering rocket stage, Kenneth Chang writes. One wit on Twitter noted that the 14-minute time delay for images from Mars to reach Earth was nothing compared to the hours of delay from NBC in showing Usain Bolts Olympic-record-setting dash in the 100-meter race.

title: A Proclamation of Innocence for a Prisoner Who Never Gave Up
description: Sometimes it turns out that people do tell the truth about themselves. Sorry if that qualifying sometimes sounds cynical. But when you meet someone in prison who says she did not commit the murder that earned her a sentence of 25 years to life, you have reason to take her claims with a shaker of salt.

title: What Were Reading
description: Epicurious: Stop yanking back the husks on that greenmarket corn; whether you keep it or throw it back in the pile, its ruined. (As one farmer asks, do you break your eggs before you buy them?) Instead, follow this simple tip for finding the best ears: Feel the outside.  Patrick Farrell

title: Going Underground: Behind the Scenes of Our Second Avenue Subway Cover Shoot
description: For this weeks cover article, the photographer Richard Barnes went deep into the bowels of New York City to capture the otherworldly atmosphere of the Second Avenue Subway construction. I accompanied Barnes on one of his descents into the construction zone, and later conducted this Q. and A. with him.

title: Slovenia Leads Games in Medals Per Capita
description: LONDON  Once again, the United States, China and, to a lesser degree, Russia, are battling to become the nation with the biggest haul of Olympic medals. That is no surprise: their teams have the best resources  training facilities and so on  to produce athletes like Michael Phelps and a raft of Michael Jordan-like badminton and table tennis players.

title: Splitsville for Team Anna?
description: Anna Hazare, the anti-corruption crusader, may be organizing a political party, but he has no plans to join it. Nor to be a candidate for office. Nor to continue the work of Team Anna.

title: Condoleezza Rice and John McCain to Speak at Republican Convention
description: Republicans plan to highlight three high-profile women as headliners during the national convention in Tampa later this summer, officials said this weekend.

title: The Shame of Putins Courts
description: MOSCOW  Of all the bad feelings one can have about ones own country, shame is the most painful. Righteous outrage motivates one to act; sadness breeds solidarity; even fear can bring people together. But shame not only makes you want to jump out of your skin, it also means you have already effectively jumped out of the skin that is your country.

title: Philippines Moves Forward With Bill to Improve Contraceptive Access
description: MANILA  Despite opposition from the powerful Roman Catholic Church, a bill that would mandate sex education in schools and subsidize contraceptives moved ahead on Monday after being stalled in the Philippine Congress for 14 years.

title: Germanys Fatal Race Problem
description: BERLIN  Is Germanys police force racist? This is the question after yet another scandal has damaged the credibility of the nations police force, an issue explored in todays Letter from Europe.

title: Business Day Live | August 6, 2012
description: Readers respond to the migration of jobs from Nissan to the United States. | Marcus Samuelsson, the chef and the brand. | NASA's $2.5 billion adventure.

title: Wisconsin Killer Fed and Was Fueled by Hate-Driven Music
description: His music, Wade M. Page once said, was about how the value of human life has been degraded by tyranny.

title: Middle East Journal: Ill Stick With Our Model (as Long as I Can)
description: This is my last post on my trip to the Middle East. Its going to be a while before I see any return on my investment, but the cost has not been outrageous. The trip cost about $4,100, including the two Gold Key fees. Ill be reimbursed for about half of that by the State of Pennsylvania. We are in the process of putting together printed materials, and Im mulling another trip in the fall to present them.

title: Video of News Conference About Shooting at Sikh Temple in Wisconsin
description: In a news conference on Monday from Oak Creek, Wisc., law enforcement officials provided more details on the shooting rampage at a sprawling Sikh temple in suburban Milwaukee that left six people dead and three people wounded. Our colleagues Steven Yaccino, Jennifer Preston and Marc Santora are following the investigation.

title: Swept Off Her Feet
description: When is a shoe not just a shoe? Why, when its a love object, a fetish or an alternate dream of self, of course. Shoes, like handbags, have grown in cultural stature over the last few decades, sending out coded and not so coded messages about the women who wear them: I am sexy, chic, kooky; I can walk without falling down in four-inch heels; I can afford to spend gobs of money on elusive brands and esoteric leathers. Manhattan department stores have, in the last few years, enlarged their shoe departments, in recognition of their allure and recession-proof sales potential, in many cases taking away space from what was once the main event  the clothes themselves.

title: Why Your Family Should Talk About Money More Often
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

title: The Week in Politics Pictures: July 29-Aug 4
description: A look back at the week in politics, from overseas trips to jobs reports.

title: John Phelan, N.Y.S.E. Chief Who Ushered In New Technology, Is Dead at 81
description: John J. Phelan Jr., a former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange who introduced computer technology to the Big Board in the 1980s and was widely praised for his calming response to the stock market crash of October 1987, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 81.

title: Image of the Day: August 6
A Year on, Marines Divided on Repeal of Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: After Marine Corps Recruit Training, Chase Davis, from Leesburg, Ga., was living a lie. He had developed a friendship with a Marine named Jackie and they had become inseparable during their first months of training. She was the only one he trusted and he confided his secret to her. He is gay.

title: Counting the Mobile Costs for Bing
description: As search goes mobile, Microsoft could pay heavily for the ride.

title: HCA Discloses U.S. Inquiry Into Cardiology Services
description: HCA Holdings stock fell about 4 percent Monday after the company disclosed that the cardiology practices at some of its Florida operations were under scrutiny by the Department of Justice.

title: Regulator Says British Bank Helped Iran Hide Deals
description: Using its New York-based operations, a major British bank schemed with the Iranian government for nearly a decade to launder $250 billion, leaving the United States financial system vulnerable to terrorists and corrupt regimes, New Yorks top banking regulator charged on Monday.

title: Q&A: Moving From PC to Mac
description: Q.

title: Ad Executive Makes Leap to Comcasts El Rey Network
description: Antionette Alfonso Zel, an advertising executive, has been named the chief executive of El Rey, the English-language cable television network aimed at second- and third-generation Latinos.

title: On a Day Off the Trail, Errands and Small Talk
description: WOLFEBORO, N.H.  In campaign jargon, Mitt Romney was down on Monday, meaning he had no public events scheduled.

description: Our tasty challenge this week is a favorite of Numberplay contributor Marco Moriconi, who had this to say about the puzzle:

title: U.S. Judoka Expelled for Positive Marijuana Test
description: 8:49 p.m. | Updated

title: This Time, Americans Aim on Last Shot Is Not Too Far Off
description: LONDON  Matt Emmons earned a coveted spot on the podium and shook off his own curse  sort of.

title: For Australians, a Blow to the Ego
description: LONDON  It may still get better for Australia, sunburned land where Olympic champions used to grow on eucalyptus trees.

title: Police Enforcing Unposted Rules at Zuccotti Park, Memo Indicates
description: A memorandum indicating that the police agreed to enforce unposted rules restricting activities at Zuccotti Park, the epicenter of the Occupy movement, surfaced on Thursday night, protesters said, handed out by a man who said that he worked for Brookfield Properties, which owns the park.

title: USA Field Hockey Looking to Continue Growth
description: Pam Stuper, the head field hockey coach at Yale, played on three national championship teams at Old Dominion University, and on the United States national team from 1990-1998, earning a bronze medal at the 1994 World Cup. She currently chairs the USA Field Hockey Board of Directors. She will be writing for the 2012 London Olympics blog throughout the Games.

title: Persistence Is Key to Treating Sexual Pain
description: Millions of women experience vaginal discomfort, and sometimes crippling pain, for a variety of reasons, most often a loss of estrogen. The resulting vaginal dryness and atrophy can make sexual intercourse, a pelvic exam, urinating, or even sitting, walking or cycling a painful nightmare.

title: How a Best Buy Takeover Might Work
description: Best Buys founder, Richard Schulze, finally confirmed on Monday that he was pursuing a takeover of the electronics retailer, one that might be worth as much as $8.8 billion.

title: Sleeping Less May Dampen Vaccine Response
description: An observational study has found evidence that people who sleep less may be less likely to benefit from a vaccine.

title: S.E.C. Gets Encouragement, but Needs Something More
description: When you are unable to win a prize playing a carnival game, the attendant usually says, Better luck next time! as you pony up for another round. That is pretty much what a federal jury told the Securities and Exchange Commission when it urged the government to continue to pursue financial fraud cases involving Wall Street while finding the agency had not proven that a former Citigroup banker, Brian H. Stoker, had violated securities laws.

title: Irish Arts Center Announces New Season
description: The theater company Fishamble, the singer Wallis Bird and an exhibition of works by the painter Colette Murphy are among the fall season offerings announced by the Irish Arts Center.

title: A Provenal Reunion, With Vegetables at the Center of the Plate
description: Last month I had a reunion in Provence with friends who discovered this magical region of France with me more than 30 years ago. It was a true southern French vacation  we relaxed, we went to the market, we cooked. Market stalls were piled high with summer squash, tomatoes and eggplant, green beans  both regular ones and the flat ones that we call romano beans and that my Provenal market labeled cocos  onions of all kinds, braids of plump pink garlic, and leeks. Even the supermarket produce sections were inspiring. We bought short-grain rice from the Camargue, southwest of our area of Provence, for our risottos, and a local wheat berry called petit peautre for chewy pilafs and grain salads. We ate peaches, apricots, amazing strawberries and melons for dessert and for breakfast.

title: Monday Motorsports: Courtney Force and Erica Enders Produce History at the Dragstrip
description: Having lost twice in final-round eliminator races this summer, Courtney Force, a rookie in the National Hot Rod Associations Funny Car division and the daughter of the driver-owner John Force, was poised for a breakthrough entering the Nationals event at Pacific Raceways, in Kent, Wash., on Sunday.

title: Age Claims a Community of Women
description: At the foot of a long drive leading to the Franciscan Retreat Center in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., the Welcome and Parking sign is misleading. The convent closed in 2011, when its original population of 100 nuns had dwindled to 35, the youngest past age 60, most in their 80s and 90s, and a few past their 100th birthdays.

title: A Stubborn Racial Disparity in Who Calls the Upper East Side Home
description: Bernard Walker had just been promoted when word began circulating at his church that there was an apartment available on 86th Street and First Avenue. The tall, beige building with neat rows of balconies did not excite his wife at first, but when she saw the apartment and its walk-in closet, he said, she was sold. That was about 45 years ago, and they have been there ever since.

description: The suspect in the shooting rampage that left six people dead and three wounded at a Sikh temple in Wisconsin has been identified as Wade Michael Page, law enforcement officials announced on Monday.

title: Comparing Credit Cards Auto Rental Insurance
description: Many credit card companies offer accident insurance when the cards are used to pay for a rental car. But details of coverage vary depending on the network behind the card, a report from CardHub.com finds.

title: John C. McGinley Joins Glengarry Glen Ross Revival on Broadway
description: The high-testosterone crucible of David Mamets Glengarry Glen Ross continues to add to its roster of prominent possessors of Y chromosomes for a coming Broadway revival. John C. McGinley, who played the acid-tongued Dr. Perry Cox on the NBC comedy Scrubs and the tough-as-nails Sergeant ONeill in Oliver Stones Vietnam War drama, Platoon, will play the embittered real estate salesman Dave Moss in the Glengarry revival, its producers said on Monday.

title: U.S.-Mexico Preview, Part 1: The A Team
description: One year ago this week, in his first game as United States national team coach, Jurgen Klinsmanns squad eked out a 1-1 draw against Mexico at Lincoln Financial Field in Philadelphia. On that night the team started poorly but seemed to draw strength from its optimistic, charismatic leader. Trailing at the half, it clawed back and got a result. All things considered, it was a good showing for both coach and team.

title: American Ballet Theater Announces Apprentice Program
description: Developing young dancers will be a new focus at American Ballet Theater. The company has announced the creation of a program for six dancers to work as apprentice members of Ballet Theaters corps de ballet, Kevin McKenzie, the artistic director, said on Monday. The selected dancers will train under Kate Lydon, ABT Studio Companys artistic associate, and Clinton Luckett, ABTs Ballet master, for 10 weeks beginning in September, and they will then advance to apprentice level with American Ballet Theater during the companys performances of The Nutcracker at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. According to the announcement, training will provide full immersion into the ballets in ABTs repertory, including tutorials in ballet story lines, history, style and mime. In addition, dancers will attend seminars in hair and makeup and company etiquette in preparation for entering the main company. The dancers will be selected first from among the students at the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis School, second from among Summer Intensive students and by audition. Their apprenticeship will continue throughout ABTs performance season ending July 2013.

title: 3 Ads Warn About Budget Cuts for Childrens Programs
description: A new campaign created by the Minneapolis office of Fallon Worldwide for the Childrens Defense Fund, the advocacy group, uses social media to explain the long-term costs of cutting government-financed initiatives for children.

title: Sparing Sewers All That Restaurant Grease
description: Every hour of every day, plants across the United States treat the waste that flows through the nations sewers. The process is energy-intensive. Wastewater treatment plants often consume more electricity than any other service a city provides  sometimes even as much as 30 to 40 percent of its overall energy consumption, according to the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Reckless and Slanderous
description: I wont defend Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, whopresumably because hes not up for reelectionclaimed last week that Mitt Romney wont release his tax returns because he hasnt paid taxes in ten years. His source: An unnamed Bain insider. Thats improbable and I agree with Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell that its beneath the dignity of Mr. Reids office to spread rumors. (If it turns out Mr. Reid is correct, Ill be the first to apologize.)

title: Del Toro Shoes Offer a Flash for Fall
description: Fall often signals dark colors and luxe fabrics. But for Del Toro, the Miami-based footwear brand best known for its velvet slippers, it means toying with the idea of reflection. The brand is introducing a limited-edition line of sneakers and wingtips made from 3M reflective material, a high-visibility fabric that could be illuminated by headlights (or in many cases, by street-style photographers).

Mr. Dumont, a French sculptor, created the one-of-a-kind twig-inspired benches and easels now on display at Anthropologies gallery at Rockefeller Center. He opened his own design studio in 2005 in Paris, where he lives.

title: Gibson Guitar To Pay $300,000 in Penalties and Lose Seized Tropical Hardwood
description: The Justice Department has closed its criminal investigation against the Gibson Guitar Company after the company agreed to a series of steps, including payment of $300,000 in penalties and forfeiture of seized rosewood and ebony shipments from India and ebony from Madagascar with an estimated value of more than $419,000.* [3:12 p.m. | Updated | The company may be able to get the Indian wood back, under the terms of the complicated agreement. ]

title: The Arctic Drilling Countdown
description: After several weeks of delays linked to mechanical problems and persistent sea ice, Shell is completing its final preparations for drilling in the Arctic Ocean, company officials said Monday. The company hopes over the next several days to demonstrate to regulators that its oil spill containment equipment is ready and to receive clearance from the Environmental Protection Agency to operate its drill ships without running afoul of air pollution laws.

title: Bill Blass Fires Designer. Again.

Since Mr. Blass retired in 1999, the struggling company has tried five different womens designers (or six if you count that season in 2003 when the public relations director was ghost-designing a collection behind the scenes), but has been unable to recapture a high-end customer for its womens wear.

title: Skewering Seattles Microsoft Elite
description: The free-range hilarity of Whered You Go, Bernadette begins with Bee Branchs report card from Galer Street School in Seattle, a place where compassion, academics and global connectitude join together to create civic-minded citizens of a sustainable and diverse planet. This school gives three grades: S for Surpasses Excellence, A for Achieves Excellence and W for Working Towards Excellence. So every kid is some kind of excellent. But Bee is a straight-S student all the way.

description: Duke University has acquired the papers of Rabbi Abraham Joshua Heschel, the influential scholar, writer and theologian, the university announced Monday. The collection has never before been available to scholars and includes manuscripts, correspondence, publications, documents and photographs over a 50-year period.

In this post, I want to look at both factors in a bit more detail.

title: The Get | 3.1 Phillip Lims Vendetta Mini Cross-Body
description: Recently, the designer Phillip Lim showed sporty-sleek silhouettes and separates for his prefall and fall collections, both of which were inspired by neo-noir comic books like Sin City and Superman. Earning its name from the classic V for Vendetta, Lims new Vendetta cross-body bag packs a powerful one-two punch: a compact shape and an extra-long strap, making it ideal for quickly slinging over the shoulder (and keeping your superwoman hands free). I like the idea of it being worn in many different ways, as a messenger during the day and as a clutch at night, Lim says. The Vendetta comes in classic brown, black and a most coveted color-blocked version. The basis of the bag comes from structured vintage satchels, Lim adds. We played with the idea of color blocking to modernize it and changed the proportion a little, too. WHAM!

title: Early Voting in Ohio
description: For the last four years, Republican lawmakers around the country have diligently tried to eliminate early-voting periods, which give people a chance to vote at their convenience. The reason is simple: early voting was wildly popular in 2008  comprising a third of the vote  and many of the people who took advantage of it voted for Barack Obama.

description: The English-language television networks have had trouble connecting with the growing Latino audience, as Tanzina Vega and Bill Carter describe in Mondays newspaper. The Latino characters that do appear in network shows often represent stereotypes  the trophy wife, the immigrant. In this video, Ms. Vega follows the production of the online series East WillyB, that one of its creators, Julia Ahumada Grob, says can be seen as a Latino Cheers set in gentrifying Brooklyn. A Kickstarter campaign has come up with $50,000 in financing for new episodes.

title: Between the Devil and the Deep Blue Sea
description: Theres some sadness in the story of the S.S. United States, which for a time in the 1950s and 1960s was the fastest and most advanced ocean liner ever built. It was the lifelong project of William Francis Gibbs, Americas preeminent naval architect, a self-taught engineer who, among his many other achievements, was instrumental in transforming a German liner captured during World War I into the Leviathan, the pride of Americas postwar passenger fleet. Then, during World War II, he pioneered a revolutionary process to construct the so-called Liberty Ships, which became symbols of Americas industrial might. All along, Gibbs nursed plans to build a revolutionary superliner. But his designs, hatched in his parents Philadelphia attic as early 1916, were not realized until 1952. Ten years after its christening, his transatlantic ship would prowl the icy North Atlantic as a kind of floating anachronism, jet planes having turned its record three-day, 10-hour crossing time into a sorry joke. Such is the sweep of A Man and His Ship (Simon & Schuster, $30) an absorbing, transporting new history by Steven Ujifusa, which coincides with a show about the S.S. United States now on view at the Forbes Gallery (through Oct. 20).

title: In the Light and Dark Corners of Poetry and Blues
description: While watching Norbert Leo Butz shoot the moon at 54 Below on Sunday evening, I lamented that Broadway stars have so little room in the musical comedy sphere to be much more than singing cartoon characters. Mr. Butz, who has won two Tonys for best performance by a leading actor in a musical (Dirty Rotten Scoundrels and Catch Me if You Can), is a much larger, more complex musical personality than could ever be contained by a single role. He has the soul of a poet and a bluesman on the same wavelength as Van Morrison and Tom Waits, two of the composers whose songs he performed.

title: An Aida for Turbulent Times
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.  A band of Egyptian soldiers, taking refuge in a bombed-out presidential palace after an onslaught by Ethiopian enemies, plots a counteroffensive and chooses a stalwart young army officer as its leader. But that officer has secretly fallen in love with a daughter of an Ethiopian royal family, who has been captured by the Egyptians and is hiding her true identity. When, having led a rout of the Ethiopian invaders, the young officer is caught revealing state secrets to his beloved, he is waterboarded to get the truth out of him.

title: Sharon Osbourne Repeats Threat to Quit NBC Show
description: Sharon Osbourne, below, has repeated her threat to leave the hit NBC summer series Americas Got Talent, though the network continues to treat her comments as less-than-official positioning for the future. Ms. Osbourne told The New York Post that she was quitting the show over a dispute involving her son, Jack, who was in discussions to appear in another NBC reality competition, Stars Earn Stripes, before he was found to have multiple sclerosis earlier this year. The show involves strenuous physical activity and requires that contestants pass a physical exam. An NBC spokeswoman said there had never been a contract with Jack Osbourne for Stars Earn Stripes. Ms. Osbourne told The Post there had been an oral commitment for him to take part in the show. The network is taking no public position about Ms. Osbournes future participation on Americas Got Talent, except to restate that she has a contract with the show, one she renegotiated last year.

description: ITS common in New York to see teams of college-age students handing out samples of goods like fruit juice and dog food. Even seen-everything New Yorkers may do a double-take this week, however, when they encounter street teams with hot dog carts stocked with vibrators.

title: After 3 Years Lost in Forest, a Camera Reveals Secrets to Its Home
description: John Noerr and his 5-year-old son were chasing snakes in the Adirondacks last month when they stumbled on a grimy, expensive digital camera sitting in a foot of water in a stream.

title: With Medal, Japan Clinches Rematch, Too
description: LONDON  The Japanese players who had left the game, guided by the ones who had not played in it, tiptoed toward the edge of the field just to feel a part of it.

title: Push by Syrian Rebels Opens Space for Foreign Journalists to Report on Conflict
description: As my colleagues Damien Cave and Hwaida Saad report, the White House said on Monday that President Bashar al-Assads grip on power is loosening, amid continued fighting on the streets of Syrias commercial capital, Aleppo, and the defection of the countrys prime minister.

title: Day 4 for Track and Field
description: Mondays action included the mens 400-meter sprint and hurdles, the womens pole vault and the womens 3,000-meter steeplechase.

title: Mets Byrdak Has Tear in Pitching Shoulder
description: Tim Byrdak, who was placed on the disabled list last week with soreness in his pitching shoulder, was give a diagnosis Monday of a torn anterior capsule in the shoulder.

title: After Shootings, Push in Albany for Tougher Gun Laws
description: In the wake of mass shootings in Colorado and Wisconsin and an uptick in gun violence in New York City, lawmakers are planning a new push in Albany to win approval of tighter gun laws in New York State.

title: Hughess Last Start in Detroit Marked Beginning of Turnaround
description: DETROIT  The last time Phil Hughes pitched against the Tigers in Detroit, he was coming off his worst outing of the season, a disastrous evening in his hometown, Anaheim, Calif., at the end of May, when he gave up seven runs in five and a third innings. The flight to Detroit was not a good one for Hughes, but once he arrived in the Midwest, he produced his best and perhaps most significant start of the season.

title: Two Contrasting Styles Lead to Semifinals
description: LONDON  Two women on the United States boxing team  the flyweight Marlen Esparza and the middleweight Claressa Shields  are assured of winning Olympic medals after winning their bouts on Monday to advance to the semifinals.

title: Aug. 6: Pace of Presidential Polling Has Slowed Considerably From 2008
description: As of 5 p.m. Monday, there were no new presidential polls out except for the two national tracking polls from Rasmussen Reports and Gallup. The Rasmussen numbers moved a tick toward President Obama, but its just not worth making much of a one-day shift in a tracking poll (a sustained shift over a week or longer would be more interesting).

title: Olympics as Bridge Between Nations? Not When These Teams Play
description: LONDON  Beyond the shoves and the elbows and the mutual disdain on Monday night, the latest mens basketball game/wrestling match between the United States and Argentina featured allegations of punches thrown.

title: Bruised and Beaten, but Nigerians Are Unbowed
description: LONDON  The buzzer sounded the end of the fairy tale, and the Nigerian team limped off the court in slow motion, unwilling, unable to let go. As they filed into the tunnel, the crowd stood in unison and cheered the team they call DTigers.

title: The Perfect Non-Crime
description: Greensboro, N.C.

title: Where Streets Are Thronged With Strays Baring Fangs
description: NEW DELHI  Victims of the surprise attacks limp into one of this citys biggest public hospitals. Among the hundreds on a recent day were children cornered in their homes, students ambushed on their way to class and old men ambling back from work.

title: Libor, Naked and Exposed
description: Washington

title: Quick Lunge for a Lifeline Helped Knight Capital Skirt Collapse
description: When Thomas M. Joyce arrived at Knight Capitals Jersey City offices on Sunday, the fate of his company and the legacy of his long Wall Street career were in jeopardy. His lawyers were preparing a potential bankruptcy filing throughout the day, according to people briefed on the matter, and the companys last hope rested with an eclectic group of investors.

title: Sprinter Gives Grenada Its First Medal
description: LONDON  Track and field is one of the most global sports, and its list of Olympic champions grew even more global on a chilly night when Kirani James won the mens 400 meters.

title: After a Runner Stops, the Questioning Starts
description: LONDON  Taoufik Makhloufi of Algeria is the 2011 African Games champion at 800 meters. So when he stopped running in his opening Olympic heat Monday, officials became suspicious.

title: Why Are Investors Fleeing Equities? Hint: Its Not the Computers
description: Lets stop with the excuses.

title: A Snarling Menace in India
description: Tens of millions of free-roaming dogs  and the rabies they carry  are wreaking havoc across the country.

title: Best Buy Founder Makes Bid for a Takeover
description: Best Buy has been troubled by declining sales and growing competition from the likes of Wal-Mart Stores and Amazon.com.

title: Ducking The Donald
description: Donald Trump and self-doubt: a proper noun and a human reality that have no business in the same sentence.

title: Mourning Victims, Sikhs Lament Being Mistaken for Radicals or Militants
description: Sikhs in New York and across the country on Monday mourned the deaths in the shooting rampage at one of their temples outside Milwaukee, and some said the killings revived bitter memories of the period just after the Sept. 11 attacks when their distinctive turbans and beards seemed to trigger harassment and violence by people who wrongly assumed that they were militant Muslims.

title: In the Financial Industry, a Less Scrupulous Class of Lawbreaker
description: To sit on the bench in Manhattan Criminal Court is to feel the embarrassment that comes with watching fellow New Yorkers get deeply humbled.

How Not to Pass a Bill
description: Among the many things the House never got around to doing before shutting down for the summer was holding a vote on a bill that would have granted permanent normal trade relations to Russia.

title: Cracks in British Governing Coalition as House of Lords Overhaul Falls Apart
description: LONDON  Britains two governing parties, the Conservatives and the Liberal Democrats, announced on Monday that they had abandoned attempts to overhaul the House of Lords, a development that many on both sides of the coalition government saw as evidence of its growing fragility.

title: Anosmia
description: Conjuring scents on screen, the filmmaker Jacob LaMendola profiles people with a rare condition that renders them unable to smell.

title: The Point of Exclamation
description: Anybody who has ever logged on knows that online writing begets exclamation points. A lot of exclamation points! Mocking this punctuational predilection is easy and fun. An amusing blog called Excessive Exclamation!! features photos of, for example, a Carls Jr. printed receipt with the words PLEASE LET US KNOW HOW WE DID!!! Another naysayer is Steve Martin, who recently wryly Tweeted:

title: Anosmia
description: To watch the video, press the play button on the image.

title: Obama Tells a Tale of Romney Hood
description: President Obama has been looking for new ways to keep pressing the same attack on Mitt Romneys tax plan, and on Monday, he coined a phrase he hopes will stick: Romney Hood.

title: In Germany, Talk of the Olympics Centers on a Rowers Choice of Boyfriend
description: BERLIN  The Olympics would not be the Olympics if the personal lives of the athletes did not play a major role in the event. But the love life of one young athlete has become the focus of a nation  not as an inspirational story but as a cautionary tale.

title: Interim Principal Named for Stuyvesant High School as Cheating Inquiry Unfolds
For Women in Street Stops, Deeper Humiliation
description: Shari Archibalds black handbag sat at her feet on the sidewalk in front of her Bronx home on a recent summer night. The two male officers crouched over her leather bag and rooted around inside, elbow-deep. One officer fished out a tampon and then a sanitary napkin, crinkling the waxy orange wrapper between his fingers in search of drugs. Next he pulled out a tray of foil-covered pills, Ms. Archibald recalled.

title: Son Is Charged in Case of Faked Drowning
description: The police on Monday arrested the son of a Long Island man who the authorities say tried to fake his own death last month. They said they charged the son with aiding his fathers scheme to collect life insurance money.

title: Lottery Numbers
If Assad Falls in Syria
description: President Bashar al-Assads security forces are continuing to kill Syrians in huge numbers, but the oppositions chances of prevailing look better than they did six months ago. The challenge for the United States and its partners is not just to step up the pressure, but also to prepare the ground for a constructive future for Syria.

title: Occupys Frankfurt Camp Is Closed as Health Hazard
description: FRANKFURT  Police in riot gear methodically cleared a tent city at the doorstep of the European Central Bank on Monday, ending months of tolerance for the encampment, following complaints that it had become more of an eyesore and health hazard than a protest against global capitalism.

title: Business Fears the Fiscal Cliff
description: So it turns out that federal spending is important to the economy after all.

title: Horace Mann Details Steps to Address Sexual Abuse Cases
description: After two months of deliberations, the Horace Mann School announced on Monday a series of steps, including increased training for faculty members and instruction for students, to address reports of past sexual abuse at the school.

title: A Thematic Complaint
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Im not big on quote themes, but this is not a quote. This is a joke, and Im all about the jokes.

title: Corrections: August 7, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Prayer in Missouri
description: Voters in Missouri on Tuesday will get to decide on an amendment to the State Constitution, which is supposedly intended to clarify the status of religion in Missouris public places. According to the amendments sponsor, Representative Mike McGhee, a Republican in the State House, the measure is needed to make clear that prayer is a right.

title: A Governors Gift to Nature
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has joined the honor role of governors and conservation groups that have stepped forward at critical moments to protect large parts of the Adirondacks from commercial development. On Sunday, Mr. Cuomo announced that the State of New York had bought 69,000 acres of timberland from the Nature Conservancy, including stretches of the upper Hudson River watershed. The purchase is the largest single addition in more than a century to the states forever wild forest preserve and will be open to hunting, fishing and recreational use but not to homebuilding and logging.

title: Afghan Transfer on Pace After Firings, General Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Faced with a sudden shift in two critical Afghan security ministries after Parliament dismissed the departments chiefs over the weekend, the new leader of the international joint command here insisted that allied forces would not let the shake-up derail the transfer of authority to Afghan forces.

title: Japan Utility Shows Recordings of Nuclear Crisis
description: TOKYO  Recordings of teleconferences between the Tokyo headquarters of the stricken Fukushima nuclear power plant and the plants managers in the early days of last years accident offer a firsthand account of the last-ditch  and ultimately unsuccessful  attempts to avert multiple meltdowns in the unfolding nuclear disaster.

title: A Tree Falls, Twice, Killing All the Power to Greenwich
description: Greenwich, Conn., may be one of the wealthiest towns in one of the wealthiest states in the country, but it is still vulnerable to the clout of a single tree.

title: U.S. Womens Soccer Wins in Thriller
description: The United States last-minute victory from start to finish, as seen in photos.

title: Christie Signs Bill Overhauling Job Guarantees for Teachers
description: It will be harder for public-school teachers in New Jersey to get tenure and easier to fire bad ones under legislation signed on Monday by Gov. Chris Christie that overhauls the states century-old tenure law.

title: Trial Due for Pastor in Dispute on Custody
description: The curious involvement of an Amish-Mennonite sect in a high-profile case of international parental kidnapping will be on display  and perhaps become clearer  in a courtroom in Burlington, Vt., this week.

title: U.S. Mens Basketball Stays Undefeated With Win Over Argentina
description: The Group A game featured physical play and high scoring from both teams.

title: Marguerite Piazza, Popular Singer of Opera, Dies at 86
description: Marguerite Piazza had a voice that could pack a concert hall and a figure that transfixed television audiences. She was sought out for ribbon cuttings and commercial endorsements and once performed as part of a Super Bowl halftime show.

title: Verlander Dominates the Yankees While Nova Proves Ineffective Again
description: DETROIT  On April 20, after a decent performance against the Boston Red Sox, Ivan Nova noted that if asked, he would say he is the best pitcher in the world, a comment meant to express self-confidence more than a critical assessment of his talent. Nova is certainly not the best in the world, especially after another dismal outing Monday. But a strong case could be made for the man who beat him.

title: Chavela Vargas, Mexican Ranchera Singer, Dies at 93
description: MEXICO CITY  Chavela Vargas, whose tender yet fierce interpretations of Mexicos classic ranchera songs made her a star in Latin America and Spain, died on Sunday in Cuernavaca, Mexico. She was 93.

title: Celebrities Turn Out for Obama Fund-Raising Event
description: President Obama finished an evening of fund-raising at a star-studded event at the Connecticut home of the movie mogul Harvey Weinstein on Monday night, and even offered his personal review of the latest Batman movie.

title: Tales and Drinks Dont Stop at the Ricks Caf of the Hamptons
description: SAG HARBOR, N.Y.  A lot of the talk at the American Hotel is about the American Hotel.

title: Zambia: Chinese Supervisor Dies During Protest at Mine
description: Workers striking at a Chinese-owned coal mine killed a Chinese supervisor when they hit him with a coal trolley, officials of the mine workers union said Monday. Employees at the Collum Coal Mine staged a protest over the weekend, demanding that their pay be raised to match Zambias new minimum wage for laborers of about $230 a month, which was announced last month. China has invested heavily in Zambia, a major producer of copper, coal and other minerals. Chinese companies in Zambia have long been accused of mistreating and underpaying their workers, and violence has broken out at the Collum mine during labor disputes in the past. President Michael Sata was elected last year on a largely anti-China platform, but has softened his position since taking office.

title: Russia: Suicide Bombers Strike at Military Unit in Chechnya
description: Suicide attacks against a military vehicle left four people dead and wounded three on Monday on the outskirts of Grozny, the capital of Chechnya, in Russias volatile North Caucasus region. A spokesman for the Russian Interior Ministry said two suicide bombers ambushed an armored military van near a police checkpoint outside of the city. The dual explosions killed three members of a military unit and wounded three others. A fourth body, presumed to be that of one of the bombers, was also found at the scene. The bombing is the first suicide attack in Grozny in nearly a year. Moscow has been battling separatists in Chechnya since the 1990s, but a leader backed by the Kremlin has cracked down on the insurgency.

title: For U.S. Volleyball Leader, Victories on Court and Off
description: LONDON  The stew of cultures served up by the Olympics is comfort food for Donald Suxho, the starting setter for the United States Olympic mens volleyball team who immigrated from Albania in the 1990s and met his Ukrainian-born wife in 2005 while playing professionally in Greece.

title: A Struggling Voting Bloc
description: Because single women have fared the worst among women during the economic downturn, some of their votes could be up for grabs as the message of a better economy becomes more appealing.

title: Weymouth Journal: British Victory Spurs Sausage Sales
description: Periodically throughout the Olympics, The New York Times will check in with Dennis Spurr, owner of the Fantastic Sausage Factory in Weymouth, England, a pretty town on the coast where the sailing events are taking place. Spurrs sausage business was targeted by the Olympic branding authorities in 2007 after he put up a sign featuring the Olympic five-ring logo fashioned out of sausage links. He took it down on their demands but replaced it with a sign featuring five squares made out of sausage links.

title: Joy and Therapy in Making Confetti
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  With great satisfaction, Margaret Carver dumped a few bags of old tax returns and bank statements into a plastic trash container here in front of the Central Square post office. Then Bob Luce, a driver for DataShredder, pushed the container into the metal arms of his mobile shredding truck.

title: Robert Hughes, Art Critic Whose Writing Was Elegant and Contentious, Dies at 74
description: Robert Hughes, the eloquent, combative art critic and historian who lived with operatic flair and wrote with a sense of authority that owed more to Zola or Ruskin than to his own century, died on Monday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 74 and had lived for many years in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: Day 12: What to Watch For
description: Here are some of the events, teams and athletes to watch on Tuesday at the London Games. (All times Eastern.)

description: bigotry \bi-g-tre\ noun

title: Fed Officials Underscore Divisions Over Action
description: WASHINGTON  A senior Federal Reserve official said Monday that the employment data released last week had reinforced his view that the Fed must act to increase economic growth.

description: Shaila Dewan reports on single women as a voting demographic that proved crucial for Barack Obama in 2008.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,057 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: In Weak Economy, an Opening to Court Votes of Single Women
description: LAS VEGAS  Being single, Alyson Sheradin had no one to rely on when the financial crisis hit. She lost the considerable savings she had tucked away after selling her business in 2002, and struggled to find work as a business consultant, recently moving in with a friend in the suburbs who does not charge her rent.

title: In-Person Visits Fade as Jails Set Up Video Units for Inmates and Families
description: WASHINGTON  Shatterproof glass used to separate inmates at the District of Columbia jail from the visitors sitting across from them. Now, they sit in separate buildings, at computers equipped with Web cameras.

title: Aides Fees Draw Critics and, Then, Defenders
description: WASHINGTON  The White House defended President Obamas senior adviser on Monday for taking $100,000 in speaking fees before joining the government from a subsidiary of a company working with the Iranian government.

title: Mob Figure Plans to Testify in His Own Defense at Trial
description: BOSTON  James (Whitey) Bulger, the feared Boston mob boss accused of committing 19 murders three decades ago, intends to take the stand at his own trial, his lawyer, J. W. Carney Jr., said Monday.

title: Wisconsin Killer Was Fueled by Hate-Driven Music
description: His music, Wade M. Page once said, was about how the value of human life has been degraded by tyranny,' Erica Goode and Serge F. Kovaleski wrote in The New York Times, of the music by the suspect of the Wisconsin shooting.

title: Romney Team Outpaces Obama in Fund-Raising Again
description: The fund-raising machine behind Mitt Romney and the Republican Party once again outperformed President Obama and the Democrats last month, raising $25 million more in July than the president and his Democratic allies.

title: Too Much Olympic Fever in China?
description: HONG KONG  China continues to lead the Olympic medal standings, just ahead of the United States, as the country tries to repeat its breakout performance at the 2008 Beijing Games.

title: Being Sikh in America
description: On Sunday, my wife and I were having a quiet brunch with friends at home in Pennsylvania when the phone started ringing. First my parents called from their home in Maryland. Then a cousin called from India. Have you seen whats on CNN? Theres been a shooting at a gurdwara in Wisconsin I felt a familiar emptiness. I had felt the same way after the morning of September 11, 2001.

title: News Quiz | August 7, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

Among the hundreds on a recent day were children cornered in their homes, students ambushed on their way to class and old men ambling back from work.

title: Delhi Strays Thrive on Affection From a Few
description: Indias vast population of stray dogs mostly survives on mounds of garbage, but there are many Indians who routinely feed the dogs out of a sense of charity and love.

title: Afghan Minibus May Have Been Mistaken Target
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A man who had been arrested on suspicion of insurgent activity and then released by the Afghan authorities detonated a remote-controlled bomb along a road outside Kabul on Tuesday, killing at least eight people in a packed minibus, the Afghan police said.

title: Test Yourself | English, Aug. 7, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article For Wealthy Indian Family, Palatial House Is Not a Home.

title: Is Michigan State Really Better Than Yale?
description: During the M.B.A. gold rush of the past three decades, the Yale School of Management accomplished the unthinkable. As the number of prospective business-school candidates shot up to more than 750,000 a year and tuition payments cleared $100,000, Harvard, Stanford, the University of Chicago and other schools hired star faculty members, built gleaming buildings, established themselves as global brands and brought in tens (and sometimes hundreds) of millions in profits to their universities each year. Meanwhile, Yale somehow lost money.

title: Photographing the Olympics: The 400-Millimeter Dash
description: The New York Times staff photographer Doug Mills is covering his fifth summer Olympics, and he has photographed seven winter games. He spoke with James Estrin by phone. The interview has been edited.

title: Miami Dolphins, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
description: O.K., so maybe HBO did not get the most glamorous team for this years Hard Knocks. Not a problem  you can still win Emmys with the Miami Dolphins. Since the day he bought this team for $1.1 billion, the owner Stephen Ross has made no secret about his desire to turn the Dolphins into an entertainment darling. No gimmick is too kitschy for Ross  anything to combat the empty orange seats that have become ubiquitous at (Whatever the latest sponsors name is) Stadium. Scoff if you want, but in the maddeningly apathetic South Beach sports community, kitschy gimmicks are part of doing business.

description: In March, The Choice introduced a series called Counselors Calendar, to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

description: Early August brings one of the final big waiver-wire pickup periods, as the fallout of the trade deadline and the flurry of prospects getting their first taste of the big leagues offer potential impact heading into the final two months. Heres a look at a few players who are available in many leagues and capable of providing a boost down the stretch.
