description: GoPago

title: The Secret of Neuromarketing: Go for the Pain
description: We all like to think we make buying decisions on a rational level, but neuroscientists tell us otherwise. While marketers have known this instinctively, brain mappers have shown that the smallest part of the brain, the amygdala, lights up like a Christmas tree when confronted with fight-or-flight or in this case buy-or-fly situations.

title: Liu of China Crashes Out of 110-Meter Mens Hurdles
description: LONDON  The champion hurdler Liu Xiang, the most prominent athlete from China competing in the London Games, suffered another painful Olympic exit on Tuesday morning.

title: Tibetan Woman Dies in Western China Blaze, Reports Say
description: BEIJING  A Tibetan woman, Dolkar Kyi, 26, killed herself through self-immolation at a monastery on Tuesday afternoon in a Tibetan area of China, according to Free Tibet, an advocacy group based in London.

title: Iran Inquiry Is Abrupt Reversal for Standard Chartered
description: 6:07 p.m. | Updated

title: The Drumbeat of Ramadan
description: ISTANBUL  It is the holy month of Ramadan and, just before twilight, my Istanbul neighborhood fills with an intoxicating smell from the two wood-fire oven bakeries feverishly producing loaf after crusty loaf of seasonal bread. Theres a bustle of last-minute shopping and of people rushing to get home. When the sun finally goes down and the call to prayer comes, the streets are eerily silent except for the clink of cutlery from open apartment windows as families sit down to break the fast.

title: Near Injection Wells, Many Quakes Go Unfelt
description: A series of small earthquakes made Halloween of 2008 an unusually scary one for people in the Dallas-Fort Worth area. While it has long been theorized that underground injections of fluids from oil and gas development operations could decrease friction and cause faults to slip, the quakes occurred in an area where people werent accustomed to tremors, renewing calls for research into the geological consequences of the booming natural gas industry in Texas.

title: Minnesota Minefield for a Best Buy Deal
description: Before Richard Schulze can acquire and turn around Best Buy, he needs to come to terms with the State of Minnesota.

title: Reviving Thomas Browne, an Expert on Oblivion
description: Back when the English language was still young and impressionable, a London-born physician who took up the pen as a gentlemans hobby made quite a dent, fathering a dictionary pages worth of words we still use and tend to think of as ageless  medical, suicide, exhaustion, hallucination and coma among them.

title: Thus, Just So
description: [PLEASE NOTE: After Deadline will be on vacation for two weeks and will return on Tuesday, Aug. 28.]

title: 10 Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of Cosmo
description: When I asked my friends about Cosmopolitan to prepare for my recentarticle in The Times Magazine, some said they wouldnt be caught dead with a copy outside a doctors office or an airplane. But it turns out that reading Cosmo on an airplane  which Im doing right now  is way, way more intense than reading it at home, because when youre poring over an article about putting a [whatever] in or around your [whatever], and touching his [whatever] in [whatever method], while trying to lean over the magazine in such a way that hides the almost-naked people in the photographs  I dont know. It was much easier at home!

title: Afghan Defense Minister Announces Resignation
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistans defense minister announced his resignation on Tuesday, just three days after Parliament voted to dismiss him and another minister as part of an effort to end corruption.

title: DreamWorks Animation Plans Shanghai Entertainment District
description: SHANGHAI  DreamWorks Animation SKG, the Hollywood studio behind hits like Shrek, Kung Fu Panda and Madagascar, said on Tuesday that it planned to develop a $3.1 billion cultural and entertainment district in Shanghai with a group of Chinese partners.

title: London Live: Follow Tuesdays Action at the Olympics
description: The track and field action kicked off on Tuesday and started with a crash: Liu Xiang of China tumbling out of the heats of the 110-meter hurdles, taking the 2004 gold medalist out of the competition and flashing back to his similar flameout in Beijing. The womens hurdles provided legitimate excitement, with Sally Pearson of Australia just holding off American Dawn Harper, the 2008 gold medalist, by .02 seconds. Kellie Wells of the United States finished third and Lolo Jones was fourth.

title: Comedian Explains His Act After Comedy Central Cuts Jokes on Colorado Shootings
description: The comedian Jeffrey Ross says that the tradition of the celebrity roast is one of the last bastions of free speech. title: Front-Row Fashion Defines Delhis Couture Week
description: India Couture Week begins tomorrow, and this means that Delhis most beautiful women are now in full preparation mode. For them, the real fashion show happens in the first row. title: The Breakfast Meeting: Sikh Temple Shooters Hate-Filled Music, and the Apple-Google Chill
description: Wade M. Page, an Army veteran and rock singer who killed six people and wounded three others when he opened fire on Sunday in a Sikh temple in Oak Creek, Wis., was among hundreds of people tracked by the Southern Poverty Law Center for his ties to the white supremacist movement and his role as the leader of a white-power band called End Apathy, Erica Goode and Serge F. Kovaleski report. In an interview posted on the Web site of the record company Label56 (and since taken down), Mr. Page mentioned going to Hammerfest, an annual white-supremacist festival; he also said he played in various neo-Nazi bands, including Blue Eyed Devils, whose song White Victory includes the lines: Now Ill fight for my race and nation/Sieg Heil!

title: Life Term for Gunman After Guilty Plea in Tucson Killings
description: TUCSON  Jared L. Loughner pleaded guilty on Tuesday to killing six people and wounding 13 others last year during a meet-and-greet event here held by Gabrielle Giffords, then a member of the House of Representatives and the primary target of his rampage. The plea brought a sudden resolution to a case that seemed threatened by the fragility of Mr. Loughners mental state.

title: Rubik Nation
description: Rubik's cube whizzes compete - some using blindfolds or their feet -  at the United States National Rubik's Cube Championship in Las Vegas.

title: Models, Models, Everywhere
description: We assign a lot of bandwidth to the FiveThirtyEight presidential forecast model, but that doesnt mean its the only thing you should look at to get a sense for where the election is headed. So its time for a quick gut-check. How does the FiveThirtyEight model  where Barack Obamas probability of winning the Electoral College recently ticked above 70 percent  compare against alternative means of forecasting the election?

title: Delayed Release of Gatsby Creates Room in Awards Season
description: LOS ANGELES  With the decision by Warner Brothers to delay its 3-D version of The Great Gatsby, directed by Baz Luhrmann, until a still unnamed date next summer, a somewhat hazy Hollywood awards season gets a little clarity  but not much.

title: For Japans Soccer Teams, a Question of Equality
description: LONDON  Japans national soccer teams made waves on their way to the Olympics last month when the mens team, which is made up mostly of under-23 players, sat in business class on the flight to Europe while the womens team, which won last years World Cup, sat in economy class.

title: The Dread of the Unknown
description: The devil we dont know is lurking in the financial system.

title: Image of the Day: August 7
Rains Flood a Third of Manila Area, Displacing Thousands
description: MANILA At least a third of this overpopulated capital and its suburbs were submerged on Tuesday as torrential rains battered the city and floodwaters poured in from almost all sides.

title: 31-Year-Old Killed in a Brooklyn Hit and Run
description: A 31-year-old man was fatally struck on Monday evening by a hit-and-run driver in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, the police said. The driver was arrested three blocks away.

title: Business Day Live | August 7, 2012
description: Regulators accuse Standard Chartered of laundering billions for Iran. | Betting on a takeover to save Best Buy. | Finding unjustified medical procedures at hospital chain HCA.

title: How to Parse Climate Change and Extreme Weather?
description: James E. Hansen, the irrepressible NASA scientist who was among the first to sound the alarm about human-caused global warming, has roiled the scientific community again with a new scientific paper explicitly linking high concentrations of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases to recent severe heat waves and drought.

title: Suspensions Are Higher for Disabled Students, Federal Data Indicate
description: Students with disabilities are almost twice as likely to be suspended from school as nondisabled students, with the highest rates among black children with disabilities.

title: The New Black
description: For years the London-based designer Markus Lupfer and the British retailer Asos.com have made cool and quirky clothes for women  at very different price points (Lupfer, high; Asos, low). Now theyve gone into business together and are meeting in the middle, offering a 10-piece, all leather, kaleidoscope-patterned collection for the Asos Black label (available in October). I love the cutout skater dress, Lupfer says. It is so cute and fun. Along the lines of Lupfers own ready-to-wear brand  which features glitter-bombed cocktail dresses and loudmouthed graphic tops  Asos Black includes tailored track pants, boxy shell tops, hot-shorts and pencil skirts, as well as pouchettes and utilitarian heels to complete the look. The collaboration hits what Lupfer calls the nonintimidating (read: cost-effective) side of high fashion, which is probably why he can comfortably add, The girls in my office want it all.

title: To the Polls, Ye Sons of Freedom! And Bring a MetroCard.
description: Your Pollsite May Have Changed, said the glossy mailer from the Board of Elections that arrived last week at the homes of nearly 1,200 active registered voters (including this reporter) who live in the West 60s.

title: Iran Envoy Casts Syria as Part of Wider Conflict
description: BEIRUT  Iran moved on Tuesday to reframe the Syrian conflict as part of a wider battle with the United States and other hostile world powers, dispatching the personal representative of its paramount leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, to Damascus for a televised display of solidarity with Syrias president as battles raged and dozens of Iranian hostages in rebel custody were threatened with death.

title: Womens Magazines Lead Overall Decline in Newsstand Sales
description: 8:12 p.m. | Updated

title: Why Attack American Muslim Women in Government?
description: Is it fear, a lack of knowledge or their sincere belief that drives some American politicians to question the loyalty of some high-profile Muslim women working for the U.S. government?

title: Should a Wine List Educate or Merely Flatter You?
description: PICTURE yourself on a first visit to a new restaurant. It could be French, Greek, Spanish, even American, specializing in the cuisine of any country with a wide-ranging wine industry.

title: A Florida Island Draws an Array of Seashells and Their Hunters
description: SANIBEL ISLAND, Fla.  The tide is low. The sun crawls toward the ocean for a final dip. The time is here: The hunt is on.

title: Jefferies Raises Questions About Schulzes Best Buy Holdings
description: As part of his audacious takeover proposal for Best Buy, the company he founded decades ago, Richard Schulze said that he would contribute about $1 billion of his holdings into a leveraged buyout offer.

title: Americans for Prosperity Begins $25 Million Anti-Obama Ad Campaign
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Americans for Prosperity, the Tea Party organization backed by the Koch brothers, is set to begin a $25 million advertising assault aimed at President Obama, its largest effort to date.

title: Grenada Moves to the Top of This List
description: LONDON  Go get em, Grenada. On Monday, we highlighted which teams have won the most medals per capita. Based on this formula, Slovenia, with four medals and just over two million people, led the leader board. China and the United States, which have the most aggregate medals, were further down the list on a per-capita basis.

title: Elizabeths Braised Leeks With Parmesan
description: My friend Elizabeth tells me that even people who think they dont like leeks like this dish. The leeks are braised in wine and water or stock until soft and golden, then topped with Parmesan and run under a broiler, so you get a crunchy layer on top of soft cooked leeks. One of the tricks here is to discard the outer layers that become papery when you cook them, so that the whole leek will be soft and easy to cut through.

title: An iPhone Case With a Focus on Photos
description: The protective cases from Gizmon leave no doubt as to what your favorite iPhone feature is; they make your phone look like a vintage Leica (a look-aLeica?) and add camera features.

title: Sabines Stuffed Zucchini Flowers
description: We found zucchini flowers, just picked that morning, at the market in a little town called Creste, and we snatched them up. You can use the same filling for stuffed tomatoes. The bread is soaked in milk, so if you have some stale bread lying around, this is a great use for it.

title: For Chinese Hurdler, an Achilles Heel Again Lives Up to Its Name
description: LONDON  As usual when Liu Xiang hurdles, it is difficult to avoid the bigger picture.

description: Last week, Mitt Romney declared thatif his new, one-page economic policy plan were implemented, the country would add 12 million new jobs by the end of [his] first term.

title: In Oregon, Truffles Are No Match for Wet Noses
description: REDLAND, Ore.

description: Three days after the shooting in Aurora, Colo., the National Rifle Association did what it does best  it sent a letter to supporters asking for money.

title: Lonely Shapes, Secret Worlds
description: These edited and condensed reviews are from the writers and editors of the gaming Web site Kotaku.com. Full reviews are at kotaku.com/nytselects.

title: Salade Nioise With Yogurt Vinaigrette
description: The market tomatoes, green beans, peppers, cucumbers and lettuces were irresistible, and we would have been happy to dine on this iconic Provenal salad every day. Im making the anchovies optional in this recipe, but they are always included in the authentic salade nioise.

title: Obama Wraps Himself in Olympic Glory
description: WASHINGTON  One of the two major candidates for president actually ran an Olympics, made a point of visiting this years Games in London and has a wife with a personal stake in one of the events.

title: Wheelies: The $3 Billion Blockage Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Rafalca, Owned by Romneys Wife, Does Not Advance in Dressage
description: LONDON  As he rode into the ring on his horse, Rafalca, the equestrian Jan Ebeling blew a kiss to a few women in the stands he calls the three amigos: his wife, Amy Ebeling; Beth Meyer; and Ann Romney, whose husband, Mitt, is the presumptive presidential candidate of the Republican Party.

title: Judith Crist, a Blunt and Influential Film Critic, Dies at 90
description: Judith Crist, one of Americas most widely read film critics for more than three decades and a provocative presence in millions of homes as a regular reviewer on the Today show, died Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 90.

description: My better half: Are you sure about this? Theyll kill you.

description: Bowhead whale calls recorded in Fram Strait in November 2010.

title: Rafalca Does Not Advance in Olympic Dressage
description: LONDON  As he rode into the ring on his horse, Rafalca, the equestrian Jan Ebeling blew a kiss to a few women in the stands he calls the three amigos: his wife, Amy Ebeling; Beth Meyer; and Ann Romney, whose husband, Mitt, is the presumptive presidential candidate for the Republican Party.

title: New York Comedy Festival Unveils 2012 Lineup
description: Kevin Hart, Bill Maher, Robin Williams and Aziz Ansari are among the funnymen who will be featured at this years New York Comedy Festival, its organizers announced on Tuesday. The five-day festival, which is produced by Carolines on Broadway in association with Comedy Central, will kick off its ninth year on Nov. 7, beginning with a Next Big Thing event at the Paley Center for Media and an interview with Ricky Gervais, in conversation with John Hodgman, at Town Hall.

title: The Daily Shoe | YSL
description: In honor of Bergdorf Goodmans 111th anniversary, Ts Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the stores famous shoe salon. Todays pick: A gold-toed flat from YSL.

title: Americans Bag Delivery Lets You Skip the Carousel
description: First there were fees for checked bags. Then for carry-ons. Now, American Airlines is adding a fee, but this time its for a perk that had not been previously included in the price of a ticket: baggage delivery to the address of a passengers choosing.

title: The Affordable Care Act Rebate Checks Are in the Mail: Now What?
description: Some small businesses were among the most strident opponents of the Affordable Care Act, but by Wednesday, many of these businesses will have received checks totaling $321 million from their health insurance providers, courtesy of the health care overhaul that became law in 2010. The checks are rebates from insurers that did not spend at least 80 percent of the premiums they collected from small group plans on either actual health care expenses or improving the quality of health care, a provision known as the medical loss ratio rule.

title: Iran Warns U.S. on Fate of Hostages in Syria
description: TEHRAN  Iran said Tuesday that it was holding the United States responsible for the fate of a group of Iranians held by Syrian rebels, as the highest-ranking Iranian official to visit Syria since the antigovernment uprising began there arrived in Damascus to show support for President Bashar al-Assad and attempt to secure the release of the hostages.

title: The Daily Shoe | YSL
description: In honor of Bergdorf Goodmans 111th anniversary, Ts Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the stores famous shoe salon. Todays pick: A gold-toed flat from YSL.

title: Russian Booster Rocket Fails to Deliver Satellites
description: MOSCOW  A Russian booster rocket carrying two telecommunications satellites malfunctioned during a launching early Tuesday, failing to deliver the satellites into their proper orbit and rendering them useless and unsalvageable.

title: Corporate Fraud Cases Often Spare Individuals
description: WASHINGTON  Pharmaceutical companies, military contractors, banks and other corporations are on track to pay as much as $8 billion this year to resolve charges of defrauding the government, analysts say  a record sum and more than twice the amount assessed last year by the Justice Department.

title: Marvin Hamlisch in Song
description: Videos from some of the films and musicals featuring the composers music.

title: Jessica Hecht and Judith Light to Star in New Richard Greenberg Play
description: Jessica Hecht and Judith Light, who won a Tony Award this year for her performance in Other Desert Cities, will star next spring in the world premiere of Richard Greenbergs new play, The Assembled Parties, the Manhattan Theater Club said on Tuesday.

title: Shopping Snapshots: August 9
description: A fresh crop of leather dresses better suited to real life; the oversize glossy street-culture magazine Sneeze can be found in conspicuously located street boxes; and Jade Lai, the owner of the hip downtown boutique Creatures of Comfort, discusses her picks for fall.

title: U.S. Coach Keeps Talking, and His Team Keeps Winning
description: LONDON  The United States womens basketball team battered another overmatched opponent Tuesday. Afterward, Geno Auriemma talked the way only Geno Auriemma can.

description: MANCHESTER, England

title: Jamaicas Blake Faces 200 With a Nudge From Bolt
description: LONDON  Yohan Blake is young and fast, but if he leaves the London Olympics without a gold medal in the individual sprints, it will be his own fault. Hes the one who woke up the sleeping giant.

title: Christie, Rubio and Ryan
description: An addendum to Bill Kristol and Stephen Hayess Weekly Standard case that Mitt Romney should choose either Marco Rubio or Paul Ryan as his running mate raises the possibility that Romney might still be considering Chris Christie:

title: Pfizer Settles U.S. Charges of Bribing Doctors Abroad
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced on Tuesday that it had reached a $45 million settlement with Pfizer to resolve charges that subsidiaries of Pfizer and Wyeth, which it acquired in 2009, bribed overseas doctors and other health care workers to increase sales of their drugs.

title: Pregnant, Depressed and Surprised
description: A pregnancy (especially a first pregnancy) is in so many ways a rabbit hole.

title: British Brothers Are Again Atop an Increasingly Popular Sport
description: LONDON  To win a medal at the mens Olympic triathlon Tuesday, it took a band of brothers, not all of them related. Alistair Brownlee, the prohibitive favorite, delivered Britain its 19th gold medal of these Games with an 11-second victory over Javier Gmez of Spain. Brownlees younger brother, Jonathan, was 31 seconds back, in third.

title: Scenes in Tableau: Drama Strategies to Use With Any Days Times (Part 2)
description: This week is Drama Week on The Learning Network, and weve teamed with David Kener, a teacher and former executive director of the American Place Theater Literature to Life Program, to bring you different strategies daily for using theater techniques in classes across the curriculum.

title: Historical Society Exhibit to Focus on World War II and New York City
description: Helping to fill the seemingly endless appetite for information about World War II, the New-York Historical Society is planning a major exhibition on the conflicts effect on the homefront this fall.

title: NBC Nightly News Adds Three Million Viewers From Olympics
description: Nothing has helped the recently flagging fortunes of NBC News like the injection of large audiences after coverage of the Olympics on the network this summer.

title: Nicoletta
description: Inside the chef Michael Whites new pizzeria in the East Village.

title: On Our Radar: Manila as Waterworld
description: Deadly torrential rains worsened by a tropical storm submerge over half of the Philippine capital. The storm is now headed for Zhejiang Province in China, where more than 250,000 people have been evacuated ahead of its anticipated landfall late Wednesday. [Reuters]

title: Broadway Shows Closings Are Good for Business
description: Three Broadway productions saw expected upticks at the box office last week given that their runs were coming to an end, two newcomers showed mixed results and big-ticket shows that have been dominant for months mostly held steady, according to the weekly grosses and other data released by the productions.

title: Alongside Rudolphs Ilk, Yoiking in Lapland
description: Nils-Heikki Paltto is far from the only reindeer herder who hates wolverines, loves the solitude of tracking his herd on snowmobile during the dim Arctic winter, and knows how to yoik, a form of singing that falls somewhere between a chant and a yodel. Yoiking is the unique tradition of his Sami people, the indigenous group that populates (minimally) the northern stretches of Norway, Sweden and Finland that we call Lapland.

title: The Quotable Robert Hughes
description: It often seemed as if Robert Hughes, the critic and historian who died Monday at 74, never wrote a bad sentence. And he wrote many hundreds of thousands of them in a wildly industrious career that stretched over almost a half-century, in books, in the pages of Time magazine and in almost any publication that asked him. Here is a highly subjective selection of some of his best:

title: N.H.T.S.A. to Pedestrians: The Streets Are Getting Meaner
description: On Monday, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration issued an advisory to pedestrians after statistics showed pedestrian fatalities rose by 4 percent in 2010 relative to their levels in 2009. The statistics represented the most recent fatality data available to the federal government as reported by individual states. N.H.T.S.A. expects to release final numbers for 2011 later this year.

title: An Empire Stretches Its Dough
description: IN an earlier, more primitive era, chefs with an entrepreneurial urge believed that success began with a delicious product. If you cooked something that enough people wanted to eat, you could build an empire that might one day span the country. First, though, you needed 11 secret herbs and spices. You needed special sauce. You needed Hot Doughnuts Now.

title: Congressional Primaries in Missouri and Michigan Among Those to Watch
description: Nope, sorry. The Congressional primaries are not over yet.

title: One on One: Steve Mann, Wearable Computing Pioneer
description: Steve Mann is considered by many to be the worlds first cyborg. He has been using wearable computers that assist his vision since the 1970s. Now he wears a display screen over his right eye and is connected to a computer and the Internet. In this edited interview, he discusses mediated reality; the coming wearable-computing wars among Apple, Google and RIM; and thebrain-computer interface.

title: An Outsize Ring on a Living-Room Scale
description: I have seen segments of the Metropolitan Operas latest production of Wagners Ring cycle, directed by Robert Lepage, from various perspectives in addition to performances in the house: Das Rheingold projected onto large screens in Times Square (in a deluge) and in an HD screening at a movie theater in Ellsworth, Me.; Die Walkre in HD at a theater in Manhattan. Soon I will be able to view it in the intimacy of my living room, and you will too, on eight DVDS or five Blu-ray discs, to be released by Deutsche Grammophon on Sept. 11.

title: Pictures of the Day From London | August 7, 2012
description: The 12th day of the London Olympics.

title: So Where do Guys Eat, After All?
description: Guy food. What is it? Well, its manly, see. Turns out there are guy-food categories: steakhouses, barbecue joints, seafood shacks, brew pubs, taco stands, pizza parlors, burger spots, sandwich places and adventurous eating. And now Mens Health magazine has announced the nine finalists, one in each of those categories, for its 2012 Manliest Restaurants in America competition.

title: Leader, but Never the Winner
description: LONDON  The capacity crowd at the Olympic Velodrome on Tuesday roars in anticipation. Six highly trained and fit cyclists set off on a race for gold.

title: Returning to Campaign Trail, Romney Presses Welfare Attack
description: ELK GROVE VILLAGE, Ill.  Mitt Romney returned to the campaign trail on Tuesday to press a theme that his campaign had hit earlier in the day  with a new advertisement, accusing President Obama of gutting the work requirement at the heart of the federal welfare program, a message designed to peel away middle-class votes from the president.

title: Indigestion for les Riches in a Plan for Higher Taxes
description: PARIS  The call to Vincent Grandils Paris law firm began like many others that have rolled in recently. On the line was the well-paid chief executive of one of Frances most profitable companies, and he was feeling nervous.

title: For One Kenyan Olympian, Throwing Beats Running
description: LONDON  Kenya has sent 44 track and field athletes to the London Games. Forty-three are runners who aspire to win gold medals from 800 meters to the marathon. The other is Julius Yego, javelin thrower.

title: In Squawk Box Case, a Delicate Line for Prosecutors
description: An appeals court ruling that reversed the convictions of six brokers and traders for misusing brokerage firm squawk boxes was a setback for the Justice Department.

title: Flooding Worsens in the Philippines
description: Thousands fled the capital, Manila, on Tuesday as flooding spread, leaving some residents stranded on their roofs awaiting rescue.

title: Lugar Urges U.S. and Russia to Team Up to Rid Syria of Chemical Weapons
description: MOSCOW  Senator Richard G. Lugar, the Indiana Republican who has been a leading proponent of joint efforts by the United States and Russia to reduce their arsenals of nuclear and chemical weapons, urged on Tuesday that the two countries team up to eliminate the stockpile of chemical weapons in Syria.

title: With Block Lifted, Paris to Cut Vehicle Traffic Along the Seine
description: PARIS  A dream project of the Socialist mayor of Paris to reduce car traffic along the banks of the Seine has been unblocked by Frances new Socialist government.

title: Luxury Living in Old Temple of the 5 and Dime
description: The Woolworth Buildings neo-Gothic tower, one of New York Citys most recognizable landmarks, is about to be turned into luxury condominiums, a transformation that would be second only to placing penthouses atop the Chrysler Building or the Empire State Building.

description: Click.

title: Philip Marlowe Set to Return in Novel by John Banville
description: Philip Marlowe is making another comeback. Henry Holt & Company said on Tuesday that Raymond Chandlers creation, one of the worlds most famous private eyes, will star in a novel written by John Banville to be published in 2013.

title: Vain Glorious | The Seaweed Secret
description: Who: Repchage Beauty From the Sea.

title: Capturing the Winter Songs of Rare Whales
description: Between Greenland and the northern island of Spitsbergen, Norway, in the blackness of the Arctic winter, a group of rare whales sing in ghostly screeches and drawn-out creaks, eerie whistles and hollow screams, day in, day out, in the ice-laden water.

title: How Mildred Pierce Explains the World
description: The four most overrated things in life, Christopher Hitchens once said, are Champagne, lobsters, anal sex and picnics. This remark was repeated at his memorial service this past April in New York City. The next speaker was the British comic Stephen Fry, who is out and proud. Well, he commented, three out of four isnt bad.

title: On Its Centenary, Celebrating a Ride That Advanced Physics
description: BAD SAAROW-PIESKOW, Germany  Precisely where Victor Hess, his electroscopes and his hot-air balloon touched down is a mystery.

title: What Influences Consumers to Buy or Rent Their Homes
description: Even the deepest housing crisis since the Great Depression wasnt enough to dampen Americans desire to own their homes.

title: British Brothers Dominate Triathlon
description: Alistair Brownlee was first and his brother Jonny finished third, giving Britain its first medals in the event.

title: Six-Second Goalkeeper Rule Proves Baffling to Many
description: The critical, controversial call that helped the United States womens soccer team score the tying goal in its overtime victory over Canada may not have been wrong, but that does not mean it was right, either.

title: TimesCast Politics | August 7, 2012
description: Republicans say Obama 'gutted' welfare. | The push for a female debate moderator. | Parts of the Republican coalition look for trouble. | Romney's new 'protective pool.'

title: The Sport of Olympic Pin Collecting
description: Pin trading at the Olympics is a sport in itself, and anyone can qualify. The Timess Ken Belson went to the Olympic park with 10 New York Times pins to see what he could acquire.

title: Sipping on a Sunset, Italy in Mind
description: JUST as the culinary cognoscenti press us into embracing certain food trends (You will eat pork belly! Love cupcakes now! Hate cupcakes now!) so, too, do they dictate our drinks.

title: The Caucus Click: A Hug for Caray
Painted Black, Nissan NV200 Taxi Is Poised for London Duty
description: The Nissan NV200 van, the same model chosen to be New Yorks Taxi of Tomorrow, was announced on Monday for service in London.

title: Marvin Hamlisch, the Pros Pro
description: 3:52 p.m. | Updated How fitting that Marvin Hamlisch, a one-time rehearsal pianist for countless singers and dancers, should have created the vamp of all Broadway musical vamps for A Chorus Line. That vamp, set to words by Edward Kleban as the song One, is the thematic thread and engine of a show whose score would not have cohered without it. This motif, so elemental that it seems to have existed forever, is the catapult behind everything else in the show.

title: Calling Jack Horner
description: Greenmarkets normally win plaudits for selling produce thats locally grown and often organic, but they also sell items that are simply not available anywhere else.

title: Marvin Hamlisch, Whose Notes Struck Gold, Dies at 68
description: Marvin Hamlisch, the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer who imbued his movie and Broadway scores with pizazz and panache and often found his songs in the upper reaches of the pop charts, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 68 and lived in New York.

title: Weight Training May Lower Diabetes Risk
description: Doctors routinely recommend regular aerobic exercise to reduce the risk of Type 2 diabetes. But for those who prefer resistance training to running on a treadmill, a new study shows that weight training can protect against diabetes as well.

title: Federal Judge Grudgingly Approves Morgan Stanley Price-Fixing Case
description: Over objections from consumer groups and New York officials, a federal judge on Tuesday approved a $4.8 million settlement between the Justice Department and Morgan Stanley over accusations of price fixing in the electricity market.

title: A Kitchen Rainbow
description: Bialetti, an Italian cookware company, introduced its five-quart oval pasta pot more than 10 years ago. I loved its shape, which neatly accommodated a pound or two of long pasta like spaghetti, and its colanderlike lid, which locked in place for easy draining. I even put up with the color, metallic blue. Now Bialetti has introduced an array of hues: red, charcoal gray, purple, turquoise and orange. Meanwhile, I have discovered some uses besides preparing pasta: It will hold six ears of corn on the cob, and is ideal for steaming or boiling two 1 -pound lobsters.

title: Filipinos Turn to Twitter as a Lifeline After Severe Flooding
description: The worst flooding since 2009 has swamped major streets in Manila and nine provincial areas around the city, as rescue workers used rafts and boats to try to rescue people trapped on rooftops or in buildings. As my colleague Floyd Whaley writes, more than 50 people have been killed and at least 250,000 have been evacuated in the last week in the flooding, which was set off by a series of storms and monsoon rains

title: Thick Crust or Thin: Whats Your Slice?
description: This week Pete Wells reviews Nicoletta, the East Village pizzeria where the chef Michael White had hoped, he said, to conjure the Wisconsin pizza of his youth, a pie with a crust thats not too thick or too thin, cut into squares. What he is serving instead has a crust that, while not deep-dish, approaches that heft, sliced into the usual triangles.

title: Sunglasses From Oliver Peoples and Parabellum
description: Oliver Peoples has paired up with Parabellum, the leather goods company, for a limited line of two unisex sunglasses, resulting in a curious intersection of rugged and polish.

title: Top Two Finishers in Beijing Trade Places
description: LONDON  As Australias Sally Pearson sailed over hurdle after hurdle Tuesday, a crowd of 80,000 at Olympic Stadium erupted in a roar, but she said she could not hear a thing.

title: A Sikh Temples Century
description: THE Stockton Gurdwara in California  the first Sikh temple in the United States  is celebrating its 100th anniversary this year. Immigrants from Punjab, India, purchased the lot on Grant Street in early 1912.

title: Get Comfy With Your Sofa Before Its Delivered
The Folly of Attacking Outsourcing
description: The middle class, Im sure youve heard, is under threat by cheap foreign labor. We must be having an election soon. President Obamas assault on Mitt Romney for sending jobs overseas draws from a playbook used repeatedly by politicians of the right and left over the last two decades.

title: George Romneys Extra, Extra-Value Meals
description: On the campaign trail, Mitt Romney rarely tells detailed personal stories from his life, an omission that has left some voters grasping for a flesh-and-blood narrative to latch onto.

title: Come See Our Play. But Watch the Movie First.
description: Theyre somewhat rare, but theater prequels and sequels are out there. There are two prequels actually running now on Broadway: Wicked, an origin story about the witches from The Wizard of Oz, and Peter and the Starcatcher, about the life of a young Peter Pan.

title: A Note to My Readers
description: In a recent blog post, I used an inappropriate phrase to refer to the late VP of PR for Chick-fil-A. My choice of words did not rise to either my own standards or to The Timess, and the phrase has been removed from the post. I regret this lapse.

title: Obama Signs Law Requiring Him to Detail Budget Cuts
description: President Obama agreed on Tuesday to tell Congress within a month just how he would make nearly $1 trillion in automatic spending cuts scheduled to take effect starting at the beginning of 2013.

title: Is Manchester Uniteds Ferguson the Ultimate Insider?
description: Real fans, as Manchester United Manager Alex Ferguson put it, should not be concerned over the Glazer familys debt-laden ownership of soccers most valuable team.

title: Buoyed by Avengers, Disney Profit Surges 24 Percent
description: LOS ANGELES  The success of the film Marvels The Avengers and the Cars-related expansion of a theme park powered the Walt Disney Company to a 24 percent increase in quarterly profit, well ahead of expectations, the company reported Tuesday.

description: These Little Piggies

title: Cake Shop Avoids Closing Down
description: After months of financial uncertainty, the indie-rock club Cake Shop has collected enough money through a novel Internet fund-raising site to avoid closing down, one of the owners, Nick Bodor, said on Tuesday.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Egypt, the Philippines and India.

title: Karmazin Tones Down Language on Sirius Takeover
description: Is the boardroom drama at Sirius XM Radio cooling down?

title: Changing Seasons
description: The view from the property where the author rented a cabin in the Maine woods and installed a game camera on a tree there last October.

title: In $440 Million Trading Error, Upside of Wall St. Failures
description: The near implosion of the Knight Capital Group on an accidental $440 million trading loss may make many feel that Wall Street firms are on automatic self-destruct with the timer set to go off fairly soon.

title: Anna Piaggi, Fashion Editor With a Keen Eye for Trends, Dies at 81
description: ANNA PIAGGI, an oracular Italian fashion editor known for an endless array of eye-popping, wildly colorful outfits of the most peculiar combinations, ranging from vintage Patou to thermal mountain rescue coats to a uniform vest from late-period McDonalds, died Tuesday at her home in Milan. She was 81.

title: Competitive Armchair Olympics: Beach Boys
description: Click.

title: Obama to Make Three-Day Campaign Swing Through Iowa
description: At a time when he usually races from state to state seeking votes, President Obama has decided to invest much of next week in a single place, Iowa, the one where it all began for him.

title: Black Keys, Foo Fighters and Neil Young to Headline Benefit Concert in Central Park
description: The Black Keys, Foo Fighters and Neil Young and Crazy Horse will be on the bill for a charity concert in Central Park next month intended to motivate people to do something to alleviate extreme poverty around the world, organizers announced on Tuesday.

title: A Beginners Guide to Olympic Pin Collecting
description: LONDON  For Olympic athletes, glory comes wrapped in gold, silver and bronze. For some of the rest of us, it comes in the form of an enamel pin.

title: Footnotes
description: The Public Theater said that its production of Into the Woods at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park would run through Sept. 1, a week longer than originally scheduled. The Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical began previews on July 24 and officially opens Thursday. ... In other fairy tale news, Rodgers & Hammersteins Cinderella, already announced for Broadway with Laura Osnes as Cinderella and Santino Fontana as the Prince, has a theater and an opening date. The musical will start previews at the Broadway Theater on Jan. 21 with an official opening night of Feb. 21, according to a release.

title: Highlighting Contrasts and Not Holding Back
description: When the Chamber Orchestra of Europe took its first steps into the spotlight, it left a mixed impression. This was an ensemble of young musicians, mostly alumni of the European Union Youth Orchestra, who wanted to continue working together as a professional group, and you wanted to root for them. They gave you plenty to work with: on their early recordings and tours the playing was energetic and trim, but it could also be cautious and prim, as if only the most finely polished performances were acceptable.

title: Our Extinction, via the Internet
description: The future according to Tom Hanks: post-apocalyptic, with electricity rationed and rebels communicating via antique radios. The future according to the CSI creator Anthony Zuiker: tenuous, with the world about to fall victim to a vast online fraud.

title: Gutting Welfare
description: In 2005, 29 Republican Governors requested more flexibility in implementing welfare work requirements. They asked Congress for increased waiver authority, allowable work activities, availability of partial work credit in order to effectively serve low-income Americans according to their states needs. One of these governors was, as the mayor of London once put it, a guy called Mitt Romney.

title: Gulping the Heady, Thin Air of Creativity
description: VAIL, Colo.  Even on a rainy evening here, the walk from the center of this town to the Gerald R. Ford Amphitheater, where most performances of the Vail International Dance Festival take place, is a thrill for the senses: you pass through pine trees beside a rushing mountain stream amid the Rockies. And after several performances, the walk home features a sky full of unusually bright stars.

title: The Family Breakfast
description: As a mother, I daydream about the ideal family dinner, a sort of mini-Thanksgiving with a Norman Rockwell haze to it. I love the idea of a family seated around the table, talking over the events of the day, learning table manners, conversational skills and good nutritional habits.

title: Woman Prepares to Officiate and Make N.F.L. History
description: Shannon Eastin, who was overruled by her mother when she wanted to play youth football, will make it to the N.F.L. on Thursday night. Eastin will become the first woman to officiate an N.F.L. game when the San Diego Chargers host the Green Bay Packers in a preseason game.

title: Lots of Sand at P.G.A., but No Bunkers
description: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C.  There are more than 30 acres of waste area at the Ocean Course, host to this weeks P.G.A. Championship, and although much of those areas is made of sand, none of it will be considered a bunker.

title: TimesCast Politics
description: Jodi Kantor reports on the push for a female debate moderator.

title: Defending Champs Advance to an All-U.S. Final
description: LONDON  Misty May-Treanor and Kerri Walsh Jennings reasserted their dominance in womens beach volleyball Tuesday, defeating China in two sets in their semifinal match. They will face their United States teammates, April Ross and Jennifer Kessy, for the gold medal Wednesday.

title: Twin Prostitutes, Growing Old Plying Their Trade in Amsterdam
description: When Martine Fokkens bustles into the small grocery store early in Meet the Fokkens, a 2011 documentary portrait of identical twin prostitutes, she calls out a cheery hello to the man behind the counter. She has a purple hat and orange scarf framing her plump white face and a Chihuahua tucked under an arm, and what she needs, she announces, is a box of condoms. She was 69 when the movie was shot and still plying her trade from one of the picture windows in Amsterdams red-light district. Two years earlier her sister, Louise, had hung up her own riding crop because, as the second twin explains in this insistently upbeat movie, I couldnt get one leg over the other.

title: Craigslists Challenger Could Be an App, or Several
description: A few days ago an incoming alert caught my eye. Someone had posted a public message through Highlight, an iPhone app that shows people who else is nearby whom they might want to meet.

title: Cuomo to Attend Only Last  Day of Democratic National Convention
description: Despite his growing stature within the Democratic Party, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is skipping most of the Democratic National Convention next month because, he said, he is too busy with his day job in New York.

title: Artistry Fades as Gymnasts Push Boundaries
description: The American gymnast Aly Raisman won an Olympic gold medal in the floor exercise Tuesday with a score of 15.6, well above the silver medalist Catalina Ponors 15.2 (a huge margin in the fractional point differences of gymnastics) and the bronze medalist Aliya Mustafinas14.9. The difference in the scores reflects the difficulty of these womens routines.

title: An Irish Revolutionary Checks Out the Sights 90 Years After His Death
description: The other day, Richard Teahan was strolling down Fifth Avenue with Michael Collins under his arm when a woman covered fully by a burqa approached him near 65th Street and asked for directions to the Port Authority Bus Terminal.

title: Lifting 545 Pounds Over His Head for Olympic Gold
description: The Iranian weight lifter Behdad Salimikordasiabi won gold with a 545-pound lift. Mark Cannella, a former United States coach, explains how he did it.

title: Take Part in Live Op-Ed Video Discussions
description: This year at the Republican and Democratic conventions, we will be training our eyes and ears as far outside the bubble as we can. In a series of four live videos, New York Times Op-Ed columnists, including Frank Bruni and Gail Collins, will be talking to you and, we hope, with you about four key issues in the campaign. Since Campaign Stops began on Nov. 6 last year, you have contributed more than 60,000 comments. Now were giving you another chance to speak up.

title: Wealthy in France May Pay More
description: How much higher taxes might be in France under a proposed law.

title: Woods Keeps Things Light, Even Amid Dark Clouds
description: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C.  Tiger Woods was speaking, but the boom of thunder overhead would not let him be heard. Then he was trying to listen, but the drumbeat of rain pounding on the roof would not let him hear.

title: Philanthropist Wants to Be Rid of His Last $1.5 Billion
description: Across from a television set with the obsolete girth of a model bought 20 years ago, beneath the grandchildrens crayon artwork taped to the wall, to the left of an abandoned hula hoop, Charles F. Feeney sits in an armchair and explains how he will get rid of his last $1.5 billion, give or take, by 2016.

title: "Understands"
description: A new ad from Priorities USA, a "super PAC" supporting President Obama, attacked Mitt Romney for the closing of a factory by Bain Capital.

title: Another Jets Dust-Up Is One Too Many for Ryan
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  On a crisp, cloudless morning, midway through the Jets second straight contentious practice, Rex Ryan finally showed Tuesday that he actually has a boiling point, abruptly stopping a drill and angrily ordering the Jets to line up.

title: Risking Life, Limb and Dignity With Stupid Human Tricks
description: When something that was originally slapdash and spontaneous becomes big business, part of the fun always seems to go out of it, a phenomenon that you can feel throughout Nitro Circus: The Movie 3D. Hurtling skyward off a rickety ramp to do a crazy flip on a tricycle, once the kind of nutty daredevilry that gave the Nitro Circus stunt troupe its signature attitude, feels like work here more than it does play.

title: Greenberg Asks: Was That Sandy Weill, or Sacha Baron Cohen?
description: Sanford I. Weills call to break up big banks certainly took many on Wall Street by surprise. But it was such a major turnabout that at least one longtime banking grandee thinks its unbelievable.

title: 'My Mind Is Like an Open Meadow'
description: Erin Leddy in a scene from her solo performance.

title: Ad Watch: Ad Tries to Link Ex-Workers Losses to Bain
description: Priorities USA Action, a super PAC supporting President Obama, released an advertisement on Tuesday suggesting that Mitt Romneys actions indirectly contributed to a womans death. Joe Soptic, a former worker at GST Steel in Kansas City, Mo., speaks into the camera, while the ad intersperses shots of a shuttered factory.

title: A Wait That Paid Off in Gold and Bronze
description: LONDON  For Aly Raisman, waiting was the worst part.

title: Dolan Will Let Obama and Romney Joke It Up at the Al Smith Dinner
description: The nations Roman Catholic bishops have been up in arms about various policies of President Obama, including his support for same-sex marriage and his insistence that employer health insurance cover contraception.

title: Collins Acknowledges Overuse of Byrdak
description: Manager Terry Collins was frank when asked if reliever Tim Byrdaks injury  a torn anterior capsule in his pitching shoulder, which could require surgery  was caused by the manner in which he was used this year.

title: William Procida
description: Mr. Procida, 50, who goes by Billy, is the president of Procida Funding and Advisors, based in Englewood Cliffs, N.J. The business provides real estate services, including financing and investment funds.

title: Buildings in Buildings Benefit Renter and Landlord
description: When WeWork began rapidly expanding in Manhattan two years ago, the business center company initially leased four entire buildings, where it in turn prepared and rented office space to small businesses, entrepreneurs and freelancers.

title: J. Crew Wants to Reconnect With Its Base
description: J. CREW, the popular purveyor of clothing classics, is rolling out a broad new advertising campaign aimed at galvanizing its customers  some of whom call themselves jcrewaholics  and also making them smile.

title: Putin v. the Punk Rockers
description: Moscow

title: Haywire on Wall Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Money in Campaigns
description: To the Editor:

title: The Loss of Hearing in a World of Sound
description: To the Editor:

title: Background Checks
description: To the Editor:

title: Reyes Keeps Hitting, and Marlins Upend Mets
description: The Mets insist that life has been just fine without Jose Reyes, their former All-Star shortstop who signed a big-money deal with the Miami Marlins last winter.

title: In Columbus, Ohio, an Arts Belt Is Thriving
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  The transformation of the Short North  a 14-block artsy strip here  from scruffy to chic began in the 1980s. And the scrappy neighborhood, which connects downtown Columbus to the sprawling campus of Ohio State University, has defied the recent economic downturn by continuing that evolution with a string of new developments.

title: Ex-Factory Worker Links Losses to Bain
description: Priorities USA Action, a super PAC supporting President Obama, released an advertisement on Tuesday suggesting that Mitt Romneys actions at Bain Capital indirectly contributed to a womans death.

title: With Eight More Hits, Jeter Will Join Aaron
description: DETROIT  Derek Jeter was standing on the field at Fenway Park before the 1999 All-Star Game when he felt a tap on his shoulder. When he looked around, he found one of the games greatest players standing there. It was Hank Aaron, who said he had long been looking forward to meeting Jeter, who was then only 25 but already had two World Series championships.

title: Stony Brook and Albany to Join Colonial Athletic Association in Football
description: The Colonial Athletic Association will add Stony Brook and Albany to its football-only membership beginning in 2013, the league announced Tuesday.

title: Court Prompts Twitter to Give Data to Police in Threat Case
description: Twitter officials have complied with a court order to turn over account information to help New York police investigators identify who threatened to carry out an attack like the Colorado movie theater shooting at a Broadway theater where Mike Tyson is appearing in a one-man show, the police said Tuesday.

title: Party Bristles at Militarys Push for More Sway in China
description: BEIJING  During a holiday banquet for Chinas military leadership early this year, a powerful general lashed out in a drunken rage against what he believed was a backhanded move to keep him from being promoted to the militarys top ruling body.

title: Raisman Wins Gold and Bronze
description: Aly Raisman of the United States won medals on the balance beam and the floor exercise, and competitors from the Netherlands and China won gold in other individual events.

title: Private Library Labors to Be Relevant Again
description: The stacks of the Huntington Free Library and Reading Room in the Bronx once overflowed with American Indian manuscripts, books and artwork so prized that the Smithsonian Institution tried unsuccessfully to seize the collection.

title: Should Doping Be Allowed?
Congressional Primary in Connecticut
description: In the intensifying battle for control of Congress, there are two open seats in Connecticut that could go either way. On Tuesday, voters will pick Democratic and Republican contenders to fill the seat now held by Senator Joseph Lieberman, who is retiring. They will also choose candidates for the Fifth Congressional District. Here are our choices:

title: Egypts Sinai Problem
description: Update: On Wednesday, after this editorial was published, Egypt was reported to have launched its first airstrikes in decades in the Sinai Peninsula, deploying attack helicopters to strike at gunmen after the shootings of 16 Egyptian soldiers on Sunday. Few details are known, but it appeared to be a retaliatory action to defend Egypt against an upsurge in attacks by militants. The strikes will add to tensions between the new government of President Mohamed Morsi, an Islamist, and the largely secular Egyptian army.

title: Fraud in Special Education
description: Over the last several weeks, Comptroller Thomas DiNapoli of New York has issued audits detailing millions of dollars in fraud by private companies that provide special education services to preschool children with learning, developmental or other disabilities.

title: Cablevision Beats Forecasts in Wake of its AMC Spinoff
description: Cablevision Systems, the New York-area cable television operator, reported a second-quarter profit on Tuesday that exceeded analysts estimates as it added more phone and broadband subscribers.

title: Music Style Is Called Supremacist Recruiting Tool
description: MILWAUKEE  The shooting rampage by an avowed white supremacist that killed six people at a suburban Sikh Temple near here came at a time of both growth and disarray in the supremacist movement.

title: The Silver Lining in the Drought
description: St. Paul

title: Lottery Numbers
Council Members Call for Widening Walkers Path on the Brooklyn Bridge
description: Three City Council members are trying to sell a plan for part of the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Mechanic Avoids Jail Time for Role in Crane Collapse
description: A mechanic who ordered a critical part for a tower crane that collapsed on the Upper East Side four years ago, killing two workers, avoided jail time on Tuesday under the terms of a plea bargain.

title: Average Is Over, Part II
description: A big mismatch exists today between how U.S. C.E.O.s look at the world and how many American politicians and parents look at the world  and it may be preventing us from taking our education challenge as seriously as we must.

title: The Ungrateful President
description: WASHINGTON

title: Iranian Easily Lifts Spirits of His Country
description: LONDON  The strongest man in the world, if hoisting heavy barbells is the measure, is a 22-year-old Iranian who Tuesday won the Olympic weight lifting gold medal among super-heavyweights, hoisting 545 pounds above his head, more than the heft of a baby grand piano.

title: Heavy Burden on Athletes Takes Joy Away From Chinas Olympic Success
description: BEIJING  When Liu Xiang, Chinas track and field superstar, crashed to the ground at the London Olympic Games on Tuesday after stumbling over the first hurdle in his 110-meter mens hurdles heat, an announcer on the state broadcaster openly wept and subway riders thronging platform television screens gasped in horror.

title: After Shooting, Searching for Clues in the Music of Hate
description: As a teenager, Wade M. Page, the 40-year-old gunman who killed six people and wounded three others at the Wisconsin Sikh Temple on Sunday, developed a passion for music. His stepmother, Laura Page, 67, recalled that he worshiped the guitarist Stevie Ray Vaughan.

title: Aug. 7: North Carolina Isnt Central to Electoral Math
description: There were two polls out in Colorado on Tuesday showing apparently contradictory results. One survey, from Rasmussen Reports, had an exact tie there. Another, from Public Policy Polling, put President Obama ahead by six points, or by four points with Gary Johnson, a Libertarian, included in the survey. (In cases where pollsters ask questions both with and without Mr. Johnson on the ballot, we simply average the numbers, so our forecast model treats the poll as showing a five-point lead for Mr. Obama.)

title: In Syria, Potential Threat to Government Air Power Emerges
description: For the first time since the conflict in Syria began last year, an activist opposed to President Bashar al-Assad has publicly presented possible evidence that the antigovernment forces have obtained a heat-seeking, shoulder-fired anti-aircraft missile.

title: Tennessee: Mosque Is Expected To Open This Week
description: A new mosque that has faced arson, vandalism and a court battle has passed inspection and will be allowed to open by Friday, in time for the final week of Ramadan, its leaders said Tuesday. The State Fire Marshals Office said it had issued a temporary certificate of occupancy for 30 days to the Islamic Center of Murfreesboro. For two years, the centers expansion has faced legal challenges and threats of violence. Vandals painted not welcome on construction signs at the mosque and set fire to construction equipment. A Texas man was indicted in June on charges that he left messages threatening to detonate a bomb at the center on Sept. 11. In May, a county judge ruled that the construction plans had not received sufficient comment from the public and that an occupancy permit could not be granted. Federal prosecutors filed a discrimination lawsuit, and a federal judge ruled in the mosques favor last month.

title: Instead of Industrial Giants, Brooklyn Has Niche Factories
description: The hulking five-story brick factory, complete with an emblematic smokestack, once braided rope for New Yorks shipbuilding industry and employed hundreds of blue-collar workers.

title: Its Just Not Done
description: Administrivial Tonights Comments Alert! The spiffing up of the emu stalls will continue briefly tonight, so the comments section will be closed from 9:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m. Please feel free to leave a comment after that time.

title: U.S.-Canada Match Draws Scrutiny
description: LONDON  Soccers governing body is believed to be investigating members of the Canadian womens soccer team after the controversial conclusion to Mondays semifinal between Canada and the United States.

title: Corrections: August 8, 2012
description: NEW YORK

title: 6 Hid Drugs in Diplomas and Candy, Officials Say
description: Drug traffickers have been widely known to employ extreme and inventive measures to smuggle narcotics into the United States, but six people arrested on Tuesday may have won a prize for creativity.

title: Primer: Brazils Rise to Global Player
description: Simon Romero, the Rio de Janeiro bureau chief for The New York Times, discusses what led to Brazils growth, despite the economic downturn, and the challenges the country faces.

title: Brazil Gains Business and Influence as It Offers Aid and Loans in Africa
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  In Mozambique, Brazils government is opening a plant making antiretroviral drugs to fight the AIDS epidemic. Brazil is lending $150 million to Kenya to build roads and ease congestion in the capital, Nairobi. And in Angola, a rising oil power, a new security agreement seeks to expand the training of Angolan military personnel in Brazil.

title: In Slip, Romney Refers to Sheik Temple Tragedy
description: DES MOINES  In extending condolences for the Wisconsin shooting, Mitt Romney mistakenly referred to the victims gunned down at a sheik temple, twice using the Arabic term for a respected leader to refer to the Sikh religion, a non-Muslim faith.

title: Plea Agreement for Jared L. Loughner
description: Under the terms of a deal brokered by his defense team and the prosecution, Jared L. Loughner will spend the rest of his life in prison, and be spared a possible death sentence.

title: In Russia, Madonna Defends a Bands Anti-Putin Stunt
description: MOSCOW  Madonna, the pop megastar known for her own less-than-pious adaptation of religious symbols and settings, used a sold-out concert here on Tuesday night to voice support for the three women from a feminist punk band who are being tried on hooliganism charges for staging an anti-Putin stunt on the altar of Moscows main Russian Orthodox cathedral.

title: Pearson Takes Gold in Hurdles
description: Sally Pearson of Australia won the gold in the 100-meter hurdles. Dawn Harper of the United States took the silver.

title: After Protest, Egypts Morsi Skips Funeral for Soldiers
description: CAIRO  President Mohamed Morsi abruptly canceled plans on Tuesday to attend the funeral of 16 soldiers killed during an attack by militants in the Sinai Peninsula after protesters shouting anti-Muslim Brotherhood slogans chased the countrys prime minister from an earlier prayer service.

title: Chavez Helping Yanks, but Theyre Struggling
description: DETROIT  When Alex Rodriguez was lost to the Yankees for several weeks because of a broken bone in his left hand, Eric Chavez was asked be the principal fill-in at third base, and he has served admirably in that role.

title: Romney Presses Obama on Work in Welfare Law
description: ELK GROVE VILLAGE, Ill.  Mitt Romney accused President Obama on Tuesday of gutting one of the signature bipartisan accomplishments of the recent political era: the overhaul of welfare policy.

title: Echoes of Syrias War in the Golan Heights
description: BUQATA, Golan Heights  As fighting rages in Syria between the government forces and the rebels, the conflict is playing out on a smaller scale in Syrian Druse villages like this one, on the Israeli-held portion of the Golan Heights across the old cease-fire line.

title: Burkina Faso Official Goes to Islamist-Held Northern Mali in Effort to Avert War
description: DAKAR, Senegal  A rare diplomatic opening inside Islamist-held northern Mali was tried on Tuesday by the foreign minister of neighboring Burkina Faso  an attempt to avert a war that some Western officials say is now nearly inevitable.

title: Obama Is an Avid Reader, and Critic, of the News
description: WASHINGTON  A few months after President Obamas $787 billion economic stimulus package passed, he began to notice news reports, but not about the jobs the bill might create or how much of the countrys infrastructure it would repair. Instead, the articles focused on traffic jams.

title: Accusations Against Bank on Iran Deals Surprised U.S. Regulators, Too
description: Top executives at Standard Chartered said they were surprised when New Yorks banking regulator accused them on Monday of scheming with the Iranian government to launder billions of dollars to potentially support terrorist activities.

title: Yes, Its a Sport, and Russias Sinister Dolls Win
description: LONDON  One team wore bathing suits decorated with a picture of what appeared to be an owl dressed in a tuxedo. Another began its routine with the athletes lying, inert, by the side of the pool. And in an homage to the Mexican artist Frida Kahlo, a third team, the synchronized swimming duet from Italy, tried to imagine how it might look to descend into madness while performing intricate leg maneuvers upside down in an Olympic swimming pool.

title: Security Questions Are Raised by Break-In at a Nuclear Site
description: WASHINGTON  An 82-year-old nun and two fellow pacifists who penetrated the defenses of one of the nations most important nuclear weapons facilities last week are due in federal court in Knoxville, Tenn., on Thursday to face charges of trespassing and spray-painting antiwar slogans on a building that houses nuclear bomb fuel. But the incident has also put the Department of Energys security system on trial.

title: Mark ODonnell, Hairspray Writer, Dies at 58
description: Mark ODonnell, who won a Tony Award in 2003 as co-author of the book for the Broadway musical Hairspray and was nominated for another in 2008 for Cry-Baby, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 58.

title: Kremlin Critic Debugs Office. Tweets About It.
description: On Monday, Aleksei Navalny, a blogger and anticorruption crusader who is perhaps Russias most influential Kremlin critic, arrived at work and with the help of a wiretap detector provided by a colleague discovered that his office was bugged.

title: Germany: Criticism Over Man Suspected as Bin Laden Guard
description: German security officials are coming under fire for allowing a Tunisian man they believe may have served as a bodyguard to Osama bin Laden in 2000 to live in western Germany for years, despite being considered a dangerous jihadist who they say is spreading extremist views. German authorities insist they have done everything legally possible to curtail the activities of the man, identified only as Sami A., in accordance with privacy laws. He has been under observation since 2004 and is restricted to the city of Bochum, where he lives with his German wife and three children and must check in daily with the police, Birgit Axler, a spokeswoman for the Interior Ministry in North Rhine-Westphalia said Tuesday. Reuters quoted German authorities saying they have had trouble deporting him because of his marriage to a German.

title: Day 13: What to Watch For
description: Here are some of the events, teams and athletes to watch on Wednesday at the London Games. (All times Eastern.)

title: Missouri Congressman to Take On McCaskill in Senate Race
description: Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri, the nations most endangered Senate Democrat, will face Representative Todd Akin in the November election, the Republican candidate she all but picked for herself who narrowly defeated two challengers in the states primary on Tuesday.

title: After Saab Bankruptcy, Boston-Power Finds a Foothold in China
description: 7:29 a.m. | Updated

title: Looking for Fitness in a Glass of Juice
description: Many of the Olympians competing in London are juiced  though not in the colloquial sense that someone is doping. Instead, the juice these athletes are imbibing is literal, with beetroot juice and tart cherry juice two of the most popular choices. Growing numbers of elite athletes are turning to these natural beverages to provide what they hope will be a legal performance benefit.

title: Starbucks and Square to Team Up
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Cash moved one small step nearer to its deathbed with the announcement on Wednesday that Square, the mobile payments start-up, would form a partnership with the Starbucks Coffee Company.

title: Open Cup Final: Seattle Goes for Four
description: One of the oldest, if not the oldest competitions in United States and North American team sports will turn 100 years old next year, but before the centennial, there is one more final to play.

title: Word of the Day | hermetic
description: hermetic \()hr-me-tik\ adjective

title: Amid the Flooding, a Certain Buoyancy in the Philippines
description: HONG KONG  The floods that have swamped most of Manila, with at least 11 people dead and a quarter-million having fled their homes, seem to have caused little public anger over further municipal dysfunction in the densely populated capital of more than 10 million.

title: Sir Bernard Lovell Dies at 98; a Radio Telescope Bears His Name
description: Sir Bernard Lovell, a pioneer in radar and radio telescopes from the days when the technology helped save Britain in World War II until the beginning of the space age, died Monday at his home in Swettenham Village, England. He was 98.

title: Fact-Checking Is Not Enough
description: The speaker is a Midwestern Everyman: White, balding, deep in middle age, with hollows around his eyes. He sits at a kitchen table, nursing a cup of coffee, talking about what happened after Bain Capital closed down his steel plant in 2001. He lost his job; his family lost its health insurance. His wife felt lousy but didnt go to the doctor, to spare the family worry and expense. When she finally ended up in the hospital, the diagnosis was cancer. She had 22 days to live.

title: A Conversation With: Former Lok Sabha Speaker Somnath Chatterjee
description: Somnath Chatterjee was the speaker of the Lok Sabha, Indias lower house of Parliament, from 2004 to 2009. A widely admired parliamentarian from West Bengal, Mr. Chatterjee had joined the Communist Party of India (Marxist) in 1968. In 2008, he was expelled from the party for refusing to step down as speaker during a no-confidence vote against the government on the issue of the India-U.S. civilian nuclear deal.

title: Wisconsin Attack Exposes the Angry Music of Hatecore
description: The shooting rampage by an avowed white supremacist that killed six people at a suburban Sikh Temple near Milwaukee came at a time of both growth and disarray in the supremacist movement, James Dao and Serge F. Kovaleski wrote in The New York Times.

title: Egyptian Officials Fired Over Soldiers Killings in Sinai
description: EL ARISH, Egypt  President Mohamed Morsi fired his intelligence chief and other top security officials on Wednesday in a sweeping response by his new government to the killings of 16 soldiers in the Sinai Peninsula.

title: How the Polls Were Conducted
description: The latest Quinnipiac University/New York Times/CBS News polls included telephone interviews conducted July 31 through Aug. 6 with a total of 5,197 adults in Colorado, Virginia and Wisconsin. Of these, 4,657 said they were registered to vote.

title: Mixed Views Are Found on Stricter Laws for Guns
description: Most voters in Colorado, Virginia and Wisconsin are not clamoring for stricter state laws covering the sale of guns, with majorities in each state saying more restrictions would not prevent violent attacks like last months killings in Aurora, Colo.

title: Polls Underline Stubborn Splits in 3 Key States
description: For all of the Democratic attacks painting Mitt Romney as an out-of-touch elitist who will help the rich at the expense of the middle class, he is maintaining the traditional  and sizable  Republican advantage among a politically vital constituency, white working-class voters in the states most likely to decide the presidential election.

title: News Quiz | August 8, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Quinnipiac University/New York Times/CBS Poll on Swing States
description: A new poll shows that Mitt Romney maintains a sizable advantage among white, working-class voters and President Obama leading with women in Wisconsin, Colorado and Virginia.

title: Mourning Victims, Sikhs Lament Being Mistaken for Radicals or Militants
description: Sikhs across the United States mourned the deaths in the Wisconsin shooting, and some said that the incident revived bitter memories of the period just after the Sept. 11 attacks when their distinctive turbans and beards seemed to trigger violence by people who mistook them for Muslims militants, Ethan Bronner wrote in The New York Times.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Aug. 8, 2012

title: Britain Gives Nuclear a 2nd Chance
description: HINKLEY POINT, ENGLAND  Along an old Roman road called Green Lane, purple thistles and scarlet poppies wave in the breeze. If things go according to the plans of EDF Energy, the British subsidiary of the French state-owned utility EDF, this verdant hillside overlooking the Bristol Channel in southwest England will be the site of two gigantic nuclear power stations  the first to be built in Britain since the mid-1990s.

title: Rebels Pull Back as Syrian Military Continues Moving In on Aleppo
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Rebel fighters in Aleppo, Syrias largest city, said Wednesday that government forces had opened a ground assault, forcing them to pull back from parts of the city because their ammunition was running low, as new disputes arose around the contentious issue of foreign military support for President Bashar al-Assad, and for the opposition.
