title: Debating the Best Way to Track Small-Business Lending
description: In a recent post, I introduced my companys effort to grade American banks on their small-business lending activity.

title: Whats So Bad About a Boy Who Wants to Wear a Dress?
description: The night before Susan and Rob allowed their son to go to preschool in a dress, they sent an e-mail to parents of his classmates. Alex, they wrote, has been gender-fluid for as long as we can remember, and at the moment he is equally passionate about and identified with soccer players and princesses, superheroes and ballerinas (not to mention lava and unicorns, dinosaurs and glitter rainbows). They explained that Alex had recently become inconsolable about his parents ban on wearing dresses beyond dress-up time. After consulting their pediatrician, a psychologist and parents of other gender-nonconforming children, they concluded that the important thing was to teach him not to be ashamed of who he feels he is. Thus, the purple-pink-and-yellow-striped dress he would be wearing that next morning. For good measure, their e-mail included a link to information on gender-variant children.

title: Watching a Spectacular Public Meltdown With Just a Hint of Jealousy
description: A few days after Whitney Houston died, a friend sent me a link to a story by Cat Marnell. What do you think of this writer? she asked.

title: Repairing the Surgery Deficit
description: LIVINGSTONE, Zambia

title: Summer Movies: A Look Back
description: Images from some of this summers films.

title: A Pattern of Dolphins
description: Scott Baker, associate director of the Marine Mammal Institute at Oregon State University, writes from Samoa, where he studies the formation of local communities among dolphins, and their genetic isolation from one another.

title: Conversion Ratings
description: KARACHI  With more than 90 cash-strapped channels competing for the attention of 40 million viewers daily, its not surprising that Pakistans independent media producers resort to sensationalism to boost ratings. During the holy Muslim month of Ramadan, channel owners and advertisers try to cash in on religious sentiment by hiring celebrities to host ever more elaborate, though only marginally religious, shows.

title: Still Together, in Separate Beds
description: The chance to watch Meryl Streep or Tommy Lee Jones is often all the encouragement the otherwise reluctant moviegoer needs to risk the kitsch pleasures of Mamma Mia!and the familiar genre beats of Men in Black 3. The new film Hope Springs holds out the delectable promise of watching them work on screen together for the first time, and in a story about a longtime marriage thats gone dry. Its a subject thats as unusual in mainstream American cinema as the sight of major stars letting it all hang out on camera, wrinkles and possibly dignity included, though perhaps not for long, given the movie industrys growing interest in the countrys aging population.

title: Feasting After Fasts in the Streets of Old Delhi
description: During this holy month of Ramadan (or Ramzan, as it is called in India), when the sun sets, Old Delhi awakens to a slew of delectable aromas and crowded markets as excited Muslim families break their fast with a feast known as iftar. A majority of the families prepare traditional delicacies in their homes and head out to the Jama Masjid, the principal mosque of the area, to eat in its gigantic courtyard. Many others throng the narrow lanes to feast after their fast.

title: Blockbusters Yield to Magic
description: WHEN Jaws landed in June 1975, it thrilled so many moviegoers week after hot sticky week that within months it had made box office history. As the critic Tom Shone put it in his book Blockbuster, Thats what America did in the summer of 1975: It watched Jaws. These days, though, Americans are rarely unified by one must-see movie for long, even when schools out. When Marvels The Avengers opened in May, it topped the box office for three weeks until it was toppled by Men in Black 3, which held the top spot for two, until it was bested by Snow White and the Huntsman, which held on for one. And so it goes as each studio behemoth is bumped by the next in what has become a faster cycle of planned obsolescence.

title: Was It Hard, Our Year in the Woods? Yes and No.
description: When our nearest neighbors in Maine (two miles away) saw us for the first time after the winter, they said, Oh, youre still here. I wasnt sure if it was a statement or a question, but I was sure that many doubted our ability to cope with the shift from a suburban New Jersey life to an off-the-grid cabin in the woods of Maine for a year.

title: British Central Bank Cuts Growth Forecast
description: LONDON  The Bank of England lowered its growth forecast on Wednesday, predicting an even slower exit from recession than foreseen just three months earlier, but its governor, Mervyn A. King, ruled out an imminent cut in interest rates or other quick moves to stimulate the economy.

title: Dont Shun a Gift Horse, Even if Its Singing
description: LONDON

title: Taliban Gun Locker: The Frankengun of Wardak Province
description: Almost no matter the place or the year, whenever analysts and arms researchers scrutinize infantry weapons circulating through a conflict, they encounter predictable finds. Time and again, the same items turn up: AK assault rifles, PK machine guns, RPG-7 shoulder-fired anti-armor weapons, and, depending on the region, a smattering of M-16 variants, Fabrique Nationale and Heckler & Koch weapons, and bolt-action or lever-action rifles from yesteryear. There are oddities, including homemade jobs. Often there are also stray vestigial arms from previous wars in the same region or from particular arms transfers to a government on the same soil. But most of these are outliers. Usually a researcher can write up a list of likely candidates, then check them off while working the beat.

title: Carlyle Swings to a Loss in 2nd Quarter
description: The Carlyle Group swung to a loss in its second quarter, the firm said on Wednesday, as it struggled to show growth in its core private equity investments.

title: China Draws In an A-List Hollywood Director
description: BEIJING  James Cameron, director of the global hit films Titanic and Avatar, said Wednesday he was setting up shop in the Chinese city of Tianjin to bring his cutting-edge 3-D technologies and production services to a high-technology industrial park aimed at aiding Chinas booming moviemaking industry.

title: What Syria Looks Like From Tehran
description: LONDON  Before rushing to judgment on Irans latest expression of solidarity with the embattled regime in Syria, it is worth considering how the conflict looks from Tehran.

title: After Baby, a Gold?
description: Qualifying for the womens Olympic high jump final begins on Thursday morning. In this years competition, at least three of the medal contenders have given birth in the last year or two, including the gold medal favorite, Anna Chicherova of Russia, and the American Olympic trials champion Chaunt Lowe. And that does not include the defending Olympic champion, Tia Hellebaut of Belgium, who is in the midst of a second comeback to the sport after having had two children since she won the gold medal four years ago.

That wont prevent the agency from continuing to review license applications, a spokesman says, adding that no final licensing decisions had been expected this year. [Bloomberg News]

title: That Newark Airport Greeter Sure Can Project
description: If the woman answering international travelers questions as they arrive at Newark Liberty International Airports Terminal B seems a little repetitive, she should be forgiven. She is an airport virtual assistant, otherwise known as AVA, a hologram-like display that was installed there late last month as part of a six-month trial run. La Guardia and Kennedy Airports were scheduled to get trial avatars of their own last week.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Obama on the News Media, and Madonna Speaks Out in Russia
description: Barack Obama has more than a spectators interest in how the news media does its job, Amy Chozick notes as she describes the presidents typical news diet. Press coverage helped propel him to the national stage when he was a state legislator, and three and a half years into his presidential term he sees news coverage as frustrating his ambitions to change the tone of political debate. His most persistent complaint is what he calls the news medias belief in a false balance, in which two opposing sides are given equal weight regardless of the facts. (A note of caution from Tom Rosenstiel, director of the Project for Excellence in Journalism: I think weve learned through history to beware of presidents playing press critic. Theyre not press critics  theyre people trying to advance a political agenda.)

title: Indias Boxing Hero Mary Kom Settles for Bronze
description: Mary Koms gold medal quest ended on Wednesday when she lost in the semifinals of the Olympic womens flyweight boxing competition to Britains Nicola Adams, the second-ranked fighter in the world.

title: TimesTalks: Women of the Summer Games
description: For the first time, the United States has sent more women than men to compete on its Olympic teams in London, reflecting the evolution of womens participation in the modern Games. The TimesTalks series hosted a panel discussion on Wednesday with Olympic athletes past and present about participating in the Games, how they have prepared and what they have discovered.

title: U.S. Decathlon Favorite Wastes No Time in Taking the Lead
description: LONDON  At times, the decathlon is best described as the world championship of standing around. Run the 100 meters, then wait through three other heats. Move to the long jump, then wait for your three attempts. On to the shot-put. More waiting. Then an afternoon break, two more events at night, and then do it all again in five new events tomorrow.

title: Ancient Energy Boost, Brewed From Toasted Leaves and Bark
description: Long ago, at a pre-Columbian ritual center across the Mississippi River from present-day St. Louis, the home of Budweiser, people were heartily imbibing a caffeinated tealike beverage commonly known as black drink. The chemical residues found in their porous, unglazed ceramic mugs tell the tale.

description: Living standards are rising for many in booming Asia even as they fall for many in debt-struck Europe. In this time of shifting fortunes, how do the two continents view each other?

title: Visa and MasterCard Settle Lawsuit, but Merchants Arent Celebrating
description: It has been called the largest private antitrust settlement in history, but the tentative $7.3 billion deal made last month between credit card companies and merchants may do little for Andy Charles, the owner of Havens Candies, which accepts credit cards at its three stores in the Portland, Me., area.

title: FAQ: Frequent Airline Questions
description: THERE are some things one invariably wonders when waiting for a plane to take off. Is the air vent above my head blowing someones flu into my face? If I neglect to turn off my cellphone, will I really endanger the plane? If I knock back a cocktail at 30,000 feet, will it knock me out? Plagued by these and other aviation questions at the height of the summer vacation season, I called government officials and medical doctors for answers. Heres what the experts had to say about five common travel bugaboos.

title: Underwater, Overexposed

title: Image of the Day: August 8
Breaking It Down: A Soccer Match for the Ages
description: Ali Krieger is a defender for the United States womens national soccer team and plays for FFC Frankfurt. Because of an injury, she is not playing for the team in the 2012 Games. She was an alternate on the 2008 United States Olympic team and started for the Americans in last summers World Cup. She has been writing for the 2012 London Olympics blog, and this is her third post.

title: Will the Credit Card Settlement Help Merchants?
description: The Times has published an article exploring the dissatisfaction brewing among some retailer advocates with a recently proposed settlement to a lawsuit that pitted merchants against Visa, MasterCard and the leading banks. Among the grievances: for the first time, merchants would gain the right to charge customers more for paying with a credit card  unless they accept American Express cards. As the article explains, American Express, which is not party to the settlement, has rules that can make it difficult or impossible for merchants to institute surcharges.

As the largest transit system in the world continues to evolve, we look back on Paul Therouxs adventure inside its tunnels, published in The Times Magazine on Jan. 31, 1982.

description: LONDON  A mobile lab drove up to the hotel and Galen Rupp prepared for what amounted to the worlds coldest shower. He climbed into a chamber wearing his socks and underwear. His head and hands poked out the top of the cylinder.

title: For the Very Old, a Surprise in Blood Pressure Readings
description: Its such a routine thing: A nurse wraps the cuff around your elderly relatives arm, squeezes the bulb, listens with a stethoscope and says: 120 over 60. Very good. Smiles all around (this was my 89-year-old fathers latest reading), because everyone knows that high blood pressure is a risky proposition.

title: Investigators Seek Clues in Gunmans Last Weeks Before Temple Murders
description: MILWAUKEE  Around the middle of June, Wade M. Page split with his girlfriend, moving out of the home they shared in South Milwaukee. In mid-July, he suddenly stopped showing up to his job as a machine operator. About two weeks later, he bought a 9-millimeter handgun, testing it by firing 50 rounds at a target in the gun shops basement.

title: Libertys Spinoff of Starz Was Firmly Denied Only a Month Ago
description: There are no plans on Starz at this time other than to grow it. Thats what the chairman of Liberty Media, John Malone, told a New York Times reporter last month at the Sun Valley, Idaho, media conference.

title: Twin Reports Stoke Cautious Optimism for Rebound in the Housing Market
description: WASHINGTON  In the latest sign that the worst might be over for the battered American housing market, the two government-controlled mortgage finance giants, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, this week reported some of their best quarterly results since the real estate collapse.

title: Too Conservative, or Just Extremely Conservative?
description: Ahead of Tuesdays G.O.P. primary in Missouri, Senator Claire McCaskill and her Democratic supporters spent around $2 million on ads describing one candidate, Representative Todd Akin, as too conservative for the state. Ms. McCaskills hope was that Missouri Republicans would think too conservative, sounds good! and support Mr. Akinin her estimation a relatively weak challenger. That strategy seems to have worked: Mr. Akin won last nights race with 36 percent of the vote.

title: New York Kids Stories
description: At a moment when crowded public schools, escalating rents, competitive hyperparenting and a flagging economy may drive wavering New York parents out to the suburbs, three newly published and gloriously illustrated books for city offspring could persuade them to stay put.

title: Natural Selections Evolution: Rebecca Stott Talks About Darwins Ghosts
description: Soon after he published On the Origin of Species, Charles Darwin was accused of neglecting to mention the thinkers who had helped to shape evolutionary theory before him. He scrambled to put together a list of predecessors that would be added to future editions of his book. In Darwins Ghosts, Rebecca Stott tells the story of those predecessors work, from the empirical research of Aristotle to the studies of Alfred Russel Wallace, who was piecing together the science around the same time as Darwin. In The New York Times Book Review, Hugh Raffles called the book an absorbing account with a narrative that flows easily across continents and centuries. In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Stott discussed the roots of her interest in Darwin, the reasons Wallace played second fiddle without complaint and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: New Fossils Indicate Early Branching of Human Family Tree
description: Fossil by fossil, scientists over the last 40 years have suspected that their models for the more immediate human family tree  the single trunk, straight as a Ponderosa pine, up from Homo habilis to Homo erectus to Homo sapiens  were oversimplified. The day for that serious revision may be at hand.

title: Diabetes and the Obesity Paradox
description: Type 2 diabetes, a condition widely thought of as a disease of the overweight and sedentary, also develops in people who arent overweight. And it may be deadlier in these normal-weight people, a new study shows.

title: Reversing Course,  Los Angeles Art Museum Will Look for Chief Curator
description: The Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles, stung by criticism of its leadership, has reversed course and decided to conduct a search for a chief curator, after initially saying that it would leave the position unfilled.

title: In a Starving Nation, Luxury for a Few
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The South Korean news media, which scrutinizes every photo of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, zeroed in this week on one particular photo released by the Norths state-run news agency on Tuesday. It shows Mr. Kim watching an art performance by soldiers during a military visit, the first reported in the North Korean media since he fired the top army leader, Vice Marshal Ri Yong-ho, on July 15.

title: Golden Boy Cast Features Tony Shalhoub, Yvonne Strahovski and Danny Burstein
description: Seth Numrich will play the lead character in Bartlett Shers coming production of Clifford Odetss Golden Boy for Lincoln Center Theater, alongside an ensemble cast including Yvonne Strahovski, Tony Shalhoub, Danny Burstein and Dagmara Dominczyk among several others, press representatives for the theater company said on Wednesday.

title: The Sound of Hate
description: THE shooting rampage on Sunday that killed six people and wounded three others at a Sikh temple in Wisconsin exposed the continued dangers of white power extremism in our midst. The shooter, Wade M. Page, was affiliated with a range of neo-Nazi skinhead groups, and during the last decade, he played in several prominent bands in the white power music scene.

title: U.S.-Mexico Preview, Part 2: The North American Solution

title: In Iowa, Romney Leaves a Stance on Wind Power Unsaid

Adelson, the billionaire casino owner who has emerged as one of the countrys biggest Republican donors, filed a $60 million libel lawsuit in federal court on Wednesday against a Democratic group that Mr. Adelson said had falsely accused him of condoning prostitution in his Macau casino properties.

description: Apple freezes over-the-phone password changes, tech designers and developers struggle to get paid and Microsoft conceptualizes the connected home.

title: A Guys Perfect Closet, Only Bigger
description: OH, the dreaded middle ground. That space between casual and tailored is the worst, really. It leaves men floundering. Not the ones who care about notched lapels or three-button jackets that roll to two and who follow Tumblrs about men who dont ever wear socks. Theyre fine, if irritating. But for men aiming for the respectable mean, the ones who understand that theoretically they can do better but have no idea how, looking crisp is a perpetual struggle.

title: A Store With Shelves Full of Crime Faces Its Demise
description: Endings, man, they werent as easy as they looked.

title: Debate in Germany Over Dangerous Jihadist
description: BERLIN  Revelations that a Tunisian man who is considered a dangerous jihadist and may have served as a bodyguard to Osama bin Laden in 2000 has been living for years in a western German city have ignited a debate over the difficulties faced by the German authorities in trying to curtail the activities of potential Islamic extremists.

title: A Rebels Cause: Fortifying the Fashion Flock
description: HE was at the Frieze Art Fair in New York, bear-hugging Johan Lindeberg, yakking with a chef from Fat Radish and exchanging grins with gallerists.

title: In London, Censure of an Elite Bank Draws Harrumphs
description: LONDON  In this summer of revelations about bad behavior by British financial institutions, bashing the banks has been Londons other Olympic sport.

title: Respectful of History, U.S. Boxer Has a Shot to Make Some
description: LONDON  Her rope-a-dope tactics and enthusiastic embrace of her talents call to mind Muhammad Ali, who as Cassius Clay was a 1960 Olympic gold medalist. But Claressa Shields, the teenager left to shoulder the gold medal expectations of the United States in a sport it once ruled with iron fists, exhibited an even longer reach into history, describing Sugar Ray Robinson as her inspiration.

title: If Rematch Means Shootout, U.S. Is Ready
description: LONDON  One year after the Womens World Cup final, so much is the same for Japan and the United States. They have the same stars. They have the same expectations. They are the two best teams, despite what the FIFA rankings say.

title: A Critical Design Change for a Bag to Carry Your Tech Stuff
description: A few months back, I wrote about what tech stuff I own  and what I carry it in. I noted that I had a Timbuk2 messenger bag. Its a Transportation Security Administration-approved model that unzips to open like a butterflys wings, so that the laptop compartment can lie flat for airport scanning.

title: Marketing Time in a Bottle Pays Off
description: THE beauty industry, long promising to stop or at least stave off time, is finding a way to market it. Over the last year or so, store shelves have become packed with so-called time-release products, which promise staggered benefits the longer they sink in.

title: The Breadbasket of the Union
description: The summer of 1862 saw the Civil Wars two fronts as a mirror image. In the West, Federal troops had harnessed long stretches of the Cumberland, Tennessee and Mississippi Rivers to drive deep into the Confederacy. Fort Henry, Fort Donelson, Nashville and Memphis had all fallen, leaving Union forces largely in control of Kentucky, middle and western Tennessee, northern Mississippi and northern Alabama.

title: Near Miss for Kibbutz in Path of Sinai Incursion
description: KEREM SHALOM, Israel  The members of the tiny kibbutz here on Israels troubled border with Egypt and the Gaza Strip were just finishing a light supper in their dining hall on Sunday evening when text messages warned them to take cover.

title: Mourinho Has Eyes on U.S.
description: Word is, he no longer cares to be called the Special One.

title: Chamberlain Works to Be Displayed at Plaza of Seagram Building
description: The plaza of the Seagram Building, which has been the stage for a procession of supersized contemporary art installations over the last few years, is about to sprout a forest of tinfoil tentacles. Or at least a bunch of towering, sinuous things that appear to be made of foil, created by the sculptor John Chamberlain, who died in 2011.

title: Us Weekly, for a Lot Fewer of Us
description: AS the textbook-thick September issues of fashion magazines begin clogging mailboxes and newsstands this week, there will be some new faces competing for your attention, especially if you are part of that vastly underserved population known as rich people.

title: What Cornfields Show, Data Now Confirm: July Set Mark as U.S.s Hottest Month
description: It may come as little surprise to the nations corn farmers or resort operators, but the official statistics are in: July was the hottest month in the lower 48 states since the government began keeping temperature records in 1895.

title: Asked & Answered | Susie Breuer
description: I love being behind the scenes, Susie Breuer insists. The spotlight isnt a comfortable place for me. But after 20 years of quietly working in fashion production for industry magnates like Tommy Hilfiger, Karl Lagerfeld and, currently, Calvin Klein, Breuer is finally getting a center-stage moment with the recent release of her first book, Blue Is the New Black: the 10 Step Guide to Developing and Producing a Fashion Collection (BIS Publishers, $45). Dispensing insider tips and personal anecdotes from years in the business, Breuer offers a thorough look at the somewhat arcane journey to building a collection, from conception to high street or catwalk, and the interplay among the many individuals who contribute along the way.

title: Kindler, Former Pfizer Chief, Joins Lux Capital
description: Jeffrey B. Kindler, who retired as Pfizers chairman and chief executive at the end of 2011, has joined Lux Capital as a venture partner, the firm announced on Wednesday.

title: Yankees Slide, but Are They in Danger?
description: We interrupt the Olympics to present a possible news alert. The Yankees, losers of 12 of their last 18 games, might, sort of, be in a little bit of trouble. But probably not.

title: Subsidies for a Global Warming Gas
description: More than 40 percent all carbon credits issued by the United Nations have been awarded to 19 plants for destroying HFC-23, a global warming gas.

title: McIlroy Gives Himself a Passing Grade, But Wants to Improve It
description: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C.  When Rory McIlroy met with the news media on the eve of the P.G.A. Championship, he assessed his season to date and graded it a B. Theres little doubt that hoisting the Wanamaker Trophy on Sunday at the seasons final major would lift his grade near the top of the class.

title: The Best and Worst Countries in the Medal Count
description: More medals or more golds? This rankings diagram shows how countries stack up.

title: Fuzzy Math
description: Mitt Romney is hardly the first Republican presidential candidate to assure Americans that cutting taxes and ending regulation will bring joy to the nation.

title: Long-Lost Le Mans Corvette, Found at Last?
description: Chip Miller, a noted collector of Chevrolet Corvettes who died in 2004 at age 61, spent much of his later life searching for a Corvette fielded by Briggs Cunningham  the driver, automotive manufacturer, yachtsman and race-team privateer  at Le Mans in 1960. Though he was unsuccessful in his search, before his death Miller passed along a valuable clue he had kept closely guarded.

title: Competitive Armchair Olympics: Rocket Man
description: POWER

title: Pole-Vaulter Bends but Doesnt Break
description: LONDON  Steve Hooker of Australia is the defending Olympic pole vault champion, but he has had a problem with the yips that would bring sympathy from any golfer.

title: Scene City: Liza Minnelli and Alan Cumming Bring Cabaret to Fire Island
description: A night of cabaret in Cherry Grove with the one and only.

title: Fire Islands Got Talent
description: THE Ice Palace nightclub in Cherry Grove on Fire Island is not a place ordinarily associated with great theater. On Friday night, Alan Cumming was there at an underwear party, dancing around in a jock strap and doing something with a gummy bear that cannot be described in this newspaper.

title: Stone Links: The Drone Wars
description: A new chapter in the ongoing debate about the morality of drones opened last week, with a profile in The Guardian of the philosopher Bradley Strawser. Strawsers perspective on just war theory and the ethics of drones, which was also featured in a recent news analysis in the Sunday Review, is all the more interesting because, as a professor at the U.S. Naval Postgraduate School, he is employed by an institution which is uniquely positioned to act on his views.

title: U.F.O. Home
description: Roberto Sanchez Rivera built his home in Puerto Rico to look like a spaceship, with lights and audio effects.

title: The Flat
description: AROUND midnight on a sweltering Friday, the Flat was no place to cool off. In the swarmed bar, young women danced with condensation-slick bottles of Dos Equis held aloft. Heems, a rapper from the group Das Racist, slouched on a zebra-print bench under a portrait of an old woman.

title: Norbert Leo Butz Will Join Katie Holmes in Dead Accounts
description: This fall on Broadway, Norbert Leo Butz will play the neer-do-well brother of Katie Holmess character, whose return to their childhood Ohio home sets off the action in Theresa Rebecks Dead Accounts, representatives for the play announced on Wednesday. Dead Accounts will begin previews at the Music Box Theater on Nov. 3, with a scheduled opening on Nov. 28.

title: Teenagers Petition on Female Moderators Draws Support
description: Quick, name the last woman who moderated a presidential debate. If you are having trouble, there is a reason: No woman has done the job in 20 years, since Carole Simpson in 1992.

title: The U.S. Bounces Back, and Over
description: LONDON  The three Americans who won gold medals in Olympic Stadium on Wednesday were competing in different ways. Aries Merritt had to clear 10 hurdles. Brittney Reese had to leave the takeoff board at full speed before treading on the Plasticine strip that marks a foul. Allyson Felix had to sprint the curve and find something new within herself and her famously smooth stride.

title: New Google Tools to Make the Search Engine More All-Knowing
description: When Google imagines the future of Web search, it sees a search engine that understands human meaning and not just words, that can have a spoken conversation with computer users and that gives users results not just from the Web but also from their personal lives.

title: A Grounded Flying Saucer in Puerto Rico
description: On a hill overlooking a highway, the colored lights of what appears to be a flying saucer are visible. A closer examination reveals a spaceship-inspired house.

title: Money, Mentoring and a Claim on the Payoff
description: If you believe someone has a great future as an entrepreneur, maybe you should own a piece of it.

title: Destination | Makepeace Island
description: Makepeace Island, Richard Bransons island in Australia, is a 10-minute ride on a private launch from Noosa, on Queenslands Sunshine Coast. The name is reason enough for any couple (quibbling or not, lets make peace!) to visit, plus the island is heart shaped  though not quite as much as it appears to be on its namesake Web site  a forgivably cheeky exaggeration.

title: Close Encounters of the Romantic Kind
description: JUANA DIAZ, P.R.

title: Police Return to Cellar Tied to Patz Suspect
description: A police evidence unit brought out several large paper bags on Wednesday from the basement in SoHo where the man charged in the Etan Patz case says he killed the boy who disappeared in 1979.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Egypt, Syria, Democratic Republic of Congo and Manila.

title: Whats Next in the Standard Chartered Case
description: The  order issued to Standard Chartered by Benjamin M. Lawsky, the superintendent of the New York State Department of Financial Services, creates a problem for the federal government in its own investigations of the bank. Mr. Lawsky accused the bank of operating as a rogue institution in its dealings with Iranian customers in violation of federal law, and seeks to revoke its license to do business in New York.

title: The Starbucks-Square Deal: Visionary or Risky?
description: The mobile wallet just became more hip with the news that Starbucks has teamed up with Square, the mobile payment start-up. Beginning this fall, youll be able to pay for a cup of joe at Starbucks by showing a Square barcode on your smartphone to a cashier.

title: A Sneakers-Only Runway
description: WANT to rub shoulders with a high-powered fashion editor? How about a designer? Arguably the best place these days isnt the Top of the Standard hotel or even Amy Saccos new bote, No. 8, but a nondescript slab of a building at 27th Street and Eighth Avenue, a neighbor to Chelsea housing projects and a Gristedes grocery store, and the home of the misleadingly titled Midtown Tennis Club. (Its not in Midtown, and membership isnt required to play there.)

title: Felix Wins Gold
description: Allyson Felix of the United States won the womens 200 meters at the London Games in 21.88 seconds on Wednesday, upgrading her previous two Olympic silver medals to gold.

title: A Flock of Keyboards, Gathered in the Round
description: When people refer to piano quartets or piano trios, they generally mean a piano and some other stuff  a violin and a cello, say. But the new ensemble Grand Band is a piano sextet in the purest sense: six pianos, and only six pianos.

title: Weymouth Journal: Beer in Sausage, Rather Than Beer and Sausage
description: Periodically throughout the Olympics we will check in with Dennis Spurr, owner of the Fantastic Sausage Factory in Weymouth, a pretty town on the English coast where the sailing events are taking place. Mr. Spurrs sausage business was a target of the Olympic branding authorities in 2007 after he put up a sign featuring the Olympic five-ring logo fashioned out of sausage links. He took it down on their demands, but replaced it with a sign featuring five squares made out of sausage links.

title: All the Trimmings Are the Main Course
description: A YEAR before Paula Cheng graduated from Parsons the New School for Design with an M.F.A. in fashion design in May, she won a contest organized by the Metropolitan Museum of Art to create designs inspired by the Alexander McQueen exhibition at the museum. Ms. Cheng focused not on bumster pants nor showstopper gowns, but on black platform-heeled shoes and sandals with winged tiers of fur that have already been pictured on Italian Vogues Web site.

title: And the Olympic Gold for Whining Goes to ...
description: LONDON  For the handful of countries sitting at the top of the medal count, the Olympics have been a source of joy and a cause for celebration.

title: R. Peter Straus, Radio Pioneer, Dies at 89
description: R. Peter Straus, who took over WMCA in New York in the late 1950s and turned it into one of the nations most innovative radio stations, broadcasting what are regarded as the first radio editorials and political endorsements and helping to popularize rock n roll, died on Monday at his home in Midtown Manhattan. He was 89.

title: An E-Mail Service With Lots of Smarts
description: Coming soon, from the creator of the Macarena!... New, from the founders of Myspace!... He has the same agent as Steven Seagal!

title: On Fridays, Partying Starts Early
description: NICOLE WASILEWICZ, 27, stood poolside at the Thompson LES hotel, toenails Day-Glo orange, bikini peeping out from beneath a tank top, clutching a frozen cocktail that she probably could not afford.

title: Grounded? Thank Mom and Dad
description: Why didnt anyone tell me that grounding my child would be this hard?

title: Making Facebook Less Infantile
description: BRANDY CASWELL, 28, turns to Facebook to keep up with her friends. But in the last year or so, she found that her newsfeed was being overrun with baby photos, documenting everything from nap times to diaper changes.

title: Brown Questions Role of Warrens Daughter in Voter Registration Effort
description: BOSTON  Senator Scott P. Brown on Wednesday accused Elizabeth Warrens daughter of using her position on the board of a nonpartisan organization in service of her mothers Senate campaign.

title: Clinical Trial Is Favorable for a Prenatal Gene Test
description: A new method of prenatal testing that can detect more genetic problems in a fetus than ever before could be headed toward wider use after encouraging results from a clinical trial, researchers said.

title: Scouting Report
description: OPENINGS

title: The Riot Girls Style
description: It has been a shock to see the bravely smiling faces of three girls from the Russian punk collective Pussy Riot locked in a glass cage in a Moscow courtroom these past two weeks. Ordinarily they are dressed in shots of clashing colors, their faces hidden behind bright balaclavas. Stripped of their costumes and dressed in plain clothes (graphic tee, button-down shirt, day dress), they are unrecognizable. Hearing their names and seeing Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, 22, Maria Alyokhina, 24, and Yekaterina Samutsevich, 29, exposed and vulnerable on national television seems only to emphasize the bands slogan: We Are All Pussy Riot. After all, if women who look like Tolokonnikova, Alyokhina and Samutsevich are Pussy Riot, why cant I be, too?

title: In a Factorys Shadow, Fears About Health
description: NATHKUVA, India  By issuing carbon credits to companies for reducing emissions in the developing world, the United Nations aimed to inject cash into poor communities supporting the growth of sustainable industry. But in this remote village adjacent to Gujarat Fluorochemicals Limiteds coolant gas plant, environmental groups and residents have been at loggerheads with the company over pollution since it opened in 1989.

title: The Agents Who Fooled the Nazis About D-Day
description: Ben Macintyre is the reigning champ when it comes to attention-grabbing World War II spy stories that are stranger than fiction. Each of his two most recent books, Agent Zigzag and Operation Mincemeat, has been suspensefully written and studded with exotic details. And each has been narrowly particular. Agent Zigzag focused on Eddie Chapman, the onetime thief who turned his duplicity toward deceiving Germany on behalf of the Allied war effort. The more amazing Operation Mincemeat outlined the elaborate use of a floating corpse to spread disinformation.

title: Kitty Cam Shows Not All Cats Are Killers
description: No owner would likely deny that cats are creatures with personality. Some spend all day stalking squirrels, some spend all day snoozing in the sun. Some like to cuddle, and some are loners.

title: Homes for $400,000
description: Properties in Virginia, Oregon and Nebraska.

title: What You Get for ... $400,000
description: RICHMOND, VA.

title: Scott Recalls Elss Show of Support at British Open
description: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C.  Ernie Els, who won last months British Open when Adam Scott bogeyed the final four holes, played nine practice holes with Scott on Wednesday at the Ocean Course.

title: Hewlett-Packards Deal-Making Missteps
description: Hewlett-Packard has no problem spending money on deals.

title: House Hunting in ... Germany
description: CONTEMPORARY FOUR-BEDROOM HOUSE IN BAD TLZ, BAVARIA

title: In Germany, a Modern Bavarian House in the Foothills of the Alps
description: This four-bedroom home is outside the spa town of Bad Tlz in Bavaria. Its on the market for $2.42 million (1.980 million euros.)

title: Romney Aide Touts Health Care Overhaul
description: A principal message-maker of the Romney campaign drew criticism from conservative circles on Wednesday by suggesting that if a laid-off steel worker in an anti-Romney ad had lived in Massachusetts, he would have had health insurance and his wife might still be alive.

title: Angry Romans Occupy Ludlow Street
description: The new production of Coriolanus, Shakespeares drama about an election that pits disdainful elites against the 99 percent, would seem to be a perfect fit for both our time and the inherently populist theater series to which it belongs, Shakespeare in the Park(ing) Lot. (Yes, this Elizabethan tragedy is performed gratis on the pavement of a functioning municipal parking lot, amid cars, trucks and pedestrians ferrying home Chinese takeout.)

title: Johnnys First Phone: A Guide for Parents
description: Wendy Sue Swanson, a pediatrician in Seattle, knows that a 9-month-old baby can perform some basic acts of imitation. You might expect smiling, blinking and some other facial expressions and gestures. But you know what shes seeing a lot of?

title: Uncertainty of Operatic Proportions
description: The new normal? Speight Jenkins, the general director of the Seattle Opera, repeated the question I had just asked him over the telephone. He paused for a moment.

title: Suburban Taxpayers Vote to Support Detroit Museum
description: The Detroit Institute of Arts was saved from devastating budget cuts Tuesday night after voters in three Michigan counties agreed to institute a property tax increase earmarked specifically for the museum.

title: Editor Fired Following Harassment Accusation
description: CONWAY, Ark.  The gathering, Marc Smirnoff said, was intended as a morale-boosting retreat for his staff at The Oxford American magazine, a July 4 overnight party at a mountain cabin that would fuel the creative intellect.

title: They Tessellate, and Dabble in Both the Sinister and the Naughty
description: At the stroke of midnight on Tuesday night Alt-J was at Glasslands Gallery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, playing Handmade, the secret track from An Awesome Wave, its new full-length debut. A simmering hymn of one-way infatuation, it boiled down to a duologue betweenJoe Newman, the bands frontman, and Gus Unger-Hamilton, its keyboardist. Legions upon legions of craftsmen handmade my feelings, they harmonized with studied imprecision, before reaching a moony refrain: For yoooouuu.

title: With School Gym as Olympic Stadium, Autistic Students Chase Goals
description: In London, thousands gathered on Wednesday to watch as two Jamaican track stars, Usain Bolt and Johan Blake, limbered up for the 200-meter sprint. At the Rebecca School for developmentally disabled children in Manhattan, however, Sam Wilkinson had eyes for only one race: the one between his team, East Side Story, and its rival, the Subway Stars.

title: A Puzzle of a Carpet to Add or Subtract
description: For home dwellers who stress over finding the perfect size and shape for an area rug, the Dutch design company Droog has an answer: All in One, a reconfigurable wool carpet made from 14 different pieces covering about 388 square feet. If you have a big room, you can use them all together as one piece, said Renny Ramakers, director of Droog. Or you can split them up for different rooms.

title: Cool Pieces for Hot August Dinners
description: Dinosaur Designs may not have anticipated a blistering hot summer, but it had the wisdom to introduce a collection called Sorbet that coincides with it. The handmade resin pieces include soy sauce dishes, gelato spoons (right), vases and salad servers, in refreshing hues that are layered to look sculptural.

title: Romney Makes a Surprise Stop at a New Jersey Wedding
description: Mitt Romneys arrival at a New Jersey fund-raiser on Wednesday capped a breakneck drive along New Jerseys highways followed by a surreal pursuit by an Orthodox Jewish wedding party, according to a reporter on the trip.

title: Classic Seating in a New Wardrobe
description: Midcentury furniture classics reimagined: thats the angle behind the designer Madeline Weinribs treatment of a score of notable pieces, which she upholstered in her signature prints. Displayed from Saturday to Sept. 3 at Sebastian & Barquets Southampton gallery, the collection includes Vladimir Kagans Erica chaise in lavender jacquard ($18,500), Osvaldo Borsanis P32 lounge chair in dove-gray striped ikat on the back and dove-gray ikat on the front ($7,000) and a three-seat sofa by Ico and Luisa Parisi in brown-striped ikat (above, $45,000). I wanted to pay tribute to the original designs, Ms. Weinrib said, while simultaneously introducing them to the viewer in a way theyve never experienced the pieces before. The exhibition is open Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., 67 Jobs Lane, Southampton, N.Y.; information: (631) 283-0456 or sebastianbarquet.com.

title: Like a Sprinter, Bursts of Power
description: A reporter sprinkled cocoa powder onto light gray carpet, then ground in cheese-flavored tortilla chips with her heel. She picked up the new Dyson DC44 Digital Slim cordless vacuum cleaner with its sapphire-blue good looks. Would it inhale the mess?

title: Sales at Lekker Home, J. Pocker and Others
description: Lekker Home is taking 30 percent off some Ethnicraft furniture pieces, through Aug. 13 (a two-door Oak Stonecut TV cabinet, originally $2,800, is $1,960); (617) 542-6464, lekkerhome.com.

title: How the French Get Connected
description: Unlike many in his profession, Mathieu Lehanneur, 38, is not driven by the desire to create the next great chair, but he would like to improve the world around him.

title: Rembering Ballesteros, the Competitor Who Never Quit
description: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C.  As the lone returning competitor from the 1991 Ryder Cup match at Kiawah Island Resorts Ocean Course to play here this week in the P.G.A. Championship, Jos Mara Olazbal couldnt help but reminisce. Olazbal paired with Seve Ballesteros to form the Spanish Armada, one of the most formidable teams in Ryder Cup history. In 1991, they went 3-0-1 in their four matches together.

title: Time Wasters, Pointless but Fun
description: Times have changed since the best way to pass an idle 10 minutes was Nokias famous Snake, or whatever flavor of game was built into your old, dumb cellphone. These basic games were simple entertainment and they were fun  to an extent. But with smartphones, we have thousands of app-enabled ways to pass the time waiting in line at the post office or even when struck with insomnia.

title: Obama Says Romney Would Take Women Back to 1950s on Health Care
description: 1:02 a.m. | Updated  An updated version of this blog post appears here.

title: Second World Mind Sports Games in France
description: LILLE, France  Play in the Second World Mind Sports Games will begin here Friday and end on Aug. 23. Five games are represented: bridge, checkers, chess, Chinese chess and go.

title: Steinbeck Family Outraged That Texas Judge Cited Of Mice and Men in Execution Ruling
description: Marvin Wilson, a mentally retarded man with an I.Q. of 61, was executed by the state of Texas on Tuesday night, after the Supreme Court refused to accept the argument that the killing violated the constitutional ban on cruel and unusual punishments.

title: For Women at the Olympics, the Spotlight Can Be Harsh
description: The American sprinter Lolo Jones may have been speaking for a number of female Olympic athletes on the Today show Wednesday morning when she tearfully deplored criticism she had received in American media related to her physical appearance.

title: Surviving the Heat
description: July was the hottest month on record in the United States. People around the country looked for creative ways to beat the heat.

title: Ideas to Make You Shiver
description: A FEW weeks ago, I made the most embarrassing fashion faux pas of my life: I wore shorts to a wedding.

title: 5 Things You Could Be Doing If You Were at the Essex County Fair Instead of Reading This Blog Post
description: In last Sundays magazine, we published Ben Stechschultes photographs of drivers in the Essex County Fairs demolition derby competition in upstate New York.

title: A Colorful Getaway
description: A founder of Fab.com decorates a house that embodies the spirit of the Web site.

title: Bringing His Work Home
description: SPARROWBUSH, N.Y.

title: Flower Riot
description: Summers bright dahlias on display.

title: Yankees Tinker With Lineup, but Its Not Panic
description: DETROIT  A day after Eric Chavez declared that there was a high level of concern among the Yankees over their poor play, Manager Joe Girardi changed his lineup.

title: Dahlias Springing Up, Just Like Moms
description: BALTIMORE

title: U.S., Too, Wants to Bolster Investment in a Continents Economic Promise
description: PRETORIA, South Africa  When Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton landed in South Africa this week, she brought along a hefty delegation of executives from some of Americas leading companies  Boeing, Walmart, FedEx, G.E.  and a message: America is ready to invest in Africa.

title: Childrens Work Spaces
description: Campion Platt searches for a work space that allows a child to spread out.

title: Work Spaces for Children
description: THIS time of year, children often begin to despair over the end of summer and the looming school year. For many parents, mid-August signals the start of school-supply shopping season and perhaps a time to rethink their childs work space.

title: Farewell to the Subway Olympics That Never Were
description: With the London Olympics approaching its end, City Room traveled this week to sites in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens that would have been utterly transformed had New York City won its bid for the 2012 Games. Neither idle nor abandoned, these waterfront areas today are home to new parks and recreational areas, light industry and heavy construction. But they are also raw-edged works in progress, where whole swathes of land stand behind chain-link fences topped in razor wire. They present a very different scene than those described by the captions in the slide show, which are quoted from the official 2004 Olympic bid package.

title: Dissolving Scotlands Old Firm
description: GLASGOW  Imagine if the Republican Party filed for bankruptcy only weeks before Election Day. Or if Apple went broke at Christmas. Or if the Letterman show was canceled ahead of sweeps week.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. Our prewar apartment has the original plumbing fixtures and fittings in the bathroom. Do they add vintage appeal or should they be replaced?

title: Aug. 8: Colorado and Virginia Flip Places in Forecast
description: Mitt Romney got one of his better polls in a long while on Wednesday. The poll, in Colorado, was one of three state surveys conducted by The New York Times in conjunction with Quinnipiac University and CBS News. It gave Mr. Romney a five-point lead there, with 50 percent of the vote, to President Obamas 45 percent.

title: Dabbing the Brow of Cowpoke or C.E.O.
description: YOU cant help but wonder if the late Richard Carlson of San Francisco would have chosen Dont Sweat the Small Stuff as the title of his motivational best seller if he had lived on the East Coast instead of the West. Surely the only self-help advice for this cruel summer in New York is Oh, Just Go Ahead and Sweat Everything.

title: Powerful Indian Financial Exchange Trades Accusations With Economist
description: MUMBAI, India  It is the business version of he said, she said.

title: Pros Line Up to Debate Use of Long Putters
description: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C.  There was grumbling about the legitimacy of the long putter when it first appeared on the professional tours decades ago. But as time passed, it remained mostly on the fringe in elite golf, with no player winning a major championship using one. Traditional shorter putters reigned, and that kept the grousing to a minimum.

title: Editorial Page Promotion at The Times
description: Terry Tang, whose 15-year career at The New York Times has included stints on the metropolitan, business and editorial desks and also involved building its online presence, has been named deputy editorial page editor.

title: Heightened Scrutiny for Horses at Travers Stakes
description: New York authorities have ordered that all horses racing in the Travers Stakes on Aug. 25 be placed under 24-hour surveillance, and their trainers will have to document each medical treatment a horse receives in the 72 hours before the race.

title: Board Finds What Marred Test of a 787
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said on Wednesday that a fan shaft fractured inside a General Electric jet engine on a Boeing 787 Dreamliner during a test run late last month, causing it to eject hot shards of metal.

title: Tough Choices Coming for Ryder Cup Captains
description: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C.  The European Ryder Cup captain Jos Mara Olazbal gathered his potential troops for dinner and said it would be the last chance for all of them to be under one roof before the team convened in September. The 39th edition of the biennial competition begins Sept. 28 at Medinah Country Club outside Chicago, and Olazbal expressed confidence that his team was rounding into shape.

title: City Council Berates Elections Board and Voices Concern Over Future Voting
description: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, said that when she and her fiance showed up to vote last fall, their ballots were disqualified because of a mistake by a poll worker.

title: A Candidate Whose Ads Are Never Off the Air
description: HONOLULU  Channel 110 is a choice spot on Hawaiis digital cable dial, coming right after Fox News and right before CNN Headline News. These days, it is the home of LL12, a station that will soon devote every minute of every day to one topic: Linda Lingle, a Republican running for the United States Senate.

title: Send Bittman Packing
description: Mark Bittman is going somewhere to write about something food related. Help decide his destination.

title: A Gold Medal Winner Returns to His Day Job
description: TORONTO  Andy Murray had all of one day in London to bask in the glory of his Olympic gold medal, which included a national stamp of approval released Monday by the British Royal Mail system. By Tuesday, Murray was being delivered first class across the Atlantic to North America, back on the trail of the Grand Slam title he still hasnt won.

title: Anti-D.W.I. Technology
description: To the Editor:

title: Massachusetts Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Life for a Piano
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bicyclist Runs Into Ethics and the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Defining Happiness
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mad Dash in the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: For Victim in Sikh Temple Shooting, a Life of Separation
description: NEW DELHI  When his chance came to go to America, Ranjit Singh promised his wife and three young children they would not be separated for too long. He was taking a position at a Sikh temple in Wisconsin and hoped his family might join him there. Until they did, he would send back money. He would call.

title: Congressmans Report of Trip Is at Issue
description: When Representative Michael G. Grimm, a first-term Staten Island Republican, went on a fact-finding trip abroad last year, he widely publicized his first stop, Israel, sending off a stream of messages about his activities there via Twitter. But he was largely silent about his second stop, Cyprus.

title: Nuns, at Juncture, Meet to Weigh Their Reply to the Vatican
description: ST. LOUIS  With their leaders saying that they stand at a historic crossroads, more than 900 Roman Catholic nuns have gathered here for a four-day meeting to decide how to respond to a biting Vatican assessment that cast them as disobedient dissenters and ordered three American bishops to overhaul the nuns organization, the Leadership Conference of Women Religious.

title: A Print Focus Returns in Lane Bryant Campaign
description: LANE BRYANT, the womens plus-size fashion retailer, is introducing a $10 million advertising and marketing campaign to make its clothing and lingerie more relevant to current and prospective customers.

title: Google Goes Back to the Drawing Board for Nexus Q
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In June, Google engineers took to the stage in front of thousands of cheering software developers to introduce the Nexus Q, a black ball meant to stream video and music. It was Googles first try at building its own hardware  in the United States, no less  and Google called it a third wave of consumer electronics.

title: U.S. and Gulf Allies Pursue a Missile Shield Against Iranian Attack
description: WASHINGTON  The United States and its Arab allies are knitting together a regional missile defense system across the Persian Gulf to protect cities, oil refineries, pipelines and military bases from an Iranian attack, according to government officials and public documents.

title: The Court at the Olympics
description: Many people are celebrating the achievements of American women at the London Olympics, where women exceed men in the number of athletes on the United States team and have walked away with an impressive number of gold medals. And many have noted the connection between the womens historic success and the 40th anniversary of Title IX, which President Richard M. Nixon signed into law on June 23, 1972.

title: Things I Saw  No. 25
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: At La Guardia, a Smiling Helper Materializes, Digitally
description: La Guardia Airports newest employee, a young woman named Marie, made quite an impression during her first day on the job Wednesday. Airport managers smiled as they watched the blue-eyed, 6-foot-tall blonde with apple-red cheeks stand in front of new arrivals and pleasantly explain where they could find the baggage claim and the taxi stands. Her bosses did not even mind when she twiddled her thumbs and rolled her eyes when no one was around.

title: With Rates Low, Banks Increase Mortgage Profit
description: Interest rates on mortgages and refinancing are at record lows, giving borrowers plenty to celebrate. But the bigger winners are the banks making the loans.

title: Christie Seeks to Weaken Oversight of Halfway Houses
description: Gov. Chris Christies administration came under heavy criticism from legislators last month at hearings on New Jerseys privately run halfway houses, which handle thousands of inmates each year. On Wednesday, Mr. Christie fired back, saying he would significantly weaken a measure approved by the legislators to increase their oversight of the system.

title: North Korea: Is That a Dior, Comrade?
description: In a country that still has trouble feeding all its people, Ri Sol-ju, the wife of the countrys young leader, was pictured this week with what appears to be a luxury many North Korean women have probably never heard of, much less owned: a Christian Dior handbag. If it is not a knockoff, the bags going price in Seoul is the equivalent of $1,600, about 16 times the monthly wage of some of North Koreas best-paid workers. The family of Ms. Ris husband, Kim Jong-un, has long been said to live in style. A former Russian presidential envoy who traveled with his father on a private train in 2001 reported that it was stocked with cases of French wine and that live lobsters were delivered. But it has been unusual for Pyongyangs elite to show wealth so publicly. In a recent speech to party leaders, Mr. Kim lovingly remembered how his father insisted on wearing a threadbare gray parka to remind himself of the famine of the 1990s.

title: All-American Ending for Beach Volleyball Team
description: LONDON  Misty May-Treanor said she wanted Wednesday nights gold medal match to be the best of her and her American beach volleyball teammate Kerri Walsh Jenningss lives. And by most accounts, it was.

title: Lottery Numbers
Hear, All Ye People;  Hearken, O Earth (Part 1)
description: This is the first installment in a two-part series.

title: China: Typhoon Leads to Evacuation
description: A typhoon struck the eastern coast of China on Wednesday, landing near Shanghai and creating torrential rain and powerful winds that knocked out power and forced the evacuation of more than a million people. There were no reports of deaths, but many businesses were closed and Shanghais two major airports delayed or canceled hundreds of flights. Shanghais ports, among the worlds busiest by container volume, were also closed Wednesday, according to Reuters. Local governments in the region were on high alert following flooding in Beijing in late July that caused the deaths of at least 77 people and led to a public outcry over the citys poor preparedness.

title: Publishing Losses Hurt Results at News Corp.
description: A write-down on News Corporations underperforming publishing unit contributed to the companys loss of $1.6 billion, or 64 cents a share, in the quarter that ended June 30.

title: A Brooklyn Block in Bloom
description: There are purple petunias, pink begonias and magenta New Guinea impatiens in front of Maureen Facey and Marian Facey-Boones home on Lincoln Road in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn.

title: Another New York Transplant, Ted Hope, to Lead San Francisco Film Society
description: Yet another leading light in the New York independent film world, Ted Hope, has been named to a position that has been held by two prominent New Yorkers: the executive directorship the San Francisco Film Society.

title: Urged to Shoot, Durant Obliges as U.S. Ousts Australia
description: LONDON  The point guards bother Kevin Durant the most. They find him in meetings, on buses, in hallways of hotels. Shoot the ball, they tell him. Shoot. The. Ball.

title: Mexico: Attack Kills Four in Acapulco
description: Gunmen burst into a house in Acapulco late Tuesday night, killing four people  including a pregnant woman and a 3-year-old girl  and wounding one person, Mexican authorities said. The attack appeared to be the work of organized criminals, according to an official from the state prosecutors office. Acapulco has become a place with high rates of drug consumption, said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Amid President Felipe Calderns crackdown against drug gangs, Acapulco, formerly a popular tourist destination for Americans, saw a drastic increase in homicides in 2010 and 2011.

title: Americans Win Gold and Silver in Beach Volleyball
description: Misty May-Treanor and Kerri Walsh Jennings defeated their fellow Americans in the final.

title: The Wacky Primary Voters
description: Missouri Republicans have just nominated a Senate candidate who appears to believe that the governments college student loan program is the equivalent of Stage 3 cancer. Actually, he said the Stage 3 cancer of socialism, which is perhaps not the exact same thing. But I believe you get the idea.

title: How to End the Chaos in Syria
Mr. Romney Hits Bottom on Welfare
description: Mitt Romneys campaign has hit new depths of truth-twisting with its accusation that President Obama plans to gut welfare reform by ending federal work requirements. The claim is blatantly false, but it says a great deal about Mr. Romneys increasingly desperate desire to define the president as something he is not.

title: News From Our Neighboring Planet
description: Mars never gets old. Every time we get a new look at the planet we see it in higher resolution. The earliest images shot from a dedicated spacecraft, taken by Mariner 4 in July 1965, look more like images from an abdominal ultrasound than photographs of a planet.

title: Heat Exhaustion in a Texas Prison
description: For much of the summer of 2008, temperatures in Beeville, Tex., soared above 90 degrees. For almost two weeks, the heat index was 130 degrees or higher, in what scientists consider the extreme danger range, when the risk of heat stroke is imminent.

title: Obama AWOL in Syria
description: ASPEN, Colo.

title: Stop-and-Frisk in New York City
description: The New York City Police Department is trumpeting a decrease of about one-third in the number of citizens detained under its increasingly unpopular stop-and-frisk program. The news comes as a relief, since New Yorkers, nearly all of whom were innocent of any crime, were stopped nearly 700,000 times last year.

title: Errant Code? Its Not Just a Bug
description: San Francisco

title: Mixing It Up With the Charmer, the Flight Attendant and the Pundette
description: Any evening of theater that includes pieces by Paul Rudnick and Neil LaBute is pretty close to a sure thing. But when neither play  fine though both are  is the best work on the program, thats unexpected.

title: Quarrelsome, Motley Crew: Flirting, Insulting, Drinking
description: IN BULLET FOR ADOLF, WHICH OPENED ON WEDNESDAY NIGHT AT NEW WORLD STAGES ... WHATS THAT? Oh, was I shouting? Im sorry. Its just that Ive seen this new play, and its performed at such a high decibel level that its hard to hear yourself think over even the recollection of it.

title: Its a Small Whirl After All
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Interesting-looking grid, isnt it? I guessed what it was right away, but the pleasure in doing Joe Krozels puzzle was in seeing exactly how he was going to pull off a pictorial representation of the completed TIC TAC TOE grid.

title: Opposing Sides Preview Strategies in Kidnapping Trial
description: BURLINGTON, Vt.  Some 50 members of an Amish-Mennonite sect filled half the federal district courtroom here Wednesday, arriving from several states to support Kenneth L. Miller, a pastor accused of abetting international parental kidnapping in a case involving same-sex marriage, conservative Christianity and a bitter custody battle.

title: In Laundering Case, a Lax Banking Law Obscured Money Flow
description: The list of global banks that have been accused in recent years of laundering foreign transactions totaling billions of dollars has been growing  Credit Suisse, Lloyds, Barclays, ING, HSBC  and now Standard Chartered.

title: Chicago Delay Fuels Concern About New York Bike Sharing
description: An ambitious bike-share program, trumpeted as a transformational initiative by a powerful big-city mayor, has been pushed back to the spring.

title: Fatal Attack Shows Plan to Unsettle Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Three NATO soldiers and an Afghan civilian were killed Wednesday in a suicide attack in the middle of the provincial capital of Kunar Province in eastern Afghanistan.

title: A Glimpse Into the Gardens Future
description: Madison Square Garden opened its doors to the news media Wednesday for a tour of the second part of a three-part renovation of the arena. The event was led by Hank Ratner, president and chief executive of Madison Square Garden Company.

title: An Open-Water Test for Swimmers
description: The 10-kilometer marathon open-water swim is perhaps the most arduous swimming event at the London Olympics, and it takes a special athlete to undertake its challenges.

title: Punk Bands Moscow Trial Offers Platform for Orthodox Protesters
description: MOSCOW  With the gold domes of the Cathedral of Christ the Savior glittering just across the Moscow River, members of three Russian Orthodox groups that espouse a fervent blend of nationalism and religiosity set fire on Wednesday to a poster of the feminist punk band Pussy Riot and also put a match to a poster of the pop star Madonna.

title: Piecing Together a Regional Missile Defense
description: The United States has been negotiating billions of dollars in weapons deals with individual Persian Gulf countries to protect against a potential attack from Iran.

title: Plots Are Tied to Shadow War of Israel and Iran
description: BERLIN  A magnetic bomb detonated on a diplomatic car in New Delhi. The police uncovered a cache of explosives at a golf course in the Kenyan city of Mombasa. Five Israeli tourists and a Bulgarian bus driver were killed in an attack outside the airport in the Black Sea coastal city of Burgas.

title: For Lefty Relievers, a Danger of Overuse
description: As the Mets Tim Byrdak continues to weigh his options after learning Monday that he tore the anterior capsule in his pitching shoulder, he has uncovered certain realities about his field of work. Namely, there are inherent risks associated with being his teams sole reliable left-handed reliever.

title: In Clamor for Roles at Convention, More Are Out Than In
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Newt Gingrich hoped to get a coveted speaking slot at the Republican National Convention. Instead the Romney campaign will have him teach a series of workshops they have nicknamed Newt University.

title: Photo Replay: U.S. Men Advance
description: The United States mens basketball team reached the Olympic semifinals with a 119-86 rout of Australia on Wednesday.

title: Corrections: August 9, 2012
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: The Welfare Gambit
description: I smell desperation.

title: Roy S. Bryce-Laporte, Who Led Black Studies at Yale, Dies at 78
description: Roy S. Bryce-Laporte, a sociologist who led one of the nations first African-American studies departments, at Yale University, and did research that advanced understanding of blacks who came to the United States voluntarily rather than as slaves, died on July 31 in Sykesville, Md. He was 78.

title: Voter Portraits: Zoey Kotzambasis
description: Like many of her young Republican peers, Zoey Kotzambasis supports abortion rights and same-sex marriage. Those liberal-to-moderate social views, she believes, will change the face of the G.O.P.

title: Mourning Wisconsin Shooting Victims, in New York
description: Amritpal Singh of Queens, right, and others held up images of the victims, including an injured police officer, of the recent shooting at a Sikh temple in Oak Creek, Wis., as they took part in a vigil Wednesday in Union Square Park.

title: Young in G.O.P. Erase the Lines on Social Issues
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Matt Hoagland, the county leader of a group of young North Carolina Republicans, is busy trying to ramp up enthusiasm for Mitt Romney at the grass-roots level. So there are a few things he avoids mentioning to prospective young voters he wants to woo, including the hot-button topics like abortion and same-sex marriage, which have dominated campaigns past.

title: Dr. William C. Reeves, Who Sought Cause of Fatigue Syndrome, Dies at 69
description: Dr. William C. Reeves, an epidemiologist who fought his own federal agency to obtain money to study chronic fatigue syndrome and then infuriated patients with the ailment by suggesting that it was linked to psychological problems rather than a virus, died on Aug. 3 at his home in Atlanta. He was 69.

title: Dr. James West, a Pioneer in Addiction Study and Care, Dies at 98
description: James W. West, a surgeon whose struggles with alcohol led him to develop treatments for addiction and eventually to become medical director of the Betty Ford Center, died on July 24 at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 98.

title: Breast Cancer Group Changes Leaders
description: Nancy G. Brinker, the founder of Susan G. Komen for the Cure, will leave her post as chief executive, and its president will resign, the group announced on Wednesday in the most significant leadership shake-up to follow its short-lived attempt to cut financing for breast cancer services provided by Planned Parenthood.

title: This Time, Sloppy Play Doesnt Sink Yankees
description: DETROIT  A day after Eric Chavez said there was a high level of concern over the Yankees recent poor play, the team came perilously close to blowing a sizable lead in what could have seemed like a catastrophic loss.

title: Rebuking Critics of Leaks, Top Counterterrorism Adviser Seeks a Little Room
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas top counterterrorism adviser bluntly rejected on Wednesday charges from Mitt Romney and other Republicans that the White House has leaked classified information for political purposes, calling the claims specious and unfounded.

title: Day 14: What to Watch For
description: Here are some of the events, teams and athletes to watch on Thursday at the London Games. (All times Eastern.)

title: Life, Interrupted: Medical Bills, Insurance and Uncertainty
description: Like a lot of other young people, I never thought about health insurance until I got sick. I was 22, and my adult life was just beginning. But less than a year after walking across the stage at my college graduation, I received an unexpected diagnosis  acute myeloid leukemia  and with it came a flurry of consultations, tests and appointments. From early on, my doctors told me I would need chemotherapy and a bone marrow transplant.

title: Think Like a Doctor: A Peculiar Heartbeat
description: The Challenge: Can you solve a medical mystery involving a 31-year-old woman with heart palpitations that leave her dizzy and short of breath?

title: Word of the Day | expropriate
description: expropriate \ek-spro-pre-at\ verb

title: Down-Ballot Races Provide Much of Seasons Election Theater
description: WASHINGTON  Santa Claus is quite possibly coming to town. And really, thats not even the weirdest thing that has happened so far in the 2012 Congressional election cycle as House and Senate primaries move into the final stages.

title: California: Company Faces 2nd Suit Over Visas
description: A new whistle-blower lawsuit has been filed against Infosys, the giant Indian outsourcing company, by a man who says he was harassed into quitting after he reported visa fraud by managers there. Satya Dev Tripuraneni, an American who worked for Infosys for five years in California, says the company billed fraudulently for workers brought from India on short-term visitor visas and also evaded taxes. After he reported his concerns, he was threatened and demoted, Mr. Tripuraneni claims in the lawsuit filed in federal court for the Northern District of California. Danielle DAngelo, an Infosys spokeswoman, said the company had started an internal investigation of the claims. A trial in the case of Jay Palmer, another whistle-blower who reported suspected visa fraud at Infosys, begins Aug. 20 in Montgomery, Ala.

title: Real Madrids Mourinho Sees a Future Coaching in the U.S.
description: Jos Mourinho of Real Madrid said he would be interested in coaching in the United States in the future, although not as the national coach. The quality of the game is good, he said in New York. They have a positive approach to the game, they want to win, want to play well, want to express good qualities. Step by step it is coming, and one day I want to give a little bit of a help. More at nytimes.com/goal.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,059 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Police Sergeant Shot in the Leg in Queens
description: A New York City police sergeant was shot in the leg while pursuing a suspect on Wednesday night on a street in Queens, the police said. Authorities said that the sergeant was expected to survive.

title: Previewing Japan-U.S. Soccer Final
description: Can the United States avenge its 2011 World Cup defeat to Japan in Thursday's Olympic Women's soccer final? Sam Borden joins Victor Mather to break down the matchup.

title: Groups Campaign Spending Scrutinized in New York
description: Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman of New York is escalating his inquiry into the fastest-growing but darkest corner of the campaign world, requesting in recent weeks tax returns and other financial documents from dozens of tax-exempt groups that are among the biggest spenders in this years election, people with knowledge of the requests said.

title: Should Britain Return to Nuclear Power?
description: HINKLEY POINT, England  For my latest Green Column I visited Hinkley Point in southwest England where Britains first nuclear plants in nearly 20 years may be built. Britain is worried about running out of power capacity. Many of the countrys coal-fired and nuclear plants are aging and are scheduled to be retired in the next few years.

title: Lost Boys of the Line of Control
description: Up in the mountains, a hushed stillness has descended on Dalaunja, the last village bordering the Line of Control, which divides Kashmir between India and Pakistan.

title: A Week of Ghosts: Japans Annual Grieving
description: HONG KONG  There may come a time when these memorials will cease, when they are unneeded, untoward, unwanted. But not yet.

title: Obama Assails Romney on Womens Health Care
description: DENVER  President Obama made one of his strongest pitches to date for the womens vote, which is crucial to his re-election, telling a mostly female crowd of 4,000 here on Wednesday that Republicans led by Mitt Romney would take them back to the era of the 1950s.

title: Internet Gambling and More Casinos Threaten Shakopee Tribe
description: After 25 years of booming profits, the tribal casino business has suddenly gone flat. The growth of commercial casinos and online gambling is raising financial concerns for one of the richest tribes.

title: In House Race, Watchdogs Question Family Finances
description: BOSTON  Representative John F. Tierney, the Massachusetts Democrat who is seeking his ninth term in the House, is facing new questions over the illegal offshore gambling business once run by two of his brothers-in-law, just a few months before an election pits him against the most viable opponent of his career.

title: News Quiz | August 9, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: $1 Million Each Year for All, as Long as Tribes Luck Holds
description: SHAKOPEE MDEWAKANTON INDIAN RESERVATION, Minn.  A generation ago, the Shakopee Mdewakanton tribe lived in a motley collection of beat-up trailer homes, melting snow for bath water when wells froze over because they lacked indoor plumbing. Three-quarters of tribal members received government food supplements.

title: For Victim in Sikh Temple Shooting, a Life of Separation
description: When his chance came to go to America, Ranjit Singh promised his wife and three young children they would not be separated for too long, Jim Yardley and Sruthi Gottipati wrote in The New York Times. He was taking a position at a Sikh temple in Wisconsin and hoped his family might join him there.

title: Growth Flagging in China, Government Data Show
description: HONG KONG  Hopes dimmed for an imminent pickup in China, the worlds growth engine, as a batch of disappointing economic data released Thursday showed industrial production and retail sales falling well short of expectations in July.

title: Test Yourself | English, Aug. 9, 2012
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Why Cant the Bronx Be More Like Brooklyn?

title: The Secret to Solar Power
description: Most mornings, Danny Kennedy hops on a bike with orange saddlebags and rides half an hour from his home to Oaklands Jack London Square. He makes for quite a picture cruising down Telegraph Avenue, decked out as he often is in an orange helmet, orange jacket and orange leather Adidas shoes. When he arrives at his office, he often makes his rounds on an orange indoor bike. (Hes not joking around with the orange thing.) Though Kennedy was once a young environmental activist documenting the horrors of the oil and mining industries, hes now a 41-year-old company man. The orange that he wears daily  which extends even to the checks on his shirts, and which drives his wife crazy  is the brand color for his rapidly growing residential solar company, Sungevity, whose revenues grew by a factor of eight in 2010 and doubled again in 2011, and whose employees have grown to 260 from 3 since the companys inception five years ago.

title: A Bipartisan Proposal for More Equity in Big Banks
description: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: A Childs Life Changes and a Story Begins
