description: Nearly three years ago, Alex Masi took a photograph of a little girl in Bhopal, India. Lens published the picture in May of 2011, shortly after it received the Photographers Giving Back Award  a sum of $5,000 that went directly to the child, Poonam Jatev, and her family.

title: What We're Watching on Day 14
description: The U.S. women's soccer team will play Japan with a gold medal on the line and Usain Bolt looks to win his second gold medal in the 200-meters.

title: Three Key States, Split Evenly
description: WHEN were poll results from three key battleground states concerning the upcoming presidential election released?

title: A Conversation With: Author Nilanjana Roy
description: In her first novel, The Wildings, the literary critic and journalist Nilanjana Roy has imagined a world where the animal kingdom is a vast, interlinked network of species that communicate with each other and follows an inviolate, ancient code of conduct. Humans are known as Bigfeet and are just puzzling, oafish creatures that form the backdrop.

title: War of Words and Arms Amid Assault in Syrian City
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian rebels in embattled Aleppo tried to maintain morale on Thursday by highlighting small gains in the midst of a withdrawal from the most contested area of the city, as government forces fired on their positions with jets, helicopters, artillery and tanks.

title: New England Patriots, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
description: Andy Benoit completes his analysis of the A.F.C. East with a look at the Patriots. Earlier this week, he assessed the Jets, the Bills and the Dolphins.

title: The Early Word: New Lines
description: Todays Times:

title: Fast-Paced Trial in China Murder Leaves Shadows
description: HEFEI, China  Worried that a longtime friend and business associate might harm her only child, Gu Kailai lured him to a rented villa in southwest China, plied him with alcohol until he could take no more and then, when he began to vomit and requested a drink of water, poured a poisonous concoction into his mouth.

title: Summer of No Discontent
description: TEL AVIV Last summer was the summer of tents and hope. This summer is the summer of no free lunches and tough economic measures. Last summer, a surprisingly vigorous social justice movement sent hundreds of thousands of Israelis to the town square. This summer, its dregs are attracting meager participation.

title: What Were Watching: U.S. Soccer Seeking Revenge, and Gold
description: (function($){var data = chameleonData;var ticker = new NYTD.NYTMM.NewsTicker($('#nytmm_embed_223'), data);})(jQuery||NYTD.jQuery);

title: Go Ahead, Send Me Packing
description: The (Times) Magazines food and drink issue will appear on Oct. 14, and the editors (of which Im one) have agreed that I should travel somewhere and write about the food. That, in itself, is not that unusual of an idea, but maybe this is: weve decided to solicit your input to determine where Ill go.

title: Go Fish
description: I used to say that I never invented a dish in my life, but now that would be disingenuous. I know Im not creative in the same sense that a talented chef is, but I also know that my experience has taken me from a place where I would slavishly follow recipes to one where I rarely look at them. Now almost every meal begins with a fantasy. I then buy what looks as if it has the potential to fulfill that fantasy  or simply open the refrigerator and see whats already there. At that point I improvise on an already established theme from I guess what youd call my repertoire. In this regard, cooking is like music, but easier: the basic skills are not difficult to attain, and the creativity comes not in reinventing them but in imagining new ways in which to combine them.

title: Punch-Drunk Love
description: On a good day, the train ride from New York to Burlington, Vt., takes about nine hours. (Train? As Ive confessed before, Im one of those hopeless nondriving New Yorkers. Besides, I love trains. Usually.) But an unseasonably hot Wednesday in late May was not a good day. Forty minutes out of Penn Station, the engine broke down. Off went the lights and the air-conditioning. A rescue engine was on its way, but after half an hour slipped by without any sign of deliverance, I began to despair. Then we changed trains. Again. And again.

title: The Problem With Performance Reviews
description: Performance reviews are standard protocol in corporate America. The objective seems to be for the company to give formal and direct feedback to employees, who are assumed to understand that the reviews represent an opportunity to get a status check (like a report card) that can help them improve their performance and in the end further their careers.

title: Uttarakhand Floods Kill Dozens and Displace Hundreds
description: Even as much of India is struggling with a weak monsoon, the Himalayan state of Uttarakhand is facing a very different emergency, as heavy rains and flash flooding have swept away homes, stranded villagers on high ground and left at least 28 people dead.

title: French Fury as Sarkozy Intervenes on Syria
description: LONDON  Hes back! Just three months after being put out of office by the French electorate, Nicolas Sarkozy has sparked a political firestorm by criticizing his successors Syria policy.

title: Special Education Reform Brings City More In Line With National Trend
An Uncertain Phase for Nuclear Power Licenses
description: In a rare action, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has acceded to a petition filed by anti-nuclear groups that it halt some licensing activities until the agency can sort out its troubled policy on nuclear waste. The groups, two dozen of them, are sounding triumphant, as if they have brought the industry to its knees.

title: Journey to Antarctica
description: Alexander Kumar, a physician and researcher at Concordia Station, writes from Antarctica, where he conducts scientific experiments for the European Space Agencys human spaceflight program.

title: Pistorius to Run in Relay Final After Teams Crash and Appeal
description: LONDON  Oscar Pistorius bounced on his carbon-fiber blades in the sun at the start-finish line Thursday, waiting for his turn to run in the 4x400-meter relay. But the handoff never came.

title: An Architects Vision: Bare Elegance in China
description: Hangzhou, China

title: The Two Halves of a Neighborhoods Soul, Bared for All to See
description: Spike Lees messy, meandering, bluntly polemical Red Hook Summer has one crucial ingredient: a raw vitality. This celebration of African-American resilience in a struggling New York neighborhood envisions two cultures coexisting uneasily in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn. It is on the side of hope.

title: Powerful Indian Financial Exchange Trades Accusations With Economist
description: One of Indias fastest-growing financial exchanges is suing a prominent economist claiming defamation, Vikas Bajaj  wrote in The New York Times. But Ajay Shah, the economist, says the Multi Commodity Exchange of India is just using legal means to quiet a critic.

title: The 2012 Cycle: Attack, Feign Outrage, Repeat
description: The Democratic outrage machine is in full lather.

title: Opinion Report: Humane Confinement
description: From the editorial page

title: Ouya Game Console Ends Kickstarter Campaign With $8.5 Million
description: The Ouya, an inexpensive gaming console that runs on Android, is the latest experimental hardware project to take the Web by storm. It raised more than $8.5 million through Kickstarter, the crowd-funding Web site, in a campaign that ended early Thursday.

title: London Live: Follow Thursdays Action at the Olympics
description: Usain Bolt of Jamaica became the first man to defend his title in the Olympic 200 meters, holding off a challenge from Jamaican teammate Yohan Blake down the final straightaway to win in 19.32 seconds. Bolt has now completed his second straight 100-200 double. Jamaica swept the medals with Warren Weir finishing third.

title: National Oilwell Varco to Buy Robbins & Myers for $2.5 Billion
description: National Oilwell Varco agreed on Thursday to buy Robbins & Myers, a maker of oil well drilling equipment, for about $2.5 billion, as deal-making in the energy sector continues unabated.

title: Daily Report: A Stumble for Google With Media Player
description: Googles Nexus Q, a black ball meant to stream video and music, is the companys first try at building its own hardware  in the United States, no less. But as Claire Cain Miller reports on Thursday in The New York Times, Googles indefinite postponement of Nexus Q shipments last week indicates the challenges it faces as it tries to move into two new areas: hardware and social technology.

title: Frida Gustavssons Most Wanted
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Q&A: Resetting a Lost Twitter Password
description: Q.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: At Last, Political Ads 24/7; and a Firing at Oxford American
description: With the influx of outside spending on campaign ads this year in many states, it can seem as if TV is wall-to-wall political advertising, but in Hawaii, Adam Nagourney reports, the Republican candidate for United States Senate is turning that vision into reality. Linda Lingle, a former two-term governor, pays $2,500 a week for channel 110 on the digital cable dial for LL12, where she airs speeches, her own ads and endorsements and video issue papers in 10 of the languages spoke on the islands. The channel, while a relatively high number, is ensconced between CNN Headline News and Fox News, so presumably gets a few politically interested channel surfers.

title: A Familiar Tale of Trump and Real Estate, This Time in Scotland
description: With so many famous people calling New York home, it is not surprising that some of them catch the attention of documentary makers. Indeed, one of our better-known citizens is the main figure in a film that opened in Manhattan a few days ago. He happens not to be one of our more beloved citizens: Donald J. Trump.

title: Funeral Services Planned for Marvin Hamlisch
description: The life of Marvin Hamlisch, the highly decorated composer of A Chorus Line and The Way We Were, among many other works, will be commemorated at visitations and a funeral service, his press representatives said on Thursday. Public visitations will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street, in Manhattan, on Sunday between 2 p.m. and 5 p.m., and between 7 p.m. and 9 p.m., and on Monday during those same hours. The funeral, which is also open to the public, will be held on Tuesday 11 a.m. at Temple Emanu-El at 65th Street and 5th Avenue in Manhattan.

title: When the Choice Is Jobs or the Environment
description: For the past couple of decades, economic common sense and fears about climate change have coincided. Relying on fossil fuels was a mistake, both because we were running out of them and because of the impact of greenhouse gases on the environment.

title: Printing From Your iPhone, at a Price
description: Seldom do plug-and-play devices live up to the name. Its usually more like, plug, fail, reread instructions, curse, hold for tech assistance, fail, curse more, Google until you find an answer, play, try to soothe frazzled nerves.

title: All the Presidents Media
description: BUENOS AIRES  Last week, Argentinas small but active Twitter scene became transfixed with more than three dozen messages sent out by Juan Cruz Sanz, a young journalist at Clarn, the countrys largest circulation daily. Sanzs short missives recounted how high-level officials pressured C5N  a cable TV news station recently bought by an executive close to the government  to renege on an offer to hire him as a panelist on a late-night program. The spokesman of President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner and her chief of cabinet allegedly made calls to C5N managers. (A manager at the channel later denied the allegations, also on Twitter.)

title: In a Factorys Shadow, Fears About Health
description: By issuing carbon credits to companies for reducing emissions in the developing world, the United Nations aimed to inject cash into poor communities supporting the growth of sustainable industry, Elisabeth Rosenthal wrote in The New York Times. But in the remote village of Nathkuva adjacent to Gujarat Fluorochemicals Limiteds coolant gas plant, environmental groups and residents have been at loggerheads with the company over pollution since it opened in 1989.

title: Thursday Reading: The Financial Problems of Parents of Olympians
What Were Reading
description: Jezebel: New Coke, Coke Zero and Diet Coke Plus have all been consigned to the recycling bin of history. But 30 years after its birth, regular old Diet Coke remains the worlds liquid crack of choice. Why? One theory holds that its mix of low-calorie cred and suspect chemicals allows conscientious people an acceptable way to be bad.  Patrick Farrell

title: Wall Street Journal Editorial Praises Ryan for No. 2 Spot
description: The Wall Street Journal editorial page, a leading forum of conservative thought, had high praise Thursday for Representative Paul D.Ryan as Mitt Romneys possible running mate, citing his determination to curb entitlement spending. The editorial said that Mr. Ryan, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, had taken on entitlement spending against the advice of every Beltway bed-wetter concerned about the implications of such a cause.

title: The Veep Cometh!
description: This week we went from wading through Republican veep speculation to swimming in it. Mitt, I beg of you: announce your choice today or tomorrow, before we drown.

title: A Good Deed Goes Unthanked
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Power of Images: California Maps Greenhouse Gases
description: One of the most significant political problems facing campaigns against air pollution these days is this: by and large, you cant see it. You can track its molecules, watch emergency room admissions go up and down as it waxes and wanes and estimate the number of lives shortened by it. But none of that provides the jolt of, say, a picture of a tornados path or a river on fire.

title: Monkees, Despite Death of Davy Jones, Say They Will Go on Tour
description: The three surviving members of the Monkees say they will go on tour in November, minus the charismatic Davy Jones, who died in February.Michael Nesmith, Micky Dolenz and Peter Tork announced that they would start a 12-date American tour in Escondido, Calif., on Nov. 8, hitting several major markets before wrapping up with a concert in New York on Dec. 2.

title: The Troubled Life of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board
description: Back in 2003, the national commission on the Sept. 11 attacks advised that as the country bulked up its defenses against terrorism, the watchers themselves would require watching. Congress heeded the warning and created the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board in 2004 to make certain more aggressive intelligence collection did not unduly infringe on Americans rights.

title: E*Trade Replaces C.E.O. Amid Turnaround Effort
description: E*Trade has abruptly replaced its chief executive as the beleaguered online brokerage firm continues to overhaul its business.

title: Real Madrid Proves Its Class at Yankee Stadium Exhibition
description: Whos going to beat these guys? Well, maybe Barcelona. But who else?

title: The Games End, But Keepsakes Keep On
description: The closing ceremony is Sunday, but visitors to London who want to preserve the Olympic spirit can visit the British Library, which has mounted an exhibition of souvenirs and memorabilia that celebrate the nostalgic, personal side of past Olympic Games.

title: How to Make a Dead Cat Bounce on Twitter
description: Ive been told that in the olden days, reporters would write articles on these things called typewriters. And get this: These machines werent even connected to the Internet!

title: U.S. Womens Soccer Team Defeats Japan for Gold Medal
description: Andrew Das is live-blogging from Wembley Stadium in London.

title: S.E.C. and Justice Dept. End Mortgage Investigations Into Goldman
description: 9:06 p.m. | Updated

title: TimesTalks: Women of the Summer Games
description: The TimesTalks series hosted a panel discussion with current and former Olympians about how women's participation in the Games has changed and about their personal experiences.

title: Paulo Coelho Calls Ulysses a Tweet, Much Twittering Ensues
description: Since its publication in 1922, James Joyces Ulysses has been put on trial for obscenity and subjected to reckless overcorrection of its punctuation. But now the novel, widely considered one of the greatest works of the 20th century, has suffered perhaps its gravest indignity yet: being insulted by Paulo Coelho.

title: Business Day Live | August 9, 2012
description: Banks make unusually large gains on mortgages. | Ahead of its public offering, a look at what makes Manchester United a financial powerhouse.

title: Kids Draw the News: Children in the Beer Garden
description: New Assignment

title: Politicians, Protesters, Police: Charlotte Braces
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  The variety of demonstrators planning to invade this Southern city for the Democratic National Convention is wide and deep.

title: Viva La Villa | Ciao, Tuscany!
description: Adventures in house-hunting: a writer chronicles her attempt to find the perfect home in Italy.

title: Dear FloFab: The Case of the Runaway Beet
description: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: A Funereal Presence Swoops In to Roost and Caw
description: The installations of Janet Cardiff and George Bures Miller have always had a poltergeist quality; they disrupt space while being more or less invisible. Using ambisonic recording technology they engulf listeners in a constantly shifting three-dimensional field  a complete soundscape, as the artists call it. Submitting to one of these works is a deeply uncanny experience, even when the sounds are derived from glorious 16th-century choral music (as in their 2001 masterwork, The Forty Part Motet).

title: On Borrowing Digital Books From the Library
description: I had resisted the lure of electronic books for as long as I could. But this year I received an e-reader for Mothers Day. Im happy  but my wallet isnt.

title: Anthonys Olympic Play Bodes Well for the Knicks
description: At its current trajectory, the United States teams run to the podium on Sunday  barring the near impossible  will be remembered as the golden conclusion to the Summer of LeBron.

title: Object Monologues: Drama Strategies to Use With Any Days Times (Part 4)
description: This is Drama Week on The Learning Network, and each day, with the help of the theater teacher David Kener, weve published new strategies that can be used across subject areas, and with content you can find in any days paper.

title: Fusing Old and New, to International Acclaim
description: Wang Shu, whose buildings combine old-world Chinese and modern idioms, is the first Chinese architect to win the Pritzker prize.

title: Image of the Day: August 9
On Our Radar: An Agent Orange Cleanup
description: The United States and Vietnam begin a cleanup operation to rid a former army air base in Da Nang of the toxic residue of Agent Orange, a defoliant that was stored there by American forces during the Vietnam War. The United States Army sprayed millions of gallons of the chemical on vegetation to destroy enemy cover, a practice that has been linked to ills like diabetes, cancer and birth defects. Washington has not admitted liability for health problems caused by the herbicide. [Voice of America]

title: Shenandoah
description: David Turnley's "Shenandoah" Trailer

title: Carlyle Strikes Deal for TCW
description: 7:42 p.m. | Updated

title: The Bullying Culture of Medical School
description: Powerfully built and with the face of a boxer, he cast a bone-chilling shadow wherever he went in the hospital.

title: More Noir Than Chardonnay
description: I was out of money, and no money, I knew, meant exile. Id moved to 5 states in 10 years  California twice. In my 30s now, I had absorbed the gypsy lessons of starting fresh. I wanted to learn the art of having a home. Besides, I had finally fallen hard for San Francisco.

title: An Interview with a Regular Ohioan
description: John Harwood speaks with Rosemary Pallen of northeast Ohio.

title: Bolt Is First to Repeat as Winner of 100 and 200 Meters
description: LONDON  Usain Bolt is an all-but-impossible track and field act to follow.

title: Search Engines Log the Fearsome Journeys of War Families
description: A wife just found out her husband is going to war. Her husband stands in a doorway. She backs down a hallway away from the news of a deployment that keeps coming closer. She locks herself in a room, sits in front of a computer, and types into a search engine the phrase husband off to Afghanistan soon. She knows Afghanistan is not a word but a place. It is a country made of mountains, men, and machine guns where her husband will go to war and live or die. But she is searching for more.

title: Lolo Jones Article Is Too Harsh
description: Readers have weighed in to complain about The New York Timess Aug. 5 piece on U.S. Olympics hurdler Lolo Jones. Below is the response I have sent to those who e-mailed me about this:

title: Five-Ku: Short Poems on Sylvester Stallone in Advance of The Expendables 2
description: Oscar nomineesFor both acting and writing:Chaplin. Welles. Stallone.

title: Crepes du Nord Heads for the Malls
description: Morten Sohlberg, the owner of the Smorgas Chef restaurants in New York and the Crepes du Nord cafe in the financial district, has started cloning the French- and Scandinavian-inspired creperie in shopping mall kiosks. As in his other restaurants, he will emphasize sustainable and organic foods, with some ingredients grown on his upstate farm.

title: The Two Civil Wars
description: Josiah Williams was 23 years old when he saw his Uncle Whits head blown apart at the Battle of Cedar Mountain, which took place in north central Virginia on Aug. 9, 1862. But even his account as witness wasnt enough to convince his parents, back in Indiana, of Whits death. They simply refused to believe him and, without a body to bring back, he had no more proof to offer.

title: Bring It On and Closer Than Ever Extend Runs
description: Gimme an E! Gimme an X! Gimme  Well lets cut to the chase: The Broadway production of Bring It On: The Musical will continue through Jan. 20 at the St. James Theater, the shows producers announced on Thursday. It had been scheduled to close on Oct. 7.

title: Raymond Harding, 77, Dies; Liberal Party Power Broker
description: Raymond B. Harding, the former leader of New York States Liberal Party, who advanced the careers of mayors and governors but was disgraced in the corruption scandal that brought down State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, died on Thursday in the Bronx. He was 77.

title: American Nuns and the Fate of Liberal Christianity
description: Heres a passage frommy colleague Laurie Goodsteins dispatch from this years assembly of the Leadership Conference of Women Religious, the American nuns organization that was criticized by the Vatican earlier this year:

title: Bourne, Under New Management
description: Just before The Bourne Legacy gets its game on, the franchises new face, played by Jeremy Renner, comes out of the Alaskan wilderness to take refuge in a cabin. There he meets another of his kind, a superspy with a scowl and enough artillery to invade a small country. By the time theyve grudgingly warmed up to each other an unmanned drone is blasting everything to bits. Its an effectively blunt opener for a series that from its start has tracked a different military drone, this one a man fighting to recover first his identity and then his humanity. That you may not remember the name of Mr. Renners agent, Aaron Cross, after all the dust finally settles, suggests that the fight goes on.

title: Hagerty: Pebble Beach Auctions Could Gross a Record $215 Million
description: Collectible vehicles worth $205 million to $215 million will be coming to auction Aug. 15-19 at five events held in conjunction with the Pebble Beach Concours dElegance, according to an estimate released Wednesday by the Hagerty Price Guide.

title: 10 Questions for an Undecided Voter in Ohio
description: In the tight race for the White House, President Obama and Mitt Romney are spending millions of dollars to reach Americas small slice of undecided voters  people like Rosemary Pallen of northeast Ohio.

title: Thinking About an Exit Strategy (Well Before the Exit)
description: At a recent meeting of the She Owns It business group the two newest members shared their long-term goals for their businesses, YogaFit, owned by Beth Shaw, and the Megawatt Hour, owned by Deirdre Lord.

title: The Daily Shoe | Giuseppe Zanotti
description: Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the Bergdorf Goodman shoe salon in honor of the stores 111th anniversary. Todays pick: a graphic, black and gold platform from Giuseppe Zanotti. $775.

title: F.T.C. Fines Google $22.5 Million for Safari Privacy Violations
description: Boris Roessler/European Pressphoto Agency

title: FX Orders Cold War Spy Drama The Americans
description: The 1980s were a time of Reaganomics, Rubiks Cubes and the possibility that your seemingly straitlaced neighbors were actually undercover Soviet spies. Thats the premise of the new television drama The Americans, which will star Keri Russell, Matthew Rhys and Noah Emmerich, and which FX said on Thursday it had ordered for next year.

title: Summer Snapshot From Sunset Park
Haley Anderson Wins Silver in 10K Swim
description: LONDON  Call Haley Anderson the Flying Fish. Her range in the water calls to mind the versatility of Paavo Nurmi on the track, where in the 1920s he earned the nickname the Flying Finn on his way to Olympic victories in distances ranging from 1,500 to 10,000 meters.

title: How Successful Is CPR in Older Patients?
description: What are the odds of survival for people whose hearts stop  not in a hospital, but out in the world  and who receive cardiopulmonary resuscitation, at least long enough to get to a hospital and then to be discharged from it?

title: The Daily Shoe | Giuseppe Zanotti
description: Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the Bergdorf Goodman shoe salon. Todays pick: a graphic, black and gold platform.

title: Romney Faces Pressure From Right to Put Ryan on Ticket
description: WASHINGTON  Conservatives are increasing the pressure on Mitt Romney again.

title: Virus Seeking Bank Data Is Tied to Attack on Iran
description: A security firm said Thursday that it had discovered what it believed was the fourth state-sponsored computer virus to surface in the Middle East in the last three years, apparently aimed at computers in Lebanon.

title: Evil Bain and the Evil Empire
description: Political ads twist the truth, create false impressions, prey on voters most primal fears or just lie outright. We all know this; but that doesnt make the most recent exchange in the presidential campaign any less reprehensible.

title: What I Did Last Weekend
description: IT is the unofficial pastime of New York living: every day, all across the city, untold numbers of people spend hours perusing properties that they have no intention  and no means  of actually purchasing.

title: Obama Draws Contrast With Romney on Wind Energy Tax Credit
description: PUEBLO, Colo.  Speaking not far from a wind turbine manufacturing plant here on the hot plains, President Obama on Thursday contrasted his support for keeping alive an expiring tax credit for wind energy producers with the opposition of Mitt Romney to that subsidy and others for clean energy alternatives to oil.

title: Tokyo Rises Early for Womens Gold Medal Game
description: TOKYO  Soccer fans were napping to prepare for what the local news media were calling the battle of the century, the womens Olympic gold medal match Thursday between Japan and the United States, which was scheduled to kick off at a ghastly 3:45 a.m. here. Its national sleepiness day! says Miki, who tweets at @Mikilin999.

title: Iran, Excluded From Other Meetings on Syria, Hosts Its Own
description: TEHRAN  Shut out of diplomatic meetings on the Syria conflict, Iran convened emergency consultations of its own on Thursday, with participants from nearly 30 countries, including Russia and China, discussing ways to reach a solution. It was the first such gathering since the special representative Kofi Annan resigned as a United Nations and Arab League mediator last week.

title: Quiet Rioters | A Colorful Show of Support in Berlin
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: 4 Decades on, U.S. Starts Cleanup of Agent Orange in Vietnam
description: DA NANG, Vietnam  In the tropical climate of central Vietnam, weeds and shrubs seem to grow everywhere  except here.

title: How to Make Your Lost Phone Findable
description: Last week, I lost my iPhone on a train. I used Apples Find My iPhone feature to track it to a house in suburban Maryland, and the local police were able to return it to me. Because Id tweeted about these developments, the quest for the phone became, much to my surprise, an Internet-wide, minute-by-minute real-life thriller. (You can read the whole story here.)

title: Barclays Names a New Chairman
description: LONDON  Barclays, whose top management was toppled amid an interest rate manipulation scandal, on Thursday turned to a former Bank of England official to be its next chairman.

title: Romney at CNN Debate
description: Mitt Romney answered a question on misconceptions at the Republican debate in Arizona.

title: When Only a Shack Will Do
description: A SEAFOOD shack should be a little tumbledown, possibly decrepit, with insufficient parking and oil-stained cartons of fried mollusks dispensed brusquely through a window. You should eat at a picnic table, salt wind whipping your hair into your mouth, or take your haul down a poison-ivy-laced path to the beach, fending off stalker gulls. There should be a sunset that lasts half the night, and nowhere else you need to be.

title: Robert Zemeckis Movie Flight, With Denzel Washington, Will Close New York Film Festival
description: Theres no official word yet on which movie will be showing when the New York Film Festival takes off this year, but its organizers know how theyll bring the festival in for a landing: Flight, a new thriller directed by Robert Zemeckis and starring Denzel Washington, will make its world premiere as the closing-night selection on Oct. 14, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Thursday.

title: A Decathlon Favorite, From 1 to 10
description: Ashton Eaton of the United States built a big lead in the competition to determine who is often considered the worlds best athlete.

title: Gu Kailai: Selected Quotations
description: Before she was standing trial in a Chinese court on a murder charge, Gu Kailai, the53-year-old lawyer andwife of deposed political leader Bo Xilai, wrote a book in a breezy style disparaging aspects of the American legal system. The following are selected quotes from the book, Winning a Lawsuit in the U.S., published by Guangming Dailypublishing house in February 1998.

title: TimesCast Politics | August 9, 2012
description: Convention preparations underway in Tampa. | Looking at young Republicans. | Behind the new Will Ferrell political comedy. | A conversation about Romney and wedge issues.

title: Brooklyn Crab
description: Inside a three-story seafood shack located only a block from the Red Hook waterfront.

title: 36 Hours in Montpellier, France
description: NOSTRADAMUS, a former resident of Frances eighth-largest metropolis, might have put it this way: The lord of multicolored pants / Will conjure two iron serpents / And a bald builder shall erect / A mighty blue monolith. It would be an apt prediction of the splashy new projects appearing in this Mediterranean city, which has recruited titans of fashion and architecture to inject some style and modernity. Christian Lacroix, celebrated for his radiant clothing lines, has decorated two recently unveiled tram lines, while the superstar architect Jean Nouvel devised the plans for the enormous new monolithic (and very blue) city hall. Throw in a forthcoming futuristic municipal archives building from the architect Zaha Hadid, and this university center and night-life hotbed may be Frances most forward-looking city.

title: A Tour of Montpellier, France
description: Christian Lacroix and Jean Nouvel provide star-powered optical pop to this city by the sea.

title: The Spanish Campaign
description: Alongside the presidential campaign we all knowcentered at the moment on a debate between Romney Hood and Obamaloneythe candidates are waging a shadow war in Spanish, more closely focused on the issues politicians assume are particularly important to Latino voters. The newest foray is a dishonestSpanish-languagead running in Nevada, which attacks President Obama for breaking a campaign promise to pass immigration reform, and for deporting too many illegal immigrants.

title: How Not to Write to Your Child at Camp
description: This is the season when rural mail carriers backs start breaking from the additional weight destined for the summer camps along their route. In my capacity as the Mail Lady of Beam Camp in Strafford, N.H., I see the impact these letters have on their intended recipients. Some bring joy. Others  well, some of the mail circumstances force me to deliver makes me feel fortunate that my job prevents me from subjecting the two campers I spawned to the same blunders, well meaning though they may be.

title: In the Soup, A Dash of Biodiversity
description: A warm, brothy bowl of fibrous shark fin cartilage may not appeal to many palates, but every culture has its delicacies. Think of crunchy fried tarantulas in Cambodia, or a plate of garlicky snails in France.

title: Returning to Her Trail of Tears
description: IN 1995, after her mothers death and her own divorce, Cheryl Strayed decided to hike the mountainous Pacific Crest Trail, which runs from the Mojave Desert through California and Oregon to Washington State, alone. Oh, and she had no experience in distance hiking.

title: After a Jog 35 Years Ago, Hes Still Running in Circles
description: At 11 a.m. on Sunday two things will happen: in London, around 100 of the worlds fastest men will launch themselves onto the 26.2-mile Olympic marathon course, dashing from Buckingham Palace to the Tower of London in front of hundreds of thousands of excited spectators.

title: Broadway and Fulton Street, 12:18 P.M.
My Extended Sunny-Day Party Playlist
description: In the sidebars to myAugust Drink column,I couldnt fit every single song I want to hear while Im drinking tequila-watermelon punch, so heres the complete list. Its a subjective undertaking, guided partly by whims, current preoccupations and you-have-to-include-this mandates from friends.

title: Look of The Moment | Lady Gaga
description: The Look: Purple Reign. A midcentury-esque coat gets the Gaga treatment paired with exaggerated platform Mary Janes, oversize shades and beehive hairdo. The flower in her hair completes the kitsch-cool look.

title: TimesCast Politics: Preparing for the Conventions
description: Associated Press

title: Man Pleads Guilty to Killing Brooklyn Boy Last Summer
description: Levi Aron pleaded guilty on Thursday to killing Leiby Kletzky, an 8-year-old boy whose disappearance last summer from the insular Hasidic community of Borough Park, Brooklyn, transfixed New York City through a search that ended with the discovery of his dismembered remains.

title: Soaring Ointment Prices Are a Dermatologic Mystery
description: They are the staples of most dermatology practices: generic creams and ointments that treat everything from skin rashes to athletes foot to scabies. Many doctors prescribe the drugs without a second thought. But increasingly, some dermatologists say, patients are complaining about a recent, mysterious and rapid rise in price.

title: Post Office Troubles Mount With $5.2 Billion Quarterly Loss
description: WASHINGTON  The Postal Services financial problems worsened in the spring. The agency reported a $5.2 billion net loss on Thursday for the quarter that ended June 30.

title: Rising Cost of Skin Care
description: The price increases for these dermatological drugs over three years range from 100 percent to over 300 percent.

title: JPMorgans Mystery Number in Derivatives
description: There is one number that JPMorgan Chase apparently doesnt want outsiders to know: the overall size of the derivatives bets that have led to large losses and much reputational damage for the bank.

title: Justice Ginsburg Discloses June Rib Injury
description: This year, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg continued to work after breaking two ribs during one of the Supreme Courts busiest months, and just a few weeks before the court released its landmark decision on President Obamas health care law.

title: TimesCast Politics | Jay Roach Interview
description: The Timess Jeremy W. Peters talks to the director Jay Roach about parodying the political trail in the Will Ferrell movie The Campaign.

title: A Musical Double Take at Lollapalooza
description: At Lollapalooza this year, the photographer Ben Sklar set out to capture the euphoria that fans experience while listening to live music.

title: Murray Pulls Out of Rogers Cup With Sore Knee
description: TORONTO  One day after winning his first match at the Rogers Cup, Andy Murray withdrew from his scheduled match against Milos Raonic of Canada on Thursday because of a sore left knee.

title: Follow the Bouncing Beau
description: For two years, our son dated a man he loved. (We never cared for him.) Enter our daughter, who met this boyfriend at our summer home. The two of them went off together  and not innocently. Sparks flew. They are now a couple, leaving our son brokenhearted. And we are in the awkward position of having this man in our home as our daughters partner. Our son thinks we should not allow it. Is there any etiquette for a mess like this? Patty, Pelham, N.Y.

title: Competitive Armchair Olympics: Finale
description: The final installment of an illustrated, interactive live report from the 2012 London Olympic Games.

title: Bruce Nauman: One Hundred Fish Fountain
description: Gagosian

title: Wooster Enterprises, 1976-78
description: Churner & Churner

title: Les Rogers: Summer Swells
description: Half Gallery

title: Julika Rudelius: Rituals of Capitalism
description: Leo Koenig 541 and 545 West 23rd Street, Chelsea

title: Bookshelf
description: The Global Tree Project (Damiani, $40) shows off Shinji Turner-Yamamotos enchanting site-specific installations, including the birch trees he suspended in the nave of an abandoned 19th-century chapel in Cincinnati. Davy Rothbart falls in love instantly, often with the wrong people, which explains the title of his achingly funny essay collection: My Heart Is an Idiot (Farrar, Straus and Giroux, $25). From a 300-year-old silk Limoges bridal purse to a Cline tote, Judith Clarks Handbags (Yale University Press, $50) assembles standout pieces from the Simone Handbag Museum, which opened last month in Seoul, South Korea.

title: TTE--TTE
description: Yancey Richardson Gallery

title: Sad News Like a Warm Hug Goodbye
description: WHEN friends and colleagues heard that my father had died in an unexpected drowning  on Fathers Day, no less  they couldnt believe I was at work the next day, that I went swimming in the morning, that I was not at home weeping.

title: Another Jolt to Global Food Prices
description: For anyone doubting the importance of American agriculture to world markets, the latest price report from the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization will be revealing. The agency reported on Thursday that its food price index jumped by 6 percent in July. That was largely because of rising grain prices, with the drought in the United States and its expected impact on the corn harvest being the biggest factor. The cereals component of the index jumped 17 percent.

title: The Elements of Grooving
description: ITS not about the move, its the groove, Val Ho, a k a Ms. Vee, said to her hip-hop class at the Broadway Dance Center in Manhattan. I tried to take this advice to heart as I warmed up alongside nine fellow students on a recent afternoon. Most of them were women in their 20s with dance backgrounds and perfect posture.

title: Leap Three Stories, Impress Judges
description: U.S. Olympic coach Drew Johansen reveals some secrets behind the 10-meter platform dive.

title: Downtown Dance Festival, African Drumming and More
description: While Weekend Miser is soaking up the rays along the beaches of North Carolina (you think hed pay Hamptons prices?), he has passed the baton  or rather forwarded several e-mails  to us about all kinds of affordable cultural goings-on around New York.

title: Best Buy Suffers for Lack of a Plan
description: Confronted with an extraordinary situation, the board of Best Buy, the large electronics retailer, did what good corporate governance practices required. It fired the chief executive.

title: Competitive Armchair Olympics: Finale
Elf Will Return to Broadway for the Holidays
description: Heres an early Christmas present for aficionados of the 2003 Will Ferrell film Elf: The musical adaptation that ran on Broadway during the 2010-11 holiday season will return to the Al Hirschfeld Theater beginning Nov. 9, its producers have announced.

title: Excerpt: 'Into the Woods'
description: Donna Murphy sings Children Will Listen in the Shakespeare in the Park production of Stephen Sondheim and James Lapines musical.

title: N.H.L. Negotiations Take a Tense Turn
description: Talks between the N.H.L. and the players association turned sour Thursday, with N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman saying that a wide gap divides the two sides and that the owners will not proceed with the 2012-13 season if no new collective bargaining agreement is in place when the current one expires on Sept. 15.

title: United States Wins Womens Soccer Gold
description: LONDON  Megan Rapinoe cried. Hope Solo danced. Christie Rampone leapt into the air, jumping into the arms of Abby Wambach as Wembley stadium erupted around them. For all the elaborate celebrations the United States womens soccer team displayed over the course of the Olympics, the most memorable one was unrehearsed.

title: Former Goldman Programmer Is Arrested Again
description: The legal odyssey of a former Goldman Sachs programmer, Sergey Aleynikov, took a surprising turn on Thursday when the Manhattan district attorney charged him with state crimes.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Syria, the Philippines, India and Afghanistan.

title: Fame, That Sleazy Siren
description: Stomach-turning, sick-making, rancid, repugnant, repellent, squalid, odious, fetid, disgusting  there is a thesaurus full of terms to describe the contents of Bruce Wagners willfully offensive new novel, Dead Stars. Photos of dead babies; paparazzi in search of crotch shots of child celebrities; Internet posts celebrating an actors getting cancer; violent, graphic group sex; parents pimping out their children  one repulsive scene follows another in these pages, drowning the reader in a more- than-600-page-deep cesspool.

title: Jackson Pollocks Hamptons
description: Images from the artists studio in the East Hampton hamlet of Springs.

title: Meandering Just This Side of the Hamptons
description: I HAVE never been a fan of the Hamptons. Sure, the pristine beaches and sloping waves are a welcome respite from the Manhattan summer scorch that can melt the soles of your flip flops. But by the time midsummer rolls around on the eastern end of Long Island, a hint of desperation seems to settle in among the summer habitus who know that the days of sunset clambakes and lazy afternoons at Georgica Beach are coming to an end.

title: Wheelies: The Undercut Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Eaton Wins Gold Medal in Decathlon
description: LONDON  By the time Ashton Eaton finished, after he dashed and hurdled and jumped and vaulted, after he completed 10 grueling events in two very long days, he struggled to stand up straight. He paused at the final finish line and bent over, hands on knees, gasping for breath.

title: Obama Campaign Tries to Distance Itself From Widely Criticized Super PAC Ad
description: President Obamas top advisers have spent the last 36 hours trying to put distance between their candidate and a super PAC ad that lays the blame for the death of a cancer victim at Mitt Romneys feet.

title: Kiss Babies, Dodge Scandal, Praise the Lord
description: The Campaign is a comedy about a North Carolina Congressional election. Since it stars Will Ferrell and Zach Galifianakis as rival candidates  you probably know this if you own a television  the movie is obviously not a realistic depiction of the American electoral process. But its relationship to the reality of contemporary politics is nonetheless interesting to consider. Too soft and silly to be satire, too upbeat to be a cautionary tale, the film (directed by Jay Roach) is a fun-house fable that both exaggerates and understates the absurdities of our democracy in this contentious election year.

title: Bolt Wins 200 Meters
description: Usain Bolt of Jamaica edged his teammate Yohan Blake to win the gold medal at the London Games.

title: Come Let Us Adore Him
description: The babys feet must smell sweet to the rapt old king who kneels and cups them to his face like flowers. One of three sages and seekers, hes come a long way to find this child, who sits upright, grave and alert, on his mothers lap, though hes only 2 weeks old.

title: In the Orbit of Sancerre
description: EVERYBODY knows Sancerre. Thats a problem among some in the wine avant-garde, for whom familiarity breeds contempt. I have heard Sancerre sneered at as a sort of comfort food, signaling timidity in a cliquish world that sizes up personality and status by choice of beverage.

title: Wisconsin Is Sued Over Dogs in Wolf Hunts
description: The wildlife agency in Wisconsin, the only state that allows people to use dogs while hunting wolves, faces a lawsuit contending that it is permitting state-sanctioned animal fighting.

title: Sisters of Summer | Haim
description: The Los Angeles sisters Alana, Este and Danielle Haim, of the girl group Haim, started their musical careers in a band with their parents. We did covers of KEarth 101 songs, bands like the Eagles, Billy Joel and Santana, explains Danielle, 23, the middle sister. It wasnt until years later  Aug. 7, 2007, to be exact  that Danielle, her younger sister, Alana, now 20, and her older sister, Este, now 26, played their first show sans their parents. After taking a break to finish high school (Alana), finish college (Este) and tour with Jenny Lewis and Julian Casablancas (Danielle), the girls of Haim are now releasing demos, and their summer anthem Forever landed them on tour with Mumford & Sons. Here are Haims picks for their favorite jams of the season:

title: Varied, Colorful Elements, United in Performance
description: There seem to be odd little pockets of convergence in the musical cosmos. One involves the pianist Garrick Ohlsson, the composer Luciano Berio and Beethovens Emperor Concerto. The last time I heard Mr. Ohlsson play the Emperor was with the Philadelphia Orchestra in 1993, in a program with Epiphanies, a major work by Berio: a concert that because of a cancellation ended up also being conducted by Berio.

title: Pronks for the Memory: Rendering Luxury
description: WASHINGTON  Still-life painting bloomed as never before in the Netherlands in the 17th century, and among its most vibrant and coveted blossoms were those of Willem van Aelst (1627-83). He is the subject of Elegance and Refinement: The Still-Life Paintings of Willem van Aelst, a small, intense exhibition of 28 paintings at the National Gallery of Art here.

title: The Rewards of Patience
description: IN the darkest days of the housing crisis, paralysis was the word of the day. Even in the rarefied world of high-end New York real estate, developers and buyers alike had to put their dreams on hold, at least for a while.

title: The First Goal in the U.S. Victory in the Womens Olympic Soccer Final
description: The U.S. womens soccer team scored the first of its two goals in the eighth minute of its gold-medal-winning match against Japan.

title: Even in Death a Choreographer Is Mixing Art and Technology
description: Throughout his life Merce Cunningham came up with new ways to blend art and technology. He changed the way we think about space and time onstage, he explored dance on film before just about anyone else, and long before James Cameron and Hollywood made motion-capture cool, he was using three-dimensional computer animation to choreograph. Now, three years after his death in 2009, Cunningham is again at the vanguard. On Friday the Aperture Foundation is to introduce its first interactive application for the iPad, Merce Cunningham: 65 Years.

title: The Market Is Speaking. It Says $95 Million.
description: ITS as if 50 Central Park South had laid down a challenge to 15 Central Park West and any other building that believes its apartments can command sky-high prices.

title: Comedy Listings for Aug. 10-16
description: Comedy

title: A Universe Like Ours, Only Weirder
description: Not all filmmakers create complete and resonant fantasy worlds, rife with strange, sometimes frightening beings as well as mysterious movement, emotional suspense and uncanny detail. Fewer still are honored with extensive museum retrospectives that do these worlds full immersive justice, allowing devotees and neophytes alike to grasp the essence of their achievement and its evolution, strengths and weaknesses all.

title: 3 Guests, 48 Hours, Constant Agita
description: At the opening of her photography show, Marion, the high-strung heroine of 2 Days in New York, has an awkward encounter with a critic. Frustrated by his poker face and his noncommittal responses, and stressed out by everything else going on in her life (about which more shortly), Marion launches into an unhinged, obscene tirade at the poor man. Later in the film a karmically empowered pigeon drops an airborne excretory insult on him. Since Marion is played by the director of the film, Julie Delpy, I will take this as a warning.

title: Movie Listings for Aug. 10-16
description: Movies

title: Pop Listings for Aug. 10-16
description: Pop

title: Jazz Listings for Aug. 10-16
description: Jazz

title: Classical Music and Opera Listings for Aug. 10-16
description: Classical

title: Romneys Bus Tour Gets Some Unwanted Company
description: Mitt Romney is about to get some unwanted company on his upcoming bus tour across several swing states.

title: The Hamptons Without the Hubris
description: How to take the roads less traveled to a different Hamptons, far from the manicured landscapes, mansions and beach crowds.

title: Romneys Running Mate? Some Say Wikipedia Holds the Answer
description: Who could be Mitt Romneys choice for vice-presidential nominee?

title: U.S. and Gulf Allies Pursue a Missile Shield Against Iranian Attack
description: Thom Shanker reports in todays paper about an effort to knit together a regional missile defense system across the Persian Gulf to protect cities, oil refineries, pipelines and military bases from an Iranian attack. The shield is meant to be a pointed message to Tehran.

title: The Quay Brothers at MoMA
description: A new exhibition explores the puppet-centered universes created by the experimental animators known as the Quay Brothers.

title: Even in Car-Buying Behavior, New Yorkers Are Exceptional
description: As a New Orleans-style funeral march for a 1982 Honda Civic illustrated last weekend, New Yorkers share at times perplexing relationships with their automobiles. It only follows, then, that buying behaviors of the citys residents would be somewhat out of step with those of buyers outside the five boroughs and its suburbs.

title: Dance Listings for Aug. 10-16
description: Dance

title: Closing Fees Ease Up
description: FOR some people, a major hurdle to homeownership is the closing costs that come on top of the required down payment. There are fees for everything from title searches to deed recordings, and if you happen to be buying in New York or New Jersey, youll find some of the highest costs in the country.

title: A Naturalists Notes on London; Bettie Page Photos
description: PHILADELPHIA  Scholars have spent months poring through scribbles on a 1739 history of London that recently arrived at the Library Company, a research center here founded in 1731. The book belonged to Peter Collinson, a British cloth merchant and naturalist who was a close friend of Benjamin Franklins and a major importer of American plants.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Aug. 10-16
description: Art

title: A Pin-Up Archive Unveiled
description: A cache of vintage stills by the octogenarian photographer Bunny Yeager is going on sale, including many photos of the pin-up queen Bettie Page.

title: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 10-16
description: PRESERVATION DETECTIVES

title: Spare Times for Aug. 10-16
description: Around Town

title: Restored River a Boon to Yonkers
description: IN large part as a result of the ongoing city-and-state-funded effort to daylight the Saw Mill River, developers in Yonkers have been able to forge ahead on various real estate projects relatively unaffected by the economic malaise thwarting new construction elsewhere.

title: Beachfront, With Cessna Parking
description: WHEN a 37-acre tract in Montauk landed on the market at $18 million two weeks ago, it may have lent the term sky-high real estate another layer of meaning. The land in question is the home of the local airport, a privately held property with a 3,200-foot runway, a taxiway, six hangars, and a small terminal with two restrooms and two showers.

title: A Giveaway to Feel Good
Trapped in a Jungle and a State of Mind
description: Marcel Proust opened Swanns Way, in 1913, with reflections that occurred at the edge of sleep. Almost 20 years earlier Joseph Conrad had kicked off his first novel, Almayers Folly, with a rude awakening from a daydream. Both writers have inspired the Belgian filmmaker Chantal Akerman to make free adaptations: La Captive, her sensual, mesmerizing 2000 film (based on Prousts Prisonnire) and now Almayers Folly (La Folie Almayer), a tropical study in helpless intransigence, from Conrads often overlooked debut.

title: Rare Matinee, and an Even Rarer Mets Home Win
description: As the Mets walked back to their clubhouse at Citi Field on Thursday, a day of work complete, they heard a rather unfamiliar noise: cheers.

title: Manchester United Prices I.P.O. at $14 a Share
description: 9:52 p.m. | Updated

title: For Taller Sand Castles, the Secret Is Less Water
description: A group of physicists say they have figured out how to build taller, thinner sand castles: by mixing 99 parts sand with only 1 part water.

title: Islamists in North Mali Amputate Mans Hand
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Islamists who control northern Mali have publicly amputated the hand of a man they accused of robbery, continuing an increasingly harsh application of what the vast regions new masters consider sacred law.

title: Best Of Lists for the Lifestyle Crowd
description: Edgewater

title: The Victims of the Shooting in Wisconsin
description: Six people were killed when a gunman opened fire at a Sikh temple in Wisconsin. Learn more about the victims.

title: In Real Estate Deal, Romney Made His Loss a Couples Gain
description: MISSOURI CITY, Tex.  Look closely and it is there, sandwiched between Goldman Sachs Hedge Fund Partners II and D3 Family Bulldog Fund: the mortgage on Timothy and Betty Stampss modest home on Gentle Bend Drive here.

title: First Recession, Then Crime and Fear
description: DUBLIN  A womans cries for help pierced the sunny afternoon, alerting me that something was wrong  though what wasnt immediately clear. This was Blackrock, after all, a posh Dublin suburb of tended lawns and expensive houses sheltered behind stone walls lining narrow lanes. But Marie was lying on a sidewalk where seconds earlier, a man had sprayed mace in her eyes, shoved her into a spiky hedge and grabbed her purse, she said, crying in shock.

title: Q&A
description: Helping a Relative Rent an Apartment

title: To Save Water, Limiting Summer Soakings to Two-Minute Bursts
description: It was hot out on Thursday at the Glendale Playground in Queens, but the weather did not deter Nazar Nemy, 9, and two friends from doing some heavy lifting on the way to the playgrounds overhead sprinklers.

title: No Need to Get Your Top Hat Wet
description: THE big iron and glass marquee is not just shelter, its like white tie and tails. Step under one, and the sunlight falling through the glass makes you stand taller, live higher, dance better. Very few have survived, but each one is a treat nearly unique to New York City.

title: Hard to Have Dreams if Moms a Nightmare
description: If the aimless characters in Goats didnt feel so uncomfortably lifelike, it would be tempting to heap scorn on this wispy screen adaptation of Mark Jude Poiriers 2001 novel, directed by Christopher Neil from a screenplay by Mr. Poirier. The story is narrated by a 15-year-old named Ellis Whitman (Graham Phillips), a latter-day Holden Caulfield, without the quirks and the pathos, who lives with his nightmarish mother, Wendy (Vera Farmiga), on the outskirts of Tucson.

title: Suspect Sought in Shooting of Police Sergeant
description: The New York City police on Thursday released the name and a photo of the man being sought in the shooting of a sergeant during a pursuit in Queens.

title: French President Shuts Down Roma Camps and Seeks Relocation for Roma
description: PARIS  Despite criticism from Roma support groups and leftist politicians, President Franois Hollandes Socialist government, following a policy adopted by his predecessor, Nicolas Sarkozy, is dismantling illegal travelers camps and rounding up Roma from Eastern Europe for repatriation.

title: Yahoos Chief Reviews Plan for Alibaba Proceeds
description: Marissa Mayer, Yahoos newly minted chief executive,is reworking the companys playbook and nothing seems off limits.

title: For U.S. College Applicants, Extra Activities Are Encouraged
description: Students interested in attending an American university should know that admissions officers will base their decisions on more than just good grades and high test scores. They want to know how a student might enhance the university just by being there. A good indicator is an examination of personal interests, often illustrated by extracurricular activities.

title: Not Quite Swan Lake, but Surprisingly Close
description: If youre not a horse person, dressage is an odd event indeed. Horse and rider carry out carefully choreographed movements, often to music, in a formal manner, with their performance evaluated on tiny points of precision, line, apparent ease of execution and musicality. Then again, if youre not a dance person, you could say almost exactly the same thing about ballet  a strange ritual involving carefully choreographed movements, often to music, in a formal manner, with performance evaluated on tiny points of precision, apparent ease of execution and musicality.

title: Amgen, Citing Weak Results, Halts Study of a Cancer Drug
description: Amgen is halting a late-stage clinical trial of an experimental drug for pancreatic cancer after an outside monitoring panel concluded that the drug was unlikely to improve the survival of patients with an advanced form of the disease.

title: Health Insurer Refunds May Stall in Employers Hands
description: It was the great health insurance giveback: $1.1 billion in premiums returned to policyholders under the Affordable Care Act. But while many people who buy their own insurance found a check in the mail last week, millions insured through employers are still wondering what is happening with the money.

title: In a City Known for Its Shoes, Water Up to Its Knees
description: MARIKINA, the Philippines  Marikina is famed for its cobblers, whose handmade shoes are a source of local pride. Its Shoe Museum is home to a pair of shoes from each president of the Philippines, including 800 of the more than 3,000 pairs in the collection of Imelda R. Marcos. A barge in the Marikina River sports statues of two giant shoes, and what the city fathers claim is the worlds largest functional shoe  more than 15 feet long  is on display in a local mall.

title: Girardi Loses His Cool, but Yankees Win the Game
description: DETROIT  Frustrations boiled over in dramatic fashion Thursday as Yankees Manager Joe Girardi  veins bulging in his neck, and arms gyrating over his head  screamed and stomped and threw his hat, gesturing emphatically to the crowd as he stormed off the field.

title: A Painting Marathon at Beach Volleyball
description: LONDON  Pop music blared as women in bikinis danced around in celebration and drunken fans continued chanting. But Peter Spens was focused on his selection of brush, color and perspective.

title: For a Zealous Cop and a Gang of Two-Bit Thieves, Crime Does Not Pay
description: In the late 60s and early 70s, on television and at the movies, the streets were full of complicated cops: big-city detectives whose confusion, frustration and unorthodox methods reflected a general crisis of authority in the societies they served. Popeye Doyle, Dirty Harry Callahan and Frank Serpico (at least as imagined by Al Pacino and Sidney Lumet) made common existential cause with small-screen counterparts like Kojak and Columbo. Max, the sad, obsessive Parisian flic at the heart of Claude Sautets Max et les Ferrailleurs, is an especially memorable addition to this international brotherhood of disaffected policemen, even if his contributions have, until now, been largely forgotten.

title: Political Disagreement, Revisited
description: I was delighted by both the number and the quality of responses to my post last week about political disagreement. Here Ill try to rethink the issue in light of the many good ideas put forward by readers. (And apologies to all those whose excellent comments I havent been able to mention here.)

title: Big-Hitting Woodland Looks Comfortable on Ocean Course
description: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C.  Gary Woodland, one of the PGA Tours longest hitters, used his length to his advantage and posted 5-under 67 in the first round of the P.G.A. Championship. That score put him in a four-way tie for second place, one shot behind Carl Pettersson.

title: Russia: Activist Fined Under New Law
description: A Moscow court on Thursday ordered a political opposition leader to pay a $380 fine for organizing an unsanctioned demonstration. It is one of the first punishments to be levied under a tough law adopted in June to clamp down on street protests. The activist, Eduard Limonov, who organized a protest without a permit in July to support the freedom of assembly, had faced the possibility of an even larger fine under the new guidelines. Mr. Limonov said he already owed nearly $17,000 from previous verdicts. I earn less and less every day, he said. So I will not pay the $380 just like I did not pay the $16,880.

title: Mexico: Drug Suspect Extradited to U.S.
description: Sandra vila Beltrn, who is accused of being a drug trafficker and is known as the Queen of the Pacific, was extradited to the United States on Thursday to face cocaine-smuggling charges filed in a United States District Court in Florida. In 2007, Ms. vilas arrest in Mexico City on charges stemming from the 2001 seizure of nine tons of cocaine from a boat in the Mexican port of Manzanillo caused a stir because she was the first woman to be charged as the leader of an international drug-smuggling operation. She was acquitted of the Mexican charges at the end of 2010 and had been fighting extradition.

title: Little Camaraderie, Plenty of Crashes at BMX Races
description: LONDON  Given the carnage on display Thursday, it is safe to assume that whoever designed the BMX racetrack really dislikes BMX racers. Or has no regard for their safety. Or kind of enjoys watching them crash.

title: Deal Making in Hong Kong, Distracted by Debauchery
description: Dry as new bank notes and doggedly uncinematic, Simon Yins $upercapitalist approaches the seamy side of international finance with a story as stale as the subprime meltdown.

title: Britain: Judge Is Picked to Lead Inquest Into Death of Former K.G.B. Officer
description: Judicial authorities said Thursday that they had taken the unusual step of appointing a senior judge to hold a long-planned inquest into the death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer poisoned in London in 2006 with a rare radioactive isotope, polonium 210. The case soured relations between Britain and Russia, and the new development may put at risk recent improvements. At British inquests, judges replace coroners only in the most high-profile cases, like the inquiry into the death of Princess Diana. The hearings to be overseen by the judge, Sir Robert Owen, could provide the first opportunity in the case for witnesses to testify under oath. A procedural hearing is to be held next month. British prosecutors have accused another former K.G.B. officer, Andrei K. Lugovoi, of Mr. Litvinenkos poisoning  a charge he denies  and are seeking his extradition, which Russia has refused. Mr. Litvinenko, who fled Russia in 2000, had secured British citizenship shortly before he died, and he accused Russias leader, Vladimir V. Putin, of responsibility for his poisoning.

title: Faster, Higher, Stronger: Day of Golden Drama
description: LONDON  The worlds fastest man and the worlds greatest half-miler ran past the finish line and into the history books. Wembley, the iconic stadium, bulged with 80,203 fans for womens soccer as the United States found redemption against Japan. Ireland won its first gold medal in 16 years as womens boxing crowned its inaugural Olympic champions. And a friendly debate ensued about exactly who was the worlds greatest athlete.

title: Among Readers in Polyglot New York, 50 Shades of Best Sellers
description: The Chinese immigrants in Flushing, Queens, devour books with titles like Romantic Flower and The Heart With a Million Knots. The Russian women in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, clamor for a diet guide advocating plenty of meat. In Greenpoint, Brooklyn, a bookseller cannot keep a tell-all by the wife of an adored Polish politician on the shelves.

title: If Guns Do Not Kill, Tax the Bullets
description: In 1993, a United States senator with one of the great political brains of 20th-century America, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, said that we ought to forget gun control as a way to stanch criminal violence. It was hopeless, Senator Moynihan pointed out: even if the sale of new guns was totally forbidden, there were already enough guns in homes and private hands to last the country for 200 years.

title: Reflections on the Holocaust and a Survivor Who Defied Nazis
description: Barely 60 minutes long, the Holocaust documentary The Lion of Judah feels less like a feature film than a well-executed school project pulling together certain required elements: travel footage, reaction interviews, archival background and licks of music. The director Matt Mindell divides time between reporting on his tour of the Warsaw Ghetto and camps (Majdanek, Auschwitz, Terezin) with a group, and ceding the stage to an 81-year-old survivor, Leo Zisman, who recounts to visitors his experiences facing down Nazis.

title: Theodor Herzl, a Life From Journalism to Zionism
description: Bland is a word you probably dont associate with either the history of Zionism or Theodor Herzl. But the documentary It Is No Dream: The Life of Theodor Herzl, directed by Richard Trank, manages to be almost boldly dull. A production of Moriah Films, a division of the Simon Wiesenthal Center, It Is No Dream satisfies neither as a movie nor as a history lesson.

title: Daly, Still Fan Favorite, Is in Hunt in the P.G.A.
description: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C.  John Daly is 46 now, with a face that is growing leathery and a sluggish gait slowed all the more by the slightest limp. His shoulders sag, he has had lap-band surgery and he seems mildly embarrassed  and like something from another era  when he steps aside, turning his back to light a cigarette.

title: Neighborhood Joint | The Runcible Spoon
description: Every weekend, the Runcible Spoon in Nyack, N.Y., turns into a buzzing social hub for New York Citys amateur cyclists.

title: National Polls Show Clear Advantage for Obama Among Independents
description: In the all-important struggle for independent voters, President Obama is opening some daylight over his Republican rival.

title: Guns, Butter and Then Some
description: Back in the administration of W., we looked for the weapons of mass destruction in Iraq. That was the wrong place; theyre here at home. Normally the W.M.D. I write about is the Standard American Diet (yes: SAD); occasionally I talk about food safety, or climate change, or related topics. But no matter what you look at, the basic problem remains so-called leadership that cannot stand up to big ag, big food, big energy, Wall Street or the N.R.A.

title: DeAndre McCullough, Drug Dealer Who Inspired The Corner, Dies at 35
description: DeAndre McCullough, whose experiences as a 15-year-old drug dealer in Baltimore inspired the writer David Simon and the former police officer Edward Burns to feature him in the book The Corner: A Year in the Life of an Inner City Neighborhood, which became an Emmy-winning mini-series on HBO, was found dead on Aug. 1 in Woodlawn, Md. He was 35.

title: In the Shadow of Assads Bombs
description: Saraqib, Syria

title: Mr. Kings English-Only Bill
description: Bills that seek to make English the official language of the United States never go anywhere, but theres at least one proposed in every Congressional session, invariably put forth by Republicans to appeal to nostalgia for a mythical past. The latest is sponsored by Representative Steve King of Iowa, one of the most ardent restrictionists in Washington, whose other hard-line bills included one to build an electrified border fence (which he designed and once demonstrated on the floor of the House).

title: For Football Fans, the Focus Is on Monday
description: ESPN on Monday will introduce a new multimedia advertising campaign for its marquee program, Monday Night Football.

title: Rights for Domestic Workers
description: The California Legislature is considering a bill to extend basic labor rights to domestic workers: the nannies, cooks, baby sitters and other caregivers whose labor allows households to function smoothly, thus contributing to the larger economy. Domestic workers toil long hours for low pay, but have long been excluded from many of the fundamental protections most other workers enjoy under federal labor law.

title: At Hearing, Customers Complain of Unfair and Inaccurate Water Bills
description: A woman from Queens said her quarterly water bill jumped by more than $500. A small-business owner said his bill for the quarter rose to $10,000 from about $1,000.

title: Where Cyclists Fuel Up on Carbs
description: MEMBERS of this particular brunch crowd do not exactly meet at noon for mimosas and omelets.

title: Riling Up the Shrewd, Wild Boys
description: Today we would consider Edmund Keyser, who kept a saloon in Philadelphia during the 1860s, a compulsive gambler. But at the time he was known as a sporting man. Keyser enjoyed all of the eras brutal entertainments. He bet on bare-knuckle boxing. He bet on rat-baiting. He played the horses. And come October of each election year, he would scrawl busy canvassing in his meticulous wager book and entertain himself hustling for the Democratic Party.

title: Sudan and South Sudan Make Progress
description: Sudan and South Sudan ended a dangerous stalemate when they finally reached an agreement on oil pipeline fees last week. The elements of the deal should be carried out as quickly as possible given the severe financial stress on both nations.

title: Accuracy in Criminal Background Checks
description: For far too long, the federal government has neglected its responsibility for regulating the companies that provide criminal background checks used by 9 in 10 companies to screen job applicants. The damage done to job seekers by flawed and unreliable data  a common problem with such services  can be devastating.

title: Hear, All Ye People; Hearken, O Earth (Part 2)
description: This is the second installment in a two-part series.

title: Male Couples Face Pressure to Fill Cradles
description: WASHINGTON  When the jubilant couple were wed in June, they exchanged personalized vows and titanium rings, cheered the heartfelt toasts and danced themselves breathless. Then, as the evening was winding down, unexpected questions started popping up.

title: Interview: Martin E. Segal
description: An interview with Martin E. Segal conducted by the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

title: Striking a Blow for Ireland
description: BRAY, Ireland  For the Irish, Katie Taylor is more than a great athlete sprung from the native soil; people speak of her as if she has sprung from themselves, for she seems everyones sister, their daughter, their friend. She is the epitome of the strong-willed Irish lass. She has known what she wants out of life: a gold medal in boxing. And she has gone for it.

title: Romneys Side Course of Culture
description: When Mitt Romney asserted last week that culture does matter, he settled into a pose that was more triumphalist than anthropologist. Romney had begun by asserting that culture explained the difference in G.D.P. between Israel and the Palestinian Authority, but soon he was claiming that culture also made the United States the greatest economic power in the history of the earth. His attempt to define American culture settled in on vague attributes like patriotism, family orientation, honor and oath and freedom, a list that seemed cribbed from Ron Swansons Pyramid of Greatness.

title: What Should Be Eliminated From the Olympics?
How to Make Congress Do Its Job: No Budget, No Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDS in Uganda: Prevention Is Better Than Treatment
description: To the Editor:
