title: Lottery Numbers
Day 17: What to Watch For
description: Here are some of the events, teams and athletes to watch on Sunday at the London Games. (All times Eastern.)

title: Corrections: August 12, 2012
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Rena Samole, Michael Leizerman
description: Rena Mara Samole and Michael Jay Leizerman are to be married Sunday at the Toledo Club in Toledo, Ohio. Rabbi Edward Harold Garsek will officiate, with assistance from Rabbi Efraim Ira Eisen.

title: Lindsay Utz, Brannon Ingram
description: Lindsay Ann Utz and Brannon Dobbs Ingram were married Saturday at the Carlton Cellars vineyard in Carlton, Ore. Vincent Gonzalez, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Kimberly Miale, John Kelley
description: Kimberly Ann Miale and John Kevin Kelley were married Saturday in Our Lady of Mercy Chapel at Salve Regina University in Newport, R.I. The Rev. Luke J. Willenberg, a Roman Catholic priest and a friend of the couple, performed the ceremony.

title: Katherine Alex, Eric Stevens
description: Katherine Vassilios Alex and Eric John Stevens are to be married Sunday evening at the Worcester Art Museum in Worcester, Mass. The Rev. Kenneth Reeves, a Unitarian Universalist minister, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Eileen Yam and Elliot Williams
description: Eileen Yam and Elliot Williams were married Saturday at the Nassau Inn in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Michael J. Kelley, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Elizabeth Crowley, John McKinnon
description: Elizabeth B. Crowley and John D. McKinnon were married Saturday at St. Brendans Chapel in Biddeford Pool, Me. The Rev. Paul S. Sughrue, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Stephanie Anderson and Derrick Garrett
description: Stephanie Janine Anderson and Derrick Lamont Garrett were married Saturday evening at Bethel United Methodist Church in Flint, Mich. The Rev. Dr. Russell F. McReynolds, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Waman French, Gregory Johnson
description: Waman William French and Gregory Gene Johnson were married Saturday on Snow Dragon Mountain in Meredith, N.H. Donna Maresha Ducharme, a minister of the Sanctuary of Universal Light in Meredith, officiated; the Rev. Susan C. Crow, a United Methodist minister, took part.

title: Jessie Epstein, Scott Rudin
description: Jessie Lee Epstein, a daughter of Jodi S. Epstein and Mark D. Epstein of Alpine, N.J., was married Saturday to Scott Harris Rudin, a son of Bonnie L. Rudin and Mitchell E. Rudin of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Jonathan Blake performed the ceremony at the LongHouse Reserve, an art space and garden in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Talia Brodecki, Robert Gibson
description: Talia Leah Brodecki and Robert Sites Gibson were married Saturday evening at the Woodmont Country Club in Rockville, Md. Rabbi Lewis D. Solomon officiated, and the Rev. Jeanne K. Hanson, a minister of the United Church of Christ, assisted.

title: Esther Neuwirth and Kristian Leibfarth
description: Esther Sara Neuwirth and Maj. Kristian Karl Leibfarth were married Saturday evening at Belle Terrace, an event space in Avon, Conn. Rabbi Jon R. Haddon officiated.

title: Laurie Handwerker, David Braun
description: Dr. Laurie Rose Handwerker and David Alexander Braun are to be married Sunday at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, N.Y. Rabbi Robert Scheinberg is to officiate.

title: Marina Virnik, Sam Yospe
description: Marina Aleksandrovna Virnik, the daughter of Yelena A. Virnik and Alexander E. Tsoyref of Delmar, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Sam Alan Yospe, a son of Marilyn J. Yospe and Joseph F. Yospe of Edison, N.J. Rabbi Alan J. Lurie is to officiate at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y., with Cantor Shirona Lurie taking part.

title: Whitney Hopkins, Martin Oehmke
description: Whitney Price Hopkins, the daughter of Pamela W. Hopkins and Thomas H. Hopkins of Vail, Colo., was married Saturday to Martin Oehmke, a son of Anke Oehmke and Frank Oehmke of Bonn, Germany. The couple performed the ceremony themselves at the home of the brides parents, under Colorados self-uniting marriage statute.

title: Susan Collins and Thomas Daffron
description: Senator Susan Margaret Collins, Republican of Maine, and Thomas Daffron were married Saturday. The Rev. Dr. Thomas Bentum performed the ceremony at Gray Memorial United Methodist Church in Caribou, Me.

title: Emma Hayward, Matthew Gold
description: Emma Catherine Juliet Hayward and Matthew Gregory Gold are to be married Sunday at the Gorrono Ranch in Telluride, Colo. Kerry Walk, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate.

title: Jenney Wilder, Steven Labrum
description: Jenney Gibbs Wilder and Steven Carlston Labrum were married Friday at the First Congregational Church of Blue Hill, Me. The Rev. Robert M. McCall, the pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Jennifer DeRose, Samuel Kilbreth
description: Jennifer Lynn DeRose and Samuel Bartlett Kilbreth were married Saturday at the summer home of the grooms parents in Harpswell, Me. The Rev. Angie Arndt, a minister of the Chaplaincy Institute of Maine, officiated.

title: Corrie Tin, Eric Villatoro
description: Corrie Tin and Eric Villatoro were married Friday at the Loeb Central Park Boathouse in Manhattan. The Rev. Dr. Robert L. Brashear, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Jennifer Zolnierz, Joachim Bleys
description: Jennifer Lane Zolnierz and Dr. Joachim Bleys were married Saturday at the Church of Saint Monica in New York. The Rev. Joby Mathew, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Sara Nayeem and George Bell IV
description: Dr. Sara Michelle Nayeem and Dr. George Wall Bell IV were married Saturday evening at River Farm in Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Michael Godzwa, an Assemblies of God minister, officiated.

title: Lynn Strawbridge, Royal Edmondson
description: Elisabeth Dawson Strawbridge and Royal Brent Edmondson were married Wednesday in a Quaker ceremony at Merion Friends Meetinghouse in Merion Station, Pa.

title: Victoria Lin, Thomas Danhakl II
description: Dr. Victoria Lin and Thomas Charles Danhakl II were married Saturday evening at the home of the grooms parents, Katherine A. Danhakl and John G. Danhakl of Los Angeles. The Rev. Dr. Steve Faubion, a minister ordained by Reinhardt Bible Church in Dallas, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Christine Palyu, Craig Tosland
description: Christine Alaina Palyu and Pfc. Craig Anthony Tosland were married Friday evening in Fairview Park, Ohio. The Rev. Steve Harper, a minister of the Christian and Missionary Alliance, officiated at Bain Park Cabin.

title: Danielle Manchester, Eric Margelefsky
description: Danielle Lauren Manchester and Eric Louis Margelefsky are to be married Sunday at Flowerfield, a weddings center in St. James, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel Stein is to officiate.

title: Caitlin McCarthy and Bayard Dodge
description: Caitlin Glasheen McCarthy and Bayard Dodge were married Friday at St. Marys Church in Winchester, Mass. The Rev. Richard C. Messina, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Eileen Conlan, Theodore Stofer
description: Eileen Patricia Conlan and Theodore William Stofer were married Saturday evening at Alder Manor, a historic house in Yonkers. The Rev. Katherine Jeddah Vailakis, an interfaith minister, officiated.

title: Susan Nathan, Andrew Sutherland
description: Dr. Susan Newman Nathan and Andrew Gordon Sutherland were married Saturday at Waterside restaurant in North Bergen, N.J. Claude M. Coleman, a New Jersey Superior Court judge who presides in Essex County, N.J., officiated.

title: Marissa Kaplan, Aaron Dobbs
description: Marissa Frances Seinfeld Kaplan and Aaron Marc Dobbs are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Andrea Frank at Fishkill Farms, an apple orchard in Hopewell Junction, N.Y.

title: Neelam Jhawar, Abhishek Dube
description: Dr. Neelam Jhawar and Abhishek Dube were married Saturday at the Chicago Marriott Oak Brook in Oak Brook, Ill. Pandit S. Sundaresa Gurukkal, a Hindu priest, officiated.

title: Anne Macaulay, Jason Donahue
description: Anne Rodger Macaulay and Jason Louie Donahue were married Saturday evening at the Mandarin Oriental hotel in New York. Judge Paul A. Crotty of Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: Miya Shay, Gene Wu
description: Miya Shay and Gene Wu were married Monday at the Bob Casey Federal Courthouse in Houston, where Judge David Hittner of Federal District Court for the Southern District of Texas officiated in his courtroom.

title: For Asia, So Far, Paul Ryan Remains Out of Focus
description: HONG KONG  The official Chinese news agency and state-run media outlets on the mainland offered little commentary on the selection of Representative Paul D. Ryan as the running mate of Mitt Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee.

title: Angela Sclafani and Michael Olexa
description: AT the very beginning, Angela Sclafani thought the biggest problems she might face in her developing romance with Michael Olexa were the complications that inevitably arise from dating someone who is also your employee.

title: Earthquakes in Iran Kill Hundreds
description: At least 250 people were killed Saturday when two powerful earthquakes struck several towns near the Iranian city of Tabriz.

title: Romney Team Hints at More Openness on Ryans Tax Records
description: DULLES, Va.  A top aide to Mitt Romney said that the campaign had obtained several years of income tax returns from potential running mates  suggesting that Representative Paul D. Ryan had produced tax returns for a greater number of years than Mr. Romney has in his run for the White House.

title: What We're Watching on Day 17
description: While there are still some big events on Sunday, it's also time to reflect on the London 2012 Olympics. Members of The Times staff select their favorite athletes and stories of the Summer Games.

title: London 2012: A Gold Medal, or An Also-Ran?
description: There were drugs, of course there were  a slew of positive tests and expulsions, in weight lifting and race walking, in gymnastics and judo.

title: What Were Watching: On Final Day, Time to Reflect
description: (function($){var data = chameleonData;var ticker = new NYTD.NYTMM.NewsTicker($('#nytmm_embed_875'), data);})(jQuery||NYTD.jQuery);

title: Cleveland Browns, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
description: Its Year 14 of the Cleveland Browns rebuilding project. Or Year 3 of their third or fourth rebuilding project  however you want to look at it (averting your gaze would be understandable). The Browns finished 4-12 last season, the third straight year, and ninth time since their reinstatement in 1999, that they have lost at least 11 games. They did it primarily with bad offense (13.6 points per game, ranked third worst), though their defense was nowhere near as good as its No. 5 scoring ranking suggested.

title: Silver and Bronze Are Not Equal
description: Watching the Olympics over the past two weeks, I noticed something odd about the heights of the podiums during the awards ceremonies. While the podium on which the gold medal winner stands is  as expected  the highest, the heights of the silver and bronze podiums are the same.

title: How Not to Be a Helicopter Parent: Volunteer
description: Years ago, when one of my children was partying too much in high school, and college applications were looming, I quit my job teaching at a university and began working full time at home. In truth, I had been teaching college students on and off for 25 years, and I was at the end of my pedagogical rope. But I also convinced myself that staying home to badger my child 24/7 would improve his chances in life.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: Open magazine ran an Independence Day special on Radical Indians this week. Particularly interesting is a dissection of the work of Arundhati Roy, the writer and activist, whom the magazine labels the Queen of Exaggeration.

title: A Young Ugandan Surprises the Field and Himself
description: LONDON  The East Africans were heavily favored to win the Olympic marathon Sunday, but they happened to be Kenyans and Ethiopians, not a Ugandan named Stephen Kiprotich.

title: Highlights and Analysis From the Mens Basketball Title Game
description: The journey to the gold medal game for the United States mens national basketball team started with a simple question to Kobe Bryant about whether the current team could beat the Dream Team from 1992.

title: Ryan Brings the Tea Party to the Ticket
description: For two years, Tea Party lawmakers in the House have been the stubborn barbarians at the gate, strong-arming their often reluctant Republican colleagues by refusing to compromise on spending, taxes, debt or social policy.

title: Government Agencies Targeting Yoga Studios, Some Owners Say
description: Three years ago, yoga studios in New York waged a spirited and successful campaign to fend off a proposed state government regulation that some studios said would have led to their demise.

title: 200 Rescued in Iran After Quakes; Death Toll Rises to 300
description: TEHRAN  Iranian relief workers saved more than 200 people from the rubble of dozens of villages destroyed when two powerful earthquakes struck Saturday in a wide area north of the city of Tabriz, an Iranian official said Sunday.

title: Racial Profiling Charges Renew Questions About Counterterrorism Program
description: My Washington bureau colleagues Mike Schmidt and Eric Lichtblau wrote a revealing story Sunday on the accusations by more than 30 Transportation Security Administration officers at Bostons Logan International Airport that a program intended to detect terrorists has instead degenerated into racial and ethnic profiling.

title: Disruptions: Dining With Robots in Silicon Valley
description: MENLO PARK, Calif.  Millions of people watched a robot descend last week on Mars, about 154 million miles away, while it shared video, photos and status updates from its own Twitter account.

title: Romney and Ryan to Give First Joint TV Interview on CBS
description: 1:32 p.m. | Updated For their first joint television interview, Mitt Romney and Representative Paul D. Ryan have picked the most popular news program on American television: CBSs 60 Minutes.

title: Syrian Jets Pound Rebel Positions as Opposition Presses for No-Fly Zone
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian jets fired on areas in and around Aleppo again on Sunday, continuing an escalation of force that has led activists and rebels to demand that foreign forces establish a no-fly zone to counter the governments air superiority.

title: Chesney and McGraw: A Country Night in New Jersey
description: More than 56,000 people packed into MetLife Stadium on Saturday to hear Kenny Chesney and Tim McGraw perform back-to-back concerts, one of the largest country music events ever in the New York City metropolitan area.

title: In Upheaval for Egypt, Morsi Forces Out Military Chiefs
description: CAIRO  President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt forced the retirement on Sunday of his powerful defense minister, the army chief of staff and other senior generals, moving more aggressively than ever before to reclaim political power that the military had seized since the fall of Hosni Mubarak last year.

title: The Bourne Legacy Leads Weekend Box Office
description: The Bourne Legacy managed to sell an estimated $40.3 million in tickets at North American movie theaters over the weekend, a No. 1 opening that was solid if not spectacular. Legacy, featuring Jeremy Renner, cost Universal Pictures and a financing partner at least $125 million to produce and tens of millions more to market.

title: James and U.S. Replenish Gold in Treasure Chest
description: LONDON  The Americans stood together on the highest platform, in the same place everyone but Spain figured they would stand Sunday afternoon. An official hung gold medals around their necks, and in that moment, the favorites, a collection of basketball millionaires, reverted to childhood.

title: U.S. Mens Basketball Team Wins Gold
description: The United States defeated Spain, 107-100, for the Olympic gold medal in mens basketball.

title: A Morning Spent Trying to Define Ryan
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama campaign wasted no time on Sunday in trying to paint Mitt Romneys newly announced running mate, Representative Paul D. Ryan, as an extreme politician who would destroy the Medicare program and deprive women of abortion rights.

title: Ugandans Moment to Shine
description: Stephen Kiprotich of Uganda surged at the 23-mile mark Sunday to win the Olympic marathon.

title: New Republican Ticket Keeps Focus on Obamas Record
description: MOORESVILLE, N.C.  On his second day as Mitt Romneys running mate, Representative Paul D. Ryan slammed President Obama, telling an energized crowd in North Carolina on Sunday that Mr. Obama had had his chance to fix the ailing economy but had failed.

title: Its About the Bike
description: To the Editor:

title: Sabathia, Not Used to Pain, Said Arm Troubles Made Him Really Nervous
description: TORONTO  C. C. Sabathia said he would definitely pitch as soon as he was eligible to come off the disabled list, which is Aug. 24 in Cleveland, but he also said he was worried when his left elbow stiffened up 10 days ago. He lost so much range of motion, he said, that he could not touch his left shoulder with the fingers on his left hand.

title: Looking Sharp
description: To the Editor:

title: The Art of Writing
description: To the Editor:

title: Fiction Fans
description: To the Editor:

title: I Laughed, I Cried
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Games, Rhythmic Gymnastics Is for Women Only
description: The mens version of the sport has more of a martial arts accent and places greater emphasis on speed and power.

title: Pictures of the Day From London | August 12, 2012
description: The 17th day of the London Olympics.

title: High Above Columbus Circle, a Living Room, TV Included
description: Imagine youre a New York City building official, and the mayors office has decided to let an artist build a living room six stories up in the air and wrap it around a historic statue of Christopher Columbus in the middle of one of Manhattans busiest intersections.

title: Enduring Drought, Farmers Draw the Line at Congress
description: THURMAN, Iowa  John Askew pulled at a soybean pod and revealed two anemic beans dappled with stem rot, the harvest of a too hot sun and too little rain. Representative Tom Latham peered in and shook his head.

title: Soros Prepares to Walk Down the Aisle for the Third Time
description: George Soros is ready to take up married life yet again.

title: In London, a Memorable and Musical Closing Ceremony
description: LONDON Campbell Robertson, Sarah Lyall and Victor Mather had prime seats in the upper deck of the Olympic Stadium for the sights and the sound of the closing ceremony of the London Olympics.

title: Officials Defend Fatal Shooting of a Knife-Wielding Man Near Times Sq.
description: The New York police officers who fatally shot a knife-wielding man after he escaped arrest near Times Square did what they were trained to do, city officials and experts on police procedure said Sunday.

title: Big-Data Investing Gets Its Own Supergroup
description: Big Data is getting a council of wise men. With money.

title: Mozart Festival Theme Takes Flight, From Lobby to Stage
description: It is hard to attend Mostly Mozart Festival concerts these days without getting birds on the brain. Birds and bird song are a pervasive element of this years festival, which is exploring the avian theme inside and outside the concert hall, as Lincoln Centers artistic director, Jane Moss, explains in a program note.

title: Digital Diary: How GIFs Became the Perfect Medium for the Olympics
description: This years Olympic Games have been the most compelling I can remember watching: the elaborate blinged-out accessories worn by Ryan Lochte, the staggering physical feats of Usain Bolt, Gabby Douglass heartwarming win.

title: Tough Love in a Tough Job Market
description: Get to Work, an eight-episode reality series that begins Monday on the Sundance Channel, sounds from the title as if it might help the mainstream unemployed  the middle-income victim of downsizing, the blue-collar laborer whose factory has closed  find employment. It wont.

title: Yanks Rally Falls Short as Hughes Loses Grip
description: TORONTO  At the moment that virtually every pitch is thrown by every pitcher at every level of baseball, the throwing hand pronates. When the hand releases the ball, the thumb tends to twist underneath the hand in a circular motion, followed by the index and middle fingers.

title: A Royal Power Player Who Sprints to the Throne
description: No character in Shakespeare is as hungry for power as Richard III. And its hard to think of an actor with a naturally hungrier look than Ron Cephas Jones, the tall, beanpole-thin, snakelike actor who portrays the title character in the production of Richard III from the Public Theaters new Mobile Shakespeare Unit. This scaled-down staging has been presented at prisons, homeless shelters and other sites in underserved neighborhoods before returning to the companys home base on Astor Place.

title: Pick a Topic, Any Topic. He Did.
description: In the final essay of this hodge-podgy collection, Nicholson Baker  best known for his microscopically detailed accounts of daily life, his love of the minute, the specific, the Seinfeld-ian small  notes that hed like to write a book for children and adults called The Way the World Works, a book that would explain everything about history, beauty, wickedness, invention, the meaning of life, the whole unseemly, bulging ball of wax.

title: Both Sides Focus on the Republican Tickets New Face
description: WAUKESHA, Wis.  Democrats moved aggressively on Sunday to wrap Mitt Romney in the politically charged details of budget-cutting proposals championed by his new running mate, Representative Paul D. Ryan, as Mr. Romney sought to capitalize on conservative enthusiasm for his choice without having to defend every element of Mr. Ryans positions.

title: Stars and Athletes Tread a New Stage, One With Live Ammo
description: The thanking of our troops is a fine gesture, but one easily exploited by anybody looking for an applause line or a few more votes or, perhaps, improved television ratings.

title: The New Boss, Not the Same as the Old Boss
description: Lets say your highly successful television show is ending because the star is moving on, and you want to create a new show that will suck in as many of the old viewers as possible. What do you do?

title: James Naughton, Newsman and Puckish Inspiration, Dies at 73
description: James M. Naughton, a prank-loving White House and national correspondent for The New York Times during the Nixon, Ford and Carter administrations and later a senior editor at The Philadelphia Inquirer for almost two decades, died on Saturday at his home in St. Petersburg, Fla. He would have been 74 on Monday.

title: Fighting Their Way Up Art World Ladder
description: Meet Liz, an aspiring pop socialite in the Olivia Palermo mold, haughty enough to disdain the commoners around her but vain enough to crave their attention. Her father is an art collector, and at least partly because of that, shes been able to secure an internship at Eli Klein Fine Art, a SoHo gallery. Thats where shell work  but not very hard  on Gallery Girls, the Bravo reality series that has its premiere on Monday and that is rooted in the belief that there is privilege, and there is bootstrapping, and neer the twain shall meet.

title: Footnote
description: Carolina Performing Arts at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, is set to announce a new concluding program for its performance season, The Rite of Spring at 100, to be presented by the Martha Graham Dance Company. Titled Myth & Transformation, the two-night program will feature Grahams interpretation of Stravinskys Rite of Spring; the world premiere of a work choreographed by Nacho Duato with music by Arvo Prt; and performances by the guest artist Wendy Whelan, a principal dancer for the New York City Ballet. The program is scheduled for April 26 and 27.

title: Beneath the Dappled Light, Theres Safety and Charm in Numbers
description: In perhaps the most famous aria in all of Handels operas, Ombra mai fu, King Xerxes of Persia states that no shade was ever so dear as that of his beloved plane tree. Though Ive observed plane trees all my life and have known that aria for decades, only on Saturday did Handels sublime melody come to mind  when I spent over two hours in the shade of plane trees in Battery Park, watching the opening event of the 31st annual Downtown Dance Festival. The charm of those trees shade on a warm afternoon, the ravishing way they filtered the brightness of the light, and the dappled look of the leaves from beneath: all brought back Xerxes words as set to music by Handel.

title: The Veil of Opulence
Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS The data will include retail sales for July, the producer price index for July and business inventories for June (Tuesday); the Consumer Price Index for July and industrial production for July (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, housing starts for July, and the Philadelphia Fed index for August(Thursday); and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for August and leading economic indicators for July (Friday).

title: Occupy Wall Street Inspires a Show
description: In commemoration of the one-year anniversary of the Occupy Wall Street movement, the Civilians theater company will assemble an evening of performance material inspired by more than 150 interviews with activists associated with the Occupy movement that have been conducted over the last year. A cabaret, called Let Me Ascertain You: Occupy #S17, is to feature monologues and songs created by Civilians artists from their interviews. It will run for one night, Sept. 17, at Joes Pub at the Public Theater.

title: A Memoir to Come From Billy Crystal
description: The comedian Billy Crystal has reached an agreement with Henry Holt & Company to publish a memoir covering over four decades of his life and featuring his thoughts on growing older, The Associated Press reported. Financial terms for the book were not disclosed, but it was reported that the deal could be worth about $4 million. Mr. Crystal, who will turn 65 next year, also hopes the book will translate to the stage in a similar fashion to his previous memoir, 700 Sundays, which was adapted into a one-man play in 2004 and won a Tony Award in 2005 for Special Theatrical Event.

title: Obama Says He Fundamentally Disagrees With Ryans Vision for the Country
description: CHICAGO  President Obama addressed his rivals vice-presidential choice for the first time on Sunday, calling Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin a nice guy whose leadership would be a national disaster.

title: Strides New Flavor of Chewing Gum: Red Herring
description: ON Aug. 1, a billboard appeared in the SoHo neighborhood of Manhattan displaying only a date, 08.13.12, and clues seemed to point to Apple.

title: Ultra Brands End Dispute Over Their Name
description: At nightclubs and festivals around the world, dance music is all about good times. But behind the scenes of this increasingly lucrative and competitive sector of the music business lie the same kinds of disputes over trademarks and exploitation rights that plague any industry.

title: Second World Mind Sports Games in France
description: LILLE, France  After Sundays play at the Second World Mind Sports Games here, the qualifying stage was just over half completed.

title: Exploring the Bounds of Propriety
description: Administrivial Vacation Alert! Ill be on vacation this week, but during the meanwhile you will be in the very capable hands of Tom Gaffney, fellow puzzlehead. Ill be back for the Tuesday, Aug. 21 post, and look for this blog to be outfitted in a Deb Amlen Went on Vacation and All This Blog Got Was a Lousy T-Shirt t-shirt upon my return. Have a great week, and keep on solving!

title: Documentary Exploring Obamas Political Roots
description: Dinesh DSouza  the author of the best seller The Roots of Obamas Rage and a former American Enterprise Institute fellow  is not a fan of President Obama. The strident documentary 2016: Obamas America (co-directed with John Sullivan) builds on Mr. DSouzas 2010 cover article for Forbes, which asserts that Mr. Obama pursues his fathers left-leaning, anticolonial ideals. Here they are presented as flaws consistent with the senior Obamas multiple relationships, alcoholism and fatal auto accident in 1982.

title: Raised Far From Home, and the Pinochet Regime
description: Opens on Monday in Manhattan.

title: Rewards and Punishments for Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Wanted, Dead or Alive: Used Books
description: ARCHER CITY, Tex.  Larry McMurtry, the famed author of Lonesome Dove and dozens of other books, was walking slowly along State Highway 79 on Friday morning toward this towns only major intersection. Down the block, more than 150 collectors and dealers were queuing up to bid on 300,000 used books  about two-thirds of the stock of Booked Up, the four-building literary mecca that Mr. McMurtry started here in 1988.

title: A Spotlight on the G.O.P. Running Mate
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Sick Leave
description: To the Editor:

title: The Beginning of Back to Normal
description: Periodically throughout the Olympics, we checked in with Dennis Spurr, the owner of the Fantastic Sausage Factory in Weymouth, a pretty town on the English coast where the sailing events took place. Spurrs sausage business was a target of the Olympic branding authorities in 2007 after he put up a sign featuring the Olympic five-ring logo done in sausage links. He took it down on their demands, but replaced it with a sign featuring five squares made of sausage links.

title: A Steep Climb Back for Facebooks Stock
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Facebook spring is over. The dog days of August have taken hold.

title: Senate Primary in Connecticut Sets Experience Against Money
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn.  It was full-service retail politics on Thursday for Christopher Shays at the New Canaan Metro-North train station.

title: Argentinas New Literary Tradition: Pensions for Aging Writers
description: BUENOS AIRES  It is not enough for this city to boast cavernous bookstores that stay open past midnight, broad avenues once roamed by literary giants like Jorge Luis Borges, cafes serving copious amounts of beef and red wine, or even a bizarre neo-Gothic skyscraper, the Palacio Barolo, inspired by Dantes Divine Comedy.

title: Cruz Cringes at Replacement Officials
description: ALBANY  Add Victor Cruz to the growing number of N.F.L. players who are concerned about the leagues replacement officials.

title: Paul Ryan, Black Panther?
description: Did Paul Ryan quote a famous 1960s Black Panther Party slogan in his speech on Saturday announcing his candidacy for vice president on the Republican ticket?

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Dale Olson, Top Hollywood Publicist, Dies at 78
description: Dale Olson, a top Hollywood publicist who protected the public images of a throng of stars, including Clint Eastwood, Steven Spielberg, Shirley MacLaine, Gene Kelly and Joan Crawford, and who helped persuade Rock Hudson to announce that he had AIDS, died on Aug. 9 in Burbank, Calif. He was 78.

title: The Last Book Sale
description: Larry McMurtry auctioned some 300,000 used books from his bookstores in Archer City, Tex.

title: A Bird Magazines Final Chirps in Print
description: For three decades, fans of Bird Talk magazine have dutifully collected issues for their articles and centerfolds. But the September issue is the last that will appear in print, leaving disappointed subscribers with BirdChannel.com, the magazines related site, as the only way to read the publications information on all types of birds  from love birds to macaws and cockatoos.

title: MundoFox to Enter the Latino TV Market
description: LOS ANGELES  The correspondents were on camera and on location in Mexico City, Washington and Los Angeles. Rolando Nichols, the lead anchor, listened intently to the receiver in his ear as he stood in front of the bright red walls of the news studio.

title: Wondering How Far Magazines Must Fall
description: Making a weekly newsmagazine has always been a tough racket. It takes a big staff working on punishing deadlines to aggregate the flurry of news, put some learned topspin on it and package it for readers. But that job now belongs to the Web and takes place in real time, not a week later.

title: Israeli Minister Asks Nations to Say Iran Talks Have Failed
description: JERUSALEM  Amid intensifying Israeli news reports saying that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is close to ordering a military strike against Irans nuclear program, his deputy foreign minister called Sunday for an international declaration that the diplomatic effort to halt Tehrans enrichment of uranium is dead.

title: Slither, Flutter and Glow: Lure of Nocturnal Creatures
description: Mike Feller directed his headlamp toward a fallen log. A dot of green beamed back, the telltale eyeshine. It was coming from a fishing spider, an arachnid known for its multiple eyes, considerable girth (two inches in diameter) and speed of movement.

title: Woman Becomes First Openly Gay General
description: WASHINGTON  An Army officer being promoted to brigadier general openly acknowledged her homosexuality on Friday by having her wife pin her star to her uniform, thus becoming the first openly gay officer of flag rank in the United States military.

title: Paul Ryans Liberal Fan Club
description: There is one point on which Democratic strategists and the hard right are united: they fervidly support Mitt Romneys decision to choose Paul Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, as his vice-presidential running mate.

title: Britain Takes a Final Bow
description: LONDON  With a gaudy three-hour farewell that mashed up theater, acrobatics, fashion and a few generations of musical idols, London extinguished the Olympic torch Sunday night, capping two weeks of athletic achievements with a jukebox collection of songs and a marathon display of endearingly wacky stagecraft.

title: In 12 Race, Mayor Seeks Immigration Discussion
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg wants the presidential candidates to talk more about immigration policy. So on Tuesday, he will be visiting the cities where their campaigns have headquarters, pressing them on the issue.

title: NBC Banks on Olympics as Springboard for New Shows
description: The Olympics have cast a spell over NBC for the last two weeks, bestowing the gift of flight on a network long stuck in ratings mud. But like Wile E. Coyote suddenly discovering his jet pack has run out of fuel, a vertiginous plunge looms.

title: Will Paul Ryan Make a Difference in the U.S. Election?
description: WASHINGTON  The selection of Paul Ryan, chairman of the U.S. House of Representatives Budget Committee as Mitt Romneys running mate has excited Republican activists, but its hard to find a successful role model for the seven-term congressmans quest to become vice president.

title: Key Officials Under Karzai Are Criticized
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The chief of Afghanistans antigraft commission has called for the countrys finance minister to step aside while he is being investigated in connection with corruption allegations, even as the minister appealed to his Western backers for support.

title: Tutoring Not Required Under a Federal Waiver
Hollywood Eager to Feed Chinas Appetite for 3-D
description: BEIJING  Zheng Huan and Tang Xiaomei, infrequent moviegoers from rural Jiangxi in southeast China, saw their first 3-D film last week while visiting the capital.

title: You Had to Be There
description: On Londons Olympic stage, athletes, fans and volunteers created a memorable experience. Four New York Times reporters reflect on their impressions covering their first Olympics.

title: Astros Begin Again, Starting With Youth and Hope
description: HOUSTON  The Mules of Central Missouri State won one game at the 1974 N.C.A.A. Division II College World Series. A tall, right-handed sophomore with a fastball, a curveball and a knuckle-change fired a 2-0 shutout against Ohio Northern, striking out 11 in a row at one point. He went undefeated as a junior but stretched a tendon in his shoulder as a senior and never pitched again.

title: Some in California Skirt a Ban on Foie Gras
description: SACRAMENTO  Seemingly an afterthought, the last appetizer listed on the menu at Restaurant Thir13en is a brioche that, at $21, may sound overpriced even if it is house made and comes with strawberry rhubarb pure and a bacon chip. Accompanying it, though, are complimentary seared foie gras and foie panna cotta.

title: Climbing the Rankings, and Hoping to Follow in His Brothers Footsteps
description: MASON, Ohio  Though he is still a long distance from where he wants to be, Christian Harrison is moving quickly through the familiar footsteps that have gone before him.

title: Final Event of the Games Concludes With a Roar
description: LONDON  By the time Narumi Kurosu entered the ring for the final meters of her run in the womens pentathlon Sunday, her native Japan, as well as Cuba, Britain, Kazakhstan, Lithuania, Russia, Uganda and the United States, had already struck Olympic gold.

title: Libor Case Energizes a Wall Street Watchdog
description: Months after he arrived in Washington in 2009, Gary Gensler knew he had a big case.

title: The One Housing Solution Left: Mass Mortgage Refinancing
description: MORE than four million Americans have lost their homes since the housing bubble began bursting six years ago. An additional 3.5 million homeowners are in the foreclosure process or are so delinquent on payments that they will be soon. With 13.5 million homeowners underwater  they owe more than their home is now worth  the odds are high that many millions more will lose their homes.

title: For Ryan and Obama, More Than the Usual Rivalry
description: When President Obama was first elected, aides say, he saw Representative Paul D. Ryan, another ambitious Midwestern policy wonk, as someone he could possibly work with to reverse the building federal debt.

title: Problems Riddle Moves to Collect Credit Card Debt
description: The same problems that plagued the foreclosure process  and prompted a multibillion-dollar settlement with big banks  are now emerging in the debt collection practices of credit card companies.

title: Korea Policing the Net. Twist? Its South Korea.
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A government critic who called the president a curse word on his Twitter account found it blocked. An activist whose Twitter posting likened officials to pirates for approving a controversial naval base was   accused by the navy of criminal defamation. And a judge who wrote that the president (His Highness) was out to screw Internet users who challenged his authority was fired in what was widely seen as retaliation.

title: Lottery Numbers
Philip Marlowe, Peerless Detective, Returns for an Encore
description: In his spare time, Philip Marlowe plays chess with the dead, working out problems from a book of historic games as though a living chess player might let him down. He reads the society page when he has run out of things to dislike. He is a softhearted cynic, yet truer to the spirit of the law than any lawman.

title: Again Backing Santana, a Met Reaffirms His Painful Decision
description: As Johan Santana delivered the first few pitches of his start against the Atlanta Braves on Saturday night, the Mets Mike Baxter momentarily felt an eerie familiarity and smiled to himself.

title: McIlroy Dominates Another Major
description: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C.  The birth of a champion, and maybe golfs next dominant player, was dispiriting, humiliating defeat. Put Rory McIlroy back in the woods of the 10th hole at the 2011 Masters as he whacked his ball from tree to tree, a boy lost in the forest on his way to a mortifying fall from the summit of the leader board.

title: Free Speech at Military Funerals
description: President Obama signed a new law last week that broadens federal limits on protests at military funerals for members or former members of the Armed Forces. The changes cover services held in private places as well as military cemeteries.

title: The Romney-Ryan Plan for America
description: Less than 24 hours after Mitt Romney chose Paul Ryan as his running mate on Saturday, his campaign was already trying to distance itself from Mr. Ryans politically toxic budget plan. His budget is not ours, the campaign said; Mr. Romney will be putting together his own plan for cutting the deficit and putting the budget on a path to balance.

title: The Romney Package
description: BRACE yourself for weeks of chatter about Mitt Romneys running mate. Vice presidents matter, as we have been spookily reminded by the recent re-emergence of Dick Cheney on our TV screens. And Paul Ryan matters more than most. (See below.)

title: In the Name of the Future, Rio Is Destroying Its Past
description: Rio de Janeiro

title: Paul Ryans Journey
description: Some of the milestones in Representative Paul D. Ryans life and career.

title: Is the Threat From Hate Groups Overlooked?
Closing Time
description: An eclectic mix of British performers took the stage as the Olympics drew to an end.

title: Robert Gould Shaws Gruesome Task
description: On Aug. 11, 1862, Robert Gould Shaw arrived in the Virginia town of Culpeper on a grim errand: the young lieutenant was there to accompany the remains of five fellow officers on the first leg of a final journey home to Boston. Before the bullet-ridden corpses were packed for shipment, Shaw carefully clipped a lock of hair from the lifeless head of one body. He repeated the somber act on the others, and put the locks away for safekeeping. He planned to present the keepsakes to mourning friends as a memento mori.

title: Effort to Cut Milan Traffic Halted as Court Favors Garage
description: MILAN  It would seem to go without saying that a measure aimed at reducing traffic in the center of a city would hurt the business of a parking garage there. It would not even seem to be a matter of dispute, much less a court case.

title: Lost Weekends Define Woodss Drought in Major Tournaments
description: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C.  Tiger Woods buried his face in a white towel, then threw the towel at his bag with undisguised contempt. His tee shot at the par-5 seventh hole had landed in gnarly rough, and going for the green appeared out of the question.

title: Traffic Jams Aggravate Around the World
description: Milan has entered a legal battle over traffic control. But gridlock is a global problem. Here is a collection of curated videos showing snarls, backups and standstills around the world.

title: Giants Kid Gloves Come Off for Developing Cornerback
description: ALBANY  The second-year Giants cornerback Prince Amukamara sometimes wears dazzling white football gloves, shiny and sleek, as if his hands were dipped in ivory.

title: Museum Defends Antiquities Collecting
description: Over the last five years, the Cleveland Museum of Art has been at work on one of the largest building programs of any art institution in the country, a $350 million project that has been unveiled in sleek new stages and will be completed by 2013, adding 35,000 more square feet of gallery space.

title: At Queens Bakery, the Art of Translating a Planets Worth of Sweet Confections
description: The vanilla in the extract sold at Pattycakes, a cake-supply store in Queens, originates in Madagascar, but it is when the tiny bottles leave the shop that the spice truly becomes multinational.

title: On Jackson Heights Sidewalks, a Treats Messy Aftermath
description: On a stroll through the busy streets of Jackson Heights, Queens, Sahadev Poudel kept gesturing at the ground with disgust. He stopped on the sidewalks in front of sari boutiques and Indian grocery stores, pointing out stains that looked like dried blood.

title: As Ryan Looks to Focus on Economy, Spotlight Shines on His Other Views
description: WASHINGTON  Though best known as an architect of conservative fiscal policy, Representative Paul D. Ryan has also been an ardent, unwavering foe of abortion rights, has tried to cut off federal money for family planning, has opposed same-sex marriage and has championed the rights of gun owners.

title: Helping Couples Facing Illness
description: WISH UPON A WEDDING, a nonprofit organization that provides free weddings for couples in which one partner is terminally ill (or both), was started in 2010 by Liz Guthrie, a former wedding planner who is now the organizations executive director.

title: Kerley Back Practicing After Hamstring Injury
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  Two days after watching the Jets first preseason game on a television in the receivers meeting room at the teams training camp, the injured second-year wide receiver Jeremy Kerley returned to the field Sunday and took one small step forward.

title: Japanese Economy Signaling a Slowdown
description: TOKYO  Japans economic growth slowed to an annual rate of just 1.4 percent in the second quarter, the government said Monday, as cooling global demand weighed on the nations exports, while domestic demand, which had helped Japan outperform other Group of 7 industrialized countries this year, appeared to lose steam.

title: A Clause That Could Salvage the Winter Classic
description: The N.H.L. can cancel the Jan. 1 Winter Classic at 115,000-seat Michigan Stadium as late as Jan. 1, the day of the game, because of a work stoppage arising from the lack of a collective bargaining agreement, the contract between the league and the University of Michigan shows.

title: U.S. Mens Basketball Team Wins Gold
description: The United States defeated Spain, 107-100, for the Olympic gold medal in mens basketball.

description: Jon Niese is in his third full season with the Mets, and so far this year, it has been hard to say whether he has taken a full step forward in his progression or arrived at a bit of a plateau.

description: Adolescents in states with strict laws regulating the sale of snacks and sugary drinks in public schools gained less weight over a three-year period than those living in states with no such laws, a new study has found.

title: A Host of Ills When Irons Out of Balance
description: Iron, an essential nutrient, has long been the nations most common nutritional deficiency. In decades past, many parents worried that children who were picky eaters would develop iron-deficiency anemia. My mother boiled meat I refused to eat and fed me the concentrated broth in hopes Id get some of its iron.

description: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  Motorola Mobility, the ailing cellphone maker that Google bought in May, told employees Sunday that it would lay off 20 percent of its work force and close a third of its 94 offices worldwide.

title: Conservative Stars Small-Town Roots
description: JANESVILLE, Wis.  Representative Paul D. Ryans childhood home here was not overtly partisan. His parents were enthusiastic supporters of Representative Les Aspin, a Democrat, yet adored President Ronald Reagan from their glimpses of him on the evening news. But the death of his father when Mr. Ryan was only 16 punctured his life of math tests and bike riding, and in that fissure, the seeds of his worldview were planted.

title: Bangalore Couples Turn to Cops for Counseling
description: As the three stars with a red-and-blue ribbon on his shoulder strap will tell you, M.L. Purushotham is a police inspector. But heres his unofficial job description: redeemer of relationships and savior of marriages.

description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: A Conversation With: Social Scientist Anandi Mani
description: Anandi Mani, an associate professor at the University of Warwick in Britain, is one of the authors of a study on womens political representation and its effect on crime in India. As the government reserves for women a third of all seats in local government institutions like the village council, the researchers sought to find out whether having female political leaders at the local level would have a positive effect on women. Instead, they found that the reported number of crimes against women rose. Ms. Mani explained in an e-mail interview with India Ink why thats not bad news.

title: Ugandan Copters, en Route to Battle Shabab, Disappear Over Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  At least two Ugandan military helicopters, crucial assets in a push against militants in Somalia, have vanished over Kenya, officials in Nairobi said on Monday.

title: Cincinnati Bengals, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
description: Temper any optimism you might have for the Cincinnati Bengals with a healthy sprinkle of caution. Yes, this is a relatively young team coming off a surprising postseason appearance. But weve seen this before. In 2005 the Bengals made the postseason only to lose in the wild-card round and then finish 8-8, 7-9 and 4-11-1 the next three years. In 2009, they surprisingly broke through with another wild-card appearance, only to lose that game and 12 more the following season. The Bengals have not had back-to-back playoff seasons in 30 years. They have not won a playoff game in 22 years  the N.F.L.s longest current drought.

title: Defending a Sanctuary With Paint and Song
description: The cove yawns like a Cheshire cats ear-to-ear grin, inviting local inhabitants and tourists to stroll along a mile-long sandy beach. Considered by many to be the Caribbeans finest, Flamenco Beach lies on Culebra, a tiny speck of land off Puerto Ricos east coast that boasts a striking range of biodiversity. The human population of 1,800 is outnumbered by multitudes of migratory birds, sea turtles and marine life, including critically endangered leatherback and hawksbill sea turtles.

title: An Antarctic State of Mind
description: Alexander Kumar, a physician and researcher at Concordia Station, writes from Antarctica, where he conducts scientific experiments for the European Space Agencys human spaceflight program.

title: Premier of Australia Backs Plan on Refugees
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Prime Minister Julia Gillard of Australia endorsed a set of sweeping changes to immigration policy on Monday that would increase the number of refugees the country accepts by nearly half while reopening remote offshore detention centers that have been criticized by human rights groups as inhumane and ineffective.

title: Syrian Rebels Claim First Jet Downing, in Possible Shift for War
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian rebels said Monday that they had shot down a Syrian fighter jet for the first time, raising new questions about the oppositions military capabilities, and whether Syrias control of the skies might be threatened.

description: Ruth Padawer, who teaches at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, wrote this weeks cover article on boys who like to dress up as girls. Her last article for the magazine was on reducing a pregnancy with twins to a single fetus.

description: SEOUL, South Korea  An influential official from North Korea left for China on Monday to discuss building joint industrial complexes on their borders, the Norths state-run Korean Central News Agency reported.

title: As Bird Talk Flies Off, a Question: What Magazine Do You Miss Most?
description: Monday brought news of the end of Bird Talk magazine. Adding to the indignity, subscribers were being sent copies of Dog Fancy in its place, Christine Haughney reports. (Sending copies of Cat Fancy with a smiling feline on the cover would be the cruelest cut of all, we suppose.)

title: Elusive FinSpy Spyware Pops Up in 10 Countries
description: It is one of the more elusive commercial cyberespionage tools available. It is marketed as a way for governments to spy on criminals. And for over a year, virus hunters unsuccessfully tried to track it down. Now it is popping up across the globe, from Qatar to an Amazon server in the United States.

title: The Stalin in Putin
description: Thirteen members of the Jewish Anti-Fascist Committee were killed in Moscow 60 years ago this past Sunday. This tragedy is sometimes referred to as Stalins last execution. Surely other people were put to death before the tyrant died in March 1953, but it was the last of the show trials to have been completed. The date has also often been referred to in the West as The Night of the Murdered Poets, based on the erroneous assumption that all of those killed wrote verse. In fact, the men were intellectuals from different fields.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Lobbying Romney to Pick Ryan, and Seeking an Olympic Afterglow
description: Mitt Romneys selection of Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin over the weekend to be his running mate is being credited with shoring up Mr. Romneys conservative bona fides  something his campaign would have known because conservative publications had been telling him through editorials that he should pick Mr. Ryan to shore up his conservative bona fides. The Weekly Standard and The Wall Street Journal both wrote editorials promoting Mr. Ryan for the Republican ticket: The Journals editorial on Thursday (Why Not Paul Ryan?) and The Weekly Standards editorial dated Monday but online earlier (Go for the Gold, Mitt!). Perhaps this is the reason, Michael Barbaro writes, that Mr. Romneys camp was eager to announce the day he made the decision, Aug. 1: Mr. Romney is sensitive to the perception that he acts at the behest of the partys right wing. Now, he is making the case that he had settled on Mr. Ryan well before a chorus of conservatives told him to.

title: Indias Olympic Program Under Spotlight Again
description: Six medals. That is all that India  the worlds second most populous country  managed to win at the London Olympics. While six is a record, it is still a pitiful showing for a country with ambitions to become a great power.

title: Being Sikh in America
description: DELHI  From 1988 to 1993 I was a graduate student at New York University. Like many nonobservant Sikhs, I did not wear a turban, but I did keep a beard. When I would travel to small-town America, my appearance sometimes gave rise to a barely concealed hostility, occasionally even a comment or two.

title: Olympic Politics: What Does It Mean for Boris?
description: Big sport can sometimes get tangled up with big politics, and the just-ended Olympic Games in London  the subject of my latest column  was no exception.

title: Stately Homes of a Five-and-Dime Store Founder
description: Crescent Beach Road in Glen Cove, on Long Island, is a pleasant suburban stretch, all pitched roofs and tidy green lawns. On a leisurely drive, it might look like a million other serene spots around the country, until suddenly, something very different emerged from around the bend: a towering marble archway about 15 feet high, which appears at the side of the road like a gateway to another era, fallen from the sky.

title: Lars von Trier Seeks Film Submissions for User-Generated Project

title: Gender Split for Debate Moderators
description: The moderating duties for the four presidential and vice-presidential debates this year will be evenly split between male and female journalists for the first time, the Commission on Presidential Debates said Monday, nearly two months before debate season begins.

title: Glow With the Flow
description: First there was the raw food movement. Then came macrobiotics, followed by the all-mighty juice cleanse. The latest detox craze isnt something you can ingest, but it has plenty of people drinking the proverbial Kool-Aid. A cardiovascular procedure called External Counter Pulsation therapy, cleared by the F.D.A. in 1987 for the treatment of angina, claims to stimulate and clear collaterals (small blood vessels) to bypass narrow or clogged arteries. During the procedure, a patients legs are strapped to an adjustable bed using pressurized cuffs hooked up to a heart monitor. The cuffs inflate and deflate in sync with the heartbeat, pumping blood upward, so it can oxygenate more rapidly and distribute with greater ease. Now rebranded as Pure Flow Pulsation at New Yorks PureFlow, E.C.P. is being offered, under the guidance of the cardiologist Dr. Samir Shah, as a multipurpose remedy for everything from fatigue to weight gain. (Andrew Barile, PureFlows co-founder, says that a 45-minute session is the aerobic equivalent of a seven-and-a-half-mile walk.) Some New Yorkers are swearing by it. At first I wasnt convinced, but by the third session I noticed that, for the first time in 20 years, I was able to enjoy a full nights sleep without interruption, says Celeste Fierro, a restaurant and nightclub consultant. Her tolerance for alcohol is lower, too. I used to be able to drink a bottle of wine at dinner, and now I can only take a glass. And for the Tom Ford stylist Sabrina Baldieri, the results are outwardly apparent, too. I have more control over my weight, she says. It also gives me immediate relief from jet lag and an overall glow.

title: Positive Test Costs Shot-Putter Gold Medal
description: LONDON  The first doping violation by a prominent athlete at the London Games was announced hours after the closing ceremony. Nadzeya Ostapchuk of Belarus was stripped of her gold medal in the shot-put Monday morning for testing positive for an anabolic steroid, the International Olympic Committee said.

title: Climate Insight From a Magical Mountain Range
description: As many people know, human civilization arose during a particularly stable period in the history of the earth  the Holocene, encompassing the 12,000 years since the end of the last ice age. It may have been no accident that civilization burst forth during an era when ice had retreated from some of the most favorable land and when climate, sea level and other conditions had settled down after the turbulence of the ice age.

description: A judge at the Vatican on Monday ordered the former butler of Pope Benedict XVI to stand trial on charges of taking and then leaking documents from the popes private apartment that raised allegations of corruption at the Vatican.

title: An Easy and Instant Chemistry on the Trail
description: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla.  It was Day 2 of the most closely watched bromance in American politics, and Mitt Romney was already missing his new running mate.

title: VH1 Cancels Chad Johnson Reality Show
description: The Miami Dolphins receiver Chad Johnsons arrest on a domestic violence charge has caused the cable channel VH1 to shelve his reality show, Ev & Ocho.

title: Marsupial Maintenance
description: Q. How does a female kangaroo rid itself of the dirt that its joey brings into its pouch as it jumps in and out?

title: Romney/Ryan: The Real Target
description: So, let me clarify what I believe is really going on in the choice of Paul Ryan as VP nominee. It is not about satisfying the conservative base, which was motivated anyway by Obama-hatred; it is not about refocusing on the issues, because R&R are both determined to avoid providing any of the crucial specifics about their plans. It is  as Jonathan Chait also seems to understand  about exploiting the gullibility and vanity of the news media, in much the same way that George W. Bush did in 2000.

title: Monday Motorsports: Marcos Ambrose Surges Late to Win Sprint Cup Race at Watkins Glen
description: In what some race analysts called the most thrilling race finish of the 2012 Nascar Sprint Cup season, Marcos Ambrose secured a victory at Watkins Glen on Sunday, seizing the lead on the final lap and aggressively defending his position against Brad Keselowski for his second consecutive win at the road course.

title: Business Day Live: Olympics Clean-Up

title: Monday Walkabout  8/13: Heathrow Crowds and T.S.A. Plaudits and Complaints
description: One Last Olympic Record After last nights closing ceremony of the London 2012 Games, Heathrow Airport expects that todays passenger volume will break the record of 236,955 passengers set on July 24. To accommodate the influx of travelers, Heathrow has built a temporary Games Terminal to assist the 10,100 athletes and Games officials and their 37,900 bags. (BBC)

title: Could Ryan Tip Wisconsin Toward Romney?
description: Today we continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Todays stop: Wisconsin, the Badger State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Charles Franklin, the director of the Marquette University Law School Poll and a professor in the political science department at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

title: What Paul Ryan Doesnt Offer
description: Anyone whos picked up a newspaper or turned on a TV news program in the last 48 hours knows by now that Paul Ryan, Mitt Romneys running mate, is best known as the very conservative author of a very conservative budget plan, which would cut $6 trillion from federal spending over the next 10 years. Anyone whos ventured below the fold probably also knows that hes a social conservative: He opposes same-sex marriage and has said that hes as pro-life as a person gets, which seems accurate since hes the co-sponsor of a bill that would grant fetuses all the legal and constitutional attributes and privileges of personhood.

title: The Sound of New Yorks Skaters
description: None of us can skateboard. We just dont have the coordination, I guess, says Michael Ian Cummings, the lead singer for a band called, of all things, Skaters. The name just reminds me of my youth and the way I felt listening to music and hanging out with my friends running around the city being a hooligan. The self-invented, devil-may-care attitude thats characterized both skate culture and the irreverent sound of so many New York bands (the Ramones and Suicide come to mind) has had a big influence on Skaters, who released their debut EP, Schemers, for free on the Web earlier this year. A rose-colored, wistful affection for the city is shared by the groups three members  Cummings, Noah Rubin (drums) and Joshua Hubbard (guitar)  and can be heard loud and clear in songs like Good Weird Woman, with its subway-station-sounding saxophone, and Are We Just Doomed? a bittersweet account of leaving home and hardly sleeping, something any New York band worth its salt knows intimately. I couldnt imagine making or listening to this music in any other environment, Cummings says. And even without the skateboards or skills, Skaters do look the part. Dressed in the British mens-wear label Folk, as they were for their T photo shoot, theres no covering up their romantically ragged edges.

title: CNN to Promote Nonfiction TV, not Reality TV, Network Says
description: CNN says it is not getting into the reality television business, though it is considering adding weekend programs that are similar to a documentary-style travel show hosted by Anthony Bourdain that it will begin showing next year.

title: CT Scans More Likely for White Children
description: White children are more likely than black or Hispanic children to be given CT scans when arriving at hospital emergency rooms with minor head trauma, a study has found.

title: Car Safety Lacking for Children
description: Many people do not appropriately use safety restraints for children in cars, a new study shows.

title: A Mexican Beer Rides a Social Media Wave
description: Pacifico, a Pilsner-style Mexican beer popular among California surfers, is running its first major national advertising campaign as it broadens its distribution across the United States.

title: More Americans Are Going for a Walk
description: The proportion of adults who said they went on a 10-minute walk at least once a week increased to 62 percent in 2010, from 56 percent in 2005, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has reported.

title: The Heartache of the Migrant Nanny
description: Domestic workers: the nannies, cooks and cleaners that make many families lives so much better, are at a high risk of being abused and exploited. Because the work they do takes place in private homes, they are invisible and often cant get government protection.On Aug. 6, the International Labor Organizations Convention on Domestic Work was ratified  setting international standards to protect the worlds 50 million to 100 million domestic workers.

title: Trout Turns Swiping Home Runs Into an Art Form
description: A lot of praise is being heaped on the Angels rookie Mike Trout, to the point where he is in serious conversation for being the American Leagues most valuable player.

description: A new Washington Post/ABC News poll finds Americans are divided over Mitt Romneys selection of Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin as his vice-presidential running mate, but that favorable opinion of Mr. Ryan rose after the announcement was made.

title: Pfizer Animal Health Unit Files for I.P.O.
description: Pfizers animal health unit on Monday filed to sell a 20 percent stake to the public in an initial public offering.

description: From sticks of butter to bacon-wrapped corn dogs, the state fair offers a vast array of unusual, batter-dipped foods.

description: An off-duty city police detective assaulted a police officer who was trying to arrest him on drunken-driving charges in Upper Manhattan early Monday, the police said.

title: Superfund Cleanup Stirs Troubled Waters
description: LYNDHURST, N.J.  This is not what a Superfund site is supposed to look like. There are no rusting barrels, no antifreeze-green slime oozing up from the ground. Theres just a deep bend in the serpentine Passaic River, a gaggle of pushy Canada geese and a lone rower in a single scull making good time on the calm, dark waters.

description: Some new residents come into the nursing home like lions, roaring at staff members and fighting admission at every turn. Others come in like lambs, including an 84-year-old woman who arrived quietly after a complicated hip fracture ended her ability to live alone.

title: German Small Businesses Reflect Country's Strength
description: FRANKFURT  A growing number of Germans may want to see the euro zone dissolve, but Dagmar Bollin-Flade, owner of a small machinery company here, is not among them. Like many German businesspeople, she is keenly aware of the economic benefits of a common currency  and willing to pay a price to keep the euro intact.

Life of Pi to Open New York Film Festival
description: Moviegoers got a peek at Ang Lees next film, Life of Pi, earlier this summer when Fox took the unusual step of showing a full uncut scene before screenings of Prometheus and other films. But New York Film Festival audiences will be the first to see the directors full 3-D adaptation of the best-selling novel when the film opens the 50th edition of the event on Sept. 28, the Film Society of Lincoln Center announced on Monday. It will be the second Lee film to kick off the festival (after The Ice Storm in 1997).

description: CHICAGO  Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr., who has been on medical leave since early June, is being treated for Bipolar II depression at the Mayo Clinic in Minnesota, according to a statement released by the clinic Monday providing the most recent update on the congressmans medical condition.

title: Links for the Dog Days
description: Guess what? When you make rules limiting the amount of junk kids can eat, their weight problems lessen. Do you think this might work for grownups too? Duh. On the other hand, when you feed hamsters food containing GMOs, they become infertile and suffer stunted growth. Yes, I know youre not a hamster, but youve got a lot of the same genes. Why risk it?

description: PrePex, a bloodless circumcision device for adults, will be tested in at least nine African countries in the next year, according to the backers of the tests.

title: How Spoiled Are Our Children? No Simple Answer
description: A mother asked me last week whether I thought she was spoiling her child. It was the typical pediatric exam-room version of the question: In the weary, self-doubting voice of the recently postpartum, she wondered if it was right to pick up and feed her crying baby.

description: Summer, with its often-violent storms, does not always mix well with business travel. But the wildfires in the West and high-security events like the London Olympics and two political conventions are making this summer particularly challenging.

title: City Breaks Ground on New Beacon High School Building
Deck Chairs That Crossed the Atlantic
description: In 2009, Tamra Gallant, a Vancouver-based entrepreneur with a background in woodworking, visited Great Britain and saw deck chairs in parks and on beaches that she wished could be readily found in North America. She founded Gallant & Jones with Gwyneth Jones, a textile designer, and began producing similar chairs in white oak and organic cotton fabrics. We made them ourselves at first because were perfectionists, Ms. Jones said. Naturally protected from water damage and rot, the oak frame has a coating of ultraviolet-resistant oil for further safekeeping. The sling and pillow fabrics are easily removable for cleaning and storage. Available through Lin Morris starting at $280, lin-morris.com.

title: A Tutoring Company in Search of a Tag Line
description: For the last couple of months, Alexandra Mayzler, a member of the She Owns It business group, has struggled to come up with a new tag line for her company, Thinking Caps Tutoring. Thinking Caps, which she started in her college dorm room, has outgrown its current tag, Students teaching students. Settling on something new that both sounds good and differentiates the company has been so difficult that she wonders how she ever came up with the first one.

title: Look of The Moment | Beyonc Knowles
description: The Look: White Flag. A serious-business dress comes with a number of curves  peplum, bell sleeve, exaggerated shoulders  making a standout statement, with just a hint of dcolletage.

Three (and later four) large rooms were lined with clear plastic incubators, and inside each, a baby. Many of them were extremely premature.

She puts flowers in her hair, bangles around her arms, bells around her ankles. After she rises, ready, the obscuring fabric is removed, and she stands, her arms out like eagle wings, her eyes and neck running back and forth, drawing you in.

More than a century ago, he went on a world tour with our blended Scotch whisky, visiting 26 countries. It took him two years. He actually wrote a journal called A Ramble Round the Globe.

title: Helen Gurley Brown, Who Gave Single Girl a Life in Full, Dies at 90

She was 90, though parts of her were considerably younger.

description: A conspiracy theorist might think that NASAs newest Mars rover, the Curiosity, is actually just in the middle of a desert on Earth.

title: Dad! Thats Not How Mom Does It!
description: A few years ago reality television was approaching its social-experiment phase, with new series that appeared to have been cooked up in university psychology seminars. In 2006, there was Black. White., in which two families  one white, one black  switched races for several weeks with the aid of makeup and some credulous supporting cast members. The next year came Kid Nation, which unleashed a group of rugrats onto a spit of land in New Mexico and watched them attempt to build a new society, all while flirting with the fine print of child labor laws.

title: Not the Death, but the Details
description: When John Banville inaugurated his pseudonymous series of Benjamin Black books in 2007 with Christine Falls, this esteemed author seemed to have taken an iffy turn. The Banville name would be reserved for literary fiction (like The Sea, winner of the Man Booker Prize); Benjamin Black would swim in the supposedly shallower waters of the whodunit. The Black books were said to be much more casually and quickly written than the serious ones. Mr. Banville would have no trouble keeping his august reputation and his day job.

title: Powerful Bank Regulator to Retire
description: A senior Wall Street regulator will step down next month as her agency undergoes a makeover, ending a nearly two-decade career as one of the banking industrys most powerful and yet polarizing watchdogs.

title: Like Wearing Heavy Wool to Ward Off Wintry Blasts
description: Bart Millard is a tender singer with a big mouth. The frontman of MercyMe, one of the steadiest and most successful bands in the hermetic world of Christian rock, hes genial but not distant, caressing in the loudest way possible.

title: Celebrating a Once-Mighty Tree, Pruned but Hardly Forgotten
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  Memorializing the French composer Camille Saint-Sans nine days after his death, in an article published on Christmas Day in 1921, the New York Times music critic Richard Aldrich wrote of Saint-Sanss stature and accomplishments in the most glowing terms.

title: Against Mexico, Is the U.S. in It to Win It?
description: On June 8, after the United States defeated Antigua and Barbuda, 3-1, in a World Cup qualifier in Tampa, Fla., Coach Jurgen Klinsmann fielded a question about the difference between friendly matches and World Cup qualifiers. To hear him tell it, little, if anything, should distinguish the two.

title: Bring It On Starts Modestly at Sis-Boom-Box Office
description: The only new Broadway musical of the summer, Bring It On, grossed $472,810 in its first full week after opening on Aug. 1, a modest showing at the box office that was still promising enough for the producers to announce a three-month extension of performances. Bring It On, inspired by the 2000 movie about a high school cheerleading rivalry, took in only 39 percent of its maximum possible gross last week  in part because many choice seats were not on sale at three performances. Those tickets instead went complimentary to late-coming critics and other members of the media.

title: NBC Says Nearly 220 Million Watched the Olympics
description: NBC announced on Monday that its coverage of the London Olympics was the most watched entertainment or sporting event ever on American television.

title: Finding Their Way to Concert Halls: Blackbirds, Sea Gulls and Chickens
description: The most famous bird in Mozart lore is the starling he bought with some silver coins in 1784 and buried, with much part-serious solemnity, three years later. He transcribed its song in his notebook along with the price he paid for it  34 kreutzer  and the melody, which he may well have taught it, closely resembles the carefree opening theme of his Piano Concerto No. 17.

title: Romney, Mormonism and Money
description: My Sunday column written before the Paul Ryan pick, but still relevant in its aftermath argues that Mitt Romneys understandable reluctance to talk about his Mormon faith has cut him off from what would otherwise be a very natural part of his campaign narrative, both in personal and philosophical terms. title: Iver Peterson, New York Times Reporter, Dies at 70
description: Iver Peterson, a reporter for The New York Times who covered the Vietnam War from the front lines and wrote about politics, education and other topics in the United States for more than 30 years, died on Aug. 1 in Philadelphia. He was 70.

description: CANCN, Mexico  Most people head off to an art exhibit with comfortable shoes and a deep appreciation for creativity. Jason deCaires Taylors work requires flippers and, to really appreciate it, a depth of at least 12 feet.

description: Johnny Pesky, the star Red Sox shortstop of the 1940s and early 50s who spent seven decades at Fenway Park as a player, manager, coach, broadcaster and instructor, becoming one of Bostons most beloved figures, died Monday in Danvers, Mass. He was 92.

title: Grisly Scene After Syrian Rebel Victory Caught on Video

title: Giants Faced With Whether to Remain in Albany
description: ALBANY  Jerry Jennings, the mayor of Albany, expressed his desire to have the Giants keep their training camp in his city. The Giants have yet to renew their contract with the University of Albany.

title: In Ohio, Serena Williams Plays on the Kind of Courts She Loves
description: MASON, Ohio  Its hard to think that someone who has won five singles titles and five in doubles at Wimbledon, not to mention the two Olympic gold medals she earned at the All England Club a week ago, could feel out of her element on grass, but that is what Serena Williams says of herself.

title: Brushing Their Teeth Until Scooby-Doo Says Times Up
description: THE Advertising Council wants to encourage children to brush their teeth  by giving them something to watch while they do it.

title: Turkmenistan: Convicts Pardoned
description: President Gurbanguly Berdymukhammedov has ordered the release of 1,327 convicts to observe the end of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan. It is the latest in a series of mass pardons set to coincide with national holidays in the isolated former Soviet republic. Turkmen state media reported on Monday that 44 foreigners would be among those pardoned.

title: Slowly, Dickey Approaches Rare Feat
description: With 47 games to go in a Mets season that has come undone, R. A. Dickey has probably become the primary reason to keep following the team. With a 15-3 record, he has a decent chance to win 20 games, and he is a legitimate candidate for the National League Cy Young award.

title: Youth Driving Laws Limit Even the Double Date
description: CLIFTON, N.J.  It is a rite of American teendom, celebrated in popular culture by American Graffiti and Fast Times at Ridgemont High: a teenager with a drivers license piling as many friends as will fit into the car for a ride.

title: Municipal Bond Rule Mired in Legislative Limbo
description: Financial reform was supposed to help protect local taxpayers from getting burned by municipal bond deals. But a measure that would require municipal bond advisers to put the interests of taxpayers first has been bogged down in a rule-making quagmire in Washington for nearly two years.

title: Joe Kubert Dies at 85; Influential Comic-Book Artist

description: For several years, the Wall Street wizards who built a faster, more fragmented stock market justified their creation by pointing to the benefits it yielded for investors in the form of lower trading costs.

title: Medicare Rises as Prime Election Issue
description: TAMPA, Fla.  With Mitt Romneys selection of Representative Paul D. Ryan as his running mate, Florida quickly emerged on Monday as a critical test of the nationwide Republican gamble that concerns over the mounting federal debt can blunt potent Democratic attacks on conservative proposals to revamp Medicare.

title: Egypt Lifts a Junior Corps Impatient Over Military Failure
