description: To the Editor:

title: Remedying the Effects of Agent Orange
description: To the Editor:

title: Major Investor in the Apthorp Cedes Its Day-to-Day Control
description: The Apthorp apartment building has long been one of New York Citys most famous structures, a heavy limestone behemoth built by the Astors in 1908, once home to Nora Ephron and Al Pacino. In recent years, however, it has developed a decidedly less glamorous reputation as one of the citys most troubled condominium conversions.

title: Overt Discrimination in Ohio
description: Update: On Wednesday afternoon, Jon Husted, the Ohio Secretary of State, announced that all Ohio counties would follow a uniform early-voting policy. The policy would extend early-voting hours to 7 p.m. on weekdays during the last two weeks before the election, though all early voting is banned during the final three days of the campaign.

title: Aug. 14: The Fog of Polling  and Ryans Bounce So Far
description: As I noted on Saturday, past vice-presidential announcements have typically been greeted with a small bounce in the polls. Harry J. Enten, at The Guardian, has run the numbers on this for vice-presidential announcements dating back to 1984. He finds a net gain of four percentage points in the polls  and a mean of six  for the party that just named its new running mate.

title: Police Sought Cellphones for Video of Times Square Shooting
description: Dozens of bystanders grabbed their cellphones and hit the record button as a knife-wielding man skipped backward through Times Square on Saturday. Some witnesses, holding their cellphones above their heads to capture the action, ran alongside police officers as they pursued the man down Seventh Avenue with guns drawn.

title: Rainbow Room, Shut by a Feud, Has a Fading Wish
description: It was probably the most cinematically perfect space in New York. It had that stylishly streamlined modern look  elegant crystal chandeliers here, a revolving dance floor there, long velvety draperies beyond. And it had those magical views that made the Empire State Building and the Chrysler Building seem small enough to reach out and touch.

title: Tall Tale: Origin of the Pesky Pole Feeds Red Sox Lore
description: The truth is, no one really knows exactly how  or why  the right-field foul pole in Fenway Park came to be known as the Pesky Pole. The truth, too, is that no one was really giving the subject that much thought until Johnny Pesky died on Monday at age 92 after seven decades with the Boston Red Sox as a player, manager, coach, broadcaster and beloved baseball ambassador.

title: New Jersey Fines Halfway Houses $45,000 Over Escapes
description: The Christie administration said on Tuesday that it had issued $45,000 in fines against New Jersey halfway houses from which nine inmates escaped in recent months, the harshest penalties ever brought against the troubled network of private operators.

title: Lottery Numbers
House Chairman Survives Florida Primary
description: Representative John L. Mica of Florida fought off Representative Sandy Adams on Tuesday in a closely watched Republican primary election that pitted two incumbents against each other in an important swing state.

title: Heartfelt Singing and Screeching, Amplified
description: Two hours into karaoke night, there was still no karaoke to be heard at Joes Place in the Bronx.

title: Ecuador: President Denies Decision to Grant WikiLeaks Founder Asylum
description: The president of Ecuador, Rafael Correa, denied on Tuesday a report on the Web site of The Guardian that he had decided to grant asylum to the WikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange, who is holed up in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London. There is still no decision, Mr. Correa said in a post on Twitter. Mr. Assange took refuge in the embassy in June, seeking to avoid extradition to Sweden, where he is wanted for questioning on allegations of sexual molestation and rape by two women.

title: Battle Lines on Care
description: Candidates and outside groups have started to inject the Medicare issue into advertising for House and Senate races.

title: Obama-Ryan Battle Intensifies Over Medicare Savings
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Paul D. Ryans budget blueprint assumes the same amount of Medicare savings as President Obamas health care law, even though Mitt Romney and Mr. Ryan have said those cuts would be devastating to millions of older Americans on Medicare.

title: L.I.R.R. Worker Pleads Guilty in Pension Fraud Scheme
description: A former worker for the Long Island Rail Road pleaded guilty on Tuesday to conspiracy and perjury charges, admitting that he had schemed to steal from a federal pension agency by pretending to be disabled and then lied to a grand jury.

title: Focus Turns to N.F.L.s Replacement Officials
description: Separated by a few plane flights and a tense negotiating chasm, the N.F.L. and its locked-out officials watched the first full slate of preseason games over the weekend. Their assessments of the debut of replacement officials were as contrasting as black and white stripes.

title: Mothers Precautions Finally Fail, 2 Blocks From Home
description: Paula Shaw-Leary had every reason to believe that the seven children she raised in Harlem were finally clear of the street violence that had worried her for years.

title: Urban League Football Classic to Be Played at Yankee Stadium
description: In 1973, George Steinbrenner made a business decision  he bought the Yankees  and a charitable decision. He chose to underwrite the struggling New York Urban League Football Classic.

title: Grandmas Grow Gold in Swaziland
description: PIGGS PEAK, Swaziland  After her daughters died, Khathazile took in her 11 orphaned grandchildren without hesitation. It is what a gogo, or grandmother, does in a country where the worlds highest H.I.V. infection rate has left a sea of motherless children.

title: Giants Defensive Tackle Out for Season With a Clot
description: ALBANY  The Giants almost escaped training camp without a major injury. That changed Tuesday, the last day of camp here, when the team discovered defensive tackle Shaun Rogers had a blood clot in his calf that would keep him out for the season.

title: Fewer Government Resources
description: The United States collects the same amount of taxes as it did 45 years ago, leaving less money for services.

title: Unions First Proposal Offers Concessions
description: The N.H.L. Players Association made a surprising initial proposal to league owners Tuesday in negotiations toward a new collective bargaining agreement, offering significant salary concessions combined with a reformed revenue-sharing plan.

title: Where Small Talk Has Epic Meanings
description: For Mrs. Robert Henry, good conversation is sacred, something to put your faith in, along with God and country. A fanatically gracious small-town matron, Mrs. Henry (Dolores to her friends) proselytizes tirelessly for this religion in the opening entry of Harrison, TX, an evening of three short, piquant plays by Horton Foote at 59E59 Theaters. And shame on those who dare dismiss her as just a flibbertigibbet.

title: Squaring the Circle
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE

title: Corrections: August 15, 2012
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Executive From CBS Will Lead Big East Conference
description: Imagine Mike Arescos enthusiasm Tuesday when he was named the commissioner of the Big East, a conference that is essentially a television free agent in a landscape of expanding media, in which networks have trampled over one another bidding for college sports.

title: William N. Wallace, Former Times Reporter, Dies at 88
description: William N. Wallace, a former sports reporter for The New York Times and one of the first to cover professional football beyond following the local team, died on Saturday in Norwalk, Conn. He was 88.

title: When Cruelty Is Cute
description: WASHINGTON

title: Japan: Cabinet Member Visits Tokyo War Shrine
description: A Japanese cabinet member visited a Tokyo war shrine on Wednesday for the first time in three years, a move that could add to already heated exchanges with neighboring South Korea over history. The visit by Jin Matsubara, the National Public Safety Commission chairman, was the first by a cabinet member to the Yasukuni Shrine since the Democratic Party came to power in 2009 with vows to build closer ties with Asia. Mr. Matsubara, an outspoken conservative, told Kyodo News that he visited the shrine to Japans war dead as a private citizen, ignoring a request from Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda not to go. The visit comes as Tokyo and Seoul have clashed over compensation for World War II-era sex slaves and over disputed islands.

title: An Ex-Wrestling Executive Wins a G.O.P. Primary
description: Linda E. McMahon, a former wrestling executive, easily captured Connecticuts Republican Senate primary on Tuesday night, clinching a second chance to run for a position she failed to win two years ago.

title: After Battling Delays, Pettitte Hopes to Return Quickly, but Not Too Quickly
description: An X-ray on Andy Pettittes broken left ankle Monday showed it had improved, but not enough to allow Pettitte to begin pitching from a mound.

title: Enlisting From Afar for the Love of Israel
description: LOD, Israel  Three days into Josh Warhits first-ever visit to Israel, as a 16-year-old on a summer tour, war broke out in Lebanon, which transformed the groups itinerary  and his life plan. On Tuesday, with talk rampant about the possibility of an imminent Israeli attack on Iran, Mr. Warhit became a citizen of Israel to enlist in its army.

title: Why Moderates Should Like Paul Ryan
description: Paul Ryan is not a moderate, not a centrist, and certainly not a perfectly neutral non-ideological number-crunching budget wonk. He is a conservative whose fiscal blueprints and budgets are drawn up with conservative goals uppermost in mind. Hes a Reaganite pro-life hawkish supply-sider who wants limited government and the lowest possible tax burden. Out of all the running mates available, Mitt Romney chose one of the most explicitly ideological options.

title: Kuroda Dominates as Yankees Defeat Rangers Again
description: The Yankees catchers have about 10 key words they use to communicate with the Japanese pitcher Hiroki Kuroda when he is on the mound. They are basic phrases of pitching  relax, keep the ball down, attack the strike zone.

title: Two-Way Jabs on Medicare Recast Races for Congress
description: WASHINGTON  In one tight Florida House race, a hastily assembled TV commercial to begin airing Wednesday takes aim at a top target of Democrats, highlighting his votes to end Medicare as we know it.

title: Penn State Warned by Accreditation Panel
description: Pennsylvania State University has been warned that its accreditation is in jeopardy unless it corrects conditions that contributed to sexual abuse of children by a former assistant football coach, Jerry Sandusky.

title: Scoreless Duel, and Then Its Over for the Mets
description: CINCINNATI  Again and again, four times in all, Cincinnati Reds hitters belted baseballs that arced toward the outfield seats, only to watch them thump off the padded walls.

title: Parking Rules
description: On Wednesday, because of the Feast of the Assumption, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Romney Delivers a Harsh Rebuke of Obama at Final Stop on Bus Tour
description: 11:14 a.m. | Updated In a CBS interview on Wednesday, Mitt Romney continued his harsh rebuke of the Obama administration, charging that President Obama is running a campaign of enmity and jealousy and anger and this is not in my view what the American people want to see.

title: Ryan Meets Casino Mogul and Major G.O.P. Donor
description: LAS VEGAS  Four days after his announcement as Mitt Romneys running mate, Representative Paul D. Ryan was not in Florida talking Medicare with elderly voters or in drought-ridden Iowa talking about a farm bill. He traveled to the Venetian hotel here for a meeting hosted by Sheldon Adelson, the billionaire casino mogul who has pledged to spend as much as $100 million this year to defeat President Obama.

title: The Making of the Indian National Flag
Strategies for Hot-Weather Exercise
description: Is it possible to stay cool while exercising in the heat?

title: Word of the Day | pessimism
description: pessimism \pe-s-mi-zm also pe-z-\ noun

title: Al Freeman Jr., Actor Prominent in Civil Rights Era, Dies at 78
description: Al Freeman Jr., a star among a generation of black actors that emerged during the civil rights era, who made his mark in both drama and race relations with his portraits of some of the movements most forbidding personalities  angry young men in the 1960s plays of James Baldwin and LeRoi Jones, Malcolm X in a television drama, and the black separatist Elijah Muhammad in Spike Lees 1992 movie Malcolm X  died on Aug. 9 in Washington. He was 78.

title: Pinterest Rolls Out Android and iPad Apps
description: Pinterest, the social networking service where people pin content from around the Web on a virtual board, said on Tuesday that it was releasing versions of its mobile app for Android devices and the iPad.

title: Gunman in Texas Wrote of Inspirational Snipers and of Buying a Gun
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex.  On his Facebook page, Thomas Caffall posted a list of inspirational people. One was Carlos Hathcock, one of the most famous snipers in the United States Marine Corps who recorded 93 confirmed kills during the Vietnam War. Another was Vasily Zaytsev, a Russian sniper during World War II who was known for his skills with the Mosin-Nagant rifle.

title: Thompson Wins G.O.P. Senate Race in Wisconsin
description: WAUKESHA, Wis.  In the final week of his primary campaign, Tommy G. Thompson, the 70-year-old former governor of Wisconsin, performed 50 push-ups for a local newspaper editorial board to prove he was spry enough for the Senate post he is seeking. He has barnstormed the state for months, visiting with voters and raking in high-profile endorsements for a candidacy that, once presumed dominant, had increasingly felt the encroachment of younger challengers for the Republican nomination.

title: Heading for the Exits in China
description: HONG KONG  Charlie Custer, a filmmaker and blogger, is back in the United States. Left China. Couldnt take it any more. Bad air. Unsafe food. And there was a nasty-scary spat with a government journalist.

title: News Quiz | August 15, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Syrian Conflict Crosses Border Into Lebanon in Abductions
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Spillover from the Syrian conflict hit Lebanon in a frightening new way on Wednesday with the abduction of more than 30 Syrians inside Lebanese territory, which their captors called revenge for the kidnapping of a relative inside Syria.

title: Reversal on Immigration Policy in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The lower house of Australias Parliament passed sweeping changes in immigration policy on Wednesday that are meant to deter asylum seekers who try to reach the country by the thousands each year on rickety, overcrowded ships and boats.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Aug. 15, 2012
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article A Financial Plan for the Truly Fed Up.

title: Finding Mars in Familiar Places
description: The rover Curiosity survived its famed seven minutes of terror and has touched down on the surface of Mars, and the world cheered.

title: The Mind of a Flip-Flopper
description: Forget for a minute everything you know about politics. Barack Obama now openly supports gay marriage. Mitt Romney now opposes roughly the same kind of health care reform he fought for as governor of Massachusetts. What if they werent two politicians calculating how to win an election but instead just two guys who changed their minds? They didnt flip-flop; they experienced, as social scientists say, an attitude change, the way any of us do when we become a vegetarian or befriend a neighbor we used to hate or even just choose to buy a new brand of toothpaste.

title: The Birthplace of Obama the Politician
description: Scenes from Roseland, the Chicago neighborhood that a young Barack Obama hoped to one day fix.

title: What Does Obama Really Believe In?
description: From the back seat of Steve Gatess white Pontiac, Monique Robbins spotted Jasmine Coleman walking home from school alone. It was an icy December afternoon on Chicagos South Side, and Jasmines only protection against the wind was a thin purple jacket. She looked cold. Gates pulled the car over to the curb, and Robbins hollered at Jasmine to get in.

title: Restrictions on a Rite of American Teendom
description: In WHAT ways have state legislatures across the country restricted teenage driving in recent years?WHAT are the results of the studies that safety campaigners point to in order to justify these strict laws?

title: Japan Holds 14 Chinese in Island Landing
description: TOKYO  The Japanese authorities arrested 14 Chinese citizens from a Hong Kong-based vessel on Wednesday after some of them staged a protest by landing on a Japanese-controlled island that is also claimed by China. The incident added to a recent flare-up in tensions between Japan and its Asian neighbors over history and territory.

title: Pittsburgh Steelers, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
description: This past off-season gave us a smorgasbord of examples of why the Pittsburgh Steelers are one of the finest organizations in professional sports. There was Mike Tomlin getting his contract extended through 2016, continuing the organizations unparalleled tradition of head coaching stability under the Rooney family. There was Kevin Colbert, the most underrated if not outright best general manager in pro football, playing hardball with the restricted free agent Mike Wallace, a burgeoning star receiver but not someone the organization is going to overpay to keep. There was the other burgeoning receiver, Antonio Brown, being signed to a new six-year contract before his value escalated further. There was a renowned receiver, Hall of Fame candidate Hines Ward, being ushered into the sunset with a heros farewell.

title: Trickle-Down Fairy Dust
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: The Early Word: Influences
description: Todays Times

title: Lloyds Bank to Sell Private Equity Assets for $1.6 Billion
description: LONDON  The Lloyds Banking Group, the partly nationalized British bank, agreed on Wednesday to sell a number of its private equity investments to the British firm Coller Capital for around 1 billion, or $1.6 billion.

title: Summer Styles | Gam On
description: A look at whos staying cool and looking cooler this season.

title: A Critics Case for Critics Who Are Actually Critical
description: In the spring of 1983, Esquire convened what it called a revenge symposium. The editors asked a group of well-known writers to let go unbridled comments on their harshest and least favorite critics. The results were spectacular.

title: Buying Versus Renting, Owners Consider the Advantages
description: At a recent She Owns It business group meeting, the conversation focused on real estate. The business owners also touched on the related subject of working remotely, a topic well explore further in coming posts.

title: For Healthy Aging, a Late Act in the Footlights
description: What kind of old age will you have?

title: Stone Links: Philosophical Fictions
description: The science-writing website io9 publishes an essay suggesting that science fiction  or as it is sometimes called, speculative fiction  is just an outgrowth of philosophy, in that the fantastical conceits of such fiction have functioned largely to test philosophical hypotheses. Many works of substantial philosophical content are equally well considered pieces of speculative fiction: Thomas Mores Utopia, Swifts Gullivers Travels, and Shelleys Frankenstein. The essay also manages to draw a line of influence from Platos Cave to the work of Philip K. Dick, and to the movie The Matrix.

title: Carlyle Group Continues an Unusually Busy Summer
description: While summer has traditionally been a slow time for deal making, the Carlyle Group has been on a buying spree in recent weeks.

title: Q&A: The Long Arm of Google on Chrome
description: Q.

title: Germans Reopen Investigation on Facebook Privacy
description: BERLIN  Data protection officials in Germany reopened an investigation into Facebooks facial recognition technology Wednesday, saying that the social networking giant was illegally compiling a huge database of members photos without their consent.

title: Standard Chartereds Shares Rally on Settlement
description: 8:32 a.m. | Updated

title: Pilot Whales in the Apolima Straits
description: Scott Baker, associate director of the Marine Mammal Institute at Oregon State University, writes from Samoa, where he studies the formation of local communities among dolphins and their genetic isolation from one another.

title: A Plea for Hunts Point: Invite Midsize Farmers
description: New York City officials are still negotiating the $350 million renovation of the citys main produce distribution center at Hunts Point in the Bronx, which farmers in the New York region are hoping will make room for them.

title: Is That New England Accent in Retreat?
description: Mitt Romney drew some criticism in March when he wrestled over the pronunciation of Missouri. But some residents of the state where he spends his vacations, according to a recent article in the journal American Speech, have become increasingly uncertain how to pronounce New Hampshire.

title: Vain Glorious | Tom Fords Jardin Noir Perfumes
description: Tom Fords latest fragrance collection, Jardin Noir, features four new scents that subvert the savor of classic blooms (rose, lily, narcissus and hyacinth) into heady concoctions that seem, as Ford puts it, practically illicit. When you showcase their darker and less innocent aspects, he says, flowers can become so thrilling and beautiful, they could almost ruin you. That was the sensation I was after. If the sexy juice itself doesnt ruin you, then its price might. A 250 milliliter bottle is $495.

title: Opinion Report: Voting in Ohio
description: From the editorial page

title: British Employment Defies Weak Economy
description: The British labor market has defied the countrys lingering recession, improving in the second quarter as businesses hired more workers before the Olympic Games, official data showed Wednesday.

title: Europe Fights to Win More Chinese, BRIC Tourists
description: LONDON  Competition is heating up in Europe to attract more tourists from the BRIC countries  Brazil, Russia, India and China  whose economies are expanding while the Europeans are standing still.

title: Wednesday Reading: Strategies for Hot Weather Exercise
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Australian Court Strikes Down Tobacco Challenge
description: SYDNEY  One of the worlds toughest cigarette labeling laws is set to take effect in Australia in December, after the countrys highest court ruled Wednesday against multinational tobacco companies that had sought to block the legislation.

title: Daily Report: Germans Reopen Facebook Privacy Inquiry
description: German officials reopened an investigation into Facebooks facial recognition technology Wednesday, contending the social network giant was illegally compiling a vast photo database of users without their consent, reports Kevin J. OBrien for The New York Times from Berlin.

title: Jack Dempsey vs. Rocky Graziano
description: Dear Diary: During the 1960s, my mother and I saw former boxing world heavyweight champion Jack Dempsey one summer evening standing outside of his famous restaurant formerly on Broadway between 49th and 50th Streets in Manhattan.

title: The Checklist | Venus in Furs
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: On Democracy in Spain
description: MADRID  On Monday, July 30, 40 Spaniards ranging in age from their mid-20s to early 70s congregated in a dilapidated plaza in central Madrid. Those wizened by past experience brought folding chairs; others tore off cardboard slabs from a nearby recycling heap to fashion makeshift cushions. Newcomers stood or crouched.

title: The Things They Stored
description: TEL AVIV  I got home Monday evening to find in my mailbox an official reminder: Did we have enough gas masks for the whole family? Getting one, or replacing an old one, is simple: the distribution center isnt far; its at the building where the Boy Scouts meet around the corner, right near where my youngest boy goes to school.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Lo-Down: As the demographics of Manhattans Chinatown change, why shouldnt its restaurants? Wilson Tang, the second-generation proprietor of Nam Wah Tea Parlor, discusses his own evolving ideas in an age that prizes authenticity.  Eric Asimov

title: The Breakfast Meeting: A New Chief at the Times Company and Farewells to H.G.B.
description: Reaching well outside the newspaper business, The New York Times Company announced that it had hired Mark Thompson, the departing director general of the BBC, as its next president and chief executive. Mr. Thompson has worked almost his entire career at the public broadcaster, making him an unusual choice. Robert Andrews of paidContent gives a British perspective on the hire, and Ken Doctor, the newspaper analyst, offers his take.

title: In Some Parts of the City, a Common Police Practice
description: Across New York City, physical force is used by the police in many of the hundreds of thousands of stops they make each year.

title: Those Corruption Protests Have Backfired in India
description: NEW DELHI  Since April last year, India has seen a wave of protests against politicians and political corruption. The latest demonstration, which ended on Tuesday, was led by the yoga master Baba Ramdev, whose alternative-medicine factory has cures for many ailments, although not corruption.

title: Frustrations of Air Travel Push Passengers to Amtrak
description: WASHINGTON  Long a punch line for harried Northeast travelers, Amtrak has come to dominate commercial travel in the corridor connecting Washington, New York and Boston, and this summer its trains are packed.

title: Pennsylvania Judge Upholds Voter ID Law
description: A Pennsylvania judge on Wednesday refused to grant an injunction on a new voter identification law that Democrats say could harm President Obamas re-election chances by unfairly targeting minorities, college students and others in a key swing state.

title: Big in Baku
description: The slim corridor that some Azeris call the Belt of Happiness starts at Bakus Heydar Aliyev International airport. The new road into town is as black and shiny as the vast pools of oil that paid for it, as well as for everything else in Azerbaijan. And what oil doesnt pay to fix, it pays to hide. Sand-colored concrete walls line the highway, but through their latticed arabesques you can just make out the woeful shacks behind them.

title: Gay Male Comics Await the Spotlight
description: COULD James Adomian become the first man to break through as an openly gay stand-up star?

title: Pneumothorax
description: A slide show depicting pneumothorax, the collection of air or gas in the space surrounding the lungs.

title: Internet Piracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Adoption, Destiny and Magical Thinking
description: Im not a big believer in destiny. Im squarely in the stuff happens camp. But the human tendency to feel that certain things were meant to be fascinates me. Im impressed by our ability to extract a sense of purpose from the random events that make up our lives.

title: Pockets of City See Higher Use of Force During Police Stops
description: The crowded neighborhoods of the West Bronx come alive at night. Residents, young and old, cluster around door stoops. Teenagers fill playground basketball courts. Police officers from the nearby 44th and 46th Precincts patrol the streets, from time to time stopping and frisking young men, mostly black and Latino. And when they do, statistics show, they use physical force far more often than the police do anywhere else in the city.

title: Carpal Tunnel Repair
description: A slide show depicting surgery to correct the compression of the median nerve at the wrist.

title: Alpha Fetoprotein
description: A slide show about alpha fetoprotein, or AFP.

title: Amniocentesis
description: A slide show explaining amniocentesis.

title: For Romney, a New Running Mate May Mean a New, Less Elliptical, Workout, Too
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Mitt Romney is a man of steady and immutable habits. He drinks Cherry Coke Zero. He eats peanut butter and honey sandwiches. And he works out on an elliptical machine.

title: Never Mind Algebra. Is Literature Necessary?
Business Day Live | August 15, 2012
description: With Standard Chartered settlement, a victory for a new regulator. | In Northeast, trains gain ground against airlines. | Importing Russia's top gun.

title: Business Day Live: Hassles of Air Travel Push Passengers to Amtrak
description: With Standard Chartered settlement, a victory for a new regulator. | In Northeast, trains gain ground against airlines. | Importing Russias top gun.

title: Checking Account Fees Rising, Analysis Finds
description: Feel as if youre paying more for your checking account?You probably are.

title: Getting a Jump on iPhone Upgraders
description: If youre thinking about selling your iPhone so you can use the money to buy Apples new smartphone when it comes out, better act fast.

title: A Different Approach to Coping With Drought
description: Water levels are low in reservoirs all over the parched West, but in many areas, the amount of water being used is no greater than the amount that evaporates, according to Moshe Alamaro, a scientist and inventor affiliated with M.I.T.

title: Senate Democrats Strategy for Ryan Includes the Deficit
description: The Democrats war on Representative Paul D. Ryan has moved into the Upper Chamber, and it is extending beyond the battle over Medicare.

title: Claressa Shields Shares Gold
description: Two months ago, Claressa Shields packed a strapless purple dress to wear in London if she became one of the first women boxers to win an Olympic medal. When the 17-year-old boxer from Flint, Mich. (who was included in our multimedia feature on Americas boxing women aiming for the Olympics this past winter), finally got to wear that dress, she had more than one historical achievement to celebrate: the first woman middleweight gold medalist, the youngest since 1924, the only American boxer to stand on top of the podium this year and the second-most-trending name on Yahoo! on the day of her victory.

title: This Old Thing?
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: A Tablet Straining to Do It All
description: The hot news in Silicon Valley legal circles these days is Apples titanic lawsuit against Samsung. Apple maintains that Samsung pilfered some of its iPhone and iPad designs when creating the Samsung Galaxy series of phones and tablets.

title: A Lament for a Supermarket, and Outrage Over Its Replacement
description: It was an unlovely place and its customers had many complaints: a chronic damp and musty smell, a poor selection unless one harbored a passion for Campbells soups, exorbitant prices, a fresh deli that could be anything but and bored workers with little interest in helping shoppers.

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: My fianc and I are planning a small wedding for family and close friends. It is important to us that the sanctity and beauty of the ceremony be respected. Several of our guests have babies and young children. We are happy to have them at our wedding under their parents supervision, but are concerned that this might lead to disruptions during the religious ceremony, which will be about 30 to 45 minutes.

title: The Truth Has A Well-Known Demagogic Bias
description: The other day I picked up on something William Saletan wrote to illustrate the conventional wisdom that has let the essentially ridiculous Paul Ryan go so far. Today let me pick on William Galston  again not a household name, but a good representative of the Beltway gone bad.

title: Leaning Toward the Light: Molly Ringwald Talks About Her New Novel
description: Molly Ringwald became a star for her roles in a beloved triumvirate of mid-80s teenage movies: Sixteen Candles, The Breakfast Club and Pretty in Pink. Now 44, she continues to act and is also focused on a career as an author. In 2010, she published Getting the Pretty Back. She called that effort a kind of entertaining, anecdotal style guide. Her new book is When It Happens to You, a novel told in stories centered around Phillip and Greta, a couple whose marriage is foundering. In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Ringwald discussed the appeal of flawed characters, advice she got from Bret Easton Ellis and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: A Battle Plan for Jet Lag
description: THERE are more so-called remedies for jet lag than there are time zones, from long-standing antidotes like No-Jet-Lags homeopathic tablets to new innovations like the Valkee Brain Stimulation Headset, which was tested earlier this year by Finnair and purports to alleviate jet lag by channeling bright light into the brain through the ear canal.

title: Just Red Sox Being Red Sox
description: With everything that changes each season in baseball, it is nice to have a constant, a touchstone that reminds you what era one is in. To that end, the Red Sox are performing a public service, their dysfunction so consistent that it is almost comforting. Only the details change, from booing Nomar Garciaparra out of town to Manny being Manny to fried chicken and beer to whatever has popped out of Bobby Valentines mouth today.

title: Wheelies: The 32-Pack Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Abby Elliott Not Returning to Saturday Night Live
description: Abby Elliott has joined the ranks of performers like Kristen Wiig and Andy Samberg who are leaving the cast of Saturday Night Live. Ms. Elliott, who joined SNL as a featured performer during its 2008-9 season, told the Web site Splitsider.com that she would not be returning to that long-running late-night comedy series. NBC declined to comment on Wednesday but a person with direct knowledge of plans at the show confirmed the report.

title: A Rare Mother Goose, Indeed
description: The renowned childrens book editor Margaret McElderry died last year, but the imprint bearing her name carries on, as does the publishers McElderry Book of...series of anthologies. The McElderry Book of Mother Goose, the fourth volume (earlier collections were of Greek myths, Aesops fables and Grimms fairy tales) does much to continue her storied tradition  and give it a fresh little tweak, especially for those whove had enough of Little Jack Horner and his over-recited ilk.

title: Ann Romney Refuses to Release More Tax Returns
description: In an interview scheduled to be broadcast Thursday evening on NBCs Rock Center, Ann Romney, the wife of the Republican nominee, Mitt Romney, found herself facing some of the same questions that have dogged her husbands campaign in recent weeks  namely, about the Romney familys tax returns.

title: Introducing Maggie Koerth-Baker
description: Readers of Boing Boing will know what I mean when I say that very few people can write about science like Maggie Koerth-Baker. She is the sites longtime science editor and also the author of the excellent book Before the Lights Go Out: Conquering the Energy Crisis Before It Conquers Us. And starting this month, shell be contributing a regular column to the magazine that were calling Eureka. Her terrific first column is about the mind of a flip-flopper. Maggie will be writing frequently about the intersection of science and culture, about studies she finds to be especially revealing or provocative, about human behavior and technological innovation and natural phenomena. In short, shell be bringing us in closer, smarter, more exciting contact with the scientific world. Were very happy to have her joining the magazine.

title: Remember Iraq?
description: Since troops withdrew at the end of 2011, Iraq has receded from the American public consciousness. Just consider the U.S. presidential campaign where the economy  understandably  predominates. President Obama and Mitt Romney rarely even mention the country we invaded.

title: Energy Security vs. Environment in Alaska
description: While the Marcellus Shale in New York and Pennsylvania and the Bakken Shale in North Dakota are trigger points in the world of fossil-fuel extraction these days, Alaska has been the lodestar for oil and gas development in the United States for the last half-century. And as befits a state dominated more by wild lands than humankind, it has been home to some of the fiercest political battles pitting energy interests against environmental concerns.

title: The Get | Skagen Denmark and Hiromichi Konno Watch
description: It could be said that Hiromichi Konno has a thing for Danish design. Four years ago, he enjoyed a certain degree of acclaim when he created the futuristic-looking Rin chair for the venerable Danish furniture collective Fritz Hansen. More recently, Konno approached the watch company Skagen Denmark about a collaboration. I was so impressed by their design philosophy, Konno said, which he defines as simple and beautiful.

title: Wall Streets Race to the 48-Millisecond Trade
description: It took just 45 minutes this month for one of Wall Streets top trading firms to lose $440 million, a loss that has focused attention on the potential problems associated with high-speed trading. Yet todays technological challenges are not unlike those faced by traders in the 19th century, whose jobs were revolutionized by the advent of ticker machines.

title: Religious Roots Tangle With the Groovy 60s
description: Wearing a bushy beard and the absent-minded expression of a father preoccupied with work at the dinner table, Eric Anderson, who plays the Jewish singer Shlomo Carlebach in the bio-musical Soul Doctor, appears smaller than life. That changes, however, when he starts to sing.

title: Reasonable Republicans?
description: Several commenters have asked that I provide examples of Republicans making reasonable economic arguments; some of them seem to be saying that Im proving my bias if I dont provide such examples.

title: Forget Harvard; Real Economic Change Will Come From the Bottom
description: In Sundays magazine, Adam Davidson finds a reason to cheer for second-rate business schools. They may lack Nobel laureate professors and ivy-covered buildings, but they have managed to drive down the cost of a business degree. Some schools, like the University of California, Irvine, even offer online classes for free. There are hundreds of millions of small farmers, shopkeepers and potential entrepreneurs, Davidson writes, for whom mass business-educational tools could be transformational in ways that make a handful of top schools seem utterly irrelevant. According to Larry Cooperman, director of U.C. Irvines OpenCourseWare program, the transformation has already begun.

title: Still Recovering From Knee Problems, Nadal Will Miss United States Open
description: Rafael Nadal withdrew from the United States Open on Wednesday, saying he was not ready to return to competition because of chronic knee problems that forced him out of the Olympics and two warm-up tournaments for the Open.

title: Police Arrest Man, 54, in Robbery of a 9-Year-Old Boy
description: The police have arrested a 54-year-old man who they say violently mugged a 9-year-old Bronx boy for $19.

title: Amtrak Dominates Northeast Corridor Travel
description: For harried travelers between the major cities of the Northeast, commercial travel increasingly means a trip to the train station, not the airport. Amtraks trains are packed this summer with passengers seeking to avoid fight delays and security lines and find space to work.

title: How to Share the Revenue Could Be Stumbling Block in N.H.L. Negotiations
description: N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman said he was not certain whether he and league negotiators would have a response by Wednesday to the proposal made Tuesday by the Players Association.

title: In Senate Races, Politics Are Local Again
description: We will soon be unveiling our forecast model for United States Senate races. But as a point of comparison and because there have been a number of important primaries for the Senate in recent weeks, I first wanted to give you my view of the contests.

title: Introducing the Ocean Health Index
description: In a potential milestone for ocean management, a team of collaborators has produced the first Ocean Health Index, a tool for appraising the state of the worlds oceans. The index takes into account the major factors that influence the quality of regional marine ecosystems like fisheries, biodiversity, tourism and carbon storage and then assigns a score from zero to 100 for each place.

title: A New Delano, This Time in Moscow
description: The Delano hotel is getting an outpost in Moscow, according to executives with the Morgans Hotel Group. The 160-room hotel, scheduled to open in 2015, will be run by Morgans and developed with the Capital Group.

title: Equal (Voting) Consideration
description: As the board mentioned on the editorial page today, Ohio doesnt treat all voters the same. Depending on where you live, your polling place may close promptly 5 p.m., or stay open in the evenings and on weekends. More specifically, if you live in a county likely to favor President Obama, youll have to get to the polls before the end of the traditional work day; if you live in a county likely to swing Republican, you can take your time.

title: In Peugeots Troubles, a Test of Contradictory Campaign Promises for Hollande
description: SOCHAUX, France  Peugeot, one of Frances iconic companies, is in trouble, presenting President Franois Hollande with an early, telling crisis that is displaying the contradictions at the heart of his campaign promises to spur economic growth while shrinking the budget deficit with tax increases.

title: Dont Discourage Outside Shareholders
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is currently considering a rule-making petition that advocates tightening the rules governing how quickly shareholders must disclose when they hold 5 percent or more of a companys shares.

title: On Medicare, Obama Plays Offense
description: DUBUQUE, Iowa  With Mitt Romney on the attack over Medicare, President Obama entered the fight on Wednesday, catapulting the popular entitlements program to the top of the presidential campaign.

title: Actress Writes to Putin to Demand Vegan Meals for Jailed Punk Protesters
description: Last Updated, 5:23 p.m. While the prosecution of three members of a Russian protest band called Pussy Riot has raised concerns about freedom of speech and the growing influence of the Orthodox Church in Russia, an American actress has identified another urgent matter about the case: Russian prisons do not serve vegan meals.

title: The Daily Shoe | Valentino
description: Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the Bergdorf Goodman shoe salon. Today's pick: a romantic, lace and suede ankle bootie from Valentino Garavani.

title: Owners Should Know What Theyre Getting With Private Equity
description: Puneet Mehta, an Atlanta entrepreneur, remembers how eager he was to take the money. When investors courted him, he felt razzle-dazzled, enchanted by their promises to help him build the online marketing business he had founded in 2006.

title: The Daily Shoe | Valentino Garavani
description: Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the Bergdorf Goodman shoe salon in honor of the stores 111th anniversary. Todays pick, No. 8 of 11: a romantic, lace and suede ankle bootie from Valentino Garavani. $1,195.

title: Would You Take a Private Equity Investment?
description: In a small-business guide weve just published, Puneet Mehta talks about feeling razzle-dazzled when private equity investors approached him about buying into the online marketing business he had founded in 2006 in Atlanta.

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 15
description: A view of the day in sports, including heroes welcomes for Olympians in Russia, Germany and Uganda, and a ceremony for the arrival of the Olympic flag in Rio de Janeiro, host of the 2016 Summer Games.

title: Video: Fifth Graders in 1995 Predict How Well Use the Internet
description: Hey, why should I be on the Internet?

title: 2013 Range Rover: A Flagship S.U.V. Takes Lessons From Its Sprightly Sibling
description: Land Rover introduced its 2013 Range Rover sport utility vehicle on Wednesday. Though the new flagship is unmistakably kin to the 2012 model, it borrows a measure of edginess from the smaller, sporty and successful Range Rover Evoque, which premiered to critical acclaim last year.

title: Day 1 of New Dream for Illegal Immigrants
New York Fringe Festival Report:  2 Households
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat from now to the festivals close on Aug. 26. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.Follow me here: I was moved by seeing a man in the role of a young woman being kissed by a second guy, playing a teenage boy, who minutes earlier portrayed an old lady. And that wasnt the only instance of unexpected emotion in 2 Households, 2 ________: Shakespeares R&J, a pretty good show despite a fairly bad (and unprintable) title.

title: For Cubs Volstad, Another Start, Another Loss
description: On the surface, it would seem logical to question the employment of a starting pitcher who has an 0-9 record and a 6.96 earned run average this season. Throw in a losing streak of 23 games, and one can start to question why the Cubs right-hander Chris Volstad is still in the rotation.

title: Fringe Benefits | Highlights from the Edinburgh Festival
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Still Pulling for a Wildflowers Survival
description: Eight years ago, a preservation battle raged on Staten Island over an inconspicuous plant called Torreys mountain mint. It was known to grow in fewer than 20 locations on the planet, and one of them was a site on the islands southwest edge where a developer planned to build a shopping center called Bricktown Centre at Charleston.

title: Treasury Appoints 2 to Ally Financial Board
description: Ally Financial, the former GMAC, said on Wednesday that Gerald Greenwald and Henry S. Miller had been elected to its board of directors.

title: Veterinarian Surprises Floridas Stearns in Republican Primary
description: A huge cash advantage and a shift to the ideological right were not enough to secure a primary victory for Representative Cliff Stearns, Republican of Florida, who lost his bid for a 13th term to a Tea Party-backed veterinarian who has never held public office.

title: Biologists Track Biggest Florida Python  17-Footer with 87 Eggs
description: [Aug. 18, 8:03 a.m. | Updated | See asterisks.]Heres a quick update on the amazing story of the Burmese pythons that, brought to Florida as a result of the  laxly regulated trade in exotic reptiles, have been spreading and breeding in the state, with the Everglades National Park providing a particularly large buffet of wildlife for feeding. (Read the United States Geological Survey reportSevere Declines in Everglades Mammals Linked to Pythonsfor more.)

title: Digital Notes: 50,000 Are Owed Royalties, Agency Says
description: 4:02 p.m. | Updated SoundExchange, which collects royalties for digital streams and Internet radio, is looking for 50,000 artists and labels that are owed money.

title: Pulp Friction
description: Joyce Carol Oates on violence, video games and sins of omission.

title: What Stands on Two Legs, Isnt Pink but Is Still a Flamingo?
description: Those in need of an adorable-baby-bird fix need look no farther than the Bronx Zoo, where a 3-day-old Caribbean flamingo emerged from under its mom and took its first steps last week at the zoos Aquatic Birds exhibit. The big moment was caught on video and released Wednesday by the zoo.

title: TimesCast Tech | August 15, 2012
description: Game designers target the tablet market. | Keeping the grass green during a drought. | Customizing education by the hour.

title: Ex-Officers Attack Obama Over Leaks on Bin Laden Raid
description: WASHINGTON  In a direct attack on one of President Obamas political strengths, a group of former special operations and C.I.A. officers started a campaign on Tuesday night accusing Mr. Obama of recklessly leaking information about the raid that killed Osama bin Laden and other security matters to gain political advantage.

title: Kinky Boots Sets April 4 Broadway Opening
description: Kinky Boots, one of the most anticipated musicals of the new Broadway season, with Cyndi Lauper making her debut as a songwriter for the stage, will begin performances on March 5, 2013, at the Al Hirschfeld Theater and open on April 4, the producers announced on Wednesday.

title: Australia Restricts Company Logos on Cigarette Packs
description: Australias highest court upheld a law on Wednesday that prohibits tobacco companies from using their logos on cigarette packets, a decision that means smokers could see more of the graphic images associated with their habit: blistered, cancer-stricken mouths; children sick from secondhand smoke, and gangrenous limbs.

title: At Ryan-Adelson Gathering, Budget Talk Trumps Israel
description: LAS VEGAS  At a private gathering with Representative Paul D. Ryan, Sheldon Adelson, the billionaire casino owner and Republican super-donor, offered no public remarks and, somewhat surprisingly, his pet cause of Israel was not part of the conversation, according to an attendee.

title: Wells Fargo Offers E-Receipts to Branch Customers
description: Lots of retailers  the online kind and the brick-and-mortar version  have begun offering electronic receipts for purchases to help cut down on paper clutter in your wallet. So why shouldnt banks get into the act, too?

title: Long Island Man Is Charged With Insurance Fraud in Faked Drowning Case
description: A Long Island man suspected of faking his drowning to collect more than $400,000 in life insurance was arrested Wednesday and formally charged with insurance fraud, conspiracy and filing a false report.

title: Romney on Regulation
description: Mitt Romneys response to Joe Bidens latest verbal fumble has been both totally predictable and totally baffling.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Mars on View, and Odes to Minecraft
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Now 43 Compilation Tops Album Chart
description: After a nine-week run at No. 1, Carly Rae Jepsens song Call Me Maybe has finally been bumped from the top spot, by Flo Ridas Whistle. But Ms. Jepsens song is now part of a different No. 1. It is the first track on the latest installment  Vol. 43  of Now Thats What I Call Music!  the long-running pop compilation series, which opens atop Billboards album chart this week.

title: Embracing the Right Fit
description: SO far, the Mitt Romney-Paul Ryan ticket has been given the approval rating typically reserved for a Hollywood bromance in the dead of August. Two thumbs up for the cute Republican dudes!

title: Illegal Immigrants Line Up by Thousands for Deportation Deferrals
description: CHICAGO  Tens of thousands of young illegal immigrants waited excitedly in lines as long as a mile and thronged to information sessions across the country on Wednesday, the first day that a federal immigration agency began accepting applications for deportation deferrals that include permits to work legally.

title: In Store | French Tips
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: 9/11 Museum Asks for Dismissal of Suit Over Cross
description: The National September 11 Memorial and Museum filed court papers this week seeking to dismiss a federal lawsuit brought by a group of atheists who oppose the museums decision to display the giant cross-shaped steel beam that became a site of daily prayer during the cleanup of ground zero.

title: Inflation Deflation
description: The Bureau of Labor Statistics estimated on Wednesday that prices rose at an annual pace of 1.4 percent over the 12 months ending in July, and even more slowly during July itself. The Federal Reserve likes an annual rate of 2 percent. So its time for more stimulus, right? QE33333333333!

title: Bridgewater to Spend $750 Million on New Offices
description: There are hedge funds, and then there is Bridgewater Associates.

title: Ratification of Unions Deal With Caterpillar May Face Difficulties
description: Caterpillar and the International Association of Machinists said on Wednesday that they had reached a tentative six-year settlement that could end a 15-week strike at the companys hydraulics parts plant in Joliet, Ill.

title: On Our Radar: Wildfires in Washington State
description: Firefighters battle more than a dozen wildfires across the West, including a massive out-of-control blaze that has burned over 28,000 acres between two national forests in Washington State. [Reuters]

title: Scouting Report
description: OPENINGS

title: The Young Persons Guide to the (Smartphone) Orchestra
description: When I was a toddler, my parents introduced me to music-making through a cheap plastic recorder. Later came a secondhand violin and the tireless efforts of my schools choir teacher. It was all fun, even if I found it so hard to learn violin the traditional way. All I could produce for ages was a horrid squeaking.

title: The Joys and Hazards of Self-Publishing on the Web
description: Not long ago, an aspiring book writer rejected by traditional publishing houses had only one alternative: vanity publishing. For $5,000 or $10,000, or sometimes much more, he could have his manuscript edited and published, provided that he agreed to buy many copies himself, often a few thousand or more. They typically ended up in the garage.

title: A Mans Humdrum Life Suddenly Turns Potent
description: Jonathan Troppers slick, manipulative new novel is about a lovable sad sack named Drew Silver. Youve got that kind of cuddly bad-boy thing going on, like youre dangerous, but only a little bit, you know? his daughter tells him.

title: Missed Chance to Reject Voting Barriers
description: Judge Robert Simpson of the Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania seems to assume that legislators have a high-minded public purpose for the laws they pass. Thats why, on Wednesday morning, he refused to grant an injunction to halt a Republican-backed voter ID law that could disenfranchise hundreds of thousands of poor and minority state residents in November.

title: A Beach Body Built in Wisconsin
description: WHEN it comes to free celebrity endorsements, they dont get much better than a presumptive vice-presidential candidate who swears by your product.

title: Despite Alarm by U.S., Europe Lets Hezbollah Operate Openly
description: BERLIN  As American officials sound the alarm over what they call a resurgent threat from the Shiite militant group Hezbollah, thousands of its members and supporters operate with few restrictions in Europe, raising money that is funneled to the groups leadership in Lebanon.

title: Cisco Revenue and Profit Exceed Forecasts as Orders in Asia Stay Strong
description: Cisco Systems, the worlds largest maker of computer networking equipment, delivered quarterly results on Wednesday that slightly surpassed Wall Streets expectations in a challenging environment for corporate technology spending.

title: A Thorny Flower
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Seeking a Reprieve
description: Thousands of young immigrants, in the country illegally, lined up to take part of a program that would allow deportations to be deferred for up to two years.

title: Casino Plan Runs Into Opposition in Spain
description: MADRID  Two struggling Spanish cities, Madrid and Barcelona, have been eagerly courting the billionaire casino magnate Sheldon G. Adelson for months, each of them trying to become the site of his planned casino and leisure resort.

title: Scene City: A Book Sale, Hamptons Style
description: The East Hampton Library holds its annual Authors Night benefit with a book sale and private dinners.

title: Carpe Aestatem': Seize Summers Last Days
description: Less than two weeks.

title: State Regulators Widen Libor Investigation
description: State regulators are widening their investigation into interest rate manipulation, pursuing wrongdoing at seven of the worlds biggest banks.

title: Anybody Have a Book?
description: ONCE you write a book, the work isnt finished. You still have to get people to buy it.

title: Another Trial Is Scheduled for Man Charged in 2008 Killing of Psychologist
description: A man accused of murdering a psychologist in her Upper East Side office in 2008 is set to face trial next year, after his lawyers said Wednesday that they would not challenge a finding that he was mentally fit. A 2010 attempt to try the man, David Tarloff, ended in a mistrial after he became psychotic during jury selection.

title: New Big East Commissioner Can Talk Ambitions but Not Details
description: There was much that Mike Aresco couldnt address Wednesday, when he was formally introduced as the Big Easts newest commissioner at the Manhattan New York Athletic Club. New to collegiate administration, he still looked as his contemporaries would, with shadows under his eyes, though his job has just begun.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Pakistan, India and South Africa.

title: Van Persie Heads to Manchester United
description: Robin van Persies escape from Arsenal needs only a doctors approval before it becomes final.

title: Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons Will Play Broadway
description: Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons will perform in a weeklong engagement at the Broadway Theater in October to celebrate the vocal groups 50th anniversary, the producers announced on Wednesday.The show will run from Oct. 19 through 27.

title: A Novel Asks Seattle to Laugh at Itself
description: SEATTLE  Maria Semple made an instant, jarring discovery when she moved with her boyfriend and daughter from Los Angeles to Seattle, a city whose Patagonia-clad inhabitants like to talk about bicycling, the environment and the eternally dull question (in her opinion) of whether it might rain.

title: Fall Trends
description: No. 1: the decorated jacket. No. 2: the wrap. No. 3: the new suit.

title: Syrian Conflict Imperils Historical Treasures
description: Preservationists and archaeologists are warning that fighting in Syrias commercial capital, Aleppo  considered the worlds oldest continuously inhabited human settlement  threatens to damage irreparably the stunning architectural and cultural legacy left by 5,000 years of civilizations.

title: Big Retailers Plan Effort for Mobile Purchases
description: Cash, credit or debit? You may one day have far more choices to make at the checkout counter. A group of big retailers, including 7-Eleven, Best Buy, CVS and Wal-Mart, said on Wednesday that they were forming a company that would offer a way for customers to pay for purchases with their smartphones, joining a wide array of businesses seeking a piece of this market.

title: Broadway, Broadway, Here We Are! (Clap!)
description: POSTERS from infamous Broadway flops loom behind the young performers gathered for lunch recently at Joe Allen, the theater district restaurant. But for these exuberant actors, all making their Broadway debuts in Bring It On: The Musical, the brutal realities of the business couldnt seem further away.

title: Giving Their Regards
description: Five Broadway newbies are performing in Bring It On: the Musical.

title: Dreaming of a Life as Vivid as Her Art
description: Inocente Izucar wants to join the circus someday and learn sign language. She paints her face every morning with colors and designs as bold as those on her sprawling canvases. She sometimes orders dessert before dinner because she emphatically believes you can never go wrong with a root-beer float.

title: On Univisions Nightly News, a Plea for Presidential Debate on Latino Issues
description: Univision will use its nightly news broadcast on Wednesday to plead with both presidential campaigns to accommodate an additional debate, on Univision, directed at the issues of concern to Latino viewers.

title: Hip-Hops Loyal Mascot Now Cheers Himself On
description: 2 Chainz is 35, tall and gangly, all awkward angles. A working-class-minded interloper into a hip-hop era that has largely shelved self-presentations that are less than 110 percent polished, he juts out, tough to miss. His luxury restaurant is Benihana, not Philippe. His luxury brand is Polo, not Margiela. He rapped for more than a decade with little to no acclaim. He is nobodys sex symbol.

title: The Perplexity of Youths in a Group
description: The opening work of the Smuin Ballets triple bill at the Joyce Theater on Monday provides evidence of one of the most singular choreographic minds working in ballet today. Trey McIntyres Oh, Inverted World  set to songs by the Shins  is a pop ballet, reminiscent of some of the best pop ballets of Twyla Tharp. Its subject, though, is one that I dont remember Ms. Tharp tackling: the perplexity of young individuals amid the group.

title: Pianist Greets Beethoven Like an Old Friend in a Festival Debut
description: The Austrian pianist Rudolf Buchbinder has had a lifelong fascination with Beethoven, performing and recording the complete concertos and sonatas on several occasions. Beethoven haunted me 24 hours, day and night, he often drove me half-crazy, Mr. Buchbinder wrote about his experience of performing the sonata cycle in 1982.

title: In Search of New Subjects to Spoof
description: One good thing about Bullet in the Face, a new series starting Thursday night on IFC, is the theme song, a jazzy, torchy spoof of a Goldfinger-era James Bond anthem. The chorus serves as a convenient plot summary:

title: Russian Mayor at Center of Protests Resigns
description: MOSCOW  It was a conflict that made clear the impunity granted to public officials by Russias criminal justice system: The editor of a local newspaper was beaten nearly to death in 2008 after criticizing the mayor of a Moscow suburb, and the police barely feigned an investigation.

title: Bridge Play at the Second World Mind Sports Games
description: LILLE, France  At the Second World Mind Sports Games here all three United States teams qualified for the round of 16, which started on Wednesday and will end on Thursday at 1:20 p.m. Eastern time. The results are at worldbridge.org.

title: Tunisian Women March to Defend Equality
description: As Reuters reported, thousands of Tunisian women marched in the capital, Tunis, on Monday night to protest a provision in the new Islamist governments draft constitution describing women as complementary to men. The 6,000 protesters pledged to defend the equality under the law they have enjoyed since Tunisia adopted its Code of Personal Status on Aug. 13, 1956.

title: A Product With Devotees Tries to Widen Its Niche
description: THE Pelican brand of protective cases for electronics is well known, but only among users in fields like the oil industry, the military and aerospace. For years, the companys primary form of marketing consisted of expos and trade publications.

title: Johnson & Johnson to Remove Formaldehyde From Products
description: Johnson & Johnson, which makes a range of personal care products like baby shampoo, acne cream and antiwrinkle lotion, announced plans Wednesday to remove a host of potentially harmful chemicals, like formaldehyde, from its line of consumer products by the end of 2015, becoming the first major consumer products company to make such a widespread commitment.

title: On Frogs, Fungi, Climate and the New News Process
description: On Monday, the University of South Florida press office put out a release to draw attention to an important new study finding amplified disease risk in frogs when exposure to a dangerous fungus coincides with increasingly varied temperatures. The headline was Frogs Getting Sick from Climate Change.

title: Boundary: Keeping Cloud Software in Shape
description: With thousands of different software applications flying around the cloud of a data centers computer servers and storage devices, things can get complex. There might be a business in explaining the story of their travels to overtaxed system managers.

title: Eternally Under Construction
description: When John Archer finds an interesting piece of architectural salvage, he often builds a new wing around it.

title: Scrap Mansion
description: DANVERS, Mass.

title: The Cherished Remainders of a Luxe Life
description: IN her heyday as the bejeweled empress of New York philanthropy, Brooke Astor entertained presidents, first ladies and a potpourri of pooh-bahs and literati at her elegant 14-room duplex on Park Avenue. And when she died on Aug. 13, 2007, at Holly Hill, her estate in Westchester County, at 105, she left behind two households worth of cherished possessions, including Qing dynasty lacquer furniture, a jade-and-diamond Cartier clock and dozens of 19th-century dog portraits.

title: Seeking an Edge, Then Falling Off the Cliff
description: The fastball left Matt Harrisons hand at 93 miles per hour, headed for the inner half of the plate, belt high. This was the All-Star Game, last month in Kansas City, and any hitter might have done what Melky Cabrera did to that pitch: lash it on a line into the left-field bullpen for a home run.

title: After Cabrera Is Suspended, Surprise and Sadness From the Yankees
description: The news that San Francisco Giants outfielder Melky Cabrera was suspended 50 games Wednesday for testing positive for testosterone was met with surprise and sadness in the Yankees clubhouse.

title: Helen Gurley Brown, as Others Saw Her
description: YOU can debate for hours whether Helen Gurley Brown liberated women or held them back, with her salacious cover lines, big-haired scantily clad cover girls and relentless focus on improving sex lives (hers and his).

title: Skinny-Dipping in the City
description: URBANITES: Consider the real estate luxuries that have consumed your thoughts, occupied your daydreams, perhaps even encroached upon your bank accounts, from the relatively modest (your own washer and dryer) to the truly extravagant (your own pool on the roof).

title: In Yucatn, a Home for Two Travel Writers
description: A couple renovates a house in the Mexican state of Yucatn.

title: In Mexico, a Dateline Beckons
description: TRAVEL writing, like any profession, has its advantages, the most obvious being the job itself: exploring faraway places on someone elses dime. One drawback, though, is that travel writers are rarely able to immerse themselves in any one place.

title: U.N. Panel Blames Syrian Army and Militia for Houla Massacre
description: An independent panel appointed by the United Nations to investigate rights abuses in Syria said Wednesday that the governments armed forces and loyalist militias were responsible for the worst known atrocity in the conflict, a massacre of 108 villagers, nearly half of them women and children, in the western village of Houla on May 25.

title: Chandeliers
description: Sara Story, an interior designer, searches for the right chandelier for each rooms temperament.

title: Master of Suspense
description: WHEN Sara Story is looking for light fixtures, her feeling is, the bolder, the better.

title: The King of Pants Hopes for a Second Reign
description: POOR pants. You never hear economists pegging a market forecast to their lengths, as they do with skirts, or magazines celebrating It pants, as they do with bags and shoes. In boom times, as in lean years, pants are just pants.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. Would a fully equipped outdoor kitchen with appliances increase the resale value of my house?

title: New York Times Magazine Plays New York Magazine in Softball, Everyone Gets Confused About Whos On Which Team
description: Where we left off, on the fertile lowlands of Central Parks public softball fields, our heroes from The New York Times Magazine were celebrating their first softball victory of the season (and maybe the last few years) against their archrival, The New Yorker. The score was around 9-1, some said. If only that were the only score of the summer we had to recall.

title: Warning Issued on Codeine for Children
description: The Food and Drug Administration issued a warning on Wednesday after three children died from respiratory arrest caused by regular doses of codeine after surgery to treat sleep apnea. The agency cautioned parents and health workers to watch for symptoms of overdose, like unusual sleepiness, difficulty being aroused or awakened, confusion or noisy and difficult breathing.

title: The Giants Top Pick Shows Grit and Speed
description: ALBANY  David Wilson jogged close to the sideline, his right hand gripping a ball. In that moment at Mondays practice, Wilson could hear the fans just 10 feet away.

title: Even Turtles Need a Nice Place to Call Home
description: Two years ago, the childrens-book author and illustrator Jan Brett and her husband, Joseph Hearne, a bassist with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, installed a turtle pond on the grounds of their two-acre home in Norwell, Mass. It was inspired by her plan to write a book about an Eastern box turtle with wildflowers and ferns sprouting from its shell. In Mossy, due out next month (G. P. Putnams Sons; $17.99), the turtle spends some unhappy months on display at a natural-history museum until a penitent biologist restores it to its habitat.

title: Ecuador to Let Assange Stay in Its Embassy
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The government of Ecuador is prepared to allow Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, to remain in its embassy in London indefinitely under a type of humanitarian protection, a government official said in Quito on Wednesday night. Mr. Assange has been holed up in the embassy for two months seeking asylum.

title: No House Training Needed
description: Visitors to the New York International Gift Fair this weekend will be greeted by a menagerie at the MollaSpace booth  a buffalo, lamb, dog and horse, all prepared to support you. Designed by Owen Chuang and Cloud Lu of BiAugust, the Black Animal Chair collection is handmade in Taiwan, where the two are based.

title: In Connecticut, a Convergence of Green Thumbs
description: From Aug. 24 to 26, gardeners may be inspired by earth-friendly techniques while exploring the art historian George Schoellkopfs Hollister House Garden in Washington, Conn., at the symposium Gardening Anew: Fresh Perspectives on the Garden. Sponsored by Hollister House Garden and the Garden Conservancy, it will convene master landscape designers and plant gurus of the Northeast. Speakers will include Edwina von Gal, a designer whose clients include Richard Serra and Calvin Klein; William Cullina, executive director of Coastal Maine Botanical Gardens, a 250-acre expanse of organically grown native plants; and Eric T. Fleisher, director of horticulture for Battery Park City Parks Conservancy, who will discuss composting, soil biology and water conservation. Late-season plants from New Englands best nurseries will be sold, and there will be tours of seven area gardens, including Mr. Schoellkopfs 25-acre masterpiece, developed over three decades.

title: Counting Stanzas and Couplets Instead of Sheep
description: Its not easy to read Kerry Larkins poetry without feeling the tug of the natural world. Truth be told, its not easy to read Ms. Larkins poetry, period. Sometimes the words are embroidered in white on white, and the messages are more like texture. Or in A Perfect Moon, above left, which mentions pines that resemble construction paper cut outs against the almost black sky, the lines are alternating bands of autumnal color.

title: On Madison Avenue, a New Vibe
description: Conspicuous consumption has made a resounding return to Madison Avenue, at least on that mile of glistening shops stretching north of Barneys New York at East 60th Street. But it isnt quite the same Madison Avenue as what was there before.

title: Industrial Ingenuity (Just Add Water)
description: Roman & Williams, the design firm founded by Robin Standefer and Stephen Alesch, won fame for its scene-setting interiors for Manhattans trendy Ace and Standard Hotels, as well as the restaurants, bars and cafes within them. Now its moved on to product design, with bath fittings for Waterworks. The R. W. Atlas collection, which was inspired in part by a 1930s Leica camera and by an old microscope displayed in the designers offices, has a strong industrial sensibility; it would look at home in any vintage factory setting.

title: Though Tone Is Familiar, Scott Has His Eye on a Different Result
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  Jets linebacker Bart Scott spoke off the field Wednesday, and he still sounded like the player whose outspokenness helped him earn the nickname the Mad Backer.

title: Sales at Baker, Ochre, Ligne Roset and Others
description: Baker furniture has introduced an Odds & Ends outlet Web site, updated weekly, with items up to 75 percent off (a Bill Sofield for Baker Cheval dining table, usually $10,124, is $2,531); (866) 222-3060, bakeroddsandends.com.

title: California: Man Convicted of Murder in Five Deaths From 2003 Wildfire
description: Rickie Lee Fowler, 30, was convicted of murder on Wednesday in the deaths of five men caused by a fire he intentionally set in 2003 in Waterman Canyon in the foothills above San Bernardino. The wildfire burned 91,000 acres and 1,000 homes. Investigators said Mr. Fowler was high on methamphetamine and angry with a friend who had thrown him out of his home. Witnesses reported seeing Mr. Fowler and another man fling a lighted flare into dry brush, the authorities said. Prosecutors said they would seek the death penalty.

title: Downtown Comes Uptown
description: EVER since the recession, Madison Avenue, a barometer of New York Citys retail health if ever there was one, has undergone what could be described as three stages of grief:

title: In Albany, Hopes of Making New York State a Yogurt Empire
description: ALBANY  After two hours, the Yogurt Summit ran out of spoons.

title: Professor Faces Firing for Joke Tied to Shootings
description: After turning down the lights in his classroom at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Prof. Gregory F. Sullivan began showing a documentary and prepared to step out for a moment.

title: Maryland: Casino Bill Goes to Voters
description: Maryland will get another casino and expand table games statewide if voters approve a measure signed by Gov. Martin OMalley on Wednesday. The legislation would allow for a casino to be built in Prince Georges County and permit table games in casinos. It also would enable the states casinos to stay open all day and lower taxes at some of them. Mr. OMalley said it would create 2,300 jobs and generate $200 million for education.

title: Stoudemire Putting New Spin on Career
description: Over a 16-month span that ended in May, Amare Stoudemire lost, in no particular order: his health, his brother, his head coach, his primacy in the Knicks universe, his scoring touch and, in the end, a little of his dignity.

title: Mexico: Confessions Are Reported in the Killing of 5 Journalists
description: The Mexican authorities announced Wednesday that captured members of a criminal cell had confessed to the killing of five journalists in the state of Veracruz this year. According to the state attorney, the criminals, one of whom was detained last week carrying identification cards belonging to Irasema Becerra, a recently slain newspaper employee, admitted to a total of 36 crimes. Press freedom activists expressed dissatisfaction with the announcement, saying that it was unacceptable for the authorities to announce the resolution of these cases based on confessions rather than conducting full investigations. A 2012 report from Human Rights Watch attributed the countrys failing justice system in part to the acceptance by some judges of confessions obtained through torture and other ill treatment.

title: Iran Group May Remain on U.S. Terror List
description: WASHINGTON  State Department officials are preparing for a possible decision by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton to redesignate an Iranian opposition group as a terrorist organization, in part because of the groups resistance to abandoning its camp in Iraq, two American officials said Wednesday.

title: Syrian Rebels Said to Be Holding Elite Fighters From Iran
description: WASHINGTON  American officials said Wednesday that they had obtained credible information that at least some of the 48 Iranians captured in Damascus this month by Syrian rebels were members of Irans elite Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, not the pilgrims described by the government in Tehran.

title: U.S. Wins in Mexico for the First Time
description: The United States mens soccer team ended a 75-year drought Wednesday night, defeating Mexico, 1-0, in a friendly for its first win on Mexican soil.

title: The NBC Sports Network Hopes Ratings Will Rise
description: In past lives, it was called the Outdoor Life Channel, OLN and Versus. But by any name, the NBC Sports Network has been a blip in a universe dominated by ESPN.

title: Hernandez Latest to Achieve Perfection, to Fans Delight
description: In what has become the year of the perfect game, Felix Hernandez of the Seattle Mariners added his name to the list Wednesday, marking the first time that three pitchers have pulled off the feat in the same season.

title: Even in a Scrabble Match, Cheat Is a 4-Letter Word
