description: Bending the rules in sports and games may have just gotten its biggest global exposure at the Olympics, where we learned, among other things, that losing in badminton and soccer is an actual strategy (and one the International Olympic Committee officially frowns upon). But now cheating has moved into a more puzzling arena: competitive Scrabble.

title: Things I Saw  No. 26
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: Paul Ryan, From Different Angles
description: To the Editor:

title: Why I No Longer Drive
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Using Deadly Force
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bias in Custom Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: Having Kids Yet?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Mineral Resources
description: To the Editor:

title: Check-Cashing Stores
description: To the Editor:

title: Can't Afford Foreign Aid, or Can't Afford to Cut It?
The Case for Natural Gas Exports
description: NEW data released last month signaled a milestone for American energy: natural gas joined coal as the top source of electric power. Gas production has boomed on the back of abundant supplies. That has spurred debates over hydraulic fracturing, a method to extract gas from shale.

title: A Chinese Murder Mystery, Far From Solved
description: LAST Thursdays hastily orchestrated murder trial of Gu Kailai, the wife of the ousted Chinese Politburo member Bo Xilai, has raised several questions that cast serious doubt on the case.

title: The View From Pyongyang
description: LIKE Havana, only more so, the North Korean capital, Pyongyang, is bereft of commercial billboards but covered with propaganda posters. In recent years, however, one company has been allowed to advertise its products: Pyonghwa Motors, a joint venture between the Rev. Sun Myung Moons South Korea-based Unification Church and North Koreas state-run Ryonbong General Corporation. A few signs promoting the companys Whistle sedan can be seen in Pyongyang and surrounding areas. Essentially a Hyundai, the Whistle is an increasingly common sight on Pyongyang streets, along with a growing number of BMW, Lexus, Mercedes, Nissan and other luxury and nonluxury vehicles, many privately owned.

title: With Arena, Rapper Rewrites Celebrity Investors Playbook
description: When the developer Bruce Ratner set out to buy the New Jersey Nets and build an arena for them in Brooklyn, he recruited Jay-Z, the hip-hop superstar who grew up in public housing a couple of miles from the site, to join his group of investors.

title: Lottery Numbers
Israeli Leaders Could Be Dissuaded From Striking Iran
description: JERUSALEM  A former Israeli national security adviser said Wednesday that the prime minister and the defense minister told him this week they had not yet decided to attack Irans nuclear facilities and could be dissuaded from a strike if President Obama approved stricter sanctions and publicly confirmed his willingness to use military force.

title: Coalition Aims to Link School Group and Romney
description: Hoping that New Yorkers will think of Romney as a dirty word, a coalition of labor unions and liberal advocacy groups is beginning a campaign on Thursday to tie the presumptive Republican presidential nominee to defenders of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs education policies.

title: Shooting at Family Research Council in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  A gunman trying to enter the downtown offices of a conservative policy organization on Wednesday morning shot and wounded a security guard before he was wrestled to the ground and arrested, a city police officer said.

title: Romney the Unknowable
description: Ten days from now, some of the worlds best-paid magicians of image and narrative will unveil a reboot of a most unfathomable man, Willard Mitt Romney, a 2012 model with a shelf life of barely two months.

title: Middle-Age Blues
description: Paul Ryan is everywhere! Nobody can talk about anything but the congressman from Wisconsin. We now know he is the intellectual, spiritual and moral center of the House of Representatives, who keeps his body fat below 8 percent and excels at a sport that involves sticking your hand inside a catfish, grabbing it by the tonsils and pulling it out of the water. Also, I believe he may have been the guy who ran the mens relay race in the Olympics on a broken fibula.

title: A Freebie Too Far
description: Most tennis fans can only dream about receiving the kind of thick, cream-colored invitation that State Senator Tony Avella of Queens got recently in the mail. The United States Tennis Association was pleased to invite him and a guest to view this years tennis championships, which begin Aug. 27. They could sit in the Presidents Suite. They could pick one session of your choice during the first week. This is tennis at its best, viewed from the best seats in Arthur Ashe Stadium.

title: Risk Builds as Junk Bonds Boom
description: Money market funds pay next to nothing. Interest rates on United States Treasuries are dismal. The volatile stock market has been dead money for more than a decade.

title: Pink Pants, Trotters and an Entourage
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  Normally on the dark day here, Tom Durkin sleeps late and catches up on bills and errands. Its the only day off for the voice of New York racing when the Saratoga meet is in session, and Durkin cherishes his alone time and silence.

title: Muni Bonds Not as Safe as Thought
description: Municipal bonds, widely seen as one of the safest investments, actually default more often than most people realize, according to research issued Wednesday by economists at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: Egypts Islamist Leaders Accused of Stifling Media
description: CAIRO  Several recent moves by government authorities against Egyptian journalists have drawn sharp criticism from the news media and led to accusations that the countrys new Islamist president is willing to tolerate  if not employ  the same heavy-handed tactics used by former President Hosni Mubarak to stifle dissent.

title: Judge Urges Apple and Samsung to Settle Their Patent Dispute
description: The judge presiding over an intellectual property dispute between Apple and Samsung Electronics said on Wednesday that the chief executives of the two companies should talk again before the jury begins its deliberations.

title: The Women of Afghanistan
description: Afghanistan can be a hard and cruel land, especially for women and girls. Many fear they will be even more vulnerable to harsh tribal customs and the men who impose them after American troops withdraw by the end of 2014.

title: Amid the Beauty of Mountains, Oil Rigs Arrive
description: The divisions within the Blackfeet tribe over oil represent two visions of the land where members have lived for centuries.

title: Four Are Arrested in 2008 Robbery of an Armored-Car Guard, Including the Guard
description: When a man staged a brazen daylight robbery of an armored-car guard in Manhattan four years ago and made off with $330,000, the police immediately suspected an inside job.

title: Tapping Into the Land, and Dividing Its People
description: BLACKFEET INDIAN RESERVATION, Mont.  The mountains along the eastern edge of Glacier National Park rise from the prairie like dinosaur teeth, their silvery ridges and teardrop fields of snow forming the doorway to one of Americas most pristine places.

title: Keyed Up
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  In solving this Thursday puzzle from Ethan Cooper, I found that many of my hunches and first guesses just wouldnt fit. It started at 1 Across with Swiss , when I felt a compulsion to fill in cheese, particularly because it started with a ch. That would have been too many letters, though, and the right answer was the much healthier Swiss CHARD.

title: No Criminal Case Is Likely in Loss at MF Global
description: A criminal investigation into the collapse of the brokerage firm MF Global and the disappearance of about $1 billion in customer money is now heading into its final stage without charges expected against any top executives.

title: N.H.L. Commissioner Not Impressed With Unions Proposal
description: Commissioner Gary Bettman on Wednesday effectively dismissed the N.H.L. Players Association proposal for a new collective bargaining agreement, saying that union and management remained far apart with one month to go before the current agreement expires.

title: Pakistani Air Force Base With Nuclear Ties Is Attacked
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Suspected Islamist militants attacked a major Pakistani Air Force base where some of the countrys nuclear weapons are thought to be stored in the early hours of Thursday, setting off an exchange of fire that lasted several hours.

title: A Talk With Peter Hedges
description: Peter Hedges, the screenwriter and director of "The Odd Life of Timothy Green," discusses elements of his work.

title: Volunteers Rescue Livestock From Raging Wildfire in Washington State
description: The Kittitas County Fairgrounds in central Washington State was being prepared for the arrival of hundreds of horses for the annual 4-H Horse Show this weekend when it suddenly became a crisis center for livestock caught in a wildfire that has consumed more than 28,000 acres since Monday.

title: Dickey Gives Up Three Homers to Reds and Two Bracelets to Umpires
description: CINCINNATI  Baseball players attach significance to routine, find comfort in repetition. The Mets starters had their routines disrupted Wednesday  in more ways than one.

title: Moments of Terror, Without Sound
description: William Saint Eloi, a deaf community leader in Leveque, Haiti, shares his memories of the earthquake of 2010.

title: In Haiti, Uneven Revival From Earthquake Disaster
description: Hundreds of thousands remain without permanent housing in Haiti, two and a half years after an earthquake devastated the country.

title: Show and Tell for Teachers, Inspired by Reality TV
description: Great teaching, it is sometimes said, is one of those things where you know it when you see it. Now, teachers in Washington will be able to see a lot more of it.

title: ESPNFC Press Pass Debuts
description: ESPNs English-language global soccer show  ESPNFC Press Pass  debuted Wednesday in the United States and will be carried throughout the coming European season. The 30-minute show will be carried on the ESPNEWS channel six nights a week, Monday through Saturday at 2 a.m. Eastern (Sunday through Friday at 11 p.m. Pacific).

title: Years After Haiti Quake, Safe Housing Is a Dream for Many
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Since the earthquake of Jan. 12, 2010, a scrappy 12-year-old boy named Givenson Fanfan has been sleeping on the rock-hard floor of a tent pitched in a fetid camp dominated by a 50-foot tower of trash. He dreams of a bed.

title: Aug. 15: To Bounce, or Not to Bounce
description: Wednesday brought more data that measured Representative Paul D. Ryans impact on the horse race. There was a new set of polls in swing states from the firm Purple Strategies, and there was a weekly national tracking poll from YouGov.

title: Fort Hood Shooting Trial Delayed Pending Ruling on Beard
description: HOUSTON  The Army psychiatrist accused of killing 13 people in a 2009 shooting rampage at the Fort Hood Army base in Killeen, Tex., won a temporary delay of his trial on Wednesday, after a military appeals court halted the proceedings to allow it time to rule on whether the judge in his case can order him to be forcibly shaved.

title: Job Losses Persist for the Less-Educated
description: After suffering the largest share of job losses in the recession, Americans with no more than a high school education have continued to lose jobs during the sputtering recovery while better-educated people have gained millions of jobs, according to a Georgetown University study.

title: Georgetown University Study on College Education and Employment
description: Americans with no more than a high school education have continued to lose jobs after the recession, while better-educated people have added millions of jobs.

title: Soccer Enthusiasts Hope for a Stadium and a Pro Team in Queens
description: On many evenings in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, there are so many pickup soccer games being played on the worn fields that some matches spill over into the parking lots.

title: Choice of Paul Ryan Shifts the Focus From Economy to Ideology
description: DES MOINES  Four years ago, John Brooks cast his ballot for Barack Obama, becoming one of the voters won over by his promise for changing Washington. This time, he had been undecided, but he said Mitt Romney made his decision easier by placing Representative Paul D. Ryan on the Republican ticket.

title: Nellie Gray, Abortion Foe and Leader of Annual March, Dies at 88
description: Nellie Gray, a steadfast opponent of abortion who for almost 40 years led a yearly protest march in Washington that drew tens of thousands of supporters, and whose battle cry was No exception! No compromise!, was found dead on Monday at her home in Washington. She was 88.

title: Pennsylvania Judge Keeps Voter ID Law Intact on Its Way to Higher Court
description: A Pennsylvania judge on Wednesday declined to block a new state law requiring specific kinds of photo identification to vote. Liberal groups, arguing that minorities and the poor would be disproportionately deprived of the ballot, said they would appeal to the State Supreme Court to stop the law before the November elections.

title: Joan Roberts Dies at 95; Original Oklahoma! Star
description: Joan Roberts, who created the role of the winsome yeller-haired heroine, Laurey, in the original Broadway production of Oklahoma!, died on Monday in Stamford, Conn. She was 95.

title: Corrections: August 16, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Health Care Leads Campaign Dialogue in Midwest
description: DUBUQUE, Iowa  With Mitt Romney on the attack on Medicare, President Obama personally engaged in the fight on Wednesday as the popular public health program catapulted to the top of the presidential campaign agenda.

title: Jews Awarded Damages in California Hotel Case
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  A jury here put the total price tag for what it held to be an anti-Semitic episode at the Hotel Shangri-La at about $1.6 million on Thursday. The award includes about $1.2 million in compensatory damages and more than $400,000 in punitive damages.

title: Life, Interrupted: Putting a Positive Spin on Cancer
description: As a cancer patient, I think a lot about how we talk about illness  or more often, how we talk around it. Even the word cancer is ugly, scary, burdensome  a roadblock for a conversation before it even starts. Who wants to go there? Much of the time, Id rather not bring it up if I dont have to  and Im the one with the disease!

title: Word of the Day | cognizance
description: cognizance \kg-n-zn(t)s\ noun

title: Homes for $1.5 Million
description: Properties in Massachusetts, Wyoming and Texas.

title: What You Get for ... $1.5 Million
description: BARNSTABLE, MASS.

title: In Gibraltar, a Restored 19th-Century Cottage
description: A three-bedroom Colonial cottage dating to 1803 is on the market in the British overseas territory of Gibraltar for $2.1 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Gibraltar
description: A HISTORIC COLONIAL HOME ON A LARGE LANDSCAPED LOT IN GIBRALTAR

title: Garcia Is Latest Yankee to Thwart Texas
description: Freddy Garcia started Wednesdays game facing the unenviable task of following perhaps the best Yankees pitching performance of the season, and he had to wait an additional 105 minutes before he could even attempt to outshine it.

title: Sex Life of Teenagers Is Subject of Study
description: The popular notion that teenagers who are not ready for intercourse are experimenting with oral sex en masse is being challenged by new data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: How Bollywoods Views on Pakistan Evolved
description: If one looks at Indias national trajectory through the lens of the Hindi film industry, in hundred years of its existence, there will be one major gap: Indias troubled relationship with Pakistan was conveniently ignored by the industry for decades.

title: The Electoral Art of War
description: Attack your opponents strength: that has become the fundamental rule of modern politics.

title: East Asias Sea Disputes: Scar Tissue from War Wounds
description: HONG KONG  Its not easy keeping track of all the territorial disputes over rocky outcrops, barren mini-islands and submerged chunks of coral in East Asian waters. Each piece of land seems to have competing and passionate claims by any number of countries in the region, and each island group is called different names by the opposing claimants.

title: News Quiz | August 16, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Does Marriage Still Define the Life of Indian Women?
description: What does young India want? At the launch of his sixth book, on just this subject, the popular author Chetan Bhagat offered an inadvertently revealing comment: Naukri aur chokri  jobs and girls,  Nilanjana S. Roy wrote in The International Herald Tribune.

title: Militants Attack Pakistani Air Force Base
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  An attack early Thursday on a major Pakistani air force base where some of the countrys nuclear weapons are thought to be stored set off a heavy gun battle in which eight attackers and one security official were killed.

title: Indian Art Exhibition Makes a Rare Stop in China
description: It is said that two thousand years ago, two priests brought the first Buddhist scriptures from India to China on the back of a pure white horse, Clare Pennington wrote in The New York Times.

title: Test Yourself | English, Aug. 16, 2012
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the Q.&A. article Returning to Her Trail of Tears.

title: Floundering Foes Help Indian Lawmakers
description: There are times when the quality of the people who hate you is the most generous compliment you can receive, Manu Joseph wrote in The International Herald Tribune. The Indian National Congress, which heads the government in Delhi, is a beneficiary of its foes.

title: Whats In The Ryan Plan?
description: A number of commenters have asked for a summary of whats actually in the Ryan plan. So this is a utility post.

title: Artists Caught on a Cameras Canvas
description: Sometimes art imitates life, sometimes life imitates art. But something special happens when art imitates art imitating life. In the 1920s, with some spillover before and after, The New York Times made a convention of photographing artists with both their works of art and the people (or pets) depicted in those works.

title: Mitt Romney and Extreme Fiscal Policy
description: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt and Why It Matters to You.

title: From Sportsman to Politician
description: Does the former cricket superstar have what it takes to lead an angry and disillusioned nation?

title: Imran Khan Must Be Doing Something Right
description: On a cool evening in March, Imran Khan, followed by his dogs, walked around the extensive lawns of his estate, sniffling with an incipient cold. My ex-wife, Jemima, designed the house  it is really paradise for me, Khan said of the villa, which sprawls on a ridge overlooking Himalayan foothills and Pakistans capital, Islamabad. My greatest regret is that she is not here to enjoy it, he added, unexpectedly poignantly. We walked through the living room and then sat in his dimly lighted bedroom, the voices of servants echoing in the empty house, the mournful azans drifting up from multiple mosques in the city below.

title: In Syria, the Demands of Life Conflict With Those of War
description: WHEN did the Syrian conflict begin?

title: Rumors Lead People from Northeast to Flee Bangalore
description: Wild rumors of pending attacks led several thousand people to flee Bangalore on Wednesday night because of fears that violence in Indias northeastern region would somehow spread south.

title: At Last, the Maybach Is Priceless
description: The word Discontinued appeared next to the five bottommost items on a price sheet issued recently by Mercedes-Benz USA for its 2013 vehicles. It was a jarring coda to the jumble of dollar signs, commas and digits  many of them stretching to six figures  that preceded it.

title: Oakland Raiders, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
description: In professional sports, were always hearing about how its a new era (!) in such-and-such-a-city. Almost always, this is just a euphemistic way of saying that a team has been bad in recent years and is now hoping that a few personnel changes can fix things. But in the case of the 2012 Oakland Raiders, it really is a new era.

title: The Early Word: Overwhelmed
description: In Todays Times:

title: Ex-Aide to Cameron Appears in Court on Hacking Charges
description: LONDON  Andy Coulson, the former communications director for Prime Minister David Cameron and a onetime top editor in Rupert Murdochs British media outpost, appeared in court with six other people on Thursday to face charges in the long-running hacking scandal.

title: Slump And Circumstance
description: The New Statesman had a good idea  it went to 20 British economists who signed a letter back in early 2010 calling for immediate austerity and asked them whether they still supported the Osborne policies now that Britain is in double-dip recession. Only one of those who replied said yes, while nine urged Osborne to reconsider his opposition to stimulus.

title: When Looking for a Loan, You Cant Fight Gravity
description: Getting a loan for your business is not a simple proposition. There are many types of loans, and many criteria that go into evaluating how much you can borrow and what you can expect to pay. There are thousands of lenders to pick from, and each one may have a slightly different proposition to suggest.

title: How to Burn Dinner
description: Here is a simple, intense late-summer dinner you could cook on a pancake griddle set on the grate above a fire pit in someones backyard, as if performing a magic trick. The result is a plate of thick, luscious pork with a deep, burnished crust, redolent of garlic and rosemary, and a sunset of soft, smoky peaches nutty with brown butter. Those with powerful venting systems in their kitchens might try to cook the dish indoors, but the threat of the smoke alarm will loom. There is little poetry to that. For this recipe, endeavor to cook outside, under the sky.

title: For Gamers, a Headset That Helps Pinpoint Opponents
description: Astro Gaming has long designed premium headsets for video game aficionados, and its latest, the A50 wireless headset, updates it for fans.

title: Registering for Justice
description: Jason Goldberg and Christian Schoenherr are having their wedding Saturday evening at the acclaimed Manhattan restaurant Craft, where roughly 100 guests will dine on lobster, squab and hen-of-the-woods mushrooms, and the couple is registered at Sur La Table, for French cookware, German steak knives and such.

title: Ecuador Grants Asylum to Assange, Defying Britain
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Ecuador forcefully rejected pressure from Britain and announced Thursday that it was granting political asylum to Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, who has been holed up for two months in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London trying to avoid extradition to Sweden.

title: Q&A: Posting Flickr Picture Links to Twitter
description: Q.

title: Did Yelp and TripAdvisor Push Google to Compete?
description: Googles acquisition of Frommers travel guides this week offered a small glimpse into what its like for Web companies to live in Googles world.

title: Should Candidates Discuss Global Warming?
description: Ever since comprehensive legislation to reduce greenhouse gases died in Congress two years ago, my colleague John Broder noted here recently, climate change has been the issue that national politicians seem to avoid at all costs. Supporting renewable energy? Fine. Advocating energy independence? Great. Calling for action on global warming? Not so much.

title: Nakedness in Dance, Taken to Extremes
description: HOW do you react to the look of a naked body onstage? Thirty-four years ago, as part of a friends bachelor party, I went to a London strip club with a group of seven other men. We were all in our early 20s; most of them were distinctly upper-crust; some qualified as what the English call chinless wonders and Hooray Henrys.

title: Romneys Message Moves Beyond Jobs
description: For most of the last year, Mitt Romney has stuck to one basic message: President Obama has botched the economy.

title: Opinion Report: Freebies
description: From the editorial page

title: Thursday Reading: Seizing the Last Days of Summer
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Seoul Judge Surprises Tycoon With Prison Term
description: SEOUL  A Seoul court on Thursday sentenced the head of the South Korean conglomerate Hanwha to four years in prison for embezzlement and made a rare decision to have the businessman dispatched directly to prison from the courtroom.

title: Europeans Skeptical of Israeli War Talk
description: LONDON  The war talk in Israel, where authorities have been handing out gas masks in anticipation of a possible imminent conflict with Iran, has been met with a degree of skepticism in Europe.

title: A Clerk With a Heart
description: Dear Diary:

title: Four Rays Form Perfect Game Club
description: The saying goes that you should do one thing and do it better than anyone else. Unfortunately for the Tampa Bay Rays, what the team does best is suffer through perfect games.

title: Daily Report: Cisco, a Tech Bellwether, Beats Forecasts
description: Cisco Systems, the worlds largest maker of computer networking equipment, delivered quarterly results on Wednesday that slightly surpassed Wall Streets expectations, and investors are responding positively on Thursday.

title: Does Your College Treat You Like a Child?
description: After a recent post on Jodhpurs emergence as an education hub, India Ink received comments describing unreasonable restrictions on college campuses. We scoured the Internet and found many rules in college dormitories, known as hostels in India, that imposed curfews and bans on certain activities even though most of the students are adults. Moreover, the rules for women were often more restrictive. Heres a selection:

title: Great Dane
description: On a muggy May afternoon, the Danish actor Mads Mikkelsen stopped in Midtown Manhattan to meet me for a beer and a cheeseburger  a brief pause in the middle of a hectic bout of international zigzagging. He had just been in Bucharest and was en route to Cannes, where he would receive the best-actor award for his performance in Thomas Vinterbergs The Hunt, in which he plays a kindergarten teacher menaced by small-town paranoia after he is accused of sexual abuse.

title: Best Buy Founder Nudges Companys Board to Consider Takeover
description: The founder of Best Buy, Richard M. Schulze, pressed his case on Thursday for a takeover of the electronics retailer, again trying to prod the company into considering his offer.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. (1), Mexico (0)
description: Twenty years from now  50 years from now  nobody will remember that the United States national teams first victory over Mexico in Mexico was not a particularly well-played match.

title: Andrew Upton to Become Sole Artistic Director of Sydney Theater Company
description: When Andrew Upton and Cate Blanchett, the husband-and-wife team that has served as the co-artistic directors of the Sydney Theater Company since 2008, complete their current and final term there, a familiar successor will be waiting in the wings: Mr. Upton will become the artistic director of that theater company, its chairman, David Gonski, said in a statement on Wednesday.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Asylum for Assange, and Jay-Zs Stamp on the Nets
description: The WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange on Thursday was granted political asylum by Ecuador, whose embassy in London is currently shielding him. Outside the embassy, the scene has become more chaotic with scuffles between the police and supporters of Mr. Assange. Hanging over the Ecuadorean decision is the possibility that the British government could revoke the diplomatic immunity of the embassy and seize Mr. Assange to extradite him to Sweden, William Neuman and Maggy Ayala report, where he is wanted for questioning over allegations that he sexually assaulted two women. Ecuadors foreign minister, Ricardo Patio, didnt take kindly to the suggestion that the British might move in: We are not a British colony. In his statement on Thursday, The Guardian reported, he said: We trust the U.K. will offer the necessary guarantees so that both governments can act adequately and properly respect international rights and the right of asylum.

title: When Will We Address the Needs in High-Needs Schools?
A Flawed Star and a Perfect Game
description: Baseballs news came in such quick succession, and carrying such different messages, that it was as if Commissioner Bud Selig had picked up the red phone and dialed the baseball gods. The San Francisco Giants Melky Cabrera had just been suspended for 50 games for performance-enhancing drug use, dredging up all of baseballs worst steroid era memories, and Selig needed something quick. How about a perfect game by Seattles Felix Hernandez, the gods offered back? Would that do?

title: What Were Reading
description: Fast Company: The Silicon Valley venture capital crowd seems to be getting all excited about lab-grown meat.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Asian Identity and the Global Economy
description: Last month I finished writing Plutocrats, a book on the rise of the global super-elite and the forces that created it, so I am somewhat obsessed with globalization, bankers and the like. Thats why those themes in a new indie movie, Supercapitalist, resonated most strongly for me.

title: Velvet Revolution | Liya Kebede
description: With storm clouds gathering, something witchy this way comes. Liya Kebede brings the seasons darkly romantic evening fabrics into the light of day.  More

title: China Urges Japan to Release Protesters Caught on Disputed Island
description: TOKYO  China pressed Japan on Thursday to release 14 Chinese citizens arrested after some of them arrived on an island claimed by both countries, amid signs that Tokyo may soon deport them without pressing charges to avert a larger standoff.

title: The Night the E.R. Staff Can Never Forget
description: AURORA, Colo.  More than three weeks have passed, but Daryl Johnson still begins his emergency room shift at the University of Colorado Hospital here with a sense of foreboding.

title: Paul Ryan and the Art of the Possible
description: In my Campaign Stops column this week, I make the point that you have to look at Paul Ryans record over the last few years in the context of where his party stood after the 2008 election  moribund, deluded, and potentially self-destructive  and recognize 1) how much hes done to move the Republicans in a more constructive direction and 2) that many of the problems with his famous/infamous House budgets reflect his partys continuing deficiencies rather than his own. The absence of a replacement for Obamacare in the budget, for instance, doesnt mean that Ryan hasnt come out for such a replacement. (He has.) Likewise with the absence of Social Security reform and the implausible cuts to discretionary spending that this absence entails: Ryans original Roadmap deals with Social Security in a more serious and plausible way; he just hasnt been able to get all of his House colleagues onside.

title: Sales at Wal-Mart, Though Still Rising, Suggest Wary Shoppers
description: Consumers in the United States still seem to be holding their breath.

title: Business Day Live | August 16, 2012
description: MF Global investigation could end without criminal charges. | Paul Ryans budget and the economy. | Jay-Z rewrites investor playbook with Nets arena in Brooklyn.

title: Michael J. Fox May Return to TV
description: 11:13 a.m. | Updated Michael J. Fox, who starred on the sitcom Spin City in the 1990s but stepped aside in 2000 as the symptoms of his Parkinsons disease worsened,may return to network television next year.

title: Facebook Shares Hit New Low as a Lockup Period Ends
description: The Facebook slide on Wall Street continued on Friday, as the companys shares reached new lows a day after early investors became eligible to sell their shares on the market. Shares closed down more than 4 percent, to $19.05, after reaching a low of $19.00 during the day  50 percent lower than its original offering price of $38 in May.

title: Another Change at News Corp. as TV Executive Steps Down
description: In the latest change at News Corporation before the company splits off its publishing businesses from its entertainment assets, David Haslingden, a long-time television executive who ran the Fox Networks Group is stepping down.

title: On View | Architectones & Richard Neutra
description: The Paris-based artist Xavier Veilhan has created a site-specific installation that sparks a dialogue between the architecture and the history of Richard Neutras house.

title: An Ode to Youth, Forever Fleeting
description: IN late May, a week after she graduated from Yale University, 22-year-old Marina Keegan headed to her familys summer cottage on Cape Cod to begin revisions of Independents, a musical whose book she had written the summer before. The plan was for her to be joined there by the shows director, lyricist and composer, but she never made it; the car in which she was riding crashed, killing her.

title: What Does Your Fridge Door Say About Your Family?
description: Want to spend some time thinking about who your family is, and how the way you live reflects the way you really want to live, as opposed to the life that youve settled into, somehow, without much thought?

title: On Our Radar: Appalachian Coal for India
description: The Booth Energy Group and the River Trading Company announce a $7 billion deal that could send nine million tons of coal a year to India from West Virginia and Kentucky. Such exports are rising as American demand for coal falls, as electric utilities burn more cheap natural gas. [The Associated Press]

description: A clip from "Ben-Hur."

title: Finding George Orwell in Venezuela
description: MONTREAL  In 2005, Venezuela became an official Territory Free of Illiteracy. A massively funded government literacy drive achieved, in just over a year, what decades of neoliberal neglect had failed to deliver: a country where every single person knows how to read.

title: Image of the Day: August 16
11 Are Killed as U.S. Copter Goes Down in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Seven American soldiers and three Afghan soldiers and an interpreter were killed after daybreak on Thursday when their Black Hawk helicopter crashed in Kandahar Province in southern Afghanistan, the American-led military command here said.

title: The Disunion of Myanmar
description: MAUNGDAW, Myanmar  At the sight of several Rohingyas collecting firewood and bringing cattle to pasture, the driver who was taking me to Maungdaw, a small town near Myanmars border with Bangladesh, screamed out that they should all be kicked out of the country or the recent bout of sectarian violence opposing them to the Rakhines would never end.

title: How Much Can Patients Learn in a 15-Minute Doctor Visit?
description: Built more like a former professional basketball player than an elementary schoolteacher nearing retirement, the patient dropped a bagful of prescription medications on the table in the examining room and fell back into a chair. He couldnt remember what most of them were for.

title: Business Day Live: Jay-Z Rewrites Celebrity Investors Playbook
description: MF Global investigation could end without criminal charges. | Paul Ryans budget and the economy. | Jay-Z rewrites investor playbook with Nets arena in Brooklyn.

title: At Monterey, Auctioning Duesenbergs and Packards for a Greater Good
description: A dozen classic cars will do more than find new owners this weekend at the Gooding & Company auction on the Monterey Peninsula. Their sale will help provide free medical care to children.

title: Two Deputies Are Shot and Killed in a Louisiana Ambush
description: LAPLACE, La.  Two sheriffs deputies were shot and killed early Thursday morning and two others were wounded in ambushes at a parking lot and a trailer park in this town about 25 miles up the Mississippi River from New Orleans.

title: Marketer of Student Debit Cards Settles Charges of Improper Fees
description: Higher One, a big marketer of student debit cards, agreed to repay $11 million to 60,000 students to settle allegations that it had charged excessive fees to students who overdrew their accounts, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said.

title: Justice Dept. Approves, With Changes, Verizon Wireless Spectrum Purchase
description: The United States Justice Department approved a deal struck by Verizon Wireless to purchase spectrum from the countrys largest cable operators, but officials also required that the agreement be altered to protect against higher prices for consumers.

title: The Get | Smythsons Currency Case
description: Back in the 1950s, Katherine Hepburn wouldnt board a plane without her Smythson address book. In its pages, Hepburn logged meetings with friends like Laurence Olivier, Frank Sinatra and Vivien Leigh. On its cover, shed stamped her initials K.H. and three places she frequented  London, California and New York  initiating a new way to personalize paper goods. (For memorabilia buffs, Hepburns book is currently on display in Smythsons in-store museum at 4 West 57th Street.) Now, in honor of Hepburns brilliant idea, the London stationer is offering four-zipper currency cases embossed with Fashion Weeks four biggest cities  New York, London, Milan and Paris  and available with the option of monogramming, too. An update on the companys original 1966 currency case, these new ones come in violet, olive and classic brown crocodile.

title: The Cinematic Chase
description: With the release of the bike messenger chase film Premium Rush, a look back at movie chase scenes.

title: Instagram Refreshes App by Including Photo Maps
description: Instagram may be waiting for its billion-dollar sale to Facebook to be finalized, but the company is not resting on its laurels. The company, working out of offices in San Francisco, continues to crank out updates to its popular photo-sharing application.

title: In Fuel Cells, Some Hope for Urban Sanitation
description: As more and more people around the world flock to cities, urban areas in developing nations are struggling to keep up with the human influx and the waste that people produce. In 2010 roughly 2.5 billion people lacked basic sanitation, according to the World Health Organization.

title: Who Owns That House?
Feverishly Pursuing a Nondigital Chase
description: IT took a lot of nerve for the director David Koepp to include a chase under an elevated New York City train in Premium Rush, about a bike messengers frantic race to deliver a package from one end of Manhattan to the other.

title: Update: Whither Eleanors Album?
description: A few weeks ago, we published a piece about a modest yet fascinating photo album that had found its way to the displays of the University of New Mexico Art Museum. Random Shots Compiled for the Edification of Eleanor T. Wragg read its first page  it was a Christmas gift from 1915, made up of 25 photos. Its pictures varied from quiet silhouettes and commonplace scenes to divers, airplanes and Gov. Jim Ferguson at the Cotton Palace Parade in Waco, Tex.

title: 5 Critics Who Deserve a Statue
description: In Sundays Riff, Dwight Garner, a literary critic for The New York Times, makes the case for critics who are actually critical. Critics take a beating, especially in popular culture, Garner writes. Jean Sibeliuss observation  No statue has ever been erected to a critic  seems to be cited somewhere weekly. As well-known quotations go, this one strikes me as especially banal. It implies something disheartening about our culture. . . . That Brooklyn lacks an Alfred Kazin statue is almost enough to make a bookish type want to move to Oxford, England  or at least to Oxford, Miss.

title: Those Julia Child Treasures
description: We asked for your favorite Julia Child recipes  the recipes that, unlike her storied boeuf bourguignon, are part of everyday kitchen life  and lo and behold, you more than delivered. The following is a list, selected from over 200 comments, that highlight your most treasured Child standbys. They also demonstrate that the lessons she taught us about food and cooking continue to resonate. (See all the suggested recipes, and add to the list, here.)

title: Ira Glass: By the Book
description: The host of This American Life and co-writer of the coming film Sleepwalk With Me would like to meet Edgar Allan Poe. I dont have a question, but dude just seems like he could use a hug.

title: Whats Your Favorite Movie Chase Scene?
description: For the coming film Premium Rush, about a bike messenger racing against time, a corrupt cop and a teeming city, David Koepp decided to include a chase under an elevated New York subway line even though he knew it would invite comparison with one of the greatest chase scenes of all time, the one in The French Connection with Gene Hackman in a car going after a bad guy in a train on the tracks overhead. As Mr. Koepp explained in this article about the difficulties of getting a pursuit right: Shooting a chase scene in New York City, youre standing on the shoulders of that giant. I almost didnt do it, but I love the trestles.

title: A Song Tries to Go Beyond the OMG Reaction to GMOs
description: [2:26 p.m. | Update | Ill be adding various interesting reviews at the bottom of the post, starting with Stewart Brand, the author of Whole Earth Discipline.]

title: Director Plans Pinter With a Twist, as Actresses Trade Off Old Times Roles
description: Most actors have enough layers to explore with just one character in Old Times, an enigmatic 1971 play about identity and fractured memories by Harold Pinter, the Nobel Prize winner best known for psychological chillers like the The Homecoming and The Caretaker. But the theater director Ian Rickson has thrown down a challenge to leading ladies Kristin Scott Thomas and Lia Williams for an coming London revival of Old Times  they will alternate in the female roles of Kate and Anna, old friends who have not seen each other in 20 years.

title: Lincolns Panama Plan
description: On Aug. 14 1862, Abraham Lincoln hosted a Deputation of Free Negroes at the White House, led by the Rev. Joseph Mitchell, commissioner of emigration for the Interior Department. It was the first time African Americans had been invited to the White House on a policy matter. The five men were there to discuss a scheme that even a contemporary described as a simply absurd piece of charlatanism: resettling emancipated slaves on a 10,000-acre parcel of land in present-day Panama.

title: Wave of Attacks Kills Dozens in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  A wave of attacks across Iraq killed more than 100 people on Thursday, including dozens of women and children at an amusement park, security and medical officials said.

title: At Camden Yards, Home Team Is Again a Draw for Fans
description: BALTIMORE  The Hampton Inn on Washington Boulevard here is just a pop fly from Camden Yards. There is even a couch shaped like a baseball glove at the entrance.

title: Another Pop Group Tells Romney to Stop Using Its Song
description: Silversun Pickups have demanded that the Romney campaign stop using the bands song Panic Switch at political rallies. It is the latest pop group to object to the use of a song at Republican events.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Compliance'
description: Craig Zobel, the writer and director of "Compliance," narrates a scene from his film.

title: Romney Says Ive Paid at Least 13% in Taxes in Past Decade
description: 10:22 p.m. | Updated  The revised version of this post is available here.

title: Few Voters Are Truly Up for Grabs, Research Suggests
description: WASHINGTON  Curtis Napier, a 52-year-old father of two in Lima, Ohio, belongs to a much-discussed group of Americans that is far smaller than is often realized: He is a true swing voter.

title: Hot Dodgers Move Into First Place
description: There is a team rolling in Southern California right now, and its not the Angels or Padres. The Dodgers are playing winning ball, and have moved into sole possession of first place, for the first time since July 13, in the National League West.

title: An App to Transport Ride-Sharing to the Road
description: Users of Ridejoy, the online ride-sharing service, can now take it on the road. The company released an iPhone app today to complement its Web site, which, like a motor version of CouchSurfing, matches travelers who need rides with drivers who have space in their cars.

title: Videos of Top Teachers Explaining Their Craft
description: Teachers are human, after all, and they dont like to be bored any more than the rest of us.

title: Square Offers Flat-Rate Plan for Small Businesses
description: Not long after Square made waves by announcing a partnership with Starbucks, the company is offering a deal to companies at the smaller end of the spectrum.

title: The Slightly Surprising Sex Lives of Teenagers
description: New numbers show fewer teenagers than you might expect report having oral sex before vaginal sex. The myth of teenagers experimenting with oral sex, and not really considering it sex, has been around for a while, but this new data, from the Centers for Disease Control and Preventions National Survey of Family Growth and reported in The Timess Health section, shows that teenagers themselves tell researchers something different.

title: As Diplomatic Efforts Stall in Syria, U.N. Says It Will End Its Observer Mission
description: The United Nations Security Council decided on Thursday to terminate the United Nations observer mission in Syria, where the increasingly violent rebellion against President Bashar al-Assads government has left diplomatic peacemaking efforts paralyzed. But the Security Council agreed to keep a much smaller United Nations office in the country, holding out hope that a political solution was still possible.

title: Tsunami Debris Strains Budgets and Patience
description: The steady increase in marine debris arriving on Pacific shorelines as a result of the March 2011 tsunami in Japan is starting to tax state budgets as well as deepen concerns over invasive species.

title: Mary McCann Nabs Plum Role in Harper Regan
description: The coming Off Broadway premiere of Harper Regan, a critically acclaimed British play about family alienation and the limits of loyalty, will star Mary McCann as the title character, one of the richest female roles on tap in New York theater this fall.

title: Seeking Real Diversity in New Schools
Return of the Swift Boat
description: In March, Karl Rove wrote an Op-Ed for the Wall Street Journal in which he belittled the presidents decision to order the raid on Osama bin Laden. Mr. Obama did what virtually any commander in chief would have done in the same situation, Mr. Rove argued. For this to be portrayed as the epic achievement of the first term tells you how bare the White House cupboards are.

title: HBO Orders Comedy Series Family Tree From Christopher Guest
description: Has Christopher Guest finally found that rarest of packages to satisfy the implacable Mort Guffman? As Corky St. Clair might put it, a beautifully wrapped, glossy, sweet-smelling show? At the very least, Mr. Guest, a writer, director and star of comedies like This Is Spinal Tap, Waiting for Guffman and A Mighty Wind, has hit upon a project that will bring him back to series television.

title: Garden of Notes by Author of Animal Farm
description: My favorite biographical detail about George Orwell might be that, when he died from tuberculosis in 1950 at the age of 46, his favorite fishing poles were standing in the corner of his London hospital room. He hoped hed be using them again, and soon.

title: The Daily Shoe | Givenchy
description: Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the Bergdorf Goodman shoe salon in honor of the stores 111th anniversary. Todays pick: an equestrian-inspired, leg-lengthening boot from Givenchy. $1,695.

title: Ideas for English Language Learners | Recipes, Travel, Idioms and More
description: This summer weve started a new monthly feature on The Learning Network called Ideas for E.L.L.s.

title: Postcards in an Artists Journey
description: BRUNSWICK, Me.  Maine has loomed large in the work of numerous American painters, from Marsden Hartley, John Marin and Edward Hopper to Andrew Wyeth, Alex Katz and Lois Dodd. But William Wegman is probably the only Conceptual artist  if an erstwhile one  to have fallen hard for the state, as evidenced by William Wegman: Hello Nature, a beguiling exhibition at the Bowdoin College Museum of Art here.

title: Keeping Score: A Solution to the Strasburg Puzzle
description: WASHINGTON  Stephen Strasburg is on his way to becoming the subject of the most debated absence in baseball since Sandy Koufax missed Game 1 of the 1965 World Series because of Yom Kippur.

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 16
description: A look at the day in sports, including Kobe Bryant drawing crowds in China and the ceremonial opening of the Little League World Series in Pennsylvania.

title: The Soccer Chronicles: The Gold Standard
description: Heather OReilly, a midfielder on the United States womens soccer team and a two-time gold medalist, will be writing regularly for the 2012 London Olympics blog. This is her sixth post.

title: Company Denies Role in Recently Uncovered Spyware
description: 6:35 p.m. | Updated  Adding discovery of latest sample of the spyware at end.

title: The Daily Shoe | Givenchy
description: Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the Bergdorf Goodman shoe salon. Today's pick: an equestrian-inspired, leg-lengthening boot from Givenchy. $1,695.

title: More Older Adults With Multiple Problems
description: I do look for good news, for promising trends for our elders and ourselves, honest. Whenever I can, I report on things like the potential health benefits of caregiving.

title: Russia Assigns Bodyguards to Judge Ahead of Verdict in Pussy Riot Trial
description: MOSCOW  Russian authorities announced on Thursday that bodyguards have been assigned to protect the judge presiding over the trial of three members of the all-female protest band Pussy Riot, after unspecified threats. The authorities did not describe the threats to the judge, Marina Syrova, who is expected to announce a verdict and possible jail terms for the women on Friday.

title: Founder of Digital Music Company Is Ousted, and Theories Abound
description: 2:40 p.m. | Updated In a surprise change that could have consequences for thousands of independent recording artists, the founder of TuneCore, a digital music distribution company, has been fired by the companys board.

title: Study of Judges Finds Evidence From Brain Scans Led to Lighter Sentences
description: Judges who learned that a convicted assailant was genetically predisposed to violence imposed lighter sentences in a hypothetical case than they otherwise would have, researchers reported on Thursday, in the most rigorous study to date of how behavioral biology can sway judicial decisions.

title: Braintree, a Payments Company, Buys Venmo for $26.2 Million
description: The mobile payments war continues to escalate.

title: TimesCast Politics | August 16, 2012
description: A new strategy from the Romney campaign. | Glimmers of hope in Florida. | The Connecticut Senate race. | Jill Abramson on the electoral landscape. | The Op-Ed columnist Joe Nocera on Paul Ryan.

title: Police Video on Handcuffed Mans Death Does Little to Calm Doubts
description: The police in Jonesboro, Ark., have released a video that they say shows how a 21-year old man, Chavis Carter, could have been able to shoot himself in the head while handcuffed in the back seat of a patrol car. But the video appeared to do little to calm the skepticism that continues to swell on social media networks after Mr. Carter was fatally shot on July 29.

title: TimesCast Politics: Romneys Strategic Shift
description: Eric Thayer for The New York Times

title: Ryan Pushes Working-Class Message in Ohio
description: NORTH CANTON, Ohio  To welcome Representative Paul D. Ryan to Walsh University, his name and that of his running mate were in lights on the basketball scoreboard: Romney, 11, Ryan, 6.

title: The Obamas First Kiss, Immortalized
description: President Obama has often told the story of how he met his wife, Michelle, in Chicago when they worked at the same law firm. Now, fans of the first couple can visit the spot where they shared their first kiss.

title: Former College Football Coach Accused of Running a Ponzi Scheme
description: Federal regulators have accused a Hall of Fame college football coach of running a Ponzi scheme that defrauded fellow coaches and his former players.

title: Q & A: Amanda Cohen of Dirt Candy
description: Just as Amanda Cohens four-year-old East Village restaurant, Dirt Candy, shrugs off the conventions of the typical vegetarian restaurant, so does her cookbook, which will be released on Tuesday and which takes the form of a graphic novel.

title: In Lebanon, Sunnis Threaten Shiites as Kidnappings of Syrians Rise
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Sectarian tensions escalated across Lebanon on Thursday as Sunnis in border towns threatened Shiites after several Shiite families who had already abducted more than 30 Syrians added several more to their hostage total.

title: Making Art Out of Novembers Election
description: If you walked into almost any contemporary art museum in the country at the moment, you would have a hard time telling that a bitterly fought presidential election was entering its final months. And while its not exactly the job of such museums to be vigilantly topical, the New York artist Jonathan Horowitz thinks that contemporary art should be more engaged with the issues being raised by the election.

title: Wheelies: The Federal Speed Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Fleur Show
description: T asked the Paris-based creative director of Dior fine jewelry, Victoire de Castellane, to redesign the magazines signature initial for the fall womens issue knowing shed create something wild and completely wonderful. Translating her elaborate three-dimensional jewels into a flat, two-dimensional illustration for our magazine was no easy task. To do so de Castellane looked to her home city, Paris, for inspiration. I very much like to stroll around le jardin des Bagatelles, in particular the iris garden, she explains. Below, de Castellane talks about the T thats anything but your average garden variety.

title: The Toucan and the Lion
description: Inside the Asian gastro pub in the East Village, where Southeast Asian flavors make gleeful riot.

title: Video Shows South African Police Shooting Miners
description: As our colleague Lydia Polgreen reports, at least 18 striking miners were shot dead on Thursday by South African police officers who opened fire as a crowd approached carrying machetes and sticks at a Lonmin platinum mine in Marikana.

title: Mine Strike Mayhem Stuns South Africa as Police Open Fire
description: MARIKANA, South Africa  The police fired on machete-wielding workers engaged in a wildcat strike at a platinum mine here on Thursday, leaving a field strewed with bodies and a deepening fault line between the governing African National Congress and a nation that, 18 years after the end of apartheid, is increasingly impatient with deep poverty, rampant unemployment and yawning inequality.

title: Bookstores for Gazers
description: Especially in the summer, when the sidewalks of the New York art world turn into barren, windswept places, I spend a lot of time visiting what I like to think of as a parallel art world, one that seems almost clandestine.

title: Drop In, and by Appointment
description: PRINTED MATTER The grande dame of New York artist-book stores. Perpetually packed to the gills with stuff. It functions like a vast net for what seems to be every publication, great or small, being cranked out by artists. 195 10th Avenue, between 21st and 22nd Streets, Chelsea; (212) 925-0325, printedmatter.org.

title: The Mediterranean On an Asian Plate
description: PEANUT BUTTER and cheese is a midnight blunder, a case of misguided nostalgia for the orange sandwich crackers in your Super Friends lunchbox. But at the Toucan and the Lion in the East Village, it makes for the most exciting dish on the menu.

title: Lottery Lout
description: Pity poor Lionel Asbo, a thug burdened by a vestigial conscience, his every ignoble thought and gesture determined by his maker, Martin Amis, a man not given to mercy. The antihero of Amiss new novel, Lionel Asbo: State of England, Lionel takes the kind of drubbing only satire can sustain. The youngest of the seven mostly criminal and largely dysfunctional children his mother bore by the age of 19, Lionel works at the very hairiest end of debt collection. Like his literary progenitor, the jet-setting John Self of Amiss 1984 novel, Money: A Suicide Note, Lionel is in hot  desperate, tormented and doomed  pursuit of whatever gratifications might be wrung from the free fall and decline of contemporary society.

title: Indianapolis Museum of Art Names New Director
description: The Indianapolis Museum of Art has chosen a new director, the museums board announced Wednesday.

title: After MF Global, a Need to Find New Ways to Protect Customers
description: The MF Global story still lingers as an insolvency matter, but now we hear rumblings that there will be no criminal charges. It may well be that no crimes were committed, but if this is so, it is time to seriously rethink how broker-dealers handle customer property.

title: Getting Rental Car Coverage for Luxury Vehicles
description: Bucks recently reported on the differences in rental car insurance that consumers get, depending on which credit card they use to pay for the rental. The report noted that for basic coverage, available to cardholders at no charge, the major card networks generally exclude luxury vehicles and that American Express also excludes some popular sport utility vehicles.

title: At Conventions, Strip Clubs Are Eager for Business
description: The convention organizers say no, no, no. But the gentlemens clubs of Tampa, Fla., and Charlotte, N.C., are saying yes, yes, yes.

title: Sole Sisters
description: Cole Haans recent collaborations  with the musician Theophilus London on a pair of blue suede bucks and with the recording artist and designer Hiroshi Fujiwara on neon-accented wingtips  have offered men of style a new view of the venerable footwear brand. This fall, the company is giving its womens line a similar treatment. For the first limited-edition womens collaboration, Olivia Kim, Opening Ceremonys vice president of creative, and her pal Jen Brill, a brand ambassador for Chanel and creative consultant, have created a collection of shoes that can be worn from day to night. Being able to run around the city comfortably and still look cute is always a challenge, Brill says. That was the starting point of the design process. Both women grew up wearing Cole Haan shoes, and for inspiration they turned to looks from the companys archive, like a leather fisherman sandal from the mid-1990s and a 1970s clog. The twist? We wanted to use colors that were different from what you may expect traditionally from Cole Haan, Kim says of their collections three styles: a strappy sandal ($528), an ankle-strap pump ($528) and an ankle boot ($548), all rendered in jewel-toned Italian suede. We personally love rich, saturated colors, added Kim, whose hair is sometimes frosted pink. (Brills signature is red lips.) The Chelsea collection will be available Sept. 10 at the Cole Haan SoHo store (128 Prince Street; 212-219-8240). Kim and Brill, meanwhile, are hard at work on their holiday line; they say to expect metallic pastels and plenty of flash.

title: 36 Hours in Johannesburg
description: TOURISTS who bypass Johannesburg and head straight to Cape Town or out on safari are missing one of Africas most thrilling metropolises. This former gold-rush town suffered in the aftermath of apartheid, but the revitalization that came with South Africas hosting of the soccer World Cup in 2010 has blossomed. With a major face-lift of the citys infrastructure  including the two-year-old mass transit rail system, the Gautrain, which was completed in June  Johannesburg is showing off its virtues and overcoming its vices. Although crime in some precincts remains stubbornly high and a bit of caution is recommended, downtown Johannesburg is in the midst of a revival. Nowadays, young Johannesburgers from different backgrounds are working together to remake their city for the next generation, tapping into a wellspring of creative energy and entrepreneurial spirit. Parts of Johannesburgs once-decrepit inner city have turned into a vital gathering place, including an old parking garage that now houses a food and fashion market, and a one-time alcohol warehouse that is today stocked with galleries and restaurants. New enticements seem to pop up every few months in this fast-changing dynamo of a city.

title: Views of Johannesburg
description: Hopeful tours, colorful dining and a lively art scene converge in the South African city.

title: Citys Unemployment Rate Remains at 10 Percent
description: New York Citys unemployment rate remained as high last month as it ever was during the long recession that officially ended more than three years ago: 10 percent.

title: An Intellect Highly Developed, but Not Superman
description: WATER MILL, N.Y.  Mike Kelley, the celebrated Los Angeles artist who took his own life at 57 this year, was a hero to many. But partly because he so determinedly defied traditional laws of stylistic consistency and coherence, the number of people who fully grasped what he was about is probably small.

title: Serious Artists Plan Whimsy in the Sand
description: THERES a sand castle competition happening on Friday at Rockaway Beach in Queens, but dont expect the typical driftwood drawbridges and sand-bucket cupolas.

title: A Filmmakers Impressions of the Bayou
description: BENH ZEITLIN, 29, wanted to make a film about holdouts  people in Louisianas bayou country who refused to evacuate from their homes during Hurricanes Katrina, Gustav and Ike.

title: Her Stories
description: Queens Museum of Art, New York City Building

title: New York Film Festival Unveils Main Slate Selections
description: New works by Noah Baumbach, Brian De Palma, Michael Haneke, Sally Potter and Alan Berliner are among the 32 features that will be presented in the main slate of the New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Thursday. Mr. Hanekes film Amour, which won the Palme dOr at the Cannes Film Festival, will make its New York debut. The festival will also present the world premiere of Mr. Berliners documentary First Cousin Once Removed, about the poet Edwin Honigs slowly succumbing to Alzheimers disease. Mr. Baumbach will be represented at the festival by Frances Ha, a comedy written with the actress Greta Gerwig and starring Ms. Gerwig as a young woman trying to start a dance career in New York.

title: Dtournement
description: Jonathan LeVine

title: Alex Gingrow
description: Mike Weiss

title: South African Police Open Fire on Striking Miners
description: South African riot police officers opened fire on striking miners armed with machetes and sticks at Lonmins Marikana platinum mine, killing at least 30 people.

title: Its Always Summer on the Inside
description: Anton Kern Gallery

title: Darpa to the People: You Think It Up, We Make Sure It Shoots
description: Most of us know what the term crowdsourcing means. Its been around for more than five years now, and its been used to tackle big, complex tasks ranging from finding many people (after natural disasters) to finding one (after a plane crash). Its been used for everyday problems like traffic and to answer scientific research questions. Crowdsourcing has even been used to make things, from books to videos.

title: Pakistani Taliban Kill 22 Shiites in Bus Attack
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistani Taliban militants pulled 22 Shiites off buses and gunned them down in a remote northern mountain pass on Thursday, in the latest iteration of a pattern of attacks targeting religious minorities.

title: CBGB Joins Efforts to Support Russian Punk Band
description: The promoters of the CBGB music festival in New York say they plan to sell special T-shirts and other merchandise online to raise money for the jailed members of the Russian punk rock band Pussy Riot, who face a prison term for singing a protest song in a church. On Friday in Moscow a judge declared them guilty of hooliganism.

title: Behind the Robots in Robot & Frank
description: Images and sketches of the robots in the film, with commentary from its director Jake Schrier.

title: Samurai Shopper | Dream Creams
description: The Samurai recently went to see the newish movie The Queen of Versailles, a documentary about people with beer tastes and Champagne pocketbooks. But for the Samurai Shopper, thats backward; my luxurious taste is often adulterated by a Pabst Blue Ribbon budget. Through the tricky economic stratagem of robbing Peter to pay Paul, I can occasionally spring for super-expensive skin care products that lighten, brighten and tighten. Why would I do this? Superman had kryptonite; I have Cle de Peaus La Creme ($775 for 1.7 ounces).

title: Hammer Museum Awards Its Crowdsourced Art Prize
description: The people have spoken, and the winner is: Meleko Mokgosi.

title: An Artistic Relationship Set in Stoneware
description: Frans and Marguerite Wildenhain, ceramists who trained at the Bauhaus, were torn from each other during World War II.

title: For Europes Economy, a Lost Decade Looms
description: FRANKFURT  The euro zone is hurtling back into recession, economists declared after official figures this week portrayed a shrinking economy. But by some measures the downturn has been under way for years.

title: 12 Great American Wines, $20 or Less
description: From New Yorks North Fork to the California coast, 12 wine selections $20 and under that are worth investigating, listed in no particular order.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Twitter Founders Trifecta and Thoughts on the iPad Mini
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: 3 Are Injured When Horse Sheds Coach in Manhattan
description: A spooked carriage horse burst out of line near Central Park on Thursday, thundered into the busy traffic on Columbus Circle, dumped his driver and two passengers, struck two cars, shed the wreckage of his carriage and ran free for four blocks before being captured on Ninth Avenue, the authorities and witnesses said.

title: Bargains From American Vines
description: A FEW weeks ago, I wrote about wines at the coveted intersection of high value and low price. I suggested that the greatest concentration of value, where you could find wines that were not merely palatable, but exciting, was in the $15 to $25 range. And I recommended 20 bottles at $20 that were the kinds of wines I would look forward to drinking any day of the week.

title: For Buckyballs Toys, Child Safety Is a Growing Issue
description: Three years ago, two pals from Brooklyn came up with the idea of creating a desktop toy out of powerful magnets. Their creation, Buckyballs, became an instant hit. And by this year, the two  Craig Zucker and Jake Bronstein  had expected annual sales to reach about $25 million.

title: City Picks Philadelphia Firm to Reopen Tavern on the Green
description: Aug. 17, 1:34 p.m. | Updated

title: Master of a Shrinking Universe
description: The first image in David Cronenbergs Cosmopolis, a cold, funny number about the erotics of money and the seduction of death, is that of a chrome grille on a white stretch limousine. The shot is a close-up thats so tightly framed that the grille, with its U shape and vertical bars, looks as if it were smiling. It also looks like a shark, a perfect starting point for a story about a master of the universe who, over one long day and night, lives, eats, evacuates and fornicates in the limo. A master who, like some kind of millennial Jonah, has taken up residence in the belly of a new beast.

title: This Weeks Movies | August 17
description: The New York Times critics on Cosmopolis, Compliance and Chicken With Plums.

title: Its Amore, Her Fathers Way
description: Deana Martin, the 63-year-old daughter of Dean Martin, might be described as a brassy, tarnished chip off the old block dusted with glitter. With a mischievous gleam in her eye, she recycled some of her fathers more famous remarks at Tuesdays opening-night performance of her show Deana Sings Dino at Feinsteins at Loews Regency.

title: Slums of New York Teem With Life and Death
description: TO film Gangs of New York, Martin Scorsese painstakingly replicated the 19th-century tenements, saloons and almshouses of Lower Manhattans infamous Five Points. On the sprawling back lot of a studio outside Rome, he recreated an incandescent vista of the pentagonal intersection that epitomized the worlds worst slum.

title: Fighting Crime in an Older, Dirtier Manhattan
description: Copper is BBC Americas declaration of independence: the first original drama from a channel built on British imports. And unlike the science-fiction and reality fare (Doctor Who, Top Gear) that BBC America has focused on, Copper is a prestige product, a dark and serious show thats being thrown into the deep end of the cable television pool on Sunday night, where its time-slot competitors include AMCs Breaking Bad, HBOs Newsroom and USAs Political Animals.

title: The Grotesque, Weird Beauty of Vices Photo Issue
description: Vice magazines annual photo issue, showcasing a selection of projects by some of the magazines favorite photographers, is equal parts weird, beautiful and grotesque. The issue was originally produced by photographer (and former Vice photo editor) Ryan McGinley in 2001, and has become something of an institution for new photography. This years selection of pictures, on display last week at Brooklyns Black and White Gallery, was as intriguing as always, featuring images from more established artists like the South African photographer Roger Ballen (who photographed the band Die Antwoord for the Times magazine earlier this year) and younger artists like Elizabeth Renstrom (who is straight out of photography school) and 17-year-old Olivia Bee (who took the photographs for the Times magazines story on teaching teens about sex).

title: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
description: Photos from South Africa, Malta, Syria and India.

title: In N.H.L. Negotiations, Unions Good Ideas May Not Matter
description: 10:59 a.m. | Updated Commissioner Gary Bettman and the owners may be coming off as the villains in the eyes of the public in the N.H.L. labor negotiations, but that wont matter to them one bit, not while they have the chance to save hundreds of millions of dollars each year with a new collective bargaining agreement, and certainly not while they have the upper hand in these negotiations.

title: Obama and Romney to Suspend Ads on 9/11
description: It is quite likely the only reprieve Americans will get from what is expected to be an especially heavy and sustained barrage of political advertising this fall. But on Sept. 11, President Obama and Mitt Romney have agreed to suspend their campaign commercials.

title: Time and CNN Reinstate Journalist After Review
description: Time magazine and CNN are reinstating the commentator Fareed Zakaria after a review of his work in light of his admission that he plagiarized parts of a New Yorker article in a recent column for Time.

title: How Hollywood Films Are Killing Opera
description: The opera? the main character of Kenneth Lonergans recent film, Margaret, sourly asks her mother. Why are you going to the opera?

title: Trial Delayed in Plot to Kill Saudi Envoy
description: The trial of Mansour J. Arbabsiar, an Iranian-American man accused of plotting to kill a Saudi ambassador, has been delayed, a federal judge said on Thursday, adding that he was concerned that the case was moving too slowly.

title: Cycling and Socializing in Central Park
description: IF youre looking for a cycling workout in New York City without having to navigate much traffic, the six-mile loop in Central Park offers one of the worlds best urban cycling courses. But for a less solitary ride, a variety of groups do the loop at paces from high octane to moderate to downright leisurely.

title: Up Front
description: Reviewing Martin Amiss new novel, Lionel Asbo, this week, Kathryn Harrison observes that it harks back to Dickens in its themes and characters. But Harrisons own work has been casting back farther than that lately, as she writes her biography of Joan of Arc. Joans story resonates on so many levels  the religious, the military, the political, the feminist  that we wondered which speaks loudest to Harrison.

title: Seeing Ghosts Wherever He Looks
description: ParaNorman, a beautiful-looking, charmingly heartfelt 3-D stop-motion animation about a boy and his ghouls, comes with an assortment of hair-raising frights. Some of these are just the flesh-and-blood people in Normans life, the bullies and teachers and even relatives who, with degrees of impatience and love, chastise the 11-year-old for his unusually morbid habits. Norman, a sprout whose black hair stands at attention as if he were in a state of perpetual alarm (he is voiced with vivid emotion by Kodi Smit-McPhee), cant help but be a little creepy. After all, he doesnt just see dead people, he also hangs out with them, sometimes while watching creature-features on the family TV.

title: Season of the Witch
description: To the Editor:

title: A Strange Formulation
description: To the Editor:

title: Batter Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Strange Tales Casting Wide Nets
description: Along with everything else thats been deflated, downsized or drained of its power in our millennial lives, the image, formerly worth 1,000 words is now worth about 200  maybe 250 on a good day. Now we rely on captions to convey meaning. These texts were already becoming obligatory in the 1930s, according to Walter Benjamin, but are now virtually a medium of their own.

title: Cold Feat
description: My pack is by the door; I leave in the morning. I am standing with my fiance, D, in the kitchen. The sight of my waiting backpack has triggered her anxiety. Shes a different person than she was just a few minutes ago. Youre always coming and going, leaving and coming, you have no time to love me, she blurts out. We have just returned from a long, romantic dinner, after having spent the afternoon together. And now the tears come.

title: Schools Pass Debt to the Next Generation
description: The deleveraging of America is well under way, as individuals and companies recover from the excess borrowing that helped to produce the boom and left many people vulnerable when the bust arrived. Household debt is down nearly $900 billion over the last four years, partly from repayments and partly from defaults.

title: Strings Coming Loose for a Violinist in Tehran
description: Graphic novels, at their best, do whatever they want; movies, all too often, do what they think they are supposed to do. No artist is freer than one with a good story and a sufficient supply of paper and ink, and the graphic-novel form, as it has evolved over the last two decades  to encompass memoir, history and eyewitness journalism  is bracingly unconstrained by visual or narrative convention. It is not surprising that some of the most interesting films in recent years have tried to capture that freedom.

title: The World of Nol Coward
description: The Miser once whiled away many autodidactic hours around Lincoln Center, triangulating between the CD racks of Tower Records, the brimming bookshelves of Barnes & Noble  who knew that someday wed miss the chains!  and the extensive media holdings of the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts.

title: Ancient Havens of Reflection and Renewal
description: Daily I stroll contentedly in my garden

title: Just Trust Me
description: Mitt Romney deigned to answer questions about his tax returns today, assuring reporters at a news conference that he had never paid less than 13 percent of his income in taxes in the last decade. Thats considerably lower than the rate many middle-class families pay, but whats really remarkable is that Mr. Romney now expects the public to accept his word and move on.

title: Q&A: Help for an Ailing Router
description: Q.

title: In Drought, a Debate Over Quota for Ethanol
description: WASHINGTON  Three big intertwined but rival agribusinesses  corn farmers, meat and poultry producers, and biofuel refineries  are in a political fight to protect their interests as a drought ravages corn producers and industrial consumers alike.

title: Comedy Listings for Aug. 17-23
description: Comedy

title: Movie Listings for Aug. 17-23
description: Movies

title: Murray Upset by a Lucky Loser
description: MASON, Ohio  Andy Murray, the defending champion and recent Olympic gold medalist, was knocked out of the Western & Southern Open in the third round Thursday, falling in straight sets to a lucky loser, Jrmy Chardy of France, 6-4, 6-4.

title: Pop Listings for Aug. 17-23
description: Pop

title: Theater Listings for Aug. 17-23
description: Theater

title: Israels President Criticizes Talk of Unilateral Strike on Iran
description: JERUSALEM  Shimon Peres, Israels president and elder statesman, spoke out Thursday against the prospect of a lone Israeli military strike on Irans nuclear facilities, a message that contradicts the hawkish, go-it-alone line emanating from the offices of Israels prime minister and defense minister.

title: Jazz Listings for Aug. 17-23
description: Jazz

description: Classical

description: Dance

description: Art

title: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 17-23
description: NYC DESIGN STUDIO

title: Trash Talk at West Sides Rat Academy
description: On West 76th Street, a sound that has been heard once or twice a week lately is that of a woman screaming. The provocation? A rat scurrying by. Close by.
