description: To the Editor:

title: Familiar Offerings Amid Ocher and Plum
description: ITS been seven years since I last reviewed Rracis, and I can report that history pretty much repeats itself, but at a higher price. A charming back dining patio has been added, but inside, the pallor of age hangs over the restaurant. Ocher walls are almost hidden by a clutter of pretty mirrors reflecting the small spaces, window swags, wine bottles and dusty bouquets of silk flowers. The dim lighting, the dark wainscoting and a deep plum ceiling can feel cozy or claustrophobic, like being at the back of a cave. The menu, too, is dated, a near copy of that offered years ago. Dishes reflect the taste of those times  a preference for the rich and the heavy with less interest in the subtle and the seasonal. When is the last time anyone had calfs liver as an appetizer?

title: Court Overturns Law Expanding Taxi Service
description: A State Supreme Court justice on Friday rebuffed the Bloomberg administrations plan to expand street hail service beyond Manhattan, signaling an uncertain future for livery taxis in the city and a victory for the yellow-cab industry, which has vigorously opposed the plan.

title: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 17
Horse Given Painkiller Breaks Down at New Mexico Racetrack
description: A horse that recently tested positive for a supercharged painkiller drawn from a type of South American frog broke down and was euthanized Thursday at a New Mexico racetrack after winning a trial heat for the coming All American Futurity, one of the worlds richest horse races.

title: A College Lifts a Hurdle for Illegal Immigrants
description: DENVER  Monday is the first day of the school year for Metropolitan State University of Denver, a compact, urban campus in the heart of the citys downtown.

title: Unitarians Break With Tradition of Extended Time Off in Summer
description: If you phone a Unitarian Church between the middle of June and Labor Day in September, the most you are apt to get is a recorded message, Charles S. Slap said in his sermon at the First Unitarian Society of Schenectady, N.Y., on Sept. 8, 1985. Our more orthodox friends never cease to be astounded by the contents of the message: This church is closed for the summer. If you are one of those people who actually need a church during the summer, try the Presbyterians.

title: When Bacon Beckons Far From Home
description: WHETHER you call it a power breakfast with colleagues or just breakfast out with the family, tucking into a big morning meal can be a terrific start to the day. These Connecticut restaurants offer excellent meals in a range of styles.

title: Adieu, Anna
description: A hundred years from now, fashion historians will want to know about the astonishing style of Anna Piaggi, an Italian fashion editor who died in Milan on Aug. 7 at age 81.

title: Warrens New Ad Looks a Lot Like Her Rivals
description: BOSTON  Has Elizabeth Warren, the Democrat running for Senate in Massachusetts, taken a page from Senator Scott P. Browns playbook?

title: A Libyans Plea to the S.E.C.
description: Tripoli, Libya

title: Woody Guthrie, Choreographers Muse
description: The performers who appear in the Downtown Dance Festival each year arent stellar. Many arent professional; quite a number arent adults. On the wrong day, too high a proportion of a mixed bill can be lackluster or foolish. The good programs, however, have often proved more than refreshing: they can be revelatory. As a permanent tourist in New York, Im more than happy to sit in the open air near the southern tip of Manhattan. As a permanent student, Im grateful when unfamiliar forms of dance teach me something new. One program this summer has shown me about important aspects of America Id overlooked.

title: Fine Arts
description: On Aug. 4, The Southampton Hospital held its annual benefit for more than 800 guests in a tent in the open fields adjacent to the hospital. A display of race cars fit the theme of the Grand Prix of Monaco.

title: A Settler Leader, Worldly and Pragmatic
description: MAALE SHOMRON, West Bank

title: Picassos Life Inspires Two Films
description: MADRID  Two events in Picassos life, a quarter of a century apart, are at the heart of new movies by two of Spains veteran directors.

title: Arctic Drilling Will Begin This Year, Shell Official Says
description: HOUSTON  Despite embarrassing delays and trouble with its equipment, Shell remains confident that it will get final approval from regulators and be able to begin drilling for oil in Arctic waters off the Alaskan coast this summer, the oil companys top Alaska executive said on Friday.

title: What Parents Dont Get About Camp
description: Its been fun over this summer to read what parents think about summer camp. All those hopes for childrens gaining self-confidence or friends or independence! But lets be honest, parents (or at least parents who werent campers themselves) dont totally get the whole camp thing. And with campers coming home in droves, those parents are getting a full dose of the in-jokes, goofy rituals and the cherished memories that make up camp.

title: A Mysterious Lady Wakes Up Dead
description: You know something is a bit strange when the hero goes home to his London flat and his comfy living-room armchairs are played by stagehands. And when the announced station stops for a train whizzing through the English countryside include Gosford Park, Downton Abbey and Brideshead Revisited. And when a news report describes a murder victim as a well-dressed woman, about 35, with a knife in her back.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,072 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Deutsche Banks Business With Sanctioned Nations Under Scrutiny
description: Federal and state prosecutors are investigating Deutsche Bank and several other global banks over accusations that they funneled billions of dollars through their American branches for Iran, Sudan and other sanctioned nations, according to law enforcement officials with knowledge of the cases.

title: Recycling Plant Fire Unnerves a New York Town
description: After a fire burned through a recycling plant for electrical equipment two weeks ago in Columbia County, N.Y., the environmental tests that followed were alone cause for anxiety among residents.

title: A Romance That Isnt What It Seems
description: She is a mousy millinery assistant, consigned to the back room because she is not considered attractive enough to deal with customers. He is a small-time con man, looking for his next mark. He swiftly marries the women he woos, beds them (just to be polite), takes control of their bank accounts (this is 1910 London, after all, and young ladies need protecting) and runs for the hills.

title: Obama Lags on Judicial Picks, Limiting His Mark on Courts
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is set to end his term with dozens fewer lower-court appointments than both Presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush achieved in their first four years, and probably with less of a lasting ideological imprint on the judiciary than many liberals had hoped for and conservatives had feared.

title: Recreating a Teenage Crush
description: First Floor TheaterLa MaMa ETC74A East Fourth Street, East Village(866) 468-7619Through Aug. 26

title: Burglar Tells How He Got Into an East Village Apartment, Twice
description: The East Village apartment burglar, successful once, came back for more, and was caught in a trap and arrested. But a mystery lingered. How did he get in that apartment? Had he lived there before? No. And the buildings super said the lock was changed after the previous tenant left.

title: Judge Bars Testimony by Expert in Frisk Suit
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has repeatedly said that the small number of guns found by police officers during stop-and-frisk encounters shows that the program is working as a deterrent, and not that the police are exercising poor judgment in deciding whom to stop, as critics have argued.

title: Scandals in Their Own Words
description: We need more Rachel Dratch in our lives.

title: Protester Briefly Skitters Out of Russian Jurisdiction
description: MOSCOW  For a few brief moments Friday, a protesters reaction to the news that three women in the punk band Pussy Riot were found guilty of hooliganism nearly caused an international incident.

title: Obama Ad Attacks the Romney Campaign on Womens Issues
description: 9:58 p.m. | Updated

title: Reviving the Memory of a Blues Pioneer
description: The blues singer known as Big Maybelle, who recorded hit singles and toured the country during the 1950s and 1960s, is largely forgotten today, except perhaps by blues aficionados. However, the powerful performance by Lillias White at the Bay Street Theater in Sag Harbor makes a strong case that the blues belters obscurity is grievously undeserved.

title: West Memphis Three, a Year Out of Prison, Navigate New Paths
description: ATLANTA  The list of things you learn about yourself when you get out of prison after 17 years is long: Youre allergic to shrimp, or youre paralyzed by the choices in a grocery store or moved to tears by the softness of the night sky.

title: For Williams Sisters, a Split in Cincinnati
description: MASON, Ohio  Serena Williams, the Olympic gold medalist and Wimbledon champion, lost her first match since May on Friday, falling to the German Angelique Kerber, 6-4, 6-4, in the quarterfinals at the Western & Southern Open in this suburb of Cincinnati.

title: Many New York City Teachers Denied Tenure in Policy Shift
description: Nearly half of New York City teachers reaching the end of their probations were denied tenure this year, the Education Department said on Friday, marking the culmination of years of efforts toward Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs goal to end tenure as we know it.

title: Watching the Olympics, Seeing Formula One
description: PARIS  I kept an eye on the Olympics, and since it is the summer break in Formula One, I tried to keep my mind off Formula One. But, inevitably, comparisons of the two spectacles kept entering my thoughts  especially since Formula One has for many years hyped itself as the worlds third most popular sporting spectacle, behind the Olympics and World Cup soccer.

title: Ailing Yankees Give Teixeira Chance to Rest Injured Wrist
description: The Yankees look more brittle with each passing day. C. C. Sabathia, Andy Pettitte and Alex Rodriguez are on the disabled list, and now Mark Teixeiras sore left wrist will most likely keep him sidelined for a couple of games.

title: Merchants and Shoppers Sour on Daily Deal Sites
description: As their e-mail in-boxes filled with daily deal offers from Web sites like Groupon, Lea Pische and Edwin Hermawan, a pizzeria waitress and a former lawyer living on the Lower East Side, finally decided to buy one: a discounted Skillshare class on how to start a business.

title: An Indecent Proposal and a Moral Dilemma
description: Isabellas quandary in the Shakespeare play Measure for Measure is a little like Joans in the 2012 season of Mad Men. Should a woman sleep with a man she finds repellent if by doing so she serves a greater good? And how much greater does that good have to be? On Mad Men, it was a matter of crass commerce, an advertising agency getting its first big auto account. In Measure for Measure, it is a question of the womans saving her brother from execution. But this story being a product of Elizabethan England, when notions of immortal damnation were taken more personally, the playwright cannot let her fall into bed with just anybody. He cannot let her fall into bed at all.

title: Ryan Tax Returns Show 20 Percent Rate in 2011
description: The Republican vice-presidential candidate Paul D. Ryan and his wife, Janna, paid 20 percent of their adjusted gross income in federal income taxes in 2011 and 15.9 percent in 2010, according to tax returns he released Friday.

title: Obamas Impact on the Federal Courts of Appeals
description: Vacancies on the district courts have increased during President Obamas term, but he has restored some partisan balance to the appeals court bench.

title: In Englands Premier League, Many Suitors for the Top Spot
description: It takes something special for England to forget about soccer  something as momentous as the greatest show on earths rolling into London for two weeks, in fact. But after a summer off, and a soaring Summer Olympics, the English Premier League is back to reclaim its title as the lands greatest sporting spectacle.

title: Thailand: 4 Die in Nightclub Fire in Phuket
description: Four people died and a dozen were injured Friday when a fire broke out at a nightclub on the Thai resort island of Phuket, the police said. The identities of the dead were not known late Friday, Maj. Gen. Chanasit Wattanawarangkul, the chief of police in Phuket, said by telephone. Phuket is about 510 miles south of Bangkok. General Chanasit said that the fire had occurred after power was cut and then restored during heavy rain in the early hours of Friday. A transformer exploded, he said, and the fire spread quickly into the building. Four French citizens were among the injured, one of whom suffered serious burns, Thai news reports said. The nightclub, the Tiger Discotheque, is in Patong, one of the islands most popular tourist spots.

title: The Minister of Death
description: From April 29 to May 30, 1862, some 300,000 men  including my great-great grandfather, Pvt. Edward Willis  converged at the tiny railroad depot of Corinth, in northern Mississippi, where they laid siege to the Confederate forces under Gen. P.G.T. Beauregard. The Union soldiers scarred the landscape with miles of earthen fortifications. But the trenches could not protect Edward and his fellow soldiers from what Thomas Macaulay called the most terrible of all the ministers of death, a predator that craved those close, confined spaces, where mens blood, breath and spit mingled freely. Although they fought on opposite sides of the trenches, the Union and Confederate forces shared a common enemy: smallpox.

title: Baseball, Faith and Doubt
description: It was impossible this week not to think about the incredible staying power of baseball.

title: Push for More Cholera Inoculations
description: Pressure to adopt a cholera vaccine as part of the routine response to outbreaks mounted as two expert panels advised the World Health Organization to use it. On Thursday, experts meeting in Washington endorsed the use of the vaccine to control the continuing outbreak in Haiti and the Dominican Republic. Studies conducted by medical charities there showed that up to 90 percent of people who had received one dose of the vaccine returned for a second dose and were therefore protected. Separately, an expert panel advised the World Health Organization this year to seek enough money to create a global stockpile of two million doses for emergencies. On Friday, Sierra Leone declared its cholera outbreak a national humanitarian emergency; it has had almost 11,000 cases and 176 deaths since January. Cholera kills through rapid dehydration. The vaccine is for healthy people, but it could be used to surround outbreaks and keep them from spreading.

title: Senator, Senator, Make Me a Match: For Staff, Schumer Is Cupid
description: Even by the standards of Capitol Hill, where ambitious and awkward young people are thrust together in cramped workplaces and crowded bars, the nuptial output of Senator Charles E. Schumers office stands out.

title: Sparkle Brightens Midday at the Multiplex
description: CULVER CITY, Calif.  It takes a lot to get an audience applauding during a movie at 2 oclock on a hot afternoon. But Sparkle did the trick, at least three times, during a showing at the Pacific Theaters Stadium 12 here on Friday.

title: Draft Horse That Bolted May End Up on Easy Street
description: Oreo, the runaway horse who dumped his carriage driver and two passengers near Columbus Circle on Thursday, may have bolted his way into an easier lifestyle.

title: This Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: A strong Canadian dollar weighs on the auto industry as contract talks start, the Kalashnikov factory in Russia is humming thanks to American buyers, and Amtraks Acela train service is dominating travel in the Washington-New York-Boston corridor.

title: Lottery Numbers
California: Young Immigrants Eligible for Drivers Licenses
description: Young illegal immigrants who qualify for President Obamas deportation deferral program will be eligible to obtain a drivers license in California. Mr. Obamas program, which began Wednesday, will grant work permits to immigrants who are 30 years or younger and meet program requirements. California law permits the Department of Motor Vehicles to issue drivers licenses to individuals who present an employment authorization document. The young immigrants, once they have been given deferred action, can apply for a drivers license, said Conrado Terrazas, a spokesman for Assemblyman Gil Cedillo, who has tried unsuccessfully to pass a law allowing licenses for illegal immigrants.

title: Combating Blight With Beauty
description: To fight the scourge of graffiti in Atlanta, an international crew of female artists created murals  sprawling, brightly colored portraits and designs  in recession-hit neighborhoods.

title: Putting a Good Face on Street Art, to Upgrade Atlanta
description: ATLANTA  Molly Rose Freeman gasped at the size of her wall: 180 feet long, 20 feet tall, a street artists dream.

title: Ever Hear the One About ...
description: Tying up loose ends before vacation:

title: Written in the Stars
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  If you solve crosswords on a regular basis, theres some random knowledge that you just accumulate over time. Some of this information can serve as a refresher for things that are useful to know, like the periodic table of elements or world capitals. Then there are the other factoids, like zodiac signs or birthstones, that fall into a less serious category of miscellany but are just as commonly used. Crossword clues are really the great equalizer.

title: Illinois Legislators Fail to Agree on Pension Package
description: CHICAGO  Illinois lawmakers, who gathered at the Capitol in Springfield for a special session on Friday, failed to reach agreement on a pension package aimed at addressing the states ballooning fiscal problems.

title: At the Beach, Vulnerability and Confidence
description: Caitlin Teal Price stalks the strand from Coney Island to Brighton Beach, pausing over sunbathers to ask if she can snap a portrait.

title: Behind Franciscos Grin: Less Than Lovely Numbers
description: WASHINGTON  The return of closer Frank Francisco from the disabled list has not stabilized the Mets shaky bullpen.

title: Ballpoint-Pen Springs and Other Fixes for Vintage Bugattis
description: MONTEREY, Calif.  In Sundays Automobiles section, I write about the Pebble Beach Motoring Classic, a 1,500-mile tour now in its eighth year as an official prelude to the concours dlgance and collector-car auctions that take place on the Monterey Peninsula of California each August.

title: Repair Costs Could Bring Down a Popular Pier
description: When it was created in the late 1990s, Hudson River Park seemed like a new genre of public space, a state-city hybrid built on and over the water, with continuing maintenance to be paid for by commercial development on a handful of piers.

title: Long Lines and Big Dreams
description: The lines on Wednesday were huge, like the ribbon of humanity at Navy Pier in Chicago that snaked through halls and stairwells and along the pier and then stretched, amazingly, out to and under Lake Shore Drive. Young illegal immigrants by the tens of thousands formed similar lines in other cities across the country. They lined up outside churches and nonprofit agencies, holding paperwork and folders, to learn more about a new Obama administration policy that would protect them from deportation and give them permission to work.

title: Elegant Newlyweds, Out With the Boss
description: Is there a local restaurant rule  Farmers Law?  that holds that the simpler and earthier the cuisine, the more sophisticated the clientele? That, at least, would seem to be the case at Rosemarys, a two-month-old trattoria at the corner of Greenwich Avenue and 10th Street in the West Village. Rosemarys not only has a rough-hewed Tuscan farmhouse look, with distressed wood and exposed beams; it also has a rooftop garden of herbs and vegetables (and soon, perhaps, a beehive and a chicken coop). The daily produce is transported from garden to kitchen in a retro-old-world manner: dropped in a basket and lowered with a block and tackle. In the dining room, one finds a discerning and affluent crowd, which one night last week included a newly wed Norwegian-Italian couple and the husbands boss.

title: Ryan, Appearing at Ease in First Week on Trail, Begins to Look Ahead
description: SPRINGFIELD, Va.  It is hard to imagine Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, sauntering into a hot-dog restaurant and having an elderly, white-haired woman shout, Hey, kick some tail!

title: City Ends School Lunch Program That Used Professional Chefs
description: A well-regarded program that recruited professional chefs to help the New York City Department of Education provide fresher, healthier food in public schools is being discontinued because it does not meet new federal nutrition standards, the department said Friday.

title: The Unsafe World of Investing
description: The JOBS Act  Jump-Start Our Business Start-Ups  is a bad law. Enacted in April, it ends longstanding investor protections, reduces market transparency and lowers accounting and auditing standards for companies that are planning to go public.

title: One Retailers Experience With Groupon
description: An online T-shirt retailer offered his customers a Groupon deal last year of a $20 coupon good for $40 worth of merchandise. But few of those who bought the coupon spent much more than its $40 value.

title: With Another Mets First, Santana Raises Concerns Instead of Spirits
description: WASHINGTON  Johan Santana began his year enveloped in a thick haze of uncertainty. He appears to be wading into that haze again.

title: Congressional Fund-Raiser Charged With Immigration Fraud
description: A former rabbinical aide who may hold the fate of a United States representative in his hands has been arrested on immigration-fraud charges, federal authorities said on Friday.

title: Defensive Back Is Latest Star to Stumble Amid All the Attention
description: Just last week, Tyrann Mathieu was the rare collegiate defensive back who had earned star status as an outspoken dervish of a player, one who demanded attention whenever he got near the ball. But Mathieus life has changed drastically, taking two sharp turns.

title: Savoring the Illicit Thrill of a Glass of Something, Outside
description: Gibran K. Brown and Jaie Jordan sat on the stoop of their brownstone, looking out over Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn, as they do most warm evenings. In the distance, dust settled on the soccer pitch as players scattered after a game. Except for a jingling dog collar, the huffing of a passing jogger and the chorus of cicadas, the cooling air was quiet.

title: Its How You Play the Game
description: Fans of honest gamesmanship should be inured by now to the spectacle of a home run hitter caught conniving with his private druggist to break the rules. The latest is Melky Cabrera, the most valuable player in last months All-Star Game who humbly attributed his success to the Lord. After drug testing, the San Francisco Giants outfielder was forced by league officials to admit this week that banned doses of testosterone also played no small role in his blazing bat speed.

title: Mandatory Class for Airport Officers Accused of Profiling
description: Transportation Security Administration officers who are in a behavioral detection program designed to spot terrorists at airports have been ordered to undergo special training after officers in Boston were accused of racially profiling passengers.

title: Jeter Hits Home Run, Savoring a Milestone
description: Shortly after the Yankees beat the Boston Red Sox, 6-4, at Yankee Stadium and Joe Girardi lauded the performances of several players, he slipped quietly into the clubhouse and placed the games lineup card on Derek Jeters chair in front of his locker.

title: Online, Love Blooms and Decays
description: There will no doubt come a time, in the not-so-distant future, when scholars data-mine Facebook for a digital literature of love. Why not? All of loves aspects can be found on Facebook: first-date photographs, swooning status updates, jealousy-stirring pokes, the not-quite-terminal its complicated. Here, meanwhile, are a few poems about Facebooks role in romance found last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.

title: Criticism Greets List of Debate Moderators
description: Complaining about the moderators of the presidential debates is a time-honored tradition of the election season. Usually, the complaints wait until the moderators have actually asked a question.

title: Abortion Cases Against Clinic in Kansas Are Dropped by Prosecutors
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The first criminal prosecution of Planned Parenthood came to an abrupt end Friday when Kansas prosecutors dropped all charges against a local affiliate accused of failing to determine the viability of fetuses before abortions were performed.

title: Dark Road to the White House
description: Shady money, voter suppression, shifting positions, murky details and widespread apathy.

title: Welcome, New York Voters
description: Registering to vote in New York State is an unnecessarily cumbersome process, time-consuming and prone to error. Voters fill out forms at one of 129 motor vehicle offices around the state, which then have to be sorted and mailed to local boards of elections. Some names never make it to the lists of registered voters. Little wonder that New York ranks a dismal 48th in the nation in voter registration, trailed only by Texas and Mississippi.

title: Political Page Turners
description: Lets see if we can clear up a few things.

title: Ryan Draws Crowds in First Week
description: Representative Paul Ryan completed his first week as the Republican vice-presidential candidate and whooshed overnight to the highest level of American celebrity with its perks and poison darts.

title: A Wall Street Trader Becomes an Ironman
description: IT was just after 11:30 p.m. on Aug. 11 when Guy Adami heard the words that had floated through his daydreams for nearly a year  to say nothing of nearly every minute of the previous 16 hours:

title: Reviewing the Porsche Boxster
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the 2013 Porsche Boxster, a slimmer, faster and more focused version of the sports car introduced by the German automaker 16 years ago.

title: Harry Harrison, a Prolific Writer of Satiric Science Fiction, Dies at 87
description: Incompetent, unlettered, unskilled writers sell to unexacting editors. All of this is going completely unnoticed by an incompetent readership.

title: Of Red Sox Many Problems, Injuries Have Hurt Most
description: There is a scene in the movie Almost Famous when the band first reads the article the young journalist has written about them for Rolling Stone. Jason Lees character is devastated by the portrayal.

title: In a Horseplayers Heaven, Its Bears Season
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  It requires a certain temperament for a horseplayer to endure the grind of the Saratoga meet day in, day out. He needs to be shrewd but good-humored, absorbed but resilient. A healthy bankroll helps, as does a strong, functioning liver.

title: Parking Rules
description: On Sunday, Monday and Tuesday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations in New York City will be suspended because of Id al-Fitr. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Premier League Preview
description: The Premier League season kicks off Saturday with seven games, including Robin van Persie-less Arsenal against Sunderland. Chelsea and Manchester City play their openers on Sunday, and Manchester United, now bolstered by van Persie, plays Everton on Monday. Graham Ruthven takes a look at what could be a crowded race for the top spot. Who do you think will end up lifting the trophy in May?

title: The Butler Wears Flip-Flops
description: THE day was hardly under way, and Billy Mackay had already sweated through his blue shirt with CABANA written across the back.

title: A Gaza Border Slams Shut, and With It, Chances for a Pilgrimage to Mecca
description: GAZA CITY  Every Ramadan for the past two decades, Mouin Mushtaha has made the pilgrimage to Mecca during the last 10 days of the Muslim holy month. This year, as Ramadan ticked away, he sat gloomily at the office of his tourism agency here, watching the festivities on television.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: North but No South

title: Jailhouse Letter: Dear Judge, The Staff Actually Discontinued My Fish Oil
description: It is said that older people like to enumerate their various health woes, and apparently aging Yippies are no different.

title: Meditation, and Cereal for Dinner
description: Robert Hammond, 42, founded Friends of the High Line in 1999 with Joshua David, helping transform the abandoned rail line in Chelsea into a linear park that draws millions of visitors a year. On Sundays, Mr. Hammond, who has lived in the West Village since 1994, spends time with his boyfriend, Justin Brennan, in the neighborhood, eating at local haunts and bicycling. While Mr. Hammond might take a prospective donor on a tour of the High Line, he usually chooses other parks for his own relaxation.

title: A Suit Familiar and Remarkable
description: THE lawsuit traversed familiar ground: lesser-known songwriter sues established artist, claiming thather work was poached and turned into a hit song.

title: The Night-Life Lawyer
description: THE New York bar, like all complex professional societies, has every sort of specialty you can think of: white-shoe litigators, Mafia defenders, crusading Legal Aiders, corporate crisis managers, City Hall fixers, real estate closers and lowly filers of slip-and-fall lawsuits. Sal Strazzullos specialty is that capricious class of person occupying the world of New York night life. In a decade as a lawyer, Mr. Strazzullo, 40, has earned a reputation for taking care of the boldface celebrities  and lesser lights of the pleasure-seeking set  who get themselves in trouble after dark.

title: Corrections: August 18, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: The Watchmens Misdirected Gaze
description: Person of Interest, the CBS television drama developed as if to risk the collective cardiovascular failure of the New York Civil Liberties Union, delivers a vision of the city in which technological innovation, boundless private capital and an outlaw disposition collude to render a fantasia of sixth-sense policing. At the center sits an obsessive billionaire computer savant who deploys his own pattern-recognition software, advanced surveillance gadgetry and the acrobatics of a former spy to identify those about to perpetrate or fall prey to violence, and pre-empt their fate. Murder and malfeasance are nipped virtually at conception. Pass the cupcakes!

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: Comedy

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Policy on Coal Concessions Cost Government Royalties, Audit Finds
description: The Indian government missed out on nearly $34 billion in royalties by selling private companies coal concessions at negotiated prices rather than auctioning them, according to an audit released on Friday, Vikas Bajaj wrote in The New York Times.

title: Ryan: The First Decade
description: Continuing with my Ryan series, lets look at what his budget (pdf) actually proposes (as opposed to vaguely promises) in its first decade.

title: Reports on Government Contracts Deal Another Blow to Coalition
Echoes of Northeastern Violence Ripple Across Indian Cities
description: Like a fever, fear has spread across India this week, from big cities like Bangalore to smaller places like Mysore, a contagion fueling a message: Run. Head home. Flee, Jim Yardley wrote in The New York Times. And that is what thousands of migrants from the countrys distant northeastern states are doing, jamming into train stations in an exodus challenging the Indian ideals of tolerance and diversity.

title: The Weekend Word: Empty Benches
description: Todays Times

title: Kansas City Chiefs, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
description: Two years ago, everything was going great for the Kansas City Chiefs. They were a bright young team under a bright young coach, Todd Haley. They rode the leagues best rushing attack to a surprising A.F.C. West title. They had invested $28 million guaranteed in quarterback Matt Cassel, whom they felt was a good fit in Haleys shotgun-based passing game. General Manager Scott Pioli was building this team the Patriot Way, stockpiling depth on both sides of the ball and retooling the classic 3-4 defense that former Patriots defensive coordinator Romeo Crennel was running. This was a team on the rise.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: In the Shopian district of southern Kashmir, people using the names Lashkar Al Qaida and Al Qaida Mujahideen have been putting up posters threatening acid attacks on women who do not live in purdah or who carry cellphones, Kashmir Live  reported. The police said the perpetrators were not affiliated with any actual militant outfit and that two school dropouts were suspected, according to the newspaper.

title: Leader Visits North Koreans at Border Post
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, has visited soldiers stationed near the two Koreas disputed sea border and bestowed official accolades on the artillery unit that shelled a South Korean island in 2010, killing four people, the Norths state-run news agency reported Saturday.

title: Latin America Sees Hand of Colonialism in Assange Standoff
description: LONDON  Ecuador was this past weekend seeking support from its Latin American partners to confront what officials described as threats by Britain over Quitos decision to grant asylum to Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder.

title: Aug. 17: Does a Bullish Stock Market Predict a Faster Recovery?
description: There wasnt much in the way of polling data on Friday. The national tracking polls were released  Mitt Romney and Paul D. Ryan got a comparatively poor number in the Rasmussen Reports tracking poll, which had President Obama pulling into a one-point lead after having trailed in that survey for much of the past few weeks. And there was a new national survey from the firm Angus Reid, which conducts online polls. It had Mr. Romney ahead by four points  up from a tie in its poll last month.

title: The Daily Shoe | Manolo Blahnik Boot
description: Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the Bergdorf Goodman shoe salon in honor of the stores 111th anniversary. Todays pick (and the last in this series): a blinding ankle boot from Manolo Blahnik thats covered in crystals and was designed exclusively for Bergdorf Goodman. $7,800.

title: Premier League: And the Winner Is
description: Let the games begin. No, not those Games. The games on the field and on the screen, TV and video. Englands Premier League and EAs FIFA Soccer 13.

title: Further Notes for the Sancerre-Inclined
description: PARIS  In his most recent Wines of The Times column, Eric Asimov tastes the so-called Sancerre satellites  appellations that produce white wine in a similar style to their better-known Loire Valley neighbor, from the same grape variety, sauvignon blanc. Indeed, wine from these appellations, which include Pouilly-Fum, Menetou-Salon, Reuilly and Quincy, can be a good bet. Pouilly-Fum sometimes matches or surpasses Sancerre in quality (and, unfortunately, in price) but all of the others are bargains.

title: The Sun Hasnt Set on the Drive-In
description: MONTCLAIR, Calif.

title: Drive-In Theaters Offer a Bit of the Past, and Its Prices
description: A symbol of 1950s-era Southern California, the drive-in has shown resilience in todays trying economy. Entry is cheap, the atmosphere is relaxed and, for some, the memories are unbeatable.

title: At Second, at Least, Cubs Are a Force
description: When Skip, the manager in the movie Bull Durham, summed up baseball, he said: This is a simple game. You throw the ball, you hit the ball, you catch the ball. Unfortunately, at some point, the importance of catching the ball has become lost on some fans and sportswriters.

title: For Russians, Corruption Is Just a Way of Life
description: Corruption in Russia is so pervasive that the whole society accepts the unacceptable as normal.

title: Next to the Manager, but a Bit Ahead
description: With a profusion of pitching changes, pinch-hitting announcements and fielding realignments, a baseball game can slow interminably in the later innings. But to decision makers in the dugout  those who make strategic adjustments while looking ahead to the next pitch, the next batter, the next inning  it feels as if it is speeding up.

title: Horses Fall Victim to Hard Times and Dry Times on the Range
description: AZTEC, N.M.  The land is parched, the fields are withering and thousands of the nations horses are being left to fend for themselves on the dried range, abandoned by people who can no longer afford to feed them.

title: Raising the Ritalin Generation
description: I REMEMBER the moment my sons teacher told us, Just a little medication could really turn things around for Will. We stared at her as if she were speaking Greek.

title: Volstead Struggling with the Cubs
description: No player sums up the futility of the 2012 Chicago Cubs better than starter Chris Volstad. The Cubs acquired Volstad from the Miami Marlins in January for Carlos Zambrano, an expensive and volatile starter the team was eager to shed. But while Volstad may be quieter than Zambrano, his results have been discouraging.

title: Blanking Out
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  The variety puzzle from Fred Piscop this week is a diagramless, so brace yourself for the sheer terror of seeing 289 white squares blankly staring at you. Warning: There is some assembly required. You have to figure out the puzzles geometry, and that is the hardest part. You have to determine which squares are to be filled in and which should be black squares. Adding to the difficulty is that you have to add the numbers to the grid.

title: Good Stuff
description: WITH all the supply lists, school clothes and emergency contact sheets required before September begins, I can barely keep track of everything I have to buy, fill out or turn in. The new school year means that a bunch of new stuff will pour into our apartment  and I still havent figured out what to do with all the stuff from last year.

title: Sunday Dialogue: The Legacy of the Baby Boom Generation
description: Readers debate whether the bashing of boomers as selfish and spoiled is justified.

title: Why Waiting Is Torture
description: Editors' note: Waiting in line is a timeless form of torture. Here's a story from the archives that explains why.

title: Flamboyant Crime Fighter Now May Face Chinese Justice Over Role in Scandal
description: CHONGQING, China  Wang Lijun reveled in his image as the consummate crime fighter. An ethnic Mongolian policeman with a fondness for expensive overcoats, he directed crackdowns on organized crime, performed autopsies, patented designs for police uniforms and was even named an honorary professor at the institute of a famous American forensic scientist. His earlier exploits inspired a television series. All that was missing was a mask and cape.

title: Why Race Is Still a Problem for Mormons
description: Fairfax, Va.

title: Bedoya Scores in Debut for New Club
description: The career of any professional soccer player will almost always have its peaks and valleys, but for Alejandro Bedoya, the last year has been a tumultuous ride beyond what most players have to endure.

title: Crank It Up
description: Cooling degree days in some of the worlds largest urban areas.

title: The Cost of Cool
description: THE blackouts that left hundreds of millions of Indians sweltering in the dark last month underscored the status of air-conditioning as one of the worlds most vexing environmental quandaries.

title: Bobak Ferdowsi
description: Bobak Ferdowsi is a flight director for NASAs Mars rover, Curiosity. Widely known as Mohawk Guy, hes become an Internet sensation since Curiositys successful landing last week, prompting President Obama to joke that hes considering getting a mohawk himself.

title: The World Is Flat, Again
description: ILL never forget my first globe. It was a basketball-size sphere with textured mountains and shining cerulean seas, but its crowning inner glory was a light bulb. Suspended in the darkness of my bedroom for most of the nights of my childhood, it served first as a night light unto my world. But night after night and year after year, it showed me the makings of things like nights and years and a permanently marvelous truth: We live on a sphere, turning in the light of a star.

title: Be More Productive. Take Time Off.
description: Editors note: Were resurfacing this story from the archives to show you that you should be taking more time off.

title: Jeter Chips Away at Hits Record as Rose Watches
description: Derek Jeter stood on first base. His single in Seattle had pulled the rookie to 4,255 hits behind baseballs career leader, Pete Rose. The ball was retrieved. He was 20 years old.

title: Tropical Diseases: The New Plague of Poverty
description: Houston

title: An Affront to Love, French-Style
description: PARIS

title: Obamas (Perceived) Transformation
description: EARLIER this month, Ann Coulter took to the airwaves of the Fox News network to denounce the dastardly machinations, large mendacity and mad villainy currently employed by the American president. Barack Obama was a liar, Coulter said, a despicable campaigner who once claimed the banner of hope and change but was now giving the American people the ugliest campaign weve ever had.

title: Punting Less Can Be Rewarding, but Coaches Arent Risking Jobs on It
description: The punt seems to contradict footballs essence, as coaches voluntarily relinquish the ball even though they have at least one more chance to move it forward.

title: As U.N. Monitors Leave Syria, More Bodies Are Found
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The United Nations sent its final group of observers out of Syria on Saturday as the war lumbered on, with activists reporting raids, airstrikes and shelling across the country, in Aleppo, Daraa, Azaz and around Damascus, where opposition groups counted 40 bodies on the streets of a nearby suburb.

title: For Russians, Corruption Is Just a Way of Life
description: CORRUPTION in Russia is so pervasive that the whole society accepts the unacceptable as normal, as the only way of survival, as the way things just are.

title: Midfielder Makes Timely Return to U.S. National Team
description: Was the United States unprecedented victory over Mexico on Wednesday significant or merely a meaningless exhibition played at the cavernous and half-empty Azteca Stadium?

title: Lawyers From Suits Against Big Tobacco Target Food Makers
description: Don Barrett, a Mississippi lawyer, took in hundreds of millions of dollars a decade ago after suing Big Tobacco and winning record settlements from R. J. Reynolds, Philip Morris and other cigarette makers. So did Walter Umphrey, Dewitt M. Lovelace and Stuart and Carol Nelkin.

title: Over the Hump (Status Update)
description: Not actually home yet, but done with the more strenuous bits, and I will be in Mondays paper.

title: Wright May Add Hits to His Record Collection
description: WASHINGTON  It has become something of a ritual this season, the systemic poaching of Mets franchise records by David Wright.

title: Los Angeles Puts a New Park at Its Heart
description: LOS ANGELES  Grand Park, one of the largest new parcels of open space in this sprawling city, is the focus of all sorts of grand visions. Designed for a major concert, a farmers market or a participatory dance recital, it opened late last month with much fanfare, meant to attract office workers, suburbanites from across the region, tourists and the urban dwellers who call downtown home.

title: A Seeming Edge, Until the Winter Classic Nears
description: It appears about 90 percent certain that a lockout will postpone the start of the N.H.L. season, so the next question is how long that postponement will last. In this high-stakes game for hundreds of millions of dollars, who will blink first?

title: Judge This Book by Its Cover
description: A graphic artist redesigns Ayn Rands novel for the election season.

title: Beware a Beautiful Calm
description: WASHINGTON

title: As Woody Turns 100, We Protest Too Little
description: In October the Kennedy Center will throw a centennial party for Woody Guthrie, a star-studded concert with tickets topping out at $175. It will be Americas ultimate tribute to a beloved troubadour. Through his unique music, words and style, the Kennedy Center says, Guthrie was able to bring attention and understanding to the critical issues of his day.

title: Truth and Lies About Medicare
description: Republican attacks on President Obamas plans for Medicare are growing more heated and inaccurate by the day. Both Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan made statements last week implying that the Affordable Care Act would eviscerate Medicare when in fact the law should shore up the programs finances.

title: 2 Jets Quarterbacks and 2 Cheering Sections
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  Midway through a Jets training camp practice last week, cornerback Antonio Cromartie picked off a pass thrown by quarterback Mark Sanchez. Cromartie soon encountered something he would never see in an actual game.

title: Michigans G.O.P. Governor Defies Easy Labels
description: DETROIT  In this political age of ideological purity, Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan is an enigma.

title: Asias Roiling Sea
description: The South China Sea, one of the worlds most important waterways, has been contested off and on for centuries. These days, with the sea bounded by some of Asias most vibrant economies  China, Vietnam, the Philippines, Taiwan and Malaysia  the competition has become a virtual free-for-all. Confrontations over territorial control are alarmingly frequent and could get out of hand, with dangerous consequences.

title: Former Reliever Olson Tells Clubhouse Tales
description: During a rain delay at Yankee Stadium last week, Texas Rangers catcher Mike Napoli sent out an urgent bulletin from the visiting locker room. This might be the funniest thing ever! Napoli wrote on Twitter, going on to say that the Rangers were playing hide and seek in their enormous clubhouse, and that Michael Young always got caught.

title: Teachers on the Defensive
description: Los Angeles

title: In Embassy Drama, Eyes of Police (and Public) Focus on Assange
description: LONDON  Over the decades, London has known other diplomatic sieges that ended dramatically.

title: Youth Golf Thrives, but Not in High School
description: Will Thomson bounded onto the practice tee lugging a double-strapped golf bag. His round of 78 was complete, but Thomson was still brimming with energy. At 11, he was the youngest and smallest junior in the field at the International Junior Golf Tours Bridgestone Golf Tournament of Champions in late May in Orlando, Fla.

title: Jim Hackett on Authentic Leadership
description: This interview with  James P. Hackett, the president and chief executive of Steelcase, the office furniture company based in Grand Rapids, Mich., was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Romney Starts a Weekly Audiocast
description: With a drawn-out Hellooo, Mitt Romney begins his first weekly audio message  attacking President Obamas Medicare plan and defending his own.

title: Goldman, Still Playing in Bayous Mud
description: THE story of the Bayou Group, the hedge fund firm that collapsed in a whirl of lies and drugs, was always a little weird. But it just keeps getting weirder.

title: Yet-to-Be Details of Olympic Golf
description: Nobody teed off in London, but in 2016 in Rio de Janeiro, golf will re-emerge as an Olympic sport.

title: Obama Attacks Republicans Over Teacher Layoffs
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Saturday bashed Congressional Republicans  and by association, the Romney campaign  for failing to prevent teacher layoffs made by cash-strapped state and local governments.

title: A Chance to Make Mortgage Shopping Easier
description: MORTGAGE rates are very low, but some people who could qualify for cheap refinancing are procrastinating. That may be because shopping for a mortgage can make root canal surgery seem fun.

title: The Daily Shoe | Manolo Blahnik
description: Jane Herman delivers The Daily Shoe from the Bergdorf Goodman shoe salon. Todays pick: a blinding ankle boot from Manolo Blahnik.

title: To Obama, Republican Budget Plans Are Snake Oil
description: WINDHAM, N.H.  President Obama took on the budget proposals of Mitt Romney and Representative Paul D. Ryan on Saturday, accusing the Republican ticket of seeking to cut trillions of dollars in taxes for the wealthy while raising taxes for the middle class and making deep cuts to programs that would benefit working Americans.

title: Act Like a Writer
description: I think there is a natural curiosity that many people have when they hear about an actor writing fiction. While its not exactly comparable to proving a mathematical theorem (Danica McKellar, the girl from The Wonder Years, can boast about that feat), it does seem an unusual endeavor to some.

title: Deluded Individualism
description: There is a curious passage early in Freuds Ego and the Id where he remarks that the id behaves as if it were unconscious. The phrase is puzzling, but the meaning is clear: the id is the secret driver of our desires, the desires that animate our conscious life, but the ego does not recognize it as such. The ego  what we take to be our conscious, autonomous self  is ignorant to the agency of the id, and sees itself in the driver seat instead. Freud offers the following metaphor: the ego is like a man on horseback, struggling to contain the powerful beast beneath; to the extent that the ego succeeds in guiding this beast, its only by transforming the ids will into action as if it were its own.

title: What Happened to Him?
description: CHESAPEAKE, Va.  From the playgrounds of Richmond, Va., to the highest levels of international basketball, the exploits of Jonathan Hargett still resonate.

title: Salmonella Outbreak in 20 States Kills 2 and Sickens 141
description: An outbreak of salmonella infections across 20 states has resulted in two deaths and sickened 141 people in recent weeks, state and federal authorities said.

title: Landing in West Virginia, Dakich Checked the Exits
description: Soon after Dan Dakich took the basketball head coaching job at West Virginia in 2002, he sat down with a yellow legal pad and wrote a list of the issues facing the Mountaineers. It became so long and daunting that he decided it was too much. Eight days after he was hired, he walked away from what he said was a seven-year contract offer worth $3.5 million to return to his old job at Bowling Green, which pays $125,000 a year.

title: In This Feast of Perfection, as Always, a Famine Lurks
description: Jim Palmer was preparing for a broadcast at Camden Yards last Wednesday when the scoreboard showed history unfolding in Seattle. Felix Hernandez, the Mariners ace, had reached the ninth inning of a perfect game, and Palmer, the Baltimore Orioles Hall of Fame right-hander, had to watch.

title: Finding Dividends in Unusual Places
description: DIVIDEND seekers are in a bit of a quandary. As frightened investors have raced into defensive equities lately, traditional income-producing areas of the stock market have become fairly frothy.

title: Both Campaigns Seize Role of Medicare Defender
description: THE VILLAGES, Fla.  After several days in which he mentioned only generalities on the campaign trail, Representative Paul D. Ryan sought on Saturday to play offense on Medicare, attacking in detail President Obamas health care plan, seizing an issue that has the potential to be one of Mr. Ryans biggest liabilities in joining the Republican presidential ticket.

title: Saturday on the Campaign Trail
description: Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican vice presidential candidate, defended his plan to overhaul Medicare on Saturday in Florida. while President Obama campaigned in New Hampshire.

title: Taliban Fighters Killed in Airstrike
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A coalition airstrike killed more than 20 Taliban insurgents after they had gathered to oversee a public execution in northeastern Afghanistan on Saturday, Afghan officials said.

title: Remy Charlip, Dancer and Childrens Author, Dies at 83
description: Remy Charlip, a dancer, choreographer and founding member of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company who dazzled avant-garde audiences for decades before finding an even larger audience writing and illustrating childrens books with titles like Dress Up and Lets Have a Party and Fortunately, died on Tuesday in San Francisco. He was 83.

title: Lining Up in Chicago, With Hopes of Gaining Legal Status
description: Young illegal immigrants discuss the impact of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program on their future.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 19
description: With Representative Paul D. Ryan joining the campaign trail this week, both campaigns have emissaries on the Sunday shows to weigh in on how the race is going  and where it will go from here.

title: Passenger Is Shot in Livery Cab
description: A passenger in a livery cab was shot in the head early Saturday when a man held up the driver after the cab stopped at a traffic light in Brooklyn, according to the police.

title: Mixed Signals in Darfur as Attacks Shadow Progress
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  It was a scene that seemed to belong to a different time, say, early 2004, when war was raging across Sudans vast desert region of Darfur. Hundreds of armed men  on horseback, camels, donkeys and in four-by-four trucks  some in street clothes, some in camouflage fatigues, swept into the Kassab displaced persons camp and began looting, burning, raping and shooting.

title: NBCs Tonight Show Cuts Staff, and Jay Leno Takes a Pay Cut
description: The NBC network on Friday instituted budget cuts at The Tonight Show, a television mainstay that has played home to Jack Paar, Johnny Carson and now Jay Leno.

title: Secret E-Scores Chart Consumers Buying Power
description: ST. CLOUD, Minn.

title: A Printer Freezes Up, and the Maker Does, Too
description: IN this episode, the Haggler features more technology that has gone wrong.

title: Thank You for Sharing. But Why at the Office?
description: LATELY Ive been hearing a lot about 20-somethings who are too eager to tell all at work. Whether they are recounting their drunken exploits or their external job searches, their tendency to provide too much information is leaving many managers scratching their heads.

title: U.S. Says Iraqis Are Helping Iran to Skirt Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama announced last month that he was barring a Baghdad bank from any dealings with the American banking system, it was a rare acknowledgment of a delicate problem facing the administration in a country that American troops just left: for months, Iraq has been helping Iran skirt economic sanctions imposed on Tehran because of its nuclear program.

title: Listen Closely
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Easier heard than seen, the big theme in this Sunday puzzle from Freddie Cheng relies on audible puns. By subbing out one phonetic sound for another in a number of common phrases, Mr. Cheng has created a way to cleverly transform a clue like Ultranationalism into an answer that sounds like the title of an Arnold Schwarzenegger Christmas movie. So keep your ears open.

title: Scoring Complaints Grow After Six-Way Tie in Russia
description: A six-way tie after regulation play at the Russian championship, where there were only 10 competitors, has raised the hackles of many chess commentators.

title: The Beating Hearts of Romance Writing
description: Scenes from the Romance Writers of Americas annual conference.

title: The Robot Factory Future
description: A new generation of adaptive vision-equipped robotics is set to change manufacturing around the world. At a lettuce factory in California, robots pack boxes alongside human employees.

title: From an Illness, a Calling
description: MY father practiced law in our hometown, Maplewood, N.J., and my mother took care of our family of six children. I was the fifth child, probably destined to follow my father into the legal profession. But at 13, I found a lump on my neck. At first, the doctors thought it was mumps or maybe a tooth infection, but after a biopsy, Hodgkins disease was diagnosed.

title: In Inelastic South Carolina, Change Is Unlikely
description: Today we continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Todays stop: South Carolina, the Palmetto State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Prof. Robert Oldendick and Associate Prof. Mark Tompkins, both of the political science department at the University of South Carolina.

title: Skilled Work, Without the Worker
description: DRACHTEN, the Netherlands  At the Philips Electronics factory on the coast of China, hundreds of workers use their hands and specialized tools to assemble electric shavers. That is the old way.

title: Von Freeman, Fiery Tenor Saxophonist, Dies at 88
description: Von Freeman, who was considered one of the finest tenor saxophonists in jazz but attained wide fame only late in life, died on Aug. 11 in Chicago. He was 88.

title: Phyllis Thaxter, Actress Who Played Supermans Mother, Dies at 92
description: Phyllis Thaxter, an actress who got her start in Hollywood in a war movie during World War II, overcame polio while pregnant and then carved out a long acting career that led to her final film role, as Supermans mother, died on Tuesday in Longwood, Fla. She was 92.

title: Sabathia Says He Feels Good After Bullpen Session
description: C. C. Sabathia threw about 23 pitches in the bullpen Saturday and afterward had an unequivocal declaration about his next outing.

title: For Romney, a Lucrative Weekend Raising Money
description: With President Obama campaigning in New Hampshire on Saturday and Representative Paul D. Ryan courting voters in Florida, which battleground state did Mitt Romney have on his weekend itinerary?

title: Karl Fleming, Journalist Who Covered Civil Rights Era, Dies at 84
description: Karl Fleming, a former Newsweek reporter who dodged bullets and choked on tear gas while covering some of the most momentous events of the civil rights era, died on Aug. 11 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 84.

title: Milton Bassin Dies at 88; Expanded York College
description: Milton Bassin, who as president of York College in Jamaica, Queens, oversaw the construction of a vast campus on a once-blighted site  steering the project through New Yorks fiscal crisis and, in the process, helping to revitalize Jamaica and educate thousands of disadvantaged students  died on Monday in the Bronx. He was 88 and lived in Somers, N.Y.

title: Saving the Prairie, and Planting Some New Ones
description: HOUSTON  Just south of here, past the oil refineries and wedged between two housing subdivisions, is one of the most endangered ecosystems on the planet  a coastal prairie.

title: Jackson Bend in Accident
description: The multiple Grade I winner Jackson Bend was involved in a mishap Saturday morning on a training track at Saratoga Race Course in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., but he appeared to have sustained no serious injuries.

title: Double Turns the iPad Into a Telepresence Robot
description: In late 2010 I had the opportunity to be a robot for a few weeks with a telepresence robot called the Texai, made by Willow Garage. I zipped around The New York Timess newsroom and attended meetingsfrom completely different locations.

title: Restaurant Manager Is Shot to Death in Queens
description: A gunman walked up behind the manager of a restaurant in Queens on Friday night and shot him fatally in the head, the police said.

title: A Literary Hero, Keeping the Last Bookshop Alive
description: ARCHER CITY  On a recent Friday afternoon, the courthouse square in this tiny North Texas ranching community was packed with sleek Mercedes-Benzes and Lexuses that occupied spots usually left empty or taken by pickups. The drivers of these cars loaded boxes of books into trunks and back seats, and trucks hauling rig equipment slowed and stopped for people rushing across the street.

title: Judge Raises New Questions About Facebook Advertising Tactic
description: A judge rejected Facebooks settlement offer in response to a lawsuit that said the company violated California law by publicizing users likes of certain advertisers without paying them or giving them a way to opt out. Facebooks advertising efforts face a new legal hurdle at a time when the social networking giant needs to increase revenue and convince investors of its long-term prospects.

title: Djokovic, Humming Again, Will Meet Federer for a Title
description: MASON, Ohio  No medal was awarded, but Novak Djokovic earned a different sort of consolation Saturday with a hard-fought, 6-3, 6-2 victory against Juan Martn del Potro in the semifinals of the Western & Southern Open near Cincinnati.

title: In Texas School District Financing, Factors are Hard to Compare
description: Canyon Independent School District did not set out to be one of the thriftiest in the state.

title: Lester Offers Red Sox a Glimpse at Whats Been Missing
description: On July 22, Jon Lester allowed 11 runs in only four innings, hitting the low point in a career-worst season. Later, several Red Sox players were said to be angry with Manager Bobby Valentine for subjecting Lester to such humiliation, but Lester has never publicly complained about it. In fact, his only public reaction has been to put together some of his best starts of the season and show that maybe all is not lost for him and the Red Sox after all.

title: Do Argentines Need Therapy? Pull Up a Couch
description: BUENOS AIRES  The cafe, just north of a leafy district affectionately nicknamed Villa Freud, was almost empty. Roberto lvarez sipped his espresso, furrowed his brow and began ticking off the names of psychologists he had seen over the past decade. He stopped counting only when he noticed that he was running short of fingers.

title: Sneaky Ways to Keep Conflicting Promises
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Lottery Numbers
Afghan Attacks on Allied Troops Prompt NATO to Shift Policy
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  After months of military leaders attempts to tamp down worries over the killings of American and NATO troops by the Afghan forces serving beside them, Gen. John R. Allen, the top commander in Afghanistan, called an urgent meeting of his generals last Wednesday to address the escalating death toll.

title: The Courtship Before Romney Elevated Ryan
description: It was supposed to be a 15-minute courtesy visit from a Republican with big presidential aspirations to a rising star in Congress with big ideas about how to address the nations fiscal problems.

title: Support Grows in Germany for Vote on Giving Up Power to European Bloc
description: BERLIN  It has become the buzzword of the summer in Berlin: referendum. The foreign and finance ministers as well as opposition leaders have all come out in favor of allowing Germans to have a direct say in whether to give up more power to European Union institutions.

title: Pinpointing Problem, Valentine Admits Hes Part of It
description: Bobby Valentine agreed with a lot of Red Sox fans and some of his own players before Saturdays 4-1 victory against the Yankees: he hasnt done a great job. In his first year as Bostons manager, Valentine has been seen by some as a meddler who wanted to force change on a team full of established players.

title: With Stellar Effort by Defense, Giants Expose Jets Flaws
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants title run last season began right here, as visitors in their own stadium, where the Super Bowl murals painted outside their locker room had been purposely obscured by a thin black veil.

title: Mets Win Pitchers Duel With One Swing of Bat
description: WASHINGTON  Throughout the season, the Mets have bemoaned their relative lack of power, identifying it as a key reason they have had such a small margin for error each game.

title: Erica Lowenthal, Nicholas Detorie
description: Erica Beth Lowenthal and Nicholas Michael Detorie were married Saturday evening at City Hall, a restaurant in New York. David Kramer, an uncle of the bride who obtained a certificate of marriage from the Open Ministry for the occasion, officiated.

description: Robin Taylor Juliano and Benjamin Marshall Gruenbaum were married Saturday at the Tidewater Inn in Easton, Md. Michael J. Rosenberg, an uncle of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

Jaya Pethe, an aunt of the bride, who also became a Universal Life minister for this event, will assist.

description: Rebecca Hughes Runyan and David Lawrence Lungren were married Saturday at the Cathedral of the Most Blessed Sacrament in Detroit. Msgr. Michael C. LeFevre, the rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

description: Molly Frances Pulda and Gary Michael Sernovitz were married Saturday evening at the Bowery Hotel in New York. Richard F. Greenberg, a friend of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

Wiest-Laird, an American Baptist minister, officiated at the Wells Reserve at Laudholm, a nature preserve and farm. The Rev. Eugene Bay, a Presbyterian minister, took part in the ceremony.

description: Linda Weiner Rosner and Charles Douglas Bethill are to be married Sunday at the Pleasantdale Chateau, a historic house in West Orange, N.J. Cantor Charles Romalis is to officiate.

description: Kristin Rene Martin and Andrew Jay Fried were married Friday morning by Rabbi Shalom Sharabi at the Beverly Wilshire Hotel in Beverly Hills, Calif.
