description: Dom Mintoff, a fiery postwar socialist leader of Malta who closed NATO bases, evicted British interests, courted China and Libya and even banned The Times of London to chart an independent course for his tiny Mediterranean island nation, died on Monday. He was 96.

title: Free Online Course Will Rely on Multiple Sites
description: A group of online-learning ventures is collaborating on a new kind of free class to be offered this fall, known as a mechanical MOOC (for massive open online course), that will teach a computer-programming language by patching together existing resources from open-learning sites.

title: Cast of Assassins Revival to Reunite for Roundabout Benefit
description: The original Broadway cast of the Stephen Sondheim-John Weidman musical Assassins is reuniting for a one-night-only benefit for the Roundabout Theater Company. Directed by Joe Mantello, the event will take place on Dec. 3 at Studio 54, where the Roundabout production, also directed by Mr. Mantello, opened in 2004.

title: Gene Tests in Yeast Aid Work on Cancer
description: People have been searching for new medicines for thousands of years, and yet we have barely explored the universe of possibilities. Recently chemists at the University of Bern in Switzerland tried to estimate how many promising molecules have yet to be tested. In June they published their best guess: over a million billion billion billion billion billion billion. Blindly testing those molecules one at a time is not practical, and most of them will turn out to be useless anyway. So many scientists are looking for strategies they can use to zero in more quickly on promising candidates.

title: Corrections: August 21, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Daily Report: Facebook Needs a Story
description: Inside Facebooks headquarters, a red-and-white poster affixed to a wall asks bluntly: What Could Go Wrong? Somini Sengupta, of The New York Times, reports that below, in black ink, someone has scrawled in tiny letters: Everything.

title: An Irishman Gives Back in Brooklyn
description: Rory McIlroy hunched over the putt Monday, his eyes determined and fixed on the hole in the middle of the putting green.

title: Paul Supporters to Rally in Tampa
description: While political conventions these days have a reputation for being overly scripted, next weeks Republican gathering in Tampa, Fla., could have one unpredictable element: a legion of Ron Paul supporters turning out, some of whom will be on the convention floor.

title: A Look Inside Chinas Club Fed
description: HONG KONG  A Chinese court has suspended Gu Kailais death sentence for the cyanide murder of a British businessman. But Ms. Gu, the wife of the disgraced Communist Party boss Bo Xilai, is headed for a long stretch in the can, the clink, the hoosegow, the pen, the joint, the slammer, the Big House.

title: Nice Line for Jeter, but Yankees Waste It
description: CHICAGO  It was a game of bloated numbers in which a dozen pitchers surrendered 25 hits and 12 walks, while 3 hours and 44 minutes passed between the first pitch to the last. But by the end, the most important number was the one that is shrinking before the Yankees eyes.

title: Judge Dismisses Whistle-Blower Suit Against Infosys
description: A federal judge in Alabama on Monday dismissed a lawsuit by an American employee of Infosys, the Indian outsourcing company, who claimed he was harassed and sidelined after he reported what he believed was visa fraud by managers there, Julia Preston wrote in The New York Times.

title: The Imaginary Line that Divides India and Bangladesh
description: Borders are significant barriers only in the minds of those who have never walked across one. Anyone who does that learns that in most places there is no crack in the earth where one country ends and another begins.

title: Prime Time for Paul Ryans Guru (the One Whos Not Ayn Rand)
description: As Paul Ryan and Mitt Romney take the stage in Tampa next week, the ghost of an Austrian economist will be hovering above them with an uneasy smile on his face. Ryan has repeatedly suggested that many of his economic ideas were inspired by the work of Friedrich von Hayek, an awkwardly shy (and largely ignored) economist and philosopher who died in 1992. A few years ago, it was probably possible to fit every living Hayekian in a conference room. Regardless of what happens in November, that will no longer be the case.

title: Shaping Foreign Policy
description: While pundits agree that this presidential election will likely turn on economic issues, the candidates have been busy demonstrating that they are capable in foreign policy.

title: In Bangalore, Classrooms Turn Into Makeshift Homes
description: A classroom on the third floor of the humanities block of St. Josephs College in Bangalore now serves as a makeshift dormitory. Mattresses have been rolled out atop benches laid side by side and on the professors wooden podium, surrounded by duffel bags packed for an indefinite stay. Since Thursday, five girls from Indias northeastern states have made this space their home.

title: Rocket Fire Damages Plane Used by Joint Chiefs Chairman
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Insurgents hiding outside the heavily fortified Bagram Air Base fired a pair of rockets early Tuesday that damaged the parked C-17 transport plane used by Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, American and Afghan officials said.

title: Exploring Mitt Romneys Taxes and Tax Plan
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: The Woodward Dream Cruise Rediscovers Its Strut
description: ROYAL OAK, Mich.  As the 18th annual Woodward Dream Cruise got under way on Saturday morning, I drove south on Woodward Avenue accompanied by my wife, Marlene, and son, Erik, in our 1955 Chevrolet Bel Air. Our immediate goal was a breakfast of sliders at the venerable Hunter House in Birmingham, a nutritionally suspect Dream Cruise tradition for the Stenquist clan.

title: Fantasy Focus: Keeper Possibilities
description: Im far from alone in playing in multiple fantasy leagues. I like all formats: A.L./N.L.-only, keeper, redraft, mixed, head-to-head, roto, Scoresheet and Strat-O-Matic. Ive succeeded in most formats, and failed in the same, with this year being no different. In at least two of my keeper leagues, Im already looking toward 2013, speculating on potential closers and looking to acquire guys that could be undervalued in next years drafts. Heres a look at a handful (with statistics through Sundays games unless noted):

title: The Early Word: Uproar
description: In Todays Times

title: Meles Zenawi, Prime Minister of Ethiopia, Dies at 57
description: Meles Zenawi, Ethiopias repressive prime minister, who lifted his country from the ruins of civil war and transformed it into one of Africas fastest-growing economies and one of the United States governments closest African allies, died on Monday, state television reported. He was 57.

title: Concerns About Al Qaeda in Syria Underscore Questions About Rebels
description: What is Al Qaeda doing in Syria?

title: Steve Gleasons Story
description: A game is just a game, but every once in a while, it transcends that.

title: Tampa Bay Bucs, 2012 Season Preview
description: Andy Benoit, who is previewing all 32 teams, turns his attention to the N.F.C. South this week, starting with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: Its Not Too Soon to Think About Crowdfunding
description: I have taken a real interest in equity crowdfunding and its potential impact on social entrepreneurs. One reason: I would have loved to have been able to take advantage of it when I was doing my initial financing of TerraCycle. Had crowdfunding existed then, I would have been able to raise money faster, on better terms, and from a wider range of investors  all good things when it comes to financing a small business.

title: Globalization and the Income Slowdown
description: Derek Thompson of The Atlantic offers a thoughtful response to our list of 14 potential causes of the great American income slowdown:

title: Q&A: Saving Laptop Battery Power
description: Q.

title: Focus of Presidential Campaign Shifts Away From Economy
description: Actually, its not the economy. At least not this week.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: A Conversation With: Chef Vikas Khanna
description: With temperatures high and the air sticky in most of the United States and India right now, the thought of eating a rich Indian meal has little appeal. But the Michelin-starred chef Vikas Khanna says that it is possible to enjoy the flavorful food India is known for without feeling weighed down.

title: Glencore Holds Firm on Price for Xstrata
description: LONDON  Ivan Glasenberg, chief executive of the commodities trading company Glencore International, on Tuesday played down speculation that the company would pay a higher price for its proposed $30 billion takeover of the mining company Xstrata.

title: Opinion Report: Todd Akin Republicans
description: From the editorial page

title: Indian and Western Colleges Set Up Joint Study Programs
description: As colleges and universities worldwide wait for Indias lawmakers to approve a bill granting full access to the countrys vast education market, Vir Singh wrote in The International Herald Tribune, some institutions are reaching Indian students through twinning programs.

title: Europes Cities: Gentrification or Ghettoization?
description: LONDON  The widening gap between haves and have-nots in debt-saddled Europe has sharpened a debate over whether the accelerating gentrification of its major cities is leading to the ghettoization of their urban poor.

title: Tuesday Reading: Baby Boomers Urged to Get Hepatitis C Test
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Cardiologist Issues Alert on St. Jude Heart Device
description: A cardiologist who studies the safety of heart devices said surgeons should stop using a component sold by St. Jude Medical until more is known about the long-term safety of the device.

title: A Set of Headphones Clever, Cool and Costly
description: Bowers & Wilkins, known for high design and high fidelity, has introduced lightweight folding headphones with a strikingly functional look.

title: Best Buys Tough Earnings May Lift Schulzes Hopes a Little
description: Best Buy may have a tough time fending off a takeover.

title: Beware of Flying Fruit
description: Dear Diary:

title: What Were Reading
description: Grist: The drought has a hashtag: farmers are using Twitter to talk to consumers, and each other, about the weather and their woes. #drought12  Emily Weinstein

title: New Label Alert | Confezioni Crosby
description: All week, T is introducing the lines to look out for this fall.

title: Head of ABCs This Week Is Leaving to Join PepsiCo
description: 9:57 a.m. | Updated ABC News will cover this presidential campaign without one of its veteran journalists. Jon Banner, executive producer of George Stephanopouloss Sunday morning public affairs show This Week, will leave ABC News for a job at PepsiCo.

title: Indian Dance via Bollywood, by Way of Russia, Near Wall Street
description: The weeklong Downtown Dance Festival closed Friday in downtown New York with its annual Erasing Borders program of Indian dance, Alastair Macaulay wrote in The New York Times. Despite the Indo-American label, the organizers included countries other than India and the United States, he wrote.

title: Obama and Romney Discuss Role of Faith in Their Lives
description: Religion is enough of a political minefield that President Obama and Mitt Romney have declined interviews with reporters about their faith. But they agreed to write answers to nine questions about their personal faith and the role of faith in public life posed to them by Cathedral Age, the magazine of the Washington National Cathedral.

title: Akin Asks for Forgiveness in New Ad
description: As part of his effort to keep his place on the November ballot, Representative Todd Akin, Republican of Missouri, released an ad Tuesday in which he asks for viewers forgiveness for his comments on Sunday about rape.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Akins Evolving Media Strategy, and Student Autonomy
description: In trying to calm the anger swirling over his comments about legitimate rape and whether rape can lead to pregnancy, Representative Todd Akin, the Republican candidate for Senate from Missouri, scheduled a prime-time appearance on CNN on Monday, but ultimately didnt show up. The host who was stood up by Mr. Akin, Piers Morgan, made the most of the nonappearance, Brian Stelter writes, telling the audience: Youre looking live at the empty chair that Todd Akin was supposed to be sitting in for a live, prime-time exclusive interview. The camera was fixed on the empty chair during the show, which appeared in an inset box.

title: Former White House Cybersecurity Official Joins Start-Up
description: In January, Sameer Bhalotra left his position as President Obamas senior director for cybersecurity without discussing his next move.

title: Barnes & Noble Narrows Its Losses as Fifty Shades of Grey Lifts Sales
description: 7:5o p.m. | Updated Add another happy beneficiary of the publishing powerhouse Fifty Shades of Grey: Barnes & Noble.

title: Comedian Rob Delaney Will Release Online Standup Special
description: Rob Delaney may not yet have the name recognition of comedians like Louis C. K., Aziz Ansari or Jim Gaffigan. But with the help of his large and loyal Internet following, he is hoping he can take a page from his accomplished industry colleagues, and start creating material for and selling it directly online.

title: Officials Lawsuit Claims Discrimination Against Men at U.S. Immigration Agency
description: A discrimination and retaliation lawsuit has embroiled the upper reaches of the federal governments immigration enforcement agency, contributing to a sense of turmoil in a bureaucracy that has been suffering major labor conflicts between senior officials and employees.

title: Obama to Focus on Education in Campaign Swing Through Ohio and Nevada
description: President Obama set off Tuesday on a two-day campaign swing through Ohio and Nevada, with plans to continue etching sharp differences with his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney  this time on education policy.

title: Fantasy Football: Wide Receiver Primer
description: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy.

title: Business Day Live | August 21, 2012
description: Whether Facebook has lost credibility with Wall Street. | The remarkable transformation of Apple.

title: Business Day Live: The Facebook Frown
description: Whether Facebook has lost credibility with Wall Street. | The remarkable transformation of Apple.

title: Image of the Day: August 21
A Chance to Walk, or Talk, With the Animals
description: Havent you always wanted to brush a goat? You can do it, maybe, this fall at the Central Park Zoo. The zoo announced Tuesday that registration is open for its fall and winter educational programming, which includes classes, internships and the like for children as young as 2, as well as teenagers and adults. More info is available on the zoos Web site.

title: Three Ways to Figure Out What Stuff You Should Keep
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

title: At a Book Party, Witches and a Wiccan Prayer Circle
description: A book party Sunday night in Manhattan attracted so many witches in New York City that as one attendee, Rhea Rivera, put it, I felt like all the brooms were just suddenly descending.

title: Price Wars Seen Hurting Solar Sector in China
description: GUANGZHOU, China  Chinas solar panel manufacturers, who dominate global sales with a two-thirds market share, are confronting growing trade and financial problems, a Chinese industry official acknowledged Tuesday, shortly before one of the industrys largest companies, Trina Solar, announced weak results for the second quarter.

title: Site to Be Seen | Hello La Mode
description: Start-ups, by nature, are something of a gamble. But the French entrepreneurs Eric Gagnaire, Thierry Sebba and Mathieu Bidart based their business model on eliminating one big risk. Customers of their new luxury e-commerce marketplace, Hello La Mode, wont have to worry about clicking to buy that Chanel bag or Herms tie because these items, and all that sell on the site, will have to pass a rigorous check for authenticity and quality by the sites team of fashion experts.

title: Bicycle Lanes Draw Wide Support Among New Yorkers, Survey Finds
description: Bicycle lanes may be little more than painted stripes on concrete, but in New York City, they have become the stuff of lawsuits, neighborhood squabbles and tense debates over the proper role of government.

title: Business Day Live: Facebook and Apple
description: The Timess daily business show looks at whether Facebook has lost credibility with Wall Street and the remarkable transformation of Apple. The video is available at nytimes.com/bits.

title: The Winning Record of Prosecutors on Insider Trading
description: The conviction of the hedge fund manager Douglas F. Whitman brings the record of the United States attorneys office for the Southern District of New York to 8-0 in insider trading cases that have gone to trial since the wide-ranging investigation came to light in October 2009. By any measure, that is quite an accomplishment, as prosecutors, led by Preet Bharara, have squared off against some very talented white-collar defense lawyers.

title: For This Man-Child, the Thrill of the Chase Has Yet to Grow Old
description: Dax Shepard, the writer, co-director and star of the silly, occasionally amusing car chase comedy Hit & Run, isnt the first actor to be defined by a signature television role. Like James Gandolfinis Tony Soprano, Crosby Braverman, the California man-child Mr. Shepard plays on Parenthood, (53 episodes and counting), is so indelible that, like it or not, everything else Mr. Shepard does registers as a pallid reflection.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times poll is based on telephone interviews with 1,026 adult residents from throughout New York City conducted Aug. 10 to 15. The interviews were in English or Spanish.

title: Fleishman Hillard and GMR Marketing Acquire Content Company
description: 1:54 p.m. | Updated Fleishman Hillard, a public relations company, and GMR Marketing announced on Tuesday that they have acquired Amos Content Group to create a new joint venture called Freshwire.

title: Bettman, Fehr and the Idea of an Industry Growth Fund
description: The N.H.L. Players Associations enhanced revenue-sharing plan may wind up going nowhere with Commissioner Gary Bettman and the owners  or perhaps enough owners of struggling teams, seeing a lifeline that the leagues current revenue-sharing scheme does not provide, will demand that parts of the players plan be accepted.

title: Politics Be Dammed
description: DELHI  Last week an unlikely new tourist destination opened in Gujarat, western India. Since Narendra Modi, the states chief minister, proclaimed in a blog post, Fantastic visual treat awaits you as Narmada Dam overflows! nearly 150,000 people have gathered to watch the accumulated water flow over the partially completed Sardar Sarovar Dam on the Narmada River.

title: Rolling Out a Smaller Barrel Sooner
description: THE indispensable ingredient in great whiskey is time: years of aging and mellowing in casks. But in the world of craft whiskey, a growing number of distillers are unwilling to wait that long.

title: Leading Off: Augusta National Inches Forward
description: There were few emphatic high-fives. Not all that many huzzahs. The reaction to Condoleezza Rice and Darla Moore becoming the first female members of Augusta National Golf Club, the host of the Masters, was more along the lines of: Eh, thats nice. Is Ryan Tannehill really starting the season opener for the Dolphins? It was not exactly Nobel Prize territory.

title: Antenna Company Raises $12 Million From Bill Gates and Lux Capital
description: Intellectual Ventures may be best known for its huge archive of patents and its willingness to pursue lawsuits in defense of those patents, but its also a part-time incubator to promising start-ups.

title: American to the Rind
description: Theyve been doing back flips at Beechers, the Seattle-based cheese company that has a shop, restaurant and cheesemaking room in New York: one of their entries won the gold at the annual meeting of the American Cheese Society earlier this month. Flagsheep, an aged mix of sheeps and cows milk that comes from Seattle in tall 16-pound clothbound cylinders, beat out 1,710 other cheeses at the event in Raleigh, N.C. It has a richly grassy aroma and flavor, and a firm texture that suggests Cheddar. And what has the folks at Beechers especially proud is that it was made with pasteurized milks. (Pasteurization kills some beneficial bacteria that could enhance aging and the quality of the cheese.) Its a testament to the cheesemaking that a pasteurized cheese could win, said Elena Santogade, the companys lead cheesemonger.

title: Romance With Chinese Characteristics
description: BEIJING  Dating is hard at the best of times. In China the stakes are high from the outset: the expectation is that it should lead to marriage; never mind love for loves sake.

title: More Dessert for Park Slope
description: Du Jour, a new Brooklyn bakery, offers a collection of well-made cookies, muffins, scones, cupcakes, cakes, brioches, croissants and desserts like butterscotch pudding. The simple but inviting brick-walled space is a largely do-it-yourself project by T. J. Obias; his wife, Vera Tong Obias; and their partner, Tae Kyung, who did most of the design and construction. The couple (shown) are both pastry chefs who have worked in a number of New York restaurants, including Dovetail, Morimoto, Caf Gray and Buddakan. But we never worked together, Mr. Obias said.

title: A Journey Home, in Search of Himself
description: A decade or so ago, when I was more physically fit, an editor at Outside magazine called to ask if Id be interested in a job. I hemmed and hawed, as the phrase goes, before saying no thanks. If only, I said, you were called Inside magazine.

title: Sicilian Almonds With a Hint of Noir
description: Fat, buttery Marcona almonds have become the stars of the nibble bowl. But serious cooks, and those with sophisticated taste buds that welcome bitterness, might consider distinctive almonds from Sicily. These are dry in texture, not oily, slightly wrinkled and dense with assertive flavor, the go-to nut when you want to leave no doubt that there are almonds in that cake or those cookies. The finest, from a company called Caff Sicilia, come from the area around Noto, a Baroque hill town in the islands southeastern corner. The almonds are protected by Slow Food. Avola, just north of Noto, is also known for its pointy bittersweet almonds. They are often coated with sugar, for the classic Jordan almonds, known as drages in France and favored in Europe for weddings and christenings.

title: Grammy Nominations Special Moves to Nashville
description: The televised concert to announce nominees for the Grammy Awards will be held in Nashville this year, in a nod to the power of country music within the music industry, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced on Tuesday.

title: Drop the Pasta, Dad, and No One Gets Hurt
description: THEY sit there, five little pasta shells, nestled in a shallow bath of melted butter and Parmesan: the remains of dinner for my toddler son and daughter. I cannot help myself. I reach over, grab the pink plastic bowl and scoop a bite into my mouth. At that moment, I realize something has gone terribly wrong.

title: New York Film Festival Adds Paperboy to Schedule
description: The New York Film Festival has added The Paperboy, a new film directed by Lee Daniels, to its coming roster, and with it a gala tribute to its star Nicole Kidman, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Tuesday.

title: My Coffee, My Clutter
description: Carl Richards recent column on throwing away unnecessary stuff got me thinking of what items I could get rid of to declutter my house. I got an easy answer while searching through a kitchen drawer for some dog biscuits  and finding instead a bag overflowing with empty Starbucks coffee sacks.

title: How Has Your Childs Diet Changed Your Own?
description: Matt Richtel writes this week about how fatherhood has led to his dietary woes. He gathers tips from bloggers and nutrition experts about the best ways to keep healthy while making meals that include the occasional hot dog or bowl of buttered pasta  foods that are not cholesterol-friendly, but are beloved by children.

title: Andy Milices Second Chance
description: By the summer of 1862, the Union Army was wearing thin, worn down by death, disease and the need to occupy extensive tracts of rebel territory. To make things worse, the Armys one-year enlistments were about to expire, sending thousands of men home.

title: Stenciled Relief for Forward Operating Base Monotony
description: While cruising a main drag in southern Afghanistan one night in late May, I spied a silhouetted Eazy-E eyeballing me from one of the Jersey barriers lining the sidewalk. I tried not to stare at his ball cap, shades, and twin-crossed pistols. About 20 feet later, there he was peering from another wall, and again 20 feet after that. He was everywhere.

title: G.O.P. Approves Strict Anti-abortion Language in Party Platform
description: 5:35 p.m. | Updated Even as the Republican establishment continued to call for Representative Todd Akin of Missouri to drop out of his Senate race because of his comments on rape and abortion, Republicans approved platform language on Tuesday calling for a constitutional amendment outlawing abortion with no explicit exceptions for cases of rape or incest.

title: S.E.C. Pays Out First Whistle-Blower Reward
description: Federal securities regulators said on Tuesday that they had handed out the first reward under a new whistle-blower program, paying nearly $50,000 to a person who helped the agency shut down an investment fraud.

title: Wheelies: The Smoke on the Water Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Iran Unveils More Defense Projects
description: TEHRAN  Irans president unveiled an upgraded short-range missile and several new defense projects on Tuesday, saying the Islamic Republic needed new weapons and navigation systems in order to defend itself against foreign threats.

title: Jay Leno Snipes at Comcast Over Tonight Show Cutbacks
description: On Friday, the NBC network, part of Comcast, imposed budget cuts at The Tonight Show, which included layoffs of between 20 and 25 staff members. The host, Jay Leno, took a pay cut, according to a person with direct knowledge of the cuts, in order to limit the number of layoffs. On Monday, Mr. Leno joined the long line of late-night hosts who use the monologue to take aim at the boss: As you may have heard, our parent company has downsized The Tonight Show. And weve consistently been No. 1 in the ratings. And if you know anything about our network, that kind of thing is frowned upon.

title: Ignoring Deadline to Quit, G.O.P. Senate Candidate Defies His Party Leaders
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Todd Akin on Tuesday ignored a deadline to abandon Missouris Senate race and vowed to remain the Republican nominee in defiance of his partys leaders, including the presidential standard-bearer, Mitt Romney.

title: ABC Sees a Contender in Jimmy Kimmel
description: In 2002, ABC pulled out every stop to lure David Letterman away from CBS, offering him the time period occupied by its news program Nightline. The network failed, and soon after inserted a new late-night host, Jimmy Kimmel, in the hour after Nightline.

title: Restoring Trust in the Futures Market
description: James E. Oliff is a member of the board of FFastFill and of the CME Group, where he previously served as vice chairman. Neal L. Wolkoff was formerly the chairman and chief executive of the American Stock Exchange, chief operating officer of the New York Mercantile Exchange and chief executive of ELX Futures.

title: The G.O.P. Platform
description: Every four years the two parties draft new platforms ahead of their presidential nominating conventions. These dont necessarily indicate immediate legislative priorities, but they do indicate general direction. Since the 1980s, the Republican platform has been a test of how far the mainstream of the party is willing to move toward the right-wing fringe. Judging from the draft circulating this week, the answer is, pretty much all the way over.

title: The Field Hockey Chronicles: Memories and Motivation
description: Michelle Kasold, a striker, has been a member of the United States field hockey team since 2006, and competed in her first Olympics in London. She has written regularly for the 2012 London Olympics blog. This is her fourth post.

title: As Fighting Rages, Syria and Russia Reject U.S. Intervention Threat
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Army shellings and shootings raged in at least three insurgency hot spots across Syria on Tuesday, including what antigovernment activists described as the deadly bombardment of mourners in a Damascus suburb during funerals for victims of a newly discovered massacre.

title: In Missouris Move to the Right, a Question of How Far
description: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Here, a look at Missouri, the Show Me State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with David Robertson, a professor in the political science department at the University of Missouri-St.Louis, and Brian R. Calfano, an associate professor of political science at Missouri State University.

title: Knocking Kids Socks Off | Hansel From Basel
description: The best thing about making accessories for children: Not worrying about how the customer will integrate the pieces into her wardrobe, says Hannah Byun, the Los Angeles-based designer of the stockings and sock line Hansel From Basel. Theres nothing holding you back. Its a free-for-all. Its true. A little girl could get away with mixing Byuns mustache-print tights, or socks that resemble strawberries with leaves around the ankles  styles from her first collection for children, available this fall  with anything she owns and look cute, not cuckoo.

title: A Resort Developers Himalayan Quest
description: The story of an Americans dream to build a luxury Himalayan ski resort shows the particular difficulties faced by foreign companies who want to do business in India.

title: American Thwarted in Quest to Build a Ski Resort in India
description: MANALI, India  To John Sims, the Himalayas, with some of the finest mountain slopes in the world, seemed like the perfect place to build Indias first Western-style ski resort.

title: Suzuki Recalls 102,000 Forenzas and Renos for Potential Headlight Failure
description: Suzuki is recalling almost 102,000 of its 2004-6 Forenza and 2005-6 Reno models because the headlights might fail. It is the second recall of those vehicles in the last five years for headlight problems.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: TimesCast Politics | August 21, 2012
description: A deadline for the Senate candidate Todd Akin in Missouri. | Convention preparations. | Mormonism and the campaign. | A lighter look at life on the campaign trail.

title: Accord Sought in Germany Over Circumcision Issue
description: BERLIN  German officials have been meeting here with Israels chief Ashkenazi rabbi over the past two days as they seek a way to enshrine some sort of legal protection for Jews and Muslims who circumcise infant boys as a religious rite, officials said Tuesday.

title: Jimmy Kimmels Gain Is Felt as a Loss at Nightline
description: With Jimmy Kimmel moving to 11:35 p.m. in January, the famed ABC News program Nightline will be moving back a full hour to 12:35 a.m. It is a deeply disappointing outcome for many at the news division, which had fought hard to keep the pre-midnight time slot.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Benefits

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Arguing With Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: TimesCast Politics: All Eyes on Missouri
description: The Associated Press

title: For Growth, Better Coordination Is Needed on Bank Regulation
description: Mohamed El-Erian is the chief executive of Pimco.

title: Storm Heads Toward Florida as Convention Nears
description: After struggling to handle two political storms this week, Republicans may face a real one at their convention in Tampa, Fla., next week as hurricane season arrives.

title: Blast on 2nd Ave. Subway Project Shatters Windows Above Ground
description: Updated, 9:15 p.m. | An intentional underground explosion on the Second Avenue subway project at 72nd Street propelled a thick column of debris and smoke into the air and shattered windows above ground on Tuesday.

title: Early Antibiotic Use Linked to Childhood Obesity
description: Before you accept antibiotics for your infant, you may want to consider the results of a study published in the International Journal of Obesity showing a correlation between antibiotic exposure before 6 months and an increased body mass later in childhood, between 10 months and 3 years of age.

title: Simplicity Is the Mother of Confection
description: MOST summer stone fruit  peaches, plums, nectarines, apricots  are candidates for a pretty tart. Fresh figs qualify, too. I cut the fruit into quarters or eighths, depending on their size, then crowd the wedges so that they stand at attention in tight concentric circles on a pastry shell. I dust the fruit with sugar and, as a typical recipe demands, I would dot the top with butter.

title: Hawks Are Hardly Sunk Without Johnson
description: Joe Johnson is no longer an Atlanta Hawk.

title: The Office to Pack Up Its Files in 2013
description: Its time to take a last nostalgic look at Jim, Pam and Dwight and their quotidian struggles and successes at the Scranton branch of the Dunder Mifflin paper company as theyve been documented on The Office. When that NBC comedy begins its ninth season on Sept. 20, it will be the final one of the series, Greg Daniels, an executive producer, said on Tuesday.

title: Saving Indias Tigers
description: Indias Supreme Court issued a ban on tourism inside the countrys game parks on June 24, and the government has been relocating hundreds of villagers to save the endangered wild tigers.

title: Israel Asks Egypt to Remove Tanks From Sinai
description: JERUSALEM  Israel is troubled by the entry of Egyptian tanks into the northern Sinai Peninsula without coordination with Israel, a violation of the terms of the 33-year-old peace treaty between the two countries, and has asked Egypt to withdraw them, an Israeli government official said Tuesday.

title: Obama Attacks Romneys Proposals for College Financing
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  President Obama, adding another verse to his litany of differences with Mitt Romney, promoted his record on education here Tuesday and assailed his Republican challenger for advising financially strapped young people who want to go to college to shop around and borrow more money from your parents.

title: Anti-Putin Hackers Seize Moscow Courts Web Site, Posting Calls to Free Pussy Riot
description: MOSCOW  Hackers briefly seized control Monday of the Web site of the Moscow district court that sentenced three members of the feminist protest band Pussy Riot to two years in a penal colony last week.

title: Rationing Health Care More Fairly
description: Older adults are understandably anxious about the political sniping over the future financing of Medicare. That is precisely the intention of the presidential campaigns.

title: 2,003 Deaths in Afghanistan
description: Chart showing deaths of identified United States service members directly involved in the war in Afghanistan.

title: Face Time | Kay Panabaker
description: I met the Los Angeles-based actress Kay Panabaker on a quick visit to New York. We chatted about a lot of things, including her coming film, Little Birds, which opens Aug. 29 and also stars Juno Temple, Kate Bosworth and Leslie Mann. Panabakers character, Alison, is solid and levelheaded, much like the actress herself. Mature beyond her 22 years, this young lady knows who she is, what she stands for and which beauty products she cant live without!

title: Kinds Of Wrong
description: Looking at the comments on my Niall Ferguson takedown (see Ezra Klein, Matthew OBrien, James Fallows, and Noah Smith for more), I found my memory jogged about a point Ive been meaning to make about the nature of error in economics.

title: Starter: Pork Slope
description: Introducing Starter, an occasional column that takes a look at restaurants as they are opening.

title: In Toll of 2,000, New Portrait of Afghan War
description: His war was almost over. Or so Marina Buckley thought when her son Lance Cpl. Gregory T. Buckley Jr. told her that he would be returning from southern Afghanistan to his Marine Corps base in Hawaii in late August, three months early.

title: Romneys Attack on Clean Energy: True, With an Asterisk
description: 4:41 p.m. | Updated This week, Mitt Romney echoed an accusation made by various conservative bloggers against President Obama  that his administration has spent $90 billion on green energy.

title: You Plan, Ill Cook: Leaving the Menu to Others
description: AFTER her first daughter was born, Lindsey Swank Meili realized that something had to give, and that something was cooking dinner. Several nights a week, she ordered Chinese food or pizza. When she did cook, it was the same old stuff: meatloaf, chicken and lots of pasta.

title: Winding Down the Elephant Season
description: Caitlin OConnell-Rodwell, who teaches at the Stanford University School of Medicine, writes from Etosha National Park in Namibia, where she is studying elephant societies.

title: A South African Miss Julie Captivates Edinburgh Festival
description: EDINBURGH  With 2,695 events in 279 locations to choose from, the process of deciding what to see here at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe can be a logistical nightmare. I dont want to miss anything really fantastic, you think. Then: Can I possibly make it from Assembly on the Mount to Underbelly in Bristo Square in 15 minutes? (Doubtful.) Planning anxiety kicks in.

title: On the Radar: Arctic Sea Ice Melt
description: Next week, Arctic sea ice may melt to its smallest size since data collection began in 1979, according to the lead scientist at the National Snow and Ice Data Center. The summer of 2007 holds the record for sea ice melt, when the minimum area of the Arctic sea ice recorded was 39 percent smaller than the average minimum from 1979 to 2000. [Reuters]

title: With X-1, McLaren Plays Custom Coachbuilder
description: The term special operations conjures images of furtive, masked figures in black, emerging like ninjas from stealthy vehicles to infiltrate a target. Those evocations are amply reflected by a one-of-a-kind supercar, the McLaren X-1, the first full product from the British marques Special Operations program.

title: Court Blocks E.P.A. Rule on Cross-State Pollution
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Tuesday overturned a federal rule that laid out how much air pollution states would have to clean up to avoid incurring violations in downwind states.

title: Syria Seen as Trying to Roil Lebanon
description: RAMA, Lebanon  As Syrias civil war drags on, the recent arrest of a former Lebanese government minister allied with the Syrian leadership on charges that he planned a campaign of bombings and assassinations has led many in Lebanon to conclude that President Bashar al-Assad is trying to push this fragile country into a sectarian war.

title: Calculating the Human Cost of the War in Afghanistan
description: Figuring out how many United States military personnel have died in the war in Afghanistan is not simple.

title: Before Finding Fame, Countless Phone Calls, and One Audition
description: In the 1960s, Phyllis Dillers New York was the New York of the performer on the way up. It was the New York of late-night comedy clubs, of grungy audition rooms, of Broadway Danny Rose types who claimed to have show-business connections  and were not afraid to pester producers for an audition.

title: La Vara
description: Inside the new restaurant that offers up Spanish-style tapas in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn.

title: Sick on the Road? Try the Grocery Store
description: ADVENTUROUS travelers are often in a quandary: how do they pack lightly and still be prepared for the unexpected?

title: A Valuable View of Trends in New U.S. Electric Power Sources
description: This is a valuable long-view chart from the Energy Information Administration showing how natural gas plants and wind turbines have been the dominant sources of new electricity generation capacity in the United States in recent years. Click here for more background from the Energy Department. Theres plenty of additional discussion of the gas age on Dot Earth. I found this via a Climate Progress post focused on new capacity built in the first half of this year.

title: With Abortion in the Spotlight, a Challenge for Romney
description: 4:07 p.m. | Updated HOUSTON  The decision by Republican convention delegates to oppose abortion without explicit exceptions for rape and incest poses a tricky political challenge for Mitt Romney as he prepares to accept the presidential nomination in Tampa, Fla., next week.

title: 1,200-Bed Halfway House in Newark Is Operating Illegally, Suit Says
description: New Jerseys largest private halfway house has operated for over a decade without legal authority and should be shut down, a union representing corrections officers claims in a lawsuit.

title: Surveillance, Civil Liberties and Inefficiency
description: After the Associated Press disclosed the N.Y.P.D.s Muslim surveillance program, the Times board editorialized against it from a civil liberties perspective. It seemed the police were spying on Muslimssending plainclothes officers to monitor Muslims at mosques, on college campuses, taking photographs of Muslim-owned businesses, listening to conversationswith no reason to think anything wrong was going on. The board acknowledged that under a federal court decree, it is permissible to collect information from public sources but argued that going to public places apparently selected on the basis of religion was another matter.

title: UBS Hires Grafstein as Co-Head of M.&A. in the Americas
description: UBS has hired Laurence Grafstein, a veteran deal maker, as a co-head of mergers and acquisitions in the Americas, the Swiss bank announced Tuesday in an internal memorandum reviewed by DealBook.

title: Prosecutors File Arguments in Effort to Return Cambodian Statue
description: Federal prosecutors seeking to repatriate a 10th century statue to Cambodia filed court papers Monday accusing Sothebys of knowing the sculpture was an important piece of cultural property that had been stolen from a remote temple complex when the auction house put the massive sandstone artifact up for sale in March 2011.

title: New York Fringe Festival Report: American Midget
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festivals close on Aug. 26. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

title: As Ryan Campaigns, the Abortion Issue Intrudes
description: CARNEGIE, Pa.  While the furor continued over Representative Todd Akins remarks about rape, Paul D. Ryan did not mention his House colleague as he campaigned for the Republican presidential ticket here on Tuesday.

title: In Sweden, My Dreams Will Find Me
description: We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence, then, is not an act, but a habit.  Aristotle

title: New Ads Attack the Koch Brothers
description: As patrons of conservative groups, the billionaire Koch brothers have bankrolled plenty of negative ads, but now they are a direct target of one.

title: Branching Out From Night Life
description: ON a humid Wednesday in June, an eclectic cross-section of the citys cool kids descended upon a former Catholic school in NoLIta for a new shopping Web site.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Cell Towers vs. Police, and the History of @
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: The New York Timess Public Opinion Poll
description: A new poll asked New Yorkers about the mayors performance, bike lanes, the soda ban and other questions about quality of life in the city.

title: Gary M. Rosenberg
description: Mr. Rosenberg, 62, is the founding partner of Rosenberg & Estis, a law firm based in New York that represents real estate developers. The firm has a longstanding relationship with the Durst Organization and has worked on the developers projects at Four Times Square and One Bryant Park. It is currently involved in the leasing of One World Trade Center.

title: A Reunion of Flavors From Spain
description: APPEARANCES count in food, but great cooking is sometimes hard to spot at first glance. When they arrive at the table, there is nothing prepossessing about the fried artichokes served at La Vara, a four-month-old Spanish restaurant in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. I took one look and thought, O.K., fried artichokes. I know what these are all about.

title: As Republicans Meet, Biden Will Campaign in Tampa
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. plans to crash the other partys party. When Republicans gather in Tampa, Fla., next week to nominate Mitt Romney and Paul D. Ryan, Mr. Biden intends to be there as well, to campaign for the Democrats.

title: Two Lives, Intoxicated by Theater
description: STRATFORD, Ontario  Much of the glory and a lot of the money in show business find their way to actors  or at least stars. But two refreshing solo shows at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival this season reorient our perceptions of where much of the magic really comes from, at least in the theater.

title: Internet Analysts Question Indias Efforts to Stem Panic
description: MUMBAI, India  The Indian governments efforts to stem a weeklong panic among some ethnic minorities has again put it at odds with Internet companies like Google, Facebook and Twitter.

title: Gentle Giant Seeks the Strength to Body Check His Mother
description: The bodybuilder Kim Kold doesnt loom over the world of Teddy Bear, a low-key Danish drama about saying hello to love and goodbye to dear old, horrible Mom, he towers. As Dennis, the movies emphatically noncuddly title character, Mr. Kold has a diffident manner that appears at odds with his outrageous physical size and his characters expert exhibitionism. A hulking contradiction tucked under a stratum of ropy muscle, his Dennis is at once massive and passive, as big as a house and shy as a mouse. He needs to roar.

title: Rising Rents Create a Demand for Manhattan Walk-Up Buildings
description: The Benchmark Real Estate Group acquired the 22-unit walk-up building at 156 Sullivan Street in SoHo for just over $6 million last year. It is now in contract to sell the rental building for $12.5 million.

title: Fog and Faces: Day and Night in the Punjab
description: In Alms for a Blind Horse the writer and director Gurvinder Singh cares more about the weathered faces of villagers and the morning fog that settles over their town and fields than he does about storytelling. His method is a slow, careful formalism  so slow and so careful that his film can feel airless and overly aestheticized.

title: A $650 Million Expansion of Port Newark Spurs Interest in Its Environs
description: In Newarks Ironbound district, a developer broke ground last month on a $50 million warehouse without a committed tenant  a bold move and a sign of how much faith there is in the potential for growth in the states industrial sector and specifically in its ports.

title: Doctor Group Is Treating Syrian Rebels and Civilians
description: PARIS  Working in a converted villa in a town in the Syrian north, an international team of doctors and nurses has been quietly treating Syrian opposition fighters and civilians for the past two months, Doctors Without Borders announced in Paris on Tuesday.

title: Gilt Adds New Twists to Mobile App
description: Gilt Groupe, the New York company known for its time-sensitive sales of designer clothing, is releasing a major upgrade for its iPhone app on Wednesday. It introduces a complete redesign as well as the ability to search automatically for apparel that matches the clothing you own.

title: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Lebanon, Pakistan, Nepal and Ecuador.

title: Guitar Strings: The Art of the Package
description: In a former life, before joining The New York Times in 2007, I managed the Guitar Shop in Washington  a famously cramped, 90-year-old vintage-instrument store. Founded in 1922 by Sophocles Papas, a Greek immigrant who became a friend, publisher and musical envoy to the renowned classical guitarist Andres Segovia, the Guitar Shop kept an inventory of almost 2,000 stringed instruments, some of which dated back to the 1700s. By the time I left for New York, we were the last remaining music store in downtown Washington.

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 21
description: Photo Replay: Aug. 21

title: Talking Death, and Promises, With a Preschooler
description: I recently had an unplanned death talk with my 4-year-old daughter that left me wondering if my explanation of mortality should have stopped at worms and dogs, at least until she gets a little bit older.

title: Canadians Ask Why Design of $100 Bill Replaced Asian Woman With White One
description: OTTAWA  When the Bank of Canada switched to plastic-based banknotes, it ran the proposed designs past eight focus groups, hoping to avoid controversy or embarrassment.

title: Elevator Music Meets Classical: Concerts in a Lobby
description: Whats wrong with this picture? New York Citys major institutions have done little to commemorate the 150th anniversary of Debussys birth, but Arts Brookfield  the performance presentation arm of Brookfield Office Properties, a real estate concern that operates large office buildings in New York and across North America  is filling the gap with Debussy 150, a free four-concert series in the lobby of 1 Liberty Plaza in Lower Manhattan.

title: IAC Is Said to Make Offer for Timess About.com
description: The New York Times Company has found there is more interest than it may have expected in its ailing About Group, a business unit that includes the informational Web site About.com.

title: Ryan Takes to Pennsylvania to Push Medicare Message
description: WEST CHESTER, Pa.  Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin customized from his menu of attacks on President Obama to fit a full day of campaigning in Pennsylvania on Tuesday, putting state-specific numbers on his assertion that current Medicare beneficiaries will suffer benefit cuts under the 2010 health care law.

title: New York Fringe Festival Report: This Too Shall Suck
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festivals close on Aug. 26. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

title: Parkinsons in Check, Fox to Star in Sitcom
description: After Michael J. Fox learned he had Parkinsons disease, but before he publicly disclosed his diagnosis in 1998, he worried that his career as a comedic actor would be ruined if viewers knew that he was, as he put it in his memoir, battling an incurable neurological disease.

title: A Northern (or Maybe Bronx?) Cheer for the Souths Independence
description: Chuck Thompson is a travel writer who has worked on assignment in more than 50 countries. Real countries. The kinds that have recognizable borders and appear on maps.

title: What the G.O.P. Platform Represents
description: Over the years, the major parties election-year platforms have been regarded as Kabuki theater scripts for convention week. The presidential candidates blithely ignored them or openly dismissed the most extreme planks with a knowing wink as merely a gesture to pacify the noisiest activists in the party.

title: The Big Problem With Small Plates
description: This week I review La Vara, a new restaurant in Brooklyn with a menu that explores the contribution that Jews and Muslims made to Spains cuisine. Have you been? If you have, Id love to know what you thought. I admired a great deal of the dishes that the owners and co-chefs, Alex Raij and Eder Montero, have put on their menu (those artichokes! That tuna salad! Those red shrimp, served with their heads!).

title: New York Fringe Festival Report: Fantasy Artists
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festivals close on Aug. 26. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.James Ryan Caldwell knows how to write. All he needs now is to learn when to quit. At 90 minutes, his expertly acted comedy-drama Fantasy Artists is rather good. But you cant help thinking that at 75 minutes it would be even better.

title: Icahn Withdraws Offer to Take Refining Company Private
description: Carl C. Icahn, who owns 82 percent of CVR Energy, said on Tuesday that he was dropping an offer to take the Texas refiner private, citing changing market conditions.

title: The Caucus Click: Signs of Youth
Profits in G.M.A.C. Bailout to Benefit Financiers, Not U.S.
description: Among the companies that were bailed out by the federal government during the financial crisis, perhaps the most intractable is proving to be the company formerly known as the General Motors Acceptance Corporation. Its a case study in how bailouts can linger and profits, when they do come, flow not to the government but to the Warren E. Buffetts of the world.

title: Why Apple Might be Better Off Losing Its Patent Lawsuit
description: Could it be in Apples self-interest to lose its bitter court battle with Samsung?

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,084 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: U.S. Companies Worry About Effect of Russia Joining W.T.O.
description: MOSCOW  After two decades of negotiations, Russia will finally join the World Trade Organization on Wednesday. The lower trade barriers that come along with membership will open up new opportunities for foreign companies to do business in Russia.

title: United States Grants Broad Sanctions Exemption for Iran Quake Aid
description: The United States cleared the way on Tuesday for American charities to expedite relief to the victims of the double earthquake that struck Iran more than two weeks ago, issuing the charities a temporary but broad exemption to the regimen of economic sanctions imposed on that country over its disputed nuclear energy program.

title: Anti-Islam Ads Remixed in San Francisco and New York
description: As my colleague Benjamin Weiser reported last month, a federal judge in Manhattan ruled that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had violated the First Amendment rights of a pro-Israel group by refusing to run an ad that refers to Arabs as savage on 318 city buses.

title: Recalling the Real Dog Day Afternoon, 40 Years On
description: The womans body stiffened with each passing second as she sat anxiously in the back row of a 14-person limousine. Suddenly, a man sitting near her was fatally shot  killed by an F.B.I. agent, the culmination of nearly 14 hours of one of the more gripping criminal episodes in recent New York City history.

title: Ethiopian Leaders Death Highlights Gap Between U.S. Interests and Ideals
description: LIBREVILLE, Gabon  There was probably no leader on the African continent who exemplified the conflict between the American governments interests and its highest ideals better than Prime Minister Meles Zenawi of Ethiopia.

title: Dell Makes Moves to Survive in Cloud-Centric World
description: Despite headwinds in its core business, Dell is trying hard to move into the new world of corporate computing.

title: TimesCast Politics | Eyes on Missouri
description: A deadline for the Senate candidate Todd Akin.

title: New Yorkers and Bike Lanes
description: When asked simply whether bike lanes were a good idea or a bad idea, 66 percent of New Yorkers said they were a good idea, according to a new poll by The New York Times.

title: Paul and Republican Party Officials Reach Deal on Delegates
description: The presidential campaign of the libertarian Republican Ron Paul has reached agreement with party leaders on delegate disputes, clearing the way for a harmonious convention to nominate Mitt Romney next week in Tampa, Fla.

title: Brain Tumor Treatment for Baseball Union Leader
description: Michael Weiner, the executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, announced Tuesday that he had begun treatment for a brain tumor. Weiner, who plans to continue working, is expected to be treated for at least a month.

title: Beneath a Humdrum Exterior, Talk of Mysterious Inner Depths
description: PARIS  The French have never been passionate about Franois Hollande, their new president. A professional politician, never a government minister, he has been engaged in the machinations of the Socialist Party for most of his career. He was elected, narrowly, on a platform of change, but in large part because he was not Nicolas Sarkozy. And now the bland Mr. Hollande faces a daunting economic landscape and a euro crisis, and the French wonder if he, or anyone, can really make much difference.

title: Giving Little Virginia Something to Sing About
description: FOR decades, Macys has been on Broadway, literally. Soon, the department store will be there figuratively, too, as it develops a musical for schools around the country.

title: Recovery for the Speedy Nicks Is Deliberately Slow
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Hakeem Nicks snared a pass in the left flat from Eli Manning during Tuesdays practice and looked as if he wanted to simply run all day.

title: Celebrate the Farmer!
description: I was at a farm dinner in Maine the other night, a long table of 60 people eating corn, chicken, salad, a spectacular herb sorbet and other goodies. When one of the hosts arose to ask someone to describe the first course on the table  huge marrow bones from the farms cattle she introduced not the chef but the farmers. Similarly, at a fund-raiser on Cape Cod a week or so earlier, the talk was all about the provenance of the produce and meat rather than the cooking technique. The most popular guy was the oyster grower.

title: After Afghanistan, a New Great Game
description: SINCE 9/11, Americas priority in Central Asia has been to defeat the Taliban in Afghanistan. But as the United States and NATO pull out, there is a new danger: that the West could become entangled in regional rivalries, local strongman politics and competition with Russia and China.

title: Comparing the Candidates on Medicare
description: How the provisions in the presidents health care law differ from the plans of Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan.

title: Setback for Rogue Immigration Laws
description: A federal appeals court in Atlanta on Monday properly blocked several provisions of immigration laws in Alabama and Georgia, saying they violated constitutional rights and undermined federal law. The rulings were huge setbacks for the repellent idea that states can bypass federal authority over immigration and create their own schemes to harass and expel undocumented residents.

title: Smart Cars Get a Connection Test in Michigan
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  Federal regulators on Tuesday announced a yearlong smart car project to determine whether wireless communication between vehicles can improve safety on the nations highways.

title: Living the Abstinent Lifestyle in New York
description: Trinity Laurel moved to Manhattan at 21 to pursue a modeling career. Raised in a Christian home, Laurel was a virgin when she reached the city, and says she has remained pure while living here since.

title: Samuel H. Lindenbaum, Dean of New York Zoning Lawyers, Dies at 77
description: Samuel H. Lindenbaum, who was widely considered New York Citys top zoning lawyer and who was credited with doing as much as any of the powerful developers among his clients to shape the modern skyline of Manhattan, died on Friday at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 77.

title: Disney World on the Hudson
description: WHEN the first segment of the High Line, the now-famous park built atop an old elevated railway on the West Side of Manhattan, opened in 2009, I experienced a moment of excitement. I had often wondered what it would be like to climb that graffiti-marked trestle with its wild urban meadow. Of course, Id seen the architectural renderings and knew not to expect a wilderness. Still, the idea was enticing: a public park above the hubbub, a contemplative space where nature softens the citys abrasiveness.

title: Prosecutorial Abuse
description: Federal law allows federal courts to award attorneys fees and other expenses to criminal defendants who prove gross misconduct on the part of federal prosecutors. The law  a 1997 amendment sponsored by Representative Henry Hyde, a Republican  is a valuable deterrent to prosecutorial abuse, providing compensation in cases where a court finds the governments position to be vexatious, frivolous or in bad faith.

title: Uncertain Future for the Gray Wolf
description: The recovery of the gray wolf in the Rocky Mountain West is one of the Endangered Species Acts great success stories. Hunted nearly to extinction, wolves were reintroduced to the region in the 1990s and have since staged a remarkable comeback, thanks to federal protections. But whether this story has a happy ending will depend on the federal governments willingness to monitor, and revise if necessary, wolf management plans it has agreed to in Idaho and Montana and is about to strike with Wyoming.

title: Pettitte Talks About Return, His and Clemenss
description: CHICAGO  After a light catch with C.C. Sabathia in the outfield Tuesday afternoon, Andy Pettitte returned to the clubhouse and was asked, among other things, about his old friend and teammate Roger Clemenss plans to pitch in a minor league game this week.

title: Risks of Syrian Intervention Limit Options for U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  Despite President Obamas warning to Syria not to use its arsenal of chemical weapons or allow them to fall into the hands of extremists, the administrations options for intervening remain limited by what its officials have described as a simple calculus: It would make the conflict even worse.

title: Patients Would Pay More if Romney Restores Medicare Savings, Analysts Say
description: WASHINGTON  Mitt Romneys promise to restore $716 billion that he says President Obama robbed from Medicare has some health care experts puzzled, and not just because his running mate, Representative Paul D. Ryan, included the same savings in his House budgets.

title: Criminal Prosecutions at a Low Rate in the Bronx, a Report Finds
description: Prosecutors have declined to pursue criminal cases far more often in the Bronx than in other parts of the city, according to a news report published Tuesday examining state judicial data.

title: A Peacock Wanders Queens, Undeterred and Unclaimed
description: Escaped peafowl tend to enrapture even the most blas of New Yorkers.

title: We Need a Conservative Party
description: There has been lots of talk that Paul Ryans nomination ensures that well now have a real debate about the role of government. Thats actually funny. The bar for this campaign is so low that we celebrate the fact that it might include a serious debate about one of the four great issues of the day, though even that is not clear yet. And even if Ryans entry does spark a meaningful debate about one of the great issues facing America  the nexus of debt, taxes and entitlements  there is little sign that well seriously debate our other three major challenges: how to generate growth and upgrade the skills of every American in an age when the merger of globalization and the information technology revolution means every good job requires more education; how to meet our energy and climate challenges; and how to create an immigration policy that will treat those who are here illegally humanely, while opening America to the worlds most talented immigrants, whom we need to remain the worlds most innovative economy.

title: A Promise Unfulfilled at an Art Deco Bathhouse in the Rockaways
description: With its octagonal brick towers rising above the beach, the sprawling bathhouse at Jacob Riis Park in the Rockaways has, since opening in 1932, served as a monument to Art Deco design, grand public works and populist fun. Lately, however, it has become a symbol of something else: public frustration.

title: Dispute Over Islands Reflects Japanese Fear of Chinas Rise
description: ISHIGAKI, Japan  When the flotilla of 21 fishing boats arrived at an island chain at the center of a growing territorial dispute with China, the captains warned the dozens of activists and politicians aboard not to attempt a landing.

title: Skinny-Dipping in Israel Casts Unwanted Spotlight on Congressional Travel
description: WASHINGTON  The trip was much like any of the hundreds hosted in recent years by a nonprofit offshoot of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, a powerful Washington lobby, and the purpose was much the same: to solidify the support of American lawmakers for Israel at a time of Middle East tumult.

title: Trespassing to Plant Flowers, and a Flag
description: The gardeners entered the empty lot, pushing in the bottom of a metal gate on the Lower East Side, ducking under it and dragging their tools behind them.

title: Akin Controversy Stirs Up Abortion Issue in Campaign
description: WASHINGTON  As an orator, Representative Todd Akin of Missouri may stand out for his clumsiness. But as a legislator, Mr. Akin has a record on abortion that is largely indistinguishable from those of most of his Republican House colleagues, who have viewed restricting abortion rights as one of their top priorities.

title: Tennis Referee, in New York for U.S. Open, Arrested in Murder Case
description: The police arrested a professional tennis referee at a Manhattan hotel on Tuesday on a charge of murder in the death of her husband in April. The referee, Lois Ann Goodman, nicknamed Lolo, was in New York to work the United States Open.

title: Social Media Propels a Song of Summer
description: YouTube versions of Carly Rae Jepsens cheerfully flirty song, Call Me Maybe, helped turn it into the song of summer.

title: Poker Is More a Game of Skill Than of Chance, a Judge Rules
description: The game was Texas Hold Em. About $300 bought a place at the table in the back room of a warehouse on Staten Island, where waitresses floated around with food and drinks and the play lasted until breakfast.

title: Progress Is Cited on New Reactor in North Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  While the regions attention has remained focused on whether the new North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, can consolidate his power, his country has been making significant progress in the construction of a new reactor widely seen as a cover for making more fuel for nuclear weapons, analysts say, citing satellite imagery of the building site.

title: Secretive Police Unit Sought to Map Terrorist Havens in City, Official Testifies
description: Despite being dispatched to hundreds of places across New York City where would-be terrorists might congregate, an eight-member Police Department unit that eavesdropped on countless conversations has not generated a lead or an investigation in at least six years, a police chief testified in a deposition unsealed Monday.

title: Just Think No
description: WASHINGTON

title: Should the Fed Risk Inflation to Spur Growth?
The New Rise of a Summer Hit: Tweet It Maybe
description: For decades, the song of the summer would emerge each year following a pattern as predictable as the beach tides.

title: Deciding Whether to Medicate a Child
description: To the Editor:

title: Lottery Numbers
Summit Meeting in Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: Using Voter ID Laws to Protect Our Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: All Yours
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  You know how everyone has at least one thing that makes their brain shut down? It might be a certain subject they studied in school (trigonometry), or the way an appliance manual is written (all of them). There is always at least one thing we encounter in life that is so complex to us that our poor brain cells just give up and put out a sign that says Closed for Lunch.

title: On Trail, Obama Attacks Romney on Student Aid
description: RENO, Nev.  President Obama, adding another chapter to his litany of differences with Mitt Romney, took to the road on Tuesday to promote his record on education and assail his Republican challenger for advising financially struggling college hopefuls to shop around and borrow more money from your parents.

title: A Politician Whose Faith Is Central to His Persistence
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Throughout his political career, Representative Todd Akins agenda has been driven by a belief that his mission came from God.

title: Chilean Ex-Officers Charged in 1985 Kidnapping of U.S. Hiker
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  A judge ordered the arrest on Tuesday of eight retired police and military officers in connection with the kidnapping and disappearance of Boris Weisfeiler, an American university professor who disappeared while hiking in Chile in 1985.

title: Warren Ties Brown to G.O.P.s Agenda on Womens Issues
description: BOSTON  Elizabeth Warren seized on the weekend comments of Missouri Representative Todd Akin on Tuesday, seeking to link his statement about legitimate rape to the Republican Partys broader agenda on womens issues  and thus, to her opponent in the Massachusetts Senate race, the incumbent Republican Senator Scott P. Brown.

title: The New High-Tech Dating Technology? Meet in a Bar
description: Online dating services have long promised to help people find a mate by using statistical science to predict personal chemistry. But some of the biggest services are now adding a retro twist.

title: A Crime That Transfixed the City
description: Revisiting a widely publicized bank robbery attempt in Brooklyn on Aug. 22, 1972, that inspired the film Dog Day Afternoon.

title: Offline Dating
description: Online daters go for a brand new dating tactic ... sort of. At a MeetMoi.com event, singles try to meet their match at the Greenwood Park bar in Brooklyn.

title: As Decision Nears on Gas Drilling, Ad War Heats Up in New York State
description: ALBANY  As Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos administration finishes up new regulations on where and how to allow hydraulic fracturing in New York State, groups on both sides of the issue are turning to the airwaves in a late-inning effort to press their cases.

title: Former G.O.P. Hero Plays Down Label
description: BOSTON  When Mitt Romney ran for governor of Massachusetts a decade ago, he said that the R after his name stood for Reform.

title: When Precedent Dictates Prudence
description: WASHINGTON

title: Questions Surround Mans Death in Patrol Car
description: On a dark suburban street in Jonesboro, Ark., last month, the police arrested a young man named Chavis Carter. They searched him, handcuffed him and put him in the back of a patrol car.

title: Mets Follow the Nationals Cue on Limiting Innings of Pitcher
description: With the Mets toddling toward the end of the season, their postseason hopes all but extinguished, how far they should push various pitchers has become a central question.

title: Appeals Court Draws Boundaries on Alabamas Immigration Law
description: When Alabamas immigration law was passed in the spring of 2011, it was the boldest test yet of the doctrine of self-deportation. If the state put up legal obstacles to nearly every aspect of illegal immigrants lives, as a chief sponsor of the law put it at the time, it would make their lives difficult and they will deport themselves.

title: Corrections: August 22, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 21
description: Flipping boats and diving plays highlighted Tuesdays events.

title: A Place for Passionate Tennis Players
description: New York, a city of subcultures, has a gem on Manhattans West Side. Bordered by 94th and 96th Streets, between the Onassis Reservoir and the West Drive of one of the worlds most famous public spaces, sits the Central Park Tennis Center.

title: With East Race Tightening, Novas Struggles Raise Concerns
description: CHICAGO  Even as their lead in the American League East has shriveled in the last few weeks, the outward calm of the Yankees has never seemed shaken. But late Tuesday night, after another poor outing by Ivan Nova, Manager Joe Girardi acknowledged that Novas problems had now endured for a significant period of time. But he bristled at questions about how much longer the Yankees could stick with Nova, their struggling right-hander.

title: Are Unlimited Data Plans Dead? T-Mobile USA Says No
description: Just when cellphone customers were beginning to think all you can eat data plans were a relic of the past, T-Mobile USA on Wednesday said that next month it will begin offering a plan that does not put any limits on the use of data for things like browsing the Web, watching videos or streaming music.

title: Riding the Wave of Surfer Fitness
description: To the casual spectator, surfing seems to involve primarily balance, grace, nervy insouciance and a certain laid-back, ineffable oneness with the powers of the deep. But a series of newly published studies of the actual physical demands of surfing reveal that other, sometimes surprising aspects of fitness may be as important to surfing success as the ability to judge and remain upright on a swell.

title: Web Sites Accused of Collecting Data on Children
description: A coalition of nearly 20 childrens advocacy, health and public interest groups plans to file complaints with the Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday, asserting that some online marketing to children by McDonalds and four other well-known companies violates a federal law protecting childrens privacy.

title: St. Johns Senior Leads Met Open
description: Pat Wilson, a St. Johns senior from Andover, N.J., shot a seven-under-par 65 to take a one-stroke lead after one round of the Met Open Championship at Plainfield Country Club in Edison, N.J. Three holes in one were made, all on the second hole.

title: A Special Subculture in Central Park
description: The Central Park Tennis Center attracts a plethora of regulars, many of whom arrive at its doors an hour before its 6:30 a.m. opening time to claim their court.

title: Has Obama Made the Job Situation Worse?
description: Without a doubt President Obama inherited a difficult situation. Heres the problem. He made it worse, Paul Ryan, the Republican vice presidential candidate,  has been saying in his stump speech.

title: Friendship as Priceless as the National Pastime
description: CHICAGO  A welcome breeze blew in from Lake Michigan as the two older women, one white and one African-American, sat in the garden of their South Side retirement home and joked and reminisced about five decades of friendship knit tight by the game of baseball.

title: The Making of a Quality Suit in Kolkatas Bustling New Market
description: The first time I met Ajit Singh, I offended him.

title: Are Drone Strikes Worth the Costs?
description: HONG KONG  American drones have launched five airstrikes in the past five days in the tribal areas between Pakistan and Afghanistan. The latest attack  carried out Tuesday in North Waziristan by a pair of American drones  killed five suspected militants. The incident was barely mentioned in the U.S. media.

title: Internet Analysts Question Indias Efforts to Stem Panic
description: The Indian governments efforts to stem a weeklong panic among some ethnic minorities has again put it at odds with Internet companies like Google, Facebook and Twitter, Vikas Bajaj  wrote in The New York Times.

title: American Thwarted in Quest to Build a Ski Resort in India
description: To John Sims, the Himalayas, with some of the finest mountain slopes in the world, seemed like the perfect place to build Indias first Western-style ski resort, Vikas Bajaj wrote in The New York Times.

title: In the Lap of Himalayas, Luxury Ski Resorts Are a Distant Dream
description: Manali, a hill station in the Kullu Valley of Himachal Pradesh state, has long been seen as a potential hub for skiing in India. Witness the efforts of a group of foreign investors who have been trying to build the Himalayan Ski Village there for nearly a decade.

title: From Bible-Belt Pastor to Atheist Leader
description: Late one night in early May 2011, a preacher named Jerry DeWitt was lying in bed in DeRidder, La., when his phone rang. He picked it up and heard an anguished, familiar voice. It was Natosha Davis, a friend and parishioner in a church where DeWitt had preached for more than five years. Her brother had been in a bad motorcycle accident, she said, and he might not survive.

title: Whats a Monkey to Do in Tampa?
description: The monkey appeared behind a Bennigans. The Bennigans was one in a row of free-standing, fast-casual joints in Clearwater, Fla., just outside Tampa, that also includes a Panda Express and a Chipotle. At one end, a Perkins Family Restaurant flies a preposterously large Stars and Stripes in its front yard, as if it were a federal building or an aircraft carrier.

title: Street Fighting in Aleppo
description: Goran Tomasevic, a staff photographer for Reuters, photographed the fighting in Aleppo, Syria, from Aug. 1 to 17. While he was there, his dramatic images ran on the front pages of newspapers throughout the world. Mr. Tomasevic, 43, has been covering armed conflicts since 1991. On Tuesday, James Estrin interviewed him via e-mail. The exchange has been edited.

title: Managing the Ocean for Humans and Whales
description: As I wrote this week in a story about the humpback whales that summer off New England, one of the main reasons researchers want to learn about the humpbacks is so that the whales can be better protected from human activities like fishing and boating.

title: The Early Word: Renegade
