description: Todays Times

title: Carolina Panthers, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
description: On paper, the 2012 Carolina Panthers are a classic sleeper team. You may have heard about how at least five new teams have reached the N.F.L. postseason every year since 1996, meaning teams that didnt make the playoffs the previous season. Generally, at least one of those teams had a bad-but-not-awful record  like, say, 6-10  the year before.

title: The Mameco-Ardun Saga Reaches a Fitting Climax at Pebble Beach
description: 8:22 a.m. | Updated

title: Is Deficit Spending the Answer?
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: The Census Zombie Eats Another Brain
description: Back in 2010 all the usual suspects were going on about how there had been a huge increase in federal employment under Obama. This was funny, for two reasons: it was all about temporary hiring for the Census, and the meme continued to be part of what everyone on the right knew, just knew, to be true long after the Census blip was over and federal employment was back below its level when Obama took office.

title: Conciliatory Notes in Germany on Easing Greece's Burden
description: BERLIN  Bild, Germanys most-read newspaper, has accused Greece of making our euro kaput and only a few days ago referred to the country as a bottomless pit.

title: How the Toilet Paper Entrepreneur Branded Himself Too Well
description: When Mike Michalowicz published a book in 2008, he was looking for a name that would stick. He chose: The Toilet Paper Entrepreneur.

title: An Attack on Grameen Bank, and the Cause of Women
description: This month, the Grameen Bank, the organization that won the Nobel Peace Prize for extending small loans to impoverished village women, has come under renewed attack from the government of Bangladesh. Last year, I reported that the government was attempting to forcibly remove the banks founder, Muhammad Yunus, from his position as managing director on the pretense that Yunus, then 70, was beyond the official retirement age. The government prevailed.

title: How I Got That Shot: Justin Novak
description: What started as a lark for three pro photographer buddies, ended up as some heroic images, and a lesson on how a little lighting can turn daytime shots on-the-fly into powerful images.

title: A Parade of Spinning Dolphins
description: Scott Baker, associate director of the Marine Mammal Institute at Oregon State University, writes from Samoa, where he studies the formation of local communities among dolphins and their genetic isolation from one another.

title: Euro Zone Talks Revive Specter of Greek Exit
description: LONDON  Have Greeces euro zone partners resigned themselves to seeing Europes most distressed economy pull out of the single currency?

title: Q&A: Turning Off an Annoying Safari Alert
description: Q.

title: Understanding Medicare Cuts
description: Jackie Calmes has a very good piece about those Medicare cuts Romney promises to repeal. As she emphasizes, all of these involve reductions in payments to insurance companies and health providers, rather than reductions in patient benefits. So what are we talking about?

title: Occupy Video
description: A pretty good video compilation related to the Occupy Handbook, featuring some people you may know:

title: Pussy Riot Was Carefully Calibrated for Protest
description: DEPENDING on your taste, punk died in 1979, or maybe 1994, or whenever studded leather cuffs became a must-have mall-girl accessory. Now, suddenly, punk has been resurrected, stitched together anew in the form of the well-accessorized Russian women who call themselves Pussy Riot.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Profits in G.M.A.C. Bailout to Benefit Financiers, Not U.S. | Among the companies that were bailed out by the federal government during the financial crisis, perhaps the most intractable is proving to be the company formerly known as the General Motors Acceptance Corporation. It is a case study in how bailouts can linger and profits, when they do come, flow not to the government but to the Warren E. Buffetts of the world, the Deal Professor writes.

title: Aug. 21: Romney Showing Improved Results in Swing State Polls
description: We can get pretty detail-oriented in our analysis of the polls here at FiveThirtyEight. But sometimes there is also value in applying a simpler approach.

title: Opinion Report: Wyoming Wolves
description: From the editorial page

title: Japanese Leader Meets With Antinuclear Protesters
description: TOKYO  For the first time since antinuclear rallies began months ago outside Prime Minister Yoshihiko Nodas office, a dozen protesters were allowed inside on Wednesday for a half-hour meeting that the fledgling movement hailed as a victory. The meeting comes at a time of growing antinuclear sentiment in Japan, and with elections expected this year.

title: A Botched Robbery That Went Hollywood
description: Temperatures were in the 90s on the afternoon of Aug. 22, 1972, when a young mop-haired gunman emerged from a Chase Manhattan Bank in Gravesend, Brooklyn, wearing a sweaty V-neck undershirt.

title: Wednesday Reading: When Your Childs Diet Changes Yours
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Peanuts, Popcorn and Dermatology at Yankee Stadium
description: Dear Diary:

title: Is Facebook Straying From the Hacker Way?
description: Has Facebook lost its hacker way?

title: Summer Styles | Lacy Ladies
description: A look at whos staying cool and looking cooler this season.

title: YouTube Will Now Let Mobile Users Choose Whether to Watch Ads
description: People often visit Web sites on their mobile phones as much or more than they do on computers. But that leaves Web companies with a challenge: how to make money on phones, where there is less space for advertisements and people have less patience for them?

title: Daily Report: Online Dating Services Go Retro
description: Online dating services have long promised to help people find a mate by using statistical science to predict personal chemistry. But some of the biggest services are now adding a retro twist, Jenna Wortham reports in Wednesdays New York Times.

title: What Were Reading
description: Washington Post: A new analysis by the Natural Resources Defense Council says that Americans throw away up to 40 percent of their food each year, with the average family of four ends up tossing out up to $2,275 worth. Emily Weinstein

title: Akin Defies Calls to Step Down in TV Interviews
description: 10:27 a.m. | Updated  Representative Todd Akin on Wednesday morning took his case for staying in Missouris Senate race to the mainstream media he has blamed for his travails, telling both ABCs Good Morning America and NBCs Today show that his decision to defy his partys leadership and conservative cognoscenti was a stand for the Republican voters of the Show Me State.

title: In Vietnam, Growing Fears of an Economic Meltdown
description: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam  Construction crews got as far as the first floor of what was to be Saigon Residence, a high-end apartment building in the center of Ho Chi Minh City. All that remains today of the abandoned project are piles of moldy bricks, rusting steel rods and a small team of security guards who have transformed the cement foundation into a parking lot for motorcycles.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Kimmel, Fox and Call Me Maybe Make Waves
description: This years ubiquitous summer hit, Call Me Maybe by Carly Jepsen, signals a bigger change than just the weather for the media business, writes Ben Sisario. Even last year, the big hits were all produced by old-style music companies pushing for radio play but this year songs like Call Me Maybe and Gotyes Somebody That I Used to Know got their initial push through social media before ending up on Top 40 radio.

title: Language and Chinas Practical Creativity
description: Every language presents challenges  English pronunciation can be idiosyncratic and Russian grammar is fairly complex, for example  but non-alphabetic writing systems like Chinese pose special challenges.

title: Health Care REIT to Buy Sunrise Senior Living
description: Health Care REIT Inc. agreed on Wednesday to buy Sunrise Senior Living for $844.6 million in cash, in a deal aimed at creating one of the biggest owners of nursing homes in the United States, Canada and Britain.

title: The New Citigroup Isnt Your Fathers Citicorp
description: Vikram S. Pandit, Citigroups chief executive, has entered the debate over splitting up big banks. But did he overstate one of his key points?

title: Citic Capital Sells Stake to Qatar Fund
description: The Chinese asset management firm Citic Capital Holdings is taking on a new shareholder by agreeing to sell a 22 percent stake to a unit of Qatars sovereign wealth fund.

title: Syrian Forces Are Said to Expand Deadly Hit and Run Efforts in Damascus
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Gunfire and shelling rocked Damascus, Syria, and its suburbs on Wednesday as opponents of President Bashar al-Assad reported a widening campaign by the military to sow fear and death in neighborhoods where the rebels are strong and the government is too weak to assert full control.

title: A Public Bathroom, Transformed Into a Gem by the Beach
description: Inside Public Comfort Station 2 on the boardwalk in Brighton Beach, even the trash receptacles are clothed, their utilitarian metal covered in burgundy fabric. The sinks have pink skirts, too, while the mirrors wear garlands of silk flowers, the soap bottles dispense fruit-scented hand cleanser and plastic ferns stand in the corner.

title: Searching Through the Ashes of an Exploded Life
description: In Infinite Jest David Foster Wallace  described  clinical depression as the Great White Shark of pain, a level of psychic pain wholly incompatible with human life as we know it, a nausea of the cells and soul, a sort of double bind in which any/all of the alternatives we associate with human agency  sitting or standing, doing or resting, speaking or keeping silent, living or dying  are not just unpleasant but literally horrible, a radical loneliness in which everything is part of the problem, and there is no solution.

title: Supreme Court Castigates Government for Poor Tiger Conservation Efforts
description: The Supreme Court of India on Wednesday extended the temporary ban on tourism in the core areas of the countrys tiger parks by another week, as it criticized the government for its inaction in protecting the endangered animal.

title: Art Lessons
description: As public schools across the country shutter their arts programs in favor of grueling test prep instruction, childrens picture books are helping make up for the loss. Two sweet new books, Mousterpiece and Sky Color, continue what seems to have become a kind of crusade to teach children the value of artistic self-expression.

title: Cholera Epidemic Envelops Coastal Slums in West Africa
description: DAKAR, Senegal  A fierce cholera epidemic is spreading through the coastal slums of West Africa, killing hundreds and sickening many more in one of the worst regional outbreaks in years, health experts said.

title: Business Day Live | August 22, 2012
description: The challenges that await Best Buy's new chief executive. | High-tech dating goes retro. | How social media is changing the music industry's hit making process.

title: Business Day Live: The New High-Tech Dating Technique? Meet in a Bar
description: The challenges that await Best Buys new chief executive. | Online dating services go retro. | How the music industrys hit-making process is changing.

title: Budget Impasse Invites Recession Risk, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Congressional Budget Office said Wednesday that the economic recovery would continue at a modest pace for the rest of the year, but that if Congress took no action to stave off tax increases and automatic budget cuts scheduled for Jan. 1, the economy could fall into a recession.

title: New Label Alert | Julia Jentzsch
description: All week, T is introducing the lines to look out for this fall.

title: France: Floor Plans for Government Offices Stolen
description: A USB memory stick and discs containing the floor plans for the lyse Palace, the Interior Ministry, the Paris police headquarters and several large companies were in a bag stolen from a car near a Parisian train station on Sunday, the Interior Ministry confirmed Tuesday. The plans, which were not encrypted, did not contain information about who occupied various rooms and were not classified, the ministry said in a statement. The information they contain does not imperil the security of the sites concerned, the statement said.

title: One on One: Ernest Cline, Author of Ready Player One
description: Ready Player One, written by the 40-year-old Ernest Cline, is a science fiction novel set in 2044. It takes place on a grimy version of Earth where people prefer to live in avirtualreality video game rather than in real life. The book follows the storyofWade Watts, who is on an epic quest to solve a multilevel puzzle that involves playing 1980s video games and trivia. Here is an edited interview with Mr. Cline.

title: The Other Wild Monkeys of Florida
description: The odd thing I found about traveling to Florida to write a story in Sundays magazine about a monkey on the loose is how many times someone asks you which monkey on the loose, exactly, youre asking after.

title: Image of the Day: August 22
The Wild Macaques of Silver River
description: Troops of monkeys running free in Florida.

title: With Clemens, You Cant Make This Stuff Up
description: There are some sports stories you just couldnt make up if you tried. For todays example, Roger Clemens comes out of retirement at 50 to pitch for an independent minor league team and also take some hacks in an over-50 mens softball league. Now, were the Atlantic League the kind of league that installs beer kegs at each base and requires someone with actual athletic talent to pitch with a small child perched on his shoulders, heads across the country might not be lolling with such fatigue. But no, the Sugar Land Skeeters (we couldnt make that up either) are apparently enough of an actual organization to have an official team backdrop  with the teams and its sponsors name, no less  for Clemenss news conference Wednesday. Oh, and the Astros consider this serious enough to send a scout to contemplate a possible major league return.

title: The Don Quixote of the Spanish Crisis
description: Bearded and blustery, with a kaffiyeh draped around his neck, Juan Manuel Snchez Gordillo cuts a rakish profile. For the last 33 years he has been the mayor of the small Andalusian town of Marinaleda, a Communist enclave in southern Spain.

title: Margaret Dunning, Queen for a Weekend at Pebble Beach
description: The Margaret Dunning Road Show made a pit stop at the Pebble Beach Concours dlgance last weekend, where the 102-year-old showed her cherished 1930 Packard.

title: Biography of Gore Vidal Coming in 2015
description: The life of Gore Vidal, the prolific and pugnacious man of letters who died in July, will be unfurled in a new biography written by Jay Parini, the novelist and scholar, and published by Doubleday.

title: Briton Who Fought for Assisted Suicide Is Dead
description: LONDON  A 58-year-old British man suffering from so-called locked-in syndrome died Wednesday, six days after a panel of High Court judges rejected his request for help in ending his life. His death is certain to galvanize the already contentious debate about assisted suicide in Britain.

title: A Quick End to TARP Means a Smaller Payoff for Taxpayers
description: Quietly, the Treasury Department is engaged in another bailout of the banks. This time, its Americas small banks that are the lucky duckies.

title: Overlooked and Underfoot: Sidewalk Cleaning in New York City
description: They say that gum stays in the stomach for seven years, but how long does a discarded piece remain on the sidewalk?

title: A Virginia Baker Is in the Spotlight at a Ryan Rally
description: ROANOKE, Va.  Joe the Plumber, meet Chris the Baker.

title: Possession Paralysis Revisited
description: Possession paralysis, it turns out, is real.

title: The Legs Take Their Turn
description: MARCY STEIN, 46, a former competitive power lifter who lives on the Upper East Side and manages large construction projects for a consulting company, keeps an eye on the shape of her legs. When youre power lifting, your legs are amazing, but theyre big and muscular, she said.

title: New York Fringe Festival Report: The Art of Painting
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festivals close on Aug. 26. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.If The Art of Painting were a real art history lecture, it would be a sophomores dream. The instructor (Mark Chrisler) is cute, and he makes the lives of long-dead white European men entertaining.

title: Death of a Strongman
description: NAIROBI  After two months of mysterious absence, Meles Zenawi, Ethiopias prime minister, is finally accounted for: Hes dead.

title: The Rhinos Have Arrived
description: O.K., its August. But the arrival of two 4,000-pound adolescent southern white rhinos  brothers, no less  at the Bronx Zoo would be news any day. The surprisingly nimble-footed pair (see video above or here) were a gift from The Wilds, a conservation park in Cumberland, Ohio, where they were born three and a half years ago.

title: Phyllis Diller and Her Comic Craft
description: Early in her career Phyllis Diller, who died on Monday at 95, made fun of her legs and her figure. Later she took aim at her wrinkles and plastic surgery. Ive had so many things done to my body, she began a joke, that when I die, God wont know me.

title: Ask Your Local G.O.P. Candidate About Legitimate Rape
description: A reporter for the Pittsburgh TV station KDKA asked Paul Ryan the other day what he thought of Rep. Todd Akins pronouncement that victims of legitimate rape can magically shut down pregnancy and so do not need the right to an abortion.

title: 60% in City Oppose Bloombergs Soda Ban, Poll Finds
description: The big-soda ban is losing some of its fizz.

title: Donations by Media Companies Tilt Heavily to Obama
description: Wall Street may lean Republican this presidential election cycle, but the New York media world is staunchly Democratic.

title: Scene City: South Central in East Hampton
description: End of Watch holds a private screening in the Hamptons.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times poll is based on telephone interviews with 1,026 adult residents from throughout New York City conducted Aug. 10 to 15. The interviews were in English or Spanish.

title: Talk of Small Plates on Twitter
description: Pete Wellss blog post about the problems of sharing a meal made up of small plates sparked an exchange on Twitter with the writers Michele Humes and Francis Lam, the chef David Chang, the Bloomberg restaurant critic Ryan Sutton and others. about Chinese cuisine and American habits, the distinction between a family-style meal and the current small plates rage, and the advantage in serving small plates for the restaurant. Here are excerpts from the conversation. To be sure we see your tweet on the subject, cc @nytdining.

title: A Big Party for a Not-So-Big Film
description: IN the new movie End of Watch, Jake Gyllenhaal plays a cop in South Central Los Angeles, working the neighborhood patrol and battling some seriously scary thugs from a Mexican drug cartel.

title: No Charges for Officer Accused by Judge
description: After a three-month investigation, the Queens district attorney has decided not to bring criminal charges against a police officer who was accused of assaulting a State Supreme Court justice on the street in what the judge contended was an unprovoked attack, officials said Wednesday.

title: Limited Convention Broadcasts Shut Out Ann Romney
description: At 10:30 on Monday night, Ann Romney is scheduled to take the stage at the Republican National Convention, in Act 1 of her husbands four-day introduction to the nation. But tens of millions of people will not be able to watch.

title: U.S. Oil and Mining Companies Must Disclose Payments to Foreign Governments
description: HOUSTON  Despite stiff industry lobbying against it, the Securities and Exchange Commission voted 2 to 1 on Wednesday to require American oil and mining companies to disclose taxes and other fees they pay to foreign governments. The disclosures are aimed at curbing corruption, which is common in some major oil-producing nations.

title: Kenya Clashes Leave Dozens Dead
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  As many as 52 people, most of them women and children, were killed Wednesday in a coastal area of Kenya in attacks involving two rival communities, officials said.

title: In Texas, Dont Even Mention Abortion
description: The Republican-controlled State Legislature in Texas and Gov. Rick Perry are perfectly willing to endanger the general health and welfare of low-income women to further their agenda of eroding abortion rights. And, now, a federal appeals court has given them a green light to do that, at least temporarily.

title: Book Will Describe Raid That Killed Bin Laden
description: A detailed first-person account of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden, written by a member of the Navy SEALs who participated in the mission and was present at Bin Ladens death, will be released next month, the publisher said on Wednesday.

title: David Champion, Director of Automotive Testing for Consumer Reports, Joins Nissan
description: To fill the newly created position of adviser for competitive assessment and quality, Nissan North America has hired David Champion, formerly the senior director of Consumer Reports auto test center. The appointment takes effect on Sept. 10, Nissan noted in a media release on Wednesday.

title: Fathers Age Is Linked to Risk of Autism and Schizophrenia
description: Older men are more likely than young ones to father a child who develops autism or schizophrenia, because of random mutations that become more numerous with advancing paternal age, scientists reported on Wednesday, in the first study to quantify the effect as it builds each year. The age of mothers had no bearing on the risk for these disorders, the study found.

title: Ryan Pressed to Explain Position on Rape and Abortion
description: Representative Paul D. Ryan sought to distance himself from Todd Akin, his House colleague, on Wednesday by condemning his comments about rape, even while deflecting questions about the meaning of forcible rape.

title: The Get | Chlos Boots
description: A fall boot is like a winter coat  so critical it can easily turn into a must-have of mythic proportions. Thankfully, Chlos Clare Waight Keller has designed three similar and pretty-close-to-perfect boot styles  the toe shape is the same on all; the heel size and height varies from pair to pair  that help make the best-ever boot something one cannot only attain but wear everyday. Available in three seasonally-appropriate colors  mustard-yellow, brick-red and rich burgundy (very important this season, take note)  the glossed-leather gives the shoes equestrian silhouettes a polished feel. The only hard part now? Picking which one to wear.

title: U.N. Visit Will Set Back a Push to Isolate Iran
description: Efforts led by the United States and Israel to isolate Iran suffered a setback on Wednesday when the United Nations announced that Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general, would join officials from 120 countries in Tehran next week for a summit meeting that Iran has trumpeted as a vindication of its defiance and enduring importance in world affairs.

title: Struggling to Recover From a Cyberattack
description: IN 2006, Peter Justen, a serial entrepreneur, founded MyBizHomepage, an online service that connected to companies QuickBooks accounting software to help business owners monitor their financial metrics. When the site went live in 2008, it attracted significant media attention. It was free to use and the company planned to make money through advertising, a recipe that appealed to Mr. Justens investors, who valued the company at $100 million based on the vast potential they perceived.

title: Die Koelner Bierhalle
description: IN the spirit of barbarian tribes, beer gardens with no-frills dcor and heavyweight glassware have invaded New Yorks bar scene. The latest is Die Koelner Bierhalle, which opened in early August in Park Slope, a few blocks from the Barclays Center.

title: Video: Primary Day in Connecticut
description: The Lieberman-Lamont race remains tight as the polls close in Connecticut. (Producer: Matthew Orr)

title: A New Addition to Police Lingo: Easy, Peasy, Lemon Squeezy
description: There are all sorts of things police officers are known to say when they arrest someone. Freeze, or Police  dont move!

title: University of Texas Compounds Conflict Question in Review of Gas Report
description: As I wrote recently, the University of Texas, Austin, appropriately initiated an independent review of the report from its Energy Institute on gas drilling using hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, methods. The review was ordered after the Public Accountability Initiative, a nonprofit research group, pointed out previously undisclosed financial ties between a leader of the report, Charles Groat, and a drilling company.

title: A Murder Sentence Underlines South African Inequality
description: JOHANNESBURG  When a leading white supremacist was found bludgeoned to death in his bed on his farm outside Johannesburg in April 2010, the Rainbow Nation shuddered.

title: Stone Links: Paul Ryan, Pussy Riot and Philosophy
description: Over the past week, philosophy made the headlines of stories from opposite ends of the political spectrum.

title: Whose Ryan Is It Anyway?
description: Gail Collins: David, welcome back! You missed so much while you were on vacation. Tim Pawlenty is the Republican vice-presidential nominee, and Michele Bachmann is going to make the keynote speech at the convention, and Donald Trump will be leading the invocation.

title: Most New Long-Term Care Claims Are Filed by Women
description: While deciding to purchase long-term care insurance is a complex decision, it is one that women, in particular, may want to spend some time considering. Nearly two-thirds of new claims under long-term care policies in 2011 were made by women, according to the latest data from an industry group.

title: Akin Remarks Push Gender Issues to Center Stage
description: Just days before Mitt Romney formally assumes the leadership of his party, he and his Republican colleagues are once again confronting the partys long-standing difficulty attracting the support of women  a demographic reality that could cost Mr. Romney the White House.

title: In Googles Inner Circle, a Falling Number of Women
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  At Google, data is king. Now the company is using data to figure out if it can anoint a few queens.

title: The Kitchen Announces Its Fall Season
description: Yoga mats, Beethoven, stories from life in America and Mary Shelleys Frankenstein all serve as fodder for offerings this season at The Kitchen performance and exhibition space, which released highlights of its program, which runs from Sept. 7  Dec. 22.

title: Reinventing Instant Film in an Age of Instant Imagery
description: In the world of photography, innovation has a shelf life. By 2008, some 60 years after Edwin Lands invention of the Polaroid camera, analog photography had been usurped by the power of the digital age. The shuttering of instant film production left a community of Polaroid enthusiasts and professional photographers with uncertain futures: Would instant film ever be produced again? Could Polaroid be resurrected?

title: Big City Book Club: Discussing Nora Ephron
description: 9:30 p.m. | Updated  Thats a wrap! The live portion of our conversation is now concluded. But please still weigh in in the comments section below with any and all thoughts on Nora Ephron and her work. Ill be checking in throughout the week. And stay tuned: well announce our next book club selection soon.

title: Older Fathers Linked to Risk of Autism and Schizophrenia
description: A new study provides some of the first solid scientific evidence for a true increase in autism. In the Science section, Benedict Carey describes the research: Older men are more likely than young ones to father a child who develops autism or schizophrenia, because of random mutations that become more numerous with advancing paternal age, scientists reported on Wednesday. The age of mothers had no bearing on the risk for these disorders. Read more.

title: Please Dont Eat the Cheese Curls
description: In the Dining Section, Matt Richtel writes about the ways having children has changed his diet  and not for the better. For him, its the main meals. He snatches the French fries and finishes the last bites of pasta.

title: Another Player Receives 50-Game Ban
description: For the second time in a week, Major League Baseball has suspended a prominent major leaguer for testing positive for an excessive level of testosterone, a clear indication that illegal performance enhancers continue to exist as a stubborn element of the sport despite intensified efforts to eliminate their use.

title: Genome Detectives Solve a Hospitals Deadly Outbreak
description: The ambulance sped up to the red brick federal research hospital on June 13, 2011, and paramedics rushed a gravely ill 43-year-old woman straight to intensive care. She had a rare lung disease and was gasping for breath. And, just hours before, the hospital learned she had been infected with a deadly strain of bacteria resistant to nearly all antibiotics.

title: David Henry Hwang Wins $200,000 Prize for Playwriting
description: The $200,000 Steinberg award for playwriting, the most generous prize in theater, has been presented to Tony Award winner David Henry Hwang for 32 years of provocative satires and dramas (Chinglish, M. Butterfly) that brought more Asian and Asian-American characters to Broadway and other stages, the Harold and Mimi Steinberg Charitable Trust announced on Wednesday.

title: Missouri Republicans Weigh In on Akin
description: Missouri residents who are active in the Republican Party are divided over Representative Todd Akins decision to continue his campaign for the United States Senate, even as a chorus of party leaders urged him to throw in the towel.

title: Many at Fed Ready to Act if Necessary
description: WASHINGTON  Many Federal Reserve officials at their most recent policy meeting pushed for further actions to support the economy if the recovery failed to strengthen over the summer, an official account released on Wednesday showed.

title: Thomas Jefferson, Founding Foodie
description: Thomas Jeffersons take on agriculture sounds remarkably like the 1800s version of Wendell Berry, with a little bit of Alice Waters thrown in.

title: Japanese Journalists Final Report From Syria Is Released After Her Death
description: Two days after a Japanese journalist, Mika Yamamoto, was shot and killed in the Syrian city of Aleppo, her news agency released some of the footage she recorded in her final hours.

title: Worst Year for West Nile Is Expected, Officials Say
description: The nation is heading toward the worst outbreak of West Nile disease in the 13 years that the virus has been on this continent, federal health authorities said Wednesday.

title: TimesCast Tech | August 22, 2012
description: Fixing a pothole with an app. | Online dating goes retro. | Presidential campaign apps raise concerns over privacy.

title: Romanias Meat Market
description: Come transfer time, professional soccer players are paraded and sold like meat at a butcher shop, their movement among various clubs becoming a public affair chronicled in news media transmissions across the globe.

title: Action Plans on CO2 that Go Beyond Woe is Me, Shame on You
description: I recently received a note from Tim Whitley, the founder and head of the nonprofit group Carbon Offsets to Alleviate Poverty, which I think merits posting as a Your Dot contribution because it takes a step beyond the woe is me, shame on you rhetoric that has long been favored by people seeking to cut greenhouse gas emissions. Heres Whitleys piece, with a postscript from me:

title: In Ultra-Secretive Case, One Veil May Be Lifted
description: The case of John Doe and Richard Roe may be about to take a small step toward transparency.

title: Postal Service Stuck With Glut of Simpsons Stamps
description: 4:42 p.m. | Updated Perhaps recalling the heady days when Bart Simpson T-shirts sold in the millions and a song like Do the Bartman had the power to become a cultural touchstone, the UnitedStates Postal Service produced 1 billion stamps featuring characters from The Simpsons in 2009 to commemorate the shows 20th year on Fox.

title: Notes From the Underground | Cerebral Ballzy
description: Having Cerebral Ballzy play at Santos Party House is like putting a tiger in a paper cage. Ballzy, one of New Yorks loudest, most raucous fire starters, comes with a thick crowd  one of elbow-throwing, neck-snapping, mosh-pit-shoving ruffians that doesnt exactly jibe with Santoss thorough, and intimidating, fleet of security guards. At a recent performance, a prominently displayed sign forbade moshing, leaving the audience somewhat castrated in its enthusiasm, but it was clear that on any other night, the scene would be pure chaos. The singer Honor Titus  channeling a mixture of Jimi Hendrix, Tony Hawk and a punk prince  was apparently singing about getting black-out drunk, refusing to be told what to do and being a native New Yorker, but youd have to be reading a karaoke screen to know that. For the raucous among you, Cerebral Ballzy will perform at the Afro Punk festival in Brooklyn this weekend.

title: Can This Company Recover From a Cyberattack?
description: A case study weve just published explains the challenges faced by Peter Justen, chief executive of MyBizHomepage, a Middleburg, Va., provider of business accounting software. The business was shut down by a wave of cyber attacks that apparently came from a disgruntled former employee.

title: A Manic Collection of Orderly Designs
description: As a design student with an inexplicable desire for accumulating all kinds ofobjects, I was filled with joy upon discovering Amass, the blog of James Phillips Williams, a former art director at Bergdorf Goodman. A successful graphic designer, Williams lives and works in New York with his wife, Allison Muench, where they run their own design studio, MW, whose clients have included the department store Takashimaya. I recently e-mailed Williams to find out more about his acquisitive nature and the blog.

title: Taylor Swift Song Sets a Record for Digital Sales
description: This week on the music charts, Taylor Swifts new song set a digital sales record, and the debut album by the rapper 2 Chainz opens at No. 1.

title: The Dance Between Belize and Its Bondholders
description: This is the dynamic at work in the negotiations between Belize and its bondholders. Really its the dynamic in most sovereign debt restructurings.

title: A Web Site That Aims to Help Manage Student Loans
description: I dont have student loans anymore (thank goodness). But I do recall that managing them was a challenge. How many loans did I have? How much was I paying in total? When would they all be paid off? Who is Sallie Mae, and why did I borrow so much money from her?

title: U.S. Road to Brazil Detours to Outer Space
description: The revolution will not be televised  and neither will United States mens national team away games in regional World Cup qualifying  unless you are among a small universe of TV viewers who have access to Al-Jazeera Sports Media Networks beIN Sport channel.

title: TimesCast Tech: Offline Dating
description: Fixing a pothole with an app, online dating goes retro and presidential campaign apps raise concerns over privacy. The video is available at nytimes.com/bits

title: Scouting Report
description: LIMITED EDITION:

title: Steel Plate Above Subway Blast Site Opened Up Like a Trapdoor
description: A 1,800-pound steel plate that was secured along only one side opened up like a trapdoor and sent rocks and other debris flying through the air when explosives were set beneath it this week at the Second Avenue subway excavation site, a transit spokesman said Wednesday.

title: Romney Returns to His Mainstay: The Economy
description: BETTENDORF, Iowa  With the unwanted distractions of Representative Todd Akins legitimate rape comments still swirling in the background on Wednesday, Mitt Romney returned to his political mainstay during a campaign stop at LeClaire Manufacturing here  hitting President Obama over the economy.

title: In a Little-Known WWII Battle, a Fathers Experience Becomes a Daughters Journey
description: DIEPPE, France  Going to the 70th anniversary commemoration of the Dieppe raid in Normandy this past weekend was part of a journey I began when I was very small. It gathered steam in college, when I first saw footage at the Canadian War Museum in Ottawa that was shot at Dieppe by the Germans. I stood in a gallery watching it, looking for my father, Francis Stanley Parker, a private in the Black Watch Regiment of Canada, in the columns marching past the camera  an American in the sea of Canadian captives.

title: Work at Slaughterhouse Is Halted After Graphic Undercover Videos
description: Federal authorities have shut down a California slaughterhouse for investigation after an animal protection charity secretly filmed cows being electrically shocked, shot in the head, suffocated and undergoing other abuses.

title: Traffic Agent Arrested but Not Charged in Alleged Rape
description: The police arrested a New York City traffic enforcement agent on Tuesday night after a woman claimed he had raped her. But a spokesman for the Bronx district attorney said Wednesday that the agent had not been charged and that prosecution of the case had been deferred because of insufficient evidence.

title: Existential Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: To Sketch, to Draw, to Create, With No Pencil in Sight
description: I used to have a habit of carrying around a red Moleskine notebook and, while sipping a beer or a coffee, Id make little sketches. My drawings were just curiosities, sometimes of the scene or of an interesting person. They were more for fun, to let my creative juices flow, than an attempt at serious art. Often Id have to borrow a pen from the bar or cafe because carrying a pencil in a jeans pocket wasnt ideal.

title: Buying Their Way to Twitter Fame
description: AS a comedian, Dan Nainan was blessed with fans, millions of YouTube views and, once, an audience with President Obama. But one thing was missing.

title: Too High to Fail
description: To the Editor:

title: Weak Sales and a Large Write-Down Give H.P. a Loss
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The pressure is building for Meg Whitman to make a miracle happen.

title: Help to Promote Canada From a Directors Chair
description: Canada, the country where the directors James Cameron, David Cronenberg and Paul Haggis were born, is tapping its creative and civic-minded public to promote tourism.

title: Two Vestiges of Vaudeville
description: As the Broadway musical in-jokes and double and triple entendres snowballed into a comic avalanche at Tuesdays opening-night performance of The Prince and the Show Boy at 54 Below, I was reminded once again that vaudeville never died. The Prince of the title is Faith Prince and the Show Boy is Jason Graae, who, although hardly a boy, conveys the brashness of a mouthy hyperactive teenager. Both are vaudevillians to the bone.

title: HTML5, Apps and JavaScript Video
description: Here are the videos from last weeks TimesOpen event on HTML5, Apps and JavaScript:

title: Ex-Giant Michael Strahan Is Seen as Favorite to Join Kelly Ripa on Live
description: Is the the former New York Giants great Michael Strahan about to play a new position on television?

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Syria, India, Mars and North Carolina.

title: The Dinner Table Debate
description: An excerpt from debate on gay marriage between Brian Brown and Dan Savage, held after dinner at Mr. Savages home.

title: Behind the Due Diligence Dispute at Best Buy
description: The squabble between Best Buy and its founder, Richard M. Schulze, appears, for the moment, to center on one basic matter: the terms of opening the electronics retailers books for due diligence.

title: Diana Nyads Neverending Swim
description: Diana Nyad is in her early 60s and all she has wanted to do for the last 35 years is swim the 103 miles that separate Havana from Key West, Fla. She tried and failed three times, starting at age 28, before she jumped into the water on Saturday night to begin her latest attempt. Last December, Elizabeth Weil profiled Nyad in the magazine, capturing her obsessive determination to successfully cross the Straits of Florida, despite the pleading from some of those closest to her that she let this mania go.

title: For Prince Harry, Vegas Exploits Didnt Stay There
description: LONDON  A year that has featured a triumphant Olympic Games and Queen Elizabeth IIs diamond jubilee struck an unwelcome bump on Wednesday for the royal family with the publication of photographs showing the queens sometimes wayward grandson, Prince Harry, naked and cavorting with a naked woman, or women, during a strip billiards game in a Las Vegas hotel room.

title: New York Fringe Festival Report: The Particulars
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festivals close on Aug. 26. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

title: Melodies, Immersive and Vibrant
description: There are many reasons to like Lincoln Centers Mostly Mozart Festival. But one of the best is its subtle yet crucial transformation of the chronically woeful Avery Fisher Hall, the home base of the festivals orchestra, which played a program of Bach, Mendelssohn and Mozart on Tuesday evening, led by Andrew Manze, making his festival debut.

title: Obama Promotes His Education Credentials, Putting Down Romneys
description: LAS VEGAS  Its back-to-school time, and President Obama has been all but handing out three-ring binders and pencil sharpeners this week, as he promotes his education credentials and slams those of his challenger, Mitt Romney.

title: In India, Preserving a Fading Tradition
description: Two friends have started a record label to preserve the music of the Manganiyars, whose songs have no written record.

title: House Subcommittee Wades Into the Universal-EMI Deal
description: The Universal Music Groups proposed $1.9 billion takeover of EMI Music, already under close scrutiny by regulators in the United States and Europe, is facing additional pressure from a subcommittee in the House of Representatives.

title: Preserving the Passion of Indias Roots Music
description: RANERI, India  In this tiny village almost 400 miles southwest of New Delhi, where women wash dishes in the sand to conserve water, and electricity is scarce, Lakha Khan sat on the floor of a stone hut, legs crossed and white turban in place. There he coaxed a bright, high-pitched, dizzyingly fast melody from his violinlike sarangi.

title: Waltzing a Famous Page Out of John Cages Book
description: Most performers who have been inclined to commemorate John Cages centenary this season have done so by performing Cages music. Kevin James, a trombonist and composer, decided instead to write a work using some of the same principles that animate Cages music, including randomness, humor and a mingling of music as it is traditionally understood and unalloyed noise. He presented the piece at the DiMenna Center on Tuesday evening, both as a tribute to Cage and as a way to introduce his new group, the [kaj] Ensemble, which clearly hopes to challenge counter)induction both as a new-music band and over its idiosyncratic orthography.

title: Defined by Words, Not by a Disease
description: TWENTY years ago this month, Mary Fisher took the stage of the Republican National Convention at the Houston Astrodome and delivered a 13-minute prime-time speech that was seen by many as a sharp rebuke of her partys negligence in the face of the growing AIDS epidemic.

title: Placing Blame for Middle-Class Doldrums
description: 6:06 p.m. | Updated to correct description of the group answering a question.

title: Its You, She Says, and at a Discount
description: ON a hot afternoon this summer, the air-conditioning was going full blast at the Loehmanns store in Chelsea. Carly Zell, the stores personal shopper, was welcoming a steady stream of visitors to her third-floor office with coos of honey and darling.

title: A Spin Around Montpelier, Vt.
description: Home to about 8,000 people, Montpelier is one of Americas smallest state capitals.

title: 36 Hours in Montpelier, Vt.
description: TUCKED away in a tangle of wilderness and clinging to the edges of the Winooski and North Branch Rivers, Montpelier, Vt., with a population of about 8,000, is one of the smallest state capitals in the country, but it is also among the most forward-thinking. Its the capital of the first state to formally abolish slavery in 1777, and the first to allow civil unions for gay couples.

title: Weight-Loss Surgery May Prevent Diabetes
description: For people who are extremely overweight and likely to develop diabetes, surgery may be the best form of prevention.

title: Second World Mind Sports Games in France
description: LILLE, France  At the Second World Mind Sports Games here the United States senior team (Richie Schwartz, Lew Finkel, Neil Chambers, John Schermer, Steve Landen and Sam Lev; I was its nonplaying captain) failed in its bid to win the world title. In the 96-board final on Tuesday and Wednesday against Hungary (Mikos Dumbovich, Mihaly Kovacs, Peter Magyar and Geza Szappanos, with its nonplaying captain, Gyorgy Barany), the United States lost by 247 international match points to 166. France came in third.

title: Artifacts | A David Among Goliaths
description: When the art world reconvenes in Chelsea this fall, it will find the usual bounty of big-name artists  and a leap into gigantism among some of their dealers. Sean Kelly, David Zwirner, Hauser & Wirth, Friedrich Petzel and Andrea Rosen are either multiplying their locations or tripling in size, or both. But one Chelsea stalwart is expanding his business by going small. And Taiwanese.

title: Inspiring Activism With an App
description: A tech company in New Haven, Conn., inspires community activism with a mobile phone app.

title: Santana Probably Wont Pitch Again This Season
description: 7:07 p.m. | Updated

title: A House Overlooking the Aegean in Turkey
description: A four-bedroom stone house built into a hill on the Bodrum Peninsula is on the market for $2.6 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Turkey
description: STONE HOUSE WITH AEGEAN SEA VIEWS ON A TURKISH PENINSULA

title: The Second Avenue Blasts, Above and Below Ground
description: The words have become a decades-long refrain: Work has been suspended on the Second Avenue subway line. The latest cause? An intentional underground explosion at 72nd Street, during which something went awry and an explosion was felt at street level, Adam Lisberg, a Metropolitan Transportation Authority spokesman, told The Times.

title: Ian Falconer: By the Book
description: The author and illustrator, most recently, of Olivia and the Fairy Princesses says good childrens books dont underestimate the reader. Children will figure things out.

title: Things to Consider When Buying a Monitor
description: Just so you know, some marketing genius out there has decided computer monitors arent computer monitors anymore. They are displays. Raise the curtain and cue the John Williams soundtrack.

description: SARATOGA, CALIF.

title: Homes for ... $3 Million
description: Properties in California, Louisiana and Colorado.

title: Pop Stars Join Growing Effort to Aid the Poor
description: If there is such a thing as a prodigy in the world of philanthropy, Hugh Evans fits the bill. At 14, after visiting a Manila slum with the Christian humanitarian group World Vision, he returned to his middle-class home outside Melbourne, Australia, and announced to his mother he wanted to dedicate his life to ending extreme poverty. She laughed.

title: New Yorks City Council Adds Climate Change Panels
description: The exodus of City Hall aides has already begun as Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs term approaches its end next year, but climate change isnt going anywhere. So in an attempt to continue Mr. Bloombergs environmental focus long after hes gone, the City Council passed legislationon Wednesday that would make two panels advising the city on the threats of global warming a permanent fixture of government.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Hackers Gain Ground, and Backpacking Tech
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: If Summer Goes, Why Wont the Guests?
description: MEGAN MURPHY SCHWAB, a marketing executive in suburban New Jersey, was seven months pregnant with her second child when a friend asked if another friend, who had just arrived in New York, might spend a night at her home to escape the summer heat. Ms. Schwab had met the woman, who seemed nice enough, so she and her husband, Jeff, an accountant, agreed to put her up.

title: After Dinner, the Fireworks
description: Seattle

title: Letter to the Director of National Intelligence
description: Thirteen senators signed a letter to James R. Clapper Jr. the Director of National Intelligence, expressing concern about a loophole in the law that permits the collection of United States data.

title: F.T.C. Ends Investigation on Facebooks Instagram Deal
description: After months of anticipation, Facebook is now closer to completing its takeover of Instagram, the popular photo-sharing application.

title: Beware the Fiscal Cliff
description: Theres an easy way to cut the deficit nearly in half, the Congressional Budget Office said today: just do nothing when the various elements of the fiscal cliff click into place on New Years Day. Taxes will go up, spending will go down, and the deficit will be cut from $1.1 trillion this year to $641 billion in 2013.

title: Backyard Stonehenges
description: Megalithic stone circles are still being built and admired in modern times.

title: Scourge of the Lionfish
description: Carl Safina is founder of Blue Ocean Institute at Stony Brook University and a MacArthur Fellow. His books include A Sea in Flames: The Deepwater Horizon Oil Blowout, and The View From Lazy Point; A Natural Year in an Unnatural World, which won the 2012 Orion Award. His series Saving the Ocean will be premiering this fall on PBS television.

title: Made by Druids, Loved by Dragons
description: WORCESTER, Vt.

title: Is Someone Trying To Tell Us Something?
A Nuclear Powerhouse
description: Exelon is one of the nations largest electric utility companies. It owns or operates 14 nuclear power plants in 5 states.

title: On the Upper West Side, Suggestions of the Sea
description: A two-bedroom Upper West Side co-op hints at the nautical.

title: Bringing the Ocean With Her
description: WHEN Marie DiManno got married in 1973, her new husband, Jerry DiManno, told her, You have to love the beach.

title: Afghanistan, Contradicting NATO, Blames Foreign Spies for Insider Attacks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Even as the Afghan government said on Wednesday that it would take new measures to counter a wave of deadly insider killings of Western troops by Afghan security forces, President Hamid Karzais office asserted for the first time that foreign spy agencies were behind most of the attacks, putting it directly at odds with NATOs assessment of the crisis.

title: Exotics
description: Ryan Korban, a 28-year-old self-taught interior designer, enjoys decorative pieces that show off exotic animal skins and tusks.

title: Spaniers Lawyers Attack Freeh Findings
description: Lawyers for the former Penn State president Graham B. Spanier issued a searing rebuttal Wednesday to findings by the former F.B.I. director Louis J. Freeh that Spanier and other top university officials had helped conceal allegations of child abuse involving the former assistant football coach Jerry Sandusky.

title: Exotics
description: RYAN KORBAN is a 28-year-old self-taught interior designer with a full-size taxidermy zebra in his living room, custom shagreen-covered chairs in his dining room and a vintage goat-parchment armoire.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. The carpeting on our stairs is worn. Should we replace it before selling our home? And if so, with what?

title: Hunt Continues for Escaped Peacock in Queens
description: As of late Wednesday afternoon, the captivating, if elusive, peacock flying around Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, had still not been apprehended.

title: Images From Wyeths World, Paint Splatters and All
description: James Wellings interest in Andrew Wyeth dates from his teenage years, when he took a drawing class at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, where some of the artists work was displayed. Flash forward four decades. Mr. Welling, 61, is a professor in the Art Department at U.C.L.A. (he will be a visiting professor at Princeton starting next month). During his prolific career, he has painted, sculptured and worked in video. At one point, he was John Baldessaris teaching assistant.

title: Hamptons Havens Open for a Day
description: Do hedge fund managers hedges grow any greener? Two of the impeccably tended Edens on view this weekend for charity may offer a clue. On Saturday, the Guild Hall of East Hampton will present its seventh annual lecture and garden tour, the Garden as Art, offering access to five private gardens.

title: A Classic Bookcase Comes to America
description: The late Danish architect Mogens Koch, one of the lesser-known heroes of Scandinavian design, is perhaps best remembered for the shelving system he created in 1928 for his own home in Copenhagen. The system soon caught the interest of Rud. Rasmussen, a local company. Rasmussen put it into production in 1932 and has been making it ever since. Last year, Carl Hansen, another Danish manufacturer, acquired Rasmussen and is giving Mr. Kochs design its American debut. The Shelving System (it features an extensive range of modular elements, including a CD/DVD unit) is exceptionally flexible. The sections for the basic six-piece unit can be installed horizontally or vertically, allowing lots of options. Made of solid oak with dovetail and rabbet joints to provide strength and stability, the basic unit measures about 30 by 30 by 10.6 inches and is $1,650. Information: (212) 242-6736 or carlhansen.com.

title: Help Paige Rense Noland Clear Her Closets
description: As the former editor of Architectural Digest, Paige Rense Noland spent 35 years influencing taste. On Saturday, at 11 a.m., Eastern time, many of the objects she collected during that time will go up for sale at the online retailer One Kings Lane.

title: The City That Always Twinkles
description: Like so many other New Yorkers, David Weeks is a bit of a voyeur. His latest product, the Lonely City USB hub, is the result of walking down the street late at night, looking up at a building and seeing that one window lit up, he said. Maybe its a lamp, maybe its the glow of a TV. The hub illuminates when plugged into an outlet, regardless of whether a device is charging (theres room for four to charge at any given time). The buildings are based on a Google map view of 16th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, a block Mr. Weeks said he has frequented over the years, whether on the way to teaching at Parsons or shopping at Paul Smith. Google maps shows the ghosted buildings at a 45-degree angle  we looked at that block, broke it into several parts and then elaborated on it, he said. The Windows- and Mac-compatible hub is $25 on Mr. Weekss retail site, tweekstudio.com.

title: Sales at Home Remedy, Modani, West Elm and Others
description: Some items from Jonathan Adler, Aid to Artisans, Kahler and others are up to 75 percent off at Home Remedy, through Sept. 3 (an Aid to Artisans throw, originally $80, is $56); (800) 363-0405, homeremedynyc.com.

title: In the City, T Stands for Taxi
description: Whats next? T Driver, starring Robert De Niro?

title: Talking Policy and Philosophy
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is looking for ideas.

title: Nova, With Soreness in Shoulder, Will Probably Miss Next Start
description: CHICAGO  With the Yankees on the verge of being forced to make a decision about whom to drop from the starting rotation, they might not have to make that call after Ivan Nova came up with soreness on the outside of his right shoulder.

title: Fans Worry After Pakistan Twitter Star Goes Off Line
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Where r u MAJOR ?? What happened 2 u ?? I hope u r safe from mad dog jihadis.

title: A Wife Recalls Her Estranged Husbands 1972 Failed Bank Robbery
description: On Aug. 22, 1972, Carmen Wojtowicz was at Rockaway Beach getting some sun with her two children when she heard a news bulletin on her portable radio about an admitted homosexual robbing a bank.

title: Sculpture City
description: A look at public art displays in New York City.

title: At Edinburgh Fringe, Topical Playwriting Is Seriously Up to the Minute
description: EDINBURGH  Political theater aims to be topical, but a recent presentation here by Theater Uncut had a sense of immediacy that was notable even by that standard.

title: A Petition to the White House: Give Up the Beer Recipe
description: Most Americans wont ever drink a beer at the White House, but some beer enthusiasts are hoping theyll soon be able to have a pint that tastes like its brew.

title: After Trip of 352 Million Miles, Cheers for 23 Feet on Mars
description: It was a modest test drive: moving forward 15 feet, turning in place 120 degrees, then backing up about 8 feet. The entire trip took about 16 minutes, with most of the time spent stopped as cameras took photographs of the progress.

title: In Fashion, Are Trends Pass?
description: Here are some style directions from some of the fashion industrys influential coterie of tastemakers.

title: Exploring Africas Big, Wild Rhino Country
description: How many times in life does anyone get to see an entirely different world, which makes one question all the old familiar things? Rick Bass, an environmental writer based in Montana, poses this question to readers in his new book, The Black Rhinos of Namibia, a conservation and adventure story set in the mean expanses of southwest Africas Namib Desert.

title: Racial Comment by Republican Official in Ohio Rekindles Battle Over Early Voting
description: CLEVELAND  A battle over early voting hours in Ohio is flaring again after a top adviser to Gov. John Kasich, a Republican, this week made remarks that Democrats cast as racist, and the Republican secretary of state suspended two local election officials who voted to extend balloting hours in one county.

title: Regulator Fines Bank for Analysts Violations
description: Rodman & Renshaw, an investment bank that sponsored numerous Chinese companies in the United States market, was fined $315,000 on Wednesday by Finra, the financial markets private regulator, for repeated violations of rules about the use of analysts to seek investment banking business.

title: Freedom of Choice
description: KATE LANPHEAR, the platinum-thatched, leather-sheathed style director of Elle, is commonly peppered at dinner parties with questions about fashions next wave.

title: Things I Saw  No. 27
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: Changes to Money Market Funds Stall
description: Attempts to make sweeping changes to a popular type of mutual fund that played a central role in the 2008 financial crisis have been derailed.

title: In Nevada, Voting for None Is No Longer an Option
description: Voters in Nevada will have to make an actual choice, a federal judge there ruled on Wednesday.

title: Beauty Spots
description: EAU DE PHONE Serge Lutens, who has done photography and art direction, and is now a celebrated perfumer, is selling his elegant cloche perfume bottles in the United States for the first time, starting this month ($280 to $300 each). The Barneys New York flagship on Madison Avenue is his exclusive retailer; the store also has a telephone number, (212) 833-2425, for those whod like to call in for their cloche, which contains a choice of 30 signature fragrances, some of them also available for the first time in this country, like Iris Silver Mist and La Myrrhe.

title: Despite #NBCFail, NBC and Twitter Say Partnership Was Success
description: If you followed the griping by Twitter users  about NBCs handling of the Olympic Games, you might think the NBC-Twitter Olympics partnership was an epic disaster. NBCs decision to time-delay most events prompted angry kvetching on Twitter and quickly popularized the hashtag #NBCFail.

title: Hoping to Get Lucky Again in the Travers
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  The pills rattled in the jar announcing that the post-position draw for the Travers Stakes was under way. On the edge of the paddock, the trainer Gary Contessa tried to explain why he had entered a horse named Speightscity that looked as if he had no chance to win the 143rd running of the Midsummer Derby on Saturday.

title: Aug. 22: Keeping Score on a Busy Polling Day
description: Wednesday was among the busiest polling days of the year; we added 14 new surveys to our database, including some from rarely polled states like Montana and New Mexico.

title: A Lemon Grower Emphasizes Uses for Citrus Outside the Kitchen
description: AMERICANS on average consume only three pounds of fresh lemons annually  the equivalent of about a dozen medium lemons  compared with the 6.2 pounds Europeans consume, according to data from the Agriculture Department.

title: Panel Wants Former Judge in Syracuse Kept Off Bench
description: A former family court judge in Syracuse should be barred from returning to the bench, the State Commission on Judicial Conduct ruled Wednesday, after an investigation into an act of sexual misconduct 40 years ago with his niece, 13 years before he became a jurist.

title: Signs of Revival, Slight but Sure, for Home Sales
description: Analysts are hailing the beginnings of a recovery in the nations housing market. But to beleaguered homeowners, it will not feel like much of one for many months to come.

title: Romney Energy Plan Would Expand Oil Drilling on U.S. Land and Offshore
description: HOUSTON  Mitt Romney plans to unveil an energy plan Thursday morning in Hobbs, N.M., that would allow states more control over the development of energy resources on federal lands within their borders, as well as aggressively expand offshore oil and gas drilling  including along the coasts of Virginia and the Carolinas  as part of a broader effort to reach energy independence.

title: Dolan to Give Benediction at Gathering of the G.O.P.
description: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the archbishop of New York, will deliver the closing prayer at the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla., after Mitt Romney accepts the partys presidential nomination next week.

title: In Defense of Big Banks
description: BANKS arent always popular even in the best of times, but the anger of recent years is unprecedented. The anger, while understandable, has fueled the misguided idea that we should break up the nations largest banks.

title: Another Senate Race Seizes on Rape Remark
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass.  Heated exchanges over the war on women have suddenly come to dominate the closely watched Senate race here, thanks to an obscure Republican congressman from Missouri.

title: Developments in Iran and Sinai Deepen Israels Worries About Egypt
description: JERUSALEM  With Egypts new Islamist president headed to Iran next week and its military deploying tanks in the Sinai Peninsula  possibly outside the parameters of his nations 33-year-old treaty with Israel  officials here are increasingly worried about what has long been their most critical regional relationship.

title: A Deeper Search for Secrets on Mars
description: Astronauts wont be landing on Mars anytime soon, but, in recent weeks, NASA has made great strides toward exploring the planet more thoroughly than ever before with automated laboratories dropped on the surface. It is a welcome development given increasingly tight budgets for robotic explorations of the solar system.

title: Snub to City by Lil Wayne Outrages an Official

title: The Program

title: The Program
description: It took me a few days to work up the nerve to phone William Binney. As someone already a target of the United States government, I found it difficult not to worry about the chain of unintended consequences I might unleash by calling Mr. Binney, a 32-year veteran of the National Security Agency turned whistle-blower. He picked up. I nervously explained I was a documentary filmmaker and wanted to speak to him. To my surprise he replied: Im tired of my government harassing me and violating the Constitution. Yes, Ill talk to you.

title: Ties to Obama Aided in Access for Big Utility
description: WASHINGTON  Early in the Obama administration, a lobbyist for the Illinois-based energy producer Exelon Corporation proudly called it the presidents utility. And it was not just because it delivers power to Barack Obamas Hyde Park neighborhood in Chicago.

title: Nina Bawden, Author of Carries War, Dies at 87
description: Nina Bawden, a writer for children and adults whose work included books born of personal tragedy, died on Wednesday at her home in London. She was 87.

description: JOHANNESBURG  Support for the opposition party that won the greatest number of votes in Zimbabwes last presidential election, turning it into an international symbol of the Zimbabwean peoples desire to end President Robert Mugabes decades of rule, has fallen considerably, according to a new survey published by Freedom House, an international research institution.

description: OTTAWA  There are no cars in Cambridge Bay, Nunavut. Aside from a few trucks, snowmobiles are the preferred form of transportation for much of the year in the hamlet high in the Canadian Arctic.

description: Nearly 20 employees of the New York Police Department have faced discipline in connection with the posting of racist or derogatory comments on a Facebook page about revelers at the 2011 West Indian American Day Parade, a heavily policed annual celebration in Brooklyn on Labor Day weekend, a spokesman for the department said Wednesday.

title: Give Small Political Donors a Voice
description: The Congressional race between two incumbent Democrats in the redrawn 30th District in California is one of the most expensive in the country, but it is hardly unusual in reflecting the influence of big donors. Howard Berman has raised $3.5 million, while his opponent, Brad Sherman, raised $2.7 million. For both candidates, only 1 percent of their money came from donations under $200.

title: Impasse Over Suspects Beard Spurs Debate in Fort Hood Shooting Case
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Inside his cell at the Bell County jail, Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan said he had a premonition months ago: He was going to die soon.

description: Martine Franck, a photographer whose documentary-style portraits of artists and marginalized populations alike helped her rise into the highest echelons of her profession while fiercely protecting the artistic legacy of her husband, Henri Cartier-Bresson, died last Thursday in Paris. She was 74.

Tobacco Companies Broke Law by Selling Untaxed Cigarettes, Judge Rules

title: Another Rebuff for Cleaner Air
description: Whats a federal agency to do? Twice in the last eight years, the Environmental Protection Agency has issued carefully vetted rules aimed at reducing air pollution that crosses state lines  the smog-forming nitrogen oxide pollutants and health-threatening sulfur dioxide that drift eastward from Midwestern power plants. And, in both cases, the agency has been shot down by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

title: Silicon Valley Techies Fight to Save a Popular but Illegal Haven
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Hacker Dojo is equal parts shared office, lecture hall and after-hours salon for a variety of tinkerers, software coders and entrepreneurs who intend to reinvent the future. The idea for Pinterest was cooked up here. The makers of Pebble watches used the space as their West Coast headquarters. Today, however, it is threatened with extinction. City officials in Mountain View have ordered Hacker Dojo to comply with city regulations for offices or move out.

title: Victory for Akin Seen as Difficult, but Still Possible
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  In the end, Representative Todd Akins fate will depend not on what happens in Washington or Tampa, Fla., or on a talk radio show, but on the voters of Missouri.

Like lines carved into the trunk of one of the copper beech trees lining the Black Course, the growth of mens golf could be measured Wednesday at Bethpage State Park in the procession of players to the interview room on the eve of the Barclays, the first FedEx Cup playoff event.

title: Willa Ward, Gospel Singer, Dies at 91

description: Late Tuesday night, shortly after the Mets bumbled their way to a dreary 6-2 loss against the Colorado Rockies, their sixth defeat in eight games, Manager Terry Collins offered reporters an impassioned recounting of a stern message he had just delivered to his players inside their locked clubhouse.

title: Rosemary Rice, Oldest Daughter of TVs Mama, Dies at 87
description: Rosemary Rice, an actress who found fame in the early days of television playing the perky oldest daughter, Katrin, on Mama, a beloved family show broadcast live on CBS for many years, died on Aug. 14 at her home in Stamford, Conn. She was 87.

title: Matthew Ianniello, the Mafia Boss Known as Matty the Horse, Dies at 92
description: Matthew Ianniello, the low-key reputed Genovese crime boss known as Matty the Horse, who was convicted of rigging construction bids, skimming union dues and wringing protection money from bar owners, pornography peddlers and topless dancers during a half-century career that, among other highlights, helped transform Times Square into the dingy world capital of peep shows in the 1960s and 70s, died on Aug. 15 at his home in Old Westbury, on Long Island. He was 92.

title: Tiny Hawaiian Island Will See if New Owner Tilts at Windmills
description: LANAI CITY, Hawaii  Lanai should be the very picture of tropical tranquillity, the kind of Pacific island where Gilligan set ground. Just 3,135 people live on its 141 square miles. There are no traffic lights, movie theaters or bakeries. There is just one gas station and three main roads. It is ringed with vast and empty beaches, accessible only by four-wheel drive. A visitor can roam its hills for hours without encountering another living being.

title: William P. Thurston, Theoretical Mathematician, Dies at 65
description: William P. Thurston, a mathematician who revolutionized understanding of the structure of three-dimensional spaces and won the Fields Medal, often described as the equivalent of the Nobel Prize for mathematics, died on Tuesday in Rochester. He was 65.

description: MIAMI  The sight of beachgoers flying hundreds of feet above a boat while dangling from a parachute is a common one up and down Floridas coast.

description: A tariff meant to provide revenue for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority by taxing businesses in the New York City region was struck down as unconstitutional on Wednesday by a State Supreme Court justice in Nassau County.

title: Healing the Knee, and Then the Psyche
description: Jamal Lewiss right knee might have been injured, but his foot was fine, and he used it to mash the gas pedal in his car. It was Oct. 4, 1998. He drove along Interstate 40 in Tennessee. First east. Then back west again, crying and agonizing all the way. The day before, Lewis, then a sophomore running back for the University of Tennessee, had torn his lateral collateral ligament in a game against Auburn, an injury that abruptly ended a promising season.

title: Romney Strategists Say Theyll Stay the Course Amid Focus on Abortion
description: WASHINGTON  Mitt Romneys campaign advisers have concluded that they do not need any major adjustments in strategy to respond to the new focus on abortion and reproductive rights caused by Representative Todd Akin, betting that their candidates economic message will still resonate with female voters after the controversy over Mr. Akins remarks about legitimate rape subsides.

title: Mets Add to Woes, Despite Solid Start by Harvey
description: The Mets wasted another strong start from the rookie Matt Harvey, failing to overtake the lowly Colorado Rockies during a 5-2 loss Wednesday night at Citi Field.

title: Georgia: 2 Waffle House Plotters Are Sentenced
description: Two of the four men who federal officials said plotted terrorist activities from a booth at a North Georgia Waffle House were sentenced to five years in prison on Wednesday for conspiring to obtain an unregistered explosive device and silencer. Defense lawyers had argued that the men were egged on by an informant and that recordings of their plot showed nothing more than old men bragging. Prosecutors said the men were members of a loose-knit militia group that had scouted federal buildings in Atlanta to attack and had planned to kill people. Judge Richard W. Story of Federal District Court said that while people have the right to talk about what they want, when they start buying bombs and silencers, Im sorry, we have crossed the line. Lawyers for the men, Frederick Thomas, 73, and Dan Roberts, 68, said the sentence was part of a plea deal that includes 100 hours of community service. The other men charged, Ray Adams and Samuel Crump, both in their 60s, plan to go to trial. They are charged with conspiracy and attempting to make the poison ricin from castor beans.

title: With Heat Turned Up, Yankees Sit Down, One by One

title: Life, Interrupted: Six Ways to Cope With Cancer
description: People are always giving advice to cancer patients. Whether it is nutritional advice or doctor recommendations or tips on how to quell the nausea that accompanies chemotherapy, just as soon as people hear you are sick they usually want to find a way to help. Most of the advice is welcome and encouraging, though in some cases youre just not in the mood to hear what someone has learned because youre too busy treading water.

title: Simon Says Dont Use Flashcards
description: Parents who want to stimulate their childrens brain development often focus on things like early reading, flashcards and language tapes. But a growing body of research suggests that playing certain kinds of childhood games may be the best way to increase a childs ability to do well in school. Variations on games like Freeze Tag and Simon Says require relatively high levels of executive function, testing a childs ability to pay attention, remember rules and exhibit self-control  qualities that also predict academic success.

description: Campaigning in swing states on Wednesday, Mitt Romney spoke about the economy while President Obama focused on education.

title: A Conversation With: Assam Students Union Adviser Bhattacharya
description: Over the last week, the conflict between the indigenous Bodo tribe and Muslims in Assam has led to panic in various Indian cities. On Aug.15, rumors of possible violence led several thousand people from Indias northeastern region to flee Bangalore. The exodus continued over the next few days as thousands flocked to train stations in Bangalore, Chennai and Pune, while Indian leaders attempted to restore calm.

title: The Fatal Shore, Awash in Plastic
description: HONG KONG  A recent typhoon off Hong Kong washed half a dozen shipping containers overboard, and it wasnt long before the cargo  150 tons of tiny plastic beads  began washing up on the beaches. Local fish farmers also started finding the plastic in the stomachs of their fish.

description: No cricketer in history has been more accustomed than Sachin Tendulkar to playing five-day test matches,  Huw Richards wrote in The International Herald Tribune.

title: New Orleans Saints, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
description: No one really knows whether the New Orleans Saints can overcome the distractions and fallout of the bounties scandal. Their situation  Coach Sean Payton suspended for the year, the interim head coach Joe Vitt suspended for the first six games, General Manager Mickey Loomis suspended for the first eight  is unprecedented in the N.F.L. Until Wednesday, it was still unknown who, exactly, would be in charge for the first month and a half of the season while Vitt was away. (The Saints chose offensive line coach Aaron Kromer.)

title: Britain and France Join the U.S. in Warning Syria About Military Action

description: BERLIN  Returning to business after their summer breaks, the German and French leaders met here Thursday to discuss the continuing crisis in the euro zone, even as fresh economic data reinforced fears that the region was sliding into recession.
