When Edgar proposes to Rachael (Claira Watson Parr), half-sister of Katrina, she replies: What? God, no. I mean, sorry, Ive got a boyfriend.

title: Attacks on Afghan Troops by Colleagues Are Rising, Allies Say
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Even as attacks by Afghan security forces on NATO troops have become an increasing source of tension, new NATO data shows another sign of vulnerability for the training mission: even greater numbers of the Afghan police and military forces have killed each other this year.

title: The Ampersand as Crate & Barrels Vital Link
description: COMMERCIALS that are the centerpiece of a coming campaign for a major retailer of home furnishings may raise eyebrows. They show neither homes nor furnishings, nor the people who live in homes or buy furnishings.

title: Crate & Barrel Commercial
description: A campaign for the Crate & Barrel retail chain, scheduled to begin on Sept. 10, shows neither homes nor furnishings, nor the people who live in homes or buy furnishings.

title: City Sets Up a Corporation to Oversee Its Tech Projects
description: Scalded by scandal, cost overruns and embarrassments in some of its most ambitious computerization efforts, the Bloomberg administration has hit upon on a new remedy: outsourcing such projects to a new quasi-governmental entity that will operate free of the usual city procurement rules, salary limits and legislative oversight.

title: From the Slums to the Soccer Field, 2 Boys Grasp at Hope
description: Hermano, the heartfelt first feature from the Venezuelan filmmaker Marcel Rasquin, follows two soccer-playing boys whose striking talents offer escape from the slums of Caracas.

title: Latinos Who Invested Savings Claim Betrayal in Ponzi Scheme
description: Before Ruben Loja decided to invest in the fruit and vegetable importing business that had Latinos in pockets of Queens buzzing over the sizable checks paid every month, he visited its warehouse in the Bronx.

title: Abortion and Akin Were Off Limits During Romney Interview, Reporter Says
description: Its the sort of statement that leaves journalists slack-jawed: The one stipulation to the interview was that I not ask him about abortion or Todd Akin.

title: Taming of the Steed
description: If youre a true horseman, this is as good as it gets, a trainer says at the outset of Wild Horse Wild Ride, a documentary about the Extreme Mustang Makeover challenge. This annual competition assigns 100 trainers 100 mustangs that had been rounded up in federal sweeps of public lands. Each trainer has 100 days to tame it before a two-day event in Fort Worth showcases the horses abilities and obedience. After a champion team is chosen, the horses are auctioned the next day, presumably to head to better lives.

title: Lessons in Life, Love and Tennis
description: Among the problems with the humorless comedy General Education is that the lead characters sister is more interesting than he is, and she spends much of her screen time as a mute mime.

title: A Creative Fold
description: Taros Origami Studio in Park Slope, Brooklyn, guides the young and old through the Japanese craft of paper folding.

title: Call to Stiffen Laws Worries Town Built by Guns
description: ILION, N.Y.  This is the town that Remington built.

title: In Effort to Curb Money Market Funds, a Plan B Is Considered
description: After the failure of one effort to overhaul a major part of the mutual fund industry, top government officials worked on Thursday to find alternative ways to rein in what they see as a systemic threat to the financial system.

title: Why China Resents Japan, and Us
description: Norman, Okla.

title: Is Private School Not Expensive Enough?
description: ANY parent of a private-school child will tell you that tuitions are painfully high  and getting worse every year. Many New York City schools are approaching the $40,000 mark. And its not just New York: charges at many private secondary boarding schools are now touching $50,000. Outrageous, many say.

title: The Medieval Roots of Todd Akins Theories
description: Middletown, Conn.

title: Season Tickets for Knicks and Rangers Are Nearly Sold Out
description: The Knicks and the Rangers are on pace to sell out nearly all their available season tickets for this season after both teams qualified for the playoffs for the second straight year.

title: Export Powerhouse Feels Pangs of Labor Strife
description: ISHWARDI, Bangladesh  The air thickened with tear gas as police and paramilitary officers jogged into the Ishwardi Export Processing Zone firing rubber bullets and swinging cane poles. Panicked factory workers tried to flee. A seamstress crumpled to the ground, knocked unconscious by a shot in the head.

title: Giving Reins to the States Over Drilling
description: By proposing to end a century of federal control over oil and gas drilling and coal mining on government lands, Mitt Romney is making a bid for anti-Washington voters in key Western states while dangling the promise of a big reward to major campaign supporters from the energy industry.

title: Lottery Numbers
Egyptian Presidents Move Ends Detention of Critic
description: CAIRO  Wielding his extensive legislative powers for the first time, Egypts president, Mohamed Morsi, on Thursday outlawed the pretrial detention of people accused of press crimes, effectively freeing one of his toughest critics, a newspaper editor who was detained just hours before the law was passed.

title: Galt, Gold and God
description: So far, most of the discussion of Paul Ryan, the presumptive Republican nominee for vice president, has focused on his budget proposals. But Mr. Ryan is a man of many ideas, which would ordinarily be a good thing.

title: Ryans Biggest Mistake
description: A few years ago, President Obama established a debt commission that was led by Alan Simpson and Erskine Bowles and had a group of eminences, including Representative Paul Ryan.

title: G.M. Has High Hopes for New, Smaller Cadillac
description: DETROIT  It has been three years since General Motors hobbled out of bankruptcy with a pledge that its newest cars would be competitive with the best in the world.

title: Haitis Unnatural Disaster
description: The tropical storm bearing down this week on Haiti threatens to add more layers of misery in a country that has been awash in suffering since the 2010 earthquake. Two-and-a-half years and billions of dollars later, the most basic necessity  safe, permanent shelter  remains out of reach for hundreds of thousands of the displaced.

title: 2 Are Shot Near Yankee Stadium
description: A sharply dressed vendor on a busy Bronx corner about a block from Yankee Stadium shot two men on Thursday afternoon, the police said.

title: A Business That Wants to Fold
description: TAHITI STARSHIP was helping her 5-year-old son, Ruvane, learn origami from a book earlier this summer. But the folding got too complex for her.

title: Run to Death at Racetracks
description: Handicappers and bettors have had an unexpected new factor to work into their predictions for the elite Travers Stakes Saturday at the racetrack in Saratoga Springs: the disclosure, on the Web, of each medication dose given to the thoroughbreds in the days before the race.

title: Romney May Be Nominated Early
description: 1:02 a.m. | Updated TAMPA, Fla.  Mitt Romneys quest to formally win the Republican Partys presidential nomination is coming two days earlier than expected.

title: Creditors of Stockton Fight Over Pension Funding While in Bankruptcy
description: Creditors of the city of Stockton, Calif., are mounting a challenge against a popular belief: that public workers pensions are impervious to cutbacks even when a city goes bankrupt.

title: Labor Unrest in Bangladeshs Garment Industry
description: As workers have demanded higher wages and labor rights, protests and violent clashes with police have become increasingly common.

title: Teachers, Unions and Education Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Ice Center With 9 Rinks Is Proposed for Bronx Armory
description: The long-empty Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx would be converted into a national ice center with nine ice rinks and extensive youth hockey and skating programs under a proposal that a group of Bronx elected officials and labor leaders endorsed on Thursday.

title: A Slim Recovery for Housing
description: The economy will not recover until the housing market recovers, and the housing market will not recover until the broader economy recovers  a chicken-and-egg problem reflected, once again, in national housing figures.

title: Documents Show Details on Romney Family Trusts
description: Hundreds of pages of confidential internal documents from the private equity firm Bain Capital published online Thursday provided new details on investments held by the Romney familys trusts, as well as aggressive strategies that Bain appears to have used to minimize its investors and partners tax liabilities.

title: Drought Extends, Crops Wither
description: An analysis by The New York Times looks at the widely varying effects of this summers heat and drought on crops critical to the nations farm economy.

title: Syrian War Plays Out Along a Street in Lebanon
description: TRIPOLI, Lebanon  The Alawite snipers here fire from behind tires in bombed-out apartment buildings as posters of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria flap in the breeze. The Sunnis just down the hill set up their own gunmen behind sandbags near flags for the Free Syrian Army.

title: Has Support for Israel Hurt U.S. Credibility?
The Terrorist List
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigration Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: An Awful Trip on Amtrak
description: To the Editor:

title: Music Shop Recognizes Somber Tune: Its Final Coda
description: It is a given among regulars at Colony Records that a customer need only whistle, hum, or la, la, la a few bars of a tune for an employee to recognize it. Through the narrow corridors and battered shelves of the cozy store in the storied Brill Building in Times Square, a knowing worker will then peruse and (more often than not) find the sheet music, vinyl record or CD the person is looking for.

title: The Crackpot Caucus
description: The tutorial in 8th grade biology that Republicans got after one of their members of Congress went public with something from the wackosphere was instructive, and not just because it offered female anatomy lessons to those who get their science from the Bible.

title: Preparing in Tampa for a Convention That Might Become a Hurricane Party
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Plan B is out of the drawer and on the table. Goody bags at receptions around town will be stuffed with umbrellas. And Republican officials are crossing fingers that the Mitt Romney for President placards will not be used, in a pinch, as hurricane shutters.

title: With Footwear Scanners Failing in Airport Tests, the Shoes Still Have to Come Off
description: WASHINGTON  After spending millions of dollars testing four different scanning devices that would allow airline passengers to keep their shoes on at security checkpoints, the United States government has decided for now that travelers must continue to remove their footwear, by far the leading source of frustration and delays at the airport.

title: Rarely Played Nowadays
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Wow, those are some wide open stretches spanning Mark Diehls grid. I used to be intimidated by those, but now Im glad whenever I see them. I know that, if the crossword gods are with me, those long entries will yield some fun. I wasnt let down today.

title: Mies Julie Wins Best of Edinburgh Fringe Award
description: Mies Julie, a smoldering South African stage adaptation of August Strindbergs 1888 drama Miss Julie, won the ninth annual Carol Tambor Best of Edinburgh award, to be presented Friday in Scotland.

title: Borussia Monchengladbach Learns a Champions League Lesson
description: Soccer, like any sport, is nothing more than emotional theater  demonstrated, in this case, through the physical act of 22 men chasing a round ball around a park. As such it often leads the typical fan down a bumpy path where turmoil and ecstasy go hand in hand.

title: Ohio Mans Shooting of Ailing Wife Raises Questions About Mercy Killings
description: MASSILLON, Ohio  John Wise tipped the taxi driver $25 that night, even though the driver had been late to pick him up and late getting him to Akron General hospital, about 30 miles north of this former steel town. Why he had to get there with such urgency the driver did not know, and did not ask, but before driving away, he wished Mr. Wise luck.

title: Woods and McIlroy Get the Attention While Harrington Grabs the Lead
description: FARMINGDALE, N.Y.  Thousands of spectators fanned out on the back nine of the Black Course at Bethpage State Park on Thursday morning to watch the first PGA Tour pairing of Tiger Woods and his latest heir apparent, Rory McIlroy. They planted themselves along the gallery ropes and broke the birdsong with cries of We love ya, baby! for Woods and observations like Rorys much slighter than I thought and How can you not be a Rory fan?

title: Armstrong Drops Fight Against Doping Charges
description: After more than a decade of outrunning accusations that he had doped during his celebrated cycling career, Lance Armstrong, one of the best known and most accomplished athletes in recent history, surrendered on Thursday, ending his fight against charges that he used performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Robert Treboux, Restaurateur, Dies at 87
description: Robert Treboux, the owner of the venerable Manhattan bistro Le Veau dOr and one of the last of the influential chefs and restaurant owners who came out of Le Pavillon and put their stamp on fine dining in New York for decades, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: Agents Sue Over Deportation Suspensions
description: Claiming they are being forced to carry out an illegal policy, 10 immigration agents filed a federal lawsuit in Texas on Thursday against Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano, seeking to overturn an Obama administration program that suspends deportations for illegal immigrants who came here when they were children.

title: Italian-American Group Suing Columbia for Misuse of Building Development Gift
description: La Casa Italiana is on Amsterdam Avenue, on the same block as the Columbia University presidents house. With its tan exterior, arched windows and Italian-style roof, it looks as though it was imported from Florence.

title: Round One at The Barclays
description: Padraig Harrington led all competitors with a seven-under-par 64 after the first round.

title: A Candidates Stumble on a Distressing Crime
description: When Representative Todd Akin of Missouri said in an interview broadcast on Sunday that rape victims rarely get pregnant, he set off an outraged national discussion. Embedded, if unexamined, in all the talk is the rapidly shifting definition of rape, the history of the derided but longstanding term forcible rape, and the wildly varied databases on sexual assault.

title: Labor Talks Will Start Again Tuesday in New York
description: Negotiations for a new N.H.L. collective bargaining agreement will reconvene in New York on Tuesday with both sides still far apart ahead of Commissioner Gary Bettmans Sept. 15 lockout deadline.

title: Livery Cab Rider Shot in Robbery Attempt Is Dead
description: A livery cab passenger who was shot in the head last weekend during a failed robbery attempt in Brooklyn died on Thursday after being taken off life support, the police said.

title: Two Different Ways Yankees Season Can Go, and Two Ways to Get There
description: CHICAGO  They are arguably the two most influential people in Yankee uniforms, two pillars the rest of the Yankees will look to for guidance over the final 38 games of the season.

title: New Twist Emerges in Handcuffed Mans Shooting Death
description: A man who Arkansas authorities say fatally shot himself in the head last month while handcuffed had called his girlfriend while sitting in the back of the squad car, telling her he had a gun and was frightened, the police said Thursday.

title: Corrections: August 24, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Signs Suggest Iran Is Speeding Up Work on Nuclear Program
description: WASHINGTON  International nuclear inspectors will soon report that Iran has installed hundreds of new centrifuges in recent months and may also be speeding up production of nuclear fuel while negotiations with the United States and its allies have ground to a near halt, according to diplomats and experts briefed on the findings.

title: Wages and Poverty Among Top Apparel Exporters
description: Bangladesh pays the lowest wages among the top five exporters of garments to the United States.

title: For the Ryans, a Union Across Political Lines
description: Their union was not necessarily one that friends and family saw coming. She was from a prominent Democratic family and dabbled in liberal causes during her college years at Wellesley, even once taking a road trip to Washington to march for womens rights. And he, an up-and-coming Republican congressman, had worked after-school jobs to help support his family as a teenager and was known for his deeply conservative views.

title: Crisis Reignites Old Conflicts
description: Across the fields of Andalusia, a longstanding social conflict has been reignited by Spains economic crisis: farmworkers against landowners.

title: Armstrong Surrenders to Doping Charges
description: Lance Armstrong said Thursday that he would not continue to fight the charges levied against him by the United States Anti-Doping Agency, which contended that he doped and was one of the ringleaders of systematic doping on his Tour-winning teams.

title: Spains Crisis Reignites an Old Social Conflict
description: HORNACHUELOS, Spain  Outmaneuvering the police, hundreds of jobless farmworkers charged through a hole in a fence and turned the manicured gardens of a vacant estate here in Spains agricultural heartland into a lively fairground of protest this week. Men more accustomed to working in the fields lounged in the shade beside a pink palace, picnicked on paella and spent a night relaxing. Some even took a dip in the pool.

title: Patrick Ricard, Who Expanded Spirits Company, Dies at 67
description: Eighty years ago, in a small shop in Marseille, Patrick Ricards father concocted an anise-flavored aperitif that became a French favorite and the foundation of one the worlds major distributors of wine and spirits.

title: Its the Presidents Message, With President Clinton
description: WASHINGTON  Former President Bill Clinton is not only campaigning for President Obama in his re-election bid. In a new 30-second commercial released on Thursday by the Obama campaign, he is practically channeling him.

title: Europeans to Debate Further Aid for Greece
description: PARIS  Vacation is over early this year in the euro zone, with Greece and its shaky future back on the table and Spain waiting in the wings to ask for help from European bailout funds.

title: South Korean Court Rejects Online Name Verification Law
description: SEOUL, South Korea  In a major victory for free speech activists in South Korea, a top court on Thursday ruled unconstitutional a law that required Internet users to verify their identity before posting comments on major local Web sites.

title: Judge Upholds Eminent Domain for Pipeline in Texas
description: PARIS, Tex.  The Canadian energy company TransCanada can take over land owned by a Texas farmer to build its Keystone XL pipeline, a county judge ruled on Wednesday night. In a 15-word ruling sent from his iPhone, Judge Bill Harris of Lamar County Court at Law upheld TransCanadas condemnation of a 50-foot strip of land across Julia Trigg Crawfords pasture here. The pipeline is being built to carry oil to Texas refineries from Canada.

title: On Ryans Campaign Plane, Kind Gestures but Few Questions Answered
description: ON BOARD REPRESENTATIVE PAUL D. RYANS CAMPAIGN PLANE  Paul Ryan really wants to be friends. He comes bearing white-chocolate macadamia nut cookies, and offering to buy you a hot dog on your birthday. If he hears you will soon be leaving his back-of-the-plane entourage, he walks down to shake your hand.

title: Romney Uses Array of Props to Help Explain Ideas to Voters
description: HOBBS, N.M.  America is meeting its newest professor: Mitt Romney.

title: Don Raleigh, All-Star Center for Rangers, Dies at 86
description: Don Raleigh, a Rangers All-Star center in the 1950s who became the first N.H.L. player to score sudden-death overtime goals in two consecutive games of a Stanley Cup final series, died on Tuesday in Kingston, Ontario. He was 86.

title: Bristol-Myers Ends a Hepatitis C Project
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb said Thursday that it was discontinuing development of a hepatitis C drug that it had acquired in a $2.5 billion deal, after nine patients in a clinical trial had to be hospitalized and one of them died.

title: Its Not Just Todd Akin
description: In this weeks Opinionator column, Timothy Egan takes readers on what he calls a tour of the crazies in the House.

title: Insider Attacks Target Afghans and Foreign Forces
description: The heightened concern within the U.S. military leadership about the growing number of insider attacks is not new. Infiltration of the Afghan National Army by the Taliban has been a known issue for some time. But recently, there have been heightened worries about how coalition troops can protect themselves while training members of the Afghan Army and the police, especially as the number of foreign forces in Afghanistan begins to decrease. The training program is a central part of Americas withdrawal strategy.

title: China: More Advanced Missiles Are Said to Be on the Horizon
description: Chinese state-controlled media acknowledged on Thursday that the country was actively developing mobile Dongfeng-41 intercontinental ballistic missiles, and seemed to hint that they might have multiple warheads. But a Chinese military expert denied to The Global Times, a newspaper controlled by the Communist Party, that the missile had already been tested last month. Multiple re-entry vehicles on a ballistic missile, each of which can carry a nuclear warhead, make it much harder for missile defense systems to stop an attack.

title: Chronicler of Bin Laden Raid Is Unmasked
description: Anonymity was short-lived for the former Navy SEAL member who has written a first-person account of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden.

title: South Korea and Japan: Old Rivalry, New Expectations
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The most recent soccer game between South Korea and Japan ended in a diplomatic row after midfielder Park Jong-woo held up a banner referring to a group of islands that are claimed by both countries located in a body of water whose name they also argue over.

title: Role of Agents Raised in Scandal
description: Brian McNamee, one of the central accusers in baseballs long-running steroid controversy, has said many things over the years about players and their use of performance-enhancing drugs.

description: Comedy

title: Virginia Beach Is Latest Community to Court Kings
description: Officials for the Sacramento Kings will be in Virginia Beach on Tuesday as part of a presentation to the City Council that could help move the team to Virginia.

title: To Baseballs Chagrin, Steroid Era Goes On
description: It came to be called the steroid era, an inglorious decade or so of cheating by major league baseball players and a lack of action by baseball owners.

title: Questions and Answers on the Armstrong Doping Case
description: Q. When and how will Lance Armstrong be stripped of his Tour de France titles?

title: Rebirth at U.S.C., the Final Presentation
description: LOS ANGELES  Monte Kiffins face filled with anticipation and disbelief. His eyes gleamed like marbles, reflecting the late afternoon sun.

title: The Gift of Roddick
Restrained Chronicler of Tumultuous Times
description: The Indian photographer Homai Vyarawalla, who died in January at 98, spoke many times, with undiminished regret, of two opportunities missed, Holland Cotter wrote in The New York Times.

title: Norway Mass Killer Gets the Maximum: 21 Years
description: OSLO  Convicted of killing 77 people in a horrific bombing and shooting attack in July last year, the Norwegian extremist Anders Behring Breivik was sentenced on Friday to 21 years in prison  fewer than four months per victim  ending a case that thoroughly tested this gentle countrys collective commitment to values like tolerance, nonviolence and merciful justice.

title: Indian Government Defends Social Media Crackdown
description: While critics have railed against the Indian governments recent demands that Internet service providers block hundreds of pages and sites, current and former government officials say the action is necessary to maintain the peace.

title: Outrage in India Over Twitter Crackdown (On Twitter, at Least)
description: The Indian governments  recent demand that Twitter block some accounts, including several that parodied Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, has unleashed a storm of mockery and criticism from among the countrys millions of Twitter users.

title: Fallout Continues at Vietnamese Bank
description: HONG KONG  Police in Vietnam have arrested the former head of one the countrys biggest banks, state media said Friday, as the fallout from a banking scandal continues to spread.

title: A Tiny Life Ends in South Sudan
description: The Intensive Therapeutic Feeding Center in Batil refugee camps only hospital is a series of dusty white tents, their flaps open to reveal rows of rope beds where parents hold their emaciated children and wait to see whether they will live or die.

title: Jan Brewer on Madmen and Mowing Lawns
description: The photograph of you confronting the president has become quite famous. If you could do it over again, would you avoid wagging your finger?  Hes the one that chose to make a brief encounter about something petty that showed his thin skin. I agree it was unfortunate, but it happened, and I moved on.

title: Atlanta Falcons, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
description: Andy Benoit, who is previewing all 32 N.F.L. teams, concludes his tour of the N.F.C. South with a look at the Falcons, whom he picks to win.

description: He is still only 22, but Jozy Altidores career path has indeed been an adventurous ride that has spanned six teams in five countries since his professional debut for the Red Bulls in 2006.

title: Polio, Another Scourge of War
description: KARACHI, Pakistan Earlier this month, Mohammad Asif, a servant in an upper-class home, spent several days visiting government hospitals around Karachi to find out whether his daughter was protected against polio. A resident of Gadap Town, an administrative district of the city, Asif was worried that his one-year-old child, who had had two of the recommended four doses of polio vaccination, was in danger of contracting the disease after the World Health Organization suspended its anti-polio drive in Karachi out of security concerns.

title: Q&A: Protecting an Electronic Passport
description: Q.

title: China Is Said to Be Bolstering Missile Capabilities
description: HONG KONG  China is moving ahead with the development of a new and more capable generation of intercontinental ballistic missiles and submarine-launched missiles, increasing its existing ability to deliver nuclear warheads to the United States and to overwhelm missile defense systems, military analysts said this week.

title: Still Running, Akin Meets With Conservatives
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Representative Todd Akin of Missouri, who set off a furor with comments on rape and pregnancy, appeared before a group of conservatives here Thursday, just as Republicans were starting to gather for their partys convention next week.

title: Aug. 23: Seven Ways to Evaluate a Poll
description: Each night before I run our presidential forecast model, I make a guess at what it will say based on my impressionistic take on the data from that day.

title: The Breivik Verdict and Europes Far Right
description: LONDON  The smirk on Anders Behring Breiviks face was an indication that the Norwegian mass murderer got the verdict he wanted. By sentencing him to 21 years in jail, an Oslo court judged he was sane when he killed 77 people in a bomb and gun rampage a year ago.

description: Yiddish curses for Republican Jews.

title: Fire Meets Its Match: Spices
description: Its the time of year when the thrill of grilling starts to wane, John Willoughby and Chris Schlesinger wrote in The New York Times. Perfectly charred steak enhanced with only salt and pepper, which seemed like nirvana in early June, doesnt necessarily excite in late August.

title: Guess Whos Coming to Dinner
description: RAROTONGA, Cook Islands  Not since Queen Elizabeth IIs hello to this remote part of her realm four decades ago have the inhabitants of Rarotonga, the largest of the Cook Islands, made such a fuss for a visitor. Hillary Clinton is expected next week for the Pacific Island Forum.

title: Militant Leader Believed Dead in Pakistan Drone Strike
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A volley of C.I.A. drone strikes in Pakistans tribal belt early Friday killed at least 18 people, security officials said, capping a week of missile attacks that have renewed tensions between Pakistan and the United States, but may have killed a major militant leader.

title: Solar Panel Trade War Highlights Subsidies
description: As American and European consumers are looking toward the sun as an alternative means of energy, the solar panel trade war between China, the United States and Europe is heating up.

title: Collapse of New Bridge Underscores Worries About China Infrastructure
description: HONG KONG  One of the longest bridges in northern China collapsed on Friday, just nine months after it opened, setting off a storm of criticism from Chinese Internet users and underscoring questions about the quality of construction in the countrys rapid expansion of its infrastructure.

title: Among Digital Crumbs from Saudi Aramco Cyberattack, Image of Burning U.S. Flag
description: The computer virus that may be responsible for a cyberattack on Saudi Aramco was intended to overwrite computers with an image of a burning American flag.

title: The Hard Choices Ahead for H.P.
description: How soon before the next big, tough decision at Hewlett-Packard? It could be as early as October.

title: At Canlis, Dinner With a Side of Camaraderie
description: Last summer, Mark and Brian Canlis  the co-owners of the Seattle restaurant Canlis  mounted two horses near Pryor, Mont., and proceeded, on Day 1 of their annual board meeting, to chase off a couple of bears. They rode out of the barn on the 200,000-acre S Ranch, an hour south of Billings, with their board members, all close confidants of the family, including a tech entrepreneur (and childhood neighbor), a restaurant owner and hotelier (a college classmate), and a finance executive who introduced Mark to his wife and insisted on only being called Big Steve.

title: What Were Reading
description: @PressSec: As Brewgate continues to ferment, Jay Carney, the White House press secretary, promises to release the presidential beer recipe if enough people sign a petition asking for it. Pete Wells

title: Daily Report: Facebook Tries to Go Mobile-First
description: At Facebook, mobile is on everyones mind, Brian X. Chen reports in Fridays New York Times. People are now spending more time using Facebook through mobile apps than on computers. And on Wall Street, investors are putting pressure on Mark Zuckerbergs social network to master the mobile world so it can speed up growth and lift its sagging stock.

title: Torrent of Syrian Refugees Strains Aid Effort and Region
description: International relief agencies reported an alarming increase in Syrian refugees on Friday, shattering calculations made by the United Nations and spreading fears that the violence in Syria is creating a broader humanitarian crisis that could further destabilize the Middle East.

title: A Run on Bug Spray Amid Fears of West Nile Virus
description: DALLAS  If there was an aroma that defined life in this city, maybe it was the scent of chicken-fried bacon and other exotic deep-fried specialties at the annual State Fair of Texas. Maybe the city smelled like football, or steakhouses, or money, or some combination thereof.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Managing Campaign Coverage, and Elisabeth Murdoch Steps Out
description: The Romney campaign is planning to change the order of events at the Republican National Convention to maximize media coverage, Jeff Zeleny writes. Noting that the television networks wont be covering the convention on Monday  the first of its four days  the campaign said it would hold the more tedious nomination roll call then, instead of in its traditional spot two days later. The plan is to have Mitt Romney go over the top and become the nominee in time for the networks nightly news.

title: Australian Magnate Abandons Bid for Whitehaven Coal
description: An effort to stage a buyout of Whitehaven Coal has fallen apart.

title: Shares Rise on Hopes for Further Fed Action
description: Stocks rose on Friday, paring the first weekly decline in almost two months for the Standard & Poors 500-stock index, as the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said he saw scope for further action, increasing speculation that the central bank would act to stimulate economic growth.

title: Japan Places Pressure on South Korea Amid Islets Dispute
description: TOKYO  Japan stepped up the pressure on South Korea in a diplomatic dispute on Friday, condemning the Souths illegal occupation of islets that lie between the two countries and threatening to scrap an agreement to provide support for the South Korean currency.

title: Two Books Coming From Steve Earle
description: How was Steve Earle persuaded to write a literary memoir  the project he has called the book I swore I would never write  and a new novel on top of that? As that down-and-dirty singer-songwriter told the Web site themusic.com.au, They made me an offer I couldnt understand.

title: Merkel Vows to Help Greeks Stay in Euro Zone
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel pledged on Friday to support the new Greek government as it struggles to reform its economy, saying the heavily indebted Greece must remain in the euro zone.

title: Gunman Dies After Killing at Empire State Building
description: The sidewalks in Midtown Manhattan were swarming with the morning crush of office workers, and crowds of tourists were already pushing their way into one of the worlds most famous buildings. Around the corner, in the shadow of the Empire State Building, stood a 58-year-old man wearing a suit and carrying a black canvas bag. Inside the bag, the police said, was a .45-caliber semiautomatic handgun.

title: No Change in Forecast for Increase in Food Costs
description: WASHINGTON  The Agriculture Department said Friday that consumers could still expect higher food prices next year, but the expected 3 percent to 4 percent increase was unchanged from last month, even as extreme heat in the Farm Belt continued to reduce the grain harvest and increase feed prices for livestock.

title: Romneys Energy Plan
description: Ridiculing a campaign document is like shooting unusually large fish in a barrel, but Mitt Romneys new energy plan is so fantastical and extreme that I feel compelled to fire away.

title: Tax Credits Shed Light on Romney
description: What doesnt Mitt Romney want us to know?

title: Friday Reading: Is Private School Not Expensive Enough?
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Sending a Child With Autism to Sleep-Away Camp
description: My 13-year-old son Jonah and his new best friend, Sebastian, were in the pool the other day, armed with Styrofoam water guns, when things escalated. I wasnt there, but my wife, Cynthia, told me the story later. It seems Jonah was getting the worst of the shootout and after a while Sebastians mother suggested her son go easy. He didnt. Im guessing the fact that Jonah found the whole thing hilarious played a part in his friend persisting. But Sebastian also had another, more big-hearted reason for drenching my son.

title: Traveling to Tropical Utah
description: Randall Irmis, curator of paleontology at the Natural History Museum of Utah and an assistant professor at the University of Utah, is investigating the rise of dinosaurs in southeastern Utah.

title: Why Does Anyone Root for Incompetent, Failing Teams?
description: In January 2002, the Oakland Raiders, a football team I have worshiped since I was 5, flew east to face the New England Patriots in a playoff game. I was living 30 miles north of Foxboro Stadium, and I can still remember the color of the sky that morning, the dense gunmetal of a looming storm. By late afternoon, snow was falling at an almost comical rate. It blotted out the yard markers and hampered traction, which lent the game a surreal, slapstick air.

title: Who Made That Tennis-Ball Hopper?
description: In the 1960s, Jake Stap ran two Wisconsin tennis camps, where he spent way too much time gathering the tennis balls scattered around the courts. That was the bugaboo  getting the kids to pick up the balls, said his daughter, Sue Kust.

title: The 8.12.12 Issue
description: BOYGIRL

title: The One-Page Magazine
description: THE BIG PROFILE

title: Impatience Takes a Number
description: Returning my cable box at the Time Warner store, I arrived to find 30 people ahead of me in line. Begrudgingly, I took a number (as you do at the deli counter) and waited. A woman turned around and told me she could no longer stay. She offered me her ticket, five numbers away from being called. At first I said no  it wouldnt be fair to everyone else who was waiting  but she insisted. I took her ticket, returned my cable box and walked out of the store while everyone else kept waiting. Was it right to take the ticket? ALEXANDRA, NEW YORK CITY

title: Vicious Little Women
description: Louisa May Alcott, author of Little Women, the classic American novel of four sisters born into a distinguished if profoundly broke family, wrote elsewhere that to help one another is part of the religion of our sisterhood.

title: The Guy Who Would Never Give Up
description: The stunning part of Lance Armstrong giving up his fight against doping charges lodged against him by the United States Anti-Doping Agency is not the guilt implicit in the surrender, it is the surrender itself. The guilt part, everyone was ready for. Because by now, it requires supernatural powers of denial to think Armstrong, a seven-time Tour de France champion, could conquer the most drug-soaked sport of them all by being the only clean one.

title: Romneys Tithing Behind Reluctance to Release Returns
description: Mitt and Ann Romney sat for a relatively substantial interview with PARADE magazine in which he is confronted on differences with his surrogates and the G.O.P., his offshore accounts, and his taxes and tithing. Mr. Romney suggests that the private nature of tithing is among the reasons he is reluctant to release more of his tax returns and that conservatives are more generous philanthropically than people who are not conservatives.

title: European Commission Sets Tentative Date to Propose New Bank Regulations
description: BRUSSELS  The European Commission on Friday set a date of Sept. 11 to announce proposals to overhaul banking regulation in Europe, a crucial step in shoring up the euro zone against future crises.

title: Ron Paul Tribute Video on the G.O.P. Convention Schedule
description: Republicans will show a Ron Paul tribute video on the second night of Mitt Romneys convention next week, part of an effort to soothe the small army of delegates that Mr. Paul collected during his long primary battle with Mr. Romney this year.

title: New Label Alert | Priory of Ten
description: All week, T is introducing the lines to look out for this fall.

title: Wenger Hasnt Changed, but the Rules Have
description: When you are on the football pitch, you dont think about the players who are not there, Arsne Wenger insisted after Arsenals disappointing opening day draw with Sunderland last weekend. There are those who wish he would cast his mind to those who have left the club since the end of the Invincibles era. It might be enough to force a rethinking of his famed philosophy.

title: Wheelies: The Carrot-and-Stick Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Sisterhood
description: For this weeks cover story on Venus and Serena Williams, we sentthe New York Times staff photographer Damon Winter to Key Biscayne in mid-Julyto shoot the sisters on the stadium court at the Crandon Tennis Center.The sweltering heat and harsh midday sun made for less than ideal picture-making conditions, but Winter found a spot with nice, diffused light under an overhang at one of the courts entrances and managed to capture some affectionate moments between Serena and Venus there. You can see a behind-the-scenes video from his shoot here.

title: Image of the Day: August 24
Another Shooting
description: Consider this juxtaposition, courtesy of The Times home page. At the top of the site were reporting that a gunman opened fire outside the Empire State Building, shooting and killing a former co-worker before he was killed by the police. A bit lower down on the page, Thomas Kaplan reports from Ilion, New York, that the Remington Arms company, which has been making guns there for more than 200 years, is threatening to leave the state and close its factory if lawmakers have the temerity to pass any new gun laws.

title: At the U.S. Open, Serving a Fresh and Local Menu
description: Novak Djokovic, the reigning United States Open mens singles champion, partly credits his success to the gluten-free diet he adopted two years ago, which he said has made him quicker, faster and stronger.

title: In South Dakota, Only the Farm Trumps Conservatism
description: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Here, a look at South Dakota, the Mount Rushmore State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Michael Card, an associate professor of political science at the University of South Dakota; John Miller, a former professor of history at South Dakota State University; and Erin Fouberg, a professor of geography at Northern State University in Aberdeen, S.D.

title: Permira to Buy Japanese Sushi Chain for About $1 Billion
description: The European private equity firm Permira has struck a deal to acquire a Japanese sushi restaurant chain, with plans to help it expand overseas.

title: Times Staffers Recommend School Books
description: To celebrate (or bemoan?) the impending academic year, I asked Times staffers to recommend books that are set in or around schools. Their answers coincide with the New York Times Book Reviews special Back to School issue, which features books about education for adults, young adults and children. On Twitter, Ill be asking readers for their own suggestions, a selection of which will be shared on this blog in the coming days.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Nathan Harden discusses his new book, Sex and God at Yale; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Pamela Paul guides us through this weeks special back-to-school issue; and Parul Sehgal has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Team Tennis Player Vies for Spot in U.S. Open Draw
description: Bobby Reynolds of the United States hopes to ride the wave of his excellent results this summer in World Team Tennis to advance through the last round of qualifying at the United States Open.

title: Met Opera to Preserve Rush Tickets
description: When Agnes Varis, a Metropolitan Opera board member and benefactor, died a year ago, the company lost the person who paid for its heavily discounted rush ticket program.

title: Conservative Forecasts, Meteorological and Political
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Along with fretting about the political fortunes of Representative Todd Akin, the Republican Senate candidate from Missouri whose comments about rape set off their own storm, the weather was a dominant topic of conversation at a pre-convention gathering of conservatives on Thursday evening.

title: Scraps of Joy and Inspiration Amid Struggle
description: PEOPLE tend to think Im insane, Chan Marshall said, and Im really tired of it.

title: My Father, the Cable Pioneer
description: YOU never know what sort of wish-Id-dones are going to pop into your head while youre at the bedside of a dying parent. A year ago this week, as I sat with my father during the last moments of his long life, this one came along unbidden: I sure wish Id asked Dad, while he could still answer me, about the time he invented cable TV.

title: Glennis McCarthy and the Gorgeous Ladies of Comedy
description: LIKE most actresses in New York, Glennis McCarthy, 33, has to juggle callbacks and performances with her day job. But unlike most actresses Ms. McCarthy has a day job that involves keeping her peers united, inspired and working. She is the brains behind Gorgeous Ladies of Comedy, or GLOC. It began as a blog just under two years ago and, under Ms. McCarthys tireless hand, has bloomed into an informal society of New Yorks brightest comediennes. Kristen Schaal, of 30 Rock and The Daily Show, the actress Kristen Johnston and the stand-up star Tig Notaro have all performed at its events or lent advice on the blog.

title: New York Fringe Festival Report: Hadrians Wall
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festivals close on Aug. 26. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

title: The Complete Engraver
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Road to Serfdom, the Graphic Version
description: In this weeks magazine, Adam Davidson writes about Friedrich von Hayek, a shy, often misunderstood Austrian economist whose ideas are inspiring a new generation of Republican leaders, most notably Paul Ryan. Ryan has cited Hayeks seminal work, The Road to Serfdom, which was published during World War II, as a major influence on his own thinking. (He also lists it, along with Ayn Rands Atlas Shrugged, as a favorite book on his Facebook page.)

title: Writing to Calm and Compose the Injured Brain
description: There is an old we. We had near photographic memories, and school was easy. We found peoples faces familiar and daily tasks were easily remembered. We didnt have any problems articulating his words. We maintained focus easily. We stood and walked without fear of stumbling. We didnt fear debilitating headaches. Life was easier.

title: U.S. Special Operations Commander Cautions Against Exploiting Celebrity Status
description: The news that Penguin would publish on Sept. 11 a book by a former member of the Navy SEALs team that killed Osama bin Laden has stirred an intense amount of interest  about what details will be revealed about the raid, but also about the protocol governing the release of information on military operations.

title: Business Day Live | August 24, 2012
description: For farmers, drought becomes a way of life. | Americans near retirement suffer big income losses. | James B. Stewart discusses Mitt Romney's foreign tax credit.

title: A Slice of Broadway in the Hudson Valley
description: When the Broadway supper club 54 Below opened in June in Manhattans Theater District, Lee Tannen decided it was time to take his plans for a similar space in a new direction: north.

title: Romney Makes a Birth Certificate Joke While Campaigning in Michigan
description: 9:40 p.m. | Updated A more recent version of this post can be found here.

title: The Shooting Near the Empire State Building
description: Map of the scene of the shooting near the Empire State Building.

title: Mayor Bloomberg on E.S.B. Shooting
description: New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg's press conference on this morning's shooting near the Empire State building.

title: Seeing and Battling a Cartel in the Hiring of Rabbis
description: DURHAM, N.C.  Four years ago, when the longtime rabbi of Beth El Synagogue here retired, a member named Barak D. Richman joined the committee searching for a successor. Everything went smoothly enough until the congregation reached outside Conservative Judaism, its formal affiliation, to consider candidates from the Reform and Reconstructionist branches, and to place a few online advertisements.

title: How Romney Applied Foreign Tax Credits
description: Details in the 2010 federal tax return released by Mitt Romney offer clues and raise questions about his income in previous years.

title: The Sweet Spot | The Unconvention
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott on the public-relations efforts of political parties, and the news media, on the eve of the two political conventions.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Glaze Teriyaki Grill, 139 Fourth Avenue (13th Street), in Union Square, opens tonight, serving Seattle-style charcoal-grilled teriyaki at its second Manhattan location. And on the Lower East Side, Andy Rickers Pok Pok Wing will reopen as Pok Pok Phat Thai, 137 Rivington Street (Norfolk Street), serving phat Thai noodle dishes.

title: The Sweet Spot | Aug. 24, 2012
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott on the public-relations efforts of political parties, and the news media, on the eve of the two politicalconventions.

title: Off the Charts: Few Have Recovered
description: Only three countries other than the United States  Mexico, Singapore and Sweden  have regained all the ground they lost when world stock markets plunged during the financial crisis of 2007-9. The chart shows the performance of 30 markets as measured by MSCI indexes, and of the MSCI All Country World Index, which includes all markets MSCI classifies as developed or emerging.

title: Armstrong, Best of His Time, Now With an Asterisk
description: Now he is for the ages, in his own Lance way. Lance Armstrong has joined the legion of the lost, the great athletes who were barred or exiled for sins admitted or charged or suspected.

title: Mitt Romney in Michigan
description: Mitt Romney made remarks about President Obama's birth certificate at a campaign event in Michigan.

title: Capitol Dome Is Imperiled by 1,300 Cracks and Partisan Rift
description: WASHINGTON  To the myriad indignities suffered by Congress, including stagnant legislation, partisan warfare and popularity on a par with petty criminals, add this: the Capitols roof is leaking, and there is no money to fix it.

title: Why Messing With Taxes Carries Risks
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Witnesses Made Case Against Armstrong Potent
description: The morning after Lance Armstrong gave up his fight against doping accusations, Travis Tygart, the chief executive of the United States Anti-Doping Agency, which brought the most recent drug charges against Armstrong, received an unexpected phone call.

title: In New Task, Tapping Into a Lifetime in Court
description: HOUSTON The key to Rusty Hardins extraordinary career, in his view, has been his ordinariness. He is just a regular guy.

title: Employing Dietitians Pays Off for Supermarkets
description: MOLINE, Ill.  Lois E. Florence recently left her doctors office with a diagnosis of colitis, an intestinal disorder, and a complicated set of instructions for changing her diet.

title: Border Checkpoints Deter Noncitizens Seeking Later Abortions
description: McALLEN  Illegal immigrants who live in the Rio Grande Valley and are seeking an abortion after 16 weeks face a hurdle beyond Texas strict laws. They must make a long drive north and face internal border checkpoints.

title: For Ry Cooder, a Dogs Life and a Deal With the Devil
description: Some of the first records Ry Cooder heard and loved as a child were Woody Guthries songs about working-class people in the Great Depression. He never quite got them out of his system. There has been a strain of social commentary in his albums, going back to his solo debut, when he covered Guthries Do Re Mi and Alfred Reeds How Can a Poor Man Stand Such Times and Live?

title: Greenpeace Activists Climb Russian Oil Rig
description: MOSCOW A team of Greenpeace activists scaled the side of a Russian oil-drilling platform far out in the Arctic Ocean on Friday and suspended themselves on ropes while unfurling a banner that said Save the Arctic, as workers above sprayed cold water on them.

title: For Gen Xers, a Wake-Up Call
description: REPRESENTATIVE Paul D. Ryan, the presumptive Republican nominee for vice president, favors grunge music, Coen brothers movies and craft brews. He sprinkles the word awesome into daily speech and, as a teenager, worked the ultimate McJob, at McDonalds.

title: Top Finishers of the Tour de France Tainted by Doping
description: More than a third of the top finishers of the Tour de France have admitted to using performance-enhancing drugs in their careers or have been officially linked to doping.

title: U.S. Stock Market Leads Most Others in Recovery
description: THE American stock market has returned to record territory  at least when dividends are included  but few other stock markets have done so. A survey of the major markets of the world indicates that North America was the best place to be for investors who chose to ride out the credit crisis, while the euro zone was clearly the worst.

title: On Top of Spaghetti
description: NOTHING in Lyndsey Butlers background suggested that she would create some of the fashion worlds more celebrated jackets.

title: Wheels Calendar for Aug. 24-26
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

title: Lawmaker Is Censured Over Sexual Harassment
description: ALBANY  Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, one of the last powerful Democratic Party bosses in New York City, was abruptly stripped of his committee chairmanship and censured Friday after he was accused of sexually harassing two women who worked in his district office this summer.

title: Charlotte Vignon and Joseph Godla
description: ON Aug. 1, an eclectic mix of New York and Los Angeles museum folk, Parisian friends and Western artists gathered at the Rainbow Ranch near Big Sky, Mont., to watch Charlotte Vignon, 37, an associate curator of decorative arts at the Frick Collection in Manhattan, and Joseph Godla, 56, the chief conservator there, exchange vows.

title: At the U.S. Open and Beyond, a Radio Announcers Internet Odyssey
description: Tennis fans will not see Ken Thomas at the 2012 United States Open. A tanned, gray-haired man wearing a headset and microphone and sitting on a scaffold platform above Court 13, Thomas has been a sideshow of his own during qualifying rounds at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Color Me Better
description: At No. 2 on the hardcover list this week is Volume 1 of the color edition of Scott Pilgrim, by Bryan Lee OMalley. The original softcover version of the series was a regular presence on our sales chart in 2010 as fans counted down the days until the release of the film version starring Michael Cera. (The movie criminally underperformed at the box office.) In August of that year, the six volumes were in the top seven of the paperback list.

title: Scandinavia on $125 a Day
description: IT was my first full day in Oslo and I thought that I had found a rare bargain: a six-pack of Carlsberg beer for under $5 (or 27.40 Norwegian kroner) at the Kiwi Minipris supermarket! Even for a mass-produced pilsner, it was a surprising deal for Norway, where just about everything costs more than youd expect. And by more, I dont mean by increments of 10 or 15 percent, but by multiples of two or three or four.

title: Herding Sheep in Basque Country (Idaho)
description: SHEEP, you may be surprised to learn, are not as dumb as they look. Some people might even describe them as shrewdly calculating, remarkably crafty animals with fierce independent streaks. Given the slightest opening, for example, they will quit a herd, striking out in small, enterprising bands for the high-desert plains  ungulate fugitives in a promised land of sagebrush and cactus  sometimes never to be seen again.

title: Should Twins Be in the Same Classroom?
description: This week, H. asks (via my Facebook page): Is it better to split up twins in school? This parent feels like the research is split; some experts suggest children will do better in separate classrooms, others the opposite.

title: In Idaho, Two Basque Stories
description: While Boise is home to thousands of people of Basque descent, there are very few Basques left on the states sheep ranges.

title: On College Move-In Day, Resist the U-Haul
description: THIS week, my neighbor Lisa, who owns a smallish Honda, asked if she could borrow our minivan to help move her daughter to college in New York City, about 40 minutes away.

title: Mitt Romney Plays the Birther Card
description: Politicians sometimes think they can get away with saying something profoundly offensive or just plain stupid by acting like it was a joke. It never works, just like it didnt work today when Mr. Romney shamelessly played the birther card in what seems like an increasingly desperate campaign against President Obama.

title: Coming of Age, From Script to Screen
description: MARSHFIELD, Mass.

title: In Kentucky, Fried Chicken History
description: WHEN making his rounds as a traveling salesman for a Chicago printing company, Duncan Hines would occasionally pull off the Dixie Highway in Corbin, Ky., and eat at Sanders Cafe. In the 1939 edition of Adventures in Good Eating, his pioneering restaurant guide, he recommended the cafe and its adjoining motor court as very good place to stop en route to Cumberland Falls and the Great Smokies, highlighting its sizzling steaks, fried chicken, country ham, hot biscuits.

title: Richard Linklater on Americas Ignored Monuments
description: RICHARD LINKLATER, 52, director of such films as Bernie, School of Rock and Dazed and Confused, is allergic to guidebooks.

title: Shooting in Midtown Manhattan
description: New York City officials say a laid-off womens accessories designer fatally shot a former co-worker outside the Empire State Building, then was killed by police in a shootout that wounded nine bystanders.

title: Uncovering the Secrets of Fukuoka
description: THE crowd at Akatan, a narrow, standing bar in the southern Japanese city of Fukuoka, thickened as each glass of sake and shochu was poured. By midnight, strangers had swept my husband, Dave, and me  the only Western faces in the smoky bar  into alcohol-fueled conversations that, with the language barrier, often devolved into comical pantomime. Every time we explained that we were visiting Fukuoka as tourists, the same question arose: But why?

title: Invitation to Cardinal Shows G.O.P.s Catholic Push
description: Some benedictions bestow a bigger blessing than others, and Mitt Romney hit the jackpot by signing up Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the president of the Conference of Catholic Bishops, to deliver the closing prayer at the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla., next week.

title: Hotel Review: Shore Hotel in Santa Monica, Calif.
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Reactions at Scene of Midtown Shooting
description: Witnesses and people passing by the Empire State Building right after the shooting share impressions and concerns.

title: Sleepwalk to Work
description: IT took a while for Athanasios Biros to solve the mystery of his noisy upstairs neighbor. Mr. Biros, 35, who works for a bank, at first suspected a bartender with odd working hours lived above his studio in Greenwich Village. Then he heard a pounding noise at 7 in the morning. I just snapped, he said. He knocked on the door, and met his neighbors, an Eastern European family with a child. The mother promised to stop the child from crisscrossing the paper-thin floors.

title: Near Yale, a District Blooms
description: New Havens Ninth Square has seen a surge in galleries, boutiques and creative energy.

title: In Private Equity, Seeking to Profit From Small-Time Deals
description: PRIVATE equity investing is getting a lot of attention this presidential season. Now that Mitt Romney, whose fortune came from his private equity work at Bain Capital, is set to accept the Republican presidential nomination next week in Tampa, Fla., the industry will certainly spend the fall in the spotlight.

title: Creativity Sprouts on a St. Petersburg Island
description: SHELTERED by a wall covered in colorful murals that depicted a horror-fairy tale with a happy ending, a Russian friend and I sat back in lawn chairs and sipped cappuccinos. To our left was a still pool once used for submarine testing. Behind it stood large, shuttered, morbidly charming brick warehouses. Its amazing! said my friend as he pointed at the row of buildings across the canal, in the midst of St. Petersburg. All those years, you couldnt come in here. Now its open, and you have a completely new view of the city.

title: Miniseries Treatment in Works for Wolf Hall and Bring Up the Bodies
description: A six-hour adaptation of two of Hilary Mantels novels, Wolf Hall and its sequel, Bring Up the Bodies, will come to television in late 2013, BBC Two has announced. Wolf Hall, a historical novel set during the reign of King Henry VIII, won the Man Booker Prize for Fiction in 2009. Peter Straughan, who wrote the screenplay for the 2011 movie version of Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy, will adapt the Mantel novels for television.

title: The 6 Worst Moments of My Raiders Fandom
description: In Sundays Riff, Steve Almond writes about the agony suffered and insight gained from remaining loyal to a terrible sports team. Painful as it was to recall, he agreed to dredge up his six worst moments of being a Raiders fan.

title: Letter From Assembly Speaker Silver Censuring Assemblyman Lopez
description: Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver censuring Assemblyman Vito Lopez of Brooklyn dated August 24, 2012.

title: Your Experience With Small-Time Private Equity Investments
description: In this weekends Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan chronicles the experience of private equity investors with less money and expertise than the Mitt Romneys of the world. An increasing number are getting in the game, frustrated with low returns in other investment arenas.

title: How to Know if You Have Enough Auto Insurance
description: Theres nothing like a good scare to send us all scurrying to our auto insurance policy to see what our coverage is. This month, those of us who have followed the story of Progressive Insurance and the Fisher family got one.

title: Making Bold First Impressions at the Piano
description: IN the spring of 1970 Rudolf Serkin announced that he would play the 32 Beethoven piano sonatas in a series of eight recitals at Carnegie Hall during the 1970-71 season to commemorate the 200th anniversary of Beethovens birth. Then nearly 67, Serkin was a pre-eminent Beethoven interpreter. Yet he had never played a complete Beethoven sonata cycle.

title: Big Ticket |  Sold for $21 Million
description: A penthouse with sophisticated steamed-beech-dominated interiors by Charles Gwathmey and sweeping views of Central Park from its perch at the Verona, an Upper East Side co-op designed by William E. Mowbray in 1908, sold under the radar for $21 million, the biggest sale of the week according to city records.

title: Aug. 26  Sept. 1
description: THE novelist Ian Fleming was not pleased when he learned that his greatest creation, James Bond, was played by Sean Connery in Dr. No, the first in the film series. Im looking for Cmdr. James Bond, he said, not an overgrown stuntman. Moviegoers disagreed, and Fleming later came to his senses. Now, in honor of the franchises 50th anniversary, the complete Connery Bonds (including Never Say Never Again, from 1983), will be screened in IFCs aptly named program JAMES BOND NO. 1: SEAN CONNERYS 007, starting Friday (with an all-day, seven-film Bond-a-thon next Sunday.)

title: Business Day Live: Drought Disrupts Everyday Tasks in Rural Midwest
description: For farmers, drought becomes a way of life. | Americans near retirement suffer big income losses. | James B. Stewart discusses Mitt Romneys foreign tax credit.

title: Auto Insurance, Scaredy-Cats and the Rollers of the Dice
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I try to lay out the facts and odds that lay behind the question of whether any of us have enough auto insurance. Some people look at the long odds of a bad wreck and buy the minimum amount that their state requires. Others buy as much as they can, figuring that its better to be safe than to be sorry.

title: In Euro Crisis, Fingers Can Point in All Directions
description: FRANKFURT  The debate about how to distribute the cost of preserving the euro often centers on a fundamental question that is unspoken but implicit: Who caused this crisis anyway?

title: Counter Intuitive | Chez Aline in Paris
description: It was happenstance that the young chef Delphine Zampetti came to open the tiny Parisian eatery Chez Aline. Last May, Zampetti, who has worked at Caf Cach and Le Verre Vol, was walking down Rue de la Roquette in the 11th Arrondissement when she noticed a butcher shop with a charmingly retro vibe. The next week, she passed the shop again, only this time there was a for sale sign in the window. It was une petite ide, just like that, she muses. And then she went for it.

title: Will Emissions Disclosure Mean Investor Pressure on Polluters?
description: A new financial tool developed by the investment firm South Pole Carbon, in partnership with the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, provides greenhouse gas emissions profiles of more than 40,000 publicly listed companies. This index is aimed at encouraging greater disclosure from companies while, hopefully, also pushing investors to build more responsible portfolios.

title: Quadrophenia, Still a Flash Point for the Mods
description: MANY years after filming the climax to the 1979 film Quadrophenia in Brighton, England, the director Franc Roddam found himself back there for a screening. Though the town had long been famous as a beachfront resort, Mr. Roddams film adaptation of the Whos rock opera has drawn fans there as well, particularly for its depiction of a 1964 gathering of the futurist Mods, which ended in a clash with their sworn enemies, the backward-gazing, leather-clad Rockers. New Mods continue to travel there for scooter rallies and weekenders.

title: A Lightning Rod in More Ways Than One
description: Oversize in almost every way, the Empire State Building has been the scene of several awful dramas in its 81 years  as well as a singular cinematic one  all magnified by the towers status as one of the most recognizable symbols of New York City.

title: You Say True Life, I Say Scripted
description: HOW, exactly, does one write reality?

title: An Affair to Remember, and Put on Screen
description: THE relationship depicted in Keep the Lights On isnt one that most people would want to revisit. The film, based on part of the director Ira Sachss life, immerses viewers in the love and protracted dysfunction involving Erik, a needy documentary filmmaker, and Paul, a charming yet drug-addicted lawyer in publishing.

title: GOP Intellectual Decline, Monetary Edition
description: There was a time, not long ago, when Republicans  whatever you might think of their other ideas  were part of the mainstream consensus on monetary policy. Heres the Economic Report of the President from 2004 (pdf), presumably written by Greg Mankiw:

title: Whats the Matter With Kids Today?
description: Bye Bye Birdie and High Time

title: Fresh Beans in the Salad Push Cans to the Side
description: ONE of the pleasures of cooking this time of year is the casual simplicity of the menus. Lots of room-temperature dishes, cool wine and no fussing.

title: A National Champion Trucker, With a Record Nearly as Spotless as His Trophy
description: Over the 2.1 million miles Don Logan has driven a commercial truck, he has been involved in only one road accident; a drunken driver collided with his rig in 1996.

title: Niallism
description: Im not even reading the back and forth at this point  its too embarrassing  but if youre interested, Matt OBrien sums it up.

title: Regulatory SWAT Team May Have to Move Slowly on Money Funds
description: A SWAT team of top regulators was formed after the financial crisis to swoop in and stamp out big risks lurking in the financial system. Should the mutual fund industry fear this team as it tries to protect one of its biggest products from further reform?

title: The Week in Pictures, August 24
description: A look back at the weeks events in New York City and the region.

title: Where Aerobic Fortitude Is a Big Plus
description: THE Harlem River curves by Kingsbridge, a middle-class neighborhood of 47,000 folded into a valley in the northwestern Bronx. Theres also a busy highway, the six-lane Major Deegan Expressway, that slices through the area. And mature trees shade many sidewalks  as along Tibbett Avenue, which is named for a brook buried long ago.

title: Debunking the Hunter-Gatherer Workout
description: DARWIN isnt required reading for public health officials, but he should be. One reason that heart disease, diabetes and obesity have reached epidemic levels in the developed world is that our modern way of life is radically different from the hunter-gatherer environments in which our bodies evolved. But which modern changes are causing the most harm?

title: The Cadillac Your Livery Driver Has Been Dreaming Of
description: IT will be the black car waiting to pick you up at the airport. Its the Cadillac upon which hearses and limousines will be based. When Hertz runs out of midsize cars, it is the luxury sedan into which youll upgrade.

title: Threes a Crowd: The Bench Seat Is Benched
description: FULL-SIZE American sedans are an endangered species, and the front bench seat is fading away with them.

title: Owner of Shangri-La Hotel Tries to Make Amends With Jewish Groups
description: LOS ANGELES  Tehmina Adaya, owner of the Hotel Shangri-La in the beach town of Santa Monica, Calif., announced on Friday some measures meant to repair her standing among Jews in the wake of a jury decision last week that found she had violated the civil rights of members of a Jewish group she tried to evict from her hotel in 2010.

title: Appreciation for Vintage Cars, in Two Senses
description: Monterey, Calif.

title: Celebrating the Classics, Confirming Their Value
description: Pebble Beach, Calif.

title: Buy High, Sell Higher
description: The Monterey auctions set a record of $262 million in sales this year, easily surpassing 2011s total of $198 million. Here is a look at some noteworthy models that were offered for sale.

title: Shocking, Not Shocking, and Mildly Amusing Links
description: Shocking (not): Monsanto joins the club and dishes out $4.2 million to fight Prop 37, Californias GMO-labeling initiative. And an Argentine study found that an ingredient in Round Up can cause birth defects.

title: Fresh Beans in the Salad Push Cans to the Side
description: In this weeks City Kitchen column, local beans become a delicious salad in a fresh version of the all-too-often canned and bland three-bean salad.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Syria, Iraq, New York and Egypt.

title: Book Review Podcast: Nathan Harden on Sex and God at Yale
description: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Hanna Rosin reviews Sex and God at Yale, in which Nathan Harden details the debauchery hiding in plain sight in the Ivy League. Ms. Rosin writes that his account is revealing, but:

title: Luxury Workhorse
description: The unpretentious 2013 Cadillac XTS may not be flashy, but the brands venerable customer base will feel right at home inside, front seat or back.

title: Gestation Crate Denial in New Jersey
description: Check out this op-ed on NJ.com by Princeton professor Peter Singer and the Humane Societys Paul Shapiro calling for the New Jersey legislature to pass a bill that would improve the lives of pigs in confinement, a bill similar to one passed in nine other states. Heres a reply from the head of New Jerseys Farm Bureau; no comment needed:

title: Chic in Review | A Close Encounter of the Calvin Klein Kind
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: The Week in Culture in Pictures, Aug. 24
description: A Korean pop band performed in Newark, Jake Gyllenhaal is making his New York stage debut, and artists built sand castles on Rockaway Beach.

title: The Stranded Unemployed
description: On Thursday I wrote about how incomes have declined sharply in the last few years, particularly for people approaching retirement age. A new report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics sheds some light on why: People who lost work, especially if theyre older, often arent finding re-employment; even when they do find new work, theyre taking major pay cuts.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Aug. 24
description: More Photographs

title: New York Fringe Festival Report: Salamander Starts Over
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festivals close on Aug. 26. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

title: Moscow Court Finds Kasparov Not Guilty of Illegal Protest During Pussy Riot Trial
description: MOSCOW  A judge here ruled on Friday that the former chess champion Garry Kasparov was not guilty of participating in an unsanctioned political demonstration outside the courthouse where three women in the punk band Pussy Riot were convicted of hooliganism last week and sentenced to two years in prison.

title: Ukrainian Dance Camp in the Catskills
description: Each summer for about three decades, children of Ukrainian descent have converged on a wooded retreat in the Catskills.

title: Ukrainian Folk Dance
description: Clips from the documentary Folk,directed and produced by Roxy Topotowych.

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 24
description: A view of the day in sports included soccer in France and Germany, cycling in Portugal and sailing in Cape Town.

title: Going Their Own Ways
description: THE other day I got hung up on a new sandbar, the words luxury-branded accommodations, a term that sadly does not apply to mortuaries (not yet) but rather to hotel rooms splashed with a peer companys status symbols. A classic twofer, but clearly intended for gullible people.

title: Reactions to Verizons Deal With the Cable Companies
description: The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday approved a deal that allows Verizon Wireless to purchase a huge swath of spectrum, the radio waves that carry wireless communications, from the countrys largest cable providers.

title: Week in Review: A Defeat for Schapiro
description: In an effort to curb money market funds, a Plan B is considered. | The New York Fed sold the last of its A.I.G. bailout bonds. | Jesse Eisinger uncovered a TARP move that isnt helping taxpayers. | And Andrew Ross Sorkin said investors in health care were betting on President Obama. A look back on our reporting of the last weeks highs and lows in finance.

title: Swedes Win in Open Teams at World Mind Games
description: LILLE, France  The Open Teams at the Second World Mind Sports Games here this week was a triumph for Sweden, represented by Krister Ahlesved, Jonas Petersson, Peter Bertheau, Per-Ola Cullin, Fredrik Nystrom and Johan Upmark, with its nonplaying captain, Mats Axdorph.

title: Crowdfunding Merger Points to Ambitions in Latin America
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  The crowdfunding site Ideame has acquired the Brazilian company Movere in a deal that may prompt more consolidation in this sector in Latin America.

title: Last of the Summer Sweet Corn
description: The summer sweet corn season is brief but memorable, and as Martha Rose Shulman explains, sweet corn can be used to create a number of delicious dishes. She writes:

title: Steve Van Buren, 91, Dies; Hall of Fame Halfback
description: Steve Van Buren, the Honduras-born son of an American fruit inspector who took up the unfamiliar game of football in high school and went on to stardom with the Philadelphia Eagles, becoming a Hall of Fame running back and, many said, one of the greatest to play the game, died on Thursday in Lancaster, Pa. He was 91.

title: Alzheimers Drug Misses Goal, but Offers Hint of Potential
description: An Alzheimers drug being tested by Eli Lilly failed in its main goal of halting progress of the disease, the company said Friday, but there were some signs it could slowcognitive decline in patients with mild cases.

title: Resort Towns Face a Last Picture Show
description: OCEAN CITY, N.J.  There are nicer and newer movie theaters than the Strand 5 on the boardwalk here on the Jersey Shore. The sound is uneven, and the auditoriums havent been renovated in decades.

title: Out of Frame
description: Small movie theaters are struggling to survive the conversion to digital projection.

title: Reviewing the Cadillac XTS
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, John Pearley Huffman reviews the 2013 Cadillac XTS, which replaces the DTS full-size sedan as the most Cadillac-like of all the current Cadillacs.

title: Pandora and Spotify Rake In the Money and Then Send It Off in Royalties
description: If you have read anything about digital music recently, you have probably encountered two names over and over: Spotify and Pandora. Both offer an abundance of free listening on easy-to-use interfaces, and music fans have embraced them. At least 33 million people have tried Spotify, more than 150 million have registered for Pandora.

title: Jury Awards $1 Billion to Apple in Samsung Patent Case
description: Apple won a decisive victory on Friday in a lawsuit against Samsung, a verdict that will give Apple ammunition in a far-flung patent war with its global competitors in the smartphone business.

title: Dad Hasnt Just Been Sitting Around
description: Along with being the father to Maude and her sister, Iris, 9, Judd Apatow has parented, mentored or gently nudged many a Hollywood project into being. Here are some of his proudest achievements.

title: The Caucus Click: Ready for Their Entrance
Shes 14, Going on 140 Characters
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Two-and-Twenty Tax Dodges
description: For Mitt Romney, probably the only thing worse than having to lay bare his financial life is for someone else to lay it all out.
