Which is, of course, exactly what Gawker did on Thursday, when the gossip Web site published confidential documents from Bain Capital, the private equity firm where Mr. Romney made his multi-millions  and from which he still takes a share of the profits.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Hacking Your Head, and Twitter Sin
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A SoHo Condo, a Clinton studio co-op and a Fort Greene co-op.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A four-bedroom Mediterranean home in Yonkers and a three-bedroom town house in Sea Bright, N.J.

title: Chefs Redemption Tells of a Softening North Korea
description: TOKYO  For years, the Japanese sushi chef who spent over a decade working for the Kim family in North Korea lived in dread of a knock on the door by an agent sent to kill him for returning to Japan and writing a tell-all book exposing the rulers extravagant lifestyle.

title: A Maelstrom of Horror in a Desert House
description: Property maintenance can be a pain, especially when a ghost appears to be the resident super. Just ask Kelly (Ashley Greene of Twilight) and Ben (Sebastian Stan of Gossip Girl), the leads in The Apparition. Recent college grads minding an investment home owned by Kellys parents, they just want to spruce up the place, a spacious desert residence, but objects simply wont stay put.

title: From Farm to Table, but Hardly Rustic
description: WHEN I hear the words farm to table, I picture an old white clapboard inn, with gardens all around. Ursino, an ambitious farm-to-table restaurant on the campus of Kean University in Union, is in a hulking glass and metal building that fronts Morris Avenue.

title: To Trip the Volynska Polka, Respectfully in the Catskills
description: KERHONKSON, N.Y.  Each summer for about three decades, children of Ukrainian descent have converged on a wooded retreat here in the Catskills, the girls donning embroidered blouses, and the boys puffy Cossack pants, to learn the folk dances of their ancestors.

title: A Kitchen Geared to a Locavores Tastes
description: FRANK LEPRI is known to Hartford-area diners from his years as chef at the late and lamented downtown bistro Pastis; when it closed, he and his wife, Debbie, opened an excellent trattoria called Da Lepri in Ellington, later adding a burger bar nearby. And last spring they opened a steak-and-seafood emporium in the 275-year-old Tolland farmhouse where the restaurant Zest had been.

title: Will Tom Stoppard Side With Graham Greene on the Last Book of Parades End?
description: Contributing to the One-Page Magazine is a fun and sometimes challenging exercise in compression and economy. For every 70 words I work into a column, there are often hundreds more I could have written on a subject. Thats never been more true than it is for Sundays edition, which focuses on the most exciting TV news in recent memory: Benedict Cumberbatch, best known as the lead in BBCs Sherlock, stars in Tom Stoppards adaptation of Ford Madox Fords Parades End. The joint BBC and HBO production was directed by Susanna White and is positioned as the smart Edwardian-era alternative to Downton Abbey, a show Cumberbatch has ridiculed far and wide. Most notoriously, he denounced its cheap sentiment in an interview with Readers Digest and called the second season atrocious, preceded by an adverb that cannot be written here.

title: The Artwork of Jeffrey Johnson
description: Jeffrey T. Johnson, the designer who killed a former colleague near the Empire State Building on Friday, had a YouTube channel dedicated to showcasing the illustrations on his Web site, St. Jollys Art, most of which depict cars, motorcycles, women and combinations thereof.

title: Bust of Civil War General Stirs Anger in Alabama
description: In Selma, Ala., a battle over what to do with a bronze bust of a contradictory and controversial Civil War general has lasted far longer than the war itself.

title: Ann Romneys Convention Speech Is Moved to Tuesday
description: Republicans are moving Ann Romneys convention speech to Tuesday night after failing to persuade any of the broadcast networks to televise any of the convention speeches on Monday.

title: What Not to Take to Tampa
description: Leave your tomatoes at home, if you plan on going to the Republican National Convention. The current list of items banned around the convention zone in Tampa varies from weapons to vegetation to puppet-making materials.

title: Having Fun With Tapas in a Flashy Room
description: TO get a bead on NoMa Social, the young hot spot in the newly refurbished Radisson Hotel, in New Rochelle, you might want to start with a special appetizer called Farm Egg in Purgatory. A little bit ironic, and deliriously good, the dish involves a poached egg floating in a fiery, basil-laden tomato brodetto, with brittle grilled toast as a means of getting at it. If youre foolish enough to pass it around, you may never see it again.

title: A Colorful Change for Jambox
description: While many have been wowed by the sound of Jawbones Jambox portable speaker, some may have been less impressed with the monochromatic look of its blue, silver, black or red cases.

title: Republicans Weather Watch
description: Bad weather at an outdoor wedding, a graduation, a picnic or a pep rally is mostly just bad luck. Bad weather at the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla. next week may be unlucky in more ways than one.

title: Friday Night Music: Fairport Convention
description: OK, I thought of trying to make it topical  in which case, given what passes for Romney humor, it should have been Born in the USA. But never mind. For whatever reason, lately Ive been listening to old folk-rock  and it doesnt get better than this:

title: Wineries Golden Haul
description: Long Island producers won the top prizes in six of 30 classes of wine in the New York Wine and Food Classic this month.

title: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 24
Men, Who Needs Them?
description: Boise, Idaho

title: New Mexican Fare, and an Old Barbecue
description: CHICHIMECAS is a Mexican restaurant with a difference. Its two-story, cream-colored brick building, situated beside the railroad tracks in Farmingdale, was previously the home of Estelles Contemporary BBQ. When Chichimecas opened in late May, its owners kept the smoker, resulting in a menu of barbecue alongside the Mexican classics.

title: The Clock Ticks for Men as Well
description: LET the baton of blame pass to the next runner.

title: Gun Used by Shooter Is Known for Its Deadly Power
description: The pistol used by a disgruntled designer to kill a former co-worker outside the Empire State Building on Friday is among the more lethal handguns on the American firearms market.

title: Apple Beats Samsung: First Reactions
description: 8:35 p.m. | Updated  Adding comment from Samsung Electronics.

title: Gambias Leader Declares Plans for Mass Executions
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The eccentric president of Gambia has warned that he will carry out a mass execution of prisoners by mid-September, a threat local journalists and opposition officials said must be taken seriously given his unpredictability and long record of human rights abuses.

title: How Hate Gets Counted
description: DO American Sikhs count?

title: Why Are People So Upset With Twitter? Lets Grab a Bite
description: A parable that may help you understand why developers of Twitter-related apps and services are so angry at Twitter after it changed its rules for them:

title: Pomp
description: Every three years, the Preservation Society of Newport County invites the Coaching Club of America for driving, parties and a grand ball.

title: Newport
description: The evening festivities surrounding the four-day coaching events included drives through some of the estates.

title: College Football Preview: In Heisman Race, Five Players to Watch
description: Matt Barkley, U.S.C., QB(2011: 308 of 446 for 3,528 yards, 39 touchdowns, 7 interceptions)

title: The Trouble With For-Profit Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: Viewing Robots as Assistants, Not Replacements
description: To the Editor:

title: Jobless and Invisible
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rapper and Poet Pushes for a New French Identity of Inclusion
description: PARIS

title: Bill Cunningham | Pomp
description: Every three years, since it began in 1968, the Preservation Society of Newport County invites the Coaching Club of America with international clubs for a weekend of coaching through the area.

title: Confirming Judges
description: To the Editor:

title: Backing, Not Backing Away From, Armstrong
description: Lance Armstrong dropped his fight against doping charges Thursday, which means he will be stripped of his seven Tour de France titles. But his loyal sponsors are not stripping him of their support.

title: One. One Beloved Puppeteer.
description: There is a moment in one of the great childrens-music LPs from the glory days of Sesame Street, Bert and Ernie Sing-Along, that causes the cast of human and Muppet characters to groan together in horror.

title: Al Gore, The End Of the Line
description: At 64, even after accumulating more than $100 million in wealth, Mr. Gore races like a man making up for lost time: blog posts to write, business deals to close, a global climate to save

title: Supposedly No Threat, Astros Send Mets to Sixth Straight Loss
description: The Mets lost to the Astros, the worst team in the major leagues, by 3-1 on Friday night at Citi Field, dropping 12 games under .500, a low for them this season.

title: Decision by 2 Officers to Open Fire in Busy Midtown Leaves Bystanders Wounded
description: As the two officers confronted a gunman in front of the Empire State Building on a busy Friday morning, they had to make a snap decision: Do they open fire in the middle of Midtown?

title: Rocking in the 70s
description: To the Editor:

title: Footage of Gunmans Death (Graphic)
description: A man fatally shot his former co-worker and was then shot and killed by the police in gunfire that injured nine other people outside the Empire State Building.

title: This Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Unsold goods are piling up in China, housing in the United States is starting to recover slightly, and Germany reaffirmed its commitment to keeping Greece in the euro zone.

title: Bloomberg Backs Responsible Extraction of Gas and Pays to Help Set Up Rules
description: After giving away a chunk of his personal fortune to the cause of eliminating coal-fired power plants, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is opening his checkbook in support of responsible extraction of natural gas by hydraulic fracturing.

title: The Caucus Click: Flipping for Paul
Pressure Increases on Yankees and Girardi After Sweep by White Sox
description: CLEVELAND  When Joe Girardi yelled at a heckling fan Wednesday night after a loss in Chicago, it appeared that the stress of a three-game losing streak and a tightening pennant race were unsettling him. The loss reduced the Yankees lead in the American League East to three games  a margin that was cut a-half game further before Friday nights game against the Cleveland Indians  and Girardi was not happy.

title: 2 U.S. Employees Wounded in Ambush on Mexican Road
description: MEXICO CITY  The circumstances were all too typical in a drug war in which roadside ambushes involving armored sport utility vehicles are a staple. But in an ambush on Friday, the vehicle belonged to the United States Embassy, the wounded were two American employees and the assailants included federal police officers.

title: Woods Stays in Chase, Wincing All the Way
description: FARMINGDALE, N.Y.  The hardest part of Tiger Woodss round at the Barclays on Friday was not getting his ball in the cup, it was picking it out of it. He woke up with a kink in his lower back from sleeping on a hotel mattress that was too soft, and as he warmed up on the range at Bethpage State Park, his back grew stiffer.

title: Amid a Renovation, Rethinking the Neuberger
description: PURCHASE, N.Y.

title: Cash Moves by HSBC in Inquiry
description: Prosecutors investigating the movement of money by global banks suspect HSBC of laundering money for Mexican drug cartels and moving cash for Saudi Arabian banks with ties to terrorists, according to federal authorities with direct knowledge of the investigations.

title: We Won, Lindgren Says, After a Loss
description: Here at The New York Times Magazine, we believe in accuracy. We hire writers who know how to relay the truth to our readers. We have a team of researchers who double-check their facts. We make corrections when we get things wrong. But sometimes, the truth gets murky. Last night was one of those times.

title: No More Bluffing
description: Chicago

title: Tropical Storm Isaac Lashes Haiti, Still Crippled by Earthquake
description: MEXICO CITY  Tropical Storm Isaac unleashed heavy rain over Haiti on Friday, raising the threat of floods and mudslides that could worsen the misery of a nation where hundreds of thousands still remain homeless from the 2010 earthquake.

title: Arms and the Duck
description: We had a shooting near the Empire State Building. An aggrieved ex-employee of an apparel company killed his former co-worker, and was himself killed by police. Except for the famous-landmark location, it was not actually a very big story. Remember the mass shooting at the lumberyard in North Carolina earlier this year, or the one last October at the California cement plant? No? Neither does anybody else except the grieving families.

title: Once Again, Landmark Is Backdrop to Violence
description: On movie screens it has been besieged by aliens, tidal waves and an overgrown ape. But on Friday morning the horror at the Empire State Building was all too real.

title: At the Carnival, Love and Looming Clouds
description: Looked at objectively, the hero of Carousel isnt very good hero material. Proud, vain and not just a little bit dumb, the carnival barker Billy Bigelow also possesses a violent streak and a hot temper.

title: College Football Preview: Five Teams to Watch
description: OHIO The last time the Bobcats won more games than any other Football Bowl Subdivision program in the state was 1962. That streak should end in 2012. Beyond the talent, experience and coaching, the Bobcats have a schedule that could not be more favorable. Ohio is simply a better team than every opponent on its schedule  and that includes Penn State, which hosts the Bobcats in the season opener.

title: Dump It on the States
description: On Thursday, Mitt Romney unveiled the latest in a series of bad ideas for taking government duties out of Washington and hiding them in the back rooms of state capitols. Mostly, Mr. Romney wants to allow states to quietly smother social programs the federal government has run for decades. In the case of his new energy policy, he wants to give states power to bypass Washingtons caution in burrowing for oil, gas and coal on federal lands.

title: Long Before Carnage, an Office Grudge Festered
description: The two men at the center of a fatal shooting outside the Empire State Building on Friday had brushed shoulders for years  often literally, two large egos stuffed into a small office  and yet could hardly have been less alike.

title: After Gay Sons Suicide, Mother Finds Blame in Herself and in Her Church
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J.  When Tyler Clementi told his parents he was gay, two days before he left for Rutgers University in the fall of 2010, he said he had known since middle school.

title: President Morsi and His Critics
description: There was another street demonstration in Cairo on Friday. This time, instead of inveighing against former President Hosni Mubarak, or his generals, people were protesting against Egypts first freely elected president, Mohamed Morsi. It was one more sign that citizens in the new Egypt are determined to make their voices heard  and a sign, too, that Mr. Morsi and his party, the Muslim Brotherhood, are having a hard time hearing those voices.

title: Aruba Shares Gain on Strong Quarter
description: Aruba Networks, a maker of components for mobile devices, surged 14 percent, to $19.36, after reporting quarterly sales and profit that exceeded analysts estimates. Revenue in the period, which ended July 31 and was the fourth quarter of Arubas fiscal year, rose 22 percent, to $139.2 million, and profit excluding some items was 18 cents a share, topping a company projection of 16 to 17 cents.

title: For Judgeships in New York City
description: With Congressional primaries decided in a separate election in June and just a few state legislative races on the ballot, New York Citys primary elections on Sept. 13 are expected to draw few voters. Holding the primaries on a Thursday instead of the customary Tuesday does not help.

title: Syrian Forces Strike Again in Suburbs of Damascus
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian troops continued to pound the suburbs of Damascus on Friday, as fighting raged in Aleppo and as rebels in the eastern city of Deir al-Zour reported seizing an armory that had been contested for days.

title: Trial to Begin for 16 Members of Amish Group Charged in Beard-Cutting Attacks
description: Sixteen members of an Amish splinter group accused of terrorizing the Amish of eastern Ohio in bizarre beard-cutting attacks are scheduled to go on trial Monday in federal court in Cleveland.

title: Romney, in His Home State, Raises Birth Certificate Issue
description: COMMERCE, Mich.  Mitt Romney, who has denounced the nasty personal tone of the presidential campaign, seemed to make a joke about President Obamas birth certificate while speaking to voters here on Friday, reinjecting the issue of the presidents birthplace into the campaign.

title: Murdoch Paper Defies a Warning and Exposes Prince Harry
description: LONDON  It took 72 hours, but one of Britains normally scandal-hungry tabloids finally broke ranks on Friday, defying a warning from palace officials and publishing two photographs of Prince Harry cavorting naked during a game of strip billiards in his Las Vegas hotel suite.

title: Lottery Numbers
Al Gore Through the Years
description: A look at Mr. Gores life from his run for presidency to his current work with global warming.

title: A New Guide to the Republican Herd
description: A look at the major blocs of the Republican Party going into the 2012 election.

title: Starving the Future
description: America is in trouble.

title: Diplomacy With Iran Still Is Viable, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration insisted Friday that there is time and space for a diplomatic solution to the Iranian nuclear crisis, despite new evidence, to be released next week by international nuclear inspectors, that Iran is bolstering its ability to produce a type of uranium that can be converted relatively quickly to bomb fuel.

title: Missouri Lawmaker Tries to Shift Focus From Comments on Rape
description: CHESTERFIELD, Mo.  Representative Todd Akin held a public event on Friday afternoon for the first time since the broadcast of his controversial comments about rape victims, and attempted to turn the focus of his Senate race in Missouri back on the issue that had once made victory seem a sure thing: Senator Claire McCaskill.

title: Point of No Return
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Note to readers under the age of 25 (Dont hide, I can see you out there): You will be able to get a toehold in this puzzle. Give it a whirl, even though its a Saturday. Its the long entries that, when filled in, give you the start you need to tell all your friends that you finished a Saturday New York Times puzzle.

title: G.O.P. Convention Will Include Video Tribute to Paul
description: WASHINGTON  Mitt Romneys campaign on Friday extended an olive branch to the small army of Ron Paul delegates who will arrive in Tampa, Fla., next week even as Mr. Romneys lawyers sought to prevent a similar show of political force at future conventions.

title: Corrections: August 25, 2012
description: NEW YORK

title: France: Remarks Cost Designer Award
description: President Franois Hollande of France has stripped John Galliano, the fashion designer convicted last year of making anti-Semitic remarks, of the Lgion dHonneur that he was awarded in 2009. Mr. Galliano, 51, who was made a chevalier of the Lgion dHonneur by former President Nicolas Sarkozy, was involved in two drunken episodes in a small Paris bar and restaurant. His anti-Semitic remarks, some of them caught on an amateur video, led to his conviction last year on charges of public insults based on origin, religious affiliation, race or ethnicity. In February 2011, Mr. Galliano harangued a museum curator about being Jewish and uttered racial insults at her friend, who is of South Asian origin. The court also saw a video of Mr. Galliano, the previous November, declaring his love for Adolf Hitler. Mr. Hollande, elected in May, has been outspoken in condemning anti-Semitism and crimes against Jews committed by the French police under Nazi occupation.

title: A Slump Cant Get in the Way
description: The Yankees, on the verge of being swept in Chicago for the first time in 21 years and in desperate need of a stabilizing victory, were trailing in the top of the seventh inning Wednesday night. There was a runner on first base representing the tying run, and Russell Martin was at the plate trying not to think about his agonizing offensive season, the worst of his career.

title: Jerry Grant, Racecar Driver Who Broke Speed Barrier, Dies at 77
description: Jerry Grant, who was the first driver to go faster than 200 miles per hour in an Indy-style racecar but who may be best remembered for his heartbreaking defeats, memorably in the 1972 Indianapolis 500, died on Aug. 12 in Orange, Calif. He was 77.

title: Daryl Hine, Poet, Editor and Translator, Dies at 76
description: Daryl Hine, an admired poet who adhered to classical themes, complicated formal structures and intricate rhyming patterns to explore themes of philosophy, history and his own sexuality, died on Monday in Evanston, Ill. He was 76.

title: Will Men Really Worry About Their Biological Clocks?
description: The most striking thing to me about the online reaction to the recent study concluding that, in a fraction of cases, increased mutations found in the sperm of older men meant they were more likely than their younger counterparts to father children with autism or schizophrenia was the reaction that wasnt. The reaction, that is, from the world of fathers who blog and write about their children and their childrens autism.

title: Putin Shows Some Openness to New Missile Reductions
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin said Friday that Russia would be willing to negotiate new reductions in nuclear arms with the United States but that Washington must first change its plans for a missile defense system in Europe strongly opposed by the Kremlin.

title: Mets Plumb the Depths of Division and Devotion
description: The Mets entered Friday nights game against the Houston Astros with a number of questions.

title: In Horse Town, Daily Doubles Give Way to Nightly Buzz
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  The man who called himself Joe smiled as he spoke of Newsdad, the horse that almost was.

title: Sharing Fire With Pollock
description: Jackson Pollock is best known for the paintings he made from 1947 to 1951 in which he poured and dripped enamel paint onto large, unprimed canvases tacked to the floor of his studio, which at that time happened to be in Springs, N.Y., a hamlet in the town of East Hampton. These are the works that broke the ice for other painters of his generation, as Willem de Kooning put it, and that turned Pollock into a legend: Jack the Dripper, according to a 1956 Life magazine article, whose approach signaled the end of easel painting for many younger artists.

title: Biden Postpones Campaign Visit to Tampa
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has postponed an in-your-face visit to Tampa scheduled for Monday, his office said Friday night.

title: A Scary Smack in the Helmet, but Sighs of Relief for Jeter and Sabathia
description: CLEVELAND  The Yankees faced their most critical test of the season Friday night. They had been swept in Chicago, and their division lead slashed to two and a half games. So the thought of C. C. Sabathia being unable to respond after a bout of inflammation in his left elbow was frightening for them to contemplate.

title: Orgy Photos Give More Than a Peek Into Chinese Officials Sex Lives
description: BEIJING  There are some things that are well known about the sex lives of Chinas most lascivious male officials.

title: Finding Humanity in a Disturbing Mind
description: The scene looks harmless enough at first. Odd but harmless. A young woman and an older man are standing on a forested hill talking about baseball. He has binoculars and is watching a game from afar. Soon we learn why he isnt at the game and why he so badly wants to be. Gradually and gracefully, his story unfolds in Gino DiIorios Release Point, having its world premiere with the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch.

title: Romney in Crisis: Two Dark Spots in Fortunate Life
description: WASHINGTON  Mitt Romney was, uncharacteristically, terrified.

title: Learning to Play Tennis Late in Life
description: There is seldom an hour I spend alone with Kirill when I dont come to feel worn and inadequate.

title: A Ghost Town on 20 Acres in Brooklyn
description: The developer Douglas C. Steiner recently reached an agreement with the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation to convert an abandoned Civil War-era hospital complex into a media and technology hub.

title: Garcia Will Skip the Deutsche Bank Championship
description: FARMINGDALE, N.Y.  After winning last week in Greensboro and holding a share of the lead at the Barclays at the halfway point, Sergio Garcia realized it is possible to play too well for ones own good.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: The Deadest Ends

title: College Football Preview: Around the Nation
description: Vanderbilt

title: Dock Master
description: Catherine Kendrick, 78, known as Kay, has covered the Yonkers waterfront as a volunteer lifeguard for 60 years, and she is still there.

title: For Boston, a Swap of Problems for Potential
description: In 2007, when the Boston Red Sox won their second championship in four years, they seemed to be the model franchise. They were rich and savvy, with a pipeline of homegrown talent and the guts and brains to act boldly and wisely when they needed to make a move.

title: A Lifetime of Guarding Lives
description: ON Wednesday afternoon, a young woman walked to the end of the city pier in Yonkers, just north of the New York City limits, and stared longingly out at the Hudson River.

title: Colorado Suspect Spoke of Plans, Prosecutors Say
description: DENVER  James E. Holmes, the former graduate student charged with murdering 12 people in a shooting spree inside a Colorado movie theater last month, told a classmate months earlier that he wanted to kill people, prosecutors said in court filings on Friday.

title: A Verdict That Alters an Industry
description: The federal court jurys decision Friday in a smartphone patent lawsuit between Apple and Samsung is expected to alter the dynamics of the highly competitive mobile phone industry.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,086 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Litigation, Rockefeller and the Yankees
description: Music, the composer Ira B. Arnstein once said, is a language in sound like Latin or French. Ill prove it. He tried. But the perennial plaintiff, who argued in lawsuit after lawsuit that more popular composers had plagiarized his music, never won a case.

title: Hertz Said to Be Close to Buying Dollar Thrifty
description: Hertz Global Holdings is near a deal to acquire the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group for nearly $2.5 billion, according to a person briefed on the transaction, ending a fierce and protracted merger battle among the nations largest car rental companies.

title: As Tough as His Task
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  Every morning, Bill and Colleen OBrien know their older son, 10-year-old Jack, will have a seizure when he wakes up. It could last 30 seconds or go on for 30 minutes, necessitating an ambulance trip to the hospital. There may be more seizures during the day, depending on disparate factors like weather patterns and Jacks growth spurts. And when they happen, the OBriens can do little except to turn their son on his side and wait for the seizure to end.

title: Tennis, of Course, and Ladybugs
description: Patrick McEnroe, 46, ESPNs affably enlightening tennis commentator, will host and call matches at the United States Open, which starts Monday at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Flushing, Queens. He also works at the site year-round, as the general manager of player development for the United States Tennis Association. Mr. McEnroe retired from professional tennis in 1998, though he and his older brother John won the over-45 legends doubles tournament at the French Open this year. He and his wife, the actress-singer  Melissa Errico, live in SoHo with their three daughters, Victoria, 6, and the twins Diana and Juliette, 3 . Sundays are family time, either in the city or at the house they rent in Sag Harbor, N.Y., in summer.

title: Wilson Shines for Giants Offense, but Amukamara Sustains Ankle Injury
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  With 12 days until the regular-season opener, the Giants entered their third preseason game with significant expectations for two young players. David Wilson, the first-round pick, is pushing to become a critical part of the running game, and Prince Amukamara, the first-round draft pick in 2011, had been trying to fit in as a de facto starting cornerback.

title: Local Stop: Sutton Place
description: The quiet neighborhood of Sutton Place runs along the East River from 53rd to 59th Street.

title: Parks, Privacy and River Views
description: Sutton Place is both a grand old residential avenue (originally known as Avenue A), running alongside the East River from 53rd to 59th Street, and a serviceable neighborhood extending west to Second Avenue. At the rivers edge, the cross streets end in little vest-pocket parks with wide views of boats navigating the rivers treacherous currents, of Roosevelt Islands Southpoint Park and of the monumental Queensboro and Williamsburg Bridges. Like many of its residents, Sutton Place is sedate and well maintained. Once here, people and businesses tend to stay put. Whenever people talk about assisted living, I say, No way, Id rather live in Sutton Place! said Vera Mayer, who moved there from Riverdale, in the Bronx, 38 years ago. Theres the privacy of Sutton Place, and then you walk over one block and you have everything you need.

title: Knicks Anthony Optimistic After Olympics
description: This off-season has been a success for Carmelo Anthony. He won his second Olympic gold medal for the United States in London, where he averaged 16.3 points and set a single-game American Olympic scoring record with 37 points against Nigeria.

title: Seeking Brooklyns Lost Mass Grave
description: NOTHING is visible at the intersection of Third Avenue and Eighth Street in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn to indicate that anything extraordinary is there. The artisanal-pie place on one corner and the auto body shops across the way suggest it is merely another spot in the city where grit is giving way to gentrification. But if a small group of history enthusiasts are right, this particular corner of Kings County is hallowed ground.

title: Calling All Refugee Kids
description: The Refugee Youth Summer Academy in Manhattan helps immigrant children and their families find their footing in the United States.

title: At Colorado Race, Mixed Reaction on Armstrong
description: BRECKENRIDGE, Colo.  Cycling fans who gathered for the start of Fridays Stage 5 of the USA Pro Challenge did not allow the Lance Armstrong scandal to diminish their enthusiasm for a sport riddled for years by doping controversy. But some were deeply worried for young competitive riders facing tough choices.

title: Newest Young Immigrants Get a Head Start on School
description: The Refugee Youth Summer Academy program helps dozens of recently arrived children, many from families of refugees, prepare to enter the school system.

title: Indias Paralyzed Parliament
description: These days, the Indian legislators have settled into a routine: At 11 a.m., members of the upper and lower houses gather at the Parliament House. Immediately, the opposition members walk to the well of the house, shouting, Nahi chalegi, nahi chalegi (will not function, will not function) and Manmohan Singh gaddi choro! (Manmohan Singh, leave the chair). The helpless speaker repeatedly tells the members, Kripya baith jaieye (Please sit down), but no one listens. After few minutes, the session is adjourned.

title: In New York, With 6 Weeks to Adapt to America
description: TWENTY-FOUR days after he arrived in the United States, Mamadou Fadja Diallo, 13, showed up for summer school in Manhattan looking wary and confused. The building itself was disorienting: big and imposing, with polished floors, nothing like his school back home in Guinea. He was surrounded by students from all over the world. He could not understand a word anyone was saying.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: A mob set fire to a police vehicle and beat up three police officers in Srinagar after prayers on Monday during the Muslim celebration of Id al-Fitr, Kashmir Live  reported.

title: Blunting Ideology With Biography
description: Unless youve subjected yourself to an Internet blackout to better commune with the natural pleasures of summer, chances are youve heard something about Mindy Meyer, the 22-year-old New York State Senate contestant, who, when asked about Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo in an interview, said she was not familiar with him in particular, like his issues, and you know, everything about him. A Brooklynite who would appear to find her intellectual stimulation in caricatures of celebrity vapidity, she has sought the endorsement of Kim Kardashian.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Wages in Bangladesh Far Below India
description: Indias neighbor Bangladesh has become the second-largest apparel exporter in the world, after China, Jim Yardley  reports, but labor unrest is growing as workers demand higher wages.

title: Remembering Steve Van Buren,  Hall of Famer for Eagles
description: Steve Van Buren led the Philadelphia Eagles to three straight Eastern Division titles and their first two N.F.L. championships, in 1948 and 1949. He retired as the leading rusher in league history. Van Buren died on Thursday in Lancaster, Pa., of pneumonia. He was 91. A few thoughts:

title: The Weekend Word: Crisis Management
description: Todays Times A 1968 car crash in France and the 1998 diagnosis of Ann Romneys multiple sclerosis were dark moments in what has otherwise seemed a charmed existence for Mitt Romney, Sheryl Gay Stolberg writes. Both offer clues into the Republican nominees character and the way he reacts to challenges.

title: Working Out With the Women of Hong Kong
description: HONG KONGHong Kong is muggy and mountainous, but that isnt slowing down the citys senior citizens.

title: Las Vegas and the Prince Harry Effect
description: LONDON  As British newspapers continued to harrumph about Prince Harrys naked antics in Las Vegas, the scandal surrounding the third-in-line to the throne appeared to have done little to chill their readers enthusiasm for visiting Sin City.

title: The End of the Line
description: AL GORE lives alone now, in a 10,000-square-foot colonial in Nashville, where magnolia trees shade the house and geothermal wells, buried beneath the driveway, cool and heat its 20 rooms.

title: Pakistani Militant Leader Dies in Airstrike, NATO Says
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  NATO forces said on Saturday that they had killed a senior Pakistani Taliban commander in an airstrike in Afghanistan, highlighting the increasingly complicated nature of the fight against Islamist militants along the border between Afghanistan and Pakistan.

title: At Least 39 Killed in Blast at Refinery in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  At least 39 people were killed on Saturday and dozens more were injured in a giant explosion that set off a raging fire at Venezuelas largest oil refinery, according to officials who rushed to the scene on the Paraguan Peninsula.

title: Eight Fantasy Football Sleepers in 2012
description: The term sleeper in fantasy football has changed over the last decade. Years ago, you could find great value with a rookie running back that no one knew about. Now, that player is going in the eighth round and every fantasy owner in your league knows his 40-yard dash time, vertical leap, college yards-per-carry and mothers maiden name.

title: Inflation Lessons
description: One of the themes Ive hit on many times is the fact that the crisis and slump have been a testing ground for economic doctrines. People came into this mess with very different views about how the economy works, and the crisis in effect provided natural experiments that tested those views.

title: College Football Preview: Overlooked, but They Shouldnt Be
description: STAR LOTULELEI, UTAH, DTLotulelei, a senior, demands double teams, collapses the pocket, clogs running lanes and tears up game plans.

title: Union Leader Works On Despite Brain Tumor
description: The player representatives for every major league team were summoned to a conference call with the unions executive director, Michael Weiner, at 1 p.m. Eastern on Tuesday. The players did not know the subject but had no reason to suspect anything unusual. Weiner wasted no time in telling them the news: the day before, he had begun treatment for a brain tumor.

title: Games Are Over; Battle Goes On
description: The Olympic sprinter Sanya Richards-Ross was at BETs Midtown studios last Wednesday for an appearance on the hip-hop show 106 & Park. Before stepping in front of the raucous studio audience, she put on her makeup with expert precision and helped a hair stylist fashion her characteristic S. R. R. braid. Later she joked with the rapper Bow Wow about his stealing the two gold medals she won at the recent London Games.

title: Romney Compares Protesters to a Greek Chorus
description: POWELL, Ohio  Mitt Romney had a message for the protesters who greeted him and Representative Paul D. Ryan, along with 5,000 supporters, here on Saturday morning: This is kind of like the Greek chorus in the background, he said, in a reference to President Obamas speech four years ago at the Democratic convention in Denver, which he delivered in front of large Greek columns.

title: The Rangers Renaissance Man
description: The death last week of the Rangers star Don Raleigh at 86 severed another of the last links to a long-vanished world of hockey where the ice was brown, chicken-wire fencing guarded the ends of the rink and a skinny player who developed a taste for opera could make it in the N.H.L.

title: Storm Adds to Misery in Haitis Homeless Camps
description: MEXICO CITY  Tropical Storm Isaac whirled across Haiti on Saturday, delivering strong winds and rain that caused flooding, mudslides and at least a few deaths, according to preliminary reports, but not the kind of widespread destruction feared in the earthquake-battered nation.

title: Jets Pouha Says He Will Be Ready
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Sione Pouha thought he knew pretty much everything there was to know about what it felt like to butt heads with offensive linemen. Pouha is a 325-pound nose tackle entering his eighth year with the Jets, and knocking helmets is just a part of the job.

title: Variety: A Fair Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  UPDATE: We apologize for the technical problems with the Acrostic. All links are now working, and the PDF should print out as a full page puzzle. The emus responsible for the glitches have been sacked.

title: French Leader Hails Greeks for Painful Efforts in Crisis
description: PARIS  President Franois Hollande of France gave the new Greek prime minister some reassurance in a meeting here on Saturday, expressing his commitment to keeping Greece in the euro zone.

title: Letter to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ragtag Revolts in Parts of Afghanistan Repel Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In small mountain villages on Taliban turf in eastern Afghanistan, Pashtun tribesmen took up arms to fight the insurgents this summer, fed up with their heavy-handed tactics of closing schools and threatening families whose sons had joined the Afghan Army.

title: Another Alternative Inflation Measure
description: A correspondent alerted me to an interesting alternative measure of inflation beyond the Billion Price Index. Those who claim that inflation is vastly understated often appeal to the authority of Shadowstats, a site that purports to provide true measures of many economic variables.

title: No Crime, No Punishment
description: When the Justice Department recently closed its criminal investigation of Goldman Sachs, it became all but certain that no major American banks or their top executives would ever face criminal charges for their role in the financial crisis.

title: Apple-Samsung Case Shows Smartphone as Legal Magnet
description: The smartphone in your hand is a marvel of innovation, packing sophisticated computing and communications technologies into a sleek digital device.

title: A Glitch in Health Care Reform
description: Confusing language in the health care reform law has raised the possibility that millions of Americans living on modest incomes may be unable to afford their employers family policies and yet fail to qualify for government subsidies to buy their own insurance. This is a bizarre development that undercuts the basic goal of health care reform  to expand the number of insured people and make their coverage affordable.

title: The Outbreak of West Nile Disease
description: The nation is in the midst of an outbreak of West Nile disease that could become the worst ever recorded since the virus was first detected in New York in 1999. The number of cases has risen sharply in recent weeks.

title: How Mr. Romney Would Force-Feed the Pentagon
description: Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan are portraying themselves as lionhearted budget-cutters, ready to slice out profligate spending in all sorts of government programs and services and lead America to lower taxes and lower deficits. Many experts say their numbers dont add up, even if they were to impose all the cuts they want.

title: How Long Do You Want to Live?
description: SINCE 1900, the life expectancy of Americans has jumped to just shy of 80 from 47 years. This surge comes mostly from improved hygiene and nutrition, but also from new discoveries and interventions: everything from antibiotics and heart bypass surgery to cancer drugs that target and neutralize the impact of specific genetic mutations.

title: Success and Risk as The Times Transforms
description: WHY on earth would you want this job?

title: After Bullets Hit Bystanders, Protocol Questions
description: The encounter was breathtakingly brief: a surveillance video showed a gunman outside the Empire State Building on Friday pulling a pistol, pointing it at two police officers, their firing at him and his falling to the sidewalk.

title: Leave Me Alone!
description: I watched Super Bowl XLVI in February by myself, the same way I watch most televised N.F.L. games. Sad? Hardly. Solo watching is a habit I adopted in high school. Although my friends and family were not overtly obnoxious, I often found them disruptive.

title: Big Chem, Big Harm?
description: NEW research is demonstrating that some common chemicals all around us may be even more harmful than previously thought. It seems that they may damage us in ways that are transmitted generation after generation, imperiling not only us but also our descendants.

title: U.S. Cup Qualifier: The View From Traffic in Brazil
description: Last weeks stunning announcement, at least to some in United States soccer circles, that the next two and possibly six away World Cup qualifying matches would be shown only on Al Jazeeras new network, beIN Sport, was not so bewildering in at least one quarter.

title: Too Late to Shake That Etch A Sketch
description: WASHINGTON

title: I Made the Robot Do It
description: Boston

title: Things I Saw  No. 28
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: 30 Seconds With Anthony Davis: Unique Twist to Hoops Trifecta
description: Anthony Davis has had a spectacular year. After leading Kentucky to the N.C.A.A. championship in April, Davis, a 6-foot-10 power forward, was chosen in June by the New Orleans Hornets as the first pick of the N.B.A. draft. This month, Davis helped the United States mens basketball team win the gold medal at the London Olympics.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Conversations Between Doctor and Patient
description: Readers discuss whether clinicians should be assertive or let the patient decide.

title: Randy Moody
description: Randy Moody is the co-chairman of Republicans for Planned Parenthood, which was founded in 1995 to give Republicans who favor abortion rights a voice. Despite his long-shot lobbying efforts and the continuing furor over Representative Todd Akins remarks about abortion and rape, the G.O.P. Platform Committee last week adopted a strict anti-abortion position with no exceptions for rape, incest or to save the life of the mother.

title: Where the Mob Keeps Its Money
description: Rome

title: Underwater, Feeling Our Ocean Origins
description: Ive always loved scuba diving and the cell-tickling feel of being underwater, though it poses unique frustrations. Alone, but with others, you may share the same sights and feelings, but you cant communicate well.

title: Dozens of Bodies Are Found in Town Outside Damascus
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Dozens of bodies, possibly more than 200, were found Saturday in a town outside Damascus, raising the specter of a massacre by Syrian troops as bad as any atrocity committed since the Syrian uprising began nearly 18 months ago.

title: The Democrats Abortion Moment
description: IN 1971, two years before Roe v. Wade, the philosopher Judith Jarvis Thomson used an arresting thought experiment to make the case for legalized abortion.

title: An Immune Disorder at the Root of Autism
description: IN recent years, scientists have made extraordinary advances in understanding the causes of autism, now estimated to afflict 1 in 88 children. But remarkably little of this understanding has percolated into popular awareness, which often remains fixated on vaccines.

title: Chinese Deny Forcing Refugees to Myanmar
description: The Chinese Foreign Ministry has denied human rights advocates reports that China is forcing ethnic Kachin refugees to return to a war zone in Myanmar, saying that the people are going home of their own accord.

title: Ever Meek, Ever Malleable
description: I INSTANTLY bought the strip-search. The nude jumping jacks, too.

title: What Would Jesus Do? Skinny-Dip
description: KEVIN YODER, a congressman from Kansas, apologized last week for swimming nude in the Sea of Galilee last summer during a trip with his wife and other members of Congress, who apparently were clothed. Actually, he apologized for any embarrassment I have caused for my colleagues and constituents.

title: Out of a Job, but Not Missing a Beat
description: Scott Radinsky pitched for four major league teams from 1990 to 2001. A left-handed reliever who appeared in 557 games, Radinsky compiled a 42-25 record, a 3.44 earned run average and 52 saves. In 2004, he began working his way up the coaching ranks for the Cleveland Indians, serving as a pitching coach for four of their minor league teams. In 2010, he became the Indians bullpen coach, and this year, he was put in charge of the pitchers. But six days after a reporter interviewed him in Cleveland, Radinsky was home in California, without a job and pondering his next move. And he was being Radinsky, which means being engagingly different, as this two-week account demonstrates.

title: Shifting Conference Alignments
description: Nearly a quarter of the 124 programs in the Football Bowl Subdivision will change their conference affiliation between 2011-13. A look at the 2012 and 2013 changes.

title: Lees Losing Battle on the Mound
description: Last Tuesday, in the seventh inning against Cincinnati at Citizens Bank Park, Cliff Lee of the Philadelphia Phillies walked Todd Frazier. It is the only walk Lee has issued in four starts this month, compared with 32 strikeouts. Alas, he has no victories in August.

title: The Antisocial Contract
description: WHEN the Republican Party meets in Tampa, Fla., this week, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey will deliver the keynote address. He promises hard truths. Twenty years ago, the Democrat-turned-Republican Phil Gramm had that job. Warning to Governor Christie: no one remembers anything Mr. Gramm said. What we do remember from the 1992 convention in Houston is the jeremiad delivered by Patrick J. Buchanan, the former speechwriter for Richard M. Nixon who won nearly a quarter of Republican primary votes that year. With his invocation of a cultural war for the soul of America, Mr. Buchanan brought down the house.

title: Drugs, Sweat and Fear
description: In the fall of 2007, I attended my first yoga class. For more than four years  ever since graduation had dumped me into adulthood  Id been leveled by anxiety. My days were plagued with worry. Was I living correctly? What if I died? What if, like in that Twilight Zone episode, the rest of the world died and I lived? Innocuous things I said to people haunted me hours later Was that dumb? Mean? Wildly inappropriate?until Id squirm with shame. Unable to sleep at night, I gobbled Tylenol PM, rationalizing that it was over-the-counter, as if over-the-counter meant nutritious.

title: Newton and Carolina Ready to Take Next Step
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  The other September cover of GQ magazine on the national newsstands  the one without the Jets Tim Tebow  features an N.F.L. quarterback who is slightly less publicized. For now.

title: Radical Islamic Attacks in a Moderate Region Unnerve the Kremlin
description: KAZAN, Russia  A string of violent attacks by Islamic militants has shattered this citys reputation as a citadel of religious tolerance and unnerved federal officials in Moscow, who have worked for decades to prevent the spread of radical Islam out of the southern borderlands and into places like this city 500 miles east of Moscow.

title: Developing Top Talent or Hindering Process?
description: The 16th-ranked junior player in the world was rallying at the Sportime tennis center on Randalls Island on a recent afternoon when the owner of the tennis academy there swaggered onto the court for a peek at one of his pet projects, Noah Rubin.

title: The Best Book Reviews Money Can Buy
description: TULSA , Okla.

title: History Lays a Course for the Next Breakthrough
description: From the other side of Raes Creek, where Augusta Country Club sits, people and practices have long trickled to Augusta National Golf Club. The club that Bobby Jones and Clifford Roberts founded in 1930 was built using a few golfers who belonged to Augusta C.C. as mortar to fill in the membership and finance the enterprise.

title: Border Cities Are Burdened With Calls for Help
description: CALEXICO, Calif.  The calls come in thick and fast from the border, just blocks from the fire station here.

title: In Mario Batalis Kitchen, Youll Refrain From Shouting
description: This interview with  Mario Batali, the chef, cookbook author and television personality, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Romneys First 100 Days
description: WASHINGTON  It is the morning of Wednesday, Nov. 7, and after a long night of celebrating and a short night of sleep, Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan wake up to confront the question awaiting every new administration: Of the campaigns many promises, which few will become the real priorities?

title: The Sun Belt, Eclipsed
description: TAMPA, Fla.  For more than 50 years, the Sun Belt  the band of states that extends from Florida to California  has been the philosophical heart and electoral engine of the Republican Party. It was more than just a source of votes. The Sun Belt infused the Republican Party with a frontier spirit: the optimistic, free-ranging embrace of individualism and the disdain for big government and regulation.

title: Another Henry for the Red Bulls?
description: The Red Bulls, not to mention a future United States national team, might have a promising player in their future  the newborn son of the clubs French captain, Thierry Henry. Then again, he could have a choice of playing for the United States, France or Bosnia.

title: When a 401(k) Is Locked in the Freezer
description: EVERYONE with a 401(k) knows that bad investments and high fees can threaten their retirement. But what if the company that sponsors your plan goes bankrupt?

title: No Quiet in the Cubicle
description: To the Editor:

title: The Hunt for Dividends
description: To the Editor:

title: Researching Your Mortgage
description: To the Editor:

title: For Big Givers, Cash and Clout Arrive Together
description: The railway giant CSX, which has spent $2 million this year lobbying on issues like greenhouse-gas regulation and hazardous-waste transportation rules, will park special train cars near the Tampa Bay Times Forum to host parties and meetings.

title: By Adding Pieces, Braves Are Hoping to Complete Puzzle
description: The Atlanta Braves understand the fleeting nature of the standings this time of year. They ended last August with an 80-55 record and an eight-and-a-half-game lead for a playoff spot, only to squander it by going 9-18 in September. A year later, they are embarking on another final sprint, with another wild-card lead but a sharper perspective.

title: Early Detection for Brain Injuries
description: FOOTBALL teams of the future  even high school squads on limited budgets  may someday have a new tool to check players for brain injuries. Its a special form of headgear, packed with sensors that read the brain waves of athletes after they come off the field, thus detecting changes caused by the trauma of hard knocks.

title: Lessons Learned From 08 Ticket, Romney and Ryan Present a United Front
description: POWELL, Ohio  It looks as if there will be no going rogue for the Republican vice-presidential candidate this time.

title: 6 Years Old, and Reaching Summits
description: Are you sure about this? I ask my daughters. Theres no way well get out of this forest before nightfall. Weve at least five miles and two water crossings to go.

title: For Friendly Foes, Trash Talk Is Now Open for Business

title: Libertarian Legion Stands Ready to Accept Torch From Paul
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The future of what Ron Paul started rests with supporters like Ashley Ryan, who will attend Mr. Pauls final presidential campaign rally here with decidedly mixed feelings.

description: In recent years, Silicon Valley seems to have forgotten about silicon. Its been about dot-coms, Web advertising, social networking and apps for smartphones.

description: Neil Armstrong, who made the giant leap for mankind as the first human to set foot on the moon, died on Saturday. He was 82.

title: Carbon Tax Silence, Overtaken by Events
description: DONT expect to hear much about climate change at the Republican and Democratic conventions.

description: NEW DELHI  The recent panic that led tens of thousands of Indians to flee their homes has largely subsided, leaving in its wake an uneven government crackdown on the Internet and text-messaging services that top officials blame for circulating the baseless rumors that set off the exodus.

title: Cleansing Trade Could Bring Back Turned-Off Red Sox Fans

The whole family left after the third inning and went home to watch the Patriots-Buccaneers football preseason game.

title: Hamas Says Egypt Will Reopen Crossing Into Gaza

Managing a smile, he touches the barren skin with his fingers, wondering aloud if it will ever grow back after an exacting battle with throat cancer that involved months of radiation therapy.

It opened its door this past January and regularly hosts events and classes and is located at 902 Broadway (at 20th St), 4th Floor in New York City. Instructor, Zoe Fraade-Blanar, has projects with the Times and teaches interactive design at NYU. The course description:

title: Tuning Out Everything but His Instincts, Garca Continues Surge

title: Before Censure, a Hushed Settlement Against Assemblyman

title: Chinese Deny Forcing Refugees to Myanmar

title: Kurodas One Year Is Enough to Wonder About Next One

Whenever a team makes a significant move that has wide-ranging implications in the division, it always captures the attention of its rivals, and no team is measured against the Yankees more than the Red Sox, and vice versa.

title: Stonewalls Bounty
description: It was the most grueling of the forced marches for which Gen. Stonewall Jackson was justly famous  56 miles in 36 hours across the rolling Virginia Piedmont. To move faster, at the beginning his men were ordered to unsling knapsacks. They were going to live off the land. But the land didnt offer much to sustain 23,000 Confederates. On the second day, remembered a South Carolina soldier, Berry Benson, My only foodwas a handful of parched corn and three or four small sour green apples.

title: Into the Laboratory for the Secrets of Spin
description: SCHILLER PARK, Ill.  Perhaps nowhere is tenniss evolution more visible than at the All England Club, which hosted Wimbledon and the Olympics this summer. The clues were found on the manicured lawns of Centre Court, where by the end of each tournament, scorching rallies had browned the grass at the baselines, a far cry from the hourglass pattern of wear and tear seen during the serve-and-volley heyday.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Editions
description: In a well-researched piece in the Economic and Political Weekly, Jyoti Punwani analyzes the run-up to the Aug. 11 rally at Azad Maidan in Mumbai and the fallout from the violence that occurred. There were clear signs of upcoming trouble, which the Mumbai police should have noticed, she argues, including a weeklong promotion of the rally thatinvolved the circulation of graphic video clips taken from the Internet and widespread discussion in the Urdu press. The Mumbai police suffer from a chronic lack of intelligence about the citys Muslim community, she argues, caused by its lack of knowledge of Urdu, lack of Muslim recruits and biased attitude.

title: Crackdown Toll Seen as Syrians Bury Hundreds

title: Reader Comments on my Big Chem Column
description: My Sunday column is about chemicals that are all around us and appear to be even more dangerous than previously thought. Ive written before about these endocrine disruptors, so called because they wreak havoc with the bodys endocrine system governing hormones. Now new research indicates that their effects may be passed down from generation to generation in humans. Using doses of the chemical BPA similar to what humans encounter, the study shows that exposure to the chemical in pregnant mice can affect the sociability of their children and their childrens children. This should be devastating for Big Chem, which has so far been able to block any meaningful national curbs on endocrine disruptors. This obviously isnt regular fodder for op-ed columns, but it seems an issue of public health and public policy that deserves more attention. Id welcome your comments on what should be done.
