description: Follow the path of the storm and the five-day forecast.

title: Obamas America Is a Box-Office Surprise
description: The movie capital didnt see this coming: The political documentary 2016: Obamas America, a cinematic extension of the best-selling book The Roots of Obamas Rage, beat two new Hollywood releases at the weekend box office and came close to passing a third. Obamas America, released by Rocky Mountain Pictures, took in an estimated $6.2 million at North American theaters, for a total of $9.1 million since opening in limited release last month. Two new movies  Hit & Run (Open Road Films) and The Apparition (Warner Brothers)  flopped, taking in less than $4.7 million each. Another new release, Premium Rush (Sony), managed to take in only $6.3 million.

title: Dealmaker for the Shotmakers
description: When Maria Sharapova decided that she wanted to stay at a new hotel for this years United States Open, her agent, Max Eisenbud, embarked on a reconnaissance mission. He met with management and interviewed security officials. He toured suites and tested room service. He took a taxi from the lobby entrance to the Midtown Tunnel, mapping out the fastest route to the tennis center in Queens.

title: Dashing to Stardom, in Step
description: After a year has spun by on the carousel that is the professional tennis tour, two young Americans find themselves back at the place where they broke through: the United States Open.

title: German Official Opposes European Debt Purchases
description: FRANKFURT  The president of the German central bank said in an interview published Sunday that he remained staunchly opposed to government bond purchases by the European Central Bank, a position that could make it more difficult to deploy a weapon many economists believe is essential to saving the euro.

title: At Rally, Paul Touts Strength of His Liberty Movement
description: 5:52 p.m. | Updated TAMPA, Fla.  After five hours of anticipation, Representative Ron Paul of Texas took the stage here at his We Are the Future rally and proclaimed his liberty movement alive and well, despite efforts to declare it dead or shut it out of the Republican National Convention.

title: Building a Grand Slam Experience
description: Switching between surfaces for a New York Grand Slam offered insights into the physical, tactical and psychological aspects of the game.

title: One City, Four Surfaces
description: When the United States Open begins in New York each summer, it is a reminder of how much this city has to offer. It is a place where you can you can shop in an African art gallery, eat in an Uighur restaurant, see a Broadway show, then dance in a Russian nightclub in one day without leaving the five boroughs. When it comes to tennis, the city also provides local players the opportinuty to play on courts that replicate tenniss four most prestigious tournaments. I call it the New York Grand Slam.

title: A Warm Welcome for Doctor Who in New York
description: You might have anticipated a minor riot on Saturday night at the Ziegfeld Theater on West 54th Street, where BBC America screened the premiere episode from the forthcoming season of Doctor Who for a select audience of lucky fans. BBC America had mounted similar events in New York for previous seasons of this long-running science-fiction franchise, filling an East Village theater with hard-core fans who had queued for hours in hopes of being among the chosen few.

title: Start With a Roof
description: The perfect United States Open would start with the declaration that Arthur Ashe Stadium, acknowledged as the worst major tennis stadium in the world, with upper deck seats so bad they might as well be in Rhode Island, will be replaced. If they want to get some use out of it, fine, use it to house the Yankees bank vault, store snowplows or Macys parade floats or spare La Guardia aircraft. Anything but tennis. And youre off and running.

title: How Will Party Conventions Affect the Presidential Race?
description: The Republican and Democratic national conventions bring the possibility of change to this static presidential race. But how will it change, and how much? Here is some of what we know.

title: A House for Fans, in a Dedication to Dinkins
description: My reconstructed United States Open would begin with the building of a new main stadium that I would dedicate to David Dinkins, the best New York friend the tournament has ever had and whose name is attached to a measly circle outside the tennis center. Call it  colloquially  the House of David and give it the atmosphere and class that unfortunately is so lacking at Arthur Ashe Stadium.

title: Romneys Talk Issues, and Fashion, in Joint Interview
description: As the Republican Party prepares this week to offer a more expansive introduction of Mitt Romney, the candidate and his wife sat down for a rare joint television interview, covering some of the heavier topics of the day  Medicare, taxes and abortion  but also lighter fare, like Mr. Romneys preference for shirts from a well-known discount chain.

title: Zombie Candidate Crashes Republican Convention
description: And they say President Obama and Mitt Romney can be stiff.

title: U.S. Arms Sales Make Up Most of Global Market
description: WASHINGTON  Weapons sales by the United States tripled in 2011 to a record high, driven by major arms sales to Persian Gulf allies concerned about Irans regional ambitions, according to a new study for Congress.

title: Spain Expects to Tap About $75 Billion in Rescue Financing for Its Banks
description: MADRID  Spain expects to use about 60 billion euros, or $75 billion, of the 100 billion euros of bank rescue financing offered by European finance ministers in June, according to the Spanish economy minister, Luis de Guindos.

title: Storm Poses Risks for Republican Convention Planners
description: 6:05 p.m. | Updated TAMPA, Fla.  It looks to be one of the worst nightmares for planners of Mitt Romneys coronation.

title: Golden Instability
description: Say this for the GOP: by resurrecting the very bad, no good, truly awful idea of a gold standard, theyve given us something to talk about.

title: Navigating Tangled Narratives
description: NW, the title of Zadie Smiths clunky new novel, refers to northwest London, where she grew up  a multicultural corner of the city that will be familiar to readers of her dazzling debut, White Teeth. In that earlier book Ms. Smith took a contemporary London mapped by writers like Martin Amis, Salman Rushdie and Hanif Kureishi and claimed it decisively as her own. There are glimpses, here and there in NW, of that cacophonous metropolis  a city in constant flux as waves of immigrants and fierce youth reinvent it year by year, day by day  but NW is a much smaller, more meager book than White Teeth.

title: Inventor Challenges a Sweeping Revision in Patent Law
description: In Silicon Valley, Apple just won big against Samsung in the patent lawsuit of the year, after trading claims and counterclaims of pilfered product ideas. Across the country, in a federal court in Florida, an inventor named Mark Stadnyk is waging a different kind of patent warfare  an ambitious and perhaps quixotic legal foray.

title: Cuomo Calls for Resignation of Brooklyn Assemblyman
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Sunday became the latest Democratic official to call for the resignation of a powerful Brooklyn assemblyman who was censured on Friday after allegations of sexual harassment.

title: Qualifying at a Location Near You
description: How about bringing the pop-up concept to Grand Slam tennis?

title: All Things Equal: Lets Play Five
description: An expanded tennis center should equal more tennis. But that does not necessarily mean expanding the field. It should mean giving the worlds greatest tennis players more time on the sports largest stage.

title: Get to the Point, in Fewer Sets
description: It is time to do away with the best-of-five format that is burdening the mens game at Grand Slam events. With the increased physicality of the sport, best-of-five matches too often turn into seemingly interminable wars of attrition rather than the displays of finesse more befitting tennis. The men play best-of-five only at the majors and the Davis Cup, and there is little recent evidence that best-of-three makes for undeserving winners. Just as Roger Federer, Novak Djokovic, Rafael Nadal and Andy Murray have ruled the Grand Slams, they have also dominated the best-of-three Masters 1000 events, having swept the last 16 consecutive tournaments at that level.

title: The Way Forward: Recalling Forest Hills
description: The National Tennis Center is about to get another face-lift. Who runs tennis, anyway  Con Edison and its old Dig-We-Must slogan?

title: Viewers Dont Want Conventional
description: If the political conventions were managed like a typical television show that was losing audience, think of the meetings that would be held during the run-up.

title: As Indians Honor John Glenn, He Honors Neil Armstrong
description: CLEVELAND  An event that was planned weeks in advance was altered Sunday after the death of Neil Armstrong, the first man to walk on the moon. John Glenn, the first American astronaut to orbit Earth and a good friend of Armstrongs, threw out the ceremonial first pitch before the Cleveland Indians game against the Yankees at Progressive Field.

title: The Living Death of Solitary Confinement
description: There are many ways to destroy a person, but the simplest and most devastating might be solitary confinement. Deprived of meaningful human contact, otherwise healthy prisoners often come unhinged. They experience intense anxiety, paranoia, depression, memory loss, hallucinations and other perceptual distortions. Psychiatrists call this cluster of symptoms SHU syndrome, named after the Security Housing Units of many supermax prisons. Prisoners have more direct ways of naming their experience. They call it living death, the gray box, or living in a black hole.

title: A Conflicted Novice in the Shadow of the Guillotine
description: Poulencs solemn, shattering 1957 opera Dialogues des Carmlites is about a novice in an order of Carmelite nuns doomed by the anticlerical extremism of the French Revolution. The young woman, Blanche, struggles mightily with the rigors of the life to which she is committing herself before ultimately, joyously accepting them.

title: Broadway Just Got More Dangerous
description: On a recent afternoon the four cast members of the satirical revue Forbidden Broadway were running through a number sending up the frenetic hard sell of the hit musical Newsies.

title: In Digital World, Advertising Age Redesigns Print Publication
description: A WEEKLY trade publication covering Madison Avenue since the Hoover administration will soon introduce its most significant redesign in years, as part of efforts to further redirect its editorial focus in a digital world toward analysis from breaking news.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Band With a Confrontational Tilt Brings the Crowd Along for the Ride
description: People who have seen the French-Canadian band Duchess Says  and in the United States there still arent that many  generally remember physical contact with its singer, Annie-Claude Deschnes. She steps off the stage, or gets down from it somehow, crouching and sitting and sliding and rolling. Then she engages.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Adventure as a Cure for Ailing Love Lives
description: STRATFORD, Ontario  It may take a little while for audiences to stop waiting for the band to strike up during The Matchmaker, the 1954 farce by Thornton Wilder that has been given a rare and loving revival at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival. Wilders confectionary comedy was the most popular of his plays on Broadway, where the original production ran for more than a year. But the fame of The Matchmaker has since been eclipsed both by the enduring greatness of Wilders two masterworks, Our Town and The Skin of Our Teeth  each a Pulitzer Prize winner  and by the huge commercial success and undeniable charm of the musical version of the play, Hello, Dolly!

title: Snooki Is a Mom
description: Nicole Polizzi, below, the star of MTVs Jersey Shore who is better known as Snooki, gave birth to her first child, Lorenzo Dominic, on Sunday at a hospital in Livingston, N.J., according to MTV. Ms. Polizzi and her fianc, Jionni LaValle, announced their engagement and the pregnancy last March, and the development became a focal point in the first season of the Jersey Shore spinoff Snooki & JWoww. Cameras followed the couple and Jennifer Farley, known as Jwow, to an ultrasound, and Ms. Polizzi appeared to give up the hard-partying ways that made her one of the most popular personalities in reality programming. MTV said that the last few months of Ms. Polizzis pregnancy would be featured in the sixth season of Jersey Shore, which has its premiere in October.

title: Bullpen Rescues Garcia to Seal Yankees Win
description: CLEVELAND  Danger lurked everywhere during the Yankees six-game Midwestern trip.

title: Writer Finds Her Niche in Dark Themes
description: DUBLIN  The identity of the murderer in Tana Frenchs thriller Broken Harbor is concealed, of course, until the end. But in some ways the killer is there all along, in the form not of a person but of a house  a malevolent family house rotting in a half-empty development begun in the Irish boom in the 2000s and all but abandoned in the subsequent crash.

title: Midnight Movies at New York Festival
description: For the first time in its 50-year history the New York Film Festival has created a Midnight Movies sidebar that will celebrate genre films, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The three chosen films to be screened during the festival, which starts on Sept. 28 and runs through Oct. 14 at Lincoln Center, are The Bay by Barry Levinson, about a deadly parasite outbreak; Takeshi Kitanos yakuza action film Outrage Beyond (with Beat Takeshi, above); and Peter Stricklands film within a film, Berberian Sound Studio. The center also said Friday that it would host a two-day conference, NYFF Convergence, with panels and workshops devoted to transmedia, a form of storytelling that uses multiple digital platforms. It is to be held Sept. 29 and 30 at the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center.

title: A Composition Fit for a Prince (and a Finale)
description: Summers seem to fly by faster than they used to, but if you are in denial about whether this one is about to end, you need only have stopped at Lincoln Center early on Saturday evening. The plaza was packed with listeners facing the Metropolitan Opera House, where The Enchanted Island  the opening installment of the Mets summer-closing HD Festival  was about to be shown on a large, flat-screen monitor. And inside Avery Fisher Hall the musicians of the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra were filing onstage to play the festivals closing concert  as sure a sign as any that the seasons days are numbered.

title: CNN Looks for a Boost From HBO Shows
description: In a bit of corporate synergy, Time Warner is planning to dip into one of its strongest cable channels, HBO, to help revive the fortunes of one of its weakest, CNN.

title: Where the Fringe, the Post-Fringe and the Anti-Fringe Gather
description: EDINBURGH  Bring together a group of theater types who all run Fringe festivals  those hand-to-mouth celebrations of artistic experimentation and DIY scrappiness  and youre bound to get differences of opinion. And so it went at the inaugural World Fringe Congress here, which drew 47 festival leaders from Amsterdam, Avignon, St. Louis, Taipei, New Delhi and other cities.

title: Casting Developments for Spinoff of The Office
description: With last weeks news that NBCs long-running sitcom The Office will end after the coming season, the network has moved forward with casting choices for the pilot of a planned spinoff called The Farm, starring Rainn Wilson as Dwight Schrute. According to Entertainment Weeklys Web site, Majandra Delfino (Roswell), Thomas Middleditch (The Campaign) and Matt Jones (Breaking Bad) have been tapped to portray members of the Schrute clan at the familys beet farm and bed-and-breakfast. No premiere date has been set.

title: While Front Office Addresses the Future, the Mets Enjoy an All-Too-Rare Moment
description: Here was their chance to interrogate a few of the men responsible for the Mets latest collapse. The manager, Terry Collins, and general manager, Sandy Alderson, entertained questions from about 1,500 season-ticket holders for about an hour Sunday morning at Citi Field, as did Mike Baxter, Jon Niese and the third base coach Tim Teufel.

title: Times Agrees to Sell About to Dillers IAC
description: The New York Times Company has agreed to sell the About Group, which includes the About.com network of topic sites, to Barry Dillers IAC/InterActiveCorp for about $300 million in cash, the company said on Sunday.

title: August in New York, Time to Honor an Eternal Spirit
description: There comes a moment during all the Charlie Parker Jazz Festivals I have seen in Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem when the crowd decides it is truly happy, and pockets of excitement form like chemical reactions onstage and in the audience. The crowd tends to be middle-aged or older  wise, skeptical, funny, good at staging an outburst.

title: After Long Pursuit, Hertz to Buy Dollar Thrifty for $2.3 Billion
description: 10:52 p.m. | Updated

title: English Women Win at World Mind Sports Games
description: LILLE, France  In the Womens Teams final at the Second World Mind Sports Games here last week, England defeated Russia by 69 international match points. England also won this event four years ago in Beijing with four of the same players: Sally Brock, Nicola Smith, Heather Dhondy and Nevena Senior. This time, the third pair was Fiona Brown and Susan Stockdale.

title: Present at Birth
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  This is Michael Farabaughs third time out in The New York Times, and he offers us a perfectly O.K. puzzle that is a twist on the vowel run theme: instead of the letters being vowel runs, Mr. Farabaugh shows us that we can have our cruciverbal cake and eat it too. This time the entire first words of each theme phrase make up the vowel run.

title: When Visitation Lasts All Summer
description: The last click is the hardest.

title: 2 Band Members in Russia Said to Flee to Avoid Arrest
description: MOSCOW  Two members of the punk collective Pussy Riot who had avoided being arrested for their anti-Kremlin demonstrations have fled Russia, the band announced in an online posting on Sunday.

title: Jimmy Kimmels Move May Seal Fate of Nightline
description: Jimmy Kimmels ascent to the main stage of late-night television  the hour directly after the 11 p.m. local news  was greeted last week with widespread congratulations for a performer who had paid his dues and for a network willing to shake up the late-night status quo and bet on a comedic challenger to David Letterman and Jay Leno.

title: The Guardian Backtracks From a Bold Move in Hiring
description: ON Thursday afternoon, the conservative commentator Joshua Trevio was in an expansive mood  he had just begun as a columnist for the United States Web site of the esteemed liberal newspaper The Guardian.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the Standard & Poors Case-Shiller home price index for June and consumer confidence for August (Tuesday); second-quarter gross domestic product (revised), pending home sales for July and the Federal Reserves so-called beige book report on current economic conditions (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, and personal income and spending for July (Thursday); the Chicago purchasing managers index for August, the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for August and factory orders for July (Friday).

title: U.S.T.A. Confirms Schedule Change and Reaffirms Commitment to Roof
description: Officials for the United States Open said more definitively than ever Sunday that their main venue, Arthur Ashe Stadium, will one day have a roof.

title: In Canada, the Impact of Americas New Patent Law Is Seen
description: In an article published in Mondays New York Times and available now online, I wrote about a lawsuit that challenges the constitutionality of the nations new patent law, the America Invents Act.

title: Storm Gains Strength Moving Toward Coast
description: TAMPA, Fla.  As Tropical Storm Isaac churned into the Gulf of Mexico on Sunday, South Florida managed to dodge the worst of it. But the fast-moving storm appeared poised to swell into a hurricane and hit land on Wednesday between the Florida Panhandle and New Orleans.

title: Intriguing Habitats, and Careful Discussions of Climate Change
description: BOSTON  Sitting on an artificial mangrove island in the middle of the ray and shark touch tank, Lindsay Jordan, a staff member at the New England Aquarium, explained the rays eating habits as children and their parents trailed fingers through the water. Does anyone know how we touch these animals when we are not at the aquarium? she asked.

title: Volunteers Keep Watch on Protests in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  They appear at the student demonstrations that are once again filling the streets and occupying the schools of Santiago, and at the hospitals and police stations where the fallout lands afterward: small troops of observers in blue or white helmets, armed with notebooks, cameras, voice recorders and gas masks.

title: Egyptian Leader Adds Rivals of West to Syria Plan
description: CAIRO  Staking out a new leadership role for Egypt in the shaken landscape of the Arab uprisings, President Mohamed Morsi is reaching out to Iran and other regional powers in an initiative to halt the escalating violence in Syria.

title: New Arrivals Change the Bills Attitude
description: When the Buffalo Bills torrid start last season culminated in a victory over the New England Patriots in Week 3, General Manager Buddy Nix was conspicuous among the skeptics who correctly predicted his team was not yet good enough to end the N.F.L.s longest playoff drought.

title: 36 Killed in China When Bus Collides With Methanol Tanker
description: HONG KONG  A double-decker sleeper bus plowed into the back of a tanker carrying flammable methanol on an expressway in Yanan in northwestern Chinas Shaanxi Province on Sunday morning, setting off a fire that killed 36 people, including the bus driver, and injured three, the state-controlled media said.

title: Rise in July Electric Bills Confuses Even Con Edison
description: If some New Yorkers were baffled about why their Consolidated Edison bills were so high last month, they are not alone: Even the utility is confused.

title: Her Opponent Stumbles, but a Candidate Still Watches Her Step
description: MARSHALL, Mo.  A political storm is swirling around Senator Claire McCaskills Republican challenger for one of the most coveted seats in the fight to control the United States Senate. But one would not have learned about that here this weekend at Bloomfields Family Restaurant, where Ms. McCaskill campaigned before military veterans and went right on talking about veterans benefits, improvements at Arlington National Cemetery and surveys at military health care facilities.

title: At Summit Meeting, Iran Has a Message for the World
description: TEHRAN  At the entrance to the convention hall where Iran is sponsoring an international summit meeting are the crumpled wreckage of three cars driven by Iranian nuclear scientists who have been killed or hurt in bomb attacks. Placards with the photos of the scientists and their children stand alongside.

title: Seeking Sparkle, Gleam and a Clean Slate
description: The wayfarers come on wheels and on foot, pausing their evenings long enough to bring a little sparkle to their lives, before the city goes about sullying them again.

title: Has Europe Failed?
description: New Haven

title: The Top Three Myths About Myths
description: Baltimore

title: Going Down With Heads Held High
description: GLASGOW  Rangers then, Rangers now, Rangers forever, shouted the Scottish soccer clubs new owner, Charles Green, in front of almost 50,000 fans on hand for the teams home opener Aug. 18. Today is just the start of the journey, he went on defiantly.

title: As Restaurants Cut Salt, Some See Reasons to Pass
description: It was a slightly curious gesture: last week, Boston Market, the national chain of rotisserie chicken restaurants, removed the salt shakers from its tables, replacing them with small placards  tucked next to the pepper shakers  promoting the companys interest in reducing sodium.

title: Older Residents and Bikes
Struggling With Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: Should the United States Export Natural Gas?
description: To the Editor:

title: Staying Cool in the Developing World
description: To the Editor:

title: 140 Passengers Stranded Aboard Trains to J.F.K.
description: About 140 rail passengers heading to or from Kennedy International Airport were stranded for hours on Saturday evening and had to walk beside the tracks to the nearest station, after a computer malfunction caused the AirTrain system to shut down. The trains run on an elevated platform high over the Van Wyck Expressway in Queens.

title: Apple Case Muddies the Future of Innovations
description: Apples victory on Friday in a patent lawsuit against Samsung could, if upheld, give its rivals a kick in the pants to create more original products.

title: Vande Velde Captures the USA Pro Challenge and Stalls a Youth Movement
description: DENVER  The young guns of American cycling will have to wait another year. The old guard is not quite ready to step aside just yet.

title: Steep Climb to Fahrenheit 9/11, but Anti-Obama Film Is a Hit
description: LOS ANGELES  Love it or loathe it, 2016: Obamas America  the director Dinesh DSouzas documentary critique of Barack Obamas policies and ideological roots  has arrived as a box-office event.

title: U.S. Open Preview: Andy Murray Managing the Olympic Aftermath
description: Throughout the United States Open, Andy Murray will be sharing his observations on his matches and his time in New York on Straight Sets. It has already been a memorable summer for Murray, who endured a heartbreaking loss in the Wimbledon final and then won the Olympic gold medal at the All England Club. Murray, the No. 3 seed, opens his United States Open on Monday against Alex Bogomolov Jr. in the second match at Arthur Ashe Stadium.

title: The Last Bipartisan
description: WHEN I first encountered Ron Wyden in 1974, he was setting up the Oregon outpost of the Gray Panthers, a lobby group founded by the liberal activist Maggie Kuhn with a broad agenda but an emphasis on empowering the elderly. Wyden, who was 25, seemed improbably boyish to be a champion of senior citizens. But he radiated a winning, wonky exuberance. He was clearly bound for a life in politics. He won an insurgent campaign for a House seat in 1980, graduated to the Senate in 1996  and now, at age 63, has spent almost exactly half his life on Capitol Hill.

title: The Comeback Skid
description: There will be two big stars at the Republican National Convention, and neither of them will be Mitt Romney. One will, of course, be Paul Ryan, Mr. Romneys running mate. The other will be Chris Christie, the governor of New Jersey, who will give the keynote address. And while the two men could hardly look or sound more different, they are brothers under the skin.

title: Westside Highway Car Wash
description: A neon sign calls to all those seeking to free themselves from the grime of the city, even if it lasts only a few minutes.

title: These Days, Its Back to School, Then Shopping
description: Samantha Paradise is starting eighth grade in Manhattan next week, but she wont be decked out in all new gear on the first day.

title: Rejuvenation at the Barclays, and Maybe a Ryder Cup Spot
description: FARMINGDALE, N.Y.  Another week, another lost player found his way back to the winners circle. Welcome to golfs great summer revival, a traveling exhibition of born-again careers. On Sunday, Nick Watney became the latest prodigal putter when he closed with a two-under-par 69 at the Black Course at Bethpage State Park for a 72-hole total of 10-under 274 for a three-stroke victory over Brandt Snedeker at the Barclays, the opening leg of the PGA Tours FedEx Cup playoffs.

title: These Cool Mornings
description: The temperature now drops into the 50s every night. The grass is heavy with dew in the mornings, and when the low sun shines through the seed heads of the grasses, it looks like a ground mist hanging over the pasture.

title: Fertility Services for Veterans
description: One of the unexpected and little-noted consequences of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan has been an increase in the number of service members whose battlefield wounds leave them unable to have children. One apparent reason is the type of combat: when troops on foot patrols are struck by improvised bombs, they are particularly vulnerable to pelvic injuries that damage their reproductive systems. Military records show that since 2003, more than 1,800 service members in those wars  the majority of them Army troops  have suffered such wounds.

title: The Amtrak Option
description: Helped by the high cost of gasoline and airline tickets, Amtrak is doing very well. The railroad recently announced that when given a choice between air or rail, three-quarters of travelers between New York and Washington take the train. Between New York and Boston, more than half prefer the rails. One of the biggest impediments to further growth is the pair of 100-year-old tunnels under the Hudson River  one going in each direction between New Jersey and New York City. The tunnels operate at capacity, creating a bottleneck that will only grow worse as the metropolitan areas population grows. Its obviously time for a new tunnel complex.

title: Lottery Numbers
Storm Rewrites G.O.P.s Script for Convention
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The prospect of a major storm blowing through the Gulf of Mexico toward New Orleans upset the tight choreography of the Republican convention on Sunday, straining the partys highly scripted plans for showcasing Mitt Romney and raising the possibility that news media attention could shift elsewhere.

title: Compared With Cubs, White Sox Cant Win for Winning
description: CHICAGO  The first-place White Sox, in the thick of a pennant race, hosted the Seattle Mariners at U.S. Cellular Field on Saturday on a gorgeous 86-degree evening. A crowd announced at 27,562 was on hand as the home team won, 5-4. Earlier in the day, eight miles north at Wrigley Field, a crowd announced as 35,296 watched the fifth-place Cubs lose to the equally bad Colorado Rockies.

title: Beyond Self-Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: For G.O.P. Congressmen in Arizona, a Fierce Primary in a Redrawn District
description: PHOENIX  The news, emerging as his campaign hit the homestretch, landed like a gift to Representative David Schweikert, a Republican who is locked in a feisty primary fight against Representative Ben Quayle: a Congressional fact-finding trip to Israel last year, drinks by the Sea of Galilee and a dip in its waters by inebriated lawmakers, one of whom stripped off his clothes.

title: In Small Town Hit by a Storm, Hope, Despair and a Mudfest
description: PRATTSVILLE, N.Y.  One house on Main Street here is not like the others. It seems to twist, stretch and taunt the fine line between hope and despair that has inextricably woven itself into the town fabric over the past year.

title: Paul Ryans Social Extremism
description: Mitt Romney, who will be officially nominated this week as the Republican nominee for president, appears to trim his social convictions to the partys prevailing winds. There is no doubt, however, about where the partys vice-presidential candidate stands. A long history of social extremism makes Paul Ryan an emblem of the Republican tack to the far right.

title: Do Party Conventions Matter Anymore?
Fires Still Burning in Aftermath of Deadly Venezuela Blast
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Scenes of destruction extended for blocks through the working-class neighborhood near the Amuay oil refinery on Sunday, as firefighters struggled to control blazes still burning in the plants huge fuel storage tanks after an explosion early Saturday that has killed at least 41 people.

title: U.S. Open Preview: Should Women Play Five Sets, or Should Men Play Three?
description: As part of the Build Your Dream Open feature in The Times United States Open preview, the Straight Sets contributors Ray Krueger and Ben Rothenberg engaged in a point/counterpoint.

title: Aug. 26: Little Momentum in Polls in Advance of Conventions
description: The FiveThirtyEight forecast for Sunday gives Barack Obama a 69.4 percent chance of winning the Electoral College on Nov. 6. Thats essentially unchanged from Saturday  although there have been some modest shifts back and forth in the numbers over the course of the past two weeks since Mitt Romney named Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin as his vice-presidential nominee.

title: A Regulators Key Role in Failed Mutual Fund Reform
description: Luis A. Aguilar, one of five members of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is generally known as one of its strongest advocates for tougher oversight of the securities industry. In public statements this year, he has pushed his S.E.C. colleagues to be more aggressive, contending that the commission was not protecting investors assiduously enough.

title: Corrections: August 27, 2012
description: NATIONAL

title: A Party of Factions Gathers, Seeking Consensus
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Mitt Romney arrives here this week to accept his nomination from the increasingly disparate coalition of factions known as the Republican Party, confronting the challenge of unifying them behind him and  should he win  exerting his own authority over a party that is in many ways still forging a post-Bush identity.

title: An End to a Career, Where It Flourished
description: After her latest last, her final news conference before her final Grand Slam tournament, Kim Clijsters retreated to the players lawn at the United States Open. Three children sat beside her. She gripped two tennis balls. They held Rice Krispies treats.

title: Gun Country
description: How do those who buy, sell and love guns come to terms with mass shootings? Meet the people at the Firing Line in Aurora, Colo.

title: Herman Cain Gives a Fiery Speech to Tea Party  Rally in Tampa

Far from the official convention grounds, at an alternate unity rally in a church made up mostly of Tea Party supporters, the former presidential hopeful Herman Cain gave a keynote speech to a roaring crowd of several hundred, explaining why he had come to Florida: Im still on a mission to defeat Barack Obama!

title: Crashing the Party

title: U.S. Open Preview: Players Dream Open Has Clear Skies and Clear Roads
description: In June, the U.S.T.A. announced an ambitious renovation plan for the National Tennis Center, which included a new Louis Armstrong Stadium and a new Grandstand Court. Players and fans have their own ideas about what the U.S. Open of their dreams would include.

title: Before Gunfire, Hints of Bad News
description: AURORA, Colo.  The text message, sent to another graduate student in early July, was cryptic and worrisome. Had she heard of dysphoric mania, James Eagan Holmes wanted to know?

title: A Law to Expose City Parks Inequalities Is Neglected
description: Four years ago, the City Council passed a law to shed light on how much money was flowing into different parks across the city. Advocates were concerned that the parks system was splitting in two: in wealthy areas of the city, gleaming, innovative green spaces, buttressed by private financing sources; elsewhere, ailing parks with far fewer resources at their disposal.

title: Arming the World
description: Last year, the United States surged far ahead of other countries as a weapons supplier, particularly to the developing world.

title: U.S. Open Preview: The Skys the Limit in Building Your Dream U.S. Open
description: In June, the U.S.T.A. announced  an ambitious renovation plan for the National Tennis Center. It included a new Louis Armstrong Stadium, a new Grandstand Court, a viewing pavilion for practice courts, expanded walkways and more. (It did not include a roof. Yet. The U.S.T.A. said Sunday that one was coming. Eventually.) Those arent the only changes coming at the Open. David Brewer has replaced Jim Curley as tournament director. The U.S.T.A. has committed to giving mens singles players a day of rest between the semifinals and final, perhaps ending the Super Saturday tradition.

title: Paul Makes Sure His Voice Is Heard in Tampa
description: TAMPA, Fla.  In a speech that was part motivational, part valedictory and at every opportunity critical of the mainstream Republican Party on the eve of its convention here this week, Representative Ron Paul declared his liberty movement alive and well on Sunday before a crowd of nearly 10,000 supporters who were eager to testify to that claim.

title: R. Palmer Beasley, Expert on Hepatitis B, Dies at 76
description: Dr. R. Palmer Beasley, an epidemiologist who discovered that hepatitis B is easily transferred from mothers to infants during childbirth, confirmed the role of the virus in causing liver cancer and saved millions of lives by helping to persuade world health officials to include a vaccine for the virus in its global recommendations for immunizations, died on Saturday at his home in Houston. He was 76.

title: Obama on the Campaign Trail
description: Campaigning in Ohio and Nevada last week, President Obama promoted his record on education.

title: Jets Continue to Have Problems Finding Consistency and the End Zone
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Before practice Wednesday, Jets Coach Rex Ryan addressed an occasional reality in the N.F.L.: what happens when one unit of a team may just be a lot better than the other?

title: Romney on the Trail
description: Mitt Romney campaigns in his home state of Michigan.

title: Terry Tracy, Model for the Big Kahuna, Dies at 77
description: Terry Tracy, who as an easygoing, fun-loving surfer inspired the Gidget movies and television series and helped make surfing an international sport  in the process becoming the embodiment of the cool alternative lifestyle of sunglass-wearing beach bums  died on Wednesday at his home in San Clemente, Calif. He was 77.

title: Word of the Day | saturate
description: saturate \sa-ch-rat\ verb

title: Prints Regent
description: The Scottish designer Jonathan Saunders loves splashing color and prints across his womens wear, but for his mens collection he toned it down. With women, I think about how to configure prints on a female body, he says. For men, my approach is about the combination of textures and patterns in a more architectural and functional way. He drew from the designs of Le Corbusier and Charlotte Perriand for the collection, which features waffle jacquard coats, sporty wool mlange suits and graphic printed shirts. The idea, Saunders says, was to create clothes that are casual and not overly formal or sharp. Available at matchesfashion.com.

title: A Scorecard Filled With Scholarships
description: KIAWAH ISLAND, S.C.  Wesley Bauguess still chokes up every time she tells the story of how her husband, Army Maj. Larry Bauguess, died at 36 during efforts to settle a border dispute. It was May 14, 2007, and her husband was participating in a peace meeting involving United States, Afghanistan and Pakistan forces in a tribal region of Pakistan. By all accounts, the meeting was successful. The participants shook hands, posed for photographs and exchanged coins.

title: Benefits of Circumcision Are Said to Outweigh Risks
description: The American Academy of Pediatrics has shifted its stance on infant male circumcision, announcing on Monday that new research, including studies in Africa suggesting that the procedure may protect heterosexual men against H.I.V., indicated that the health benefits outweighed the risks.

title: Endowments Grow From Chalkboards to the Sidelines
description: Joel Smilow, a former chairman and chief executive of Playtex, is a philanthropist whose name is attached to hospitals, Boys and Girls Clubs, and buildings at Yale, his alma mater.

title: Quietly Confident, Michigans Leader Has Promise to Keep
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  Timothy Robinson sat on his grandmothers couch, not looking well. Timothy, 11, was home from school with a stomachache, though it had always been difficult to tell if he was hurting. He was tough, and Denard  the shorter, younger brother  thought the world of him for that.

title: Relaxed and Loose, Candidate Obama Hits His Mark
description: BEXLEY, Ohio  During his three-minute chat on Tuesday with the man introducing him to 3,300 supporters at a campaign rally here, President Obama achieved four must-dos in every politicians instruction manual.

title: DC Comics Unveils New Power Couple
description: Do you ever feel alone? Of course I ... do. And with that exchange, Wonder Woman and Superman embrace and kiss in issue No. 12 of Justice League, published by DC Comics, which is to be available in comics stores on Wednesday. The cover of that issue  featuring the two heroes in flight canoodling  got comic book fans talking when it was released last week. Those strong reactions, good and bad, were exactly the goal of Geoff Johns, the writer of Justice League, and Jim Lee, the books artist. In 2011 Mr. Lee was named co-publisher at DC Comics along with Dan DiDio, and Mr. Johns was named chief creative officer of DC Entertainment. In an interview they said that the Superman-Wonder Woman romance had been one of the most exciting elements they had conceived of when DCs heroes were given a reboot last fall. When we thought about relaunching the entire DC universe, we considered not what we were going to remove, but what we could add to the mythology, Mr. Lee said. Mr. Johns said the romance and how it affects the characters, their teammates and their supporting casts will affect the DC universe for years. Fans with longer memories will recall that in 1986, after a previous reboot, Superman and Wonder Woman had another flirtation but eventually decided they were not right for each other. That version of Superman eventually revealed his identity to Lois Lane. He proposed to her, and they were married. And that version of Wonder Woman later caught the eye of Aquaman and Batman.

description: The Republican ticket is flooding the airwaves with commercials that develop two themes designed to turn the presidential contest into a racially freighted resource competition pitting middle class white voters against the minority poor.

The report alleges that the government lost out on nearly $34 billion in revenues by selling coal assets in private negotiations, rather than auctioning them. The prime minister and other central government officials dispute this figure.

Many assume all gay people will first be confused about their sexuality, figure out theyre gay, accept that they are and finally, take pride in it. But for many gay men, including the photographer Alan Charlesworth, theres another step of confusion thrown into the mix.

The lights have come on inside, some treetops are visible along the arenas edge, and some bright blue signage has gone up along the buildings facade, an undulating shell of brownish steel.

title: With Isaac Bearing Down, Networks Weigh Their Options

But theres also a political convention beginning in Tampa, Fla., representing the start of a two-month sprint to Election Day. Where do you send the symbols of your news division, your news anchors?

title: Key Dates Between Now and Election Day
description: President Obama and Mitt Romney have 71 days of campaigning from Monday until the election. The closing chapter of the race will be highlighted by a handful of marquee events that could change the dynamic of the contest. The political conventions will give way to a burst of campaigning in September, followed by the closely watched debates in October. While the election is not until Nov. 6, tens of millions of voters will not wait. Early voting begins in less than a month in Iowa, and four years ago, 88 percent of the electorate in the battleground state of Colorado cast their ballots before Election Day.

title: Summer Fruit Galettes
description: As long as there are still peaches, plums, apricots, berries and nectarines to be had, Im buying them up and making pies and galettes. A galette is a free-form pie, more rustic than a tart. Although theyre usually made with classic buttery pie dough or puff pastry, Ive been working at developing a dough recipe that is delicate and tasty but not too rich. I decided that a yeasted dough could work, and came up with a formula that yields enough for two galettes but has only 60 grams of butter (about 4 tablespoons). The flavor is nutty and rich because of the whole-wheat flour, but the dough isnt heavy. The trick is to roll it very thin, then freeze it right away so that it doesnt continue to rise and become too bready, and also so that its easy to work with when you are ready to assemble the tart. The dough works beautifully for these free-form galettes.

title: Vain Glorious | The Andy Warhol Collection From Nars
description: Andy Warhol once proclaimed that an artist is somebody who produces things that people dont need to have, a statement exemplified by his namesake foundation, which, in recent years, has allowed the artists work to be paired with everything from retail marketing initiatives (Barneys) to limited-edition luxury goods, ranging from accessories (Philip Treacy) to wine (Dom Perignon) and even skateboards (Alien Workshop). Noticeably missing from the portfolio, however, has been a beauty collaboration. Enter the Nars autumn/winter 2012 color collection.

title: Nip and Tuck?
description: TEL AVIV  It appears Judaism is under attack in Western Europe. Following a ruling by a local German court this spring that banned circumcisions for infringing a childs fundamental right to bodily integrity, a criminal complaint was filed last week against a rabbi [paid content] in Germany for performing that sacred Jewish ritual. It still isnt clear whether the complaint should have been pursued at all  the ruling and the rabbi depend on different jurisdictions. But this attack on freedom of religious practice has already sparked quite a bit of outrage.

title: When the Mango Bites Back
description: NEW DELHI  Accepting a just-picked mango from a stranger in Lodi Gardens and then putting it directly into my mouth  skin and all  was stupid. I admit that.

title: Giants Place Canty and Beckum on PUP List

title: Occupy Hong Kong Holdouts Defy Order to Leave Despite Effort by HSBC
description: HONG KONG  Occupy Wall Street and the movements it inspired in cities around the world last autumn have largely disappeared, brushed aside by battalions of police officers, but a handful of activists still cling to a site in the heart of Hong Kongs central financial district, and on Monday evening they defied a court-imposed deadline for them to leave.

title: A Youthful Populace Helps Make the Philippines an Economic Bright Spot in Asia
description: MANILA  In the upscale business district of Manila, a midweek crowd spills out into the street. The New York-themed Borough restaurant is pulsating to the beat of a Bon Jovi song, while young, hip Filipinos take shots of tequila from a passing tray and sing in unison.

title: Washington in Disarray
description: Capt. Charles Francis Adams Jr., grandson and great-grandson of presidents and son of the current minister to Britain, arrived in Washington on Aug. 27, 1862. His regiment, the 1st Massachusetts Cavalry, had been hastily snatched from its operations on the South Carolina coast and shipped north to meet the emergency created by Gen. Robert E. Lees stunning counteroffensive after the failure of the Unions Peninsula campaign. Adams knew the capital city well, and was appalled by its atmosphere of treason, jealousy, and dissension  more than usual, given the recriminations pouring forth as federal forces retreated.

title: The Foreign Terrain Where We Travel Each Night
description: You may dye your gray hairs and Botox your wrinkles, but you will never sleep the sleep of your youth again. Not without serious illness or a powerful blow to the brain, that is. One of the many underappreciated facts David K. Randall puts forth in his perfectly paced tour of the subject is that adults are insomniacs because nature made them that way.
