description: Life has a habit of turning up in the most unlikely of places. Geysers, desert cliffs, even heaps of dung are environments that at least a few creatures call home.

title: Mitt Romney As James K. Polk?
description: In one of the stranger stories circulating on eve of the rain-delayed Republican convention, sources in Romneyland have invoked a highly unusual model for their hoped-for adminstration: The 11th president of the United States, James Knox Polk. From the Huffington Posts Jon Ward:

title: When the Vice Presidency Was a Job for New Yorkers
description: If Virginia used to be the mother of presidents, as schoolchildren there were taught for generations, New York used to be the mother of vice presidents. But what happened in the 20th century? There has not been an elected vice president from New York in nearly 100 years.

title: What Do Democrats and Republicans Agree On?
description: In the next two weeks, during the Republican and Democratic conventions, well hear a lot about the differences between the parties. How great we are. How terrible the other guy is. How were better on Medicare, on Social Security, on foreign policy, on defense, on education, on taxes. How theyre awful in policy realms you never even thought of.

title: Stosur Beats Rain and Her First Opponent
description: With the first storm clouds of the United States Open bearing down on the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center on Monday, the biggest challenge for the defending champion Samantha Stosur of Australia was whether she could polish off Petra Martic of Croatia before the raindrops arrived.

title: The Dirty Little Secret of Nursing Homes
description: This sounds like common sense: If you work in a nursing home, you wash your hands when you start your shift and again before you leave. You wash your hands (or, in some cases, use an alcohol-based antimicrobial) before and after any direct contact with residents. Before you help someone with tooth-brushing, bathing, eating or using the toilet. Before and after handling a catheter or taking a finger-stick blood sample or changing a dressing. Or handling used bed linens. Or blowing your own nose.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Acsys Interactive, Farmington, Conn., was renamed Primacy. The agency will continue to use the Acsys brand on products.

title: In the Bay Area, Renting Electric BMWs by the Half Hour
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  A BMW 1 Series costs more than $30,000. But for the price of a few gallons of gas, Bay Area residents can zip around in a purely electric version of the compact coupe using DriveNow, a electric-car-sharing service from the German automaker.

title: Science Times Podcast
description: Medical overtreatment; pit vipers; and guidelines for bone-density screening.

title: As Isaac Approaches, Jindal Cancels Convention Speech
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The prime-time Republican National Convention speech of Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana has become another casualty of Tropical Storm Isaac.

title: Bermudas New Pitch Is Short: So Much More
description: A popular vacation destination is trying again to encourage tourists to expect the unexpected, as well as all that visitors have traditionally traveled there for.

title: Dont Let the Original Price Haunt Your Decision to Sell
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

title: Farewell, Count von Count
description: Teaching is a collaborative art. When I stand in front of my classroom and explain the magic of a Dickens metaphor, I conjure up the voice of my sixth-grade teacher, Mr. Akeley. When I describe the heroic journey of King Arthur, I hear Don Cannons words in my ear. But when I count? Well, thats my favorite voice, a Transylvanian chant of numerical mirth:

title: Motown: The Musical Announces Broadway Opening Date and Lead Cast
description: Brandon Victor Dixon will play Berry Gordy Jr. and Valisia LeKae will play Diana Ross when Motown: The Musical opens on Broadway in April, the producers announced on Monday.

title: Fruitful Flowers
description: Q. Why do some of my roses simply wither while some blooms morph into rose hips?

title: Goldman Executive Is Said to Buy $27 Million Luxury Apartment
description: It is an apartment fit for a king, or, perhaps, a Goldman Sachs chief executive.

title: Photo Replay: Aug. 27
description: A view of the day in sports included handball in Doha, Qatar, and preparations for the Paralympics in London.

title: Curtis Sittenfelds Summer Fiction Series
description: Three months of very, very short stories.

title: NBC Searches for New Normal Home in Salt Lake City
description: When the NBC television affiliate in Salt Lake City decided against showing The New Normal, a sitcom about a gay couple adopting a baby, network executives were not surprised. That station, KSL-TV, which is owned by a subsidiary of the Mormon Church, has a long history of steering clear of NBC programs it deems of questionable content. Last fall it blocked the NBC drama The Playboy Club and for years it has refused to carry one of the pillars of NBC entertainment, Saturday Night Live. It also blocked a previous NBC comedy considered too racy, the short-lived Coupling.

title: Learning Doesnt Stop When Youre Asleep
description: People can learn new associations between scents and sounds in their sleep, according to a new study in the journal Nature Neuroscience.

title: At Souvenir Stands, Selling Tourists on Ending Stop-and-Search
description: Last week, a 37-year-old artist from Oakland, Calif., named Aaron Gach joined the crowds of tourists swarming the sidewalk souvenir stands set up around the perimeter of Battery Park in Lower Manhattan.

title: Drug-Resistant Bacteria Is Found in Chimpanzees
description: Chimpanzees in African sanctuaries harbor human strains of the bacterium Staphylococcus aureus, according to a new paper in The American Journal of Primatology.

title: Satellites Show Sea Ice in Arctic Is at a Record Low
description: The amount of sea ice in the Arctic has fallen to the lowest level on record, a confirmation of the drastic warming in the region and a likely harbinger of larger changes to come.

title: How Video Games Could Improve Our Vision
description: The developmental psychologist Daphne Maurer made headlines this year with research suggesting that people born with cataracts could improve their eyesight by playing Medal of Honor, the first-person shooter video game. But her fame goes far beyond the video screen.

title: The Story Behind My Very, Very Short Stories
description: Certain writers (Ernest Hemingway, Lydia Davis) are  among their other literary talents  considered masters of the form known as flash fiction. Im not. In fact, my last novel clocked in at 555 pages. Even so, because it sounded fun, I agreed last spring to write a bunch of really short stories for the One-Page Magazine. I knew that their appearance might perplex readers (fiction in The New York Times?), so my editor and I agreed that each one would run with the label Summer Fiction Series. Confusion nevertheless ensued.

title: Last-Minute Labor Day | One-for-All Weekenders
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Open Tickets Are in Demand
description: The economy may be sluggish, but demand for tickets at the U.S. Open remains strong. The average price of tickets for resale are up 7.6 percent this year compared to the same time last year, and 49 percent higher than in 2010.

title: The Caucus Click: Get Your Souvenirs Here
description: Want to buy a Mitt Romney T-shirt? Or a hat? Or anything else with Mitt Romneys name on it? Delegates to the Republican National Convention can find it all at a pop-up store on the third level of the convention hall.

title: Whole Fish Baked in Salt Crust From le de R
description: Adapted from Daniel Mass, Le Chat Bott, St-Clment-des-Baleines, France

title: Overtreatment Is Taking a Harmful Toll
description: When it comes to medical care, many patients and doctors believe more is better.

title: Monday Motorsports: Denny Hamlin Wins, as Sprint Cup Chase Takes Shape
description: After passing forgettable summers, early front-runners of this 2012 Nascar Sprint Cup season are reestablishing their dominance. And with just two races before the chase, the series de facto postseason, begins, the late surge is well timed.

title: Salt Harvesting in France
description: On le de R off the west coast of France, the most famous agricultural product is salt.

title: The Deciders
description: Meet voters living in the most hotly contested states in the 2012 election.

title: More Than One Kind of Partner for a Supernova
description: When a white dwarf star gets too big after absorbing material from another nearby star, it explodes, sending a burst of light out into the universe in what is called a Type 1a supernova.

title: Deal for About.com Fits Dillers Strategy
description: Barry Diller has a new toy.

title: Shooting Reported on First Day of School in Maryland
description: The Associated Press is reporting that one student has been shot, and another taken into custody on the first day of classes at a Baltimore County high school. The Huffington Post reports an ominous Facebook post that preceded the shooting, and local news station WJZ-TV says police and students describe teachers as tackling the shooter as he fired the first shot.

title: The West Side Tennis Club Then (1977) and Now
description: When we were looking for pictures to accompany Michael Steinbergers story about the U.S. Open in 1977  the last year the tournament was held at the West Side Tennis Club in Queens  we went to the photographer Russ Adams, who was there. His shot of Guillermo Vilas on the shoulders of fans after his championship win over Jimmy Connors opens the story.

title: Magic Measured in a Pile of Salt
description: LE DE R, France

title: Apple Seeks Order Blocking Sale of Samsung Products
description: 4:16 p.m. | Updated  Adding background and commentary.

title: Consumer Bureau Shuffles Staff
description: The nations consumer financial watchdog shuffled its staff on Monday as a top official departed for the private sector.

title: President of Myanmar Reshuffles His Cabinet
description: BANGKOK  President Thein Sein of Myanmar announced a major cabinet reshuffle on Monday that appeared to centralize the power of his office, put his closest allies in key positions and sideline at least one hard-line minister left over from the days of military rule.

title: The U.S. Open Chronicles: No More Tennis Ghost Town
description: Irina Falconi, who will be playing at the United States Open this year, will write posts throughout the tournament for Straight Sets. She has her own tumblr page, and can be followed on Twitter.Ive been thinking about a solid introduction to my first New York Times blog all morning but havent really found something that has stuck. But the thing about being a creative/abstract/silly writer  you have options. Options are good. O.K., I hope you enjoyed that intro.

title: Early Marijuana Use Linked to I.Q. Loss
description: People in a study who began smoking marijuana as teenagers and continued to use it heavily for decades lost a few I.Q. points along the way, while those who started in adulthood did not, researchers reported on Monday.

title: Voucherizing Medicare
description: So there it is: the draft Republican platform says of Medicare and Medicaid,

title: March on the R.N.C.
description: TAMPA, Fla.  When James Ingle of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers took the stage at this mornings March on the R.N.C. protest, he paraphrased Dwight Eisenhowers 1953 Chance for Peace address. Every dollar spent on the military is a dollar not spent on the poor, he said. Eisenhowers exact words on the opportunity cost of defense spending were: Every gun that is made, every warship launched, every rocket fired signifies, in the final sense, a theft from those who hunger and are not fed, those who are cold and are not clothed. This world in arms is not spending money alone.

title: M.T.A. Seeks $65 Million for Cost of Tropical Storm Irene Last Year
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said Monday that it had submitted claims to recover $65 million in losses resulting from Tropical Storm Irene, whicha year ago felled trees onto the tracks of its commuter rails, flooded train yards and prompted an unprecedented pre-emptive subway shutdown.

title: Infant Antibiotics Linked With Heavier Weight
description: Young farm animals given antibiotics gain weight quickly. Now a new study suggests that the same thing may happen to human infants treated with antibiotics.

title: German at European Central Bank at Odds With Countrys Policy Makers
description: FRANKFURT  A top German official at the European Central Bank on Monday defended the banks plans to intervene in bond markets to push down borrowing costs for businesses and encourage economic growth. The position puts him at odds with the president of Germanys central bank and highlights a growing split in the countrys policy-making elite.

title: Factor in Breast Milk May Cut H.I.V. Spread
description: A substance in human breast milk seems to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission of H.I.V., scientists have reported.

title: Changing Our Tune on Exercise
description: What would it take to persuade you to exercise?

title: Notes From the Recipe Tester: A Whole Fish for Two
description: Denise Landis has been testing recipes for The New York Times for more than 20 years. She is also the author of Dinner for Eight: 40 Great Dinner Party Menus for Friends and Family. Here, she offers tips for making one of this weeks Dining recipes.

title: Before the Convention, a Hometown Rally for Ryan
description: JANESVILLE, Wis.  Here where the first sparks of his political career were struck with his election as class president, Representative Paul D. Ryan returned for a boisterous rally at Joseph A. Craig High School on Monday, before flying to the Republican National Convention to accept his partys vice-presidential nomination  a trip now delayed by a day, until Tuesday, because of Tropical Storm Isaac.

title: Designers Set Sail, Turning to Wind to Help Power Cargo Ships
description: If the worlds shipping fleet were a country, it would be the worlds sixth leading emitter of greenhouse gases. To reduce those emissions  and, not incidentally, to conserve expensive fossil fuels  cargo ship designers are now turning to the oldest source of power there is: the wind.

title: After Unpaid Tickets, Singers Van Is Towed and Sold
description: 5:18 p.m. | Updated If you need proof that New York City is serious about parking tickets, talk to Joseph Arthur, the singer-songwriter and painter. The city towed Mr. Arthurs van from outside a Brooklyn garage where it was being repaired, because he said he had failed to pay $361 in parking tickets from earlier this year.

title: U.S. Open Food of the Day: Ouzo Shrimp
description: This is our first installment of a daily food review from the United States Open concession stands.

title: Wealth, Taxes and Public Opinion
description: Last week I wrote about a new Pew Research Center report on the ailing middle class. Today, Pew has come out with a comparable report about the wealthy and how Americans feel about this upper-income class.

title: Really? During a Heart Attack, Dial 911 and Chew an Aspirin
description: THE FACTS

title: In Dollar Thrifty Deal, Hertz Bets Big on Certainty of Closing
description: It took Hertz Global Holdings two years to reach an agreement to buy the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group.

title: New York Film Festival Adds Heavens Gate to Masterworks Lineup
description: Set aside 219 minutes of your life and get ready to stake out a position on one of the more controversial works of contemporary cinema: Heavens Gate is coming to the New York Film Festival. That 1980 Michael Cimino western  which, depending on your perspective, is either an underrated epic that was misunderstood in its day or the overwrought behemoth that brought down an entire motion-picture studio (or possibly both); but definitely features Kris Kristofferson on roller skates  will be presented as part of the festivals Masterworks lineup, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Monday.

title: Health Care Flaws (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Medical Imagings Gains (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Genes and Memory (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: After Deadly Sweep Through Haiti, Tropical Storm Isaac Heads for Gulf Coast
description: Tropical Storm Isaac churned toward the central Gulf Coast of the United States on Monday after a weekend of flooding in southern Florida and destruction in Haiti, where at least 19 people died, according to The Associated Press, from the effects of its violent winds and torrential rains. Another five died in the Dominican Republic, The A.P. said.

title: Stigma of H.I.V. Is a Barrier to Prenatal Care
description: Fear of being stigmatized as an AIDS patient is still a major barrier to good medical care for pregnant young women in many countries, a new study and a literature review have found.

title: The End of the Offline World as We Know It?
description: On Sunday, I wrote a column about re-learning to live in the moment  something that has become a challenge given that I am constantly tuning into the lives of my friends and the people I know though my smartphone and various social networks.

title: To Keep Inventors Flame Bright, Fans Return to His Workshop
description: Nikola Tesla electrified the world with alternating current, then slipped into obscurity, dying penniless in 1943 on the 33rd floor of the New Yorker Hotel in Manhattan. But though his fame was eclipsed by other inventors, he was never forgotten: A hardy band of enthusiasts has long sought to give this eccentric genius his due.

title: TimesCast Politics | August 27, 2 P.M.
description: Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi discusses the weather's impact on the convention. | Rallies and protests outside. | David Firestone of The Times's editorial board on Paul Ryan's social policies.

title: Arctic Sea Ice Hits New and Early Summer Low for Satellite Era
description: 11:44 p.m. | Updates from several scientists below |The planet is warming and the Arctic is warming the most, as long foreseen by scientists in a climate system pushed out of balance through the rapid buildup of heat-trapping greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. One result is greater loss of Arctic sea ice in the annual summer warmup.

title: Best Man, One Man, Two Guvnors Turn a Profit
description: Only a fraction of Broadway musicals ever turn a profit, and even rarer are plays that end up making money for their investors. But in the last week, two did: The producers of the Gore Vidals The Best Man announced on Monday that they had recouped their $3.25 million capitalization costs, a few days after producers of the comedy One Man, Two Guvnors said they had recouped their investment of $3.25 million as well.

title: People Watching | Steve Roden
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Woman, 29, Found Fatally Injured on Lower East Side
description: Updated, 10:51 p.m. |  A 29-year-old woman was found fatally injured and bleeding from her neck in a stairwell on the Lower East Side on Monday, the police said.

title: Street Style: Afro-Punk Music Festival
description: The eighth annual Afro-Punk Festival took place at Commodore Barry Park in Brooklyn.

title: What Children Really Need for Back to School
description: Looking over summer homework assignments, last-minute shopping for clothes and supplies, and checking classroom placements  these are among the things parents do in the final weeks before their children start school.

title: Schumer Urges Repairs to the Capitol Dome
description: 6:46 p.m. | Updated Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York, citing years of inclement weather, sent a letter to Speaker John A. Boehner on Monday about the severe disrepair plaguing the Capitol dome.

title: Van Cliburn Has Advanced Bone Cancer
description: The pianist Van Cliburn, who famously triumphed at the International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow in 1958, has advanced bone cancer, a spokeswoman said on Monday.

title: Boehner Sees G.O.P. Victory, but Not Necessarily a Mandate on Medicare
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The House speaker, John A. Boehner, on Monday cautiously predicted victory for Republicans up and down the ticket in November, but he avoided saying that a Republican victory would mean a mandate for the sweeping changes to Medicare that Mitt Romney and Representative Paul D. Ryan have proposed.

title: Scourge of the Lionfish, Part 2: Counterattack
description: Carl Safina is founder of Blue Ocean Institute at Stony Brook University and a MacArthur Fellow. His books include A Sea in Flames: The Deepwater Horizon Oil Blowout, and The View From Lazy Point; A Natural Year in an Unnatural World, which won the 2012 Orion Award. His series Saving the Ocean will be premiering this fall on PBS television.

title: New Warren Ad Keeps Focus on Womens Issues
description: BOSTON  A new television ad released by Elizabeth Warren on Monday aimed to keep Massachusetts voters attention on womens issues after Ms. Warren and her Republican opponent, Senator Scott P. Brown, pounced on the comments about rape made by Representative Todd Akin of Missouri.

title: Happy Days, of All Kinds, for a Town in Ulster
description: ENNISKILLEN, Northern Ireland  Happy Days! said the waiter as he neatly deposited plates of the Beckett Special Antipasti (chicken and foie gras terrine, a curried soup with mussels, smoked haddock fish cake) at our table. As this phrase is the title of Samuel Becketts 1961 play, and also of a new Beckett festival in this small town, he might well have been joking. But he wasnt. Happy days, as it turns out, is a commonly used salutation in these parts.

title: Afro-Punk Festival in Brooklyn
description: The festival returned last weekend to Commodore Barry Park in Fort Greene with 32 bands and disc jockeys.

title: A Punk Fest, Defiant and Undefinable
description: Slamming together categories  and, when appropriate, bodies  is the ever-expanding mission of the annual Afro-Punk Festival, which returned last weekend to Commodore Barry Park in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

title: The Storm, Again
description: Tropical Storm Isaac is more than just a logistical inconvenience for Republicans gathered in Tampa: it is a powerful reminder both of Republican incompetence in handling Hurricane Katrina seven years ago, and the partys no-less-disastrous plans to further cut emergency-related spending.

title: As Convention Opens, Debt Clock Ticks
description: As Republicans gather in Tampa, Fla., for their convention, party leaders want to drive home a message to voters: The federal debt is hurtling toward $16 trillion, and it is President Obamas fault.

title: Should the President Deliver a Marine Citation in Person?
description: In his Op-Ed column today, Roger Cohen quoted a letter from John Kael Weston to President Obama. Mr. Weston, who served for the State Department in the city of Fallujah in Iraq and in Afghanistans Helmand Province, suggested that Mr. Obama appear in person at Camp Lejeune, in North Carolina, next month to present the Presidential Unit Citation to soldiers who fought under the Marine Expeditionary Brigade-Afghanistan from May 29, 2009, to April 12, 2010.

title: As Genes Learn Tricks, Animal Lifestyles Evolve
description: Early one evening a few years ago, I took a short hike with my wife, Jamie, in the Cockscomb Basin Wildlife Sanctuary in Belize. The large, lush reserve is known for its healthy population of jaguars, so, following closely behind our guide, we kept our eyes peeled for the elusive cats. We saw a few tracks and some claw marks on trees, but elected to leave the jungle before nightfall.

title: Many Bone Tests for Some, and Too Few for Others
description: Though Riva Schwartz, who manages a law office in Garden City, N.Y., has never broken a bone, she began receiving bone-density scans almost 10 years ago, when she turned 50. Eventually she was given a diagnosis of osteoporosis and started treatment. But every bone-building medication she took had side effects.

title: Aspirin May Aid Cancer Recovery
description: Men treated for prostate cancer who took aspirin regularly for other medical conditions were less likely to die of their cancer than patients who werent taking aspirin, according to a new study published on Tuesday in The Journal of Clinical Oncology.

title: Fuel Factory Explodes, Then Comedy Ensues
description: The countrys insatiable appetite for energy powers Dan ONeils Victor Frange Presents Gas, a diffuse and fitfully insightful eco-comedy from the Incubator Arts Project. With one roaring engine.

title: Dented Souls, on the Road to Redemption
description: Before I became Mr. Mom, says Ben Benjamin Jr., the unlucky hero of The Revised Fundamentals of Caregiving, Jonathan Evisons third and most stealthily powerful novel, I had decent options. O.K., options. Ben had a work history of painting parade floats and stacking scones in a bakery, then switched gears to become a doting father and husband. He gave his all to domesticity. He had no idea how evanescent his ordinary life would be.

title: Times Talks: Looking Back on 'Lost'
description: Carlton Cuse and Damon Lindelof, executive producers, discuss the finale of the ABC series.

title: Times Talks: Looking Back on 'Lost'
description: Carlton Cuse and Damon Lindelof, executive producers, discuss the "sideways" timeline of the final season.

title: Times Talks: Looking Back on 'Lost'
description: Carlton Cuse and Damon Lindelof, executive producers, talk about why the answers to questions on "Lost" simply lead to more questions.

title: Docking and Dining on Jamaica Bay
description: Here are spots on the bay side that remain little known except to the locals and boaters who ply Jamaica Bay and make a ritual of stopping by.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Smartphone Satellites and Inheriting E-Books and iTunes
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Boss Vetoes Your Upgrade. (Its the Seat Next to Him.)
description: IVE been flying all of my life. When you start a business, its great to have to fly because that means your business is growing. But the process is infuriating. As a former counterterrorism agent in Britain, I cant argue against safety. And at my company, Tough Mudder, we take safety very seriously. But there just needs to be a more efficient manner to conduct security at the airports.

title: AMC Ad Uses Snarky Blog Post to Mock Dish Network
description: 5:47 p.m. | Updated Does the snarkiness of a blog post translate for a mainstream, general audience? A cable company is hoping to find out.

title: Music From Yeasayer, Tamia, Lionel Loueke and Divine Fits
description: YEASAYER

title: Obama Gets Briefing on Tropical Storm
description: President Obama received a briefing on Monday afternoon about Tropical Storm Isaac as it approached hurricane force, but aides say no decision has been made to cancel his campaign trip on Tuesday to two swing states, Iowa and Colorado.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, North Korea, Maryland and Ethiopia.

title: City to City, on the Cheap
description: The intercity bus business has expanded rapidly since companies like BoltBus and Megabus took to the highways, promising fares as low as a dollar between cities like Boston and New York.

title: Multiple Clips of Syrian Helicopter Crash
description: As my colleague Steven Erlanger reports, Syrian rebels claimed responsibility for shooting down a government helicopter during fighting in the eastern suburbs of Damascus on Monday.

title: American Roots Music, Earnestly Embraced Onstage
description: Normally it works like this: A band comes to town, does a soundcheck on its stage for the night, maybe grabs a quick meal of debatable quality, plays a show, then squeezes in some carousing before it is time for its car or van or bus to depart for the next carnival.

title: Portman to Reprise Obama Role for Romney Debate Preparation
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Its time for Senator Rob Portman to dust off those old Obama audiobooks again. He has been tapped to reprise his role of playing President Obama to help Mitt Romney prepare for his debates.

title: A Cynical Portrait of Two Political Bases
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Romney campaign isnt going to admit that its outrageous welfare ad, falsely accusing President Obama of gutting the welfare-to-work requirement, is a nakedly racial appeal to white working-class voters. (Tom Edsalls expert dissection this morning makes that clear.)

title: New Book in Battle Over East vs. West
description: In 1988 Pankaj Mishra was a recent university graduate in the northern Indian city of Benares with big literary ambitions he had little idea how to fulfill. But when he heard that a local library was going to be auctioning back issues of The New York Review of Books as waste paper, he knew exactly what to do.

title: Far From Wall Street and Silicon Valley, a Focus on Family Ties
description: MILWAUKEE  When the hedge fund manager David Einhorn was just another investment analyst in the mid-1990s, his family gave him $500,000 to get his fund, Greenlight Capital, off the ground. Now that he is a billionaire after a career of doing battle with large corporations, he has returned the favor.

title: Protests Muted as Convention Gears Up
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The storm that caused Republican officials to cancel the bulk of the first day of their convention is also dampening the protests, as fewer demonstrators than were expected turned out for the first day of rallies.

title: Top American Junior Will Turn Pro After U.S. Open
description: Mitchell Krueger of Aledo, Tex., has decided to skip college and turn professional after the United States Open junior tournament, which begins next weekend.

title: Photo Released for Suspect in 13-Year-Olds Killing
description: Three days after a 13-year-old boy was killed in Brownsville, Brooklyn, the police released a photo on Monday of a 17-year-old who they say they believe is the gunman.

title: Willard C. Butcher, Former Chief of Chase Manhattan, Dies at 85
description: Willard C. Butcher, the former chairman and chief executive of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, who led the bank during a period of international growth in the 1980s, died on Saturday at his home in Hobe Sound, Fla. He was 85.

title: U.S. Military Disciplines 9 Over Video and Koran Burning
description: WASHINGTON  American military authorities disciplined nine service members on Monday for two episodes this year  the burning of Korans and the posting of a video showing Marines urinating on dead insurgents  that prompted nationwide outrage in Afghanistan. The punishments did not include criminal charges or jail time, and they fell short of what President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan had demanded.

title: Assembly Paid $103,000 in Harassment Case
description: ALBANY  Sheldon Silver, the New York State Assembly speaker, authorized a secret payment of $103,080 to settle sexual harassment claims against Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez this year, according to records released by the Assembly on Monday night.

title: Connecting the Dots After Cyberattack on Saudi Aramco
description: Publicly released details of a cyberattack on Saudi Aramco, the worlds largest oil producer, appear to confirm reports that critical data on three-quarters of the companys PCs was replaced with the image of a burning American flag.

title: Where Pirates Can Dock and Dine in New York
description: ON a recent Sunday, as a guitar player did his best Tom Petty imitation, a pirate politely enjoyed brunch on the deck of the Wharf Bar and Restaurant, overlooking Jamaica Bay. In a knit cap with rhinestone skull and crossbones, a jacket with golden epaulets and a scruffy and ashen beard, he hoisted his Budweiser in a toast: To the captain!

title: Founders of Diaspora, Intended as the Anti-Facebook, Move On
description: Two summers ago, a quartet of students at New York University started an ambitious project called Diaspora that was intended to be an open alternative to Facebook, one that would give its users greater control over their data and personal information. They created a project on Kickstarter with the modest goal of raising $10,000, enough capital to support themselves for the time it would take to develop the software. The project caught fire around the Web, and the group ended up raising $200,000.

title: Expect Fewer Seats, Even for Overseas Flights
description: WHERE are we going?

title: Somalia: Troops Seize Port From the Shabab
description: Somali and African Union troops seized the port of Marka, Somalia, on Monday from the Shabab as part of a campaign to secure Somalia, which is trying to establish its first effective national government since 1991. African Union officials said its fighters met little resistance in the battle for Marka, which is about 68 miles south of Mogadishu. The Shabab earned income from taxes and port fees in Marka, according to a United Nations report.

title: China: 2 Tibetan Teenagers Set Themselves on Fire
description: Two Tibetan teenagers set themselves on fire and burned to death on Monday in an anti-Chinese political protest in a restive Tibetan-populated area of western Chinas Sichuan Province, the rights group Free Tibet reported. At least 50 people have set themselves on fire since March 2011. The latest victims were identified as Lobsang Kalsang, an 18-year-old monk, and Damchoek, 17, a former monk. Free Tibet, which has networks of contacts in Tibetan-populated areas of China, said the teenagers staged their protest outside the Kirti monastery in the town of Ngaba, known in Chinese as Aba, a center of anti-Chinese sentiment.

title: City Revives a Lunch Program That Takes Chefs Into Schools
description: Reversing course, city education officials said on Monday that a well-regarded culinary organization that recruits professional chefs to prepare school lunches could continue doing so when the new year begins next week.

title: F.D.A. Approves Once-a-Day Pill for H.I.V.
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new once-a-day H.I.V. treatment from Gilead Sciences that contains four different drugs in one pill.

title: In Mexico, Rehearsing to Inject Drama Into the Courtroom
description: MEXICO CITY  The witnesss testimony was beginning to show cracks. He grew visibly tense, his knuckles turning white as he gripped the table harder.

title: Morsis Syria Plan Suggests Regional Approach to Foreign Affairs
description: Did President Obama watch Egypt swing from pivotal ally to potential opponent? Versions of that question have hovered around the presidential campaign from the early Republican primary debates through Mitt Romneys comments on his recent trip to Israel about the Islamist electoral victories in the wake of the Arab spring.

title: Timescast: Day 1 of the Republican Convention
description: Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images

title: The Man in the Moon
description: Norfolk, Va.

title: Destroying Precious Land for Gas
description: ON the northern tip of Delaware County, N.Y., where the Catskill Mountains curl up into little kitten hills, and Ouleout Creek slithers north into the Susquehanna River, there is a farm my parents bought before I was born. My earliest memories there are of skipping stones with my father and drinking unpasteurized milk. There are bald eagles and majestic pines, honeybees and raspberries. My mother even planted a ring of white birch trees around the property for protection.

title: Romney to Arrive in Tampa on Tuesday
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Republican National Convention will be welcoming its newest  and most high-profile  guest on Tuesday: Mitt Romney himself.

title: Newspapers Fighting Deal on Postage for Ad Fliers
description: WASHINGTON  Having confronted significant declines in advertising revenue, the newspaper industry was dealt another blow last week when the Postal Regulatory Commission approved a plan granting potentially deep discounts to one of the nations largest direct marketers.

title: Deal Helps a Bank Catch Up in Capital
description: One of the nations bigger regional banks, M&T Bank, has had a hectic few days of deal-making.

title: News Outlets Stay Alert but in Place
description: TAMPA, Fla.  As a huge storm churned toward New Orleans, the countrys major television news divisions found themselves torn between covering two rapidly unfolding stories almost 700 miles apart.

title: At 15, Ko Shows Confidence and Game
description: At home in Palm Beach on Sunday, the Hall of Fame golfer JoAnne Carner was trying to watch one force of nature, but another, Tropical Storm Isaac, dumped so much rain on South Florida that Carner kept losing the satellite picture on her television.

title: Keynoter Christie Is a Skilled Speaker and Tea Party Pleaser
description: You could set a watch to the cadence of the town hall-style meetings that have helped make Chris Christie a Republican favorite in his 2  years as the governor of New Jersey.

title: Romney Campaign and Activists Reach Compromise on Delegate Rule
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Mitt Romneys campaign has reached a compromise with conservative activists in the Republican Party who had been angered by efforts to change rules for delegate selection leading up to the 2016 election.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,087 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: For Putin, Report Says, State Perks Pile High
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin is rumored to be among the worlds wealthiest men, with an oil-fed fortune worth tens of billions of dollars. He denies that, vehemently, but a report to be published Tuesday suggests that the dispute may be beside the point.

title: Gangs Truce Buys El Salvador a Tenuous Peace
description: SAN SALVADOR  They had faced off many times before, on the streets, with guns in their hands. But when top leaders of two of the hemispheres most violent street gangs sat across from one another in the stifling air of a maximum security prison here this year, the encounter had a very different aim: peace.

title: In a Post-9/11 City, a Persons Language Can Be a Cause for Police Suspicion
description: Earlier this summer, Thomas P. Galati, commanding officer of the New York Police Departments elite intelligence division, sat for an unusual legal interrogation, during which he talked of his keen interest in Urdu-speaking New Yorkers.

title: Stealing Coverage From the Republicans
description: On Sunday August 26th, a number of fringe groups staged actions to take attention away from the Republican National Convention.

title: Composers Unknown Political Oeuvre
description: Lin-Manuel Miranda has had a busy few years since his musical In the Heights, a hip-hop-infused celebration of the grit and dreams of Latino immigrants in Washington Heights, became a hit on Broadway and won a shelf full of Tony Awards.

title: Obama, DSouza and Anti-Colonialism
description: Ive never before had the experience of seeing a movie based on the ideas of a friend who is also the films producer, writer, co-director and on-camera star. The friend is Dinesh DSouza and the movie is 2016: Obamas America. Its a bit less than 90 minutes long and for the most part it follows the path of DSouzas 2010 book The Roots of Obamas Rage.

title: Samsung Case Puts Apple Closer to Google Fight
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Steven P. Jobs minced no words when talking about Android, Googles mobile operating system, which he saw as too similar to the iPhones. He told his biographer, Walter Isaacson, that Android was a stolen product and said, Im willing to go thermonuclear war on this.

title: Where the Clothes Are as Eclectic as the Music
description: Music flowed through the streets outside Commodore Barry Park in Brooklyn last weekend, luring more than 30,000 concertgoers (according to festival organizers) inside the park for the eighth annual Afro-Punk Festival. The diverse musical lineup, which included Erykah Badu, who is known for her sultry soul sound, and Das Racist, the New York hip-hop group, reflected the crowd that gathered.

title: In Tampa: Charles Blow & David Firestone
description: The Op-Ed columnist Charles M. Blow asks David Firestone about his editorial on Paul Ryans radicalism and the political calculations of the Romney campaign.

title: Huggability and Helium
description: TAMPA, Fla.

title: The Real Romney
description: The purpose of the Republican convention is to introduce America to the real Mitt Romney. Fortunately, I have spent hours researching this subject. I can provide you with the definitive biography and a unique look into the Byronic soul of the Republican nominee:

title: Museum Showcases Ichiros Baseball Career
description: TOYOYAMA, Japan  Proud parents often keep mementos from their childrens sports exploits. Nobuyuki and Yoshie Suzuki went several steps further.

title: Palin Spends First Day of Republican Convention in Arizona
description: GILBERT, Ariz.  Sarah Palin spent the first day of the Republican National Convention serving baked beans and sliders at a barbecue joint here, in a last-minute campaign stop for Kirk Adams, a former state legislator who is vying for the Republican nomination in Arizonas Fifth Congressional District race.

title: After Empire State Building Shooting, a Gunmans Mother Asks Why
description: From the moment she learned that her son had coldly and calculatingly shot and killed a former co-worker in Midtown, the mother of Jeffrey T. Johnson has replayed every reel of his life from birth to boyhood and beyond, searching her memory for something that might help explain why.

title: Active in Cloud, Amazon Reshapes Computing
description: SEATTLE  Within a few years, Amazon.coms creative destruction of both traditional book publishing and retailing may be footnotes to the companys larger and more secretive goal: giving anyone on the planet access to an almost unimaginable amount of computing power.

title: After Attacks, Israeli Schools Confront Hate
description: JERUSALEM  Tamer Jbarah, a 17-year-old Palestinian student who speaks accentless Hebrew after years in a bilingual school that is about half Jewish, said he was not at all surprised when a mob of Jewish teenagers beat an Arab teenager unconscious this month while hundreds watched and did nothing to help.

title: The Yellow Test
description: I went to see Carrie a week after her accident. Her shoulder had been broken, the bone shattered, and 24 stitches were needed to sew the cuts on her face. Her arm was in a sling. Her feet were propped on a pillow. A bottle of Vicodin was on a table within easy reach.

title: Upstate Judge Is Censured for Accidentally Firing Gun in Chambers
description: On second thought, Judge Vincent A. Sgueglia admitted to state judicial officials, the landmark courthouse in Owego, N.Y., was probably not the best place to repair a revolver with a faulty firing mechanism.

title: Latest Scandals From Albany
description: It is time for Vito Lopez to resign after 28 years as a New York state assemblyman. On Friday, Speaker Sheldon Silver censured him after the Assemblys bipartisan ethics committee found that Mr. Lopez had sexually harassed and groped two female employees. Mr. Lopez, who says the accusations are unfair and untrue, was stripped of his powerful position as Housing Committee chairman. A fixture on the political landscape since 1984, Mr. Lopez is also the Democratic Party boss in Brooklyn.

title: Business and Political Experiences Pull Romney 2 Ways on Economy
description: WASHINGTON  When Mitt Romney declared during his unsuccessful campaign for the Senate in 1994 that the federal minimum wage should rise with inflation, a break with Republican doctrine, both Democrats and Republicans accused him of pandering to Massachusetts voters.

title: After Replacing Coach, Li Finds Quick Success
description: After losing in the first round at the London Olympics, an event especially important at home in China, Li Na decided it was time for a change.

title: Video From Tampa: Paul Ryans Extremism
description: In Tampa, Op-Ed columnist Charles Blow talks to David Firestone about Paul Ryans socially conservative policies and his impact on Mitt Romneys electoral prospects.

title: Yankees Bring Back a Bat They Hope Can Help
description: The Yankees acquired outfielder Steve Pearce from the Houston Astros on Monday, completing a circuitous route for the 29-year-old journeyman who has switched teams numerous times this season.

title: Military Spending on Biofuels Draws Fire
description: When the Navy put a Pacific fleet through maneuvers on a $12 million cocktail of biofuels this summer, it proved that warships could actually operate on diesel from algae or chicken fat.

title: New York Rabbis Prayer Will Open G.O.P. Convention
description: The Republican Party does not often mention New York City as the place it turns to for religious guidance. But this year, New Yorkers will give both the opening and the closing prayers at the Republican National Convention, in a quirk of timing that nevertheless highlights the increased importance the party is placing on appealing to Jewish and Catholic voters.

title: With Referees Out, N.F.L. Stars Throw Flag on Novice Fill-Ins
description: In one National Football League preseason game, the referee announced a penalty with his back to the television camera. In another, an official twice referred to a team from Atlanta as Arizona. That referee, whose previous experience included a stint in the Lingerie Football League, also mixed up which team had won the coin toss.

title: Lottery Numbers
Warning: Smoking Can Kill You
description: Tobacco use is the leading preventable cause of death in the United States. Around 400,000 people die each year from smoking, which cuts lives short on average about 13 years. And that does not include the 50,000 who die from exposure to secondhand smoke or the 8.6 million whose illnesses are caused by smoking.

title: 2 Courts Cite a Vague Rule in Rejecting State Laws
description: For years, opponents of a payroll tax to help finance the Metropolitan Transportation Authority argued that it unfairly made people in the suburbs underwrite a service that mostly benefited people in New York City.

title: Irans Nuclear Quest
description: Iran appears to have installed a few hundred more centrifuges at its deep underground site known as Fordow, thus enhancing its ability to produce uranium enriched to 20 percent, a purity that can be converted relatively quickly to bomb-grade fuel.

title: Aftermath of the Amuay Refinery Explosion
description: A deadly explosion at Venezuelas largest oil refinery over the weekend has killed at least 41 people, leaving the neighboring town of Punto Fijo to cope with the destruction.

title: Venezuelan Government Criticized in Deadly Refinery Blast
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  A deadly explosion at Venezuelas largest oil refinery over the weekend has unleashed a barrage of criticism at the governments management of the state-run oil company, Petrleos de Venezuela. Even as President Hugo Chvez has turned the oil company into the financial engine of his socialist revolution, critics say it has neglected essential activities like maintenance, safety and the development of new sources of production.

title: All the Discomforts of Home
description: Deep in the second act of Heartless, the murky new play by Sam Shepard, a luminous lunacy lights up the stage. It is generated by Lois Smith and Jenny Bacon, playing a mother and daughter who thus far havent had much to say to each other and wouldnt even appear to have much in common, aside from that inconvenient matter of being related. But just listen to them now.

title: Path of a Pop-Up
description: Administrivial Acrostic Update Alert! As some of you commented on the 8/26/12 Acrostic blog post about Garrison Keillor, there was a minor goof in one of the clues. I asked Will Shortz about it, and here is his response: Amazingly, there were two Hunchback movies  one in 1996, the other in 1997. Salma Hayek was in the 1997 one, so the clue should have referenced that date. The date in the puzzle has now been updated.

title: A Salvadoran Cease-Fire Holds, for Now
description: A jailhouse truce between two of Latin Americas most violent street gangs appears to have held for five months, leading to a steep drop in homicides. But there are questions over its durability.

title: Corrections: August 28, 2012
description: FRONT PAGE

title: One Match Down in Rise to Stardom
description: When we last saw Jack Sock at the United States Open, a year ago September, he was holding a trophy over his head and  not yet 19 and a newly declared professional  being hailed a Grand Slam champion. Granted, as major titles go, mixed doubles (with Melanie Oudin) was akin to a serving of cheese and crackers, with the steak, or singles title, still lodged in the freezer.

The Argentine Therapist

title: On a Day Off for a Storm, Republicans Try to Keep Sharp

title: Roger D. Fisher, Expert at Getting to Yes, Dies at 90
description: Roger D. Fisher, a Harvard law professor who was a co-author of the 1981 best seller Getting to Yes: Negotiating Agreement Without Giving In and whose expertise in resolving conflicts led to a role in drafting the Camp David accords between Egypt and Israel and in ending apartheid in South Africa, died on Saturday in Hanover, N.H. He was 90.

title: Convention Postponed, but the Show Must Go On
description: Athletes can forfeit a basketball game or a tennis match, but there is no rain day for a political convention. Especially when a hurricane looms, and events are delayed, the news media doesnt stand down; it keeps smacking the ball onto an empty court.

title: Pankaj Mishras New Book, From the Ruins of Empire
description: Pankaj Mishras flair for the grace note is matched by a sometimes ferocious instinct for the jugular, Jennifer Schuessler wrote in a profile in The New York Times.

title: Unconventional Wisdom
description: With fewer Americans interested in party conventions and television executives providing less prime time coverage, the calls to just scrap em are mounting. This summer, CBS announced it preferred broadcasting a rerun of Hawaii Five-0to convention speeches, while Chris Wallace of Fox News toasted the good old days when real business got done.

title: An Image of Tolerance Still Manages to Flicker in Old Movie Theaters
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The red velvet curtains opened and a fantasy of Lebanon emerged, devoid of disputes over sect, politics or nationality.

title: Official Stirs Texas City With Talk of Rebellion
description: LUBBOCK, Tex.  A hearing on a proposed tax increase had just started at the county courthouse here Monday when Grace Rogers, a retired teacher, addressed local leaders. Ms. Rogers said she supported the idea of increasing the property tax by 1.7 cents to 34.6 cents per $100 valuation from 32.9 cents to finance the hiring of additional sheriffs deputies  with one reservation.

title: Alternative Republican Voices at the Convention
description: As Republicans gathered to name Mitt Romney their presidential candidate, not everyone in the party was on the same page.

title: Isaac Follows a Familiar Path, but With Less Intensity
description: Tropical Storm Isaac is on a path similar to that of Hurricane Katrina in 2005.

title: Getting Bolder With Age
description: ONE morning this month, three women, all over 40, were perched in the cushy gray chairs at the Yves Durif hair salon, on 76th Street off Madison Avenue in the Carlyle hotel.

title: Jan Sawka, Polish Artist, Dies at 65
description: Jan Sawka, a Polish artist, arrived in New York in 1977 with his wife and baby, four suitcases and a portfolio of the theatrical posters that had provoked the Polish government to expel him.

title: Pictures of the Day: Aug. 27
description: Convening for only a short session, the Republican National Convention was adjourned and events were rescheduled because of bad weather bearing down on the Gulf Coast.

title: Jets Trade Hunter to the Rams
description: Wayne Hunters time with the Jets was tumultuous. It was exasperating. It is also over. Four days after benching him, the Jets traded Hunter to the St. Louis Rams on Monday night in what could be described as a classic change-of-scenery trade. Out goes one underperforming right tackle and in comes another, Jason Smith, who lost his starting job a few weeks ago.

title: Mexico Detains 12 Officers in Attack on U.S. Embassy Vehicle
description: MEXICO CITY  The federal police officers who shot up an American Embassy vehicle on Friday, wounding two American law-enforcement workers, were detained on Monday as prosecutors determine whether they abused their authority or committed other crimes, Mexican officials said.

title: What to Watch on Tuesday
description: Christina McHale was one of the great stories of last years United States Open, knocking out the eighth-seeded Marion Bartoli in the second round before losing to Maria Kirilenko.

title: A Giant Used to Starting Over Will Get to Start
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants cornerback Michael Coe searched his vocabulary for the words to describe how he has approached a six-year N.F.L. career that has included three teams and shoulder and knee surgeries but not  until now  an opportunity to become a starter.

title: Levee Needing Costly Repairs Lands Ohio Village on Endangered List
description: ZOAR, Ohio  For years, Joe and Gayle Potelicki searched for a country bed-and-breakfast to buy and run. In 2009 they found it: a former 19th-century schoolhouse tucked in the center of this historic village, which lies along a lazy tributary of the Ohio River.

title: Strong Roots for the Romney Family
description: The Romney campaign and clan are eager to emphasize that no matter what voters think of Mitt Romneys politics and policies, he is a successful father and family man.

title: With Five Romney Sons, Five More Spokesmen
description: WASHINGTON  When Tagg Romney, the eldest of Mitt and Ann Romneys five sons, was not quite 12, he decided, in a fit of adolescent rebellion, that his father was a nerd.

title: Two Killed in Ambulance Collision on Staten Island
description: A sport utility vehicle collided with an ambulance on Staten Island on Monday, killing the two drivers, the police said.

title: Federer Wins Easily; After a Sluggish Start, So Does Clijsters
description: Roger Federer was his effortless self Monday in the first round of the United States Open. He was never threatened as he dismantled Donald Young, 6-3, 6-2, 6-4, to stretch his record in Open night matches to 22-0.

title: Word of the Day | errant
description: errant \er-nt, e-rnt\ adjective

title: Yanks Lose, but Focus Is Teixeiras Calf Injury
description: Mark Teixeiras swing looked innocuous enough  a trickled foul ball on a 1-0 changeup  but the reverberations might echo at a bad time for the Yankees. Running out of the batters box, Teixeira injured his left calf.

title: Colombia Explores Talks With FARC
description: BOGOT, Colombia  President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia said on Monday that his government had held exploratory conversations with the countrys largest rebel group, aimed at ending a nearly five-decade-old conflict.

title: I.B.M. Mainframe Evolves to Serve the Digital World
description: I.B.M. is introducing on Tuesday a new line of mainframe computers, adding yet another chapter to a remarkable story of technological longevity and business strategy.

title: Legislators Jeer India Prime Minister on Coal Deals
description: Indias Parliament became a noisy stage of political theater on Monday, as opposition lawmakers shouted down Prime Minister Manmohan Singhs attempt to rebut claims that his government had awarded sweetheart coal deals to power companies, the latest scandal to hit his administration, Jim Yardley wrote in The New York Times.

title: Did the U.S. Lose Ho Chi Minh to Communism?
description: HONG KONG  The principal architect of Vietnams military victories over France and the United States turned 102 the other day, and the old general, Vo Nguyen Giap, while frail, is said to be holding his own.

title: Intersection: A Trendy Rep
description: At Staten Island Mall, we met Val Pacuku, whose peach sherbet-colored pants and tan wedges were a welcome distraction from the fluorescent lights.

title: Jets Trim a Bright Spot From a Dismal Offense
description: Most teams that score precisely 21 points do so the conventional way, by taking the football and crossing the goal line three times. But the Jets, as has been widely established, are not most teams.

title: Rallies and Protests Outside the R.N.C.
description: Rallies and protests outside the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla.

title: After Heart Scare, Fish Keeps Perspective and Fights On
description: His coach watched Mardy Fish late Monday, on court at the United States Open, roughly three months after Fish underwent a heart procedure in May. Rarely has a straight-set, first-round victory meant as much as it did to these two.

title: Texas: Appeals Court Declines to Rule on Forced Shaving of Defendant
description: The highest military appeals court ruled on Monday that it was premature for them to decide whether Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, the Army psychiatrist accused in a shooting rampage at an Army base in Texas in 2009, could have his beard forcibly shaved before the start of his trial. Major Hasan told his lawyers that he began growing a beard because of his Muslim faith. But the judge overseeing his pretrial hearings at Fort Hood said that Major Hasan was disrupting the proceedings and violating Army regulations, and that he would be forcibly shaved if he did not do so voluntarily. Major Hasans lawyers appealed, but on Monday the United States Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces said that since the judge had not issued a definitive order for a forcible shaving, it was too early for them to decide. The court said that if such an order were issued, Major Hasan could appeal to a lower Army appeals court. But the court appeared to agree with Major Hasans lawyers on elements of the case, asking the judge to address, if an order for shaving was given, why a forcible shaving was the least restrictive means of intruding on his religious liberties. With the courts stay on the proceedings lifted, neither a hearing date nor a trial date had yet been scheduled.

title: Going Deeper Into the Hall
description: The Republican National Convention opens Tuesday in Tampa, Fla., and The New York Times will provide live, comprehensive coverage of the events, people and politics on the Web and mobile devices and in print. Among the highlights:

title: U.S. Open: Day 1
description: Despite play being interrupted because of rain, the favorites stayed on course at the U.S. Open.

title: Republican National Convention Enlists First Sikh Speaker
description: An American Sikh is scheduled to speak Wednesday at the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla., the first time the party has invited a Sikh to speak at a national convention.

title: Conversations With Andy Murray: A Passion For Boxing
description: Andy Murray toppled Alex Bogomolov Jr., 6-2, 6-4, 6-1, in the first round of the United States Open on Monday, although Murray did struggle some with the wind and dehydration. Afterward, in his regular Q. and A. with Straight Sets, Murray discussed his other favorite sport.

title: TimesCast Politics | August 27, 7 P.M.
description: Full broadcast of day one of the Republican National Convention.

title: News Quiz | August 28, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Live Illustrating Tweets of the R.N.C.
description: Christoph Niemann illustrates the tweets of the 2012 G.O.P. convention.

title: Sonia Gandhi Accuses Opposition of Blackmail
description: With Parliament paralyzed for a sixth consecutive day, Sonia Gandhi, president of the Congress party, launched an attack Tuesday against the opposition Bharatiya Janata Party, blaming it for holding Parliament to ransom by blackmail, even as she tried to rally her party to fight back against criticism over the coal scandal that is now shaking Indian politics.

title: Court Rules Israel Is Not at Fault in Death of American Activist
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli judge ruled on Tuesday that the state bore no responsibility for the death of Rachel Corrie, the young American woman who was run over by a military bulldozer in 2003 as she protested the demolition of Palestinian homes in the Gaza Strip.

title: Test Yourself | English, Aug. 28, 2012
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the music review Hour by Hour, Celebrating an Eclectic Festival.

title: Party Down, Favela Style
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  A Colt AR-15 rifle was aimed at my gut, an FMK-3 sub-machine gun a little lower. The men holding the weapons were barely that, and they shared a bottle of cheirinho da lol, passing the cheap chloroform-ether mix back and forth, sniffing it for a glossy high. This was a baile funk, Rio de Janeiros illegal block party of music, guns and narcotics  one of those all-night festas that exist in myth for those who cannot gain access to them or are too fearful to attend.

title: The Euro Crisis Is Back From Vacation
description: In June, it seemed as if any day might bring about the collapse of the Greek economy and with it, the entire euro zone and its decade-old currency. Then in July and August, it seemed as if everyone was on vacation. Now theyre back  finance officials and political leaders have been flying all over Europe to meet with one another  and along with them the crisis that has been raging for the last two years. Here is a guide to the new seasons most intriguing (and terrifying) story lines.

title: Puerto Rican Identity, In and Out of Focus
description: Adl Maldonado has been a photographic documentarian, a Dadaist visual satirist and a Nuyorican conceptual artist.

title: Back-to-School Shopping, After the First Day
description: WHO is Samantha Paradise?

title: Indianapolis Colts, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
description: Sometimes the best thing to do is tap Control-Alt-Delete twice and move forward. Theres no shame in doing that after a disastrous 2-14 season when, for 12 years before that, you ran one of the sharpest programs in your industry. The Indianapolis Colts owner,Jim Irsay, can be proud of what his club accomplished during the Peyton Manning Era, and he can be proud of the all-in approach he has taken in starting what he hopes will one day come to be known as the Andrew Luck Era.

title: Driving the Winnebago Via
description: WILMINGTON, N.C.  After five minutes of wrestling with the electronic parking-meter station, I had my receipts to place beneath the windshield wiper. A roving meter maid would see that I had paid for my spot. And the spot next to it. And the one next to that, thus answering the question, Where do you park a 25-foot Winnebago Via motor coach? Ill take spaces 113 through 115, thanks.

title: Hunting for Debris and Answers in Alaska
description: Throughout months of measuring trees, I carried the hope of finding a glass float on the outer coast of Southeast Alaska. Green and blue and made of hand-blown glass, they are remnants of the deep sea fishing industry, used long before plastic and other materials kept nets afloat. Most that remain today originated in Japan. Since I last wrote for the Green Blog, weve visited 24 sites in dead, dying and stressed yellow cedar forests in the West Chichagof-Yakobi Wilderness over the course of a three-week expedition.

title: 19-Year-Old American Flashes Potential for Birmingham City
description: With the season well under way in England, one of the more interesting American players is Will Packwood, a 19-year-old who looks to become a regular with Birmingham City.

title: Why Hayek Isnt Paul Ryans Guru
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Storms Approach Complicates Democratic Response to G.O.P. Convention
description: TAMPA, Fla.  With Republicans cautiously proceeding to open their convention on Tuesday, Democrats have decided to move ahead with their no-holds-barred counterprogramming, including a campaign swing by President Obama as Mitt Romney prepares to accept the nomination.

title: Speaking Urdu or Bengali a Cause for Police Suspicion in NYC
description: Earlier this summer, Thomas P. Galati, commanding officer of the New York Police Departments elite intelligence division, sat for an unusual legal interrogation, during which he talked of his keen interest in Urdu-speaking New Yorkers, Michael Powell wrote in The New York Times.

title: Hurricane Isaac Makes Landfall Along Gulf Coast
description: NEW ORLEANS  On the eve of the seventh anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, which brought widespread devastation after the colossal failure of the system built to protect the city, New Orleans on Tuesday night once again found itself facing the impending arrival of a huge and deadly storm.

title: Big Brother in Antarctica
description: Alexander Kumar, a physician and researcher at Concordia Station, writes from Antarctica, where he conducts scientific experiments for the European Space Agencys human spaceflight program.

title: Welcome to the Superhuman Games
description: LONDON  The 14th Summer Paralympic Games open in London on Wednesday, and spectators and an anticipated four billion viewers worldwide are being told to forget about the athletes disabilities and focus on the sport.

title: A Start-Up Tries to Prepare Students to Work in Start-Ups
description: For new graduates, shifting from college to a full-time job can deliver a jolt of culture shock. Thats doubly true for those who join start-ups, where teams are small and newcomers are often expected to acclimate quickly, finding their way without much formal training.

title: Intersection: Staten Island, the Forgotten Borough
description: 1:47 p.m. | Updated When we set out to produce our Intersection video series, we wanted to explore all the culture and street style New York City has to offer. It was important that we didnt overlook the fifth, and often forgotten borough, Staten Island.

title: Police Chief in Southern Afghanistan Survives Attack That Kills 4 Civilians
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  The Taliban tried and failed to kill one of their most hated enemies late on Monday when the police chief of Kandahar Province, who is pursuing an aggressive campaign against the insurgents in their former southern homeland, survived a powerful suicide car bombing that killed four civilians and wounded 20 more, Afghan officials said Tuesday.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Red Pencils Ready?
description: For this weeks roundup of grammar, style and other editing missteps, were resurrecting the always-popular After Deadline Quiz. Try to identify at least one problem in each of the following passages from recent editions; answers and explanations are below. (Thanks to colleagues and readers for contributions.)

title: Moonshine County That Is Stirred, Not Shaken
description: John Hillcoats new movie, Lawless  written by Nick Cave  is based on a true-story novel called The Wettest County in the World, by Matt Bondurant. The area in question is Franklin County, Va., and in 1931, when most of the action in the film takes place, it was a bloody paradise of bootleggers. This picturesque corner of Appalachia has now provided a bonanza for dialect coaches and their charges, who set the hills alive with a symphony of dropped consonants and attenuated vowels almost as violent as the gunfire that periodically erupts.

title: Opinion Report: Vito Lopez
description: From the editorial page

title: Aug. 27: Michigan Isnt a Tossup
description: In this update, Im going to focus on the polling weve seen in one particular state, Michigan, where there is an exceptionally wide spread between firms showing relatively strong numbers for Barack Obama, and those which have good numbers for Mitt Romney instead.

title: CBS News Poll Finds Presidential Candidates Essentially Tied
description: As the Republicans began to gather in Tampa, Fla., for their convention this week, the latest CBS News poll shows the race between President Obama and Mitt Romney essentially tied.

description: Sarah Palin is not at the Republican National Convention, but she is nonetheless weighing in on the proceedings there, and perhaps helping to sow discontent.

description: BEDFORD, Mass.  Former Gov. Mitt Romney took off on Tuesday morning en route to the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla., to capitalize on the national spotlight even as his team kept a wary eye on storm clouds both metaphoric and literal.

title: Tuesday Reading: Treating Illness When the Mango Bites Back
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Light on Your Feet
description: Who says cap-toe shoes have to be all business? Not Sir Paul Smith. The designer has reimagined the John Lobb classic  along with the British boot makers loafer and derby  in a series of waggish hues.

title: Considering Political Corruption and, Perhaps, a New City Motto
description: My colleague Sam Roberts wrote on Monday about a Latin motto woven into the Bronx borough flag. Its from Virgil. Ne cede malis, it goes. Do not yield to evil.

title: Hard-Hit Cities Show a Housing Rebound
description: Even some of the cities that suffered the most in the housing bust are showing signs of improvement, with prices beginning to recover in places like Miami, Atlanta and Detroit, according to the latest housing data.

title: Clayton, Dubilier & Rice to Buy Davids Bridal
description: Love is in the air.

title: Neo Fights (Slightly Wonkish and Vague)
description: Via Mark Thoma, David Glasner gets upset over claims by Austrians to have rejected or superseded neoclassical economics. Hayek was a neoclassical economist,Glasner declares.

title: What Were Reading
description: The New York Post: Squirrel: Its what for dinner. At least at the Brooklyn home of an author and self-styled urban hunter (English sparrow, anyone?), who offers a squirrel recipe with lemon and thyme.  Patrick Farrell

title: HSBCs Rising Legal Liability
description: The legal headaches at HSBC may not go away anytime soon, and when they do, the resolutions could be costly.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Isaac Still Stealing the Show, and Signs of Apple v. Google
description: Tropical Storm Isaac on Tuesday was fast becoming a hurricane, with landfall expected Tuesday evening along the Mississippi and Louisiana coastlines, Campbell Robertson reported, with officials warning that the greatest danger could be from flooding, rather than the winds. For now, the networks were leaving their anchors 700 miles away in Tampa to cover the Republican National Convention, Jeremy W. Peters reported. Still the networks said they were being flexible in their planning; for example, NBC said it was prepared to send Brian Williams to New Orleans if the storm strengthened to a strong Category 2 or 3 hurricane.

title: Lawyers Seek the Release of a Christian Girl Charged With Blasphemy in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The fate of a Pakistani Christian girl at the center of a contentious blasphemy case hung in the balance on Tuesday, as lawyers applied for her release from jail and an influential Muslim cleric offered his support.

description: TAMPA, Fla.

title: Daily Report: Samsung Verdict Puts Apple Closer to Google Fight
description: So far Apple has not gone to war with Google, at least not directly. Instead, Apple has sued the cellphone makers that use the Android operating system in their products  like Samsung, which was hit with a claim of more than $1 billion in damages last week.

title: Obama Warns Gulf Coast Residents Ahead of Storm
description: TAMPA, Fla.  President Obama urged Gulf Coast residents to pay attention to Tropical Storm Isaac and make preparations for a dangerous storm that is likely to hit late Tuesday.

title: A More Lighthearted Protest Overnight
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The protesters began assembling just before 11 p.m. on Monday night, with people arriving in twos and threes at Centennial Park, in Ybor City, until there were about 100 of them gathered in the darkness a block away from one of the citys main night life areas.

title: Avast, Ye Readers! Memoir Coming From Michael Bolton
description: This is the tale of Captain Jack Sparrow, a pirate so brave on the seven seas  wait, sorry, scratch that: This is the tale of the singer Michael Bolton, the latter-day crooner with hair spun from gold, wholl be unspooling his life story in a new memoir. The Center Street imprint of the Hachette Book Group said on Tuesday that it had acquired a book titled The Soul of It All from Mr. Bolton, the singer-songwriter (and devoted fan of the Pirates of the Caribbean movies, at least according to a recent Lonely Island/Saturday Night Live video).

title: Syrian Refugees Flood Into Jordan and Turkey in a Sharp Rise
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The United Nations refugee agency said on Tuesday that the number of Syrian refugees fleeing to Jordan last week had more than doubled from the previous week, raising further fears of a growing exodus from Syria that threatens to overwhelm international relief efforts.

title: Wheelies: The Resurrection Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Christoph Niemann, Live From Tampa
description: Earlier this month, Christoph Niemann, the illustrator who produced the magazines Abstract Sunday column, went to London to live draw the Olympics. This week, for some morejockeyingaction, we sent him to the Republican National Convention. Straight from Tampa, heres Day 1 of the convention, seen through the eyes of Christoph and the Twitterverse (or whatever you want to call it):

title: Image of the Day: August 28
Ann Romney Gets Ready for Her Big Night
description: TAMPA, Fla.  As he made his way to the convention that will nominate him for president of the United States, Mitt Romney sat in a window seat on his campaign plane, occasionally talking with his wife or aides but spending much of the flight alone, calm and quiet, reading or resting.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: The Corporate Citizen
description: To the Editor:

title: After 6-Year Quest, Romney Wins G.O.P. Nomination
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Mitt Romneys six-year quest for the Republican presidential nomination culminated Tuesday afternoon when the 4,400 delegates gathered here officially made him their choice to reclaim the White House from President Obama and the Democrats.

title: Jekyll & Hyde Revival Sets Spring Broadway Opening
description: Add the Frank Wildhorn musical Jekyll & Hyde to the list of shows being revived on Broadway not long after their last appearance there.

title: Filling the Empty Suit
description: TAMPA, Fla.

title: Strip Club Workers Can Tell, Youre From the Convention, Arent You?
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Youre from the convention, arent you? asks Rico, the security guard stationed outside of one of Tampas hottest strip clubs.

title: Finding Something Worthy in Every Find
description: Like busmen, critics often have job-related holidays, leisure time activities that feed into, spill over from  and, with luck, provide respite from  more diligent pursuits in their supposed areas of expertise. One of mine comes remarkably close. In summer I like to browse yard sales, thrift shops and, lately, flea markets, looking for paintings that speak to me. If the price is right (it usually is), I buy them and take them home.

title: Pepper Hamilton to Acquire Louis Freehs Firms
description: Pepper Hamilton, the corporate law firm, has acquired the investigative group and legal practice run by Louis J. Freeh, the former director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Is Ron Paul Winning the Future?
description: With no actual convention to cover here in Tampa these last two days, the press has gravitated toward what you might call para-convention events: Newt Gingrichs week-long Newt University tutorial in conservative ideas, for instance, and Ron Pauls We Are the Future rally for his army of supporters, held Sunday at the University of South Florida. About Gingrich, at this point, there is little of interest to be said, but the boasting title of Pauls rally has at least some claim to be the truth, given how well the libertarian congressman performed with younger voters in the primary season. Writing for the American Conservative, Jim Antle makes a plausible case that Paul has moved the Republican Party in his direction, and might move it further still: From the party-wide enthusiasm for critiques of the Federal Reserve to the reappearance of bona-fide noninterventionists in Republican House contests to the emergence of Kentucky Senator Rand Paul as a more mainstream advocate for his fathers ideas, Antle writes, the rapid progress of Paulism in a short period of time is undeniable.

description: How junk mail could put the Postal Service back on track. | Apple sets the stage for a war with Google. | Solving the mystery of a bourbon-loving fungus.

title: Dolan to Offer Prayer at Democratic Convention, Too
description: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan of New York has accepted an invitation to deliver the closing prayer at the Democratic National Convention next week, following through on a promise he made when accepting the same role at the Republican convention.
